1. dÄ«ghanikÄyo sÄ«lakkhandhavaggapÄá¸·i namo tassa bhagavato arahato sammÄsambuddhassa 1. brahmajÄlasuttaá¹ƒ paribbÄjakakathÄ 1. evaá¹ƒ me sutaá¹ƒ â€“ ekaá¹ƒ samayaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ antarÄ ca rÄjagahaá¹ƒ antarÄ ca nÄá¸·andaá¹ƒ addhÄnamaggappaá¹­ipanno hoti mahatÄ bhikkhusaá¹…ghena saddhiá¹ƒ paÃ±camattehi bhikkhusatehi. suppiyopi kho paribbÄjako antarÄ ca rÄjagahaá¹ƒ antarÄ ca nÄá¸·andaá¹ƒ addhÄnamaggappaá¹­ipanno hoti saddhiá¹ƒ antevÄsinÄ brahmadattena mÄá¹‡avena. tatra sudaá¹ƒ suppiyo paribbÄjako anekapariyÄyena buddhassa avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, dhammassa avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, saá¹…ghassa avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, suppiyassa pana paribbÄjakassa antevÄsÄ« brahmadatto mÄá¹‡avo anekapariyÄyena buddhassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, dhammassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, saá¹…ghassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati. itiha te ubho ÄcariyantevÄsÄ« aÃ±Ã±amaÃ±Ã±assa ujuvipaccanÄ«kavÄdÄ bhagavantaá¹ƒ piá¹­á¹­hito piá¹­á¹­hito anubandhÄ [anubaddhÄ (ka. sÄ«. pÄ«.)] honti bhikkhusaá¹…ghaÃ±ca. 2. atha kho bhagavÄ ambalaá¹­á¹­hikÄyaá¹ƒ rÄjÄgÄrake ekarattivÄsaá¹ƒ upagacchi [upagaÃ±chi (sÄ«. syÄ. kaá¹ƒ. pÄ«.)] saddhiá¹ƒ bhikkhusaá¹…ghena. suppiyopi kho paribbÄjako ambalaá¹­á¹­hikÄyaá¹ƒ rÄjÄgÄrake ekarattivÄsaá¹ƒ upagacchi [upagaÃ±chi (sÄ«. syÄ. kaá¹ƒ. pÄ«.)] antevÄsinÄ brahmadattena mÄá¹‡avena. tatrapi sudaá¹ƒ suppiyo paribbÄjako anekapariyÄyena
BrahmajÄla Sutta The Discourse about the Wanderers
2. dÄ«ghanikÄyo sÄ«lakkhandhavaggapÄá¸·i namo tassa bhagavato arahato sammÄsambuddhassa 1. brahmajÄlasuttaá¹ƒ paribbÄjakakathÄ 1. evaá¹ƒ me sutaá¹ƒ â€“ ekaá¹ƒ samayaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ antarÄ ca rÄjagahaá¹ƒ antarÄ ca nÄá¸·andaá¹ƒ addhÄnamaggappaá¹­ipanno hoti mahatÄ bhikkhusaá¹…ghena saddhiá¹ƒ paÃ±camattehi bhikkhusatehi. suppiyopi kho paribbÄjako antarÄ ca rÄjagahaá¹ƒ antarÄ ca nÄá¸·andaá¹ƒ addhÄnamaggappaá¹­ipanno hoti saddhiá¹ƒ antevÄsinÄ brahmadattena mÄá¹‡avena. tatra sudaá¹ƒ suppiyo paribbÄjako anekapariyÄyena buddhassa avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, dhammassa avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, saá¹…ghassa avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, suppiyassa pana paribbÄjakassa antevÄsÄ« brahmadatto mÄá¹‡avo anekapariyÄyena buddhassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, dhammassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, saá¹…ghassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati. itiha te ubho ÄcariyantevÄsÄ« aÃ±Ã±amaÃ±Ã±assa ujuvipaccanÄ«kavÄdÄ bhagavantaá¹ƒ piá¹­á¹­hito piá¹­á¹­hito anubandhÄ [anubaddhÄ (ka. sÄ«. pÄ«.)] honti bhikkhusaá¹…ghaÃ±ca. 2. atha kho bhagavÄ ambalaá¹­á¹­hikÄyaá¹ƒ rÄjÄgÄrake ekarattivÄsaá¹ƒ upagacchi [upagaÃ±chi (sÄ«. syÄ. kaá¹ƒ. pÄ«.)] saddhiá¹ƒ bhikkhusaá¹…ghena. suppiyopi kho paribbÄjako ambalaá¹­á¹­hikÄyaá¹ƒ rÄjÄgÄrake ekarattivÄsaá¹ƒ upagacchi [upagaÃ±chi (sÄ«. syÄ. kaá¹ƒ. pÄ«.)] antevÄsinÄ brahmadattena mÄá¹‡avena. tatrapi sudaá¹ƒ suppiyo paribbÄjako anekapariyÄyena
Thus have I heard: At one time the Blessed One was travelling along the road between RÄjagaha and NÄá¸·andÄ with a large Saá¹…gha of bhikkhus, with about five hundred bhikkhus. Suppiya the wanderer was also travelling along the road between RÄjagaha and NÄá¸·andÄ with his pupil Brahmadatta, a young man. There, Suppiya the wanderer, in many ways, spoke in disparagement of the Buddha, spoke in disparagement of the Dharma, spoke in disparagement of the Saá¹…gha. But Suppiyaâ€™s pupil, Brahmadatta the young man, in many ways, spoke in praise of the Buddha, spoke in praise of the Dharma, spoke in praise of the Saá¹…gha. Thus, these two, teacher and pupil, holding directly opposing views, followed behind the Blessed One and the Saá¹…gha of bhikkhus.
3. buddhassa avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, dhammassa avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, saá¹…ghassa avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, suppiyassa pana paribbÄjakassa antevÄsÄ« brahmadatto mÄá¹‡avo anekapariyÄyena buddhassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, dhammassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, saá¹…ghassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati. itiha te ubho ÄcariyantevÄsÄ« aÃ±Ã±amaÃ±Ã±assa ujuvipaccanÄ«kavÄdÄ viharanti. 3. atha kho sambahulÄnaá¹ƒ bhikkhÅ«naá¹ƒ rattiyÄ paccÅ«sasamayaá¹ƒ paccuá¹­á¹­hitÄnaá¹ƒ maá¹‡á¸alamÄá¸·e sannisinnÄnaá¹ƒ sannipatitÄnaá¹ƒ ayaá¹ƒ saá¹…khiyadhammo udapÄdi â€“ "acchariyaá¹ƒ, Ävuso, abbhutaá¹ƒ, Ävuso, yÄvaÃ±cidaá¹ƒ tena bhagavatÄ jÄnatÄ passatÄ arahatÄ sammÄsambuddhena sattÄnaá¹ƒ nÄnÄdhimuttikatÄ suppaá¹­ividitÄ. ayaÃ±hi suppiyo paribbÄjako anekapariyÄyena buddhassa avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, dhammassa avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, saá¹…ghassa avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, suppiyassa pana paribbÄjakassa antevÄsÄ« brahmadatto mÄá¹‡avo anekapariyÄyena buddhassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, dhammassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, saá¹…ghassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati. itihame ubho ÄcariyantevÄsÄ« aÃ±Ã±amaÃ±Ã±assa ujuvipaccanÄ«kavÄdÄ bhagavantaá¹ƒ piá¹­á¹­hito piá¹­á¹­hito anubandhÄ honti bhikkhusaá¹…ghaÃ±cÄ"ti. 4. atha kho bhagavÄ tesaá¹ƒ bhikkhÅ«naá¹ƒ imaá¹ƒ saá¹…khiyadhammaá¹ƒ viditvÄ yena maá¹‡á¸alamÄá¸·o tenupasaá¹…kami, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ paÃ±Ã±atte Äsane nisÄ«di. nisajja kho bhagavÄ bhikkhÅ« Ämantesi â€“ "kÄyanuttha, bhikkhave, etarahi kathÄya sannisinnÄ sannipatitÄ, kÄ ca pana vo antarÄkathÄ vippakatÄ"ti? evaá¹ƒ vutte te bhikkhÅ« bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavocuá¹ƒ â€“ "idha, bhante, amhÄkaá¹ƒ rattiyÄ paccÅ«sasamayaá¹ƒ paccuá¹­á¹­hitÄnaá¹ƒ maá¹‡á¸alamÄá¸·e sannisinnÄnaá¹ƒ sannipatitÄnaá¹ƒ ayaá¹ƒ saá¹…khiyadhammo udapÄdi â€“ â€˜acchariyaá¹ƒ, Ävuso, abbhutaá¹ƒ, Ävuso, yÄvaÃ±cidaá¹ƒ tena bhagavatÄ jÄnatÄ passatÄ arahatÄ sammÄsambuddhena sattÄnaá¹ƒ nÄnÄdhimuttikatÄ suppaá¹­ividitÄ. ayaÃ±hi suppiyo paribbÄjako anekapariyÄyena buddhassa avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, dhammassa avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, saá¹…ghassa avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, suppiyassa pana paribbÄjakassa antevÄsÄ« brahmadatto mÄá¹‡avo anekapariyÄyena buddhassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, dhammassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, saá¹…ghassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati. itihame ubho ÄcariyantevÄsÄ« aÃ±Ã±amaÃ±Ã±assa ujuvipaccanÄ«kavÄdÄ bhagavantaá¹ƒ piá¹­á¹­hito
Then the Blessed One went to the royal rest house in Ambalaá¹­á¹­hika, and stayed there for one night with the Saá¹…gha of bhikkhus. Suppiya the wanderer also went to the royal rest house in Ambalaá¹­á¹­hika, and stayed there for one night with his pupil Brahmadatta, a young man. There, too, Suppiya the wanderer, in many ways, spoke in disparagement of the Buddha, spoke in disparagement of the Dharma, spoke in disparagement of the Saá¹…gha. But Suppiyaâ€™s pupil, Brahmadatta the young man, in many ways, spoke in praise of the Buddha, spoke in praise of the Dharma, spoke in praise of the Saá¹…gha. Thus, these two, teacher and pupil, holding directly opposing views, lived together.
4. buddhassa avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, dhammassa avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, saá¹…ghassa avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, suppiyassa pana paribbÄjakassa antevÄsÄ« brahmadatto mÄá¹‡avo anekapariyÄyena buddhassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, dhammassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, saá¹…ghassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati. itiha te ubho ÄcariyantevÄsÄ« aÃ±Ã±amaÃ±Ã±assa ujuvipaccanÄ«kavÄdÄ viharanti. 3. atha kho sambahulÄnaá¹ƒ bhikkhÅ«naá¹ƒ rattiyÄ paccÅ«sasamayaá¹ƒ paccuá¹­á¹­hitÄnaá¹ƒ maá¹‡á¸alamÄá¸·e sannisinnÄnaá¹ƒ sannipatitÄnaá¹ƒ ayaá¹ƒ saá¹…khiyadhammo udapÄdi â€“ "acchariyaá¹ƒ, Ävuso, abbhutaá¹ƒ, Ävuso, yÄvaÃ±cidaá¹ƒ tena bhagavatÄ jÄnatÄ passatÄ arahatÄ sammÄsambuddhena sattÄnaá¹ƒ nÄnÄdhimuttikatÄ suppaá¹­ividitÄ. ayaÃ±hi suppiyo paribbÄjako anekapariyÄyena buddhassa avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, dhammassa avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, saá¹…ghassa avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, suppiyassa pana paribbÄjakassa antevÄsÄ« brahmadatto mÄá¹‡avo anekapariyÄyena buddhassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, dhammassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, saá¹…ghassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati. itihame ubho ÄcariyantevÄsÄ« aÃ±Ã±amaÃ±Ã±assa ujuvipaccanÄ«kavÄdÄ bhagavantaá¹ƒ piá¹­á¹­hito piá¹­á¹­hito anubandhÄ honti bhikkhusaá¹…ghaÃ±cÄ"ti. 4. atha kho bhagavÄ tesaá¹ƒ bhikkhÅ«naá¹ƒ imaá¹ƒ saá¹…khiyadhammaá¹ƒ viditvÄ yena maá¹‡á¸alamÄá¸·o tenupasaá¹…kami, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ paÃ±Ã±atte Äsane nisÄ«di. nisajja kho bhagavÄ bhikkhÅ« Ämantesi â€“ "kÄyanuttha, bhikkhave, etarahi kathÄya sannisinnÄ sannipatitÄ, kÄ ca pana vo antarÄkathÄ vippakatÄ"ti? evaá¹ƒ vutte te bhikkhÅ« bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavocuá¹ƒ â€“ "idha, bhante, amhÄkaá¹ƒ rattiyÄ paccÅ«sasamayaá¹ƒ paccuá¹­á¹­hitÄnaá¹ƒ maá¹‡á¸alamÄá¸·e sannisinnÄnaá¹ƒ sannipatitÄnaá¹ƒ ayaá¹ƒ saá¹…khiyadhammo udapÄdi â€“ â€˜acchariyaá¹ƒ, Ävuso, abbhutaá¹ƒ, Ävuso, yÄvaÃ±cidaá¹ƒ tena bhagavatÄ jÄnatÄ passatÄ arahatÄ sammÄsambuddhena sattÄnaá¹ƒ nÄnÄdhimuttikatÄ suppaá¹­ividitÄ. ayaÃ±hi suppiyo paribbÄjako anekapariyÄyena buddhassa avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, dhammassa avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, saá¹…ghassa avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, suppiyassa pana paribbÄjakassa antevÄsÄ« brahmadatto mÄá¹‡avo anekapariyÄyena buddhassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, dhammassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati, saá¹…ghassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsati. itihame ubho ÄcariyantevÄsÄ« aÃ±Ã±amaÃ±Ã±assa ujuvipaccanÄ«kavÄdÄ bhagavantaá¹ƒ piá¹­á¹­hito
Then, in the morning, many bhikkhus, having arisen at dawn, gathered together in the round pavilion, and this was the subject that arose in their conversation: â€œIt is wonderful, friends, it is marvellous, friends, how well that Blessed One, the knower, the seer, the worthy one, the perfectly enlightened Buddha, understands the variety of inclinations in beings. This Suppiya the wanderer, in many ways, speaks in disparagement of the Buddha, speaks in disparagement of the Dharma, speaks in disparagement of the Saá¹…gha. But Suppiyaâ€™s pupil, Brahmadatta the young man, in many ways, speaks in praise of the Buddha, speaks in praise of the Dharma, speaks in praise of the Saá¹…gha. Thus, these two, teacher and pupil, holding directly opposing views, follow behind the Blessed One and the Saá¹…gha of bhikkhus."
5. piá¹­á¹­hito anubandhÄ honti bhikkhusaá¹…ghaÃ±cÄâ€™ti. ayaá¹ƒ kho no, bhante, antarÄkathÄ vippakatÄ, atha bhagavÄ anuppatto"ti. 5. "mamaá¹ƒ vÄ, bhikkhave, pare avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, dhammassa vÄ avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, saá¹…ghassa vÄ avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, tatra tumhehi na ÄghÄto na appaccayo na cetaso anabhiraddhi karaá¹‡Ä«yÄ. mamaá¹ƒ vÄ, bhikkhave, pare avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, dhammassa vÄ avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, saá¹…ghassa vÄ avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, tatra ce tumhe assatha kupitÄ vÄ anattamanÄ vÄ, tumhaá¹ƒ yevassa tena antarÄyo. mamaá¹ƒ vÄ, bhikkhave, pare avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, dhammassa vÄ avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, saá¹…ghassa vÄ avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, tatra ce tumhe assatha kupitÄ vÄ anattamanÄ vÄ, api nu tumhe paresaá¹ƒ subhÄsitaá¹ƒ dubbhÄsitaá¹ƒ ÄjÄneyyÄthÄ"ti? "no hetaá¹ƒ, bhante". "mamaá¹ƒ vÄ, bhikkhave, pare avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, dhammassa vÄ avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, saá¹…ghassa vÄ avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, tatra tumhehi abhÅ«taá¹ƒ abhÅ«tato nibbeá¹­hetabbaá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜itipetaá¹ƒ abhÅ«taá¹ƒ, itipetaá¹ƒ atacchaá¹ƒ, natthi cetaá¹ƒ amhesu, na ca panetaá¹ƒ amhesu saá¹ƒvijjatÄ«â€™ti. 6. "mamaá¹ƒ vÄ, bhikkhave, pare vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, dhammassa vÄ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, saá¹…ghassa vÄ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, tatra tumhehi na Änando na somanassaá¹ƒ na cetaso uppilÄvitattaá¹ƒ karaá¹‡Ä«yaá¹ƒ. mamaá¹ƒ vÄ, bhikkhave, pare vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, dhammassa vÄ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, saá¹…ghassa vÄ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, tatra ce tumhe assatha Änandino sumanÄ uppilÄvitÄ tumhaá¹ƒ yevassa tena antarÄyo. mamaá¹ƒ vÄ, bhikkhave, pare vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, dhammassa vÄ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, saá¹…ghassa vÄ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, tatra tumhehi bhÅ«taá¹ƒ bhÅ«tato paá¹­ijÄnitabbaá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜itipetaá¹ƒ bhÅ«taá¹ƒ, itipetaá¹ƒ tacchaá¹ƒ, atthi cetaá¹ƒ amhesu, saá¹ƒvijjati ca panetaá¹ƒ amhesÅ«â€™ti. cÅ«á¸·asÄ«laá¹ƒ 7. "appamattakaá¹ƒ kho panetaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, oramattakaá¹ƒ sÄ«lamattakaá¹ƒ, yena puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya. katamaÃ±ca taá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, appamattakaá¹ƒ oramattakaá¹ƒ sÄ«lamattakaá¹ƒ, yena puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya.
Then the Blessed One, knowing the topic of conversation of those bhikkhus, went to the round pavilion, and after arriving, sat down on the prepared seat. Having sat down, the Blessed One addressed the bhikkhus, â€œAbout what topic are you gathered here, bhikkhus? What was the interrupted conversation among you?â€ When this was said, those bhikkhus said this to the Blessed One: â€œHere, venerable sir, we, having arisen at dawn, gathered together in the round pavilion, and this was the subject that arose in our conversation: â€˜It is wonderful, friends, it is marvellous, friends, how well that Blessed One, the knower, the seer, the worthy one, the perfectly enlightened Buddha, understands the variety of inclinations in beings. This Suppiya the wanderer, in many ways, speaks in disparagement of the Buddha, speaks in disparagement of the Dharma, speaks in disparagement of the Saá¹…gha. But Suppiyaâ€™s pupil, Brahmadatta the young man, in many ways, speaks in praise of the Buddha, speaks in praise of the Dharma, speaks in praise of the Saá¹…gha. Thus, these two, teacher and pupil, holding directly opposing views, follow behind the Blessed One Through exertion, application, diligence, and right reflection, I attain to such a degree of mental concentration ( *ceto-samÄdhi*) that with my mind thus concentrated, I recollect my numerous past lives (*pÅ«rbbe-nivÄsa*) in their modes and their details. That is to say, one birth, two births, three births, four births, five births, ten births, twenty births, thirty births, forty births, fifty births, a hundred births, a thousand births, a hundred thousand births, many hundreds of births, many thousands of births, many hundreds of thousands of births: â€˜There I had such a name, belonged to such a clan, had such an appearance; such was my food, such my experience of pleasure and pain, such my span of life. Passing away thence, I re-arose there. There too I had such a name, belonged to such a clan, had such an appearance; such was my food, such my experience of pleasure and pain, such my span of life. Passing away thence, I arose here.â€™ In this way I recollect many past lives (*pÅ«rbbe-nivÄsa*) with their characteristics and particulars. That is how I know the self (*attÄ*) and the world (*loka*) are eternal, barren, steadfast as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar. And though these beings roam and wander, pass away and re-arise, yet the self (*attÄ*) and the world (*loka*) remain the same just like eternity itself.â€™ This, monks (*bhikkhave*), is the first ground, on which some ascetics (*samaá¹‡a*) and Brahmins (*brÄhmaá¹‡a*) are based and relying on which they proclaim the eternity (*sassata*) of the self (*attÄ*) and the world (*loka*).
6. piá¹­á¹­hito anubandhÄ honti bhikkhusaá¹…ghaÃ±cÄâ€™ti. ayaá¹ƒ kho no, bhante, antarÄkathÄ vippakatÄ, atha bhagavÄ anuppatto"ti. 5. "no hetaá¹ƒ, bhante". "mamaá¹ƒ vÄ, bhikkhave, pare avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, dhammassa vÄ avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, saá¹…ghassa vÄ avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, tatra tumhehi abhÅ«taá¹ƒ abhÅ«tato nibbeá¹­hetabbaá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜itipetaá¹ƒ abhÅ«taá¹ƒ, itipetaá¹ƒ atacchaá¹ƒ, natthi cetaá¹ƒ amhesu, na ca panetaá¹ƒ amhesu saá¹ƒvijjatÄ«â€™ti. 6. "mamaá¹ƒ vÄ, bhikkhave, pare vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, dhammassa vÄ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, saá¹…ghassa vÄ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, tatra tumhehi na Änando na somanassaá¹ƒ na cetaso uppilÄvitattaá¹ƒ karaá¹‡Ä«yaá¹ƒ. mamaá¹ƒ vÄ, bhikkhave, pare vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, dhammassa vÄ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, saá¹…ghassa vÄ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, tatra ce tumhe assatha Änandino sumanÄ uppilÄvitÄ tumhaá¹ƒ yevassa tena antarÄyo. mamaá¹ƒ vÄ, bhikkhave, pare vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, dhammassa vÄ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, saá¹…ghassa vÄ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, tatra tumhehi bhÅ«taá¹ƒ bhÅ«tato paá¹­ijÄnitabbaá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜itipetaá¹ƒ bhÅ«taá¹ƒ, itipetaá¹ƒ tacchaá¹ƒ, atthi cetaá¹ƒ amhesu, saá¹ƒvijjati ca panetaá¹ƒ amhesÅ«â€™ti. cÅ«á¸·asÄ«laá¹ƒ 7. "appamattakaá¹ƒ kho panetaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, oramattakaá¹ƒ sÄ«lamattakaá¹ƒ, yena puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya. katamaÃ±ca taá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, appamattakaá¹ƒ oramattakaá¹ƒ sÄ«lamattakaá¹ƒ, yena puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya.
"Monks, if others should speak in praise of me, or in praise of the *Dhamma*, or in praise of the *Sangha*, you should not give way to joy (*Änanda*), gladness (*somanassa*), or mental elation. Monks, if others should speak in praise of me, or in praise of the *Dhamma*, or in praise of the *Sangha*, if you were to be joyful, cheerful, and elated, that would only be an obstacle for you. Monks, if others should speak in praise of me, or in praise of the *Dhamma*, or in praise of the *Sangha*, you should acknowledge what is factual as factual, saying: 'For such and such a reason this is a fact, this is true, there is such a thing in us, this is found among us.'" The Lesser Morality (*cÅ«á¸·asÄ«laá¹ƒ*)
7. piá¹­á¹­hito anubandhÄ honti bhikkhusaá¹…ghaÃ±cÄâ€™ti. ayaá¹ƒ kho no, bhante, antarÄkathÄ vippakatÄ, atha bhagavÄ anuppatto"ti. 5. "mamaá¹ƒ vÄ, bhikkhave, pare avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, dhammassa vÄ avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, saá¹…ghassa vÄ avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, tatra tumhehi na ÄghÄto na appaccayo na cetaso anabhiraddhi karaá¹‡Ä«yÄ. mamaá¹ƒ vÄ, bhikkhave, pare avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, dhammassa vÄ avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, saá¹…ghassa vÄ avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, tatra ce tumhe assatha kupitÄ vÄ anattamanÄ vÄ, tumhaá¹ƒ yevassa tena antarÄyo. mamaá¹ƒ vÄ, bhikkhave, pare avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, dhammassa vÄ avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, saá¹…ghassa vÄ avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, tatra ce tumhe assatha kupitÄ vÄ anattamanÄ vÄ, api nu tumhe paresaá¹ƒ subhÄsitaá¹ƒ dubbhÄsitaá¹ƒ ÄjÄneyyÄthÄ"ti? "no hetaá¹ƒ, bhante". "mamaá¹ƒ vÄ, bhikkhave, pare avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, dhammassa vÄ avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, saá¹…ghassa vÄ avaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, tatra tumhehi abhÅ«taá¹ƒ abhÅ«tato nibbeá¹­hetabbaá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜itipetaá¹ƒ abhÅ«taá¹ƒ, itipetaá¹ƒ atacchaá¹ƒ, natthi cetaá¹ƒ amhesu, na ca panetaá¹ƒ amhesu saá¹ƒvijjatÄ«â€™ti. 6. The JÄliya Discourse The incident regarding two wanderers

The Great Lion's Roar Discourse. The Account of the Naked Ascetic Kassapa.

The Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda Discourse The subject of Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda the Wanderer

The Subha Sutta The Account of Subha, the Student
11. majjhimasÄ«laá¹ƒ 11. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«paá¹ƒ bÄ«jagÄmabhÅ«tagÄmasamÄrambhaá¹ƒ anuyuttÄ viharanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ [seyyathÄ«daá¹ƒ (sÄ«. syÄ.)] â€“ mÅ«labÄ«jaá¹ƒ khandhabÄ«jaá¹ƒ phaá¸·ubÄ«jaá¹ƒ aggabÄ«jaá¹ƒ bÄ«jabÄ«jameva paÃ±camaá¹ƒ [paÃ±camaá¹ƒ iti vÄ (sÄ«. syÄ. ka.)], iti evarÅ«pÄ bÄ«jagÄmabhÅ«tagÄmasamÄrambhÄ paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya. 12. The Kevatta Sutta The story of Kevatta, the householder's son
12. majjhimasÄ«laá¹ƒ 11. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«paá¹ƒ jÅ«tappamÄdaá¹­á¹­hÄnÄnuyogaá¹ƒ anuyuttÄ viharanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ aá¹­á¹­hapadaá¹ƒ dasapadaá¹ƒ ÄkÄsaá¹ƒ parihÄrapathaá¹ƒ santikaá¹ƒ khalikaá¹ƒ ghaá¹­ikaá¹ƒ salÄkahatthaá¹ƒ akkhaá¹ƒ paá¹…gacÄ«raá¹ƒ vaá¹…kakaá¹ƒ mokkhacikaá¹ƒ ciá¹…gulikaá¹ƒ [ciá¹…gulakaá¹ƒ (ka. sÄ«.)] pattÄá¸·hakaá¹ƒ rathakaá¹ƒ dhanukaá¹ƒ akkharikaá¹ƒ manesikaá¹ƒ yathÄvajjaá¹ƒ
The Lohicca Discourse The Story of the Brahmin Lohicca
13. majjhimasÄ«laá¹ƒ 11. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«paá¹ƒ visÅ«kadassanaá¹ƒ anuyuttÄ viharanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ naccaá¹ƒ gÄ«taá¹ƒ vÄditaá¹ƒ pekkhaá¹ƒ akkhÄnaá¹ƒ pÄá¹‡issaraá¹ƒ vetÄá¸·aá¹ƒ kumbhathÅ«á¹‡aá¹ƒ [kumbhathÅ«naá¹ƒ (syÄ. ka.), kumbhathÅ«á¹‡aá¹ƒ (sÄ«.)] sobhanakaá¹ƒ [sobhanagharakaá¹ƒ (sÄ«.), sobhanagarakaá¹ƒ (syÄ. kaá¹ƒ. pÄ«.)] caá¹‡á¸Älaá¹ƒ vaá¹ƒsaá¹ƒ dhovanaá¹ƒ hatthiyuddhaá¹ƒ assayuddhaá¹ƒ mahiá¹ƒsayuddhaá¹ƒ [mahisayuddhaá¹ƒ (sÄ«. syÄ. kaá¹ƒ. pÄ«.)] usabhayuddhaá¹ƒ ajayuddhaá¹ƒ meá¹‡á¸ayuddhaá¹ƒ kukkuá¹­ayuddhaá¹ƒ vaá¹­á¹­akayuddhaá¹ƒ daá¹‡á¸ayuddhaá¹ƒ muá¹­á¹­hiyuddhaá¹ƒ nibbuddhaá¹ƒ uyyodhikaá¹ƒ balaggaá¹ƒ senÄbyÅ«haá¹ƒ anÄ«kadassanaá¹ƒ iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄ visÅ«kadassanÄ paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya. 14. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«paá¹ƒ jÅ«tappamÄdaá¹­á¹­hÄnÄnuyogaá¹ƒ anuyuttÄ viharanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ aá¹­á¹­hapadaá¹ƒ dasapadaá¹ƒ ÄkÄsaá¹ƒ parihÄrapathaá¹ƒ santikaá¹ƒ khalikaá¹ƒ ghaá¹­ikaá¹ƒ salÄkahatthaá¹ƒ akkhaá¹ƒ paá¹…gacÄ«raá¹ƒ vaá¹…kakaá¹ƒ mokkhacikaá¹ƒ ciá¹…gulikaá¹ƒ [ciá¹…gulakaá¹ƒ (ka. sÄ«.)] pattÄá¸·hakaá¹ƒ rathakaá¹ƒ dhanukaá¹ƒ akkharikaá¹ƒ manesikaá¹ƒ yathÄvajjaá¹ƒ
The Tevijja Sutta
14. majjhimasÄ«laá¹ƒ 11. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«paá¹ƒ bÄ«jagÄmabhÅ«tagÄmasamÄrambhaá¹ƒ anuyuttÄ viharanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ [seyyathÄ«daá¹ƒ (sÄ«. syÄ.)] â€“ mÅ«labÄ«jaá¹ƒ khandhabÄ«jaá¹ƒ phaá¸·ubÄ«jaá¹ƒ aggabÄ«jaá¹ƒ bÄ«jabÄ«jameva paÃ±camaá¹ƒ [paÃ±camaá¹ƒ iti vÄ (sÄ«. syÄ. ka.)], iti evarÅ«pÄ bÄ«jagÄmabhÅ«tagÄmasamÄrambhÄ paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya. 12. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«paá¹ƒ sannidhikÄraparibhogaá¹ƒ anuyuttÄ viharanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ annasannidhiá¹ƒ pÄnasannidhiá¹ƒ vatthasannidhiá¹ƒ yÄnasannidhiá¹ƒ sayanasannidhiá¹ƒ gandhasannidhiá¹ƒ Ämisasannidhiá¹ƒ iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄ sannidhikÄraparibhogÄ paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya. 13. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«paá¹ƒ visÅ«kadassanaá¹ƒ anuyuttÄ viharanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ naccaá¹ƒ gÄ«taá¹ƒ vÄditaá¹ƒ pekkhaá¹ƒ akkhÄnaá¹ƒ pÄá¹‡issaraá¹ƒ vetÄá¸·aá¹ƒ kumbhathÅ«á¹‡aá¹ƒ [kumbhathÅ«naá¹ƒ (syÄ. ka.), kumbhathÅ«á¹‡aá¹ƒ (sÄ«.)] sobhanakaá¹ƒ [sobhanagharakaá¹ƒ (sÄ«.), sobhanagarakaá¹ƒ (syÄ. kaá¹ƒ. pÄ«.)] caá¹‡á¸Älaá¹ƒ vaá¹ƒsaá¹ƒ dhovanaá¹ƒ hatthiyuddhaá¹ƒ assayuddhaá¹ƒ mahiá¹ƒsayuddhaá¹ƒ [mahisayuddhaá¹ƒ (sÄ«. syÄ. kaá¹ƒ. pÄ«.)] usabhayuddhaá¹ƒ ajayuddhaá¹ƒ meá¹‡á¸ayuddhaá¹ƒ kukkuá¹­ayuddhaá¹ƒ vaá¹­á¹­akayuddhaá¹ƒ daá¹‡á¸ayuddhaá¹ƒ muá¹­á¹­hiyuddhaá¹ƒ nibbuddhaá¹ƒ uyyodhikaá¹ƒ balaggaá¹ƒ senÄbyÅ«haá¹ƒ anÄ«kadassanaá¹ƒ iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄ visÅ«kadassanÄ paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya. 14. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«paá¹ƒ jÅ«tappamÄdaá¹­á¹­hÄnÄnuyogaá¹ƒ anuyuttÄ viharanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ aá¹­á¹­hapadaá¹ƒ dasapadaá¹ƒ ÄkÄsaá¹ƒ parihÄrapathaá¹ƒ santikaá¹ƒ khalikaá¹ƒ ghaá¹­ikaá¹ƒ salÄkahatthaá¹ƒ akkhaá¹ƒ paá¹…gacÄ«raá¹ƒ vaá¹…kakaá¹ƒ mokkhacikaá¹ƒ ciá¹…gulikaá¹ƒ [ciá¹…gulakaá¹ƒ (ka. sÄ«.)] pattÄá¸·hakaá¹ƒ rathakaá¹ƒ dhanukaá¹ƒ akkharikaá¹ƒ manesikaá¹ƒ yathÄvajjaá¹ƒ
â€œWhereas some venerable ascetics and Brahmins, while living on food given in faith, remain addicted to such games that are a basis for negligence, that is to say, *aá¹­á¹­hapadaá¹ƒ*, *dasapadaá¹ƒ*, *ÄkÄsaá¹ƒ*, *parihÄrapathaá¹ƒ*, *santikaá¹ƒ*, *khalikaá¹ƒ*, *ghaá¹­ikaá¹ƒ*, *salÄkahatthaá¹ƒ*, *akkhaá¹ƒ*, *paá¹…gacÄ«raá¹ƒ*, *vaá¹…kakaá¹ƒ*, *mokkhacikaá¹ƒ*, *ciá¹…gulikaá¹ƒ*, *pattÄá¸·hakaá¹ƒ*, *rathakaá¹ƒ*, *dhanukaá¹ƒ*, *akkharikaá¹ƒ*, *manesikaá¹ƒ*, *yathÄvajjaá¹ƒ*... Archers, Celakas, Calakas, almsgivers, Uggas, princes, shock troops, bull-warriors, heroes, mail-clad warriors, sons of slave women, confectioners, barbers, bath attendants, cooks, garland makers, laundrymen, weavers, basket makers, potters, calculators, accountants, and whatever other various crafts there are, they live enjoying here and now the visible fruit of their craft. They please and gratify themselves with it. They please and gratify their mothers and fathers, they please and gratify their children and wives, they please and gratify their friends and colleagues, they establish a high offering to ascetics and Brahmins, conducive to heaven, with happy result and leading to heaven. Is it possible, venerable sir, to point out any fruit of the monastic life that is similarly visible here and now?â€
15. iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄ jÅ«tappamÄdaá¹­á¹­hÄnÄnuyogÄ paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya. 15. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«paá¹ƒ uccÄsayanamahÄsayanaá¹ƒ anuyuttÄ viharanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ Äsandiá¹ƒ pallaá¹…kaá¹ƒ gonakaá¹ƒ cittakaá¹ƒ paá¹­ikaá¹ƒ paá¹­alikaá¹ƒ tÅ«likaá¹ƒ vikatikaá¹ƒ uddalomiá¹ƒ ekantalomiá¹ƒ kaá¹­á¹­issaá¹ƒ koseyyaá¹ƒ kuttakaá¹ƒ hatthattharaá¹ƒ assattharaá¹ƒ rathattharaá¹ƒ [hatthattharaá¹‡aá¹ƒ assattharaá¹‡aá¹ƒ rathattharaá¹‡aá¹ƒ (sÄ«. ka. pÄ«.)] ajinappaveá¹‡iá¹ƒ kadalimigapavarapaccattharaá¹‡aá¹ƒ sauttaracchadaá¹ƒ ubhatolohitakÅ«padhÄnaá¹ƒ iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄ uccÄsayanamahÄsayanÄ paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya. 16. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«paá¹ƒ maá¹‡á¸anavibhÅ«sanaá¹­á¹­hÄnÄnuyogaá¹ƒ anuyuttÄ viharanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ ucchÄdanaá¹ƒ parimaddanaá¹ƒ nhÄpanaá¹ƒ sambÄhanaá¹ƒ ÄdÄsaá¹ƒ aÃ±janaá¹ƒ mÄlÄgandhavilepanaá¹ƒ [mÄlÄvilepanaá¹ƒ (sÄ«. syÄ. kaá¹ƒ. pÄ«.)] mukhacuá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ mukhalepanaá¹ƒ hatthabandhaá¹ƒ sikhÄbandhaá¹ƒ daá¹‡á¸aá¹ƒ nÄá¸·ikaá¹ƒ asiá¹ƒ [khaggaá¹ƒ (sÄ«. pÄ«.), asiá¹ƒ khaggaá¹ƒ (syÄ. kaá¹ƒ.)] chattaá¹ƒ citrupÄhanaá¹ƒ uá¹‡hÄ«saá¹ƒ maá¹‡iá¹ƒ vÄlabÄ«janiá¹ƒ odÄtÄni vatthÄni dÄ«ghadasÄni iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄ maá¹‡á¸anavibhÅ«sanaá¹­á¹­hÄnÄnuyogÄ paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya. 17. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«paá¹ƒ tiracchÄnakathaá¹ƒ anuyuttÄ viharanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ rÄjakathaá¹ƒ corakathaá¹ƒ mahÄmattakathaá¹ƒ senÄkathaá¹ƒ bhayakathaá¹ƒ yuddhakathaá¹ƒ annakathaá¹ƒ pÄnakathaá¹ƒ vatthakathaá¹ƒ sayanakathaá¹ƒ mÄlÄkathaá¹ƒ gandhakathaá¹ƒ Ã±Ätikathaá¹ƒ yÄnakathaá¹ƒ gÄmakathaá¹ƒ nigamakathaá¹ƒ nagarakathaá¹ƒ janapadakathaá¹ƒ itthikathaá¹ƒ [itthikathaá¹ƒ purisakathaá¹ƒ (syÄ. kaá¹ƒ. ka.)] sÅ«rakathaá¹ƒ visikhÄkathaá¹ƒ kumbhaá¹­á¹­hÄnakathaá¹ƒ pubbapetakathaá¹ƒ nÄnattakathaá¹ƒ lokakkhÄyikaá¹ƒ samuddakkhÄyikaá¹ƒ itibhavÄbhavakathaá¹ƒ iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnakathÄya paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya.
â€œOr he might say: â€˜Whereas some honorable ascetics and Brahmins, while living on food offered in faith, remain addicted to the use of high and luxurious beds and seats, such as: a couch, a throne, a long-haired coverlet, a variegated coverlet, a white woollen coverlet, a coverlet embroidered with flowers, a quilt stuffed with cotton, a coverlet embroidered with animal figures, a woollen coverlet with hair on both sides, a woollen coverlet with hair on one side, a silk coverlet, a rug, an elephant-covering, a horse-covering, a chariot-covering, a spread of antelope skin, a choice spread of antelope-hide, a canopy with an awning, or a couch with red cushions at both ends; the *samaá¹‡a* Gotama refrains from such high and luxurious beds.â€™ Thus, or in this way, the ordinary person, when describing the virtues of the *TathÄgata*, might speak.
16. iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄ jÅ«tappamÄdaá¹­á¹­hÄnÄnuyogÄ paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya. 15. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«paá¹ƒ uccÄsayanamahÄsayanaá¹ƒ anuyuttÄ viharanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ Äsandiá¹ƒ pallaá¹…kaá¹ƒ gonakaá¹ƒ cittakaá¹ƒ paá¹­ikaá¹ƒ paá¹­alikaá¹ƒ tÅ«likaá¹ƒ vikatikaá¹ƒ uddalomiá¹ƒ ekantalomiá¹ƒ kaá¹­á¹­issaá¹ƒ koseyyaá¹ƒ kuttakaá¹ƒ hatthattharaá¹ƒ assattharaá¹ƒ rathattharaá¹ƒ [hatthattharaá¹‡aá¹ƒ assattharaá¹‡aá¹ƒ rathattharaá¹‡aá¹ƒ (sÄ«. ka. pÄ«.)] ajinappaveá¹‡iá¹ƒ kadalimigapavarapaccattharaá¹‡aá¹ƒ sauttaracchadaá¹ƒ ubhatolohitakÅ«padhÄnaá¹ƒ iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄ uccÄsayanamahÄsayanÄ paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya. 16. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«paá¹ƒ maá¹‡á¸anavibhÅ«sanaá¹­á¹­hÄnÄnuyogaá¹ƒ anuyuttÄ viharanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ ucchÄdanaá¹ƒ parimaddanaá¹ƒ nhÄpanaá¹ƒ sambÄhanaá¹ƒ ÄdÄsaá¹ƒ aÃ±janaá¹ƒ mÄlÄgandhavilepanaá¹ƒ [mÄlÄvilepanaá¹ƒ (sÄ«. syÄ. kaá¹ƒ. pÄ«.)] mukhacuá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ mukhalepanaá¹ƒ hatthabandhaá¹ƒ sikhÄbandhaá¹ƒ daá¹‡á¸aá¹ƒ nÄá¸·ikaá¹ƒ asiá¹ƒ [khaggaá¹ƒ (sÄ«. pÄ«.), asiá¹ƒ khaggaá¹ƒ (syÄ. kaá¹ƒ.)] chattaá¹ƒ citrupÄhanaá¹ƒ uá¹‡hÄ«saá¹ƒ maá¹‡iá¹ƒ vÄlabÄ«janiá¹ƒ odÄtÄni vatthÄni dÄ«ghadasÄni iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄ maá¹‡á¸anavibhÅ«sanaá¹­á¹­hÄnÄnuyogÄ paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya. 17. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«paá¹ƒ tiracchÄnakathaá¹ƒ anuyuttÄ viharanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ rÄjakathaá¹ƒ corakathaá¹ƒ mahÄmattakathaá¹ƒ senÄkathaá¹ƒ bhayakathaá¹ƒ yuddhakathaá¹ƒ annakathaá¹ƒ pÄnakathaá¹ƒ vatthakathaá¹ƒ sayanakathaá¹ƒ mÄlÄkathaá¹ƒ gandhakathaá¹ƒ Ã±Ätikathaá¹ƒ yÄnakathaá¹ƒ gÄmakathaá¹ƒ nigamakathaá¹ƒ nagarakathaá¹ƒ janapadakathaá¹ƒ itthikathaá¹ƒ [itthikathaá¹ƒ purisakathaá¹ƒ (syÄ. kaá¹ƒ. ka.)] sÅ«rakathaá¹ƒ visikhÄkathaá¹ƒ kumbhaá¹­á¹­hÄnakathaá¹ƒ pubbapetakathaá¹ƒ nÄnattakathaá¹ƒ lokakkhÄyikaá¹ƒ samuddakkhÄyikaá¹ƒ itibhavÄbhavakathaá¹ƒ iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnakathÄya paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya.
â€œOr he might say: â€˜Whereas some honorable ascetics and Brahmins, while living on food offered in faith, remain addicted to such practices that involve self-adornment and embellishment, such as rubbing scented powder into the body, massaging with oils, bathing in perfumed water, kneading the limbs, using mirrors, ointments, garlands, perfumes, unguents, face-powder, make-up, bracelets, headbands, decorated walking sticks, ornamented medicine tubes, swords, sunshades, embroidered sandals, turbans, jewels, yak tail whisks and long-fringed white robes; the *samaá¹‡a* Gotama refrains from such practices that involve self-adornment and embellishment.â€™ Thus, or in this way, the ordinary person, when describing the virtues of the *TathÄgata*, might speak.
17. iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄ jÅ«tappamÄdaá¹­á¹­hÄnÄnuyogÄ paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya. 15. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«paá¹ƒ uccÄsayanamahÄsayanaá¹ƒ anuyuttÄ viharanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ Äsandiá¹ƒ pallaá¹…kaá¹ƒ gonakaá¹ƒ cittakaá¹ƒ paá¹­ikaá¹ƒ paá¹­alikaá¹ƒ tÅ«likaá¹ƒ vikatikaá¹ƒ uddalomiá¹ƒ ekantalomiá¹ƒ kaá¹­á¹­issaá¹ƒ koseyyaá¹ƒ kuttakaá¹ƒ hatthattharaá¹ƒ assattharaá¹ƒ rathattharaá¹ƒ [hatthattharaá¹‡aá¹ƒ assattharaá¹‡aá¹ƒ rathattharaá¹‡aá¹ƒ (sÄ«. ka. pÄ«.)] ajinappaveá¹‡iá¹ƒ kadalimigapavarapaccattharaá¹‡aá¹ƒ sauttaracchadaá¹ƒ ubhatolohitakÅ«padhÄnaá¹ƒ iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄ uccÄsayanamahÄsayanÄ paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya. 16. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«paá¹ƒ maá¹‡á¸anavibhÅ«sanaá¹­á¹­hÄnÄnuyogaá¹ƒ anuyuttÄ viharanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ ucchÄdanaá¹ƒ parimaddanaá¹ƒ nhÄpanaá¹ƒ sambÄhanaá¹ƒ ÄdÄsaá¹ƒ aÃ±janaá¹ƒ mÄlÄgandhavilepanaá¹ƒ [mÄlÄvilepanaá¹ƒ (sÄ«. syÄ. kaá¹ƒ. pÄ«.)] mukhacuá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ mukhalepanaá¹ƒ hatthabandhaá¹ƒ sikhÄbandhaá¹ƒ daá¹‡á¸aá¹ƒ nÄá¸·ikaá¹ƒ asiá¹ƒ [khaggaá¹ƒ (sÄ«. pÄ«.), asiá¹ƒ khaggaá¹ƒ (syÄ. kaá¹ƒ.)] chattaá¹ƒ citrupÄhanaá¹ƒ uá¹‡hÄ«saá¹ƒ maá¹‡iá¹ƒ vÄlabÄ«janiá¹ƒ odÄtÄni vatthÄni dÄ«ghadasÄni iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄ maá¹‡á¸anavibhÅ«sanaá¹­á¹­hÄnÄnuyogÄ paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya. 17. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«paá¹ƒ tiracchÄnakathaá¹ƒ anuyuttÄ viharanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ rÄjakathaá¹ƒ corakathaá¹ƒ mahÄmattakathaá¹ƒ senÄkathaá¹ƒ bhayakathaá¹ƒ yuddhakathaá¹ƒ annakathaá¹ƒ pÄnakathaá¹ƒ vatthakathaá¹ƒ sayanakathaá¹ƒ mÄlÄkathaá¹ƒ gandhakathaá¹ƒ Ã±Ätikathaá¹ƒ yÄnakathaá¹ƒ gÄmakathaá¹ƒ nigamakathaá¹ƒ nagarakathaá¹ƒ janapadakathaá¹ƒ itthikathaá¹ƒ [itthikathaá¹ƒ purisakathaá¹ƒ (syÄ. kaá¹ƒ. ka.)] sÅ«rakathaá¹ƒ visikhÄkathaá¹ƒ kumbhaá¹­á¹­hÄnakathaá¹ƒ pubbapetakathaá¹ƒ nÄnattakathaá¹ƒ lokakkhÄyikaá¹ƒ samuddakkhÄyikaá¹ƒ itibhavÄbhavakathaá¹ƒ iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnakathÄya paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya.
â€œOr he might say: â€˜Whereas some honorable ascetics and Brahmins, while living on food offered in faith, remain addicted to the following types of frivolous talk (*tiracchÄnakathaá¹ƒ*), such as talk about kings, talk about thieves, talk about ministers, talk about armies, talk about dangers, talk about battles, talk about food, talk about drinks, talk about clothes, talk about beds, talk about garlands, talk about perfumes, talk about relatives, talk about vehicles, talk about villages, talk about towns, talk about cities, talk about countries, talk about women, talk about heroes, street gossip, gossip at the well, stories of those long dead, diverse talk, accounts of the world, accounts of the sea, talk about existence and non-existence, the *samaá¹‡a* Gotama refrains from such frivolous talk.â€™ Thus, or in this way, the ordinary person, when describing the virtues of the *TathÄgata*, might speak. He suffuses, drenches, fills, and permeates this very body with delight and joy born of detachment ( *vivekajena pÄ«tisukhena*), so that there is no part of his entire body untouched by this delight and joy born of detachment.
18. 18. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«paá¹ƒ viggÄhikakathaá¹ƒ anuyuttÄ viharanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ na tvaá¹ƒ imaá¹ƒ dhammavinayaá¹ƒ ÄjÄnÄsi, ahaá¹ƒ imaá¹ƒ dhammavinayaá¹ƒ ÄjÄnÄmi, kiá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ imaá¹ƒ dhammavinayaá¹ƒ ÄjÄnissasi, micchÄ paá¹­ipanno tvamasi, ahamasmi sammÄ paá¹­ipanno, sahitaá¹ƒ me, asahitaá¹ƒ te, purevacanÄ«yaá¹ƒ pacchÄ avaca, pacchÄvacanÄ«yaá¹ƒ pure avaca, adhiciá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ te viparÄvattaá¹ƒ, Äropito te vÄdo, niggahito tvamasi, cara vÄdappamokkhÄya, nibbeá¹­hehi vÄ sace pahosÄ«ti iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄya viggÄhikakathÄya paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya. 19. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«paá¹ƒ dÅ«teyyapahiá¹‡agamanÄnuyogaá¹ƒ anuyuttÄ viharanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ raÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ, rÄjamahÄmattÄnaá¹ƒ, khattiyÄnaá¹ƒ, brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ, gahapatikÄnaá¹ƒ, kumÄrÄnaá¹ƒ "idha gaccha, amutrÄgaccha, idaá¹ƒ hara, amutra idaá¹ƒ ÄharÄ"ti iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄ dÅ«teyyapahiá¹‡agamanÄnuyogÄ paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya. 20. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te kuhakÄ ca honti, lapakÄ ca nemittikÄ ca nippesikÄ ca, lÄbhena lÄbhaá¹ƒ nijigÄ«sitÄro ca [lÄbhena lÄbhaá¹ƒ nijigiá¹ƒ bhitÄro (sÄ«. syÄ.), lÄbhena ca lÄbhaá¹ƒ nijigÄ«sitÄro (pÄ«.)] iti [iti vÄ, iti (syÄ. kaá¹ƒ. ka.)] evarÅ«pÄ kuhanalapanÄ paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya. majjhimasÄ«laá¹ƒ niá¹­á¹­hitaá¹ƒ. mahÄsÄ«laá¹ƒ 21. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vena jÄ«vitaá¹ƒ
â€œOr he might say: â€˜Whereas some recluses and *brÄhmaá¹‡as*, while living on the food offered by the faithful, engage in wrangling argumentation, such as: â€œYou donâ€™t understand this *dharma* and *vinaya*â€”I do!â€ â€œHow can you understand this *dharma* and *vinaya*?â€ â€œYour way is all wrongâ€”mine is right!â€ â€œI am consistentâ€”you arenâ€™t!â€ â€œWhat should have been said first you said last, what should have been said last you said first!â€ â€œWhat you took so long to think up has been refuted!â€ â€œYour argument has been overthrown, youâ€™re defeated!â€ â€˜Go on, save your doctrine ( *vÄda* )â€™â€”the recluse Gotama abstains from such wrangling argumentation.â€™ It is in this way, *bhikkhus*, that a worldling would speak when speaking in praise of the *TathÄgata*.

â€œOr he might say: â€˜Whereas some recluses and *brÄhmaá¹‡as*, while living on the food offered by the faithful, engage in running messages and errands for kings ( *rajÃ±am* ), ministers of state ( *rÄjamahÄmattÄnam* ), *ká¹£atriyas*, *brÄhmaá¹‡as*, householders ( *gahapatikÄnam* ), or youths ( *kumÄrÄnam* ), such as: â€œGo here, go there, take this, bring that from thereâ€â€”the recluse Gotama abstains from running such messages and errands.â€™ It is in this way, *bhikkhus*, that a worldling would speak when speaking in praise of the *TathÄgata*.

â€œOr he might say: â€˜Whereas some recluses and *brÄhmaá¹‡as*, while living on the food offered by the faithful, engage in scheming ( *kuhakÄ* ), talking ( *lapakÄ* ), hinting ( *nemittikÄ* ), belittling others ( *nippesikÄ* ), and pursuing gain with gainâ€”the recluse Gotama abstains from such kinds of scheming and talking.â€™ â€œIt is in this way, *bhikkhus*, that a worldling would speak when speaking in praise of the *TathÄgata*. The intermediate morality ( *majjhimasÄ«laá¹ƒ* ) is finished. The great morality ( *mahÄsÄ«laá¹ƒ* )
