â€œOr he might say: â€˜Whereas some recluses and *brÄhmaá¹‡as*, while living on the food offered by the faithful, earn their living by a wrong means of livelihood ( *micchÄjÄ«vena* ), by such debased knowledge ( *tiracchÄnavijjÄya* )
22. kappenti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ aá¹…gaá¹ƒ nimittaá¹ƒ uppÄtaá¹ƒ supinaá¹ƒ lakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ mÅ«sikacchinnaá¹ƒ aggihomaá¹ƒ dabbihomaá¹ƒ thusahomaá¹ƒ kaá¹‡ahomaá¹ƒ taá¹‡á¸ulahomaá¹ƒ sappihomaá¹ƒ telahomaá¹ƒ mukhahomaá¹ƒ lohitahomaá¹ƒ aá¹…gavijjÄ vatthuvijjÄ khattavijjÄ [khettavijjÄ (bahÅ«su)] sivavijjÄ bhÅ«tavijjÄ bhÅ«rivijjÄ ahivijjÄ visavijjÄ vicchikavijjÄ mÅ«sikavijjÄ sakuá¹‡avijjÄ vÄyasavijjÄ pakkajjhÄnaá¹ƒ saraparittÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ migacakkaá¹ƒ iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vÄ paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya. 22. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vena jÄ«vitaá¹ƒ kappenti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ maá¹‡ilakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ vatthalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ daá¹‡á¸alakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ satthalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ asilakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ usulakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ dhanulakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ Ävudhalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ itthilakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ purisalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ kumÄralakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ kumÄrilakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ dÄsalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ dÄsilakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ hatthilakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ assalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ mahiá¹ƒsalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ [mahisalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ (sÄ«. syÄ. kaá¹ƒ. pÄ«.)] usabhalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ golakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ ajalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ meá¹‡á¸alakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ kukkuá¹­alakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ vaá¹­á¹­akalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ godhÄlakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ kaá¹‡á¹‡ikÄlakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ kacchapalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ migalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vÄ paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya. 23. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vena jÄ«vitaá¹ƒ kappenti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ raÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ niyyÄnaá¹ƒ bhavissati, raÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ aniyyÄnaá¹ƒ bhavissati, abbhantarÄnaá¹ƒ raÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ upayÄnaá¹ƒ bhavissati, bÄhirÄnaá¹ƒ raÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ apayÄnaá¹ƒ bhavissati, bÄhirÄnaá¹ƒ raÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ upayÄnaá¹ƒ bhavissati, abbhantarÄnaá¹ƒ raÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ apayÄnaá¹ƒ bhavissati, abbhantarÄnaá¹ƒ raÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ jayo bhavissati, bÄhirÄnaá¹ƒ raÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ parÄjayo bhavissati, bÄhirÄnaá¹ƒ raÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ jayo bhavissati, abbhantarÄnaá¹ƒ raÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ parÄjayo bhavissati, iti imassa jayo bhavissati, imassa parÄjayo bhavissati iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vÄ paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya.
"Or he might say: 'Whereas some ascetics and Brahmins, while living on the food offered by the faithful, earn their living by a wrong means of livelihood, by such debased arts as interpreting the significance of the colour, shape, and other features of the following items to determine whether they portend fortune or misfortune for their owners: gems (*maá¹‡ilakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ*), garments (*vatthalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ*), staffs (*daá¹‡á¸alakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ*), swords (*satthalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ*), spears (*asilakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ*), arrows (*usulakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ*), bows (*dhanulakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ*), other weapons (*Ävudhalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ*), women (*itthilakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ*), men (*purisalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ*), boys (*kumÄralakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ*), girls (*kumÄrilakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ*), slaves (*dÄsalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ*), slave-women (*dÄsilakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ*), elephants (*hatthilakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ*), horses (*assalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ*), buffaloes (*mahiá¹ƒsalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ*), bulls (*usabhalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ*), cows (*golakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ*), goats (*ajalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ*), rams (*meá¹‡á¸alakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ*), cocks (*kukkuá¹­alakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ*), quail (*vaá¹­á¹­akalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ*), iguanas (*godhÄlakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ*), bamboo-rats (*kaá¹‡á¹‡ikÄlakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ*), tortoises (*kacchapalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ*), deer (*migalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ*)â€”the ascetic Gotama refrains from such base arts. Thus, indeed, mendicants, a worldling, when speaking in praise of the *tathÄgata*, might speak.
23. kappenti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ aá¹…gaá¹ƒ nimittaá¹ƒ uppÄtaá¹ƒ supinaá¹ƒ lakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ mÅ«sikacchinnaá¹ƒ aggihomaá¹ƒ dabbihomaá¹ƒ thusahomaá¹ƒ kaá¹‡ahomaá¹ƒ taá¹‡á¸ulahomaá¹ƒ sappihomaá¹ƒ telahomaá¹ƒ mukhahomaá¹ƒ lohitahomaá¹ƒ aá¹…gavijjÄ vatthuvijjÄ khattavijjÄ [khettavijjÄ (bahÅ«su)] sivavijjÄ bhÅ«tavijjÄ bhÅ«rivijjÄ ahivijjÄ visavijjÄ vicchikavijjÄ mÅ«sikavijjÄ sakuá¹‡avijjÄ vÄyasavijjÄ pakkajjhÄnaá¹ƒ saraparittÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ migacakkaá¹ƒ iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vÄ paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya. 22. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vena jÄ«vitaá¹ƒ kappenti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ maá¹‡ilakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ vatthalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ daá¹‡á¸alakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ satthalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ asilakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ usulakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ dhanulakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ Ävudhalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ itthilakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ purisalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ kumÄralakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ kumÄrilakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ dÄsalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ dÄsilakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ hatthilakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ assalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ mahiá¹ƒsalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ [mahisalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ (sÄ«. syÄ. kaá¹ƒ. pÄ«.)] usabhalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ golakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ ajalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ meá¹‡á¸alakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ kukkuá¹­alakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ vaá¹­á¹­akalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ godhÄlakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ kaá¹‡á¹‡ikÄlakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ kacchapalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ migalakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vÄ paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya. 23. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vena jÄ«vitaá¹ƒ kappenti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ raÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ niyyÄnaá¹ƒ bhavissati, raÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ aniyyÄnaá¹ƒ bhavissati, abbhantarÄnaá¹ƒ raÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ upayÄnaá¹ƒ bhavissati, bÄhirÄnaá¹ƒ raÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ apayÄnaá¹ƒ bhavissati, bÄhirÄnaá¹ƒ raÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ upayÄnaá¹ƒ bhavissati, abbhantarÄnaá¹ƒ raÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ apayÄnaá¹ƒ bhavissati, abbhantarÄnaá¹ƒ raÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ jayo bhavissati, bÄhirÄnaá¹ƒ raÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ parÄjayo bhavissati, bÄhirÄnaá¹ƒ raÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ jayo bhavissati, abbhantarÄnaá¹ƒ raÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ parÄjayo bhavissati, iti imassa jayo bhavissati, imassa parÄjayo bhavissati iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vÄ paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya.
"Or he might say: 'Whereas some recluses and brahmins, while living on the food offered by the faithful, earn their living by a wrong means of livelihood, by such debased arts as making predictions to the effect that: the king will march forth (*raÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ niyyÄnaá¹ƒ bhavissati*); the king will not march forth (*raÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ aniyyÄnaá¹ƒ bhavissati*); our king will attack (*abbhantarÄnaá¹ƒ raÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ upayÄnaá¹ƒ bhavissati*) and the enemy king will retreat (*bÄhirÄnaá¹ƒ raÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ apayÄnaá¹ƒ bhavissati*); the enemy king will attack (*bÄhirÄnaá¹ƒ raÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ upayÄnaá¹ƒ bhavissati*) and our king will retreat (*abbhantarÄnaá¹ƒ raÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ apayÄnaá¹ƒ bhavissati*); our king will triumph (*abbhantarÄnaá¹ƒ raÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ jayo bhavissati*) and the enemy king will be defeated (*bÄhirÄnaá¹ƒ raÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ parÄjayo bhavissati*); the enemy king will triumph (*bÄhirÄnaá¹ƒ raÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ jayo bhavissati*) and our king will be defeated (*abbhantarÄnaá¹ƒ raÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ parÄjayo bhavissati*); thus there will be victory for one (*iti imassa jayo bhavissati*) and defeat for the other (*imassa parÄjayo bhavissati*)â€”the ascetic Gotama refrains from such base arts. Thus, indeed, mendicants, a worldling, when speaking in praise of the *tathÄgata*, might speak. â€œWell then, Gotama, are you and your teacher endowed with the unexcelled perfection of knowledge and conduct? I am far from the unexcelled perfection of knowledge and conduct.â€ â€œWhat do you think, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha? Could you and your teacher, being unable to gain this unexcelled perfection of knowledge and conduct, go with your carrying-poles into the depths of the forest, intending to live on windfalls?â€ â€œNo, Gotama.â€ â€œWhat do you think, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha? Could you and your teacher, being unable to gain this unexcelled perfection of knowledge and conduct, live on windfalls and, being unable to gain that, take up a spade and basket and go into the depths of the forest, intending to live on tubers and roots?â€ â€œNo, Gotama.â€ â€œWhat do you think, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha? Could you and your teacher, being unable to gain this unexcelled perfection of knowledge and conduct, live on windfalls and, being unable to gain that, live on tubers and roots and, being unable to gain that, build a fire-hut near a village or town, tending the fire?â€ â€œNo, Gotama.â€ â€œWhat do you think, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha? Could you and your teacher, being unable to gain this unexcelled perfection of knowledge and conduct, live on windfalls and, being unable to gain that, live on tubers and roots and, being unable to gain that, tend the fire and, being unable to gain that, build a four-doored rest-house at the crossroads in the hopes that whatever ascetic or Brahmin comes from the four directions, we will honor and serve him according to our ability and power?â€ â€œNo, Gotama.â€ And so, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, not only are you and your teacher incapable of attaining this unexcelled perfection of knowledge and conduct, but even the four paths of failure are beyond you. And yet you and your teacher the *brÄhmaá¹‡a* PokkharasÄti utter these words: â€œThese shaven little ascetics, menials, black scrapings from Brahmaâ€™s foot, what converse can they have with Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas?â€ â€” even though you canâ€™t even manage the duties of one who has failed. See how your teacher has let you down! Following the conduct of the ancient seers The *brÄhmaá¹‡a* PokkharasÄti lives by the grace and favour of King Pasenadi of Kosala. And yet the King does not allow him to have audience face to face. When he confers with the King it is through a curtain. Why should the King not grant audience face to face to one on whom he has bestowed a proper and blameless source of revenue? See how your teacher has let you down! What do you think, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha? Suppose King Pasenadi was sitting on the neck of an elephant or on horseback, or was standing on the chariot-mat, conferring with his ministers and princes about something. And suppose he were to step aside. And suppose he were to step aside and some workman or workmanâ€™s servant were to come along and stand in his place. And standing there he might say: â€œThis is what King Pasenadi of Kosala says!â€ Would he be speaking the Kingâ€™s words, or conferring about the Kingâ€™s business? Would he to that extent be the King, or a royal minister?â€ â€œNo, Gotama.â€ Well then, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, it is just the same thing. Those who were, as you say, the first *á¹›á¹£is* of the *brÄhmaá¹‡as*, the makers and expounders of the *mantras*, whose ancient verses are chanted, pronounced and collected by the *brÄhmaá¹‡as* of today â€” Aá¹­á¹­haka, VÄmaka, VÄmadeva, VessÄmitta, Yamataggi, Aá¹…gÄ«rasa, BhÄradvÄja, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, Kassapa, Bhagu â€” whose *mantras* are said to be passed on to you and your teacher: yet you do not thereby become a *á¹›á¹£i* or one practiced in the way of a *á¹›á¹£i* â€” such a thing is impossible. What do you think, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha? What have you heard said by *brÄhmaá¹‡as* who are venerable, aged, the teachers of teachers? Those first *á¹›á¹£is* of the *brÄhmaá¹‡as*, the makers and expounders of the *mantras*, Those ancient verses which the Brahmins of today chant, pronounce and collect, whose origin lies with brahmin seers of the past, the creators of the hymns, the composers of the hymns â€” Aá¹­á¹­haka, VÄmaka, VÄmadeva, VessÄmitta, Yamataggi, Aá¹…girasa, BhÄradvÄja, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, Kassapa & Bhaguâ€”did they live well-bathed, perfumed, their hair and beards trimmed, adorned with jewels, earrings and ornaments, dressed in white clothes, indulging in the pleasures of the five senses, as you and your teacher do now?â€ â€œNo, Master Gotama.â€ â€œâ€¦peâ€¦ Or did they eat special fine rice with various soups and curries, as you and your teacher do now?â€ â€œNo, Master Gotama.â€ â€œâ€¦peâ€¦ Or did they amuse themselves with women dressed up in flounces and furbelows, as you and your teacher do now?â€ â€œNo, Master Gotama.â€ â€œâ€¦peâ€¦ Or did they ride around in chariots drawn by mares with braided tails, that they urged on with long goad-sticks, as you and your teacher do now?â€ â€œNo, Master Gotama.â€ â€œâ€¦peâ€¦ Or did they have themselves guarded in fortified towns with palisades and barricades, by men with long swords, as you and your teacher do now?â€ â€œNo, Master Gotama.â€ â€œSo, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, neither you nor your teacher are a sage or one trained in the way of a sage. And now, as for your doubts and perplexities concerning me, we will clarify these by your asking me, and by my answering your questions.â€ Display of the Two Characteristics.
24. 24. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vena jÄ«vitaá¹ƒ kappenti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ candaggÄho bhavissati, sÅ«riyaggÄho [suriyaggÄho (sÄ«. syÄ. kaá¹ƒ. pÄ«.)] bhavissati, nakkhattaggÄho bhavissati, candimasÅ«riyÄnaá¹ƒ pathagamanaá¹ƒ bhavissati, candimasÅ«riyÄnaá¹ƒ uppathagamanaá¹ƒ bhavissati, nakkhattÄnaá¹ƒ pathagamanaá¹ƒ bhavissati, nakkhattÄnaá¹ƒ uppathagamanaá¹ƒ bhavissati, ukkÄpÄto bhavissati, disÄá¸Äho bhavissati, bhÅ«micÄlo bhavissati, devadudrabhi [devadundubhi (syÄ. kaá¹ƒ. pÄ«.)] bhavissati, candimasÅ«riyanakkhattÄnaá¹ƒ uggamanaá¹ƒ ogamanaá¹ƒ saá¹ƒkilesaá¹ƒ vodÄnaá¹ƒ bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄko candaggÄho bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄko sÅ«riyaggÄho bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄko nakkhattaggÄho bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄkaá¹ƒ candimasÅ«riyÄnaá¹ƒ pathagamanaá¹ƒ bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄkaá¹ƒ candimasÅ«riyÄnaá¹ƒ uppathagamanaá¹ƒ bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄkaá¹ƒ nakkhattÄnaá¹ƒ pathagamanaá¹ƒ bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄkaá¹ƒ nakkhattÄnaá¹ƒ uppathagamanaá¹ƒ bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄko ukkÄpÄto bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄko disÄá¸Äho bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄko bhÅ«micÄlo bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄko devadudrabhi bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄkaá¹ƒ candimasÅ«riyanakkhattÄnaá¹ƒ uggamanaá¹ƒ ogamanaá¹ƒ saá¹ƒkilesaá¹ƒ vodÄnaá¹ƒ bhavissati iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vÄ paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya. 25. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vena jÄ«vitaá¹ƒ kappenti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ suvuá¹­á¹­hikÄ bhavissati, dubbuá¹­á¹­hikÄ bhavissati, subhikkhaá¹ƒ bhavissati, dubbhikkhaá¹ƒ bhavissati, khemaá¹ƒ bhavissati, bhayaá¹ƒ bhavissati, rogo bhavissati, Ärogyaá¹ƒ bhavissati, muddÄ, gaá¹‡anÄ, saá¹…khÄnaá¹ƒ, kÄveyyaá¹ƒ, lokÄyataá¹ƒ iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vÄ paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya. 26. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vena jÄ«vitaá¹ƒ
â€œOr he might say: â€˜Whereas some venerable ascetics and Brahmins, after consuming food given in faith, maintain their lives through a wrong livelihood, by means of such base arts, specifically: There will be an eclipse of the moon (*candaggÄho bhavissati*), there will be an eclipse of the sun (*sÅ«riyaggÄho bhavissati*), there will be an eclipse of a star (*nakkhattaggÄho bhavissati*), the moon and the sun will follow their proper course (*candimasÅ«riyÄnaá¹ƒ pathagamanaá¹ƒ bhavissati*), the moon and the sun will deviate from their proper course (*candimasÅ«riyÄnaá¹ƒ uppathagamanaá¹ƒ bhavissati*), the stars will follow their proper course (*nakkhattÄnaá¹ƒ pathagamanaá¹ƒ bhavissati*), the stars will deviate from their proper course (*nakkhattÄnaá¹ƒ uppathagamanaá¹ƒ bhavissati*), there will be a meteor shower (*ukkÄpÄto bhavissati*), there will be a fire in the sky (*disÄá¸Äho bhavissati*), there will be an earthquake (*bhÅ«micÄlo bhavissati*), there will be a divine drum (*devadudrabhi bhavissati*), there will be a rising, setting, darkening and brightening of the moon, sun, and stars (*candimasÅ«riyanakkhattÄnaá¹ƒ uggamanaá¹ƒ ogamanaá¹ƒ saá¹ƒkilesaá¹ƒ vodÄnaá¹ƒ bhavissati*), the result of this will be an eclipse of the moon, the result of this will be an eclipse of the sun, the result of this will be an eclipse of a star, the result of this will be the moon and the sun following their proper course, the result of this will be the moon and the sun deviating from their proper course, the result of this will be the stars following their proper course, the result of this will be the stars deviating from their proper course, the result of this will be a meteor shower, the result of this will be a fire in the sky, the result of this will be an earthquake, the result of this will be a divine drum, the result of this will be a rising, setting, darkening and brightening of the moon, sun, and stars.â€™ Thus, the ascetic Gotama abstains from such base arts and wrong livelihood." Thus, monks, a common person might describe the virtues of the TathÄgata.
25. 24. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vena jÄ«vitaá¹ƒ kappenti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ candaggÄho bhavissati, sÅ«riyaggÄho [suriyaggÄho (sÄ«. syÄ. kaá¹ƒ. pÄ«.)] bhavissati, nakkhattaggÄho bhavissati, candimasÅ«riyÄnaá¹ƒ pathagamanaá¹ƒ bhavissati, candimasÅ«riyÄnaá¹ƒ uppathagamanaá¹ƒ bhavissati, nakkhattÄnaá¹ƒ pathagamanaá¹ƒ bhavissati, nakkhattÄnaá¹ƒ uppathagamanaá¹ƒ bhavissati, ukkÄpÄto bhavissati, disÄá¸Äho bhavissati, bhÅ«micÄlo bhavissati, devadudrabhi [devadundubhi (syÄ. kaá¹ƒ. pÄ«.)] bhavissati, candimasÅ«riyanakkhattÄnaá¹ƒ uggamanaá¹ƒ ogamanaá¹ƒ saá¹ƒkilesaá¹ƒ vodÄnaá¹ƒ bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄko candaggÄho bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄko sÅ«riyaggÄho bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄko nakkhattaggÄho bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄkaá¹ƒ candimasÅ«riyÄnaá¹ƒ pathagamanaá¹ƒ bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄkaá¹ƒ candimasÅ«riyÄnaá¹ƒ uppathagamanaá¹ƒ bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄkaá¹ƒ nakkhattÄnaá¹ƒ pathagamanaá¹ƒ bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄkaá¹ƒ nakkhattÄnaá¹ƒ uppathagamanaá¹ƒ bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄko ukkÄpÄto bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄko disÄá¸Äho bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄko bhÅ«micÄlo bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄko devadudrabhi bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄkaá¹ƒ candimasÅ«riyanakkhattÄnaá¹ƒ uggamanaá¹ƒ ogamanaá¹ƒ saá¹ƒkilesaá¹ƒ vodÄnaá¹ƒ bhavissati iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vÄ paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya. 25. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vena jÄ«vitaá¹ƒ kappenti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ suvuá¹­á¹­hikÄ bhavissati, dubbuá¹­á¹­hikÄ bhavissati, subhikkhaá¹ƒ bhavissati, dubbhikkhaá¹ƒ bhavissati, khemaá¹ƒ bhavissati, bhayaá¹ƒ bhavissati, rogo bhavissati, Ärogyaá¹ƒ bhavissati, muddÄ, gaá¹‡anÄ, saá¹…khÄnaá¹ƒ, kÄveyyaá¹ƒ, lokÄyataá¹ƒ iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vÄ paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya. 26. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vena jÄ«vitaá¹ƒ
"Or he might say: â€˜Whereas some venerable ascetics and Brahmins, after consuming food given in faith, maintain their lives through a wrong livelihood, by means of such base arts, specifically: There will be abundant rain (*suvuá¹­á¹­hikÄ bhavissati*), there will be a drought (*dubbuá¹­á¹­hikÄ bhavissati*), there will be a good harvest (*subhikkhaá¹ƒ bhavissati*), there will be a famine (*dubbhikkhaá¹ƒ bhavissati*), there will be security (*khemaá¹ƒ bhavissati*), there will be danger (*bhayaá¹ƒ bhavissati*), there will be disease (*rogo bhavissati*), there will be health (*Ärogyaá¹ƒ bhavissati*), or accounting (*muddÄ*), computation (*gaá¹‡anÄ*), calculation (*saá¹…khÄnaá¹ƒ*), composing poetry (*kÄveyyaá¹ƒ*), and speculation about the world (*lokÄyataá¹ƒ*).' Thus, the ascetic Gotama abstains from such base arts and wrong livelihood.â€ Thus, monks, a common person might describe the virtues of the TathÄgata.
26. 24. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vena jÄ«vitaá¹ƒ kappenti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ candaggÄho bhavissati, sÅ«riyaggÄho [suriyaggÄho (sÄ«. syÄ. kaá¹ƒ. pÄ«.)] bhavissati, nakkhattaggÄho bhavissati, candimasÅ«riyÄnaá¹ƒ pathagamanaá¹ƒ bhavissati, candimasÅ«riyÄnaá¹ƒ uppathagamanaá¹ƒ bhavissati, nakkhattÄnaá¹ƒ pathagamanaá¹ƒ bhavissati, nakkhattÄnaá¹ƒ uppathagamanaá¹ƒ bhavissati, ukkÄpÄto bhavissati, disÄá¸Äho bhavissati, bhÅ«micÄlo bhavissati, devadudrabhi [devadundubhi (syÄ. kaá¹ƒ. pÄ«.)] bhavissati, candimasÅ«riyanakkhattÄnaá¹ƒ uggamanaá¹ƒ ogamanaá¹ƒ saá¹ƒkilesaá¹ƒ vodÄnaá¹ƒ bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄko candaggÄho bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄko sÅ«riyaggÄho bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄko nakkhattaggÄho bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄkaá¹ƒ candimasÅ«riyÄnaá¹ƒ pathagamanaá¹ƒ bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄkaá¹ƒ candimasÅ«riyÄnaá¹ƒ uppathagamanaá¹ƒ bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄkaá¹ƒ nakkhattÄnaá¹ƒ pathagamanaá¹ƒ bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄkaá¹ƒ nakkhattÄnaá¹ƒ uppathagamanaá¹ƒ bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄko ukkÄpÄto bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄko disÄá¸Äho bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄko bhÅ«micÄlo bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄko devadudrabhi bhavissati, evaá¹ƒvipÄkaá¹ƒ candimasÅ«riyanakkhattÄnaá¹ƒ uggamanaá¹ƒ ogamanaá¹ƒ saá¹ƒkilesaá¹ƒ vodÄnaá¹ƒ bhavissati iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vÄ paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya. 25. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vena jÄ«vitaá¹ƒ kappenti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ suvuá¹­á¹­hikÄ bhavissati, dubbuá¹­á¹­hikÄ bhavissati, subhikkhaá¹ƒ bhavissati, dubbhikkhaá¹ƒ bhavissati, khemaá¹ƒ bhavissati, bhayaá¹ƒ bhavissati, rogo bhavissati, Ärogyaá¹ƒ bhavissati, muddÄ, gaá¹‡anÄ, saá¹…khÄnaá¹ƒ, kÄveyyaá¹ƒ, lokÄyataá¹ƒ iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vÄ paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya. 26. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vena jÄ«vitaá¹ƒ
"Or he might say: â€˜Whereas some venerable ascetics and Brahmins, after consuming food given in faith, maintain their lives through a wrong livelihood, by means of such base arts...' â€˜It is possible, Gotama. Indeed, Master Gotama, we could leave out appearance of these five qualities. What can appearance do? If, Master Gotama, a *brÄhmaá¹‡a* is well-born on both sides, from his mother and father, of pure descent back to the seventh generation of ancestors, unblemished and irreproachable in regard to his birth; and is a scholar, versed in the mantras, who has mastered the three Vedas along with the *nighaá¹‡á¸u* (glossary), *keá¹­ubha* (commentary), with their literal divisions and arrangement of words, and fifthly the traditions, skilled in *pada* (grammar) and *veyyÄkaraá¹‡a* (etymology), and is unerring in *lokÄyata* (natural philosophy) and the characteristics of a great man; and is virtuous, of increasing virtue, endowed with increasing virtue; and is learned and wise, and is the first or second to hold the sacrificial ladle. Brahmins recognize a Brahmin by these four qualities, good Gotama, and when declaring â€œI am a Brahminâ€ one would speak correctly, and not incur falsehood.â€™
27. kappenti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ ÄvÄhanaá¹ƒ vivÄhanaá¹ƒ saá¹ƒvaraá¹‡aá¹ƒ vivaraá¹‡aá¹ƒ saá¹ƒkiraá¹‡aá¹ƒ vikiraá¹‡aá¹ƒ subhagakaraá¹‡aá¹ƒ dubbhagakaraá¹‡aá¹ƒ viruddhagabbhakaraá¹‡aá¹ƒ jivhÄnibandhanaá¹ƒ hanusaá¹ƒhananaá¹ƒ hatthÄbhijappanaá¹ƒ hanujappanaá¹ƒ kaá¹‡á¹‡ajappanaá¹ƒ ÄdÄsapaÃ±haá¹ƒ kumÄrikapaÃ±haá¹ƒ devapaÃ±haá¹ƒ Ädiccupaá¹­á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ mahatupaá¹­á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ abbhujjalanaá¹ƒ sirivhÄyanaá¹ƒ iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vÄ paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya. 27. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vena jÄ«vitaá¹ƒ kappenti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ santikammaá¹ƒ paá¹‡idhikammaá¹ƒ bhÅ«takammaá¹ƒ bhÅ«rikammaá¹ƒ vassakammaá¹ƒ vossakammaá¹ƒ vatthukammaá¹ƒ vatthuparikammaá¹ƒ Äcamanaá¹ƒ nhÄpanaá¹ƒ juhanaá¹ƒ vamanaá¹ƒ virecanaá¹ƒ uddhaá¹ƒvirecanaá¹ƒ adhovirecanaá¹ƒ sÄ«savirecanaá¹ƒ kaá¹‡á¹‡atelaá¹ƒ nettatappanaá¹ƒ natthukammaá¹ƒ aÃ±janaá¹ƒ paccaÃ±janaá¹ƒ sÄlÄkiyaá¹ƒ sallakattiyaá¹ƒ dÄrakatikicchÄ mÅ«labhesajjÄnaá¹ƒ anuppadÄnaá¹ƒ osadhÄ«naá¹ƒ paá¹­imokkho iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vÄ paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya. "idaá¹ƒ kho, bhikkhave, appamattakaá¹ƒ oramattakaá¹ƒ sÄ«lamattakaá¹ƒ, yena puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya. mahÄsÄ«laá¹ƒ niá¹­á¹­hitaá¹ƒ. pubbantakappikÄ 28. "atthi, bhikkhave, aÃ±Ã±eva dhammÄ gambhÄ«rÄ duddasÄ duranubodhÄ santÄ paá¹‡Ä«tÄ atakkÄvacarÄ nipuá¹‡Ä paá¹‡á¸itavedanÄ«yÄ, ye tathÄgato sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ pavedeti, yehi tathÄgatassa yathÄbhuccaá¹ƒ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ sammÄ vadamÄnÄ vadeyyuá¹ƒ. katame ca te, bhikkhave, dhammÄ gambhÄ«rÄ duddasÄ duranubodhÄ santÄ paá¹‡Ä«tÄ atakkÄvacarÄ nipuá¹‡Ä paá¹‡á¸itavedanÄ«yÄ, ye tathÄgato sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ pavedeti, yehi tathÄgatassa yathÄbhuccaá¹ƒ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ sammÄ vadamÄnÄ vadeyyuá¹ƒ.
"â€˜Whereas some ascetics and Brahmins, while living on the food offered by the faithful, earn their living by a wrong means of livelihood, by such debased arts as: promising gifts (*santikammaá¹ƒ*) and redeeming vows (*paá¹‡idhikamma*) to deities; demonology (*bhÅ«takammaá¹ƒ*); inducing virility (*bhÅ«rikammaá¹ƒ*) and impotence (*vassakammaá¹ƒ*); preparing and consecrating sites for a house (*vatthukammaá¹ƒ, vatthuparikammaá¹ƒ*); giving ceremonial mouthwashes (*Äcamanaá¹ƒ*) and ceremonial bathing (*nhÄpanaá¹ƒ*); offering sacrificial fires (*juhanaá¹ƒ*); administering emetics (*vamanaá¹ƒ*), purgatives (*virecanaá¹ƒ*), expectorants (*uddhaá¹ƒvirecanaá¹ƒ*) and phlegmagogues (*adhovirecanaá¹ƒ, sÄ«savirecanaá¹ƒ*); giving ear-medicine (*kaá¹‡á¹‡atelaá¹ƒ*), eye-medicine (*nettatappanaá¹ƒ*), nose-medicine (*natthukammaá¹ƒ*), ointments (*aÃ±janaá¹ƒ*) and counter-ointments (*paccaÃ±janaá¹ƒ*); eye-surgery (*sÄlÄkiyaá¹ƒ*), surgery (*sallakattiyaá¹ƒ*), pediatric medicine (*dÄrakatikicchÄ*); administering root-based medicines (*mÅ«labhesajjÄnaá¹ƒ anuppadÄnaá¹ƒ*) and herbal remedies (*osadhÄ«naá¹ƒ paá¹­imokkho*)â€™â€” thus it is that the ascetic Gotama refrains from such base arts and wrong means of livelihood.â€™ Thus it is, monks, that an ordinary person, when speaking in praise of the *TathÄgata*, would speak." "These, monks, are those trifling and insignificant matters, those minor details of mere moral virtue (*sÄ«lamattakaá¹ƒ*), that a worldling would refer to when speaking in praise of the *TathÄgata*. The Long Section on Moral Virtue is Finished. Speculators about the past.
28. kappenti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ ÄvÄhanaá¹ƒ vivÄhanaá¹ƒ saá¹ƒvaraá¹‡aá¹ƒ vivaraá¹‡aá¹ƒ saá¹ƒkiraá¹‡aá¹ƒ vikiraá¹‡aá¹ƒ subhagakaraá¹‡aá¹ƒ dubbhagakaraá¹‡aá¹ƒ viruddhagabbhakaraá¹‡aá¹ƒ jivhÄnibandhanaá¹ƒ hanusaá¹ƒhananaá¹ƒ hatthÄbhijappanaá¹ƒ hanujappanaá¹ƒ kaá¹‡á¹‡ajappanaá¹ƒ ÄdÄsapaÃ±haá¹ƒ kumÄrikapaÃ±haá¹ƒ devapaÃ±haá¹ƒ Ädiccupaá¹­á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ mahatupaá¹­á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ abbhujjalanaá¹ƒ sirivhÄyanaá¹ƒ iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vÄ paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya. 27. "â€˜yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vena jÄ«vitaá¹ƒ kappenti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ santikammaá¹ƒ paá¹‡idhikammaá¹ƒ bhÅ«takammaá¹ƒ bhÅ«rikammaá¹ƒ vassakammaá¹ƒ vossakammaá¹ƒ vatthukammaá¹ƒ vatthuparikammaá¹ƒ Äcamanaá¹ƒ nhÄpanaá¹ƒ juhanaá¹ƒ vamanaá¹ƒ virecanaá¹ƒ uddhaá¹ƒvirecanaá¹ƒ adhovirecanaá¹ƒ sÄ«savirecanaá¹ƒ kaá¹‡á¹‡atelaá¹ƒ nettatappanaá¹ƒ natthukammaá¹ƒ aÃ±janaá¹ƒ paccaÃ±janaá¹ƒ sÄlÄkiyaá¹ƒ sallakattiyaá¹ƒ dÄrakatikicchÄ mÅ«labhesajjÄnaá¹ƒ anuppadÄnaá¹ƒ osadhÄ«naá¹ƒ paá¹­imokkho iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vÄ paá¹­ivirato samaá¹‡o gotamoâ€™ti â€“ iti vÄ hi, bhikkhave, puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya. "idaá¹ƒ kho, bhikkhave, appamattakaá¹ƒ oramattakaá¹ƒ sÄ«lamattakaá¹ƒ, yena puthujjano tathÄgatassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vadamÄno vadeyya. mahÄsÄ«laá¹ƒ niá¹­á¹­hitaá¹ƒ. pubbantakappikÄ 28. "atthi, bhikkhave, aÃ±Ã±eva dhammÄ gambhÄ«rÄ duddasÄ duranubodhÄ santÄ paá¹‡Ä«tÄ atakkÄvacarÄ nipuá¹‡Ä paá¹‡á¸itavedanÄ«yÄ, ye tathÄgato sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ pavedeti, yehi tathÄgatassa yathÄbhuccaá¹ƒ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ sammÄ vadamÄnÄ vadeyyuá¹ƒ. katame ca te, bhikkhave, dhammÄ gambhÄ«rÄ duddasÄ duranubodhÄ santÄ paá¹‡Ä«tÄ atakkÄvacarÄ nipuá¹‡Ä paá¹‡á¸itavedanÄ«yÄ, ye tathÄgato sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ pavedeti, yehi tathÄgatassa yathÄbhuccaá¹ƒ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ sammÄ vadamÄnÄ vadeyyuá¹ƒ.
â€œThere are, monks, other *dharmas*, deep, difficult to see, difficult to understand, peaceful and sublime, beyond the sphere of reasoning, subtle, comprehensible only to the wise (*paá¹‡á¸itavedanÄ«yÄ*), which the *TathÄgata*, having realized for himself with direct knowledge (*abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ*), propounds to others; and it is concerning these that those who would rightly praise the *TathÄgata* in accordance with reality would speak. And what are these *dharmas*, monks, deep, difficult to see, difficult to understand, peaceful and sublime, beyond the sphere of reasoning, subtle, comprehensible only to the wise (*paá¹‡á¸itavedanÄ«yÄ*), which the *TathÄgata*, having realized for himself with direct knowledge (*abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ*), propounds to others; and it is concerning these that those who would rightly praise the *TathÄgata* in accordance with reality would speak?
29. 29. "santi, bhikkhave, eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä pubbantakappikÄ pubbantÄnudiá¹­á¹­hino, pubbantaá¹ƒ Ärabbha anekavihitÄni adhimuttipadÄni [adhivuttipadÄni (sÄ«. pÄ«.)] abhivadanti aá¹­á¹­hÄrasahi vatthÅ«hi. te ca bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä kimÄgamma kimÄrabbha pubbantakappikÄ pubbantÄnudiá¹­á¹­hino pubbantaá¹ƒ Ärabbha anekavihitÄni adhimuttipadÄni abhivadanti aá¹­á¹­hÄrasahi vatthÅ«hi. sassatavÄdo 30. "santi, bhikkhave, eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä sassatavÄdÄ, sassataá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti catÅ«hi vatthÅ«hi. te ca bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä kimÄgamma kimÄrabbha sassatavÄdÄ sassataá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti catÅ«hi vatthÅ«hi. 31. "idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaá¹‡o vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡o vÄ ÄtappamanvÄya padhÄnamanvÄya anuyogamanvÄya appamÄdamanvÄya sammÄmanasikÄramanvÄya tathÄrÅ«paá¹ƒ cetosamÄdhiá¹ƒ phusati, yathÄsamÄhite citte ( ) [(parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pattilese) (syÄ. ka.)] anekavihitaá¹ƒ pubbenivÄsaá¹ƒ anussarati. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ ekampi jÄtiá¹ƒ dvepi jÄtiyo tissopi jÄtiyo catassopi jÄtiyo paÃ±capi jÄtiyo dasapi jÄtiyo vÄ«sampi jÄtiyo tiá¹ƒsampi jÄtiyo cattÄlÄ«sampi jÄtiyo paÃ±Ã±Äsampi jÄtiyo jÄtisatampi jÄtisahassampi jÄtisatasahassampi anekÄnipi jÄtisatÄni anekÄnipi jÄtisahassÄni anekÄnipi jÄtisatasahassÄni â€“ â€˜amutrÄsiá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒnÄmo evaá¹ƒgotto evaá¹ƒvaá¹‡á¹‡o evamÄhÄro evaá¹ƒsukhadukkhappaá¹­isaá¹ƒvedÄ« evamÄyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapÄdiá¹ƒ, tatrÄpÄsiá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒnÄmo evaá¹ƒgotto evaá¹ƒvaá¹‡á¹‡o evamÄhÄro evaá¹ƒsukhadukkhappaá¹­isaá¹ƒvedÄ« evamÄyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhÅ«papannoâ€™ti. iti sÄkÄraá¹ƒ sauddesaá¹ƒ anekavihitaá¹ƒ pubbenivÄsaá¹ƒ anussarati. "so evamÄha â€“ â€˜sassato attÄ ca loko ca vaÃ±jho kÅ«á¹­aá¹­á¹­ho esikaá¹­á¹­hÄyiá¹­á¹­hito, te ca sattÄ sandhÄvanti saá¹ƒsaranti cavanti upapajjanti, atthitveva sassatisamaá¹ƒ. taá¹ƒ kissa hetu? ahaÃ±hi ÄtappamanvÄya
â€œThere are, monks, some ascetics and Brahmins who are speculators about the past (*pubbantakappikÄ*) and hold views about the past (*pubbantÄnudiá¹­á¹­hino*), who, with reference to the past (*pubbantaá¹ƒ Ärabbha*), assert various conceptual theorems (*adhimuttipadÄni*)â€¦â€ And owing to what, with reference to what, do these honourable ascetics and Brahmins who are speculators about the past (*pubbantakappikÄ*) and hold views about the past (*pubbantÄnudiá¹­á¹­hino*), assert various conceptual theorems (*adhimuttipadÄni*) with reference to the past (*pubbantaá¹ƒ Ärabbha*)? The Doctrine of Eternalism (*sassatavÄdo*).
30. 29. "santi, bhikkhave, eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä pubbantakappikÄ pubbantÄnudiá¹­á¹­hino, pubbantaá¹ƒ Ärabbha anekavihitÄni adhimuttipadÄni [adhivuttipadÄni (sÄ«. pÄ«.)] abhivadanti aá¹­á¹­hÄrasahi vatthÅ«hi. te ca bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä kimÄgamma kimÄrabbha pubbantakappikÄ pubbantÄnudiá¹­á¹­hino pubbantaá¹ƒ Ärabbha anekavihitÄni adhimuttipadÄni abhivadanti aá¹­á¹­hÄrasahi vatthÅ«hi. sassatavÄdo 30. "santi, bhikkhave, eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä sassatavÄdÄ, sassataá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti catÅ«hi vatthÅ«hi. te ca bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä kimÄgamma kimÄrabbha sassatavÄdÄ sassataá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti catÅ«hi vatthÅ«hi. 31. "idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaá¹‡o vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡o vÄ ÄtappamanvÄya padhÄnamanvÄya anuyogamanvÄya appamÄdamanvÄya sammÄmanasikÄramanvÄya tathÄrÅ«paá¹ƒ cetosamÄdhiá¹ƒ phusati, yathÄsamÄhite citte ( ) [(parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pattilese) (syÄ. ka.)] anekavihitaá¹ƒ pubbenivÄsaá¹ƒ anussarati. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ ekampi jÄtiá¹ƒ dvepi jÄtiyo tissopi jÄtiyo catassopi jÄtiyo paÃ±capi jÄtiyo dasapi jÄtiyo vÄ«sampi jÄtiyo tiá¹ƒsampi jÄtiyo cattÄlÄ«sampi jÄtiyo paÃ±Ã±Äsampi jÄtiyo jÄtisatampi jÄtisahassampi jÄtisatasahassampi anekÄnipi jÄtisatÄni anekÄnipi jÄtisahassÄni anekÄnipi jÄtisatasahassÄni â€“ â€˜amutrÄsiá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒnÄmo evaá¹ƒgotto evaá¹ƒvaá¹‡á¹‡o evamÄhÄro evaá¹ƒsukhadukkhappaá¹­isaá¹ƒvedÄ« evamÄyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapÄdiá¹ƒ, tatrÄpÄsiá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒnÄmo evaá¹ƒgotto evaá¹ƒvaá¹‡á¹‡o evamÄhÄro evaá¹ƒsukhadukkhappaá¹­isaá¹ƒvedÄ« evamÄyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhÅ«papannoâ€™ti. iti sÄkÄraá¹ƒ sauddesaá¹ƒ anekavihitaá¹ƒ pubbenivÄsaá¹ƒ anussarati. "so evamÄha â€“ â€˜sassato attÄ ca loko ca vaÃ±jho kÅ«á¹­aá¹­á¹­ho esikaá¹­á¹­hÄyiá¹­á¹­hito, te ca sattÄ sandhÄvanti saá¹ƒsaranti cavanti upapajjanti, atthitveva sassatisamaá¹ƒ. taá¹ƒ kissa hetu? ahaÃ±hi ÄtappamanvÄya
â€œThere are, monks, some ascetics and Brahmins who are eternalists (*sassatavÄdÄ*), and who on four grounds proclaim the self (*attÄnaá¹ƒ*) and the world (*lokaá¹ƒ*) to be eternal (*sassataá¹ƒ*). And owing to what, with reference to what, do these honourable ascetics and Brahmins who are eternalists (*sassatavÄdÄ*), proclaim the self (*attÄnaá¹ƒ*) and the world (*lokaá¹ƒ*) to be eternal (*sassataá¹ƒ*) on four grounds?
31. 29. "santi, bhikkhave, eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä pubbantakappikÄ pubbantÄnudiá¹­á¹­hino, pubbantaá¹ƒ Ärabbha anekavihitÄni adhimuttipadÄni [adhivuttipadÄni (sÄ«. pÄ«.)] abhivadanti aá¹­á¹­hÄrasahi vatthÅ«hi. te ca bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä kimÄgamma kimÄrabbha pubbantakappikÄ pubbantÄnudiá¹­á¹­hino pubbantaá¹ƒ Ärabbha anekavihitÄni adhimuttipadÄni abhivadanti aá¹­á¹­hÄrasahi vatthÅ«hi. sassatavÄdo 30. "santi, bhikkhave, eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä sassatavÄdÄ, sassataá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti catÅ«hi vatthÅ«hi. te ca bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä kimÄgamma kimÄrabbha sassatavÄdÄ sassataá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti catÅ«hi vatthÅ«hi. 31. "idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaá¹‡o vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡o vÄ ÄtappamanvÄya padhÄnamanvÄya anuyogamanvÄya appamÄdamanvÄya sammÄmanasikÄramanvÄya tathÄrÅ«paá¹ƒ cetosamÄdhiá¹ƒ phusati, yathÄsamÄhite citte ( ) [(parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pattilese) (syÄ. ka.)] anekavihitaá¹ƒ pubbenivÄsaá¹ƒ anussarati. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ ekampi jÄtiá¹ƒ dvepi jÄtiyo tissopi jÄtiyo catassopi jÄtiyo paÃ±capi jÄtiyo dasapi jÄtiyo vÄ«sampi jÄtiyo tiá¹ƒsampi jÄtiyo cattÄlÄ«sampi jÄtiyo paÃ±Ã±Äsampi jÄtiyo jÄtisatampi jÄtisahassampi jÄtisatasahassampi anekÄnipi jÄtisatÄni anekÄnipi jÄtisahassÄni anekÄnipi jÄtisatasahassÄni â€“ â€˜amutrÄsiá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒnÄmo evaá¹ƒgotto evaá¹ƒvaá¹‡á¹‡o evamÄhÄro evaá¹ƒsukhadukkhappaá¹­isaá¹ƒvedÄ« evamÄyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapÄdiá¹ƒ, tatrÄpÄsiá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒnÄmo evaá¹ƒgotto evaá¹ƒvaá¹‡á¹‡o evamÄhÄro evaá¹ƒsukhadukkhappaá¹­isaá¹ƒvedÄ« evamÄyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhÅ«papannoâ€™ti. iti sÄkÄraá¹ƒ sauddesaá¹ƒ anekavihitaá¹ƒ pubbenivÄsaá¹ƒ anussarati. "so evamÄha â€“ â€˜sassato attÄ ca loko ca vaÃ±jho kÅ«á¹­aá¹­á¹­ho esikaá¹­á¹­hÄyiá¹­á¹­hito, te ca sattÄ sandhÄvanti saá¹ƒsaranti cavanti upapajjanti, atthitveva sassatisamaá¹ƒ. taá¹ƒ kissa hetu? ahaÃ±hi ÄtappamanvÄya
â€œHerein, monks, a certain ascetic or Brahmin, by means of ardour (*ÄtappamanvÄya*), endeavour (*padhÄnamanvÄya*), application (*anuyogamanvÄya*), diligence (*appamÄdamanvÄya*), and right reflection (*sammÄmanasikÄramanvÄya*), attains to such a degree of mental concentration (*cetosamÄdhiá¹ƒ phusati*) that with his mind thus concentrated (*yathÄsamÄhite citte*)â€¦recollects his numerous past lives (*anekavihitaá¹ƒ pubbenivÄsaá¹ƒ anussarati*). That is, one birth (*ekampi jÄtiá¹ƒ*), two births (*dvepi jÄtiyo*), three births, four births, five births, ten births, twenty births, thirty births, forty births, fifty births, a hundred births, a thousand births, a hundred thousand births, many hundreds of births, many thousands of births, many hundreds of thousands of births: â€˜There I had such a name (*evaá¹ƒnÄmo*), belonged to such a clan (*evaá¹ƒgotto*), had such an appearance (*evaá¹ƒvaá¹‡á¹‡o*); such was my food (*evamÄhÄro*), such my experience of pleasure and pain (*evaá¹ƒsukhadukkhappaá¹­isaá¹ƒvedÄ«*), such my span of life (*evamÄyupariyanto*). Passing away thence, I re-arose there. There too I had such a name (*evaá¹ƒnÄmo*), belonged to such a clan (*evaá¹ƒgotto*), had such an appearance (*evaá¹ƒvaá¹‡á¹‡o*); such was my food (*evamÄhÄro*), such my experience of pleasure and pain (*evaá¹ƒsukhadukkhappaá¹­isaá¹ƒvedÄ«*), such my span of life (*evamÄyupariyanto*). Passing away thence, I re-arose here.â€™ Thus he recollects his numerous past lives in their modes and their details (*sÄkÄraá¹ƒ sauddesaá¹ƒ anekavihitaá¹ƒ pubbenivÄsaá¹ƒ anussarati*). â€œHe speaks thus: â€˜The self (*attÄ*) and the world (*loko*) are eternal (*sassato*), barren (*vaÃ±jho*), steadfast as a mountain peak (*kÅ«á¹­aá¹­á¹­ho*), standing firm like a pillar. And though these beings roam and wander, pass away and re-arise, yet the self and the world remain the same just like eternity itself (*sassatisamaá¹ƒ*) . What is the reason for that (*taá¹ƒ kissa hetu*)? Because I abide in ardour (*ÄtappamanvÄya*). Or someone might say: â€˜King MahÄvijita is making a great sacrifice, but he is not of pure lineage, of pure maternal and paternal descent seven generations back, unassailable and impeccable in respect of birth, and yet the honored king makes such a great sacrifice.â€™ But such words would not be in accordance with the truth. Indeed, the king's chaplain, the *brÄhmaá¹‡a*, is well-born on both sides, of pure maternal and paternal descent seven generations back, unassailable and impeccable in respect of birth. Thus the King may know this, may the honored king perform the sacrifice, may the honored king be prepared, may the honored king rejoice, and may the honored king calm his inner heart. "Someone might say: â€˜King MahÄvijita is making a great sacrifice. And his chaplain, the *brÄhmaá¹‡a*, is not a student, nor a reciter of mantras, nor one who has reached the end of the three Vedas, with their Nighaá¹‡á¸u, Keá¹­ubha, complete phonology, histories as fifth, skilled in grammar, with no doubts about materialism and the marks of a great manâ€¦peâ€¦ and his chaplain, the *brÄhmaá¹‡a*, is not virtuous, old in virtue, endowed with the virtue of the eldersâ€¦peâ€¦ and his chaplain, the *brÄhmaá¹‡a*, is not wise, clever, intelligent, able to grasp things quickly, and yet the honored king makes such a great sacrifice.â€™ But such words would not be in accordance with the truth. Indeed, the king's chaplain, the *brÄhmaá¹‡a*, is wise, clever, intelligent, able to grasp things quickly. Thus the King may know this, may the honored king perform the sacrifice, may the honored king be prepared, may the honored king rejoice, and may the honored king calm his inner heart. By these sixteen reasons, O *brÄhmaá¹‡a*, the chaplain, the *brÄhmaá¹‡a*, showed, persuaded, aroused, and gladdened the heart of King MahÄvijita, who was performing the great sacrifice.
32. padhÄnamanvÄya anuyogamanvÄya appamÄdamanvÄya sammÄmanasikÄramanvÄya tathÄrÅ«paá¹ƒ cetosamÄdhiá¹ƒ phusÄmi, yathÄsamÄhite citte anekavihitaá¹ƒ pubbenivÄsaá¹ƒ anussarÄmi seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ ekampi jÄtiá¹ƒ dvepi jÄtiyo tissopi jÄtiyo catassopi jÄtiyo paÃ±capi jÄtiyo dasapi jÄtiyo vÄ«sampi jÄtiyo tiá¹ƒsampi jÄtiyo cattÄlÄ«sampi jÄtiyo paÃ±Ã±Äsampi jÄtiyo jÄtisatampi jÄtisahassampi jÄtisatasahassampi anekÄnipi jÄtisatÄni anekÄnipi jÄtisahassÄni anekÄnipi jÄtisatasahassÄni â€“ amutrÄsiá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒnÄmo evaá¹ƒgotto evaá¹ƒvaá¹‡á¹‡o evamÄhÄro evaá¹ƒsukhadukkhappaá¹­isaá¹ƒvedÄ« evamÄyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapÄdiá¹ƒ, tatrÄpÄsiá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒnÄmo evaá¹ƒgotto evaá¹ƒvaá¹‡á¹‡o evamÄhÄro evaá¹ƒsukhadukkhappaá¹­isaá¹ƒvedÄ« evamÄyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhÅ«papannoti. iti sÄkÄraá¹ƒ sauddesaá¹ƒ anekavihitaá¹ƒ pubbenivÄsaá¹ƒ anussarÄmi. iminÄmahaá¹ƒ etaá¹ƒ jÄnÄmi "yathÄ sassato attÄ ca loko ca vaÃ±jho kÅ«á¹­aá¹­á¹­ho esikaá¹­á¹­hÄyiá¹­á¹­hito, te ca sattÄ sandhÄvanti saá¹ƒsaranti cavanti upapajjanti, atthitveva sassatisama"nti. idaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, paá¹­hamaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ, yaá¹ƒ Ägamma yaá¹ƒ Ärabbha eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä sassatavÄdÄ sassataá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti. 32. "dutiye ca bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä kimÄgamma kimÄrabbha sassatavÄdÄ sassataá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti? idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaá¹‡o vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡o vÄ ÄtappamanvÄya padhÄnamanvÄya anuyogamanvÄya appamÄdamanvÄya sammÄmanasikÄramanvÄya tathÄrÅ«paá¹ƒ cetosamÄdhiá¹ƒ phusati, yathÄsamÄhite citte anekavihitaá¹ƒ pubbenivÄsaá¹ƒ anussarati. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ ekampi saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­avivaá¹­á¹­aá¹ƒ dvepi saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­avivaá¹­á¹­Äni tÄ«á¹‡ipi saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­avivaá¹­á¹­Äni cattÄripi saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­avivaá¹­á¹­Äni paÃ±capi saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­avivaá¹­á¹­Äni dasapi saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­avivaá¹­á¹­Äni â€“ â€˜amutrÄsiá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒnÄmo evaá¹ƒgotto evaá¹ƒvaá¹‡á¹‡o evamÄhÄro evaá¹ƒsukhadukkhappaá¹­isaá¹ƒvedÄ« evamÄyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapÄdiá¹ƒ, tatrÄpÄsiá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒnÄmo evaá¹ƒgotto evaá¹ƒvaá¹‡á¹‡o evamÄhÄro evaá¹ƒsukhadukkhappaá¹­isaá¹ƒvedÄ« evamÄyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhÅ«papannoâ€™ti. iti sÄkÄraá¹ƒ sauddesaá¹ƒ anekavihitaá¹ƒ pubbenivÄsaá¹ƒ anussarati.
"And what, monks (*bhonto*), is the basis and reliance on which other ascetics (*samaá¹‡a*) and Brahmins (*brÄhmaá¹‡a*) proclaim the eternity (*sassata*) of the self (*attÄ*) and the world (*loka*)? Here, monks (*bhikkhave*), some ascetics (*samaá¹‡a*) or Brahmins (*brÄhmaá¹‡a*), through ardour, endeavour, application, diligence, and right reflection, attain to such a degree of mental concentration (*ceto-samÄdhi*) that with their mind thus concentrated, they recollect their numerous past lives (*pÅ«rbbe-nivÄsa*). That is to say, one aeon of world-contraction and expansion (*saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­a-vivaá¹­á¹­a*), two such periods, three, four, five, ten periods of contraction and expansion (*saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­a-vivaá¹­á¹­a*)â€¦â€ â€œThere my name was so-and-so, my clan was so-and-so, my appearance was so-and-so, such was my food, such my experience of pleasure and pain, such was my life-term. Having passed away from there, I arose there. There my name was so-and-so, my clan was so-and-so, my appearance was so-and-so, such was my food, such my experience of pleasure and pain, such was my life-term. Having passed away from there, I arose here.â€ Thus he remembers various past births (*pÅ«rbbe-nivÄsa*), their conditions and details.
33. "so evamÄha â€“ â€˜sassato attÄ ca loko ca vaÃ±jho kÅ«á¹­aá¹­á¹­ho esikaá¹­á¹­hÄyiá¹­á¹­hito, te ca sattÄ sandhÄvanti saá¹ƒsaranti cavanti upapajjanti, atthitveva sassatisamaá¹ƒ. taá¹ƒ kissa hetu? ahaÃ±hi ÄtappamanvÄya padhÄnamanvÄya anuyogamanvÄya appamÄdamanvÄya sammÄmanasikÄramanvÄya tathÄrÅ«paá¹ƒ cetosamÄdhiá¹ƒ phusÄmi yathÄsamÄhite citte anekavihitaá¹ƒ pubbenivÄsaá¹ƒ anussarÄmi. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ ekampi saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­avivaá¹­á¹­aá¹ƒ dvepi saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­avivaá¹­á¹­Äni tÄ«á¹‡ipi saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­avivaá¹­á¹­Äni cattÄripi saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­avivaá¹­á¹­Äni paÃ±capi saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­avivaá¹­á¹­Äni dasapi saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­avivaá¹­á¹­Äni. amutrÄsiá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒnÄmo evaá¹ƒgotto evaá¹ƒvaá¹‡á¹‡o evamÄhÄro evaá¹ƒsukhadukkhappaá¹­isaá¹ƒvedÄ« evamÄyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapÄdiá¹ƒ, tatrÄpÄsiá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒnÄmo evaá¹ƒgotto evaá¹ƒvaá¹‡á¹‡o evamÄhÄro evaá¹ƒsukhadukkhappaá¹­isaá¹ƒvedÄ« evamÄyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhÅ«papannoti. iti sÄkÄraá¹ƒ sauddesaá¹ƒ anekavihitaá¹ƒ pubbenivÄsaá¹ƒ anussarÄmi. iminÄmahaá¹ƒ etaá¹ƒ jÄnÄmi "yathÄ sassato attÄ ca loko ca vaÃ±jho kÅ«á¹­aá¹­á¹­ho esikaá¹­á¹­hÄyiá¹­á¹­hito, te ca sattÄ sandhÄvanti saá¹ƒsaranti cavanti upapajjanti, atthitveva sassatisama"nti. idaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, dutiyaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ, yaá¹ƒ Ägamma yaá¹ƒ Ärabbha eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä sassatavÄdÄ sassataá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti. 33. "tatiye ca bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä kimÄgamma kimÄrabbha sassatavÄdÄ sassataá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti? idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaá¹‡o vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡o vÄ ÄtappamanvÄya padhÄnamanvÄya anuyogamanvÄya appamÄdamanvÄya sammÄmanasikÄramanvÄya tathÄrÅ«paá¹ƒ cetosamÄdhiá¹ƒ phusati, yathÄsamÄhite citte anekavihitaá¹ƒ pubbenivÄsaá¹ƒ anussarati. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ dasapi saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­avivaá¹­á¹­Äni vÄ«sampi saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­avivaá¹­á¹­Äni tiá¹ƒsampi saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­avivaá¹­á¹­Äni cattÄlÄ«sampi saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­avivaá¹­á¹­Äni â€“ â€˜amutrÄsiá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒnÄmo evaá¹ƒgotto evaá¹ƒvaá¹‡á¹‡o evamÄhÄro evaá¹ƒsukhadukkhappaá¹­isaá¹ƒvedÄ« evamÄyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapÄdiá¹ƒ, tatrÄpÄsiá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒnÄmo evaá¹ƒgotto evaá¹ƒvaá¹‡á¹‡o evamÄhÄro evaá¹ƒsukhadukkhappaá¹­isaá¹ƒvedÄ« evamÄyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhÅ«papannoâ€™ti. iti sÄkÄraá¹ƒ sauddesaá¹ƒ anekavihitaá¹ƒ pubbenivÄsaá¹ƒ anussarati.
â€œAnd in the third case, venerable monks (*bhonto bhikkhave*), what is the basis for the ascetics and Brahmins who are eternalists (*sassatavÄdÄ*) to proclaim the self (*Ätman*) and the world as eternal? Here, monks (*bhikkhave*), a certain ascetic (*samaá¹‡o*) or Brahmin, by means of ardour (*Ätappa*), endeavor (*padhÄna*), application (*anuyoga*), diligence (*appamÄda*), and right reflection (*sammÄmanasikÄra*), attains to such a degree of mental concentration (*cetosamÄdhi*) that with his mind thus concentrated, he recollects his numerous past lives (*pubbenivÄsa*). That is to say, ten periods of contraction and expansion of the world, twenty periods of contraction and expansion of the world, thirty periods of contraction and expansion of the world, forty periods of contraction and expansion of the world â€“ â€˜There I was of such a name, such a clan, such an appearance; such was my food, such my experience of pleasure and pain, such my life span. Passing away from there, I arose there. There too I was of such a name, such a clan, such an appearance; such was my food, such my experience of pleasure and pain, such my life span. Passing away from there, I was reborn here.â€™ In this way he recollects his numerous past lives (*pubbenivÄsa*) in their modes and their details.
34. "so evamÄha â€“ â€˜sassato attÄ ca loko ca vaÃ±jho kÅ«á¹­aá¹­á¹­ho esikaá¹­á¹­hÄyiá¹­á¹­hito, te ca sattÄ sandhÄvanti saá¹ƒsaranti cavanti upapajjanti, atthitveva sassatisamaá¹ƒ. taá¹ƒ kissa hetu? ahaÃ±hi ÄtappamanvÄya padhÄnamanvÄya anuyogamanvÄya appamÄdamanvÄya sammÄmanasikÄramanvÄya tathÄrÅ«paá¹ƒ cetosamÄdhiá¹ƒ phusÄmi, yathÄsamÄhite citte anekavihitaá¹ƒ pubbenivÄsaá¹ƒ anussarÄmi. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ dasapi saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­avivaá¹­á¹­Äni vÄ«sampi saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­avivaá¹­á¹­Äni tiá¹ƒsampi saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­avivaá¹­á¹­Äni cattÄlÄ«sampi saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­avivaá¹­á¹­Äni â€“ â€˜amutrÄsiá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒnÄmo evaá¹ƒgotto evaá¹ƒvaá¹‡á¹‡o evamÄhÄro evaá¹ƒsukhadukkhappaá¹­isaá¹ƒvedÄ« evamÄyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapÄdiá¹ƒ, tatrÄpÄsiá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒnÄmo evaá¹ƒgotto evaá¹ƒvaá¹‡á¹‡o evamÄhÄro evaá¹ƒsukhadukkhappaá¹­isaá¹ƒvedÄ« evamÄyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhÅ«papannoti. iti sÄkÄraá¹ƒ sauddesaá¹ƒ anekavihitaá¹ƒ pubbenivÄsaá¹ƒ anussarÄmi. iminÄmahaá¹ƒ etaá¹ƒ jÄnÄmi "yathÄ sassato attÄ ca loko ca vaÃ±jho kÅ«á¹­aá¹­á¹­ho esikaá¹­á¹­hÄyiá¹­á¹­hito, te ca sattÄ sandhÄvanti saá¹ƒsaranti cavanti upapajjanti, atthitveva sassatisama"nti. idaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, tatiyaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ, yaá¹ƒ Ägamma yaá¹ƒ Ärabbha eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä sassatavÄdÄ sassataá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti. 34. "catutthe ca bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä kimÄgamma kimÄrabbha sassatavÄdÄ sassataá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti? idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaá¹‡o vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡o vÄ takkÄ« hoti vÄ«maá¹ƒsÄ«, so takkapariyÄhataá¹ƒ vÄ«maá¹ƒsÄnucaritaá¹ƒ sayaá¹ƒ paá¹­ibhÄnaá¹ƒ evamÄha â€“ â€˜sassato attÄ ca loko ca vaÃ±jho kÅ«á¹­aá¹­á¹­ho esikaá¹­á¹­hÄyiá¹­á¹­hito, te ca sattÄ sandhÄvanti saá¹ƒsaranti cavanti upapajjanti, atthitveva sassatisamaâ€™nti. idaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, catutthaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ, yaá¹ƒ Ägamma yaá¹ƒ Ärabbha eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä sassatavÄdÄ sassataá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti. 35. "imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä sassatavÄdÄ sassataá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti catÅ«hi vatthÅ«hi. ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡Ä vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä vÄ sassatavÄdÄ sassataá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti, sabbe te imeheva catÅ«hi vatthÅ«hi, etesaá¹ƒ vÄ aÃ±Ã±atarena, natthi ito bahiddhÄ.
â€œIn the fourth case, owing to what, with reference to what, are some honourable ascetics and Brahmins (*samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä*) proclaim the eternity of the self (*attÄ*) and the world (*loka*)? Here, monks (*bhikkhave*), some recluse (*samaá¹‡o*) or Brahmin (*brÄhmaá¹‡o*) is a rationalist (*takkÄ«*), an investigator (*vÄ«maá¹ƒsÄ«*). He declares his viewâ€”hammered out by reason, deduced from his investigations, following his own flight of thoughtâ€”thus: â€œThe self (*attÄ*) and the world (*loka*) are eternal, barren, steadfast as a mountain peak (*kÅ«á¹­aá¹­á¹­ho*), standing firm like a pillar (*esikaá¹­á¹­hÄyiá¹­á¹­hito*). And though these beings roam and wander (*sandhÄvanti saá¹ƒsaranti*), pass away (*cavanti*) and re-arise (*upapajjanti*), yet the self and the world remain the same just like eternity itself. This, monks (*bhikkhave*), is the fourth case, owing to which, with reference to which, some ascetics and Brahmins (*samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä*) proclaim the eternity of the self (*attÄ*) and the world (*loka*).

"so evamÄha â€“ â€˜sassato attÄ ca loko ca vaÃ±jho kÅ«á¹­aá¹­á¹­ho esikaá¹­á¹­hÄyiá¹­á¹­hito, te ca sattÄ sandhÄvanti saá¹ƒsaranti cavanti upapajjanti, atthitveva sassatisamaá¹ƒ. taá¹ƒ kissa hetu? ahaÃ±hi ÄtappamanvÄya padhÄnamanvÄya anuyogamanvÄya appamÄdamanvÄya sammÄmanasikÄramanvÄya tathÄrÅ«paá¹ƒ cetosamÄdhiá¹ƒ phusÄmi, yathÄsamÄhite citte anekavihitaá¹ƒ pubbenivÄsaá¹ƒ anussarÄmi. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ dasapi saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­avivaá¹­á¹­Äni vÄ«sampi saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­avivaá¹­á¹­Äni tiá¹ƒsampi saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­avivaá¹­á¹­Äni cattÄlÄ«sampi saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­avivaá¹­á¹­Äni â€“ â€˜amutrÄsiá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒnÄmo evaá¹ƒgotto evaá¹ƒvaá¹‡á¹‡o evamÄhÄro evaá¹ƒsukhadukkhappaá¹­isaá¹ƒvedÄ« evamÄyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapÄdiá¹ƒ, tatrÄpÄsiá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒnÄmo evaá¹ƒgotto evaá¹ƒvaá¹‡á¹‡o evamÄhÄro evaá¹ƒsukhadukkhappaá¹­isaá¹ƒvedÄ« evamÄyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhÅ«papannoti. iti sÄkÄraá¹ƒ sauddesaá¹ƒ anekavihitaá¹ƒ pubbenivÄsaá¹ƒ anussarÄmi. iminÄmahaá¹ƒ etaá¹ƒ jÄnÄmi "yathÄ sassato attÄ ca loko ca vaÃ±jho kÅ«á¹­aá¹­á¹­ho esikaá¹­á¹­hÄyiá¹­á¹­hito, te ca sattÄ sandhÄvanti saá¹ƒsaranti cavanti upapajjanti, atthitveva sassatisama"nti. idaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, tatiyaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ, yaá¹ƒ Ägamma yaá¹ƒ Ärabbha eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä sassatavÄdÄ sassataá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti. 34. "catutthe ca bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä kimÄgamma kimÄrabbha sassatavÄdÄ sassataá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti? idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaá¹‡o vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡o vÄ takkÄ« hoti vÄ«maá¹ƒsÄ«, so takkapariyÄhataá¹ƒ vÄ«maá¹ƒsÄnucaritaá¹ƒ sayaá¹ƒ paá¹­ibhÄnaá¹ƒ evamÄha â€“ â€˜sassato attÄ ca loko ca vaÃ±jho kÅ«á¹­aá¹­á¹­ho esikaá¹­á¹­hÄyiá¹­á¹­hito, te ca sattÄ sandhÄvanti saá¹ƒsaranti cavanti upapajjanti, atthitveva sassatisamaâ€™nti. idaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, catutthaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ, yaá¹ƒ Ägamma yaá¹ƒ Ärabbha eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä sassatavÄdÄ sassataá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti. 35. "imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä sassatavÄdÄ sassataá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti catÅ«hi vatthÅ«hi. ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡Ä vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä vÄ sassatavÄdÄ sassataá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti, sabbe te imeheva catÅ«hi vatthÅ«hi, etesaá¹ƒ vÄ aÃ±Ã±atarena, natthi ito bahiddhÄ.
â€œIt is on these four grounds, monks (*bhikkhave*), that those ascetics and Brahmins (*samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä*) who are eternalists proclaim the self (*attÄ*) and the world (*loka*) to be eternal. Whatever recluses (*samaá¹‡Ä*) and brahmins (*brÄhmaá¹‡Ä*) there may be who proclaim the self (*attÄ*) and the world (*loka*) to be eternal, all of them do so on these four grounds or on a certain one of them. Outside of these there is none.
36. 36. "tayidaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, tathÄgato pajÄnÄti â€“ â€˜ime diá¹­á¹­hiá¹­á¹­hÄnÄ evaá¹ƒgahitÄ evaá¹ƒparÄmaá¹­á¹­hÄ evaá¹ƒgatikÄ bhavanti evaá¹ƒabhisamparÄyÄâ€™ti, taÃ±ca tathÄgato pajÄnÄti, tato ca uttaritaraá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, taÃ±ca pajÄnanaá¹ƒ [pajÄnaá¹ƒ (?) dÄ«. ni. 3.36 pÄá¸·iaá¹­á¹­hakathÄ passitabbaá¹ƒ] na parÄmasati, aparÄmasato cassa paccattaÃ±Ã±eva nibbuti viditÄ. vedanÄnaá¹ƒ samudayaÃ±ca atthaá¹…gamaÃ±ca assÄdaÃ±ca ÄdÄ«navaÃ±ca nissaraá¹‡aÃ±ca yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ viditvÄ anupÄdÄvimutto, bhikkhave, tathÄgato. 37. "ime kho te, bhikkhave, dhammÄ gambhÄ«rÄ duddasÄ duranubodhÄ santÄ paá¹‡Ä«tÄ atakkÄvacarÄ nipuá¹‡Ä paá¹‡á¸itavedanÄ«yÄ, ye tathÄgato sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ pavedeti, yehi tathÄgatassa yathÄbhuccaá¹ƒ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ sammÄ vadamÄnÄ vadeyyuá¹ƒ. paá¹­hamabhÄá¹‡avÄro. ekaccasassatavÄdo 38. "santi, bhikkhave, eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä ekaccasassatikÄ ekaccaasassatikÄ ekaccaá¹ƒ sassataá¹ƒ ekaccaá¹ƒ asassataá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti catÅ«hi vatthÅ«hi. te ca bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä kimÄgamma kimÄrabbha ekaccasassatikÄ ekaccaasassatikÄ ekaccaá¹ƒ sassataá¹ƒ ekaccaá¹ƒ asassataá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti catÅ«hi vatthÅ«hi. 39. "hoti kho so, bhikkhave, samayo, yaá¹ƒ kadÄci karahaci dÄ«ghassa addhuno accayena ayaá¹ƒ loko saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­ati. saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­amÄne loke yebhuyyena sattÄ Äbhassarasaá¹ƒvattanikÄ honti. te tattha honti manomayÄ pÄ«tibhakkhÄ sayaá¹ƒpabhÄ antalikkhacarÄ subhaá¹­á¹­hÄyino, ciraá¹ƒ dÄ«ghamaddhÄnaá¹ƒ tiá¹­á¹­hanti. 40. "hoti kho so, bhikkhave, samayo, yaá¹ƒ kadÄci karahaci dÄ«ghassa addhuno accayena ayaá¹ƒ loko vivaá¹­á¹­ati. vivaá¹­á¹­amÄne loke suÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ brahmavimÄnaá¹ƒ pÄtubhavati. atha kho aÃ±Ã±ataro satto ÄyukkhayÄ vÄ puÃ±Ã±akkhayÄ vÄ ÄbhassarakÄyÄ cavitvÄ suÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ brahmavimÄnaá¹ƒ upapajjati.
â€œThis, monks (*bhikkhave*), the TathÄgata understands: â€˜These standpoints, thus assumed and thus misapprehended, lead to such a future destination, to such a state in the world beyond.â€™ He understands as well what transcends this, yet even that understanding he does not misapprehend. And because he is free from misapprehension, he has realized within himself the state of perfect peace (*nibbuti*). Having understood as they really are the origin (*samudayaÃ±ca*) and the passing away (*atthaá¹…gamaÃ±ca*) of feelings (*vedanÄnaá¹ƒ*), their satisfaction (*assÄdaÃ±ca*), their unsatisfactoriness (*ÄdÄ«navaÃ±ca*), and the escape (*nissaraá¹‡aÃ±ca*) from them, the TathÄgata, monks (*bhikkhave*), is emancipated through non-clinging (*anupÄdÄvimutto*).
37. 36. "tayidaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, tathÄgato pajÄnÄti â€“ â€˜ime diá¹­á¹­hiá¹­á¹­hÄnÄ evaá¹ƒgahitÄ evaá¹ƒparÄmaá¹­á¹­hÄ evaá¹ƒgatikÄ bhavanti evaá¹ƒabhisamparÄyÄâ€™ti, taÃ±ca tathÄgato pajÄnÄti, tato ca uttaritaraá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, taÃ±ca pajÄnanaá¹ƒ [pajÄnaá¹ƒ (?) dÄ«. ni. 3.36 pÄá¸·iaá¹­á¹­hakathÄ passitabbaá¹ƒ] na parÄmasati, aparÄmasato cassa paccattaÃ±Ã±eva nibbuti viditÄ. vedanÄnaá¹ƒ samudayaÃ±ca atthaá¹…gamaÃ±ca assÄdaÃ±ca ÄdÄ«navaÃ±ca nissaraá¹‡aÃ±ca yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ viditvÄ anupÄdÄvimutto, bhikkhave, tathÄgato. 37. â€œThese are those dhammas, monks (*bhikkhave*), that are deep, difficult to see, difficult to understand, peaceful and sublime, beyond the sphere of reasoning, subtle, comprehensible only to the wise, which the TathÄgata, having realized for himself with direct knowledge, propounds to others; and it is concerning these that those who would rightly praise the TathÄgata in accordance with reality would speak. The first recitation section . Partial-eternalism
38. 36. "tayidaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, tathÄgato pajÄnÄti â€“ â€˜ime diá¹­á¹­hiá¹­á¹­hÄnÄ evaá¹ƒgahitÄ evaá¹ƒparÄmaá¹­á¹­hÄ evaá¹ƒgatikÄ bhavanti evaá¹ƒabhisamparÄyÄâ€™ti, taÃ±ca tathÄgato pajÄnÄti, tato ca uttaritaraá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, taÃ±ca pajÄnanaá¹ƒ [pajÄnaá¹ƒ (?) dÄ«. ni. 3.36 pÄá¸·iaá¹­á¹­hakathÄ passitabbaá¹ƒ] na parÄmasati, aparÄmasato cassa paccattaÃ±Ã±eva nibbuti viditÄ. vedanÄnaá¹ƒ samudayaÃ±ca atthaá¹…gamaÃ±ca assÄdaÃ±ca ÄdÄ«navaÃ±ca nissaraá¹‡aÃ±ca yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ viditvÄ anupÄdÄvimutto, bhikkhave, tathÄgato. 37. "ime kho te, bhikkhave, dhammÄ gambhÄ«rÄ duddasÄ duranubodhÄ santÄ paá¹‡Ä«tÄ atakkÄvacarÄ nipuá¹‡Ä paá¹‡á¸itavedanÄ«yÄ, ye tathÄgato sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ pavedeti, yehi tathÄgatassa yathÄbhuccaá¹ƒ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ sammÄ vadamÄnÄ vadeyyuá¹ƒ. paá¹­hamabhÄá¹‡avÄro. ekaccasassatavÄdo 38. "santi, bhikkhave, eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä ekaccasassatikÄ ekaccaasassatikÄ ekaccaá¹ƒ sassataá¹ƒ ekaccaá¹ƒ asassataá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti catÅ«hi vatthÅ«hi. te ca bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä kimÄgamma kimÄrabbha ekaccasassatikÄ ekaccaasassatikÄ ekaccaá¹ƒ sassataá¹ƒ ekaccaá¹ƒ asassataá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti catÅ«hi vatthÅ«hi. 39. "hoti kho so, bhikkhave, samayo, yaá¹ƒ kadÄci karahaci dÄ«ghassa addhuno accayena ayaá¹ƒ loko saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­ati. saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­amÄne loke yebhuyyena sattÄ Äbhassarasaá¹ƒvattanikÄ honti. te tattha honti manomayÄ pÄ«tibhakkhÄ sayaá¹ƒpabhÄ antalikkhacarÄ subhaá¹­á¹­hÄyino, ciraá¹ƒ dÄ«ghamaddhÄnaá¹ƒ tiá¹­á¹­hanti. 40. "hoti kho so, bhikkhave, samayo, yaá¹ƒ kadÄci karahaci dÄ«ghassa addhuno accayena ayaá¹ƒ loko vivaá¹­á¹­ati. vivaá¹­á¹­amÄne loke suÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ brahmavimÄnaá¹ƒ pÄtubhavati. atha kho aÃ±Ã±ataro satto ÄyukkhayÄ vÄ puÃ±Ã±akkhayÄ vÄ ÄbhassarakÄyÄ cavitvÄ suÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ brahmavimÄnaá¹ƒ upapajjati.
â€œThere are, monks (*bhikkhave*), some ascetics and Brahmins (*samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä*) who are eternalists in regard to some things and non-eternalists in regard to other things, and who on four grounds proclaim the self (*attÄ*) and the world (*loka*) to be partly eternal and partly non-eternal. And owing to what, with reference to what, are those honourable ascetics and Brahmins (*samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä*) who are eternalists in regard to some things and non-eternalists in regard to other things proclaim the self (*attÄ*) and the world (*loka*) to be partly eternal and partly non-eternal on four grounds?
39. 36. "tayidaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, tathÄgato pajÄnÄti â€“ â€˜ime diá¹­á¹­hiá¹­á¹­hÄnÄ evaá¹ƒgahitÄ evaá¹ƒparÄmaá¹­á¹­hÄ evaá¹ƒgatikÄ bhavanti evaá¹ƒabhisamparÄyÄâ€™ti, taÃ±ca tathÄgato pajÄnÄti, tato ca uttaritaraá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, taÃ±ca pajÄnanaá¹ƒ [pajÄnaá¹ƒ (?) dÄ«. ni. 3.36 pÄá¸·iaá¹­á¹­hakathÄ passitabbaá¹ƒ] na parÄmasati, aparÄmasato cassa paccattaÃ±Ã±eva nibbuti viditÄ. vedanÄnaá¹ƒ samudayaÃ±ca atthaá¹…gamaÃ±ca assÄdaÃ±ca ÄdÄ«navaÃ±ca nissaraá¹‡aÃ±ca yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ viditvÄ anupÄdÄvimutto, bhikkhave, tathÄgato. 37.
