"idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaá¹‡o vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡o vÄ â€˜idaá¹ƒ kusalaâ€™nti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ nappajÄnÄti, â€˜idaá¹ƒ akusalaâ€™nti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ nappajÄnÄti. tassa evaá¹ƒ hoti â€“ â€˜ahaá¹ƒ kho "idaá¹ƒ kusala"nti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ nappajÄnÄmi, "idaá¹ƒ akusala"nti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ nappajÄnÄmi. ahaÃ±ce kho pana
â€œThese are those *dharmas*, mendicants, that are deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful and sublime, beyond the sphere of reasoning, subtle, comprehensible only to the wise, which the *TathÄgata*, having realized for himself with direct knowledge, propounds to others; and it is concerning these that those who would rightly praise the *TathÄgata* in accordance with reality would speak. Eel-Wriggling
61. antavÄ, na panÄnantoâ€™ti. idaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, catutthaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ, yaá¹ƒ Ägamma yaá¹ƒ Ärabbha eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä antÄnantikÄ antÄnantaá¹ƒ lokassa paÃ±Ã±apenti. 58. "imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä antÄnantikÄ antÄnantaá¹ƒ lokassa paÃ±Ã±apenti catÅ«hi vatthÅ«hi. ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡Ä vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä vÄ antÄnantikÄ antÄnantaá¹ƒ lokassa paÃ±Ã±apenti, sabbe te imeheva catÅ«hi vatthÅ«hi, etesaá¹ƒ vÄ aÃ±Ã±atarena, natthi ito bahiddhÄ. 59. "tayidaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, tathÄgato pajÄnÄti â€“ â€˜ime diá¹­á¹­hiá¹­á¹­hÄnÄ evaá¹ƒgahitÄ evaá¹ƒparÄmaá¹­á¹­hÄ evaá¹ƒgatikÄ bhavanti evaá¹ƒabhisamparÄyÄâ€™ti. taÃ±ca tathÄgato pajÄnÄti, tato ca uttaritaraá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, taÃ±ca pajÄnanaá¹ƒ na parÄmasati, aparÄmasato cassa paccattaÃ±Ã±eva nibbuti viditÄ. vedanÄnaá¹ƒ samudayaÃ±ca atthaá¹…gamaÃ±ca assÄdaÃ±ca ÄdÄ«navaÃ±ca nissaraá¹‡aÃ±ca yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ viditvÄ anupÄdÄvimutto, bhikkhave, tathÄgato. 60. "ime kho te, bhikkhave, dhammÄ gambhÄ«rÄ duddasÄ duranubodhÄ santÄ paá¹‡Ä«tÄ atakkÄvacarÄ nipuá¹‡Ä paá¹‡á¸itavedanÄ«yÄ, ye tathÄgato sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ pavedeti, yehi tathÄgatassa yathÄbhuccaá¹ƒ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ sammÄ vadamÄnÄ vadeyyuá¹ƒ. amarÄvikkhepavÄdo 61. "santi, bhikkhave, eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä amarÄvikkhepikÄ, tattha tattha paÃ±haá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­hÄ samÄnÄ vÄcÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ Äpajjanti amarÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ catÅ«hi vatthÅ«hi. te ca bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä kimÄgamma kimÄrabbha amarÄvikkhepikÄ tattha tattha paÃ±haá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­hÄ samÄnÄ vÄcÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ Äpajjanti amarÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ catÅ«hi vatthÅ«hi? 62. "idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaá¹‡o vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡o vÄ â€˜idaá¹ƒ kusalaâ€™nti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ nappajÄnÄti, â€˜idaá¹ƒ akusalaâ€™nti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ nappajÄnÄti. tassa evaá¹ƒ hoti â€“ â€˜ahaá¹ƒ kho "idaá¹ƒ kusala"nti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ nappajÄnÄmi, "idaá¹ƒ akusala"nti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ nappajÄnÄmi. ahaÃ±ce kho pana
â€œThere are, mendicants, some ascetics and Brahmins who are Eel-Wrigglers. When asked about this or that matter, they resort to evasive statements, and they wriggle like eels on four grounds. And owing to what, with reference to what, do these honorable ascetics and Brahmins wriggle like eels, and when asked about this or that matter, resort to evasive statements, and wriggle like eels on four grounds?
62. antavÄ, na panÄnantoâ€™ti. idaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, catutthaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ, yaá¹ƒ Ägamma yaá¹ƒ Ärabbha eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä antÄnantikÄ antÄnantaá¹ƒ lokassa paÃ±Ã±apenti. 58. "imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä antÄnantikÄ antÄnantaá¹ƒ lokassa paÃ±Ã±apenti catÅ«hi vatthÅ«hi. ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡Ä vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä vÄ antÄnantikÄ antÄnantaá¹ƒ lokassa paÃ±Ã±apenti, sabbe te imeheva catÅ«hi vatthÅ«hi, etesaá¹ƒ vÄ aÃ±Ã±atarena, natthi ito bahiddhÄ. 59. "tayidaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, tathÄgato pajÄnÄti â€“ â€˜ime diá¹­á¹­hiá¹­á¹­hÄnÄ evaá¹ƒgahitÄ evaá¹ƒparÄmaá¹­á¹­hÄ evaá¹ƒgatikÄ bhavanti evaá¹ƒabhisamparÄyÄâ€™ti. taÃ±ca tathÄgato pajÄnÄti, tato ca uttaritaraá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, taÃ±ca pajÄnanaá¹ƒ na parÄmasati, aparÄmasato cassa paccattaÃ±Ã±eva nibbuti viditÄ. vedanÄnaá¹ƒ samudayaÃ±ca atthaá¹…gamaÃ±ca assÄdaÃ±ca ÄdÄ«navaÃ±ca nissaraá¹‡aÃ±ca yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ viditvÄ anupÄdÄvimutto, bhikkhave, tathÄgato. 60. "ime kho te, bhikkhave, dhammÄ gambhÄ«rÄ duddasÄ duranubodhÄ santÄ paá¹‡Ä«tÄ atakkÄvacarÄ nipuá¹‡Ä paá¹‡á¸itavedanÄ«yÄ, ye tathÄgato sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ pavedeti, yehi tathÄgatassa yathÄbhuccaá¹ƒ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ sammÄ vadamÄnÄ vadeyyuá¹ƒ. amarÄvikkhepavÄdo 61. "santi, bhikkhave, eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä amarÄvikkhepikÄ, tattha tattha paÃ±haá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­hÄ samÄnÄ vÄcÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ Äpajjanti amarÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ catÅ«hi vatthÅ«hi. te ca bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä kimÄgamma kimÄrabbha amarÄvikkhepikÄ tattha tattha paÃ±haá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­hÄ samÄnÄ vÄcÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ Äpajjanti amarÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ catÅ«hi vatthÅ«hi? 62. "idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaá¹‡o vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡o vÄ â€˜idaá¹ƒ kusalaâ€™nti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ nappajÄnÄti, â€˜idaá¹ƒ akusalaâ€™nti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ nappajÄnÄti. tassa evaá¹ƒ hoti â€“ â€˜ahaá¹ƒ kho "idaá¹ƒ kusala"nti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ nappajÄnÄmi, "idaá¹ƒ akusala"nti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ nappajÄnÄmi. ahaÃ±ce kho pana
â€œHere, mendicants, a certain ascetic or Brahmin doesnâ€™t truly know what is skillful and what is unskillful. They think: â€˜I donâ€™t truly know what is skillful and what is unskillful. If I Not knowing what is truly wholesome (*kusala*), and not knowing what is truly unwholesome (*akuÅ›ala*), I might declare, 'This is wholesome,' or 'This is unwholesome,' and that would be a lie for me. If my declaration should be false, that would distress me. And if I were distressed, that would be an obstacle for me. Therefore, out of fear and loathing of making a false statement, he does not declare anything to be wholesome or unwholesome. But when he is questioned about this or that point, he resorts to evasive statements and to endless equivocation: "I do not take it thus, nor do I take it in that way, nor do I take it in some other way. I do not say that it is not, nor do I say that it is neither this nor that." This, monks, is the first instance where, based on what they have come to and what they have undertaken, some ascetics and Brahmins, being eel-wrigglers, when questioned about this or that point, resort to evasive statements and to endless equivocation.
63. "idaá¹ƒ kusala"nti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ appajÄnanto, "idaá¹ƒ akusala"nti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ appajÄnanto, â€˜idaá¹ƒ kusalaâ€™nti vÄ byÄkareyyaá¹ƒ, â€˜idaá¹ƒ akusalaâ€™nti vÄ byÄkareyyaá¹ƒ, taá¹ƒ mamassa musÄ. yaá¹ƒ mamassa musÄ, so mamassa vighÄto. yo mamassa vighÄto so mamassa antarÄyoâ€™ti. iti so musÄvÄdabhayÄ musÄvÄdaparijegucchÄ nevidaá¹ƒ kusalanti byÄkaroti, na panidaá¹ƒ akusalanti byÄkaroti, tattha tattha paÃ±haá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­ho samÄno vÄcÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ Äpajjati amarÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜evantipi me no, tathÄtipi me no, aÃ±Ã±athÄtipi me no, notipi me no, no notipi me noâ€™ti. idaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, paá¹­hamaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ, yaá¹ƒ Ägamma yaá¹ƒ Ärabbha eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä amarÄvikkhepikÄ tattha tattha paÃ±haá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­hÄ samÄnÄ vÄcÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ Äpajjanti amarÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ. 63. "dutiye ca bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä kimÄgamma kimÄrabbha amarÄvikkhepikÄ tattha tattha paÃ±haá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­hÄ samÄnÄ vÄcÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ Äpajjanti amarÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ? idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaá¹‡o vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡o vÄ â€˜idaá¹ƒ kusalaâ€™nti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ nappajÄnÄti, â€˜idaá¹ƒ akusalaâ€™nti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ nappajÄnÄti. tassa evaá¹ƒ hoti â€“ â€˜ahaá¹ƒ kho "idaá¹ƒ kusala"nti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ nappajÄnÄmi, "idaá¹ƒ akusala"nti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ nappajÄnÄmi. ahaÃ±ce kho pana "idaá¹ƒ kusala"nti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ appajÄnanto, "idaá¹ƒ akusala"nti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ appajÄnanto, "idaá¹ƒ kusala"nti vÄ byÄkareyyaá¹ƒ, "idaá¹ƒ akusalaâ€™nti vÄ byÄkareyyaá¹ƒ, tattha me assa chando vÄ rÄgo vÄ doso vÄ paá¹­igho vÄ. yattha [yo (?)] me assa chando vÄ rÄgo vÄ doso vÄ paá¹­igho vÄ, taá¹ƒ mamassa upÄdÄnaá¹ƒ. yaá¹ƒ mamassa upÄdÄnaá¹ƒ, so mamassa vighÄto. yo mamassa vighÄto, so mamassa antarÄyoâ€™ti. iti so upÄdÄnabhayÄ upÄdÄnaparijegucchÄ nevidaá¹ƒ kusalanti byÄkaroti, na panidaá¹ƒ akusalanti byÄkaroti, tattha tattha paÃ±haá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­ho samÄno vÄcÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ Äpajjati amarÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜evantipi me no, tathÄtipi me no, aÃ±Ã±athÄtipi me no, notipi me no, no notipi me noâ€™ti. idaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, dutiyaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ, yaá¹ƒ Ägamma yaá¹ƒ Ärabbha eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä
"And again, venerable monks, based on what have those ascetics and Brahmins become eel-wrigglers, and when questioned about this or that point, resort to evasive statements and to endless equivocation? Here, monks, some ascetic or Brahmin does not truly understand what is wholesome (*kusala*), and does not truly understand what is unwholesome (*akuÅ›ala*). He thinks: 'I do not truly know what is wholesome, and I do not truly know what is unwholesome.' If, without understanding, I were to declare something to be wholesome or unwholesome, desire or lust, hatred or aversion might arise in me. If desire, lust, hatred, or aversion should arise in me, that would be clinging (*upÄdÄna*) on my part. If I felt attachment, that would distress me. And if I were distressed, that would be an obstacle for me.â€ Therefore, out of fear and loathing of clinging (*upÄdÄna*), he does not declare anything to be wholesome or unwholesome. But when he is questioned about this or that point, he resorts to evasive statements and to endless equivocation: 'I do not take it thus, nor do I take it in that way, nor do I take it in some other way. I do not say that it is not, nor do I say that it is neither this nor that.' This, monks, is the second instance where, based on what they have come to and what they have undertaken, some ascetics and Brahmins Endless equivocators, when questioned about this or that point, resort to evasive statements and to endless equivocation.
64. amarÄvikkhepikÄ tattha tattha paÃ±haá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­hÄ samÄnÄ vÄcÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ Äpajjanti amarÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ. 64. "tatiye ca bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä kimÄgamma kimÄrabbha amarÄvikkhepikÄ tattha tattha paÃ±haá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­hÄ samÄnÄ vÄcÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ Äpajjanti amarÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ? idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaá¹‡o vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡o vÄ â€˜idaá¹ƒ kusalaâ€™nti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ nappajÄnÄti, â€˜idaá¹ƒ akusalaâ€™nti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ nappajÄnÄti. tassa evaá¹ƒ hoti â€“ â€˜ahaá¹ƒ kho "idaá¹ƒ kusala"nti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ nappajÄnÄmi, "idaá¹ƒ akusalaâ€™nti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ nappajÄnÄmi. ahaÃ±ce kho pana "idaá¹ƒ kusala"nti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ appajÄnanto "idaá¹ƒ akusala"nti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ appajÄnanto "idaá¹ƒ kusala"nti vÄ byÄkareyyaá¹ƒ, "idaá¹ƒ akusala"nti vÄ byÄkareyyaá¹ƒ. santi hi kho samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä paá¹‡á¸itÄ nipuá¹‡Ä kataparappavÄdÄ vÄlavedhirÅ«pÄ, te bhindantÄ [vobhindantÄ (sÄ«. pÄ«.)] maÃ±Ã±e caranti paÃ±Ã±Ägatena diá¹­á¹­higatÄni, te maá¹ƒ tattha samanuyuÃ±jeyyuá¹ƒ samanugÄheyyuá¹ƒ samanubhÄseyyuá¹ƒ. ye maá¹ƒ tattha samanuyuÃ±jeyyuá¹ƒ samanugÄheyyuá¹ƒ samanubhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, tesÄhaá¹ƒ na sampÄyeyyaá¹ƒ. yesÄhaá¹ƒ na sampÄyeyyaá¹ƒ, so mamassa vighÄto. yo mamassa vighÄto, so mamassa antarÄyoâ€™ti. iti so anuyogabhayÄ anuyogaparijegucchÄ nevidaá¹ƒ kusalanti byÄkaroti, na panidaá¹ƒ akusalanti byÄkaroti, tattha tattha paÃ±haá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­ho samÄno vÄcÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ Äpajjati amarÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜evantipi me no, tathÄtipi me no, aÃ±Ã±athÄtipi me no, notipi me no, no notipi me noâ€™ti. idaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, tatiyaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ, yaá¹ƒ Ägamma yaá¹ƒ Ärabbha eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä amarÄvikkhepikÄ tattha tattha paÃ±haá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­hÄ samÄnÄ vÄcÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ Äpajjanti amarÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ. 65. "catutthe ca bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä kimÄgamma kimÄrabbha amarÄvikkhepikÄ tattha tattha paÃ±haá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­hÄ samÄnÄ vÄcÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ Äpajjanti amarÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ? idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaá¹‡o vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡o vÄ mando hoti momÅ«ho. so mandattÄ momÅ«hattÄ tattha tattha paÃ±haá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­ho samÄno vÄcÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ Äpajjati amarÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜atthi paro lokoâ€™ti iti ce maá¹ƒ pucchasi, â€˜atthi paro lokoâ€™ti iti ce
"In the third case, owing to what, with reference to what, are some honourable recluses and brahmins endless equivocators, resorting to evasive statements and to endless equivocation? Here, bhikkhus, some recluse or brahmin does not understand as it really is what is *kusala* (wholesome), and does not understand as it really is what is *akusala* (unwholesome). He thinks: â€˜I do not in truth know whether this is *kusala* (good) or whether this is *akusala* (bad). If, without understanding, I were to declare something to be *kusala* (wholesome) or *akusala* (unwholesome). Now, there are recluses and brahmins who are wise, clever, experienced in controversy, who wander about demolishing the views of others with their wisdom. If, without understanding, I were to declare something to be wholesome or unwholesome, they might cross-examine me about my views, press me for reasons and refute my statements. If they should do so, I might not be able to reply. Not being able to reply would distress me. And that distress would be an obstacle for me.â€™ Therefore, out of fear and loathing of being cross-examined, he does not declare anything to be *kusala* (wholesome) or *akusala* (unwholesome). But, when questioned about this or that point, he resorts to evasive statements and to endless equivocation: â€˜I do not take it thus, nor do I take it in that way, nor do I take it in some other way. I do not say that it is not, nor do I say that it is neither this nor that.â€™ This, bhikkhus, is the third case, owing to which, with reference to which, some recluses and brahmins are endless equivocators, resorting to evasive statements and to endless equivocation.
65. amarÄvikkhepikÄ tattha tattha paÃ±haá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­hÄ samÄnÄ vÄcÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ Äpajjanti amarÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ. 64. "tatiye ca bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä kimÄgamma kimÄrabbha amarÄvikkhepikÄ tattha tattha paÃ±haá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­hÄ samÄnÄ vÄcÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ Äpajjanti amarÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ? idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaá¹‡o vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡o vÄ â€˜idaá¹ƒ kusalaâ€™nti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ nappajÄnÄti, â€˜idaá¹ƒ akusalaâ€™nti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ nappajÄnÄti. tassa evaá¹ƒ hoti â€“ â€˜ahaá¹ƒ kho "idaá¹ƒ kusala"nti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ nappajÄnÄmi, "idaá¹ƒ akusalaâ€™nti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ nappajÄnÄmi. ahaÃ±ce kho pana "idaá¹ƒ kusala"nti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ appajÄnanto "idaá¹ƒ akusala"nti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ appajÄnanto "idaá¹ƒ kusala"nti vÄ byÄkareyyaá¹ƒ, "idaá¹ƒ akusala"nti vÄ byÄkareyyaá¹ƒ. santi hi kho samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä paá¹‡á¸itÄ nipuá¹‡Ä kataparappavÄdÄ vÄlavedhirÅ«pÄ, te bhindantÄ [vobhindantÄ (sÄ«. pÄ«.)] maÃ±Ã±e caranti paÃ±Ã±Ägatena diá¹­á¹­higatÄni, te maá¹ƒ tattha samanuyuÃ±jeyyuá¹ƒ samanugÄheyyuá¹ƒ samanubhÄseyyuá¹ƒ. ye maá¹ƒ tattha samanuyuÃ±jeyyuá¹ƒ samanugÄheyyuá¹ƒ samanubhÄseyyuá¹ƒ, tesÄhaá¹ƒ na sampÄyeyyaá¹ƒ. yesÄhaá¹ƒ na sampÄyeyyaá¹ƒ, so mamassa vighÄto. yo mamassa vighÄto, so mamassa antarÄyoâ€™ti. iti so anuyogabhayÄ anuyogaparijegucchÄ nevidaá¹ƒ kusalanti byÄkaroti, na panidaá¹ƒ akusalanti byÄkaroti, tattha tattha paÃ±haá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­ho samÄno vÄcÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ Äpajjati amarÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜evantipi me no, tathÄtipi me no, aÃ±Ã±athÄtipi me no, notipi me no, no notipi me noâ€™ti. idaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, tatiyaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ, yaá¹ƒ Ägamma yaá¹ƒ Ärabbha eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä amarÄvikkhepikÄ tattha tattha paÃ±haá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­hÄ samÄnÄ vÄcÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ Äpajjanti amarÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ. 65. "catutthe ca bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä kimÄgamma kimÄrabbha amarÄvikkhepikÄ tattha tattha paÃ±haá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­hÄ samÄnÄ vÄcÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ Äpajjanti amarÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ? idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaá¹‡o vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡o vÄ mando hoti momÅ«ho. so mandattÄ momÅ«hattÄ tattha tattha paÃ±haá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­ho samÄno vÄcÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ Äpajjati amarÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜atthi paro lokoâ€™ti iti ce maá¹ƒ pucchasi, â€˜atthi paro lokoâ€™ti iti ce
"In the fourth case, owing to what, with reference to what, are some honourable recluses and brahmins endless equivocators, resorting to evasive statements and to endless equivocation? Here, bhikkhus, some recluse or brahmin is dull and stupid. Due to his dullness and stupidity, when he is questioned about this or that point, he resorts to evasive statements and to endless equivocation: â€˜If you ask me whether there is a world beyondâ€”if I thought there is another world, I would declare that there is. But I do not take it thus, nor do I take it in that way, nor do I take it in some other way. I do not say that it is not, nor do I say that is neither this nor that.â€™ If I were to think so, I would declare, "There is another world." But I donâ€™t say so. And I donâ€™t say otherwise. And I donâ€™t say it is not, and I donâ€™t not say it is not.â€™ â€˜There is no other worldâ€¦and so onâ€¦ â€˜There both is and is not another worldâ€¦and so onâ€¦ â€˜There neither is nor is not another worldâ€¦and so onâ€¦ â€˜There are beings who are spontaneously bornâ€¦and so onâ€¦ â€˜There are no beings who are spontaneously bornâ€¦and so onâ€¦ â€˜There both are and are not beings who are spontaneously bornâ€¦and so onâ€¦ â€˜There neither are nor are not beings who are spontaneously bornâ€¦and so onâ€¦ â€˜There is fruit and result of good and bad actions ( *sukata-dukkata-karma*)â€¦and so onâ€¦ â€˜There is no fruit and result of good and bad actionsâ€¦and so onâ€¦ â€˜There both is and is not fruit and result of good and bad actionsâ€¦and so onâ€¦ â€˜There neither is nor is not fruit and result of good and bad actionsâ€¦and so onâ€¦ â€˜The *TathÄgata* exists after deathâ€¦and so onâ€¦ â€˜The *TathÄgata* does not exist after deathâ€¦and so onâ€¦ â€˜The *TathÄgata* both exists and does not exist after deathâ€¦and so onâ€¦ â€˜The *TathÄgata* neither exists nor does not exist after deathâ€”if you ask me this, and if I were to think that the *TathÄgata* neither exists nor does not exist after death, then I would declare this to you. But I donâ€™t say so. And I donâ€™t say otherwise. And I donâ€™t say it is not, and I donâ€™t not say it is not.â€™ This, *bhikkhus*, is the fourth case, on which those ascetics and *BrÄhmaá¹‡as* who are eel-wrigglers, when questioned on this or that point, resort to evasive statements and endless equivocation.
66. me assa, â€˜atthi paro lokoâ€™ti iti te naá¹ƒ byÄkareyyaá¹ƒ, â€˜evantipi me no, tathÄtipi me no, aÃ±Ã±athÄtipi me no, notipi me no, no notipi me noâ€™ti. â€˜natthi paro lokoâ€¦peâ€¦ â€˜atthi ca natthi ca paro lokoâ€¦peâ€¦ â€˜nevatthi na natthi paro lokoâ€¦peâ€¦ â€˜atthi sattÄ opapÄtikÄ â€¦peâ€¦ â€˜natthi sattÄ opapÄtikÄâ€¦peâ€¦ â€˜atthi ca natthi ca sattÄ opapÄtikÄâ€¦peâ€¦ â€˜nevatthi na natthi sattÄ opapÄtikÄâ€¦peâ€¦ â€˜atthi sukatadukkaá¹­Änaá¹ƒ [sukaá¹­adukkaá¹­Änaá¹ƒ (sÄ«. syÄ. kaá¹ƒ.)] kammÄnaá¹ƒ phalaá¹ƒ vipÄkoâ€¦peâ€¦ â€˜natthi sukatadukkaá¹­Änaá¹ƒ kammÄnaá¹ƒ phalaá¹ƒ vipÄkoâ€¦peâ€¦ â€˜atthi ca natthi ca sukatadukkaá¹­Änaá¹ƒ kammÄnaá¹ƒ phalaá¹ƒ vipÄkoâ€¦peâ€¦ â€˜nevatthi na natthi sukatadukkaá¹­Änaá¹ƒ kammÄnaá¹ƒ phalaá¹ƒ vipÄkoâ€¦peâ€¦ â€˜hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äâ€¦peâ€¦ â€˜na hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äâ€¦peâ€¦ â€˜hoti ca na ca hoti [na hoti ca (sÄ«. ka.)] tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äâ€¦peâ€¦ â€˜neva hoti na na hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äti iti ce maá¹ƒ pucchasi, â€˜neva hoti na na hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äâ€™ti iti ce me assa, â€˜neva hoti na na hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äâ€™ti iti te naá¹ƒ byÄkareyyaá¹ƒ, â€˜evantipi me no, tathÄtipi me no, aÃ±Ã±athÄtipi me no, notipi me no, no notipi me noâ€™ti. idaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, catutthaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ, yaá¹ƒ Ägamma yaá¹ƒ Ärabbha eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä amarÄvikkhepikÄ tattha tattha paÃ±haá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­hÄ samÄnÄ vÄcÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ Äpajjanti amarÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ. 66. "imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä amarÄvikkhepikÄ tattha tattha paÃ±haá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­hÄ samÄnÄ vÄcÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ Äpajjanti amarÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ catÅ«hi vatthÅ«hi. ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡Ä vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä vÄ amarÄvikkhepikÄ tattha tattha paÃ±haá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­hÄ samÄnÄ vÄcÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ Äpajjanti amarÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ, sabbe te imeheva catÅ«hi vatthÅ«hi, etesaá¹ƒ vÄ aÃ±Ã±atarena, natthi ito bahiddhÄâ€¦peâ€¦ yehi tathÄgatassa yathÄbhuccaá¹ƒ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ sammÄ vadamÄnÄ vadeyyuá¹ƒ. adhiccasamuppannavÄdo 67. "santi, bhikkhave, eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä adhiccasamuppannikÄ adhiccasamuppannaá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti dvÄ«hi vatthÅ«hi. te ca bhonto
"It is on these four grounds, *bhikkhus*, that those ascetics and *BrÄhmaá¹‡as* who are endless equivocators resort to evasive statements and endless equivocation when questioned about this or that point. Whatever ascetics or *BrÄhmaá¹‡as* there may be, *bhikkhus*, who are eel-wrigglers, when questioned on this or that point, resort to evasive statements and endless equivocation, all of them do so on these four grounds, or on one of these. There is none outside of theseâ€¦and so onâ€¦ it is concerning these that those who would rightly praise the *TathÄgata* in accordance with reality would speak. The doctrine of fortuitous origination
67. me assa, â€˜atthi paro lokoâ€™ti iti te naá¹ƒ byÄkareyyaá¹ƒ, â€˜evantipi me no, tathÄtipi me no, aÃ±Ã±athÄtipi me no, notipi me no, no notipi me noâ€™ti. â€˜natthi paro lokoâ€¦peâ€¦ â€˜atthi ca natthi ca paro lokoâ€¦peâ€¦ â€˜nevatthi na natthi paro lokoâ€¦peâ€¦ â€˜atthi sattÄ opapÄtikÄ â€¦peâ€¦ â€˜natthi sattÄ opapÄtikÄâ€¦peâ€¦ â€˜atthi ca natthi ca sattÄ opapÄtikÄâ€¦peâ€¦ â€˜nevatthi na natthi sattÄ opapÄtikÄâ€¦peâ€¦ â€˜atthi sukatadukkaá¹­Änaá¹ƒ [sukaá¹­adukkaá¹­Änaá¹ƒ (sÄ«. syÄ. kaá¹ƒ.)] kammÄnaá¹ƒ phalaá¹ƒ vipÄkoâ€¦peâ€¦ â€˜natthi sukatadukkaá¹­Änaá¹ƒ kammÄnaá¹ƒ phalaá¹ƒ vipÄkoâ€¦peâ€¦ â€˜atthi ca natthi ca sukatadukkaá¹­Änaá¹ƒ kammÄnaá¹ƒ phalaá¹ƒ vipÄkoâ€¦peâ€¦ â€˜nevatthi na natthi sukatadukkaá¹­Änaá¹ƒ kammÄnaá¹ƒ phalaá¹ƒ vipÄkoâ€¦peâ€¦ â€˜hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äâ€¦peâ€¦ â€˜na hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äâ€¦peâ€¦ â€˜hoti ca na ca hoti [na hoti ca (sÄ«. ka.)] tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äâ€¦peâ€¦ â€˜neva hoti na na hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äti iti ce maá¹ƒ pucchasi, â€˜neva hoti na na hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äâ€™ti iti ce me assa, â€˜neva hoti na na hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äâ€™ti iti te naá¹ƒ byÄkareyyaá¹ƒ, â€˜evantipi me no, tathÄtipi me no, aÃ±Ã±athÄtipi me no, notipi me no, no notipi me noâ€™ti. idaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, catutthaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ, yaá¹ƒ Ägamma yaá¹ƒ Ärabbha eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä amarÄvikkhepikÄ tattha tattha paÃ±haá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­hÄ samÄnÄ vÄcÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ Äpajjanti amarÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ. 66. "imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä amarÄvikkhepikÄ tattha tattha paÃ±haá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­hÄ samÄnÄ vÄcÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ Äpajjanti amarÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ catÅ«hi vatthÅ«hi. ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡Ä vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä vÄ amarÄvikkhepikÄ tattha tattha paÃ±haá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­hÄ samÄnÄ vÄcÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ Äpajjanti amarÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ, sabbe te imeheva catÅ«hi vatthÅ«hi, etesaá¹ƒ vÄ aÃ±Ã±atarena, natthi ito bahiddhÄâ€¦peâ€¦ yehi tathÄgatassa yathÄbhuccaá¹ƒ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ sammÄ vadamÄnÄ vadeyyuá¹ƒ. adhiccasamuppannavÄdo 67. "santi, bhikkhave, eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä adhiccasamuppannikÄ adhiccasamuppannaá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti dvÄ«hi vatthÅ«hi. te ca bhonto
"There are, *bhikkhus*, some ascetics and *BrÄhmaá¹‡as* who are fortuitous originationists, and who on two grounds proclaim the self (*Ätman*) and the world to originate fortuitously. And those venerable ones... These two followed closely behind the Exalted One and the company of *bhikkhus*. This was our discussion, venerable sir, that was interrupted when the Blessed One arrived.
68. samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä kimÄgamma kimÄrabbha adhiccasamuppannikÄ adhiccasamuppannaá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti dvÄ«hi vatthÅ«hi? 68. "santi, bhikkhave, asaÃ±Ã±asattÄ nÄma devÄ. saÃ±Ã±uppÄdÄ ca pana te devÄ tamhÄ kÄyÄ cavanti. á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ kho panetaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, vijjati, yaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±ataro satto tamhÄ kÄyÄ cavitvÄ itthattaá¹ƒ Ägacchati. itthattaá¹ƒ Ägato samÄno agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajati. agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajito samÄno ÄtappamanvÄya padhÄnamanvÄya anuyogamanvÄya appamÄdamanvÄya sammÄmanasikÄramanvÄya tathÄrÅ«paá¹ƒ cetosamÄdhiá¹ƒ phusati, yathÄsamÄhite citte saÃ±Ã±uppÄdaá¹ƒ anussarati, tato paraá¹ƒ nÄnussarati. so evamÄha â€“ â€˜adhiccasamuppanno attÄ ca loko ca. taá¹ƒ kissa hetu? ahaÃ±hi pubbe nÄhosiá¹ƒ, somhi etarahi ahutvÄ santatÄya pariá¹‡atoâ€™ti. idaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, paá¹­hamaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ, yaá¹ƒ Ägamma yaá¹ƒ Ärabbha eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä adhiccasamuppannikÄ adhiccasamuppannaá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti. 69. "dutiye ca bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä kimÄgamma kimÄrabbha adhiccasamuppannikÄ adhiccasamuppannaá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti? idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaá¹‡o vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡o vÄ takkÄ« hoti vÄ«maá¹ƒsÄ«. so takkapariyÄhataá¹ƒ vÄ«maá¹ƒsÄnucaritaá¹ƒ sayaá¹ƒpaá¹­ibhÄnaá¹ƒ evamÄha â€“ â€˜adhiccasamuppanno attÄ ca loko cÄâ€™ti. idaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, dutiyaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ, yaá¹ƒ Ägamma yaá¹ƒ Ärabbha eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä adhiccasamuppannikÄ adhiccasamuppannaá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti. 70. "imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä adhiccasamuppannikÄ adhiccasamuppannaá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti dvÄ«hi vatthÅ«hi. ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡Ä vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä vÄ adhiccasamuppannikÄ adhiccasamuppannaá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti, sabbe te imeheva dvÄ«hi vatthÅ«hi, etesaá¹ƒ vÄ aÃ±Ã±atarena, natthi ito bahiddhÄâ€¦peâ€¦ yehi tathÄgatassa yathÄbhuccaá¹ƒ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ sammÄ vadamÄnÄ vadeyyuá¹ƒ. 71. "imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä pubbantakappikÄ pubbantÄnudiá¹­á¹­hino pubbantaá¹ƒ Ärabbha anekavihitÄni adhimuttipadÄni abhivadanti
â€œThere are, monks, certain gods called â€˜non-percipient beings.â€™ As soon as a perception arises in them, those *devas* fall from that realm. And it may happen that a being falls from that realm and arises in this world. Having arisen in this world, he goes forth from the household life into homelessness. Having gone forth, he by means of effort, exertion, application, earnestness and right attention attains to such a degree of mental concentration that he thereby recalls the arising of perception, but recalls none before that. He speaks thus: â€˜The self and the world originate fortuitously.â€™ What is the reason for that? Before this I did not exist. Now from not-being I have been brought to being.â€ This, monks, is the first reason, owing to which, with reference to which, some recluses and brahmins, being fortuitous originationists, proclaim the self and the world to originate fortuitously.
69. samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä kimÄgamma kimÄrabbha adhiccasamuppannikÄ adhiccasamuppannaá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti dvÄ«hi vatthÅ«hi? 68. "santi, bhikkhave, asaÃ±Ã±asattÄ nÄma devÄ. saÃ±Ã±uppÄdÄ ca pana te devÄ tamhÄ kÄyÄ cavanti. á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ kho panetaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, vijjati, yaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±ataro satto tamhÄ kÄyÄ cavitvÄ itthattaá¹ƒ Ägacchati. itthattaá¹ƒ Ägato samÄno agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajati. agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajito samÄno ÄtappamanvÄya padhÄnamanvÄya anuyogamanvÄya appamÄdamanvÄya sammÄmanasikÄramanvÄya tathÄrÅ«paá¹ƒ cetosamÄdhiá¹ƒ phusati, yathÄsamÄhite citte saÃ±Ã±uppÄdaá¹ƒ anussarati, tato paraá¹ƒ nÄnussarati. so evamÄha â€“ â€˜adhiccasamuppanno attÄ ca loko ca. taá¹ƒ kissa hetu? ahaÃ±hi pubbe nÄhosiá¹ƒ, somhi etarahi ahutvÄ santatÄya pariá¹‡atoâ€™ti. idaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, paá¹­hamaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ, yaá¹ƒ Ägamma yaá¹ƒ Ärabbha eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä adhiccasamuppannikÄ adhiccasamuppannaá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti. 69. "dutiye ca bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä kimÄgamma kimÄrabbha adhiccasamuppannikÄ adhiccasamuppannaá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti? idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaá¹‡o vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡o vÄ takkÄ« hoti vÄ«maá¹ƒsÄ«. so takkapariyÄhataá¹ƒ vÄ«maá¹ƒsÄnucaritaá¹ƒ sayaá¹ƒpaá¹­ibhÄnaá¹ƒ evamÄha â€“ â€˜adhiccasamuppanno attÄ ca loko cÄâ€™ti. idaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, dutiyaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ, yaá¹ƒ Ägamma yaá¹ƒ Ärabbha eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä adhiccasamuppannikÄ adhiccasamuppannaá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti. 70. "imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä adhiccasamuppannikÄ adhiccasamuppannaá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti dvÄ«hi vatthÅ«hi. ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡Ä vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä vÄ adhiccasamuppannikÄ adhiccasamuppannaá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti, sabbe te imeheva dvÄ«hi vatthÅ«hi, etesaá¹ƒ vÄ aÃ±Ã±atarena, natthi ito bahiddhÄâ€¦peâ€¦ yehi tathÄgatassa yathÄbhuccaá¹ƒ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ sammÄ vadamÄnÄ vadeyyuá¹ƒ. 71. "imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä pubbantakappikÄ pubbantÄnudiá¹­á¹­hino pubbantaá¹ƒ Ärabbha anekavihitÄni adhimuttipadÄni abhivadanti
â€œIn the second case, owing to what, with reference to what, are some honourable recluses and brahmins fortuitous originationists, proclaiming the self and the world to originate fortuitously? Here, monks, some recluse or *brÄhmin* is a rationalist, an investigator. He declares his viewâ€”hammered out by reason, deduced from his investigations, following his own flight of thoughtâ€”thus: â€˜The self and the world originate fortuitously.â€™ This, monks, is the second reason, owing to which, with reference to which, some recluses and brahmins, being fortuitous originationists, proclaim the self and the world to originate fortuitously.
70. samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä kimÄgamma kimÄrabbha adhiccasamuppannikÄ adhiccasamuppannaá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti dvÄ«hi vatthÅ«hi? 68. "santi, bhikkhave, asaÃ±Ã±asattÄ nÄma devÄ. saÃ±Ã±uppÄdÄ ca pana te devÄ tamhÄ kÄyÄ cavanti. á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ kho panetaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, vijjati, yaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±ataro satto tamhÄ kÄyÄ cavitvÄ itthattaá¹ƒ Ägacchati. itthattaá¹ƒ Ägato samÄno agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajati. agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajito samÄno ÄtappamanvÄya padhÄnamanvÄya anuyogamanvÄya appamÄdamanvÄya sammÄmanasikÄramanvÄya tathÄrÅ«paá¹ƒ cetosamÄdhiá¹ƒ phusati, yathÄsamÄhite citte saÃ±Ã±uppÄdaá¹ƒ anussarati, tato paraá¹ƒ nÄnussarati. so evamÄha â€“ â€˜adhiccasamuppanno attÄ ca loko ca. taá¹ƒ kissa hetu? ahaÃ±hi pubbe nÄhosiá¹ƒ, somhi etarahi ahutvÄ santatÄya pariá¹‡atoâ€™ti. idaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, paá¹­hamaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ, yaá¹ƒ Ägamma yaá¹ƒ Ärabbha eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä adhiccasamuppannikÄ adhiccasamuppannaá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti. 69. "dutiye ca bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä kimÄgamma kimÄrabbha adhiccasamuppannikÄ adhiccasamuppannaá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti? idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaá¹‡o vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡o vÄ takkÄ« hoti vÄ«maá¹ƒsÄ«. so takkapariyÄhataá¹ƒ vÄ«maá¹ƒsÄnucaritaá¹ƒ sayaá¹ƒpaá¹­ibhÄnaá¹ƒ evamÄha â€“ â€˜adhiccasamuppanno attÄ ca loko cÄâ€™ti. idaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, dutiyaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ, yaá¹ƒ Ägamma yaá¹ƒ Ärabbha eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä adhiccasamuppannikÄ adhiccasamuppannaá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti. 70. "imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä adhiccasamuppannikÄ adhiccasamuppannaá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti dvÄ«hi vatthÅ«hi. ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡Ä vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä vÄ adhiccasamuppannikÄ adhiccasamuppannaá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti, sabbe te imeheva dvÄ«hi vatthÅ«hi, etesaá¹ƒ vÄ aÃ±Ã±atarena, natthi ito bahiddhÄâ€¦peâ€¦ yehi tathÄgatassa yathÄbhuccaá¹ƒ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ sammÄ vadamÄnÄ vadeyyuá¹ƒ. 71. "imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä pubbantakappikÄ pubbantÄnudiá¹­á¹­hino pubbantaá¹ƒ Ärabbha anekavihitÄni adhimuttipadÄni abhivadanti
â€œIt is on these two grounds, monks, that those recluses and brahmins who are fortuitous originationists proclaim the self and the world to originate fortuitously. Whatever recluses or brahmins there may be who proclaim the self and the world to originate fortuitously, all of them do so on these two grounds or on a certain one of them. Outside of these there is noneâ€¦and it is concerning these that those who would rightly praise the *TathÄgata* in accordance with reality would speak.
71. samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä kimÄgamma kimÄrabbha adhiccasamuppannikÄ adhiccasamuppannaá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti dvÄ«hi vatthÅ«hi? 68. "santi, bhikkhave, asaÃ±Ã±asattÄ nÄma devÄ. saÃ±Ã±uppÄdÄ ca pana te devÄ tamhÄ kÄyÄ cavanti. á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ kho panetaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, vijjati, yaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±ataro satto tamhÄ kÄyÄ cavitvÄ itthattaá¹ƒ Ägacchati. itthattaá¹ƒ Ägato samÄno agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajati. agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajito samÄno ÄtappamanvÄya padhÄnamanvÄya anuyogamanvÄya appamÄdamanvÄya sammÄmanasikÄramanvÄya tathÄrÅ«paá¹ƒ cetosamÄdhiá¹ƒ phusati, yathÄsamÄhite citte saÃ±Ã±uppÄdaá¹ƒ anussarati, tato paraá¹ƒ nÄnussarati. so evamÄha â€“ â€˜adhiccasamuppanno attÄ ca loko ca. taá¹ƒ kissa hetu? ahaÃ±hi pubbe nÄhosiá¹ƒ, somhi etarahi ahutvÄ santatÄya pariá¹‡atoâ€™ti. idaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, paá¹­hamaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ, yaá¹ƒ Ägamma yaá¹ƒ Ärabbha eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä adhiccasamuppannikÄ adhiccasamuppannaá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti. 69. "dutiye ca bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä kimÄgamma kimÄrabbha adhiccasamuppannikÄ adhiccasamuppannaá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti? idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaá¹‡o vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡o vÄ takkÄ« hoti vÄ«maá¹ƒsÄ«. so takkapariyÄhataá¹ƒ vÄ«maá¹ƒsÄnucaritaá¹ƒ sayaá¹ƒpaá¹­ibhÄnaá¹ƒ evamÄha â€“ â€˜adhiccasamuppanno attÄ ca loko cÄâ€™ti. idaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, dutiyaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ, yaá¹ƒ Ägamma yaá¹ƒ Ärabbha eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä adhiccasamuppannikÄ adhiccasamuppannaá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti. 70. "imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä adhiccasamuppannikÄ adhiccasamuppannaá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti dvÄ«hi vatthÅ«hi. ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡Ä vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä vÄ adhiccasamuppannikÄ adhiccasamuppannaá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti, sabbe te imeheva dvÄ«hi vatthÅ«hi, etesaá¹ƒ vÄ aÃ±Ã±atarena, natthi ito bahiddhÄâ€¦peâ€¦ yehi tathÄgatassa yathÄbhuccaá¹ƒ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ sammÄ vadamÄnÄ vadeyyuá¹ƒ. 71. "imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä pubbantakappikÄ pubbantÄnudiá¹­á¹­hino pubbantaá¹ƒ Ärabbha anekavihitÄni adhimuttipadÄni abhivadanti
â€œIt is on these eighteen grounds, monks, that those recluses and brahmins who are speculators about the past and hold settled views about the past assert various conceptual theorems referring to the past in eighteen ways. Whatever recluses or brahmins are speculators about the past, hold settled views about the past, and assert various conceptual theorems referring to the past, all of them do so on these eighteen grounds or on a certain one of them. Outside of these there is none.
72. aá¹­á¹­hÄrasahi vatthÅ«hi. ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡Ä vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä vÄ pubbantakappikÄ pubbantÄnudiá¹­á¹­hino pubbantamÄrabbha anekavihitÄni adhimuttipadÄni abhivadanti, sabbe te imeheva aá¹­á¹­hÄrasahi vatthÅ«hi, etesaá¹ƒ vÄ aÃ±Ã±atarena, natthi ito bahiddhÄ. 72. "tayidaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, tathÄgato pajÄnÄti â€“ â€˜ime diá¹­á¹­hiá¹­á¹­hÄnÄ evaá¹ƒgahitÄ evaá¹ƒparÄmaá¹­á¹­hÄ evaá¹ƒgatikÄ bhavanti evaá¹ƒabhisamparÄyÄâ€™ti. taÃ±ca tathÄgato pajÄnÄti, tato ca uttaritaraá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, taÃ±ca pajÄnanaá¹ƒ na parÄmasati, aparÄmasato cassa paccattaÃ±Ã±eva nibbuti viditÄ. vedanÄnaá¹ƒ samudayaÃ±ca atthaá¹…gamaÃ±ca assÄdaÃ±ca ÄdÄ«navaÃ±ca nissaraá¹‡aÃ±ca yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ viditvÄ anupÄdÄvimutto, bhikkhave, tathÄgato. 73. "ime kho te, bhikkhave, dhammÄ gambhÄ«rÄ duddasÄ duranubodhÄ santÄ paá¹‡Ä«tÄ atakkÄvacarÄ nipuá¹‡Ä paá¹‡á¸itavedanÄ«yÄ, ye tathÄgato sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ pavedeti, yehi tathÄgatassa yathÄbhuccaá¹ƒ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ sammÄ vadamÄnÄ vadeyyuá¹ƒ. dutiyabhÄá¹‡avÄro. aparantakappikÄ 74. "santi, bhikkhave, eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä aparantakappikÄ aparantÄnudiá¹­á¹­hino, aparantaá¹ƒ Ärabbha anekavihitÄni adhimuttipadÄni abhivadanti catucattÄrÄ«sÄya [catucattÄlÄ«sÄya (syÄ. kaá¹ƒ.)] vatthÅ«hi. te ca bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä kimÄgamma kimÄrabbha aparantakappikÄ aparantÄnudiá¹­á¹­hino aparantaá¹ƒ Ärabbha anekavihitÄni adhimuttipadÄni abhivadanti catucattÄrÄ«sÄya vatthÅ«hi? saÃ±Ã±Ä«vÄdo 75. "santi, bhikkhave, eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä uddhamÄghÄtanikÄ saÃ±Ã±Ä«vÄdÄ uddhamÄghÄtanaá¹ƒ saÃ±Ã±iá¹ƒ attÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti soá¸·asahi vatthÅ«hi.
â€œThis, monks, the *TathÄgata* understands. And he understands: â€˜These standpoints, thus assumed and thus misapprehended, lead to such a future destination, to such a state in the world beyond.â€™ He understands as well what transcends this, yet even that understanding he does not misapprehend. And because he is free from misapprehension, he has realized within himself the state of perfect peace. Having understood as they really are the origin and the passing away of feelings, their satisfaction, their unsatisfactoriness, and the escape from them, the *TathÄgata*, monks, is emancipated through non-clinging.
73. aá¹­á¹­hÄrasahi vatthÅ«hi. ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡Ä vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä vÄ pubbantakappikÄ pubbantÄnudiá¹­á¹­hino pubbantamÄrabbha anekavihitÄni adhimuttipadÄni abhivadanti, sabbe te imeheva aá¹­á¹­hÄrasahi vatthÅ«hi, etesaá¹ƒ vÄ aÃ±Ã±atarena, natthi ito bahiddhÄ. 72. "tayidaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, tathÄgato pajÄnÄti â€“ â€˜ime diá¹­á¹­hiá¹­á¹­hÄnÄ evaá¹ƒgahitÄ evaá¹ƒparÄmaá¹­á¹­hÄ evaá¹ƒgatikÄ bhavanti evaá¹ƒabhisamparÄyÄâ€™ti. taÃ±ca tathÄgato pajÄnÄti, tato ca uttaritaraá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, taÃ±ca pajÄnanaá¹ƒ na parÄmasati, aparÄmasato cassa paccattaÃ±Ã±eva nibbuti viditÄ. vedanÄnaá¹ƒ samudayaÃ±ca atthaá¹…gamaÃ±ca assÄdaÃ±ca ÄdÄ«navaÃ±ca nissaraá¹‡aÃ±ca yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ viditvÄ anupÄdÄvimutto, bhikkhave, tathÄgato. 73. "ime kho te, bhikkhave, dhammÄ gambhÄ«rÄ duddasÄ duranubodhÄ santÄ paá¹‡Ä«tÄ atakkÄvacarÄ nipuá¹‡Ä paá¹‡á¸itavedanÄ«yÄ, ye tathÄgato sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ pavedeti, yehi tathÄgatassa yathÄbhuccaá¹ƒ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ sammÄ vadamÄnÄ vadeyyuá¹ƒ. dutiyabhÄá¹‡avÄro. aparantakappikÄ 74. "santi, bhikkhave, eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä aparantakappikÄ aparantÄnudiá¹­á¹­hino, aparantaá¹ƒ Ärabbha anekavihitÄni adhimuttipadÄni abhivadanti catucattÄrÄ«sÄya [catucattÄlÄ«sÄya (syÄ. kaá¹ƒ.)] vatthÅ«hi. te ca bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä kimÄgamma kimÄrabbha aparantakappikÄ aparantÄnudiá¹­á¹­hino aparantaá¹ƒ Ärabbha anekavihitÄni adhimuttipadÄni abhivadanti catucattÄrÄ«sÄya vatthÅ«hi? saÃ±Ã±Ä«vÄdo 75. "santi, bhikkhave, eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä uddhamÄghÄtanikÄ saÃ±Ã±Ä«vÄdÄ uddhamÄghÄtanaá¹ƒ saÃ±Ã±iá¹ƒ attÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti soá¸·asahi vatthÅ«hi.
â€œThese are those *dharmas*, monks, that are deep, difficult to see, difficult to understand, peaceful and sublime, beyond the sphere of reasoning, subtle, comprehensible only to the wise, which the *TathÄgata*, having realized for himself with direct knowledge, propounds to others; and it is concerning these that those who would rightly praise the *TathÄgata* in accordance with reality would speak. End of second recitation-section. Speculators about the future
74. aá¹­á¹­hÄrasahi vatthÅ«hi. ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡Ä vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä vÄ pubbantakappikÄ pubbantÄnudiá¹­á¹­hino pubbantamÄrabbha anekavihitÄni adhimuttipadÄni abhivadanti, sabbe te imeheva aá¹­á¹­hÄrasahi vatthÅ«hi, etesaá¹ƒ vÄ aÃ±Ã±atarena, natthi ito bahiddhÄ. 72. "tayidaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, tathÄgato pajÄnÄti â€“ â€˜ime diá¹­á¹­hiá¹­á¹­hÄnÄ evaá¹ƒgahitÄ evaá¹ƒparÄmaá¹­á¹­hÄ evaá¹ƒgatikÄ bhavanti evaá¹ƒabhisamparÄyÄâ€™ti. taÃ±ca tathÄgato pajÄnÄti, tato ca uttaritaraá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, taÃ±ca pajÄnanaá¹ƒ na parÄmasati, aparÄmasato cassa paccattaÃ±Ã±eva nibbuti viditÄ. vedanÄnaá¹ƒ samudayaÃ±ca atthaá¹…gamaÃ±ca assÄdaÃ±ca ÄdÄ«navaÃ±ca nissaraá¹‡aÃ±ca yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ viditvÄ anupÄdÄvimutto, bhikkhave, tathÄgato. 73. "ime kho te, bhikkhave, dhammÄ gambhÄ«rÄ duddasÄ duranubodhÄ santÄ paá¹‡Ä«tÄ atakkÄvacarÄ nipuá¹‡Ä paá¹‡á¸itavedanÄ«yÄ, ye tathÄgato sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ pavedeti, yehi tathÄgatassa yathÄbhuccaá¹ƒ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ sammÄ vadamÄnÄ vadeyyuá¹ƒ. dutiyabhÄá¹‡avÄro. aparantakappikÄ 74. "santi, bhikkhave, eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä aparantakappikÄ aparantÄnudiá¹­á¹­hino, aparantaá¹ƒ Ärabbha anekavihitÄni adhimuttipadÄni abhivadanti catucattÄrÄ«sÄya [catucattÄlÄ«sÄya (syÄ. kaá¹ƒ.)] vatthÅ«hi. te ca bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä kimÄgamma kimÄrabbha aparantakappikÄ aparantÄnudiá¹­á¹­hino aparantaá¹ƒ Ärabbha anekavihitÄni adhimuttipadÄni abhivadanti catucattÄrÄ«sÄya vatthÅ«hi? saÃ±Ã±Ä«vÄdo 75. "santi, bhikkhave, eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä uddhamÄghÄtanikÄ saÃ±Ã±Ä«vÄdÄ uddhamÄghÄtanaá¹ƒ saÃ±Ã±iá¹ƒ attÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti soá¸·asahi vatthÅ«hi.
â€œThere are, monks, some recluses and brahmins who are speculators about the future, who hold settled views about the future, and who on forty-four grounds assert various conceptual theorems referring to the future. On what basis, on what grounds do they do so? A Doctrine of Conscious Post-Mortem Survival

â€œThere are, monks, some ascetics and Brahmins who maintain a doctrine of percipient immortality and who on sixteen grounds proclaim the self to survive percipient after death. And those venerable ascetics and Brahmins, based on what, relying on what, do they propound the self as conscious after death, in sixteen ways?

â€œThe self is material ( *rÅ«pÄ« attÄ*), healthy, and conscious after death,â€ they proclaim. â€œThe self is immaterial ( *arÅ«pÄ« attÄ*), healthy, and conscious after death,â€ they proclaim. â€œThe self is both material and immaterial ( *rÅ«pÄ« ca arÅ«pÄ« ca attÄ*)...neither material nor immaterial ( *nevarÅ«pÄ« nÄrÅ«pÄ« attÄ*)...finite ( *antavÄ attÄ*)...infinite ( *anantavÄ attÄ*)...both finite and infinite ( *antavÄ ca anantavÄ ca attÄ*)...neither finite nor infinite ( *nevantavÄ nÄnantavÄ attÄ*)...of uniform perception ( *ekattasaÃ±Ã±Ä« attÄ*)...of diversified perception ( *nÄnattasaÃ±Ã±Ä« attÄ*)...of limited perception ( *parittasaÃ±Ã±Ä« attÄ*)...of boundless perception ( *appamÄá¹‡asaÃ±Ã±Ä« attÄ*)...exclusively happy ( *ekantasukhÄ« attÄ*)...exclusively miserable ( *ekantadukkhÄ« attÄ*). The self is both happy and miserable ( *sukhadukkhÄ« attÄ*). The self is neither happy nor miserable ( *adukkhamasukhÄ« attÄ*), healthy, and conscious after death,â€ they proclaim.

"It is on these sixteen grounds, monks, that those ascetics and Brahmins who maintain a doctrine of percipient immortality proclaim the self to survive percipient after death. Whatever ascetics or Brahmins maintain a doctrine of percipient immortality, all of them do so on these sixteen grounds or on a certain one of them. Outside of these there is none...about which those who would rightly praise the *TathÄgata* in accordance with reality would speak. The doctrine of non-percipient immortality

"â€˜rÅ«pÄ« attÄ hoti arogo paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä nevasaÃ±Ã±Ä«nÄsaÃ±Ã±Ä«â€™ti naá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti â€˜arÅ«pÄ« attÄ hotiâ€¦peâ€¦ rÅ«pÄ« ca arÅ«pÄ« ca attÄ hotiâ€¦ nevarÅ«pÄ« nÄrÅ«pÄ« attÄ hotiâ€¦ antavÄ attÄ hotiâ€¦ anantavÄ attÄ hotiâ€¦ antavÄ ca anantavÄ ca attÄ hotiâ€¦ nevantavÄ nÄnantavÄ attÄ hoti arogo paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä nevasaÃ±Ã±Ä«nÄsaÃ±Ã±Ä«â€™ti naá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti. 83. "imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä uddhamÄghÄtanikÄ nevasaÃ±Ã±Ä«nÄsaÃ±Ã±Ä«vÄdÄ uddhamÄghÄtanaá¹ƒ nevasaÃ±Ã±Ä«nÄsaÃ±Ã±iá¹ƒ attÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti aá¹­á¹­hahi vatthÅ«hi. ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡Ä vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä vÄ uddhamÄghÄtanikÄ nevasaÃ±Ã±Ä«nÄsaÃ±Ã±Ä«vÄdÄ uddhamÄghÄtanaá¹ƒ nevasaÃ±Ã±Ä«nÄsaÃ±Ã±iá¹ƒ attÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti, sabbe te imeheva aá¹­á¹­hahi vatthÅ«hiâ€¦peâ€¦ yehi tathÄgatassa yathÄbhuccaá¹ƒ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ sammÄ vadamÄnÄ vadeyyuá¹ƒ. ucchedavÄdo 84. "santi, bhikkhave, eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä ucchedavÄdÄ sato sattassa ucchedaá¹ƒ vinÄsaá¹ƒ vibhavaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti sattahi vatthÅ«hi. te ca
"It is on these eight grounds, monks, that those ascetics and Brahmins who maintain a doctrine of non-percipient immortality proclaim the self to survive non-percipient after death. Whatever ascetics or Brahmins maintain a doctrine of non-percipient immortality, all of them do so on these eight grounds or on a certain one of them. Outside of these there is none...about which those who would rightly praise the *TathÄgata* in accordance with reality would speak. The doctrine of neither-percipient-nor-non-percipient immortality
81. 80. "imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä uddhamÄghÄtanikÄ asaÃ±Ã±Ä«vÄdÄ uddhamÄghÄtanaá¹ƒ asaÃ±Ã±iá¹ƒ attÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti aá¹­á¹­hahi vatthÅ«hi. ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡Ä vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä vÄ uddhamÄghÄtanikÄ asaÃ±Ã±Ä«vÄdÄ uddhamÄghÄtanaá¹ƒ asaÃ±Ã±iá¹ƒ attÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti, sabbe te imeheva aá¹­á¹­hahi vatthÅ«hi, etesaá¹ƒ vÄ aÃ±Ã±atarena, natthi ito bahiddhÄâ€¦peâ€¦ yehi tathÄgatassa yathÄbhuccaá¹ƒ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ sammÄ vadamÄnÄ vadeyyuá¹ƒ. nevasaÃ±Ã±Ä«nÄsaÃ±Ã±Ä«vÄdo 81. "There are, monks, some ascetics and Brahmins who maintain a doctrine of neither percipient nor non-percipient immortality and who on eight grounds proclaim the self to survive neither percipient nor non-percipient after death. And those venerable ascetics and Brahmins, based on what, relying on what, do they propound the self as neither percipient nor non-percipient after death, in eight ways?

â€œThe self is material ( *rÅ«pÄ« attÄ*), healthy, and neither percipient nor non-percipient after death,â€ they proclaim. â€œThe self is immaterial ( *arÅ«pÄ« attÄ*)...both material and immaterial ( *rÅ«pÄ« ca arÅ«pÄ« ca attÄ*)...neither material nor immaterial ( *nevarÅ«pÄ« nÄrÅ«pÄ« attÄ*)...finite ( *antavÄ attÄ*)...infinite ( *anantavÄ attÄ*)...both finite and infinite ( *antavÄ ca anantavÄ ca attÄ*)...neither finite nor infinite ( *nevantavÄ nÄnantavÄ attÄ*), healthy, and neither percipient nor non-percipient after death,â€ they proclaim.

â€œHere, *bhikkhus*, a certain recluse or a *brÄhmin* asserts the following doctrine or view: â€˜When this self (*attÄ*), good sir, has material form, is composed of the four great elements (*cÄtumahÄbhÅ«tika*), and originates from father and mother; since this self, good sir, is annihilated and destroyed with the breakup of the body and does not exist after death, at this point the self is completely annihilated.â€™" In this way, some proclaim the annihilation, destruction, and extermination of an existent being.

"idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaá¹‡o vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡o vÄ evaá¹ƒvÄdÄ« hoti evaá¹ƒdiá¹­á¹­hi [evaá¹ƒdiá¹­á¹­hÄ« (ka. pÄ«.)] â€“ â€˜yato kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ rÅ«pÄ« cÄtumahÄbhÅ«tiko mÄtÄpettikasambhavo kÄyassa bhedÄ ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä, ettÄvatÄ kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ sammÄ samucchinno hotÄ«â€™ti. ittheke sato sattassa ucchedaá¹ƒ vinÄsaá¹ƒ vibhavaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti. 86. "tamaÃ±Ã±o evamÄha â€“ â€˜atthi kho, bho, eso attÄ, yaá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ vadesi, neso natthÄ«ti vadÄmi, no ca kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ ettÄvatÄ sammÄ samucchinno hoti. atthi kho, bho, aÃ±Ã±o attÄ dibbo rÅ«pÄ« kÄmÄvacaro kabaá¸·Ä«kÄrÄhÄrabhakkho. taá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ na jÄnÄsi na passasi. tamahaá¹ƒ jÄnÄmi passÄmi. so kho, bho, attÄ yato kÄyassa bhedÄ ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä, ettÄvatÄ kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ sammÄ samucchinno hotÄ«â€™ti. ittheke sato sattassa ucchedaá¹ƒ vinÄsaá¹ƒ vibhavaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti. 87. "tamaÃ±Ã±o evamÄha â€“ â€˜atthi kho, bho, eso attÄ, yaá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ vadesi, neso natthÄ«ti vadÄmi, no ca kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ ettÄvatÄ sammÄ samucchinno hoti. atthi kho, bho, aÃ±Ã±o attÄ dibbo rÅ«pÄ« manomayo sabbaá¹…gapaccaá¹…gÄ« ahÄ«nindriyo. taá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ na jÄnÄsi na passasi. tamahaá¹ƒ jÄnÄmi passÄmi. so kho, bho, attÄ yato kÄyassa bhedÄ ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä, ettÄvatÄ kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ sammÄ samucchinno hotÄ«â€™ti. ittheke sato sattassa ucchedaá¹ƒ vinÄsaá¹ƒ vibhavaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti. 88. â€œTo him another says: â€˜There is, good sir, such a self (*attÄ*) as you assert. That I do not deny. But it is not at that point that the self is completely annihilated. For there is, good sir, another selfâ€”divine, having material form, pertaining to the sense sphere, feeding on edible nutriment. That you neither know nor see. But I know it and see it. Since this self, good sir, is annihilated and destroyed with the breakup of the body and does not exist after death, at this point the self is completely annihilated.â€™" In this way, some proclaim the annihilation, destruction, and extermination of an existent being.

â€œTo him another says: â€˜There is, good sir, such a self (*attÄ*) as you assert. That I do not deny. But it is not at that point that the self is completely annihilated. For there is, good sir, another self belonging to the base of nothingness, completely surmounting the base of infinite consciousness : â€œThere is nothing.â€ That you neither know nor see. But I know it and see it. For, good sir, it is when this self is annihilated and destroyed with the breakup of the body, and does not exist after death, that the self is completely annihilated. In this way, some proclaim the annihilation ( *uccheda*), destruction (*vinÄsa*), and extermination (*vibhava*) of an existent being.
91. ettÄvatÄ sammÄ samucchinno hoti. atthi kho, bho, aÃ±Ã±o attÄ sabbaso rÅ«pasaÃ±Ã±Änaá¹ƒ samatikkamÄ paá¹­ighasaÃ±Ã±Änaá¹ƒ atthaá¹…gamÄ nÄnattasaÃ±Ã±Änaá¹ƒ amanasikÄrÄ "ananto ÄkÄso"ti ÄkÄsÄnaÃ±cÄyatanÅ«pago. taá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ na jÄnÄsi na passasi. tamahaá¹ƒ jÄnÄmi passÄmi. so kho, bho, attÄ yato kÄyassa bhedÄ ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä, ettÄvatÄ kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ sammÄ samucchinno hotÄ«â€™ti. ittheke sato sattassa ucchedaá¹ƒ vinÄsaá¹ƒ vibhavaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti. 89. "tamaÃ±Ã±o evamÄha â€“ â€˜atthi kho, bho, eso attÄ yaá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ vadesi, neso natthÄ«ti vadÄmi, no ca kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ ettÄvatÄ sammÄ samucchinno hoti. atthi kho, bho, aÃ±Ã±o attÄ sabbaso ÄkÄsÄnaÃ±cÄyatanaá¹ƒ samatikkamma "anantaá¹ƒ viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡a"nti viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aÃ±cÄyatanÅ«pago. taá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ na jÄnÄsi na passasi. tamahaá¹ƒ jÄnÄmi passÄmi. so kho, bho, attÄ yato kÄyassa bhedÄ ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä, ettÄvatÄ kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ sammÄ samucchinno hotÄ«â€™ti. ittheke sato sattassa ucchedaá¹ƒ vinÄsaá¹ƒ vibhavaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti. 90. "tamaÃ±Ã±o evamÄha â€“ â€˜atthi kho, bho, so attÄ, yaá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ vadesi, neso natthÄ«ti vadÄmi, no ca kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ ettÄvatÄ sammÄ samucchinno hoti. atthi kho, bho, aÃ±Ã±o attÄ sabbaso viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aÃ±cÄyatanaá¹ƒ samatikkamma "natthi kiÃ±cÄ«"ti ÄkiÃ±caÃ±Ã±ÄyatanÅ«pago. taá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ na jÄnÄsi na passasi. tamahaá¹ƒ jÄnÄmi passÄmi. so kho, bho, attÄ yato kÄyassa bhedÄ ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä, ettÄvatÄ kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ sammÄ samucchinno hotÄ«"ti. ittheke sato sattassa ucchedaá¹ƒ vinÄsaá¹ƒ vibhavaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti. 91. â€˜tamaÃ±Ã±o evamÄha â€“ "atthi kho, bho, eso attÄ, yaá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ vadesi, neso natthÄ«ti vadÄmi, no ca kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ ettÄvatÄ sammÄ samucchinno hoti. atthi kho, bho, aÃ±Ã±o
Another says to him: "Indeed, good sir, there is such a self (*ÄtmÄ*) as you say; I do not say it does not exist; but, good sir, the self (*ÄtmÄ*) is not completely annihilated (*sammÄ samucchinno*) at just that point." For there is, good sir, another... There is another self which, by entirely overcoming the sphere of nothingness (*ÄkiÃ±caÃ±Ã±Äyatana*) and thinking, "This is peaceful, this is sublime," has attained to the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception (*nevasaÃ±Ã±ÄnÄsaÃ±Ã±Äyatana*). You neither know it nor see it. But I know it and see it. That self, good sir, is annihilated and destroyed with the breakup of the body and does not exist after death. At this point, good sir, the self is completely annihilated. In this way, some proclaim the annihilation (*uccheda*), destruction (*vinÄsa*), and extermination (*vibhava*) of an existing being.
92. attÄ sabbaso ÄkiÃ±caÃ±Ã±Äyatanaá¹ƒ samatikkamma "santametaá¹ƒ paá¹‡Ä«tameta"nti nevasaÃ±Ã±ÄnÄsaÃ±Ã±ÄyatanÅ«pago. taá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ na jÄnÄsi na passasi. tamahaá¹ƒ jÄnÄmi passÄmi. so kho, bho, attÄ yato kÄyassa bhedÄ ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä, ettÄvatÄ kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ sammÄ samucchinno hotÄ«â€™ti. ittheke sato sattassa ucchedaá¹ƒ vinÄsaá¹ƒ vibhavaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti. 92. "imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä ucchedavÄdÄ sato sattassa ucchedaá¹ƒ vinÄsaá¹ƒ vibhavaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti sattahi vatthÅ«hi. ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡Ä vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä vÄ ucchedavÄdÄ sato sattassa ucchedaá¹ƒ vinÄsaá¹ƒ vibhavaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti, sabbe te imeheva sattahi vatthÅ«hiâ€¦peâ€¦ yehi tathÄgatassa yathÄbhuccaá¹ƒ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ sammÄ vadamÄnÄ vadeyyuá¹ƒ. diá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnavÄdo 93. "santi, bhikkhave, eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä diá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnavÄdÄ sato sattassa paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti paÃ±cahi vatthÅ«hi. te ca bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä kimÄgamma kimÄrabbha diá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnavÄdÄ sato sattassa paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti paÃ±cahi vatthÅ«hi? 94. "idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaá¹‡o vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡o vÄ evaá¹ƒvÄdÄ« hoti evaá¹ƒdiá¹­á¹­hi â€“ "yato kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ paÃ±cahi kÄmaguá¹‡ehi samappito samaá¹…gÄ«bhÅ«to paricÄreti, ettÄvatÄ kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ patto hotÄ«â€™ti. ittheke sato sattassa paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti. 95. "tamaÃ±Ã±o evamÄha â€“â€˜atthi kho, bho, eso attÄ, yaá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ vadesi, neso natthÄ«ti vadÄmi, no ca kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ ettÄvatÄ paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ patto hoti. taá¹ƒ kissa hetu? kÄmÄ hi, bho, aniccÄ dukkhÄ vipariá¹‡ÄmadhammÄ, tesaá¹ƒ vipariá¹‡ÄmaÃ±Ã±athÄbhÄvÄ uppajjanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupÄyÄsÄ. yato kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ vivicceva kÄmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaá¹ƒ savicÄraá¹ƒ vivekajaá¹ƒ pÄ«tisukhaá¹ƒ paá¹­hamaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒ upasampajja viharati, ettÄvatÄ kho, bho,
"These ascetics and Brahmins who are annihilationists (*ucchedavÄdÄ*) proclaim the annihilation (*uccheda*), destruction (*vinÄsa*), and extermination (*vibhava*) of an existing being on seven grounds (*sattahi vatthÅ«hi*)." Whatever ascetics or Brahmins proclaim the annihilation (*uccheda*), destruction (*vinÄsa*), and extermination (*vibhava*) of an existing being, all of them do so on these seven groundsâ€¦ and it is concerning these that those who would rightly praise the *TathÄgata* in accordance with reality would speak. The doctrine of *NibbÄna* here and now (*diá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnavÄdo*).
93. attÄ sabbaso ÄkiÃ±caÃ±Ã±Äyatanaá¹ƒ samatikkamma "santametaá¹ƒ paá¹‡Ä«tameta"nti nevasaÃ±Ã±ÄnÄsaÃ±Ã±ÄyatanÅ«pago. taá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ na jÄnÄsi na passasi. tamahaá¹ƒ jÄnÄmi passÄmi. so kho, bho, attÄ yato kÄyassa bhedÄ ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä, ettÄvatÄ kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ sammÄ samucchinno hotÄ«â€™ti. ittheke sato sattassa ucchedaá¹ƒ vinÄsaá¹ƒ vibhavaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti. 92. "imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä ucchedavÄdÄ sato sattassa ucchedaá¹ƒ vinÄsaá¹ƒ vibhavaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti sattahi vatthÅ«hi. ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡Ä vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä vÄ ucchedavÄdÄ sato sattassa ucchedaá¹ƒ vinÄsaá¹ƒ vibhavaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti, sabbe te imeheva sattahi vatthÅ«hiâ€¦peâ€¦ yehi tathÄgatassa yathÄbhuccaá¹ƒ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ sammÄ vadamÄnÄ vadeyyuá¹ƒ. diá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnavÄdo 93. "santi, bhikkhave, eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä diá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnavÄdÄ sato sattassa paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti paÃ±cahi vatthÅ«hi. te ca bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä kimÄgamma kimÄrabbha diá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnavÄdÄ sato sattassa paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti paÃ±cahi vatthÅ«hi? 94. "idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaá¹‡o vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡o vÄ evaá¹ƒvÄdÄ« hoti evaá¹ƒdiá¹­á¹­hi â€“ "yato kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ paÃ±cahi kÄmaguá¹‡ehi samappito samaá¹…gÄ«bhÅ«to paricÄreti, ettÄvatÄ kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ patto hotÄ«â€™ti. ittheke sato sattassa paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti. 95. "tamaÃ±Ã±o evamÄha â€“â€˜atthi kho, bho, eso attÄ, yaá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ vadesi, neso natthÄ«ti vadÄmi, no ca kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ ettÄvatÄ paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ patto hoti. taá¹ƒ kissa hetu? kÄmÄ hi, bho, aniccÄ dukkhÄ vipariá¹‡ÄmadhammÄ, tesaá¹ƒ vipariá¹‡ÄmaÃ±Ã±athÄbhÄvÄ uppajjanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupÄyÄsÄ. yato kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ vivicceva kÄmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaá¹ƒ savicÄraá¹ƒ vivekajaá¹ƒ pÄ«tisukhaá¹ƒ paá¹­hamaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒ upasampajja viharati, ettÄvatÄ kho, bho,
"There are, *bhikkhus*, some ascetics and Brahmins who are proclaimers of *NibbÄna* here and now (*diá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnavÄdÄ*) and who, on five grounds (*paÃ±cahi vatthÅ«hi*), proclaim the supreme *NibbÄna* here and now (*paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ*) for an existing being." And those venerable ascetics and Brahmins, relying on what, taking hold of what, being proclaimers of *NibbÄna* here and now (*diá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnavÄdÄ*), proclaim the supreme *NibbÄna* here and now (*paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ*) for an existing being on five grounds (*paÃ±cahi vatthÅ«hi*)?
94. attÄ sabbaso ÄkiÃ±caÃ±Ã±Äyatanaá¹ƒ samatikkamma "santametaá¹ƒ paá¹‡Ä«tameta"nti nevasaÃ±Ã±ÄnÄsaÃ±Ã±ÄyatanÅ«pago. taá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ na jÄnÄsi na passasi. tamahaá¹ƒ jÄnÄmi passÄmi. so kho, bho, attÄ yato kÄyassa bhedÄ ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä, ettÄvatÄ kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ sammÄ samucchinno hotÄ«â€™ti. ittheke sato sattassa ucchedaá¹ƒ vinÄsaá¹ƒ vibhavaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti. 92. "Here, *bhikkhus*, a certain ascetic or Brahmin asserts the following doctrine or view: â€˜When this self, good sir, furnished and supplied with the five strands of sense pleasures (*paÃ±cahi kÄmaguá¹‡ehi*), revels in themâ€”at this point the self attains supreme *NibbÄna* here and now (*paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ*)â€™." In this way, some proclaim the supreme *NibbÄna* here and now (*paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ*) for an existing being.
95. attÄ sabbaso ÄkiÃ±caÃ±Ã±Äyatanaá¹ƒ samatikkamma "santametaá¹ƒ paá¹‡Ä«tameta"nti nevasaÃ±Ã±ÄnÄsaÃ±Ã±ÄyatanÅ«pago. taá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ na jÄnÄsi na passasi. tamahaá¹ƒ jÄnÄmi passÄmi. so kho, bho, attÄ yato kÄyassa bhedÄ ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä, ettÄvatÄ kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ sammÄ samucchinno hotÄ«â€™ti. ittheke sato sattassa ucchedaá¹ƒ vinÄsaá¹ƒ vibhavaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti. 92. "imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä ucchedavÄdÄ sato sattassa ucchedaá¹ƒ vinÄsaá¹ƒ vibhavaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti sattahi vatthÅ«hi. ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡Ä vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä vÄ ucchedavÄdÄ sato sattassa ucchedaá¹ƒ vinÄsaá¹ƒ vibhavaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti, sabbe te imeheva sattahi vatthÅ«hiâ€¦peâ€¦ yehi tathÄgatassa yathÄbhuccaá¹ƒ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ sammÄ vadamÄnÄ vadeyyuá¹ƒ. diá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnavÄdo 93. "santi, bhikkhave, eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä diá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnavÄdÄ sato sattassa paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti paÃ±cahi vatthÅ«hi. te ca bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä kimÄgamma kimÄrabbha diá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnavÄdÄ sato sattassa paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti paÃ±cahi vatthÅ«hi? 94. "idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaá¹‡o vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡o vÄ evaá¹ƒvÄdÄ« hoti evaá¹ƒdiá¹­á¹­hi â€“ "yato kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ paÃ±cahi kÄmaguá¹‡ehi samappito samaá¹…gÄ«bhÅ«to paricÄreti, ettÄvatÄ kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ patto hotÄ«â€™ti. ittheke sato sattassa paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti. 95. "tamaÃ±Ã±o evamÄha â€“â€˜atthi kho, bho, eso attÄ, yaá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ vadesi, neso natthÄ«ti vadÄmi, no ca kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ ettÄvatÄ paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ patto hoti. taá¹ƒ kissa hetu? kÄmÄ hi, bho, aniccÄ dukkhÄ vipariá¹‡ÄmadhammÄ, tesaá¹ƒ vipariá¹‡ÄmaÃ±Ã±athÄbhÄvÄ uppajjanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupÄyÄsÄ. yato kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ vivicceva kÄmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaá¹ƒ savicÄraá¹ƒ vivekajaá¹ƒ pÄ«tisukhaá¹ƒ paá¹­hamaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒ upasampajja viharati, ettÄvatÄ kho, bho,
"To him, another says: â€˜There is, good sir, such a self as you assert. I do not say that it does not exist; however, it is not at that point that the self attains supreme *NibbÄna* here and now (*paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ*).â€™ What is the reason for that? Because, good sir, sense pleasures (*kÄmÄ*) are impermanent (*aniccÄ*), suffering (*dukkhÄ*), subject to change (*vipariá¹‡ÄmadhammÄ*), and through their change and transformation, there arise sorrow (*soka*), lamentation (*parideva*), pain (*dukkha*), grief (*domanassa*), and despair (*upÄyÄsÄ*). But when the self, quite secluded from sense pleasures (*kÄmehi*), secluded from unwholesome states (*akusalehi dhammehi*), enters and abides in the first *jhÄna*, which is accompanied by initial and sustained thought (*savitakkaá¹ƒ savicÄraá¹ƒ*) and contains the rapture and happiness born of seclusion (*vivekajaá¹ƒ pÄ«tisukhaá¹ƒ*)â€”at this point, good sir, This self attains the highest *NibbÄna* here and now.â€ In this way some proclaim the highest *NibbÄna* here and now for an existent being.
96. ayaá¹ƒ attÄ paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ patto hotÄ«â€™ti. ittheke sato sattassa paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti. 96. "tamaÃ±Ã±o evamÄha â€“ â€˜atthi kho, bho, eso attÄ, yaá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ vadesi, neso natthÄ«ti vadÄmi, no ca kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ ettÄvatÄ paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ patto hoti. taá¹ƒ kissa hetu? yadeva tattha vitakkitaá¹ƒ vicÄritaá¹ƒ, etenetaá¹ƒ oá¸·Ärikaá¹ƒ akkhÄyati. yato kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ vitakkavicÄrÄnaá¹ƒ vÅ«pasamÄ ajjhattaá¹ƒ sampasÄdanaá¹ƒ cetaso ekodibhÄvaá¹ƒ avitakkaá¹ƒ avicÄraá¹ƒ samÄdhijaá¹ƒ pÄ«tisukhaá¹ƒ dutiyaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒ upasampajja viharati, ettÄvatÄ kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ patto hotÄ«â€™ti. ittheke sato sattassa paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti. 97. "tamaÃ±Ã±o evamÄha â€“ â€˜atthi kho, bho, eso attÄ, yaá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ vadesi, neso natthÄ«ti vadÄmi, no ca kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ ettÄvatÄ paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ patto hoti. taá¹ƒ kissa hetu? yadeva tattha pÄ«tigataá¹ƒ cetaso uppilÄvitattaá¹ƒ, etenetaá¹ƒ oá¸·Ärikaá¹ƒ akkhÄyati. yato kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ pÄ«tiyÄ ca virÄgÄ upekkhako ca viharati, sato ca sampajÄno, sukhaÃ±ca kÄyena paá¹­isaá¹ƒvedeti, yaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ ariyÄ Äcikkhanti "upekkhako satimÄ sukhavihÄrÄ«"ti, tatiyaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒ upasampajja viharati, ettÄvatÄ kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ patto hotÄ«â€™ti. ittheke sato sattassa paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti. 98. "tamaÃ±Ã±o evamÄha â€“ â€˜atthi kho, bho, eso attÄ, yaá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ vadesi, neso natthÄ«ti vadÄmi, no ca kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ ettÄvatÄ paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ patto hoti. taá¹ƒ kissa hetu? yadeva tattha sukhamiti cetaso Äbhogo, etenetaá¹ƒ oá¸·Ärikaá¹ƒ akkhÄyati. yato kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ sukhassa ca pahÄnÄ dukkhassa ca pahÄnÄ pubbeva somanassadomanassÄnaá¹ƒ atthaá¹…gamÄ adukkhamasukhaá¹ƒ upekkhÄsatipÄrisuddhiá¹ƒ catutthaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒ upasampajja viharati, ettÄvatÄ kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ patto hotÄ«â€™ti. ittheke sato sattassa paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti.
â€œTo him another says: â€˜There is, good sir, such a self as you assert. That I do not deny. But it is not at that point that the self attains the highest *NibbÄna* here and now. What is the reason for that? Because that *jhÄna* contains initial thought (*vitakka*) and sustained thought (*vicÄra*); therefore it is declared to be gross (*oá¸·Ärika*). But when the self, by the subsiding of initial and sustained thought, enters and abides in the second *jhÄna*, with inner tranquility and oneness of mind, which is free from initial and sustained thought and is born of concentration (*samÄdhija*), and accompanied by delight (*pÄ«ti*) and joy (*sukha*), that is when the self realizes the highest *NibbÄna* here and now.â€ In this way some proclaim the highest *NibbÄna* here and now for an existent being.
97. ayaá¹ƒ attÄ paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ patto hotÄ«â€™ti. ittheke sato sattassa paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti. 96. "tamaÃ±Ã±o evamÄha â€“ â€˜atthi kho, bho, eso attÄ, yaá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ vadesi, neso natthÄ«ti vadÄmi, no ca kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ ettÄvatÄ paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ patto hoti. taá¹ƒ kissa hetu? yadeva tattha vitakkitaá¹ƒ vicÄritaá¹ƒ, etenetaá¹ƒ oá¸·Ärikaá¹ƒ akkhÄyati. yato kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ vitakkavicÄrÄnaá¹ƒ vÅ«pasamÄ ajjhattaá¹ƒ sampasÄdanaá¹ƒ cetaso ekodibhÄvaá¹ƒ avitakkaá¹ƒ avicÄraá¹ƒ samÄdhijaá¹ƒ pÄ«tisukhaá¹ƒ dutiyaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒ upasampajja viharati, ettÄvatÄ kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ patto hotÄ«â€™ti. ittheke sato sattassa paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti. 97. "tamaÃ±Ã±o evamÄha â€“ â€˜atthi kho, bho, eso attÄ, yaá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ vadesi, neso natthÄ«ti vadÄmi, no ca kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ ettÄvatÄ paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ patto hoti. taá¹ƒ kissa hetu? yadeva tattha pÄ«tigataá¹ƒ cetaso uppilÄvitattaá¹ƒ, etenetaá¹ƒ oá¸·Ärikaá¹ƒ akkhÄyati. yato kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ pÄ«tiyÄ ca virÄgÄ upekkhako ca viharati, sato ca sampajÄno, sukhaÃ±ca kÄyena paá¹­isaá¹ƒvedeti, yaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ ariyÄ Äcikkhanti "upekkhako satimÄ sukhavihÄrÄ«"ti, tatiyaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒ upasampajja viharati, ettÄvatÄ kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ patto hotÄ«â€™ti. ittheke sato sattassa paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti. 98. "tamaÃ±Ã±o evamÄha â€“ â€˜atthi kho, bho, eso attÄ, yaá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ vadesi, neso natthÄ«ti vadÄmi, no ca kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ ettÄvatÄ paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ patto hoti. taá¹ƒ kissa hetu? yadeva tattha sukhamiti cetaso Äbhogo, etenetaá¹ƒ oá¸·Ärikaá¹ƒ akkhÄyati. yato kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ sukhassa ca pahÄnÄ dukkhassa ca pahÄnÄ pubbeva somanassadomanassÄnaá¹ƒ atthaá¹…gamÄ adukkhamasukhaá¹ƒ upekkhÄsatipÄrisuddhiá¹ƒ catutthaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒ upasampajja viharati, ettÄvatÄ kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ patto hotÄ«â€™ti. ittheke sato sattassa paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti.
â€œTo him another says: â€˜There is, good sir, such a self as you assert. That I do not deny. But it is not at that point that the self attains the highest *NibbÄna* here and now. What is the reason for that? It is declared to be gross because of the mental exhilaration (*uppilÄvitatta*) connected with rapture (*pÄ«ti*) that exists there. But when, with the fading away of rapture (*pÄ«ti*), one abides in equanimity (*upekkhÄ*), mindful (*sato*) and clearly comprehending (*sampajÄno*), and still experiencing happiness (*sukha*) with the body (*kÄya*), enters and abides in the third *jhÄna*, so that the noble ones (*ariyÄ*) announce: â€œHe abides happily, in equanimity and mindfulness (*upekkhako satimÄ sukhavihÄrÄ«*)â€â€”at this point, good sir, the self attains supreme *NibbÄna* here and now. In this way some proclaim the highest *NibbÄna* here and now for an existent being.
98. ayaá¹ƒ attÄ paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ patto hotÄ«â€™ti. ittheke sato sattassa paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti. 96. "tamaÃ±Ã±o evamÄha â€“ â€˜atthi kho, bho, eso attÄ, yaá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ vadesi, neso natthÄ«ti vadÄmi, no ca kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ ettÄvatÄ paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ patto hoti. taá¹ƒ kissa hetu? yadeva tattha vitakkitaá¹ƒ vicÄritaá¹ƒ, etenetaá¹ƒ oá¸·Ärikaá¹ƒ akkhÄyati. yato kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ vitakkavicÄrÄnaá¹ƒ vÅ«pasamÄ ajjhattaá¹ƒ sampasÄdanaá¹ƒ cetaso ekodibhÄvaá¹ƒ avitakkaá¹ƒ avicÄraá¹ƒ samÄdhijaá¹ƒ pÄ«tisukhaá¹ƒ dutiyaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒ upasampajja viharati, ettÄvatÄ kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ patto hotÄ«â€™ti. ittheke sato sattassa paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti. 97. "tamaÃ±Ã±o evamÄha â€“ â€˜atthi kho, bho, eso attÄ, yaá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ vadesi, neso natthÄ«ti vadÄmi, no ca kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ ettÄvatÄ paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ patto hoti. taá¹ƒ kissa hetu? yadeva tattha pÄ«tigataá¹ƒ cetaso uppilÄvitattaá¹ƒ, etenetaá¹ƒ oá¸·Ärikaá¹ƒ akkhÄyati. yato kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ pÄ«tiyÄ ca virÄgÄ upekkhako ca viharati, sato ca sampajÄno, sukhaÃ±ca kÄyena paá¹­isaá¹ƒvedeti, yaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ ariyÄ Äcikkhanti "upekkhako satimÄ sukhavihÄrÄ«"ti, tatiyaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒ upasampajja viharati, ettÄvatÄ kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ patto hotÄ«â€™ti. ittheke sato sattassa paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti. 98. "tamaÃ±Ã±o evamÄha â€“ â€˜atthi kho, bho, eso attÄ, yaá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ vadesi, neso natthÄ«ti vadÄmi, no ca kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ ettÄvatÄ paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ patto hoti. taá¹ƒ kissa hetu? yadeva tattha sukhamiti cetaso Äbhogo, etenetaá¹ƒ oá¸·Ärikaá¹ƒ akkhÄyati. yato kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ sukhassa ca pahÄnÄ dukkhassa ca pahÄnÄ pubbeva somanassadomanassÄnaá¹ƒ atthaá¹…gamÄ adukkhamasukhaá¹ƒ upekkhÄsatipÄrisuddhiá¹ƒ catutthaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒ upasampajja viharati, ettÄvatÄ kho, bho, ayaá¹ƒ attÄ paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ patto hotÄ«â€™ti. ittheke sato sattassa paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti.
â€œTo him another says: â€˜There is, good sir, such a self as you assert. That I do not deny. But it is not at that point that the self attains the highest *NibbÄna* here and now. What is the reason for that? Because the mind contains the idea of joy (*sukha*), and that state is considered gross (*oá¸·Ärika*). But when, with the abandonment of pleasure (*sukha*) and pain (*dukkha*), with the disappearance of previous joy (*somanassa*) and grief (*domanassa*), one enters and abides in a state beyond pleasure and pain in the fourth *jhÄna*, which is purified by equanimity (*upekkhÄ*) and mindfulness (*sati*)â€”at this point, good sir, the self attains supreme *NibbÄna* here and now. In this way some proclaim the highest *NibbÄna* here and now for an existent being.
99. 99. "imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä diá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnavÄdÄ sato sattassa paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti paÃ±cahi vatthÅ«hi. ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡Ä vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä vÄ diá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnavÄdÄ sato sattassa paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti, sabbe te imeheva paÃ±cahi vatthÅ«hiâ€¦peâ€¦ yehi tathÄgatassa yathÄbhuccaá¹ƒ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ sammÄ vadamÄnÄ vadeyyuá¹ƒ. 100. "It is on these five grounds, monks, that those ascetics and Brahmins who maintain a doctrine of *NibbÄna* here and now proclaim supreme *NibbÄna* here and now for an existent being. Whatever ascetics or Brahmins, monks, proclaim supreme *NibbÄna* here and now for an existent being, all of them do so on these five groundsâ€¦ and it is concerning these that those who would rightly praise the *TathÄgata* in accordance with reality would speak.

"It is on these forty-four grounds, monks, that those ascetics and Brahmins who are speculators about the future, who hold settled views about the future, assert various conceptual theorems referring to the future. Whatever ascetics or Brahmins, monks, are speculators about the future, hold settled views about the future, and assert various conceptual theorems referring to the future, all of them do so on these forty-four groundsâ€¦ and it is concerning these that those who would rightly praise the *TathÄgata* in accordance with reality would speak.

"It is on these sixty-two grounds, monks, that those ascetics and Brahmins who are speculators about the past, speculators about the future, and speculators about the past and the future together, who hold settled views about the past and the future, assert various conceptual theorems referring to the past and the future.

"Whatever ascetics or Brahmins, monks, are speculators about the past, speculators about the future, speculators about the past and the future together, who hold settled views about the past and the future and assert various conceptual theorems referring to the past and the futureâ€”all of them do so on these sixty-two grounds or on a certain one of them. Outside of these there is none.
103. 99. "imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä diá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnavÄdÄ sato sattassa paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti paÃ±cahi vatthÅ«hi. ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡Ä vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä vÄ diá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnavÄdÄ sato sattassa paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti, sabbe te imeheva paÃ±cahi vatthÅ«hiâ€¦peâ€¦ yehi tathÄgatassa yathÄbhuccaá¹ƒ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ sammÄ vadamÄnÄ vadeyyuá¹ƒ. 100. "ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaá¹‡Ä vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä vÄ pubbantakappikÄ vÄ aparantakappikÄ vÄ pubbantÄparantakappikÄ vÄ pubbantÄparantÄnudiá¹­á¹­hino pubbantÄparantaá¹ƒ Ärabbha anekavihitÄni adhimuttipadÄni abhivadanti, sabbe te imeheva dvÄsaá¹­á¹­hiyÄ vatthÅ«hi, etesaá¹ƒ vÄ aÃ±Ã±atarena, natthi ito bahiddhÄ. 103. "tayidaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, tathÄgato pajÄnÄti â€“ â€˜ime diá¹­á¹­hiá¹­á¹­hÄnÄ evaá¹ƒgahitÄ evaá¹ƒparÄmaá¹­á¹­hÄ evaá¹ƒgatikÄ bhavanti evaá¹ƒabhisamparÄyÄâ€™ti. taÃ±ca tathÄgato pajÄnÄti, tato ca uttaritaraá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, taÃ±ca pajÄnanaá¹ƒ na parÄmasati, aparÄmasato cassa paccattaÃ±Ã±eva nibbuti viditÄ. vedanÄnaá¹ƒ samudayaÃ±ca atthaá¹…gamaÃ±ca assÄdaÃ±ca ÄdÄ«navaÃ±ca nissaraá¹‡aÃ±ca yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ viditvÄ anupÄdÄvimutto, bhikkhave, tathÄgato.
"This, monks, the *TathÄgata* understands: â€˜These standpoints, thus assumed and thus misapprehended, lead to such a future destination, to such a state in the world beyond.â€™ This the *TathÄgata* knows, and more, but he is not attached to that knowledge. And because he is free from misapprehension, he has realized within himself the state of perfect peace (*nibbuti*). Having understood as they really are the origin and the passing away of feelings, their satisfaction, their unsatisfactoriness, and the escape from them, the *TathÄgata*, monks, is emancipated through non-clinging.
104. 104. "ime kho te, bhikkhave, dhammÄ gambhÄ«rÄ duddasÄ duranubodhÄ santÄ paá¹‡Ä«tÄ atakkÄvacarÄ nipuá¹‡Ä paá¹‡á¸itavedanÄ«yÄ, ye tathÄgato sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ pavedeti, yehi tathÄgatassa yathÄbhuccaá¹ƒ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ sammÄ vadamÄnÄ vadeyyuá¹ƒ. paritassitavipphanditavÄro 105. "tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä amarÄvikkhepikÄ tattha tattha paÃ±haá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­hÄ samÄnÄ vÄcÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ Äpajjanti amarÄvikkhepaá¹ƒ catÅ«hi vatthÅ«hi, tadapi tesaá¹ƒ bhavataá¹ƒ samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ ajÄnataá¹ƒ apassataá¹ƒ vedayitaá¹ƒ taá¹‡hÄgatÄnaá¹ƒ paritassitavipphanditameva. 109. "tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä adhiccasamuppannikÄ adhiccasamuppannaá¹ƒ attÄnaÃ±ca lokaÃ±ca paÃ±Ã±apenti dvÄ«hi vatthÅ«hi, tadapi tesaá¹ƒ bhavataá¹ƒ samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ ajÄnataá¹ƒ apassataá¹ƒ vedayitaá¹ƒ taá¹‡hÄgatÄnaá¹ƒ paritassitavipphanditameva. 110. "tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä pubbantakappikÄ pubbantÄnudiá¹­á¹­hino pubbantaá¹ƒ Ärabbha anekavihitÄni adhimuttipadÄni abhivadanti
"These are those *dhammas*, monks, that are deep, difficult to see, difficult to understand, peaceful and sublime, beyond the sphere of reasoning, subtle, comprehensible only to the wise, which the *TathÄgata*, having realized for himself with direct knowledge (*abhiÃ±Ã±Ä*), propounds to others; and it is concerning these that those who would rightly praise the *TathÄgata* in accordance with reality would speak. The round of agitation and vacillation.
105. 104. "ime kho te, bhikkhave, dhammÄ gambhÄ«rÄ duddasÄ duranubodhÄ santÄ paá¹‡Ä«tÄ atakkÄvacarÄ nipuá¹‡Ä paá¹‡á¸itavedanÄ«yÄ, ye tathÄgato sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ pavedeti, yehi tathÄgatassa yathÄbhuccaá¹ƒ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ sammÄ vadamÄnÄ vadeyyuá¹ƒ. paritassitavipphanditavÄro 105. "Therein, monks, when those ascetics and Brahmins who are speculators about the past (*pubbantakappikÄ*) and hold settled views about the past (*pubbantÄnudiá¹­á¹­hino*) assert on eighteen grounds various conceptual theorems (*adhimuttipadÄni*) referring to the past (*pubbantaá¹ƒ*) With eighteen grounds, that is only the feeling of those venerable ascetics and Brahmins who do not know and do not see; that is only the agitation and vacillation of those who are immersed in craving.
111. aá¹­á¹­hÄrasahi vatthÅ«hi, tadapi tesaá¹ƒ bhavataá¹ƒ samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ ajÄnataá¹ƒ apassataá¹ƒ vedayitaá¹ƒ taá¹‡hÄgatÄnaá¹ƒ paritassitavipphanditameva. 111. "tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä uddhamÄghÄtanikÄ saÃ±Ã±Ä«vÄdÄ uddhamÄghÄtanaá¹ƒ saÃ±Ã±iá¹ƒ attÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti soá¸·asahi vatthÅ«hi, tadapi tesaá¹ƒ bhavataá¹ƒ samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ ajÄnataá¹ƒ apassataá¹ƒ vedayitaá¹ƒ taá¹‡hÄgatÄnaá¹ƒ paritassitavipphanditameva. 112. "tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä uddhamÄghÄtanikÄ asaÃ±Ã±Ä«vÄdÄ uddhamÄghÄtanaá¹ƒ asaÃ±Ã±iá¹ƒ attÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti aá¹­á¹­hahi vatthÅ«hi, tadapi tesaá¹ƒ bhavataá¹ƒ samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ ajÄnataá¹ƒ apassataá¹ƒ vedayitaá¹ƒ taá¹‡hÄgatÄnaá¹ƒ paritassitavipphanditameva. 113. "tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä uddhamÄghÄtanikÄ nevasaÃ±Ã±Ä«nÄsaÃ±Ã±Ä«vÄdÄ uddhamÄghÄtanaá¹ƒ nevasaÃ±Ã±Ä«nÄsaÃ±Ã±iá¹ƒ attÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti aá¹­á¹­hahi vatthÅ«hi, tadapi tesaá¹ƒ bhavataá¹ƒ samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ ajÄnataá¹ƒ apassataá¹ƒ vedayitaá¹ƒ taá¹‡hÄgatÄnaá¹ƒ paritassitavipphanditameva. 114. "There, *bhikkhus*, when those ascetics and Brahmins who maintain a doctrine of percipient immortality proclaim on sixteen grounds the self to survive percipient after death, that is only the feeling of those venerable ascetics and Brahmins who do not know and do not see; that is only the agitation and vacillation of those who are immersed in craving.

"There, *bhikkhus*, when those ascetics and Brahmins who are annihilationists proclaim on seven grounds the annihilation, destruction, and extermination of an existent being, that is only the feeling of those venerable ascetics and Brahmins who do not know and do not see; that is only the agitation and vacillation of those who are immersed in craving.

"There, *bhikkhus*, when those ascetics and Brahmins who maintain a doctrine of *NibbÄna* here and now proclaim on five grounds supreme *NibbÄna* here and now for an existent being, that is only the feeling of those venerable ascetics and Brahmins who do not know and do not see; that is only the agitation and vacillation of those who are immersed in craving.

"There, *bhikkhus*, when those ascetics and Brahmins who are speculators about the future and hold settled views about the future assert on forty-four grounds various conceptual theorems referring to the future, that is only the feeling of those venerable ascetics and Brahmins who do not know and do not see; that is only the agitation and vacillation of those who are immersed in craving.

"tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä pubbantakappikÄ ca aparantakappikÄ ca pubbantÄparantakappikÄ ca pubbantÄparantÄnudiá¹­á¹­hino pubbantÄparantaá¹ƒ Ärabbha anekavihitÄni adhimuttipadÄni abhivadanti dvÄsaá¹­á¹­hiyÄ vatthÅ«hi, tadapi tesaá¹ƒ bhavataá¹ƒ samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ ajÄnataá¹ƒ apassataá¹ƒ vedayitaá¹ƒ taá¹‡hÄgatÄnaá¹ƒ paritassitavipphanditameva. phassapaccayÄvÄro 118. "There, *bhikkhus*, when those ascetics and Brahmins who are speculators about the past, speculators about the future, speculators about the past and the future together, who hold settled views about the past and the future, assert on sixty-two grounds various conceptual theorems referring to the past and the futureâ€”that too is only the feeling of those who do not know and do not see; that is only the agitation and vacillation of those who are immersed in craving. The round conditioned by contact.
118. 117. "There, *bhikkhus*, when those ascetics and Brahmins who are eternalists proclaim on four grounds the self and the world to be eternal, that is conditioned by contact.

"There, *bhikkhus*, when those ascetics and Brahmins who are eternalists in regard to some things and non-eternalists in regard to other things proclaim on four grounds the self and the world to be partly eternal and partly non-eternal, that too is conditioned by contact.

"There, monks, when those ascetics and Brahmins who are proponents of unconscious survival after death propound an unconscious self after death on eight grounds, that too is conditioned by contact.

"There, monks, when those ascetics and Brahmins who are proponents of the finite and infinite propound a world that is finite and infinite on four grounds, that they would experience feeling apart from contact is impossible.

"tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä uddhamÄghÄtanikÄ saÃ±Ã±Ä«vÄdÄ uddhamÄghÄtanaá¹ƒ saÃ±Ã±iá¹ƒ attÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti soá¸·asahi vatthÅ«hi, te vata aÃ±Ã±atra phassÄ paá¹­isaá¹ƒvedissantÄ«ti netaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ vijjati. 138. "tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä uddhamÄghÄtanikÄ asaÃ±Ã±Ä«vÄdÄ, uddhamÄghÄtanaá¹ƒ asaÃ±Ã±iá¹ƒ attÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti aá¹­á¹­hahi vatthÅ«hi, te vata aÃ±Ã±atra phassÄ paá¹­isaá¹ƒvedissantÄ«ti netaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ vijjati. 139. "tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä uddhamÄghÄtanikÄ nevasaÃ±Ã±Ä«nÄsaÃ±Ã±Ä«vÄdÄ uddhamÄghÄtanaá¹ƒ nevasaÃ±Ã±Ä«nÄsaÃ±Ã±iá¹ƒ attÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti aá¹­á¹­hahi vatthÅ«hi, te vata aÃ±Ã±atra phassÄ paá¹­isaá¹ƒvedissantÄ«ti netaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ vijjati. 140. "tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä ucchedavÄdÄ sato sattassa ucchedaá¹ƒ vinÄsaá¹ƒ vibhavaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti sattahi vatthÅ«hi, te vata aÃ±Ã±atra phassÄ paá¹­isaá¹ƒvedissantÄ«ti netaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ vijjati.
"There, monks, when those ascetics and Brahmins who are annihilationists propound the annihilation, destruction, and extermination of an existing being on seven grounds, that they would experience feeling apart from contact is impossible.
141. 141. "tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä diá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnavÄdÄ sato sattassa paramadiá¹­á¹­hadhammanibbÄnaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti paÃ±cahi vatthÅ«hi, te vata aÃ±Ã±atra phassÄ paá¹­isaá¹ƒvedissantÄ«ti netaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ vijjati. 142.
