"Another time, venerable sir, I approached Nigaá¹‡á¹­ha NÄá¹­aputta, and after approaching, I exchanged greetings with Nigaá¹‡á¹­ha NÄá¹­aputta. Having exchanged courteous talk that encourages friendliness, I sat down to one side. Having sat down to one side, venerable sir, I said this to Nigaá¹‡á¹­ha NÄá¹­aputta: â€˜Just as these various crafts areâ€¦peâ€¦ is it possible, venerable Aggivessana, to describe in the same way a visible fruit of recluseship in this very life?â€™
177. 177. "evaá¹ƒ vutte, bhante, nigaá¹‡á¹­ho nÄá¹­aputto maá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ â€˜idha, mahÄrÄja, nigaá¹‡á¹­ho cÄtuyÄmasaá¹ƒvarasaá¹ƒvuto hoti. kathaÃ±ca, mahÄrÄja, nigaá¹‡á¹­ho cÄtuyÄmasaá¹ƒvarasaá¹ƒvuto hoti? idha, mahÄrÄja, nigaá¹‡á¹­ho sabbavÄrivÄrito ca hoti, sabbavÄriyutto ca, sabbavÄridhuto ca, sabbavÄriphuá¹­o ca. evaá¹ƒ kho, mahÄrÄja, nigaá¹‡á¹­ho cÄtuyÄmasaá¹ƒvarasaá¹ƒvuto hoti. yato kho, mahÄrÄja, nigaá¹‡á¹­ho evaá¹ƒ cÄtuyÄmasaá¹ƒvarasaá¹ƒvuto hoti, ayaá¹ƒ vuccati, mahÄrÄja, nigaá¹‡á¹­ho [nigaá¹‡á¹­ho nÄá¹­aputto (syÄ. ka.)] gatatto ca yatatto ca á¹­hitatto cÄâ€™ti. 178. "itthaá¹ƒ kho me, bhante, nigaá¹‡á¹­ho nÄá¹­aputto sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­ho samÄno cÄtuyÄmasaá¹ƒvaraá¹ƒ byÄkÄsi. seyyathÄpi, bhante, ambaá¹ƒ vÄ puá¹­á¹­ho labujaá¹ƒ byÄkareyya, labujaá¹ƒ vÄ puá¹­á¹­ho ambaá¹ƒ byÄkareyya, evameva kho me, bhante, nigaá¹‡á¹­ho nÄá¹­aputto sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­ho samÄno cÄtuyÄmasaá¹ƒvaraá¹ƒ byÄkÄsi. tassa mayhaá¹ƒ, bhante, etadahosi â€“ â€˜kathaÃ±hi nÄma mÄdiso samaá¹‡aá¹ƒ vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡aá¹ƒ vÄ vijite vasantaá¹ƒ apasÄdetabbaá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±eyyÄâ€™ti. so kho ahaá¹ƒ, bhante, nigaá¹‡á¹­hassa nÄá¹­aputtassa bhÄsitaá¹ƒ neva abhinandiá¹ƒ nappaá¹­ikkosiá¹ƒ. anabhinanditvÄ appaá¹­ikkositvÄ anattamano anattamanavÄcaá¹ƒ anicchÄretvÄ tameva vÄcaá¹ƒ anuggaá¹‡hanto anikkujjanto uá¹­á¹­hÄyÄsanÄ pakkamiá¹ƒ. saÃ±cayabelaá¹­á¹­haputtavÄdo 179. "ekamidÄhaá¹ƒ, bhante, samayaá¹ƒ yena saÃ±cayo belaá¹­á¹­haputto tenupasaá¹…kamiá¹ƒ, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ saÃ±cayena belaá¹­á¹­haputtena saddhiá¹ƒ sammodiá¹ƒ. sammodanÄ«yaá¹ƒ kathaá¹ƒ sÄraá¹‡Ä«yaá¹ƒ vÄ«tisÄretvÄ ekamantaá¹ƒ nisÄ«diá¹ƒ. ekamantaá¹ƒ nisinno kho ahaá¹ƒ bhante, saÃ±cayaá¹ƒ belaá¹­á¹­haputtaá¹ƒ etadavocaá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜yathÄ nu kho imÄni, bho saÃ±caya, puthusippÄyatanÄniâ€¦peâ€¦ sakkÄ nu kho, bho saÃ±caya, evameva diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apetuâ€™nti? 180. "evaá¹ƒ vutte, bhante, saÃ±cayo belaá¹­á¹­haputto maá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ â€˜atthi paro lokoti iti ce maá¹ƒ pucchasi, atthi paro lokoti iti ce me assa, atthi paro lokoti iti te naá¹ƒ byÄkareyyaá¹ƒ. evantipi me no, tathÄtipi me no, aÃ±Ã±athÄtipi me no, notipi
"When this was said, venerable sir, the Nigaá¹‡á¹­ha NÄá¹­aputta said this to me: 'Here, great king, a Nigaá¹‡á¹­ha is restrained by a fourfold restraint (*cÄtuyÄmasaá¹ƒvarasaá¹ƒvuto*). And how, great king, is a Nigaá¹‡á¹­ha restrained by a fourfold restraint? Here, great king, a Nigaá¹‡á¹­ha is restrained with regard to all water (*sabbavÄrivÄrito*), he is endowed with the avoidance of all evil (*sabbavÄriyutto*); he is cleansed by the avoidance of all evil (*sabbavÄridhuto*); and he is suffused with the avoidance of all evil (*sabbavÄriphuá¹­o*). In this way, great king, a Nigaá¹‡á¹­ha is restrained by a fourfold restraint (*cÄtuyÄmasaá¹ƒvarasaá¹ƒvuto*). Because, great king, a Nigaá¹‡á¹­ha is thus restrained by a fourfold restraint (*cÄtuyÄmasaá¹ƒvarasaá¹ƒvuto*), he is called, great king, a Nigaá¹‡á¹­ha who is self-perfected (*gatatto*), self-controlled (*yatatto*), and self-established (*á¹­hitatto*)."
178. 177. "evaá¹ƒ vutte, bhante, nigaá¹‡á¹­ho nÄá¹­aputto maá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ â€˜idha, mahÄrÄja, nigaá¹‡á¹­ho cÄtuyÄmasaá¹ƒvarasaá¹ƒvuto hoti. kathaÃ±ca, mahÄrÄja, nigaá¹‡á¹­ho cÄtuyÄmasaá¹ƒvarasaá¹ƒvuto hoti? idha, mahÄrÄja, nigaá¹‡á¹­ho sabbavÄrivÄrito ca hoti, sabbavÄriyutto ca, sabbavÄridhuto ca, sabbavÄriphuá¹­o ca. evaá¹ƒ kho, mahÄrÄja, nigaá¹‡á¹­ho cÄtuyÄmasaá¹ƒvarasaá¹ƒvuto hoti. yato kho, mahÄrÄja, nigaá¹‡á¹­ho evaá¹ƒ cÄtuyÄmasaá¹ƒvarasaá¹ƒvuto hoti, ayaá¹ƒ vuccati, mahÄrÄja, nigaá¹‡á¹­ho [nigaá¹‡á¹­ho nÄá¹­aputto (syÄ. ka.)] gatatto ca yatatto ca á¹­hitatto cÄâ€™ti. 178. "itthaá¹ƒ kho me, bhante, nigaá¹‡á¹­ho nÄá¹­aputto sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­ho samÄno cÄtuyÄmasaá¹ƒvaraá¹ƒ byÄkÄsi. seyyathÄpi, bhante, ambaá¹ƒ vÄ puá¹­á¹­ho labujaá¹ƒ byÄkareyya, labujaá¹ƒ vÄ puá¹­á¹­ho ambaá¹ƒ byÄkareyya, evameva kho me, bhante, nigaá¹‡á¹­ho nÄá¹­aputto sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­ho samÄno cÄtuyÄmasaá¹ƒvaraá¹ƒ byÄkÄsi. tassa mayhaá¹ƒ, bhante, etadahosi â€“ â€˜kathaÃ±hi nÄma mÄdiso samaá¹‡aá¹ƒ vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡aá¹ƒ vÄ vijite vasantaá¹ƒ apasÄdetabbaá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±eyyÄâ€™ti. so kho ahaá¹ƒ, bhante, nigaá¹‡á¹­hassa nÄá¹­aputtassa bhÄsitaá¹ƒ neva abhinandiá¹ƒ nappaá¹­ikkosiá¹ƒ. anabhinanditvÄ appaá¹­ikkositvÄ anattamano anattamanavÄcaá¹ƒ anicchÄretvÄ tameva vÄcaá¹ƒ anuggaá¹‡hanto anikkujjanto uá¹­á¹­hÄyÄsanÄ pakkamiá¹ƒ. saÃ±cayabelaá¹­á¹­haputtavÄdo 179. "ekamidÄhaá¹ƒ, bhante, samayaá¹ƒ yena saÃ±cayo belaá¹­á¹­haputto tenupasaá¹…kamiá¹ƒ, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ saÃ±cayena belaá¹­á¹­haputtena saddhiá¹ƒ sammodiá¹ƒ. sammodanÄ«yaá¹ƒ kathaá¹ƒ sÄraá¹‡Ä«yaá¹ƒ vÄ«tisÄretvÄ ekamantaá¹ƒ nisÄ«diá¹ƒ. ekamantaá¹ƒ nisinno kho ahaá¹ƒ bhante, saÃ±cayaá¹ƒ belaá¹­á¹­haputtaá¹ƒ etadavocaá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜yathÄ nu kho imÄni, bho saÃ±caya, puthusippÄyatanÄniâ€¦peâ€¦ sakkÄ nu kho, bho saÃ±caya, evameva diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apetuâ€™nti? 180. "evaá¹ƒ vutte, bhante, saÃ±cayo belaá¹­á¹­haputto maá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ â€˜atthi paro lokoti iti ce maá¹ƒ pucchasi, atthi paro lokoti iti ce me assa, atthi paro lokoti iti te naá¹ƒ byÄkareyyaá¹ƒ. evantipi me no, tathÄtipi me no, aÃ±Ã±athÄtipi me no, notipi
"Thus, venerable sir, when I asked the Nigaá¹‡á¹­ha NÄá¹­aputta about a visible fruit of the ascetic life (*sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ*), he explained the fourfold restraint (*cÄtuyÄmasaá¹ƒvaraá¹ƒ*) to me. Venerable sir, just as if one asked about a mango would speak about a breadfruit, or as if one asked about a breadfruit would speak about a mango, in the same way, when I asked Nigaá¹‡á¹­ha NÄá¹­aputta about a visible fruit of the ascetic life (*sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ*), he explained the fourfold restraint (*cÄtuyÄmasaá¹ƒvaraá¹ƒ*) to me. Then, venerable sir, this thought occurred to me: 'How could one like me think of troubling an ascetic or a Brahmin dwelling in my realm?' So I, venerable sir, neither rejoiced in the statement of Nigaá¹‡á¹­ha NÄá¹­aputta, nor did I reject it. Without accepting his doctrine, without embracing it, being displeased, without expressing displeasure, keeping that very statement in mind, without overturning it, I got up from my seat and departed. The Doctrine of SaÃ±caya Belaá¹­á¹­haputta
179. 177. "evaá¹ƒ vutte, bhante, nigaá¹‡á¹­ho nÄá¹­aputto maá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ â€˜idha, mahÄrÄja, nigaá¹‡á¹­ho cÄtuyÄmasaá¹ƒvarasaá¹ƒvuto hoti. kathaÃ±ca, mahÄrÄja, nigaá¹‡á¹­ho cÄtuyÄmasaá¹ƒvarasaá¹ƒvuto hoti? idha, mahÄrÄja, nigaá¹‡á¹­ho sabbavÄrivÄrito ca hoti, sabbavÄriyutto ca, sabbavÄridhuto ca, sabbavÄriphuá¹­o ca. evaá¹ƒ kho, mahÄrÄja, nigaá¹‡á¹­ho cÄtuyÄmasaá¹ƒvarasaá¹ƒvuto hoti. yato kho, mahÄrÄja, nigaá¹‡á¹­ho evaá¹ƒ cÄtuyÄmasaá¹ƒvarasaá¹ƒvuto hoti, ayaá¹ƒ vuccati, mahÄrÄja, nigaá¹‡á¹­ho [nigaá¹‡á¹­ho nÄá¹­aputto (syÄ. ka.)] gatatto ca yatatto ca á¹­hitatto cÄâ€™ti. 178. "Once, venerable sir, I approached SaÃ±caya Belaá¹­á¹­haputta; having approached, I exchanged greetings with SaÃ±caya Belaá¹­á¹­haputta. Having exchanged courteous and amiable talk, I sat down to one side. Having sat down to one side, venerable sir, I said this to SaÃ±caya Belaá¹­á¹­haputta: 'Just as there are these various fields of skillâ€¦peâ€¦ is it possible, venerable SaÃ±caya, to explain a visible fruit of the ascetic life (*sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ*) in the very Dhamma that is seen?'
180. 177. "evaá¹ƒ vutte, bhante, nigaá¹‡á¹­ho nÄá¹­aputto maá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ â€˜idha, mahÄrÄja, nigaá¹‡á¹­ho cÄtuyÄmasaá¹ƒvarasaá¹ƒvuto hoti. kathaÃ±ca, mahÄrÄja, nigaá¹‡á¹­ho cÄtuyÄmasaá¹ƒvarasaá¹ƒvuto hoti? idha, mahÄrÄja, nigaá¹‡á¹­ho sabbavÄrivÄrito ca hoti, sabbavÄriyutto ca, sabbavÄridhuto ca, sabbavÄriphuá¹­o ca. evaá¹ƒ kho, mahÄrÄja, nigaá¹‡á¹­ho cÄtuyÄmasaá¹ƒvarasaá¹ƒvuto hoti. yato kho, mahÄrÄja, nigaá¹‡á¹­ho evaá¹ƒ cÄtuyÄmasaá¹ƒvarasaá¹ƒvuto hoti, ayaá¹ƒ vuccati, mahÄrÄja, nigaá¹‡á¹­ho [nigaá¹‡á¹­ho nÄá¹­aputto (syÄ. ka.)] gatatto ca yatatto ca á¹­hitatto cÄâ€™ti. 178. "itthaá¹ƒ kho me, bhante, nigaá¹‡á¹­ho nÄá¹­aputto sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­ho samÄno cÄtuyÄmasaá¹ƒvaraá¹ƒ byÄkÄsi. seyyathÄpi, bhante, ambaá¹ƒ vÄ puá¹­á¹­ho labujaá¹ƒ byÄkareyya, labujaá¹ƒ vÄ puá¹­á¹­ho ambaá¹ƒ byÄkareyya, evameva kho me, bhante, nigaá¹‡á¹­ho nÄá¹­aputto sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­ho samÄno cÄtuyÄmasaá¹ƒvaraá¹ƒ byÄkÄsi. tassa mayhaá¹ƒ, bhante, etadahosi â€“ â€˜kathaÃ±hi nÄma mÄdiso samaá¹‡aá¹ƒ vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡aá¹ƒ vÄ vijite vasantaá¹ƒ apasÄdetabbaá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±eyyÄâ€™ti. so kho ahaá¹ƒ, bhante, nigaá¹‡á¹­hassa nÄá¹­aputtassa bhÄsitaá¹ƒ neva abhinandiá¹ƒ nappaá¹­ikkosiá¹ƒ. anabhinanditvÄ appaá¹­ikkositvÄ anattamano anattamanavÄcaá¹ƒ anicchÄretvÄ tameva vÄcaá¹ƒ anuggaá¹‡hanto anikkujjanto uá¹­á¹­hÄyÄsanÄ pakkamiá¹ƒ. saÃ±cayabelaá¹­á¹­haputtavÄdo 179. "ekamidÄhaá¹ƒ, bhante, samayaá¹ƒ yena saÃ±cayo belaá¹­á¹­haputto tenupasaá¹…kamiá¹ƒ, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ saÃ±cayena belaá¹­á¹­haputtena saddhiá¹ƒ sammodiá¹ƒ. sammodanÄ«yaá¹ƒ kathaá¹ƒ sÄraá¹‡Ä«yaá¹ƒ vÄ«tisÄretvÄ ekamantaá¹ƒ nisÄ«diá¹ƒ. ekamantaá¹ƒ nisinno kho ahaá¹ƒ bhante, saÃ±cayaá¹ƒ belaá¹­á¹­haputtaá¹ƒ etadavocaá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜yathÄ nu kho imÄni, bho saÃ±caya, puthusippÄyatanÄniâ€¦peâ€¦ sakkÄ nu kho, bho saÃ±caya, evameva diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apetuâ€™nti? 180. "evaá¹ƒ vutte, bhante, saÃ±cayo belaá¹­á¹­haputto maá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ â€˜atthi paro lokoti iti ce maá¹ƒ pucchasi, atthi paro lokoti iti ce me assa, atthi paro lokoti iti te naá¹ƒ byÄkareyyaá¹ƒ. evantipi me no, tathÄtipi me no, aÃ±Ã±athÄtipi me no, notipi
"When this was said, venerable sir, SaÃ±caya Belaá¹­á¹­haputta said this to me: 'If you ask me, "Is there another world (*paro loko*)?" if I thought that there is another world (*paro loko*), I would declare to you that "There is another world (*paro loko*)." I donâ€™t think so. I donâ€™t say it is so, and I donâ€™t say otherwise. I donâ€™t say it is not. But I do not say â€œIt is this way,â€ nor do I say â€œIt is not not so.â€ If you ask: â€˜Isnâ€™t there another world? â€˜. . . â€˜Both? â€˜. . . â€˜Neither? â€˜. . . â€˜Are there beings who have taken rebirth spontaneously? â€˜ â€˜Arenâ€™t there? â€˜. . . â€˜Both? â€˜. . . â€˜Neither? â€˜ . . . â€˜Is there fruit and result of good and bad deeds? â€˜ â€˜Isnâ€™t there? â€˜. . . â€˜Both? â€˜. . . â€˜Neither? â€˜ . . . â€˜Does the *TathÄgata* exist after death? Does he not exist after death? Does he both exist and not exist after death? Does he neither exist nor not exist after death?â€™ If you ask me this, I would answer that the *TathÄgata* neither exists nor does not exist after death. But I do not say â€œIt is this way,â€ nor â€œIt is that way,â€ nor â€œIt is otherwise.â€ I do not say â€œIt is not so,â€ nor do I say â€œIt is not not so.â€
181. me no, no notipi me no. natthi paro lokoâ€¦peâ€¦ atthi ca natthi ca paro lokoâ€¦peâ€¦ nevatthi na natthi paro lokoâ€¦peâ€¦ atthi sattÄ opapÄtikÄâ€¦peâ€¦ natthi sattÄ opapÄtikÄâ€¦peâ€¦ atthi ca natthi ca sattÄ opapÄtikÄâ€¦peâ€¦ nevatthi na natthi sattÄ opapÄtikÄâ€¦peâ€¦ atthi sukatadukkaá¹­Änaá¹ƒ kammÄnaá¹ƒ phalaá¹ƒ vipÄkoâ€¦peâ€¦ natthi sukatadukkaá¹­Änaá¹ƒ kammÄnaá¹ƒ phalaá¹ƒ vipÄkoâ€¦peâ€¦atthi ca natthi ca sukatadukkaá¹­Änaá¹ƒ kammÄnaá¹ƒ phalaá¹ƒ vipÄkoâ€¦peâ€¦ nevatthi na natthi sukatadukkaá¹­Änaá¹ƒ kammÄnaá¹ƒ phalaá¹ƒ vipÄkoâ€¦peâ€¦ hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äâ€¦peâ€¦ na hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äâ€¦peâ€¦ hoti ca na ca hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äâ€¦peâ€¦ neva hoti na na hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äti iti ce maá¹ƒ pucchasi, neva hoti na na hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äti iti ce me assa, neva hoti na na hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äti iti te naá¹ƒ byÄkareyyaá¹ƒ. evantipi me no, tathÄtipi me no, aÃ±Ã±athÄtipi me no, notipi me no, no notipi me noâ€™ti. 181. "itthaá¹ƒ kho me, bhante, saÃ±cayo belaá¹­á¹­haputto sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­ho samÄno vikkhepaá¹ƒ byÄkÄsi. seyyathÄpi, bhante, ambaá¹ƒ vÄ puá¹­á¹­ho labujaá¹ƒ byÄkareyya, labujaá¹ƒ vÄ puá¹­á¹­ho ambaá¹ƒ byÄkareyya, evameva kho me, bhante, saÃ±cayo belaá¹­á¹­haputto sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­ho samÄno vikkhepaá¹ƒ byÄkÄsi. tassa mayhaá¹ƒ, bhante, etadahosi â€“ â€˜ayaÃ±ca imesaá¹ƒ samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ sabbabÄlo sabbamÅ«á¸·ho. kathaÃ±hi nÄma sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­ho samÄno vikkhepaá¹ƒ byÄkarissatÄ«â€™ti. tassa mayhaá¹ƒ, bhante, etadahosi â€“ â€˜kathaÃ±hi nÄma mÄdiso samaá¹‡aá¹ƒ vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡aá¹ƒ vÄ vijite vasantaá¹ƒ apasÄdetabbaá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±eyyÄâ€™ti. so kho ahaá¹ƒ, bhante, saÃ±cayassa belaá¹­á¹­haputtassa bhÄsitaá¹ƒ neva abhinandiá¹ƒ nappaá¹­ikkosiá¹ƒ. anabhinanditvÄ appaá¹­ikkositvÄ anattamano anattamanavÄcaá¹ƒ anicchÄretvÄ tameva vÄcaá¹ƒ anuggaá¹‡hanto anikkujjanto uá¹­á¹­hÄyÄsanÄ pakkamiá¹ƒ. paá¹­hamasandiá¹­á¹­hikasÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ 182. "sohaá¹ƒ, bhante, bhagavantampi pucchÄmi â€“ â€˜yathÄ nu kho imÄni, bhante, puthusippÄyatanÄni seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ hatthÄrohÄ assÄrohÄ rathikÄ
â€œThus, venerable sir, when asked about the visible fruit of recluseship, SaÃ±jaya Belatthaputta answered me evasively. Venerable sir, just as if one asked about a mango would speak about a breadfruit, or as if one asked about a breadfruit would speak about a mango, in the same way, when I asked SaÃ±jaya Belatthaputta about a visible fruit of recluseship, he answered me evasively. Then, venerable sir, I thought to myself: â€˜Of all these ascetics and Brahmins, this SaÃ±jaya is the most stupid and confused. How could someone, when asked about a visible fruit of recluseship, answer evasively?â€™ Then, venerable sir, I thought to myself: â€˜One like myself should not think of troubling a *Å›ramaá¹‡a* or *brÄhmaá¹‡a* living in his realm.â€™ So I neither rejoiced in the statement of SaÃ±jaya Belatthaputta nor did I reject it. Without accepting his doctrine, without rejecting it, feeling dissatisfied, without uttering a word of dissatisfaction, I got up from my seat and left. The first visible fruit of recluseship.

"itthaá¹ƒ kho me, bhante, saÃ±cayo belaá¹­á¹­haputto sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­ho samÄno vikkhepaá¹ƒ byÄkÄsi. seyyathÄpi, bhante, ambaá¹ƒ vÄ puá¹­á¹­ho labujaá¹ƒ byÄkareyya, labujaá¹ƒ vÄ puá¹­á¹­ho ambaá¹ƒ byÄkareyya, evameva kho me, bhante, saÃ±cayo belaá¹­á¹­haputto sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­ho samÄno vikkhepaá¹ƒ byÄkÄsi. tassa mayhaá¹ƒ, bhante, etadahosi â€“ â€˜ayaÃ±ca imesaá¹ƒ samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ sabbabÄlo sabbamÅ«á¸·ho. kathaÃ±hi nÄma sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­ho samÄno vikkhepaá¹ƒ byÄkarissatÄ«â€™ti. tassa mayhaá¹ƒ, bhante, etadahosi â€“ â€˜kathaÃ±hi nÄma mÄdiso samaá¹‡aá¹ƒ vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡aá¹ƒ vÄ vijite vasantaá¹ƒ apasÄdetabbaá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±eyyÄâ€™ti. so kho ahaá¹ƒ, bhante, saÃ±cayassa belaá¹­á¹­haputtassa bhÄsitaá¹ƒ neva abhinandiá¹ƒ nappaá¹­ikkosiá¹ƒ. anabhinanditvÄ appaá¹­ikkositvÄ anattamano anattamanavÄcaá¹ƒ anicchÄretvÄ tameva vÄcaá¹ƒ anuggaá¹‡hanto anikkujjanto uá¹­á¹­hÄyÄsanÄ pakkamiá¹ƒ. paá¹­hamasandiá¹­á¹­hikasÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ 182. â€œSo, venerable sir, I ask the Blessed One (*Bhagavant*), too: â€˜Just as there are these various crafts, such as elephant trainers, horse trainers, charioteers, Middle morality.
183. dhanuggahÄ celakÄ calakÄ piá¹‡á¸adÄyakÄ uggÄ rÄjaputtÄ pakkhandino mahÄnÄgÄ sÅ«rÄ cammayodhino dÄsikaputtÄ Äá¸·ÄrikÄ kappakÄ nhÄpakÄ sÅ«dÄ mÄlÄkÄrÄ rajakÄ pesakÄrÄ naá¸·akÄrÄ kumbhakÄrÄ gaá¹‡akÄ muddikÄ, yÄni vÄ panaÃ±Ã±Änipi evaá¹ƒgatÄni puthusippÄyatanÄni, te diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sippaphalaá¹ƒ upajÄ«vanti, te tena attÄnaá¹ƒ sukhenti pÄ«á¹‡enti, mÄtÄpitaro sukhenti pÄ«á¹‡enti, puttadÄraá¹ƒ sukhenti pÄ«á¹‡enti, mittÄmacce sukhenti pÄ«á¹‡enti, samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡esu uddhaggikaá¹ƒ dakkhiá¹‡aá¹ƒ patiá¹­á¹­hapenti sovaggikaá¹ƒ sukhavipÄkaá¹ƒ saggasaá¹ƒvattanikaá¹ƒ. sakkÄ nu kho me, bhante, evameva diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apetuâ€™nti? 183. "sakkÄ, mahÄrÄja. tena hi, mahÄrÄja, taÃ±Ã±evettha paá¹­ipucchissÄmi. yathÄ te khameyya, tathÄ naá¹ƒ byÄkareyyÄsi. taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, mahÄrÄja, idha te assa puriso dÄso kammakÄro [kammakaro (sÄ«. syÄ. kaá¹ƒ. pÄ«.)] pubbuá¹­á¹­hÄyÄ« pacchÄnipÄtÄ« kiá¹…kÄrapaá¹­issÄvÄ« manÄpacÄrÄ« piyavÄdÄ« mukhullokako [mukhullokiko (syÄ. kaá¹ƒ. ka.)]. tassa evamassa â€“ â€˜acchariyaá¹ƒ, vata bho, abbhutaá¹ƒ, vata bho, puÃ±Ã±Änaá¹ƒ gati, puÃ±Ã±Änaá¹ƒ vipÄko. ayaÃ±hi rÄjÄ mÄgadho ajÄtasattu vedehiputto manusso, ahampi manusso. ayaÃ±hi rÄjÄ mÄgadho ajÄtasattu vedehiputto paÃ±cahi kÄmaguá¹‡ehi samappito samaá¹…gÄ«bhÅ«to paricÄreti, devo maÃ±Ã±e. ahaá¹ƒ panamhissa dÄso kammakÄro pubbuá¹­á¹­hÄyÄ« pacchÄnipÄtÄ« kiá¹…kÄrapaá¹­issÄvÄ« manÄpacÄrÄ« piyavÄdÄ« mukhullokako. so vatassÄhaá¹ƒ puÃ±Ã±Äni kareyyaá¹ƒ. yaá¹ƒnÅ«nÄhaá¹ƒ kesamassuá¹ƒ ohÄretvÄ kÄsÄyÄni vatthÄni acchÄdetvÄ agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajeyyaâ€™nti. so aparena samayena kesamassuá¹ƒ ohÄretvÄ kÄsÄyÄni vatthÄni acchÄdetvÄ agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajeyya. so evaá¹ƒ pabbajito samÄno kÄyena saá¹ƒvuto vihareyya, vÄcÄya saá¹ƒvuto vihareyya, manasÄ saá¹ƒvuto vihareyya, ghÄsacchÄdanaparamatÄya santuá¹­á¹­ho, abhirato paviveke. taá¹ƒ ce te purisÄ evamÄroceyyuá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜yagghe deva jÄneyyÄsi, yo te so puriso [yo te puriso (sÄ«. ka.)] dÄso kammakÄro pubbuá¹­á¹­hÄyÄ« pacchÄnipÄtÄ« kiá¹…kÄrapaá¹­issÄvÄ« manÄpacÄrÄ« piyavÄdÄ« mukhullokako, so, deva, kesamassuá¹ƒ ohÄretvÄ kÄsÄyÄni vatthÄni acchÄdetvÄ agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajito. so evaá¹ƒ
"It is possible, great king. Well then, great king, I will question you about this same matter. Answer as you see fit. What do you think, great king? Suppose you have a man, a slave, a workman, rising up before you, retiring after you, doing whatever you want, acting always for your pleasure, speaking politely to you, and is ever on the lookout to see that you are satisfied. He might think: â€˜It is wonderful, it is marvelous, the destiny and result of meritorious deeds! This King of Magadha, AjÄtasattu, son of Vedehi, is a man, and I too am a man. This King of Magadha, AjÄtasattu, son of Vedehi, lives replete with the five strands of sense pleasures, I deem him to be like a god. But I am his slave, his workmanâ€” rising before him, retiring after him, doing whatever he wants,acting always for his pleasure, speaking politely to him, ever on the lookout to see that he is satisfied. I ought to do something meritorious. What if I were to shave off my hair & beard, put on the ochre robes, and go forth from the household life into homelessness?â€™ After some time he shaves off his hair and beard, puts on the saffron robes, and goes forth from home to homelessness. Having thus gone forth, he lives restrained in body, restrained in speech, restrained in mind, content with the simplest food and shelter, delighting in solitude. And if people were to tell you this: â€˜Your Majesty should know, that man of yoursâ€” the slave, the workman, rising up before you, retiring after you, doing whatever you want, acting always for your pleasure, speaking politely to you, and ever on the lookout to see that you are satisfiedâ€” he has shaved off his hair and beard, put on the saffron robes, and gone forth from home to homelessness.â€™ Having gone forth, he dwells restrained in body (kÄyena saá¹ƒvuto), speech (vÄcÄya saá¹ƒvuto), and mind (manasÄ saá¹ƒvuto), content with the simplest food and shelter, delighting in solitude. Would you say: â€˜Bring that man back to me, men. Let him again become my slave, my workman, rising before me, retiring after me, doing whatever I want, acting always for my pleasure, speaking politely to me, ever on the lookout to see that I am satisfiedâ€™?â€
184. pabbajito samÄno kÄyena saá¹ƒvuto viharati, vÄcÄya saá¹ƒvuto viharati, manasÄ saá¹ƒvuto viharati, ghÄsacchÄdanaparamatÄya santuá¹­á¹­ho, abhirato pavivekeâ€™ti. api nu tvaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ vadeyyÄsi â€“ â€˜etu me, bho, so puriso, punadeva hotu dÄso kammakÄro pubbuá¹­á¹­hÄyÄ« pacchÄnipÄtÄ« kiá¹…kÄrapaá¹­issÄvÄ« manÄpacÄrÄ« piyavÄdÄ« mukhullokakoâ€™ti? 184. "no hetaá¹ƒ, bhante. atha kho naá¹ƒ mayameva abhivÄdeyyÄmapi, paccuá¹­á¹­heyyÄmapi, Äsanenapi nimanteyyÄma, abhinimanteyyÄmapi naá¹ƒ cÄ«varapiá¹‡á¸apÄtasenÄsanagilÄnappaccayabhesajjaparikkhÄrehi, dhammikampissa rakkhÄvaraá¹‡aguttiá¹ƒ saá¹ƒvidaheyyÄmÄ"ti. 185. "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, mahÄrÄja, yadi evaá¹ƒ sante hoti vÄ sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ no vÄ"ti? "addhÄ kho, bhante, evaá¹ƒ sante hoti sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphala"nti. "idaá¹ƒ kho te, mahÄrÄja, mayÄ paá¹­hamaá¹ƒ diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±atta"nti. dutiyasandiá¹­á¹­hikasÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ 186. "sakkÄ pana, bhante, aÃ±Ã±ampi evameva diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apetu"nti? "sakkÄ, mahÄrÄja. tena hi, mahÄrÄja, taÃ±Ã±evettha paá¹­ipucchissÄmi. yathÄ te khameyya, tathÄ naá¹ƒ byÄkareyyÄsi. taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, mahÄrÄja, idha te assa puriso kassako gahapatiko karakÄrako rÄsivaá¸á¸hako. tassa evamassa â€“ â€˜acchariyaá¹ƒ vata bho, abbhutaá¹ƒ vata bho, puÃ±Ã±Änaá¹ƒ gati, puÃ±Ã±Änaá¹ƒ vipÄko. ayaÃ±hi rÄjÄ mÄgadho ajÄtasattu vedehiputto manusso, ahampi manusso. ayaÃ±hi rÄjÄ mÄgadho ajÄtasattu vedehiputto paÃ±cahi kÄmaguá¹‡ehi samappito samaá¹…gÄ«bhÅ«to paricÄreti, devo maÃ±Ã±e. ahaá¹ƒ panamhissa kassako gahapatiko karakÄrako rÄsivaá¸á¸hako. so vatassÄhaá¹ƒ puÃ±Ã±Äni kareyyaá¹ƒ. yaá¹ƒnÅ«nÄhaá¹ƒ kesamassuá¹ƒ ohÄretvÄ kÄsÄyÄni vatthÄni acchÄdetvÄ agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajeyyaâ€™nti. "so aparena samayena appaá¹ƒ vÄ bhogakkhandhaá¹ƒ pahÄya mahantaá¹ƒ vÄ bhogakkhandhaá¹ƒ pahÄya, appaá¹ƒ vÄ Ã±Ätiparivaá¹­á¹­aá¹ƒ pahÄya mahantaá¹ƒ vÄ Ã±Ätiparivaá¹­á¹­aá¹ƒ pahÄya kesamassuá¹ƒ ohÄretvÄ kÄsÄyÄni vatthÄni acchÄdetvÄ
"Certainly not, venerable sir." Then rather, we would pay homage to him, rise up out of respect for him, invite him to a seat, and invite him to accept from us robes (cÄ«vara), almsfood (piá¹‡á¸apÄta), dwelling (senÄsana), and medicinal requirements (gilÄnappaccayabhesajjaparikkhÄrehi). And we would provide him with righteous protection, defense, and security."
185. pabbajito samÄno kÄyena saá¹ƒvuto viharati, vÄcÄya saá¹ƒvuto viharati, manasÄ saá¹ƒvuto viharati, ghÄsacchÄdanaparamatÄya santuá¹­á¹­ho, abhirato pavivekeâ€™ti. api nu tvaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ vadeyyÄsi â€“ â€˜etu me, bho, so puriso, punadeva hotu dÄso kammakÄro pubbuá¹­á¹­hÄyÄ« pacchÄnipÄtÄ« kiá¹…kÄrapaá¹­issÄvÄ« manÄpacÄrÄ« piyavÄdÄ« mukhullokakoâ€™ti? 184. "no hetaá¹ƒ, bhante. atha kho naá¹ƒ mayameva abhivÄdeyyÄmapi, paccuá¹­á¹­heyyÄmapi, Äsanenapi nimanteyyÄma, abhinimanteyyÄmapi naá¹ƒ cÄ«varapiá¹‡á¸apÄtasenÄsanagilÄnappaccayabhesajjaparikkhÄrehi, dhammikampissa rakkhÄvaraá¹‡aguttiá¹ƒ saá¹ƒvidaheyyÄmÄ"ti. 185. "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, mahÄrÄja, yadi evaá¹ƒ sante hoti vÄ sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ no vÄ"ti? "addhÄ kho, bhante, evaá¹ƒ sante hoti sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphala"nti. "idaá¹ƒ kho te, mahÄrÄja, mayÄ paá¹­hamaá¹ƒ diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±atta"nti. dutiyasandiá¹­á¹­hikasÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ 186. "sakkÄ pana, bhante, aÃ±Ã±ampi evameva diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apetu"nti? "sakkÄ, mahÄrÄja. tena hi, mahÄrÄja, taÃ±Ã±evettha paá¹­ipucchissÄmi. yathÄ te khameyya, tathÄ naá¹ƒ byÄkareyyÄsi. taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, mahÄrÄja, idha te assa puriso kassako gahapatiko karakÄrako rÄsivaá¸á¸hako. tassa evamassa â€“ â€˜acchariyaá¹ƒ vata bho, abbhutaá¹ƒ vata bho, puÃ±Ã±Änaá¹ƒ gati, puÃ±Ã±Änaá¹ƒ vipÄko. ayaÃ±hi rÄjÄ mÄgadho ajÄtasattu vedehiputto manusso, ahampi manusso. ayaÃ±hi rÄjÄ mÄgadho ajÄtasattu vedehiputto paÃ±cahi kÄmaguá¹‡ehi samappito samaá¹…gÄ«bhÅ«to paricÄreti, devo maÃ±Ã±e. ahaá¹ƒ panamhissa kassako gahapatiko karakÄrako rÄsivaá¸á¸hako. so vatassÄhaá¹ƒ puÃ±Ã±Äni kareyyaá¹ƒ. yaá¹ƒnÅ«nÄhaá¹ƒ kesamassuá¹ƒ ohÄretvÄ kÄsÄyÄni vatthÄni acchÄdetvÄ agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajeyyaâ€™nti. "so aparena samayena appaá¹ƒ vÄ bhogakkhandhaá¹ƒ pahÄya mahantaá¹ƒ vÄ bhogakkhandhaá¹ƒ pahÄya, appaá¹ƒ vÄ Ã±Ätiparivaá¹­á¹­aá¹ƒ pahÄya mahantaá¹ƒ vÄ Ã±Ätiparivaá¹­á¹­aá¹ƒ pahÄya kesamassuá¹ƒ ohÄretvÄ kÄsÄyÄni vatthÄni acchÄdetvÄ
"What do you think, great king? If such is the case, is there or is there not a visible fruit of recluseship (sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ)?" "Assuredly, venerable sir, if such is the case, there is a visible fruit of recluseship (sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ)." "This, great king, is the first fruit of recluseship (sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ), visible here and now (diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme), that I point out to you." The second visible fruit of recluseship (dutiyasandiá¹­á¹­hikasÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ).
186. pabbajito samÄno kÄyena saá¹ƒvuto viharati, vÄcÄya saá¹ƒvuto viharati, manasÄ saá¹ƒvuto viharati, ghÄsacchÄdanaparamatÄya santuá¹­á¹­ho, abhirato pavivekeâ€™ti. api nu tvaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ vadeyyÄsi â€“ â€˜etu me, bho, so puriso, punadeva hotu dÄso kammakÄro pubbuá¹­á¹­hÄyÄ« pacchÄnipÄtÄ« kiá¹…kÄrapaá¹­issÄvÄ« manÄpacÄrÄ« piyavÄdÄ« mukhullokakoâ€™ti? 184. "no hetaá¹ƒ, bhante. atha kho naá¹ƒ mayameva abhivÄdeyyÄmapi, paccuá¹­á¹­heyyÄmapi, Äsanenapi nimanteyyÄma, abhinimanteyyÄmapi naá¹ƒ cÄ«varapiá¹‡á¸apÄtasenÄsanagilÄnappaccayabhesajjaparikkhÄrehi, dhammikampissa rakkhÄvaraá¹‡aguttiá¹ƒ saá¹ƒvidaheyyÄmÄ"ti. 185. "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, mahÄrÄja, yadi evaá¹ƒ sante hoti vÄ sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ no vÄ"ti? "addhÄ kho, bhante, evaá¹ƒ sante hoti sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphala"nti. "idaá¹ƒ kho te, mahÄrÄja, mayÄ paá¹­hamaá¹ƒ diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±atta"nti. dutiyasandiá¹­á¹­hikasÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ 186. "sakkÄ pana, bhante, aÃ±Ã±ampi evameva diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apetu"nti? "sakkÄ, mahÄrÄja. tena hi, mahÄrÄja, taÃ±Ã±evettha paá¹­ipucchissÄmi. yathÄ te khameyya, tathÄ naá¹ƒ byÄkareyyÄsi. taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, mahÄrÄja, idha te assa puriso kassako gahapatiko karakÄrako rÄsivaá¸á¸hako. tassa evamassa â€“ â€˜acchariyaá¹ƒ vata bho, abbhutaá¹ƒ vata bho, puÃ±Ã±Änaá¹ƒ gati, puÃ±Ã±Änaá¹ƒ vipÄko. ayaÃ±hi rÄjÄ mÄgadho ajÄtasattu vedehiputto manusso, ahampi manusso. ayaÃ±hi rÄjÄ mÄgadho ajÄtasattu vedehiputto paÃ±cahi kÄmaguá¹‡ehi samappito samaá¹…gÄ«bhÅ«to paricÄreti, devo maÃ±Ã±e. ahaá¹ƒ panamhissa kassako gahapatiko karakÄrako rÄsivaá¸á¸hako. so vatassÄhaá¹ƒ puÃ±Ã±Äni kareyyaá¹ƒ. yaá¹ƒnÅ«nÄhaá¹ƒ kesamassuá¹ƒ ohÄretvÄ kÄsÄyÄni vatthÄni acchÄdetvÄ agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajeyyaâ€™nti. "so aparena samayena appaá¹ƒ vÄ bhogakkhandhaá¹ƒ pahÄya mahantaá¹ƒ vÄ bhogakkhandhaá¹ƒ pahÄya, appaá¹ƒ vÄ Ã±Ätiparivaá¹­á¹­aá¹ƒ pahÄya mahantaá¹ƒ vÄ Ã±Ätiparivaá¹­á¹­aá¹ƒ pahÄya kesamassuá¹ƒ ohÄretvÄ kÄsÄyÄni vatthÄni acchÄdetvÄ
"Is it possible, venerable sir, to point out some other fruit of recluseship (sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ) visible here and now (diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme)?" "It is possible, great king. "Well then, great king, I will question you about this same matter. Answer as you see fit. What do you think, great king? Suppose there is a farmer (kassako), a householder (gahapatiko), who pays taxes (karakÄrako) to maintain the royal revenue, one who increases his store (rÄsivaá¸á¸hako). He might think: â€œIt is strange, it is wonderful, the destiny (gati) and fruits (vipÄko) of meritorious deeds (puÃ±Ã±Änaá¹ƒ)! This King AjÄtasattu, son of the Videhi princess, is a man, and I too am a man. This King AjÄtasattu, son of the Videhi princess, enjoys himself fully endowed and supplied with the five strands of sense pleasure, as if he were a god, I think. Whereas I am a farmer, a householder, who pays taxes to maintain the royal revenue, one who increases his store. I ought to do meritorious deeds (puÃ±Ã±Äni kareyyaá¹ƒ). What if I were to shave off my hair and beard (kesamassuá¹ƒ ohÄretvÄ), put on the ochre robes (kÄsÄyÄni vatthÄni acchÄdetvÄ), and go forth from the household life into homelessness (agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajeyya)â€™nti. "After some time, he abandons his accumulation of wealth, be it large or small, abandons his circle of relatives, be it large or small; he shaves off his hair and beard (kesamassuá¹ƒ ohÄretvÄ), puts on saffron robes (kÄsÄyÄni vatthÄni acchÄdetvÄ, He should go forth from the household life into homelessness. Having thus gone forth, he dwells restrained in body, restrained in speech, restrained in mind, content with the bare necessities of food and clothing, delighting in solitude. And if people were to announce to you: "Sire, you should know that so-and-so, that man of yours who was a farmer, a householder, a tax-payer, a revenue-increaser, has now shaved off his hair and beard, put on the saffron robes, and gone forth from the household life into homelessness." Having thus gone forth, he lives restrained in body, restrained in speech, restrained in mind, content with the bare necessities of food and clothing, delighting in solitude. Would you then say: "Let that man come back to me, men. Let him again become a farmer, a householder, a tax-payer, a revenue-increaser?"

"Is it possible, venerable sir, to point out any other fruit of recluseship visible here and now, more excellent and sublime than these two fruits?" "It is possible, great king. "sakkÄ pana, bhante, aÃ±Ã±ampi diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apetuá¹ƒ imehi sandiá¹­á¹­hikehi sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalehi abhikkantataraÃ±ca paá¹‡Ä«tataraÃ±cÄ"ti? "sakkÄ, mahÄrÄja. tena hi, mahÄrÄja, suá¹‡ohi, sÄdhukaá¹ƒ manasi karohi, bhÄsissÄmÄ«"ti. "evaá¹ƒ, bhante"ti kho rÄjÄ mÄgadho ajÄtasattu vedehiputto bhagavato paccassosi. 190. bhagavÄ etadavoca â€“ "idha, mahÄrÄja, tathÄgato loke uppajjati arahaá¹ƒ sammÄsambuddho vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampanno sugato lokavidÅ« anuttaro purisadammasÄrathi satthÄ devamanussÄnaá¹ƒ buddho bhagavÄ. so
The Blessed One said this: "Here, great king, a *TathÄgata* arises in the world, an *arahant*, a fully enlightened *Buddha*, endowed with wisdom and conduct, a *Sugata*, a knower of the world, unsurpassed trainer of men to be tamed, teacher of gods and humans, enlightened, blessed. He makes knownâ€”having realized it through direct knowledgeâ€”this world with its *devas*, *MÄras*, & *BrahmÄs*, its generations with their contemplatives & brahmans, their rulers & commonfolk; He teaches the *Dhamma* admirable in the beginning, admirable in the middle, admirable in the end; he expounds the holy life both in its particulars & in its essence, entirely perfect, surpassingly pure.
191. imaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ sadevakaá¹ƒ samÄrakaá¹ƒ sabrahmakaá¹ƒ sassamaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡iá¹ƒ pajaá¹ƒ sadevamanussaá¹ƒ sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ pavedeti. so dhammaá¹ƒ deseti ÄdikalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ majjhekalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ pariyosÄnakalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ sÄtthaá¹ƒ sabyaÃ±janaá¹ƒ, kevalaparipuá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ parisuddhaá¹ƒ brahmacariyaá¹ƒ pakÄseti. 191. "taá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ suá¹‡Äti gahapati vÄ gahapatiputto vÄ aÃ±Ã±atarasmiá¹ƒ vÄ kule paccÄjÄto. so taá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ sutvÄ tathÄgate saddhaá¹ƒ paá¹­ilabhati. so tena saddhÄpaá¹­ilÄbhena samannÄgato iti paá¹­isaÃ±cikkhati â€“ â€˜sambÄdho gharÄvÄso rajopatho, abbhokÄso pabbajjÄ. nayidaá¹ƒ sukaraá¹ƒ agÄraá¹ƒ ajjhÄvasatÄ ekantaparipuá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ ekantaparisuddhaá¹ƒ saá¹…khalikhitaá¹ƒ brahmacariyaá¹ƒ carituá¹ƒ. yaá¹ƒnÅ«nÄhaá¹ƒ kesamassuá¹ƒ ohÄretvÄ kÄsÄyÄni vatthÄni acchÄdetvÄ agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajeyyaâ€™nti. 192. "so aparena samayena appaá¹ƒ vÄ bhogakkhandhaá¹ƒ pahÄya mahantaá¹ƒ vÄ bhogakkhandhaá¹ƒ pahÄya appaá¹ƒ vÄ Ã±Ätiparivaá¹­á¹­aá¹ƒ pahÄya mahantaá¹ƒ vÄ Ã±Ätiparivaá¹­á¹­aá¹ƒ pahÄya kesamassuá¹ƒ ohÄretvÄ kÄsÄyÄni vatthÄni acchÄdetvÄ agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajati. 193. "so evaá¹ƒ pabbajito samÄno pÄtimokkhasaá¹ƒvarasaá¹ƒvuto viharati ÄcÄragocarasampanno, aá¹‡umattesu vajjesu bhayadassÄvÄ«, samÄdÄya sikkhati sikkhÄpadesu, kÄyakammavacÄ«kammena samannÄgato kusalena, parisuddhÄjÄ«vo sÄ«lasampanno, indriyesu guttadvÄro [guttadvÄro, bhojane mattaÃ±Ã±Å« (ka.)], satisampajaÃ±Ã±ena samannÄgato, santuá¹­á¹­ho. cÅ«á¸·asÄ«laá¹ƒ 194. "kathaÃ±ca, mahÄrÄja, bhikkhu sÄ«lasampanno hoti? idha, mahÄrÄja, bhikkhu pÄá¹‡ÄtipÄtaá¹ƒ pahÄya pÄá¹‡ÄtipÄtÄ paá¹­ivirato hoti. nihitadaá¹‡á¸o nihitasattho lajjÄ« dayÄpanno sabbapÄá¹‡abhÅ«tahitÄnukampÄ« viharati. idampissa hoti sÄ«lasmiá¹ƒ.
"A householder or a householderâ€™s son or one born in some other clan hears that *Dhamma*. Having heard this *Dhamma*, he gains faith in the *TathÄgata*. Possessing that faith, he considers thus: 'Household life is crowded and dusty; life gone forth is wide open. It is not easy while living in a home to lead the holy life utterly perfect and pure as a polished shell. What if I were to shave off my hair & beard, put on the ochre robes, and go forth from the household life into homelessness?â€™
192. imaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ sadevakaá¹ƒ samÄrakaá¹ƒ sabrahmakaá¹ƒ sassamaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡iá¹ƒ pajaá¹ƒ sadevamanussaá¹ƒ sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ pavedeti. so dhammaá¹ƒ deseti ÄdikalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ majjhekalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ pariyosÄnakalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ sÄtthaá¹ƒ sabyaÃ±janaá¹ƒ, kevalaparipuá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ parisuddhaá¹ƒ brahmacariyaá¹ƒ pakÄseti. 191. "taá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ suá¹‡Äti gahapati vÄ gahapatiputto vÄ aÃ±Ã±atarasmiá¹ƒ vÄ kule paccÄjÄto. so taá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ sutvÄ tathÄgate saddhaá¹ƒ paá¹­ilabhati. so tena saddhÄpaá¹­ilÄbhena samannÄgato iti paá¹­isaÃ±cikkhati â€“ â€˜sambÄdho gharÄvÄso rajopatho, abbhokÄso pabbajjÄ. nayidaá¹ƒ sukaraá¹ƒ agÄraá¹ƒ ajjhÄvasatÄ ekantaparipuá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ ekantaparisuddhaá¹ƒ saá¹…khalikhitaá¹ƒ brahmacariyaá¹ƒ carituá¹ƒ. yaá¹ƒnÅ«nÄhaá¹ƒ kesamassuá¹ƒ ohÄretvÄ kÄsÄyÄni vatthÄni acchÄdetvÄ agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajeyyaâ€™nti. 192. "so aparena samayena appaá¹ƒ vÄ bhogakkhandhaá¹ƒ pahÄya mahantaá¹ƒ vÄ bhogakkhandhaá¹ƒ pahÄya appaá¹ƒ vÄ Ã±Ätiparivaá¹­á¹­aá¹ƒ pahÄya mahantaá¹ƒ vÄ Ã±Ätiparivaá¹­á¹­aá¹ƒ pahÄya kesamassuá¹ƒ ohÄretvÄ kÄsÄyÄni vatthÄni acchÄdetvÄ agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajati. 193. "kathaÃ±ca, mahÄrÄja, bhikkhu sÄ«lasampanno hoti? idha, mahÄrÄja, bhikkhu pÄá¹‡ÄtipÄtaá¹ƒ pahÄya pÄá¹‡ÄtipÄtÄ paá¹­ivirato hoti. nihitadaá¹‡á¸o nihitasattho lajjÄ« dayÄpanno sabbapÄá¹‡abhÅ«tahitÄnukampÄ« viharati. idampissa hoti sÄ«lasmiá¹ƒ.
"After some time he abandons his accumulation of wealth, be it large or small; he abandons his circle of relatives, be it large or small; he shaves off his hair and beard, puts on saffron robes, and goes forth from home to homelessness.
193. imaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ sadevakaá¹ƒ samÄrakaá¹ƒ sabrahmakaá¹ƒ sassamaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡iá¹ƒ pajaá¹ƒ sadevamanussaá¹ƒ sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ pavedeti. so dhammaá¹ƒ deseti ÄdikalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ majjhekalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ pariyosÄnakalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ sÄtthaá¹ƒ sabyaÃ±janaá¹ƒ, kevalaparipuá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ parisuddhaá¹ƒ brahmacariyaá¹ƒ pakÄseti. 191. "taá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ suá¹‡Äti gahapati vÄ gahapatiputto vÄ aÃ±Ã±atarasmiá¹ƒ vÄ kule paccÄjÄto. so taá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ sutvÄ tathÄgate saddhaá¹ƒ paá¹­ilabhati. so tena saddhÄpaá¹­ilÄbhena samannÄgato iti paá¹­isaÃ±cikkhati â€“ â€˜sambÄdho gharÄvÄso rajopatho, abbhokÄso pabbajjÄ. nayidaá¹ƒ sukaraá¹ƒ agÄraá¹ƒ ajjhÄvasatÄ ekantaparipuá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ ekantaparisuddhaá¹ƒ saá¹…khalikhitaá¹ƒ brahmacariyaá¹ƒ carituá¹ƒ. yaá¹ƒnÅ«nÄhaá¹ƒ kesamassuá¹ƒ ohÄretvÄ kÄsÄyÄni vatthÄni acchÄdetvÄ agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajeyyaâ€™nti. 192. "so aparena samayena appaá¹ƒ vÄ bhogakkhandhaá¹ƒ pahÄya mahantaá¹ƒ vÄ bhogakkhandhaá¹ƒ pahÄya appaá¹ƒ vÄ Ã±Ätiparivaá¹­á¹­aá¹ƒ pahÄya mahantaá¹ƒ vÄ Ã±Ätiparivaá¹­á¹­aá¹ƒ pahÄya kesamassuá¹ƒ ohÄretvÄ kÄsÄyÄni vatthÄni acchÄdetvÄ agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajati. 193. "so evaá¹ƒ pabbajito samÄno pÄtimokkhasaá¹ƒvarasaá¹ƒvuto viharati ÄcÄragocarasampanno, aá¹‡umattesu vajjesu bhayadassÄvÄ«, samÄdÄya sikkhati sikkhÄpadesu, kÄyakammavacÄ«kammena samannÄgato kusalena, parisuddhÄjÄ«vo sÄ«lasampanno, indriyesu guttadvÄro [guttadvÄro, bhojane mattaÃ±Ã±Å« (ka.)], satisampajaÃ±Ã±ena samannÄgato, santuá¹­á¹­ho. cÅ«á¸·asÄ«laá¹ƒ 194. "kathaÃ±ca, mahÄrÄja, bhikkhu sÄ«lasampanno hoti? idha, mahÄrÄja, bhikkhu pÄá¹‡ÄtipÄtaá¹ƒ pahÄya pÄá¹‡ÄtipÄtÄ paá¹­ivirato hoti. nihitadaá¹‡á¸o nihitasattho lajjÄ« dayÄpanno sabbapÄá¹‡abhÅ«tahitÄnukampÄ« viharati. idampissa hoti sÄ«lasmiá¹ƒ.
"And having gone forth, he dwells restrained by the restraint of the *PÄtimokkha*, possessed of proper behavior and resort. Having taken up the rules of training, he trains himself in them, seeing danger in the slightest faults. He comes to be endowed with wholesome bodily and verbal action, his livelihood is purified, and he is possessed of moral discipline. He guards the doors of his sense faculties, is endowed with mindfulness and clear comprehension, and is content. The Lesser Morality
194. imaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ sadevakaá¹ƒ samÄrakaá¹ƒ sabrahmakaá¹ƒ sassamaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡iá¹ƒ pajaá¹ƒ sadevamanussaá¹ƒ sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ pavedeti. so dhammaá¹ƒ deseti ÄdikalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ majjhekalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ pariyosÄnakalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ sÄtthaá¹ƒ sabyaÃ±janaá¹ƒ, kevalaparipuá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ parisuddhaá¹ƒ brahmacariyaá¹ƒ pakÄseti. 191. "taá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ suá¹‡Äti gahapati vÄ gahapatiputto vÄ aÃ±Ã±atarasmiá¹ƒ vÄ kule paccÄjÄto. so taá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ sutvÄ tathÄgate saddhaá¹ƒ paá¹­ilabhati. so tena saddhÄpaá¹­ilÄbhena samannÄgato iti paá¹­isaÃ±cikkhati â€“ â€˜sambÄdho gharÄvÄso rajopatho, abbhokÄso pabbajjÄ. nayidaá¹ƒ sukaraá¹ƒ agÄraá¹ƒ ajjhÄvasatÄ ekantaparipuá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ ekantaparisuddhaá¹ƒ saá¹…khalikhitaá¹ƒ brahmacariyaá¹ƒ carituá¹ƒ. yaá¹ƒnÅ«nÄhaá¹ƒ kesamassuá¹ƒ ohÄretvÄ kÄsÄyÄni vatthÄni acchÄdetvÄ agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajeyyaâ€™nti. 192. "so aparena samayena appaá¹ƒ vÄ bhogakkhandhaá¹ƒ pahÄya mahantaá¹ƒ vÄ bhogakkhandhaá¹ƒ pahÄya appaá¹ƒ vÄ Ã±Ätiparivaá¹­á¹­aá¹ƒ pahÄya mahantaá¹ƒ vÄ Ã±Ätiparivaá¹­á¹­aá¹ƒ pahÄya kesamassuá¹ƒ ohÄretvÄ kÄsÄyÄni vatthÄni acchÄdetvÄ agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajati. 193. "so evaá¹ƒ pabbajito samÄno pÄtimokkhasaá¹ƒvarasaá¹ƒvuto viharati ÄcÄragocarasampanno, aá¹‡umattesu vajjesu bhayadassÄvÄ«, samÄdÄya sikkhati sikkhÄpadesu, kÄyakammavacÄ«kammena samannÄgato kusalena, parisuddhÄjÄ«vo sÄ«lasampanno, indriyesu guttadvÄro [guttadvÄro, bhojane mattaÃ±Ã±Å« (ka.)], satisampajaÃ±Ã±ena samannÄgato, santuá¹­á¹­ho. cÅ«á¸·asÄ«laá¹ƒ 194. "kathaÃ±ca, mahÄrÄja, bhikkhu sÄ«lasampanno hoti? idha, mahÄrÄja, bhikkhu pÄá¹‡ÄtipÄtaá¹ƒ pahÄya pÄá¹‡ÄtipÄtÄ paá¹­ivirato hoti. nihitadaá¹‡á¸o nihitasattho lajjÄ« dayÄpanno sabbapÄá¹‡abhÅ«tahitÄnukampÄ« viharati. idampissa hoti sÄ«lasmiá¹ƒ.
"And how, great king, is a *bhikkhu* perfected in morality? Here, great king, having abandoned the destruction of life, the *bhikkhu* abstains from the destruction of life. He has laid down the rod and weapon and dwells conscientious, full of kindness, sympathetic for the welfare of all living beings. This pertains to his moral discipline. He abstains from accepting cocks and pigs. He abstains from accepting elephants, cattle, horses and mares. He abstains from accepting fields and plots. He abstains from running errands. He abstains from buying and selling. He abstains from cheating with false weights, false metals, and false measures. He abstains from the crooked ways of bribery, deception, and fraud. â€œHe abstains from mutilating, executing, imprisoning, robbery, plunder, and violence. This pertains to his moral discipline. The Lesser Morality is finished. The Middle Morality
195. kukkuá¹­asÅ«karapaá¹­iggahaá¹‡Ä paá¹­ivirato hoti. hatthigavassavaá¸·avapaá¹­iggahaá¹‡Ä paá¹­ivirato hoti. khettavatthupaá¹­iggahaá¹‡Ä paá¹­ivirato hoti. dÅ«teyyapahiá¹‡agamanÄnuyogÄ paá¹­ivirato hoti. kayavikkayÄ paá¹­ivirato hoti. tulÄkÅ«á¹­akaá¹ƒsakÅ«á¹­amÄnakÅ«á¹­Ä paá¹­ivirato hoti. ukkoá¹­anavaÃ±cananikatisÄciyogÄ paá¹­ivirato hoti. chedanavadhabandhanaviparÄmosaÄlopasahasÄkÄrÄ paá¹­ivirato hoti. idampissa hoti sÄ«lasmiá¹ƒ. cÅ«á¸·asÄ«laá¹ƒ niá¹­á¹­hitaá¹ƒ. majjhimasÄ«laá¹ƒ 195. "yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«paá¹ƒ bÄ«jagÄmabhÅ«tagÄmasamÄrambhaá¹ƒ anuyuttÄ viharanti. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ mÅ«labÄ«jaá¹ƒ khandhabÄ«jaá¹ƒ phaá¸·ubÄ«jaá¹ƒ aggabÄ«jaá¹ƒ bÄ«jabÄ«jameva paÃ±camaá¹ƒ, iti evarÅ«pÄ bÄ«jagÄmabhÅ«tagÄmasamÄrambhÄ paá¹­ivirato hoti. idampissa hoti sÄ«lasmiá¹ƒ. 196. "yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«paá¹ƒ sannidhikÄraparibhogaá¹ƒ anuyuttÄ viharanti. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ annasannidhiá¹ƒ pÄnasannidhiá¹ƒ vatthasannidhiá¹ƒ yÄnasannidhiá¹ƒ sayanasannidhiá¹ƒ gandhasannidhiá¹ƒ Ämisasannidhiá¹ƒ, iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄ sannidhikÄraparibhogÄ paá¹­ivirato hoti. idampissa hoti sÄ«lasmiá¹ƒ. 197. "yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«paá¹ƒ visÅ«kadassanaá¹ƒ anuyuttÄ viharanti. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ naccaá¹ƒ gÄ«taá¹ƒ vÄditaá¹ƒ pekkhaá¹ƒ akkhÄnaá¹ƒ pÄá¹‡issaraá¹ƒ vetÄá¸·aá¹ƒ kumbhathÅ«á¹‡aá¹ƒ sobhanakaá¹ƒ caá¹‡á¸Älaá¹ƒ vaá¹ƒsaá¹ƒ dhovanaá¹ƒ hatthiyuddhaá¹ƒ assayuddhaá¹ƒ mahiá¹ƒsayuddhaá¹ƒ usabhayuddhaá¹ƒ ajayuddhaá¹ƒ meá¹‡á¸ayuddhaá¹ƒ kukkuá¹­ayuddhaá¹ƒ vaá¹­á¹­akayuddhaá¹ƒ daá¹‡á¸ayuddhaá¹ƒ muá¹­á¹­hiyuddhaá¹ƒ nibbuddhaá¹ƒ uyyodhikaá¹ƒ balaggaá¹ƒ senÄbyÅ«haá¹ƒ anÄ«kadassanaá¹ƒ iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄ visÅ«kadassanÄ paá¹­ivirato hoti. idampissa hoti sÄ«lasmiá¹ƒ.
â€œWhereas some honourable ascetics and Brahmins, while living on food offered by the faithful, are addicted to continually causing damage to seed and plant lifeâ€” as are propagated from roots (mÅ«labÄ«jaá¹ƒ), from stems (khandhabÄ«jaá¹ƒ), from joints (phaá¸·ubÄ«jaá¹ƒ), from cuttings (aggabÄ«jaá¹ƒ), from seeds (bÄ«jabÄ«jameva paÃ±camaá¹ƒ), the he refrains from such destruction. This pertains to his moral discipline.
196. kukkuá¹­asÅ«karapaá¹­iggahaá¹‡Ä paá¹­ivirato hoti. hatthigavassavaá¸·avapaá¹­iggahaá¹‡Ä paá¹­ivirato hoti. khettavatthupaá¹­iggahaá¹‡Ä paá¹­ivirato hoti. dÅ«teyyapahiá¹‡agamanÄnuyogÄ paá¹­ivirato hoti. kayavikkayÄ paá¹­ivirato hoti. tulÄkÅ«á¹­akaá¹ƒsakÅ«á¹­amÄnakÅ«á¹­Ä paá¹­ivirato hoti. ukkoá¹­anavaÃ±cananikatisÄciyogÄ paá¹­ivirato hoti. chedanavadhabandhanaviparÄmosaÄlopasahasÄkÄrÄ paá¹­ivirato hoti. idampissa hoti sÄ«lasmiá¹ƒ. cÅ«á¸·asÄ«laá¹ƒ niá¹­á¹­hitaá¹ƒ. majjhimasÄ«laá¹ƒ 195. "yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«paá¹ƒ visÅ«kadassanaá¹ƒ anuyuttÄ viharanti. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ naccaá¹ƒ gÄ«taá¹ƒ vÄditaá¹ƒ pekkhaá¹ƒ akkhÄnaá¹ƒ pÄá¹‡issaraá¹ƒ vetÄá¸·aá¹ƒ kumbhathÅ«á¹‡aá¹ƒ sobhanakaá¹ƒ caá¹‡á¸Älaá¹ƒ vaá¹ƒsaá¹ƒ dhovanaá¹ƒ hatthiyuddhaá¹ƒ assayuddhaá¹ƒ mahiá¹ƒsayuddhaá¹ƒ usabhayuddhaá¹ƒ ajayuddhaá¹ƒ meá¹‡á¸ayuddhaá¹ƒ kukkuá¹­ayuddhaá¹ƒ vaá¹­á¹­akayuddhaá¹ƒ daá¹‡á¸ayuddhaá¹ƒ muá¹­á¹­hiyuddhaá¹ƒ nibbuddhaá¹ƒ uyyodhikaá¹ƒ balaggaá¹ƒ senÄbyÅ«haá¹ƒ anÄ«kadassanaá¹ƒ iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄ visÅ«kadassanÄ paá¹­ivirato hoti. idampissa hoti sÄ«lasmiá¹ƒ.
â€œWhereas some honourable ascetics and Brahmins, while living on food offered by the faithful, enjoy the use of stored-up goods, such as stored-up food (annasannidhiá¹ƒ), drinks (pÄnasannidhiá¹ƒ), garments (vatthasannidhiá¹ƒ), vehicles (yÄnasannidhiá¹ƒ), bedding (sayanasannidhiá¹ƒ), scents (gandhasannidhiá¹ƒ), and comestibles (Ämisasannidhiá¹ƒ)â€”he abstains from the use of stored-up goods. This pertains to his moral discipline.
197. kukkuá¹­asÅ«karapaá¹­iggahaá¹‡Ä paá¹­ivirato hoti. hatthigavassavaá¸·avapaá¹­iggahaá¹‡Ä paá¹­ivirato hoti. khettavatthupaá¹­iggahaá¹‡Ä paá¹­ivirato hoti. dÅ«teyyapahiá¹‡agamanÄnuyogÄ paá¹­ivirato hoti. kayavikkayÄ paá¹­ivirato hoti. tulÄkÅ«á¹­akaá¹ƒsakÅ«á¹­amÄnakÅ«á¹­Ä paá¹­ivirato hoti. ukkoá¹­anavaÃ±cananikatisÄciyogÄ paá¹­ivirato hoti. chedanavadhabandhanaviparÄmosaÄlopasahasÄkÄrÄ paá¹­ivirato hoti. idampissa hoti sÄ«lasmiá¹ƒ. cÅ«á¸·asÄ«laá¹ƒ niá¹­á¹­hitaá¹ƒ. majjhimasÄ«laá¹ƒ 195. "yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«paá¹ƒ bÄ«jagÄmabhÅ«tagÄmasamÄrambhaá¹ƒ anuyuttÄ viharanti. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ mÅ«labÄ«jaá¹ƒ khandhabÄ«jaá¹ƒ phaá¸·ubÄ«jaá¹ƒ aggabÄ«jaá¹ƒ bÄ«jabÄ«jameva paÃ±camaá¹ƒ, iti evarÅ«pÄ bÄ«jagÄmabhÅ«tagÄmasamÄrambhÄ paá¹­ivirato hoti. idampissa hoti sÄ«lasmiá¹ƒ. 196. "yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«paá¹ƒ sannidhikÄraparibhogaá¹ƒ anuyuttÄ viharanti. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ annasannidhiá¹ƒ pÄnasannidhiá¹ƒ vatthasannidhiá¹ƒ yÄnasannidhiá¹ƒ sayanasannidhiá¹ƒ gandhasannidhiá¹ƒ Ämisasannidhiá¹ƒ, iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄ sannidhikÄraparibhogÄ paá¹­ivirato hoti. idampissa hoti sÄ«lasmiá¹ƒ. 197. "yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«paá¹ƒ visÅ«kadassanaá¹ƒ anuyuttÄ viharanti. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ naccaá¹ƒ gÄ«taá¹ƒ vÄditaá¹ƒ pekkhaá¹ƒ akkhÄnaá¹ƒ pÄá¹‡issaraá¹ƒ vetÄá¸·aá¹ƒ kumbhathÅ«á¹‡aá¹ƒ sobhanakaá¹ƒ caá¹‡á¸Älaá¹ƒ vaá¹ƒsaá¹ƒ dhovanaá¹ƒ hatthiyuddhaá¹ƒ assayuddhaá¹ƒ mahiá¹ƒsayuddhaá¹ƒ usabhayuddhaá¹ƒ ajayuddhaá¹ƒ meá¹‡á¸ayuddhaá¹ƒ kukkuá¹­ayuddhaá¹ƒ vaá¹­á¹­akayuddhaá¹ƒ daá¹‡á¸ayuddhaá¹ƒ muá¹­á¹­hiyuddhaá¹ƒ nibbuddhaá¹ƒ uyyodhikaá¹ƒ balaggaá¹ƒ senÄbyÅ«haá¹ƒ anÄ«kadassanaá¹ƒ iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄ visÅ«kadassanÄ paá¹­ivirato hoti. idampissa hoti sÄ«lasmiá¹ƒ.
â€œWhereas some honourable ascetics and Brahmins, while living on food offered by the faithful, attend unsuitable shows, such as shows featuring dancing (naccaá¹ƒ), singing (gÄ«taá¹ƒ), or instrumental music (vÄditaá¹ƒ); theatrical performances (pekkhaá¹ƒ); narrations of legends (akkhÄnaá¹ƒ); music played by hand-clapping (pÄá¹‡issaraá¹ƒ), cymbals (vetÄá¸·aá¹ƒ), and drums (kumbhathÅ«á¹‡aá¹ƒ); acrobatic performances (sobhanakaá¹ƒ); the caá¹‡á¸Äla; vaá¹ƒsaá¹ƒ; dhovanaá¹ƒ; combats of elephants (hatthiyuddhaá¹ƒ), horses (assayuddhaá¹ƒ), buffaloes (mahiá¹ƒsayuddhaá¹ƒ), bulls (usabhayuddhaá¹ƒ), goats (ajayuddhaá¹ƒ), rams (meá¹‡á¸ayuddhaá¹ƒ), cocks (kukkuá¹­ayuddhaá¹ƒ) and quails (vaá¹­á¹­akayuddhaá¹ƒ); stick-fights (daá¹‡á¸ayuddhaá¹ƒ), boxing (muá¹­á¹­hiyuddhaá¹ƒ), and wrestling (nibbuddhaá¹ƒ); uyyodhikaá¹ƒ; balaggaá¹ƒ; battle-arrays (senÄbyÅ«haá¹ƒ), and regimental reviews (anÄ«kadassanaá¹ƒ)â€”he abstains from attending such unsuitable shows. This pertains to his moral discipline.

"yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«paá¹ƒ maá¹‡á¸anavibhÅ«sanaá¹­á¹­hÄnÄnuyogaá¹ƒ anuyuttÄ viharanti. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ ucchÄdanaá¹ƒ parimaddanaá¹ƒ nhÄpanaá¹ƒ sambÄhanaá¹ƒ ÄdÄsaá¹ƒ aÃ±janaá¹ƒ mÄlÄgandhavilepanaá¹ƒ mukhacuá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ mukhalepanaá¹ƒ hatthabandhaá¹ƒ sikhÄbandhaá¹ƒ daá¹‡á¸aá¹ƒ nÄá¸·ikaá¹ƒ asiá¹ƒ [khaggaá¹ƒ (sÄ«. pÄ«.), asiá¹ƒ khaggaá¹ƒ (syÄ. kaá¹ƒ.), khaggaá¹ƒ asiá¹ƒ (ka.)] chattaá¹ƒ citrupÄhanaá¹ƒ uá¹‡hÄ«saá¹ƒ maá¹‡iá¹ƒ vÄlabÄ«janiá¹ƒ odÄtÄni vatthÄni dÄ«ghadasÄni iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄ maá¹‡á¸anavibhÅ«sanaá¹­á¹­hÄnÄnuyogÄ paá¹­ivirato hoti. idampissa hoti sÄ«lasmiá¹ƒ. 201. "yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«paá¹ƒ tiracchÄnakathaá¹ƒ anuyuttÄ viharanti. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ rÄjakathaá¹ƒ corakathaá¹ƒ mahÄmattakathaá¹ƒ senÄkathaá¹ƒ bhayakathaá¹ƒ yuddhakathaá¹ƒ annakathaá¹ƒ pÄnakathaá¹ƒ vatthakathaá¹ƒ sayanakathaá¹ƒ mÄlÄkathaá¹ƒ gandhakathaá¹ƒ Ã±Ätikathaá¹ƒ yÄnakathaá¹ƒ gÄmakathaá¹ƒ nigamakathaá¹ƒ nagarakathaá¹ƒ janapadakathaá¹ƒ itthikathaá¹ƒ [itthikathaá¹ƒ purisakathaá¹ƒ kumÄrakathaá¹ƒ kumÄrikathaá¹ƒ (ka.)] sÅ«rakathaá¹ƒ visikhÄkathaá¹ƒ kumbhaá¹­á¹­hÄnakathaá¹ƒ pubbapetakathaá¹ƒ nÄnattakathaá¹ƒ
â€œWhereas some ascetics and Brahmins, while living on food offered by the faithful, remain addicted to such games and idle pursuits, namely: *aá¹£á¹­Äpada*, *daÅ›apada*, â€˜chess in the airâ€™, hopscotch, spillikins, dicing, hitting sticks, â€˜hand-picturesâ€™, ball-games, blowing through toy pipes, playing with toy ploughs, turning somersaults, playing with toy windmills, measures, carriages, and bows, guessing letters, guessing thoughts, mimicking deformities, he abstains from such games that are a basis for negligence. This pertains to his moral discipline.

"yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«paá¹ƒ tiracchÄnakathaá¹ƒ anuyuttÄ viharanti. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ rÄjakathaá¹ƒ corakathaá¹ƒ mahÄmattakathaá¹ƒ senÄkathaá¹ƒ bhayakathaá¹ƒ yuddhakathaá¹ƒ annakathaá¹ƒ pÄnakathaá¹ƒ vatthakathaá¹ƒ sayanakathaá¹ƒ mÄlÄkathaá¹ƒ gandhakathaá¹ƒ Ã±Ätikathaá¹ƒ yÄnakathaá¹ƒ gÄmakathaá¹ƒ nigamakathaá¹ƒ nagarakathaá¹ƒ janapadakathaá¹ƒ itthikathaá¹ƒ [itthikathaá¹ƒ purisakathaá¹ƒ kumÄrakathaá¹ƒ kumÄrikathaá¹ƒ (ka.)] sÅ«rakathaá¹ƒ visikhÄkathaá¹ƒ kumbhaá¹­á¹­hÄnakathaá¹ƒ pubbapetakathaá¹ƒ nÄnattakathaá¹ƒ
â€œWhereas some ascetics and Brahmins, while living on food offered by the faithful, remain addicted to high and wide beds and long chairs, namely: spacious couches; thrones with animal figures carved on the supports; long-haired coverlets; multi-coloured patchwork coverlets; white woolen coverlets; woolen coverlets embroidered with flowers; quilts stuffed with cotton; woolen coverlets embroidered with animal figures; woolen coverlets with hair on both sides or on one side; bedspreads embroidered with gems; silk coverlets; dance-hall carpets; elephant, horse, or chariot rugs; rugs of antelope-skins; choice spreads made of *kadalÄ«* deer hide, couches with awnings, or with red cushions at both ends, he refrains from such high and wide beds. This pertains to his moral discipline.

"yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«paá¹ƒ tiracchÄnakathaá¹ƒ anuyuttÄ viharanti. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ rÄjakathaá¹ƒ corakathaá¹ƒ mahÄmattakathaá¹ƒ senÄkathaá¹ƒ bhayakathaá¹ƒ yuddhakathaá¹ƒ annakathaá¹ƒ pÄnakathaá¹ƒ vatthakathaá¹ƒ sayanakathaá¹ƒ mÄlÄkathaá¹ƒ gandhakathaá¹ƒ Ã±Ätikathaá¹ƒ yÄnakathaá¹ƒ gÄmakathaá¹ƒ nigamakathaá¹ƒ nagarakathaá¹ƒ janapadakathaá¹ƒ itthikathaá¹ƒ [itthikathaá¹ƒ purisakathaá¹ƒ kumÄrakathaá¹ƒ kumÄrikathaá¹ƒ (ka.)] sÅ«rakathaá¹ƒ visikhÄkathaá¹ƒ kumbhaá¹­á¹­hÄnakathaá¹ƒ pubbapetakathaá¹ƒ nÄnattakathaá¹ƒ
â€œWhereas some ascetics and Brahmins, while living on the food offered by the faithful, remain addicted to such forms of self-adornment and embellishment, namely: rubbing scented powders into the body, massaging with oils, bathing in perfumed water, kneading the limbs, mirrors, ointments (*aÃ±jana*), garlands (*mÄlÄ*), scents (*gandha*), unguents, face-powders, make-up, bracelets (*hatthabandha*), head-bands (*Å›ikhÄbandha*), decorated walking sticks (*daá¹‡á¸a*), ornamented medicine-tubes (*nÄá¸·ika*), swords (*asi*), sunshades (*chatta*), embroidered sandals (*citrupÄhana*), turbans (*uá¹‡hÄ«sa*), diadems (*maá¹‡i*), yak-tail whisks (*vÄlabÄ«jani*), and long-fringed white robes (*odÄtÄni vatthÄni dÄ«ghadasÄni*), he abstains from the use of such devices for embellishment and beautification. This pertains to his moral discipline.

"yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«paá¹ƒ maá¹‡á¸anavibhÅ«sanaá¹­á¹­hÄnÄnuyogaá¹ƒ anuyuttÄ viharanti. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ ucchÄdanaá¹ƒ parimaddanaá¹ƒ nhÄpanaá¹ƒ sambÄhanaá¹ƒ ÄdÄsaá¹ƒ aÃ±janaá¹ƒ mÄlÄgandhavilepanaá¹ƒ mukhacuá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ mukhalepanaá¹ƒ hatthabandhaá¹ƒ sikhÄbandhaá¹ƒ daá¹‡á¸aá¹ƒ nÄá¸·ikaá¹ƒ asiá¹ƒ [khaggaá¹ƒ (sÄ«. pÄ«.), asiá¹ƒ khaggaá¹ƒ (syÄ. kaá¹ƒ.), khaggaá¹ƒ asiá¹ƒ (ka.)] chattaá¹ƒ citrupÄhanaá¹ƒ uá¹‡hÄ«saá¹ƒ maá¹‡iá¹ƒ vÄlabÄ«janiá¹ƒ odÄtÄni vatthÄni dÄ«ghadasÄni iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄ maá¹‡á¸anavibhÅ«sanaá¹­á¹­hÄnÄnuyogÄ paá¹­ivirato hoti. idampissa hoti sÄ«lasmiá¹ƒ. 201. "yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«paá¹ƒ tiracchÄnakathaá¹ƒ anuyuttÄ viharanti. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ rÄjakathaá¹ƒ corakathaá¹ƒ mahÄmattakathaá¹ƒ senÄkathaá¹ƒ bhayakathaá¹ƒ yuddhakathaá¹ƒ annakathaá¹ƒ pÄnakathaá¹ƒ vatthakathaá¹ƒ sayanakathaá¹ƒ mÄlÄkathaá¹ƒ gandhakathaá¹ƒ Ã±Ätikathaá¹ƒ yÄnakathaá¹ƒ gÄmakathaá¹ƒ nigamakathaá¹ƒ nagarakathaá¹ƒ janapadakathaá¹ƒ itthikathaá¹ƒ [itthikathaá¹ƒ purisakathaá¹ƒ kumÄrakathaá¹ƒ kumÄrikathaá¹ƒ (ka.)] sÅ«rakathaá¹ƒ visikhÄkathaá¹ƒ kumbhaá¹­á¹­hÄnakathaá¹ƒ pubbapetakathaá¹ƒ nÄnattakathaá¹ƒ
â€œWhereas some ascetics and Brahmins, while living on food offered by the faithful, engage in frivolous chatter, namely: conversation about kings (*rÄjakathaá¹ƒ*), robbers (*corakathaá¹ƒ*), & ministers of state (*mahÄmattakathaá¹ƒ*); armies (*senÄkathaá¹ƒ*), alarms (*bhayakathaá¹ƒ*), & battles (*yuddhakathaá¹ƒ*); food (*annakathaá¹ƒ*) & drink (*pÄnakathaá¹ƒ*); clothing (*vatthakathaá¹ƒ*), furniture (*sayanakathaá¹ƒ*), garlands (*mÄlÄkathaá¹ƒ*), & scents (*gandhakathaá¹ƒ*); relatives (*Ã±Ätikathaá¹ƒ*); vehicles (*yÄnakathaá¹ƒ*); villages (*gÄmakathaá¹ƒ*), towns (*nigamakathaá¹ƒ*), cities (*nagarakathaá¹ƒ*), the countryside (*janapadakathaá¹ƒ*); women (*itthikathaá¹ƒ*) & heroes (*sÅ«rakathaá¹ƒ*); the gossip of the street (*visikhÄkathaá¹ƒ*) & the well (*kumbhaá¹­á¹­hÄnakathaá¹ƒ*); tales of the dead (*pubbapetakathaá¹ƒ*); tales of diversity (*nÄnattakathaá¹ƒ*), He abstains from such base conversation as talking about the world, talking about the ocean, talking about becoming and not becoming. This pertains to his moral discipline.
202. lokakkhÄyikaá¹ƒ samuddakkhÄyikaá¹ƒ itibhavÄbhavakathaá¹ƒ iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnakathÄya paá¹­ivirato hoti. idampissa hoti sÄ«lasmiá¹ƒ. 202. "yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«paá¹ƒ viggÄhikakathaá¹ƒ anuyuttÄ viharanti. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ na tvaá¹ƒ imaá¹ƒ dhammavinayaá¹ƒ ÄjÄnÄsi, ahaá¹ƒ imaá¹ƒ dhammavinayaá¹ƒ ÄjÄnÄmi, kiá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ imaá¹ƒ dhammavinayaá¹ƒ ÄjÄnissasi, micchÄ paá¹­ipanno tvamasi, ahamasmi sammÄ paá¹­ipanno, sahitaá¹ƒ me, asahitaá¹ƒ te, pure vacanÄ«yaá¹ƒ pacchÄ avaca, pacchÄ vacanÄ«yaá¹ƒ pure avaca, adhiciá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ te viparÄvattaá¹ƒ, Äropito te vÄdo, niggahito tvamasi, cara vÄdappamokkhÄya, nibbeá¹­hehi vÄ sace pahosÄ«ti iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄya viggÄhikakathÄya paá¹­ivirato hoti. idampissa hoti sÄ«lasmiá¹ƒ. 203. "yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«paá¹ƒ dÅ«teyyapahiá¹‡agamanÄnuyogaá¹ƒ anuyuttÄ viharanti. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ raÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ, rÄjamahÄmattÄnaá¹ƒ, khattiyÄnaá¹ƒ, brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ, gahapatikÄnaá¹ƒ, kumÄrÄnaá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜idha gaccha, amutrÄgaccha, idaá¹ƒ hara, amutra idaá¹ƒ ÄharÄâ€™ti iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄ dÅ«teyyapahiá¹‡agamanÄnuyogÄ paá¹­ivirato hoti. idampissa hoti sÄ«lasmiá¹ƒ. 204. "yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te kuhakÄ ca honti lapakÄ ca nemittikÄ ca nippesikÄ ca lÄbhena lÄbhaá¹ƒ nijigÄ«sitÄro ca. iti evarÅ«pÄ kuhanalapanÄ paá¹­ivirato hoti. idampissa hoti sÄ«lasmiá¹ƒ". majjhimasÄ«laá¹ƒ niá¹­á¹­hitaá¹ƒ. mahÄsÄ«laá¹ƒ 205. "yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vena jÄ«vitaá¹ƒ kappenti. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ aá¹…gaá¹ƒ nimittaá¹ƒ uppÄtaá¹ƒ supinaá¹ƒ lakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ mÅ«sikacchinnaá¹ƒ aggihomaá¹ƒ dabbihomaá¹ƒ thusahomaá¹ƒ kaá¹‡ahomaá¹ƒ taá¹‡á¸ulahomaá¹ƒ sappihomaá¹ƒ
â€œOr he might say: â€˜Whereas some recluses and brahmins, while living on the food offered by the faithful, engage in wrangling argumentation.â€™ Such as: â€˜You donâ€™t understand this *dharma*-discipline (dharma-vinaya). I am the one who understands this *dharma*-discipline.â€™ â€œHow can you understand this *dharma*-discipline?â€ â€œYouâ€™re practicing the wrong way. Iâ€™m practicing the right way.â€ â€œIâ€™m being consistent. Youâ€™re inconsistent.â€ â€œWhat should have been said first you said last, what should have been said last you said first.â€ â€œWhat you took so long to think out has been confuted.â€ â€˜Your doctrine has been refuted. Youâ€™re defeated. Go, try to save your doctrine!â€™ He refrains from such disputation. This pertains to his moral discipline.

â€œOr he might say: â€˜Whereas some *Å›ramaá¹‡as* and *brÄhmaá¹‡as*, while living on the food offered by the faithful, engage in running messages and errands.â€™ such as for kings, ministers, nobles (*ká¹£atriyas*), Brahmins (*brÄhmaá¹‡as*), householders (*gá¹›hapatis*) and young men who say: â€˜Go here â€” go there! Take this there â€” bring that from there!â€™ He refrains from such errand-running. This pertains to his moral discipline.

This pertains to his moral discipline.â€ The middling morality (majjhimasÄ«la) is finished. The great morality (mahÄsÄ«la)
205. lokakkhÄyikaá¹ƒ samuddakkhÄyikaá¹ƒ itibhavÄbhavakathaá¹ƒ iti vÄ iti evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnakathÄya paá¹­ivirato hoti. idampissa hoti sÄ«lasmiá¹ƒ. 202.
