The reed is one thing, the sheath another, but the reed has been drawn out from the sheath.' Or suppose a man were to draw a sword out from its scabbard. He would think: 'This is the sword, this is the scabbard. The sword is one thing, the scabbard another, but the sword has been drawn out from the scabbard.' Or suppose a man were to pull a snake out from its slough. He would think: 'This is the snake; this is the slough. The snake is one thing, the slough another, but the snake has been pulled out from the slough.â€™ In the same way, great king, when his mind is thus concentrated, pure and bright, unblemished, free from defects, malleable, wieldy, steady, and attained to imperturbability, the monk directs and inclines it to creating a mind-made body. He creates from this body another body having material form, mind-made, complete in all its parts, not lacking any faculties. This, great king, is a visible fruit of recluseship more excellent and sublime than the previous ones. The knowledge of the modes of supernormal power.
238. manomayiddhiÃ±Äá¹‡aá¹ƒ 236. "so evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte manomayaá¹ƒ kÄyaá¹ƒ abhinimmÄnÄya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so imamhÄ kÄyÄ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ kÄyaá¹ƒ abhinimminÄti rÅ«piá¹ƒ manomayaá¹ƒ sabbaá¹…gapaccaá¹…giá¹ƒ ahÄ«nindriyaá¹ƒ. 237. "seyyathÄpi, mahÄrÄja, puriso muÃ±jamhÄ Ä«sikaá¹ƒ pavÄheyya [pabbÄheyya (syÄ. ka.)]. tassa evamassa â€“ â€˜ayaá¹ƒ muÃ±jo, ayaá¹ƒ Ä«sikÄ, aÃ±Ã±o muÃ±jo, aÃ±Ã±Ä Ä«sikÄ, muÃ±jamhÄ tveva Ä«sikÄ pavÄá¸·hÄâ€™ti [pabbÄá¸·hÄti (syÄ. ka.)]. seyyathÄ vÄ pana, mahÄrÄja, puriso asiá¹ƒ kosiyÄ pavÄheyya. tassa evamassa â€“ â€˜ayaá¹ƒ asi, ayaá¹ƒ kosi, aÃ±Ã±o asi, aÃ±Ã±Ä kosi, kosiyÄ tveva asi pavÄá¸·ho"ti. seyyathÄ vÄ pana, mahÄrÄja, puriso ahiá¹ƒ karaá¹‡á¸Ä uddhareyya. tassa evamassa â€“ â€˜ayaá¹ƒ ahi, ayaá¹ƒ karaá¹‡á¸o. aÃ±Ã±o ahi, aÃ±Ã±o karaá¹‡á¸o, karaá¹‡á¸Ä tveva ahi ubbhatoâ€™ti [uddharito (syÄ. kaá¹ƒ.)]. evameva kho, mahÄrÄja, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte manomayaá¹ƒ kÄyaá¹ƒ abhinimmÄnÄya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so imamhÄ kÄyÄ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ kÄyaá¹ƒ abhinimminÄti rÅ«piá¹ƒ manomayaá¹ƒ sabbaá¹…gapaccaá¹…giá¹ƒ ahÄ«nindriyaá¹ƒ. idampi kho, mahÄrÄja, sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ purimehi sandiá¹­á¹­hikehi sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalehi abhikkantataraÃ±ca paá¹‡Ä«tataraÃ±ca. iddhividhaÃ±Äá¹‡aá¹ƒ 238. "so evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte iddhividhÄya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so anekavihitaá¹ƒ iddhividhaá¹ƒ paccanubhoti â€“ ekopi hutvÄ bahudhÄ hoti, bahudhÄpi hutvÄ eko hoti, ÄvibhÄvaá¹ƒ tirobhÄvaá¹ƒ tirokuá¹­á¹­aá¹ƒ tiropÄkÄraá¹ƒ tiropabbataá¹ƒ asajjamÄno gacchati seyyathÄpi ÄkÄse. pathaviyÄpi ummujjanimujjaá¹ƒ karoti seyyathÄpi udake. udakepi abhijjamÄne gacchati [abhijjamÄno (sÄ«. ka.)] seyyathÄpi
"When his mind is thus concentrated, pure and bright, unblemished, free from defects, malleable, wieldy, steady, and attained to imperturbability, he directs and inclines it to the modes of supernormal power. He experiences the manifold supernormal powers: Being one, he becomes many; being many, he becomes one; he appears and vanishes; he goes unimpeded through walls, ramparts, and mountains as if through space. He dives in and out of the earth as if it were water. He walks on the water without breaking the surface as if on land. By means of the earth. Sitting cross-legged, he travels through space like a winged bird. With his hand he touches and strokes even the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful. He exercises mastery over the body as far as the Brahma-world. "Just as, great king, a skilled potter or his apprentice were to make and fashion out of well-prepared clay whatever kind of vessel he might desire. Or suppose, great king, a skilled ivory-worker or his apprentice were to make and fashion out of well-prepared ivory whatever kind of ivory work he might desire. Or suppose, great king, a skilled goldsmith or his apprentice were to make and fashion out of well-prepared gold whatever kind of gold work he might desire. In the same way, great king, when his mind is thus concentrated, pure and bright, unblemished, free from defects, malleable, wieldy, steady, and attained to imperturbability, the monk directs and inclines it to the modes of supernormal power. He experiences the various modes of supernormal power: having been one, he becomes many and having been many, he becomes one; he appears and vanishes; he goes unimpeded through walls, ramparts, and mountains as if through space. He dives in and out of the earth as if it were water. He walks on the water without breaking the surface as if on land. Sitting cross-legged, he travels through space like a winged bird. With his hand he touches and strokes even the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful. He exercises mastery over the body as far as the Brahma-world. This, great king, is a visible fruit of the ascetic life more excellent and sublime than the previous ones. Knowledge of the divine ear. "When his mind is thus concentrated, pure and bright, unblemished, free from defects, malleable, wieldy, steady, and attained to imperturbability, he directs and inclines it to the divine ear-element. With the divine ear-element, which is purified and surpasses the human, he hears both kinds of sound, the divine and the human, those which are distant and those which are near.
239. pathaviyÄ. ÄkÄsepi pallaá¹…kena kamati seyyathÄpi pakkhÄ« sakuá¹‡o. imepi candimasÅ«riye evaá¹ƒmahiddhike evaá¹ƒmahÄnubhÄve pÄá¹‡inÄ parÄmasati parimajjati. yÄva brahmalokÄpi kÄyena vasaá¹ƒ vatteti. 239. "seyyathÄpi, mahÄrÄja, dakkho kumbhakÄro vÄ kumbhakÄrantevÄsÄ« vÄ suparikammakatÄya mattikÄya yaá¹ƒ yadeva bhÄjanavikatiá¹ƒ Äkaá¹…kheyya, taá¹ƒ tadeva kareyya abhinipphÄdeyya. seyyathÄ vÄ pana, mahÄrÄja, dakkho dantakÄro vÄ dantakÄrantevÄsÄ« vÄ suparikammakatasmiá¹ƒ dantasmiá¹ƒ yaá¹ƒ yadeva dantavikatiá¹ƒ Äkaá¹…kheyya, taá¹ƒ tadeva kareyya abhinipphÄdeyya. seyyathÄ vÄ pana, mahÄrÄja, dakkho suvaá¹‡á¹‡akÄro vÄ suvaá¹‡á¹‡akÄrantevÄsÄ« vÄ suparikammakatasmiá¹ƒ suvaá¹‡á¹‡asmiá¹ƒ yaá¹ƒ yadeva suvaá¹‡á¹‡avikatiá¹ƒ Äkaá¹…kheyya, taá¹ƒ tadeva kareyya abhinipphÄdeyya. evameva kho, mahÄrÄja, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte iddhividhÄya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so anekavihitaá¹ƒ iddhividhaá¹ƒ paccanubhoti â€“ ekopi hutvÄ bahudhÄ hoti, bahudhÄpi hutvÄ eko hoti, ÄvibhÄvaá¹ƒ tirobhÄvaá¹ƒ tirokuá¹­á¹­aá¹ƒ tiropÄkÄraá¹ƒ tiropabbataá¹ƒ asajjamÄno gacchati seyyathÄpi ÄkÄse. pathaviyÄpi ummujjanimujjaá¹ƒ karoti seyyathÄpi udake. udakepi abhijjamÄne gacchati seyyathÄpi pathaviyÄ. ÄkÄsepi pallaá¹…kena kamati seyyathÄpi pakkhÄ« sakuá¹‡o. imepi candimasÅ«riye evaá¹ƒmahiddhike evaá¹ƒmahÄnubhÄve pÄá¹‡inÄ parÄmasati parimajjati. yÄva brahmalokÄpi kÄyena vasaá¹ƒ vatteti. idampi kho, mahÄrÄja, sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ purimehi sandiá¹­á¹­hikehi sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalehi abhikkantataraÃ±ca paá¹‡Ä«tataraÃ±ca. dibbasotaÃ±Äá¹‡aá¹ƒ 240. "so evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte dibbÄya sotadhÄtuyÄ cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so dibbÄya sotadhÄtuyÄ visuddhÄya atikkantamÄnusikÄya ubho sadde suá¹‡Äti dibbe ca mÄnuse ca ye dÅ«re santike ca.
[Translation for paragraph 239]
240. pathaviyÄ. ÄkÄsepi pallaá¹…kena kamati seyyathÄpi pakkhÄ« sakuá¹‡o. imepi candimasÅ«riye evaá¹ƒmahiddhike evaá¹ƒmahÄnubhÄve pÄá¹‡inÄ parÄmasati parimajjati. yÄva brahmalokÄpi kÄyena vasaá¹ƒ vatteti. 239. "seyyathÄpi, mahÄrÄja, dakkho kumbhakÄro vÄ kumbhakÄrantevÄsÄ« vÄ suparikammakatÄya mattikÄya yaá¹ƒ yadeva bhÄjanavikatiá¹ƒ Äkaá¹…kheyya, taá¹ƒ tadeva kareyya abhinipphÄdeyya. seyyathÄ vÄ pana, mahÄrÄja, dakkho dantakÄro vÄ dantakÄrantevÄsÄ« vÄ suparikammakatasmiá¹ƒ dantasmiá¹ƒ yaá¹ƒ yadeva dantavikatiá¹ƒ Äkaá¹…kheyya, taá¹ƒ tadeva kareyya abhinipphÄdeyya. seyyathÄ vÄ pana, mahÄrÄja, dakkho suvaá¹‡á¹‡akÄro vÄ suvaá¹‡á¹‡akÄrantevÄsÄ« vÄ suparikammakatasmiá¹ƒ suvaá¹‡á¹‡asmiá¹ƒ yaá¹ƒ yadeva suvaá¹‡á¹‡avikatiá¹ƒ Äkaá¹…kheyya, taá¹ƒ tadeva kareyya abhinipphÄdeyya. evameva kho, mahÄrÄja, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte iddhividhÄya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so anekavihitaá¹ƒ iddhividhaá¹ƒ paccanubhoti â€“ ekopi hutvÄ bahudhÄ hoti, bahudhÄpi hutvÄ eko hoti, ÄvibhÄvaá¹ƒ tirobhÄvaá¹ƒ tirokuá¹­á¹­aá¹ƒ tiropÄkÄraá¹ƒ tiropabbataá¹ƒ asajjamÄno gacchati seyyathÄpi ÄkÄse. pathaviyÄpi ummujjanimujjaá¹ƒ karoti seyyathÄpi udake. udakepi abhijjamÄne gacchati seyyathÄpi pathaviyÄ. ÄkÄsepi pallaá¹…kena kamati seyyathÄpi pakkhÄ« sakuá¹‡o. imepi candimasÅ«riye evaá¹ƒmahiddhike evaá¹ƒmahÄnubhÄve pÄá¹‡inÄ parÄmasati parimajjati. yÄva brahmalokÄpi kÄyena vasaá¹ƒ vatteti. idampi kho, mahÄrÄja, sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ purimehi sandiá¹­á¹­hikehi sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalehi abhikkantataraÃ±ca paá¹‡Ä«tataraÃ±ca. dibbasotaÃ±Äá¹‡aá¹ƒ 240. "so evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte dibbÄya sotadhÄtuyÄ cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so dibbÄya sotadhÄtuyÄ visuddhÄya atikkantamÄnusikÄya ubho sadde suá¹‡Äti dibbe ca mÄnuse ca ye dÅ«re santike ca.
[Translation for paragraph 240]
241. 241. "seyyathÄpi, mahÄrÄja, puriso addhÄnamaggappaá¹­ipanno. so suá¹‡eyya bherisaddampi mudiá¹…gasaddampi [mutiá¹…gasaddampi (sÄ«. pÄ«.)] saá¹…khapaá¹‡avadindimasaddampi [saá¹…khapaá¹‡avadeá¹‡á¸imasaddampi (sÄ«. pÄ«.), saá¹…khasaddaá¹ƒpi paá¹‡avasaddaá¹ƒpi dendimasaddaá¹ƒpi (syÄ. kaá¹ƒ.)]. tassa evamassa â€“ â€˜bherisaddoâ€™ itipi, â€˜mudiá¹…gasaddoâ€™ itipi, â€˜saá¹…khapaá¹‡avadindimasaddoâ€™ itipi [saá¹…khasaddo itipi paá¹‡avasaddo itipi dendimasaddo itipi (syÄ. kaá¹ƒ.)]. evameva kho, mahÄrÄja, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte dibbÄya sotadhÄtuyÄ cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so dibbÄya sotadhÄtuyÄ visuddhÄya atikkantamÄnusikÄya ubho sadde suá¹‡Äti dibbe ca mÄnuse ca ye dÅ«re santike ca. idampi kho, mahÄrÄja, sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ purimehi sandiá¹­á¹­hikehi sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalehi abhikkantataraÃ±ca paá¹‡Ä«tataraÃ±ca. cetopariyaÃ±Äá¹‡aá¹ƒ 242. "so evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte cetopariyaÃ±Äá¹‡Äya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so parasattÄnaá¹ƒ parapuggalÄnaá¹ƒ cetasÄ ceto paricca pajÄnÄti â€“ sarÄgaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜sarÄgaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, vÄ«tarÄgaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜vÄ«tarÄgaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, sadosaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜sadosaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, vÄ«tadosaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜vÄ«tadosaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, samohaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜samohaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, vÄ«tamohaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜vÄ«tamohaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, saá¹…khittaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜saá¹…khittaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, vikkhittaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜vikkhittaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, mahaggataá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜mahaggataá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, amahaggataá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜amahaggataá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, sauttaraá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜sauttaraá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, anuttaraá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜anuttaraá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, samÄhitaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜samÄhitaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, asamÄhitaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜asamÄhitaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, vimuttaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜vimuttaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, avimuttaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜avimuttaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti.
â€œJust as, great king, a man traveling along a highway, might hear the sound of a *bheri* drum, a *má¹›dÄ«á¹…ga* drum, a conch, a *paá¹‡ava* cymbal, or a *dindima* kettle-drum. It might occur to him, â€˜That is the sound of a *bheri* drum,â€™ â€˜That is the sound of a *má¹›dÄ«á¹…ga* drum,â€™ â€˜That is the sound of a conch, a *paá¹‡ava* cymbal, or a *dindima* kettle-drum.â€™ In the same way, great king, when a monk's mind is thus concentrated, purified, bright, unblemished, free from defilements, malleable, ready to act, firm, and unshakeable, he directs and inclines his mind to the divine ear-element (*dibbÄya sotadhÄtuyÄ*). With the divine ear-element (*dibbÄya sotadhÄtuyÄ*), which is purified and surpasses the human, he hears both kinds of sounds, divine and human, those that are far and near. This, too, great king, is a visible fruit of the monastic life more excellent and sublime than the previous ones. Knowledge of others' minds (*cetopariyaÃ±Äá¹‡aá¹ƒ*).
242. 241. "seyyathÄpi, mahÄrÄja, puriso addhÄnamaggappaá¹­ipanno. so suá¹‡eyya bherisaddampi mudiá¹…gasaddampi [mutiá¹…gasaddampi (sÄ«. pÄ«.)] saá¹…khapaá¹‡avadindimasaddampi [saá¹…khapaá¹‡avadeá¹‡á¸imasaddampi (sÄ«. pÄ«.), saá¹…khasaddaá¹ƒpi paá¹‡avasaddaá¹ƒpi dendimasaddaá¹ƒpi (syÄ. kaá¹ƒ.)]. tassa evamassa â€“ â€˜bherisaddoâ€™ itipi, â€˜mudiá¹…gasaddoâ€™ itipi, â€˜saá¹…khapaá¹‡avadindimasaddoâ€™ itipi [saá¹…khasaddo itipi paá¹‡avasaddo itipi dendimasaddo itipi (syÄ. kaá¹ƒ.)]. evameva kho, mahÄrÄja, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte dibbÄya sotadhÄtuyÄ cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so dibbÄya sotadhÄtuyÄ visuddhÄya atikkantamÄnusikÄya ubho sadde suá¹‡Äti dibbe ca mÄnuse ca ye dÅ«re santike ca. idampi kho, mahÄrÄja, sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ purimehi sandiá¹­á¹­hikehi sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalehi abhikkantataraÃ±ca paá¹‡Ä«tataraÃ±ca. cetopariyaÃ±Äá¹‡aá¹ƒ 242. "so evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte cetopariyaÃ±Äá¹‡Äya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so parasattÄnaá¹ƒ parapuggalÄnaá¹ƒ cetasÄ ceto paricca pajÄnÄti â€“ sarÄgaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜sarÄgaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, vÄ«tarÄgaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜vÄ«tarÄgaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, sadosaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜sadosaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, vÄ«tadosaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜vÄ«tadosaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, samohaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜samohaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, vÄ«tamohaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜vÄ«tamohaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, saá¹…khittaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜saá¹…khittaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, vikkhittaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜vikkhittaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, mahaggataá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜mahaggataá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, amahaggataá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜amahaggataá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, sauttaraá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜sauttaraá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, anuttaraá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜anuttaraá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, samÄhitaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜samÄhitaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, asamÄhitaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜asamÄhitaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, vimuttaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜vimuttaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, avimuttaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜avimuttaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti.
"When his mind is thus concentrated, purified, bright, unblemished, free from defilements, malleable, ready to act, firm, and unshakeable, he directs and inclines his mind to knowledge of others' minds (*cetopariyaÃ±Äá¹‡Äya*). He knows and understands the minds of other beings and individuals, having encompassed them with his own mind: He understands a mind with passion (*sarÄgaá¹ƒ citta*) as â€˜a mind with passionâ€™ (*sarÄgaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti*), a mind without passion (*vÄ«tarÄgaá¹ƒ citta*) as â€˜a mind without passionâ€™ (*vÄ«tarÄgaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti*), a mind with aversion (*sadosaá¹ƒ citta*) as â€˜a mind with aversionâ€™ (*sadosaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti*), a mind without aversion (*vÄ«tadosaá¹ƒ citta*) as â€˜a mind without aversionâ€™ (*vÄ«tadosaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti*), a mind with delusion (*samohaá¹ƒ citta*) as â€˜a mind with delusionâ€™ (*samohaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti*), a mind without delusion (*vÄ«tamohaá¹ƒ citta*) as â€˜a mind without delusionâ€™ (*vÄ«tamohaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti*), a constricted mind (*saá¹…khittaá¹ƒ citta*) as â€˜a constricted mindâ€™ (*saá¹…khittaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti*), a scattered mind (*vikkhittaá¹ƒ citta*) as â€˜a scattered mindâ€™ (*vikkhittaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti*), a developed mind (*mahaggataá¹ƒ citta*) as â€˜a developed mindâ€™ (*mahaggataá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti*), an undeveloped mind (*amahaggataá¹ƒ citta*) as â€˜an undeveloped mindâ€™ (*amahaggataá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti*), a surpassed mind (*sauttaraá¹ƒ citta*) as â€˜a surpassed mindâ€™ (*sauttaraá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti*), an unsurpassed mind (*anuttaraá¹ƒ citta*) as â€˜an unsurpassed mindâ€™ (*anuttaraá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti*), a concentrated mind (*samÄhitaá¹ƒ citta*) as â€˜a concentrated mindâ€™ (*samÄhitaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti*), an unconcentrated mind (*asamÄhitaá¹ƒ citta*) as â€˜an unconcentrated mindâ€™ (*asamÄhitaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti*), a liberated mind (*vimuttaá¹ƒ citta*) as â€˜a liberated mindâ€™ (*vimuttaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti*), and an unliberated mind (*avimuttaá¹ƒ citta*) as â€˜an unliberated mindâ€™ (*avimuttaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti*)."
243. 243. "seyyathÄpi, mahÄrÄja, itthÄ« vÄ puriso vÄ daharo yuvÄ maá¹‡á¸anajÄtiko ÄdÄse vÄ parisuddhe pariyodÄte acche vÄ udakapatte sakaá¹ƒ mukhanimittaá¹ƒ paccavekkhamÄno sakaá¹‡ikaá¹ƒ vÄ â€˜sakaá¹‡ikaâ€™nti jÄneyya, akaá¹‡ikaá¹ƒ vÄ â€˜akaá¹‡ikaâ€™nti jÄneyya, evameva kho, mahÄrÄja, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte cetopariyaÃ±Äá¹‡Äya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so parasattÄnaá¹ƒ parapuggalÄnaá¹ƒ cetasÄ ceto paricca pajÄnÄti â€“ sarÄgaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜sarÄgaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, vÄ«tarÄgaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜vÄ«tarÄgaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, sadosaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜sadosaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, vÄ«tadosaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜vÄ«tadosaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, samohaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜samohaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, vÄ«tamohaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜vÄ«tamohaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, saá¹…khittaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜saá¹…khittaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, vikkhittaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜vikkhittaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, mahaggataá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜mahaggataá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, amahaggataá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜amahaggataá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, sauttaraá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜sauttaraá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, anuttaraá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜anuttaraá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, samÄhitaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜samÄhitaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, asamÄhitaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜asamÄhitaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, vimuttaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜vimuttaá¹ƒ citta"nti pajÄnÄti, avimuttaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜avimuttaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti. idampi kho, mahÄrÄja, sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ purimehi sandiá¹­á¹­hikehi sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalehi abhikkantataraÃ±ca paá¹‡Ä«tataraÃ±ca. pubbenivÄsÄnussatiÃ±Äá¹‡aá¹ƒ 244. "so evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte pubbenivÄsÄnussatiÃ±Äá¹‡Äya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so anekavihitaá¹ƒ pubbenivÄsaá¹ƒ anussarati, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ ekampi jÄtiá¹ƒ dvepi jÄtiyo tissopi jÄtiyo catassopi jÄtiyo paÃ±capi jÄtiyo dasapi jÄtiyo vÄ«sampi jÄtiyo tiá¹ƒsampi jÄtiyo cattÄlÄ«sampi jÄtiyo paÃ±Ã±Äsampi jÄtiyo jÄtisatampi jÄtisahassampi jÄtisatasahassampi anekepi saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­akappe anekepi vivaá¹­á¹­akappe anekepi saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­avivaá¹­á¹­akappe, â€˜amutrÄsiá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒnÄmo
â€œJust as, great king, a woman or a man, a young person, fond of adornment, examining their own facial reflection in a clear, bright mirror or in a bowl of clear water, would know, if there were a spot, â€˜It has a spot,â€™ and if there were no spot, â€˜It has no spot,â€™ so too, great king, a *bhiká¹£u*, with their mind well-concentrated, purified, and cleansed, without blemish, free from imperfections, pliable, workable, steady, and having attained imperturbability, directs and inclines their mind towards the knowledge of encompassing the minds of others (*cetopariyaÃ±Äá¹‡a*). They understand the minds of other beings and persons, having encompassed them with their own mind. They understand a mind with lust (*sarÄgaá¹ƒ citta*) as a mind with lust and a mind without lust (*vÄ«tarÄgaá¹ƒ citta*) as a mind without lust; they understand a mind with hatred (*sadosaá¹ƒ citta*) as a mind with hatred and a mind without hatred (*vÄ«tadosaá¹ƒ citta*) as a mind without hatred; they understand a mind with delusion (*samohaá¹ƒ citta*) as a mind with delusion and a mind without delusion (*vÄ«tamohaá¹ƒ citta*) as a mind without delusion; they understand a contracted mind (*saá¹…khittaá¹ƒ citta*) as a contracted mind and a distracted mind (*vikkhittaá¹ƒ citta*) as a distracted mind; they understand an exalted mind (*mahaggataá¹ƒ citta*) as an exalted mind and an unexalted mind (*amahaggataá¹ƒ citta*) as an unexalted mind; they understand a surpassable mind (*sauttaraá¹ƒ citta*) as a surpassable mind and an unsurpassed mind (*anuttaraá¹ƒ citta*) as an unsurpassed mind; they understand a concentrated mind (*samÄhitaá¹ƒ citta*) as a concentrated mind and an unconcentrated mind (*asamÄhitaá¹ƒ citta*) as an unconcentrated mind; they understand a liberated mind (*vimuttaá¹ƒ citta*) as a liberated mind and an unliberated mind (*avimuttaá¹ƒ citta*) as an unliberated mind. This too, great king, is a visible fruit of the ascetic life (*sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphala*) more excellent and sublime than the previous ones. Knowledge of the recollection of past lives (*pubbenivÄsÄnussatiÃ±Äá¹‡a*).
244. 243. "seyyathÄpi, mahÄrÄja, itthÄ« vÄ puriso vÄ daharo yuvÄ maá¹‡á¸anajÄtiko ÄdÄse vÄ parisuddhe pariyodÄte acche vÄ udakapatte sakaá¹ƒ mukhanimittaá¹ƒ paccavekkhamÄno sakaá¹‡ikaá¹ƒ vÄ â€˜sakaá¹‡ikaâ€™nti jÄneyya, akaá¹‡ikaá¹ƒ vÄ â€˜akaá¹‡ikaâ€™nti jÄneyya, evameva kho, mahÄrÄja, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte cetopariyaÃ±Äá¹‡Äya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so parasattÄnaá¹ƒ parapuggalÄnaá¹ƒ cetasÄ ceto paricca pajÄnÄti â€“ sarÄgaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜sarÄgaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, vÄ«tarÄgaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜vÄ«tarÄgaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, sadosaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜sadosaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, vÄ«tadosaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜vÄ«tadosaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, samohaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜samohaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, vÄ«tamohaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜vÄ«tamohaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, saá¹…khittaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜saá¹…khittaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, vikkhittaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜vikkhittaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, mahaggataá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜mahaggataá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, amahaggataá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜amahaggataá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, sauttaraá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜sauttaraá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, anuttaraá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜anuttaraá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, samÄhitaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜samÄhitaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, asamÄhitaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜asamÄhitaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, vimuttaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜vimuttaá¹ƒ citta"nti pajÄnÄti, avimuttaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ â€˜avimuttaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti. idampi kho, mahÄrÄja, sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ purimehi sandiá¹­á¹­hikehi sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalehi abhikkantataraÃ±ca paá¹‡Ä«tataraÃ±ca. pubbenivÄsÄnussatiÃ±Äá¹‡aá¹ƒ 244. "so evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte pubbenivÄsÄnussatiÃ±Äá¹‡Äya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so anekavihitaá¹ƒ pubbenivÄsaá¹ƒ anussarati, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ ekampi jÄtiá¹ƒ dvepi jÄtiyo tissopi jÄtiyo catassopi jÄtiyo paÃ±capi jÄtiyo dasapi jÄtiyo vÄ«sampi jÄtiyo tiá¹ƒsampi jÄtiyo cattÄlÄ«sampi jÄtiyo paÃ±Ã±Äsampi jÄtiyo jÄtisatampi jÄtisahassampi jÄtisatasahassampi anekepi saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­akappe anekepi vivaá¹­á¹­akappe anekepi saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­avivaá¹­á¹­akappe, â€˜amutrÄsiá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒnÄmo
And so, with mind well-concentrated, purified and cleansed, without blemish, free from imperfections, pliable, workable, steady, and having attained imperturbability, they direct and incline their mind towards the knowledge of recollection of past lives (*pubbenivÄsÄnussatiÃ±Äá¹‡a*). They recollect many past lives, that is, one birth (*jÄti*), two births, three births, four births, five births, ten births, twenty births, thirty births, forty births, fifty births, a hundred births, a thousand births, a hundred thousand births, many eons of world-contraction (*saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­akappa*), many eons of world-expansion (*vivaá¹­á¹­akappa*), many eons of world-contraction and expansion (*saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­avivaá¹­á¹­akappa*), â€˜There I was so named Of such a clan, of such an appearance; such was my food, such my experience of pleasure and pain, such my span of life. Passing away thence, I arose there. There too I had such a name, belonged to such a clan, had such an appearance; such was my food, such my experience of pleasure and pain, such my span of life. Passing away thence, I was reborn here.â€™ Thus he remembers various past births, their conditions and details.
245. evaá¹ƒgotto evaá¹ƒvaá¹‡á¹‡o evamÄhÄro evaá¹ƒsukhadukkhappaá¹­isaá¹ƒvedÄ« evamÄyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapÄdiá¹ƒ, tatrÄpÄsiá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒnÄmo evaá¹ƒgotto evaá¹ƒvaá¹‡á¹‡o evamÄhÄro evaá¹ƒsukhadukkhappaá¹­isaá¹ƒvedÄ« evamÄyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhÅ«papannoâ€™ti. iti sÄkÄraá¹ƒ sauddesaá¹ƒ anekavihitaá¹ƒ pubbenivÄsaá¹ƒ anussarati. 245. "seyyathÄpi, mahÄrÄja, puriso sakamhÄ gÄmÄ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ gÄmaá¹ƒ gaccheyya, tamhÄpi gÄmÄ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ gÄmaá¹ƒ gaccheyya. so tamhÄ gÄmÄ sakaá¹ƒyeva gÄmaá¹ƒ paccÄgaccheyya. tassa evamassa â€“ â€˜ahaá¹ƒ kho sakamhÄ gÄmÄ amuá¹ƒ gÄmaá¹ƒ agacchiá¹ƒ [agaÃ±chiá¹ƒ (syÄ. kaá¹ƒ.)], tatrÄpi evaá¹ƒ aá¹­á¹­hÄsiá¹ƒ, evaá¹ƒ nisÄ«diá¹ƒ, evaá¹ƒ abhÄsiá¹ƒ, evaá¹ƒ tuá¹‡hÄ« ahosiá¹ƒ, tamhÄpi gÄmÄ amuá¹ƒ gÄmaá¹ƒ agacchiá¹ƒ, tatrÄpi evaá¹ƒ aá¹­á¹­hÄsiá¹ƒ, evaá¹ƒ nisÄ«diá¹ƒ, evaá¹ƒ abhÄsiá¹ƒ, evaá¹ƒ tuá¹‡hÄ« ahosiá¹ƒ, somhi tamhÄ gÄmÄ sakaá¹ƒyeva gÄmaá¹ƒ paccÄgatoâ€™ti. evameva kho, mahÄrÄja, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte pubbenivÄsÄnussatiÃ±Äá¹‡Äya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so anekavihitaá¹ƒ pubbenivÄsaá¹ƒ anussarati, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ ekampi jÄtiá¹ƒ dvepi jÄtiyo tissopi jÄtiyo catassopi jÄtiyo paÃ±capi jÄtiyo dasapi jÄtiyo vÄ«sampi jÄtiyo tiá¹ƒsampi jÄtiyo cattÄlÄ«sampi jÄtiyo paÃ±Ã±Äsampi jÄtiyo jÄtisatampi jÄtisahassampi jÄtisatasahassampi anekepi saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­akappe anekepi vivaá¹­á¹­akappe anekepi saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­avivaá¹­á¹­akappe, â€˜amutrÄsiá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒnÄmo evaá¹ƒgotto evaá¹ƒvaá¹‡á¹‡o evamÄhÄro evaá¹ƒsukhadukkhappaá¹­isaá¹ƒvedÄ« evamÄyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapÄdiá¹ƒ, tatrÄpÄsiá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒnÄmo evaá¹ƒgotto evaá¹ƒvaá¹‡á¹‡o evamÄhÄro evaá¹ƒsukhadukkhappaá¹­isaá¹ƒvedÄ« evamÄyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhÅ«papannoâ€™ti, iti sÄkÄraá¹ƒ sauddesaá¹ƒ anekavihitaá¹ƒ pubbenivÄsaá¹ƒ anussarati. idampi kho, mahÄrÄja, sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ purimehi sandiá¹­á¹­hikehi sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalehi abhikkantataraÃ±ca paá¹‡Ä«tataraÃ±ca.
"Great king, suppose a man were to go from his own village to another village, then from that village to still another village. and thence return to his home village. He might think: â€˜I went from my own village to that village, and there I stood in such a way, sat in such a way, spoke in such a way, kept silent in such a way; and from that village I went to that other village and there I stood in such a wayâ€¦kept silent in such a way; and from that village I came back again to my own village.â€™ In the same way, great king, when his mind is thus concentrated, pure and bright, without blemish, rid of defilements, gentle, pliable, steady, and has attained imperturbability, the *bhikkhu* directs and inclines it to the knowledge of recollecting past lives. He recollects his numerous past lives, that is, one birth, two births, three, four, or five births; ten, twenty, thirty, forty, or fifty births; a hundred births, a thousand births, a hundred thousand births; many aeons of world contraction, many aeons of world expansion, many aeons of world contraction and expansion: â€˜There I had such a name, belonged to such a clan, had such an appearance; such was my food, such my experience of pleasure and pain, such my span of life. Passing away from that existence, I arose in another place. There too I had such a name, belonged to such a clan, had such an appearance; such was my food, such my experience of pleasure and pain, such my span of life. Passing away from that existence, I was reborn here.â€™ Thus he remembers various past births, their conditions and details. This too, great king, is a visible fruit of the life of a recluse, more excellent and sublime than the previous ones. Knowledge of the divine eye.
246. dibbacakkhuÃ±Äá¹‡aá¹ƒ 246. "so evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte sattÄnaá¹ƒ cutÅ«papÄtaÃ±Äá¹‡Äya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so dibbena cakkhunÄ visuddhena atikkantamÄnusakena satte passati cavamÄne upapajjamÄne hÄ«ne paá¹‡Ä«te suvaá¹‡á¹‡e dubbaá¹‡á¹‡e sugate duggate, yathÄkammÅ«page satte pajÄnÄti â€“ â€˜ime vata bhonto sattÄ kÄyaduccaritena samannÄgatÄ vacÄ«duccaritena samannÄgatÄ manoduccaritena samannÄgatÄ ariyÄnaá¹ƒ upavÄdakÄ micchÄdiá¹­á¹­hikÄ micchÄdiá¹­á¹­hikammasamÄdÄnÄ. te kÄyassa bhedÄ paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä apÄyaá¹ƒ duggatiá¹ƒ vinipÄtaá¹ƒ nirayaá¹ƒ upapannÄ. ime vÄ pana bhonto sattÄ kÄyasucaritena samannÄgatÄ vacÄ«sucaritena samannÄgatÄ manosucaritena samannÄgatÄ ariyÄnaá¹ƒ anupavÄdakÄ sammÄdiá¹­á¹­hikÄ sammÄdiá¹­á¹­hikammasamÄdÄnÄ, te kÄyassa bhedÄ paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä sugatiá¹ƒ saggaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ upapannÄâ€™ti. iti dibbena cakkhunÄ visuddhena atikkantamÄnusakena satte passati cavamÄne upapajjamÄne hÄ«ne paá¹‡Ä«te suvaá¹‡á¹‡e dubbaá¹‡á¹‡e sugate duggate, yathÄkammÅ«page satte pajÄnÄti. 247. "seyyathÄpi, mahÄrÄja, majjhe siá¹…ghÄá¹­ake pÄsÄdo. tattha cakkhumÄ puriso á¹­hito passeyya manusse gehaá¹ƒ pavisantepi nikkhamantepi rathikÄyapi vÄ«thiá¹ƒ saÃ±carante [rathiyÄpÄ« rathiá¹ƒ saÃ±carante (sÄ«.), rathiyÄya vithiá¹ƒ saÃ±carantepi (syÄ.)] majjhe siá¹…ghÄá¹­ake nisinnepi. tassa evamassa â€“ â€˜ete manussÄ gehaá¹ƒ pavisanti, ete nikkhamanti, ete rathikÄya vÄ«thiá¹ƒ saÃ±caranti, ete majjhe siá¹…ghÄá¹­ake nisinnÄâ€™ti. evameva kho, mahÄrÄja, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte sattÄnaá¹ƒ cutÅ«papÄtaÃ±Äá¹‡Äya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so dibbena cakkhunÄ visuddhena atikkantamÄnusakena satte passati cavamÄne upapajjamÄne hÄ«ne paá¹‡Ä«te suvaá¹‡á¹‡e dubbaá¹‡á¹‡e sugate duggate, yathÄkammÅ«page satte pajÄnÄti â€“ â€˜ime vata bhonto sattÄ kÄyaduccaritena samannÄgatÄ vacÄ«duccaritena samannÄgatÄ manoduccaritena samannÄgatÄ ariyÄnaá¹ƒ upavÄdakÄ micchÄdiá¹­á¹­hikÄ micchÄdiá¹­á¹­hikammasamÄdÄnÄ, te kÄyassa bhedÄ paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä apÄyaá¹ƒ duggatiá¹ƒ vinipÄtaá¹ƒ nirayaá¹ƒ upapannÄ.
When his mind is thus concentrated, purified, bright, unblemished, rid of imperfections, malleable, wieldy, steady, and has attained imperturbability, he directs and inclines his mind to the knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings. With the divine eye ( *dibbena cakkhunÄ* ), which is purified and surpasses the human, he sees beings passing away and arisingâ€”inferior and superior, fair and ugly, fortunate and unfortunateâ€”and he understands how beings pass on according to their *karma* ( *yathÄkammÅ«page satte pajÄnÄti* ), thus: â€˜These beingsâ€”who were endowed with bad conduct of body (*kÄyaduccaritena*), speech (*vacÄ«duccaritena*), and mind (*manoduccaritena*), who reviled the noble ones (*ariyÄnaá¹ƒ upavÄdakÄ*), held wrong views (*micchÄdiá¹­á¹­hikÄ*), and undertook actions governed by wrong views (*micchÄdiá¹­á¹­hikammasamÄdÄnÄ*)â€”at the breaking up of the body, after death, have reappeared in the plane of misery (*apÄyaá¹ƒ*), the bad destinations (*duggatiá¹ƒ*), the lower realms (*vinipÄtaá¹ƒ*), in hell (*nirayaá¹ƒ upapannÄ*). But these beingsâ€”who were endowed with good conduct of body (*kÄyasucaritena*), speech (*vacÄ«sucaritena*), and mind (*manosucaritena*), who did not revile the noble ones (*ariyÄnaá¹ƒ anupavÄdakÄ*), held right views (*sammÄdiá¹­á¹­hikÄ*), and undertook actions governed by right views (*sammÄdiá¹­á¹­hikammasamÄdÄnÄ*)â€”at the break-up of the body, after death, have reappeared in the good destinations (*sugatiá¹ƒ*), in the heavenly world (*saggaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ upapannÄ*) .â€™ Thus, with the divine eye ( *dibbena cakkhunÄ* ), purified and surpassing the human, he sees beings passing away and reappearingâ€”inferior and superior, fair and ugly, fortunate and unfortunateâ€”and he understands how beings fare according to their *karma* ( *yathÄkammÅ«page satte pajÄnÄti* ).
247. dibbacakkhuÃ±Äá¹‡aá¹ƒ 246. "so evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte sattÄnaá¹ƒ cutÅ«papÄtaÃ±Äá¹‡Äya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so dibbena cakkhunÄ visuddhena atikkantamÄnusakena satte passati cavamÄne upapajjamÄne hÄ«ne paá¹‡Ä«te suvaá¹‡á¹‡e dubbaá¹‡á¹‡e sugate duggate, yathÄkammÅ«page satte pajÄnÄti â€“ â€˜ime vata bhonto sattÄ kÄyaduccaritena samannÄgatÄ vacÄ«duccaritena samannÄgatÄ manoduccaritena samannÄgatÄ ariyÄnaá¹ƒ upavÄdakÄ micchÄdiá¹­á¹­hikÄ micchÄdiá¹­á¹­hikammasamÄdÄnÄ. te kÄyassa bhedÄ paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä apÄyaá¹ƒ duggatiá¹ƒ vinipÄtaá¹ƒ nirayaá¹ƒ upapannÄ. ime vÄ pana bhonto sattÄ kÄyasucaritena samannÄgatÄ vacÄ«sucaritena samannÄgatÄ manosucaritena samannÄgatÄ ariyÄnaá¹ƒ anupavÄdakÄ sammÄdiá¹­á¹­hikÄ sammÄdiá¹­á¹­hikammasamÄdÄnÄ, te kÄyassa bhedÄ paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä sugatiá¹ƒ saggaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ upapannÄâ€™ti. iti dibbena cakkhunÄ visuddhena atikkantamÄnusakena satte passati cavamÄne upapajjamÄne hÄ«ne paá¹‡Ä«te suvaá¹‡á¹‡e dubbaá¹‡á¹‡e sugate duggate, yathÄkammÅ«page satte pajÄnÄti. 247. "seyyathÄpi, mahÄrÄja, majjhe siá¹…ghÄá¹­ake pÄsÄdo. tattha cakkhumÄ puriso á¹­hito passeyya manusse gehaá¹ƒ pavisantepi nikkhamantepi rathikÄyapi vÄ«thiá¹ƒ saÃ±carante [rathiyÄpÄ« rathiá¹ƒ saÃ±carante (sÄ«.), rathiyÄya vithiá¹ƒ saÃ±carantepi (syÄ.)] majjhe siá¹…ghÄá¹­ake nisinnepi. tassa evamassa â€“ â€˜ete manussÄ gehaá¹ƒ pavisanti, ete nikkhamanti, ete rathikÄya vÄ«thiá¹ƒ saÃ±caranti, ete majjhe siá¹…ghÄá¹­ake nisinnÄâ€™ti. evameva kho, mahÄrÄja, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte sattÄnaá¹ƒ cutÅ«papÄtaÃ±Äá¹‡Äya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so dibbena cakkhunÄ visuddhena atikkantamÄnusakena satte passati cavamÄne upapajjamÄne hÄ«ne paá¹‡Ä«te suvaá¹‡á¹‡e dubbaá¹‡á¹‡e sugate duggate, yathÄkammÅ«page satte pajÄnÄti â€“ â€˜ime vata bhonto sattÄ kÄyaduccaritena samannÄgatÄ vacÄ«duccaritena samannÄgatÄ manoduccaritena samannÄgatÄ ariyÄnaá¹ƒ upavÄdakÄ micchÄdiá¹­á¹­hikÄ micchÄdiá¹­á¹­hikammasamÄdÄnÄ, te kÄyassa bhedÄ paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä apÄyaá¹ƒ duggatiá¹ƒ vinipÄtaá¹ƒ nirayaá¹ƒ upapannÄ.
"Suppose, great king, there were a building with an upper terrace at a crossroads. A man with good eyesight standing there might see people entering or leaving a house, walking in the street, or sitting in the middle of the crossroads. He might think: â€˜These people are entering a house, those are leaving it, those are walking along the street, and those are sitting in the middle of the crossroads.â€™ In the same way, great king, when his mind is thus concentrated, purified, bright, unblemished, rid of imperfections, malleable, wieldy, steady, and has attained imperturbability, the *bhikkhu* directs and inclines it to the knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings. With the divine eye ( *dibbena cakkhunÄ* ), which is purified and surpasses the human, he sees beings passing away and arisingâ€”inferior and superior, fair and ugly, fortunate and unfortunateâ€”and he understands how beings fare according to their *karma* ( *yathÄkammÅ«page satte pajÄnÄti* ), thus: â€˜These beingsâ€”who were endowed with bad conduct of body (*kÄyaduccaritena*), speech (*vacÄ«duccaritena*), and mind (*manoduccaritena*), who reviled the noble ones (*ariyÄnaá¹ƒ upavÄdakÄ*), held wrong views (*micchÄdiá¹­á¹­hikÄ*), and undertook actions governed by wrong views (*micchÄdiá¹­á¹­hikammasamÄdÄnÄ*)â€”at the breaking up of the body, after death, have reappeared in the plane of misery (*apÄyaá¹ƒ*), the bad destinations (*duggatiá¹ƒ*), the lower realms (*vinipÄtaá¹ƒ*), in hell (*nirayaá¹ƒ upapannÄ*). Moreover, these worthy beings were endowed with good conduct in body (*kÄyasucarita*), good conduct in speech (*vacÄ«sucarita*), and good conduct in mind (*manosucarita*); they did not speak ill of the Noble Ones (*ariyÄnaá¹ƒ*), held right view (*sammÄdiá¹­á¹­hi*), and undertook actions based on right view (*sammÄdiá¹­á¹­hikammasamÄdÄnÄ*). Upon the dissolution of the body, after death, they have been reborn in a good destination, a heavenly world (*sugatiá¹ƒ saggaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ upapannÄâ€™ti*). Thus, with the divine eye (*dibbena cakkhunÄ*), purified and surpassing the human, he sees beings passing away and being reborn, inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, fortunate and unfortunate, and understands beings passing on according to their actions (*yathÄkammÅ«page satte pajÄnÄti*). This, O great king (*mahÄrÄja*), is a visible fruit of the ascetic life (*sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ*) more excellent and sublime than the previous ones (*purimehi sandiá¹­á¹­hikehi sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalehi abhikkantataraÃ±ca paá¹‡Ä«tataraÃ±ca*). Knowledge of the destruction of the cankers (*ÄsavakkhayaÃ±Äá¹‡aá¹ƒ*).
248. ime vÄ pana bhonto sattÄ kÄyasucaritena samannÄgatÄ vacÄ«sucaritena samannÄgatÄ manosucaritena samannÄgatÄ ariyÄnaá¹ƒ anupavÄdakÄ sammÄdiá¹­á¹­hikÄ sammÄdiá¹­á¹­hikammasamÄdÄnÄ. te kÄyassa bhedÄ paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä sugatiá¹ƒ saggaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ upapannÄâ€™ti. iti dibbena cakkhunÄ visuddhena atikkantamÄnusakena satte passati cavamÄne upapajjamÄne hÄ«ne paá¹‡Ä«te suvaá¹‡á¹‡e dubbaá¹‡á¹‡e sugate duggate, yathÄkammÅ«page satte pajÄnÄti. â€˜idampi kho, mahÄrÄja, sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ purimehi sandiá¹­á¹­hikehi sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalehi abhikkantataraÃ±ca paá¹‡Ä«tataraÃ±ca. ÄsavakkhayaÃ±Äá¹‡aá¹ƒ 248. "so evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte ÄsavÄnaá¹ƒ khayaÃ±Äá¹‡Äya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so idaá¹ƒ dukkhanti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, ayaá¹ƒ dukkhasamudayoti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, ayaá¹ƒ dukkhanirodhoti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, ayaá¹ƒ dukkhanirodhagÄminÄ« paá¹­ipadÄti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti. ime ÄsavÄti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, ayaá¹ƒ Äsavasamudayoti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, ayaá¹ƒ Äsavanirodhoti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, ayaá¹ƒ ÄsavanirodhagÄminÄ« paá¹­ipadÄti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti. tassa evaá¹ƒ jÄnato evaá¹ƒ passato kÄmÄsavÄpi cittaá¹ƒ vimuccati, bhavÄsavÄpi cittaá¹ƒ vimuccati, avijjÄsavÄpi cittaá¹ƒ vimuccati, â€˜vimuttasmiá¹ƒ vimuttamiâ€™ti Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹ƒ hoti, â€˜khÄ«á¹‡Ä jÄti, vusitaá¹ƒ brahmacariyaá¹ƒ, kataá¹ƒ karaá¹‡Ä«yaá¹ƒ, nÄparaá¹ƒ itthattÄyÄâ€™ti pajÄnÄti. 249. "seyyathÄpi, mahÄrÄja, pabbatasaá¹…khepe udakarahado accho vippasanno anÄvilo. tattha cakkhumÄ puriso tÄ«re á¹­hito passeyya sippisambukampi sakkharakathalampi macchagumbampi carantampi tiá¹­á¹­hantampi. tassa evamassa â€“ â€˜ayaá¹ƒ kho udakarahado accho vippasanno anÄvilo. tatrime sippisambukÄpi sakkharakathalÄpi macchagumbÄpi carantipi tiá¹­á¹­hantipÄ«â€™ti. evameva kho, mahÄrÄja, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte ÄsavÄnaá¹ƒ khayaÃ±Äá¹‡Äya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. â€˜so idaá¹ƒ dukkhaâ€™nti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, â€˜ayaá¹ƒ dukkhasamudayoâ€™ti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ
"When his mind is thus concentrated, purified, bright, unblemished, free from defilements, malleable, workable, firm, and has attained imperturbability, he directs and applies his mind to the knowledge of the destruction of the cankers (*ÄsavÄnaá¹ƒ khayaÃ±Äá¹‡Äya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti*). He understands according to reality: "This is suffering (*idaá¹ƒ dukkha*)"; he understands according to reality: "This is the origin of suffering (*dukkhasamudayo*)"; he understands according to reality: "This is the cessation of suffering (*dukkhanirodho*)"; he understands according to reality: "This is the path leading to the cessation of suffering (*dukkhanirodhagÄminÄ« paá¹­ipadÄ*)". He understands according to reality: "These are the cankers (*ÄsavÄ*)"; he understands according to reality: "This is the origin of the cankers (*Äsavasamudayo*)"; he understands according to reality: "This is the cessation of the cankers (*Äsavanirodho*)"; he understands according to reality: "This is the path leading to the cessation of the cankers (*ÄsavanirodhagÄminÄ« paá¹­ipadÄ*)". Knowing thus, seeing thus, his mind is liberated from the canker of sensual desire (*kÄmÄsava*), liberated from the canker of becoming (*bhavÄsava*), liberated from the canker of ignorance (*avijjÄsava*). The knowledge arises in him: â€˜It is liberated! (*vimuttasmiá¹ƒ vimuttamiti Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹ƒ hoti*)â€™ He understands: â€˜Destroyed is birth (*khÄ«á¹‡Ä jÄti*), the holy life has been lived (*vusitaá¹ƒ brahmacariyaá¹ƒ*), what had to be done has been done (*kataá¹ƒ karaá¹‡Ä«yaá¹ƒ*), there is nothing further beyond this (*nÄparaá¹ƒ itthattÄyÄâ€™ti pajÄnÄti*).â€™
249. ime vÄ pana bhonto sattÄ kÄyasucaritena samannÄgatÄ vacÄ«sucaritena samannÄgatÄ manosucaritena samannÄgatÄ ariyÄnaá¹ƒ anupavÄdakÄ sammÄdiá¹­á¹­hikÄ sammÄdiá¹­á¹­hikammasamÄdÄnÄ. te kÄyassa bhedÄ paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä sugatiá¹ƒ saggaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ upapannÄâ€™ti. iti dibbena cakkhunÄ visuddhena atikkantamÄnusakena satte passati cavamÄne upapajjamÄne hÄ«ne paá¹‡Ä«te suvaá¹‡á¹‡e dubbaá¹‡á¹‡e sugate duggate, yathÄkammÅ«page satte pajÄnÄti. â€˜idampi kho, mahÄrÄja, sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ purimehi sandiá¹­á¹­hikehi sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalehi abhikkantataraÃ±ca paá¹‡Ä«tataraÃ±ca. ÄsavakkhayaÃ±Äá¹‡aá¹ƒ 248. "so evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte ÄsavÄnaá¹ƒ khayaÃ±Äá¹‡Äya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so idaá¹ƒ dukkhanti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, ayaá¹ƒ dukkhasamudayoti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, ayaá¹ƒ dukkhanirodhoti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, ayaá¹ƒ dukkhanirodhagÄminÄ« paá¹­ipadÄti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti. ime ÄsavÄti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, ayaá¹ƒ Äsavasamudayoti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, ayaá¹ƒ Äsavanirodhoti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, ayaá¹ƒ ÄsavanirodhagÄminÄ« paá¹­ipadÄti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti. tassa evaá¹ƒ jÄnato evaá¹ƒ passato kÄmÄsavÄpi cittaá¹ƒ vimuccati, bhavÄsavÄpi cittaá¹ƒ vimuccati, avijjÄsavÄpi cittaá¹ƒ vimuccati, â€˜vimuttasmiá¹ƒ vimuttamiâ€™ti Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹ƒ hoti, â€˜khÄ«á¹‡Ä jÄti, vusitaá¹ƒ brahmacariyaá¹ƒ, kataá¹ƒ karaá¹‡Ä«yaá¹ƒ, nÄparaá¹ƒ itthattÄyÄâ€™ti pajÄnÄti. 249. "seyyathÄpi, mahÄrÄja, pabbatasaá¹…khepe udakarahado accho vippasanno anÄvilo. tattha cakkhumÄ puriso tÄ«re á¹­hito passeyya sippisambukampi sakkharakathalampi macchagumbampi carantampi tiá¹­á¹­hantampi. tassa evamassa â€“ â€˜ayaá¹ƒ kho udakarahado accho vippasanno anÄvilo. tatrime sippisambukÄpi sakkharakathalÄpi macchagumbÄpi carantipi tiá¹­á¹­hantipÄ«â€™ti. evameva kho, mahÄrÄja, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte ÄsavÄnaá¹ƒ khayaÃ±Äá¹‡Äya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. â€˜so idaá¹ƒ dukkhaâ€™nti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, â€˜ayaá¹ƒ dukkhasamudayoâ€™ti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ
"Just as, O great king (*mahÄrÄja*), in a mountain glen there might be a lake with clear water, limpid and undisturbed (*udakarahado accho vippasanno anÄvilo*). There a man with good sight, standing on the bank, might see shellfish, gravel, and shoals of fish, both moving and standing still (*sippisambukampi sakkharakathalampi macchagumbampi carantampi tiá¹­á¹­hantampi*). He might think: 'This lake is clear, limpid, and undisturbed (*ayaá¹ƒ kho udakarahado accho vippasanno anÄvilo*). There are these shellfish, gravel, and shoals of fish, both moving and standing still (*tatrime sippisambukÄpi sakkharakathalÄpi macchagumbÄpi carantipi tiá¹­á¹­hantipÄ«â€™ti*). In the same way, O great king (*mahÄrÄja*), when a monk's mind is thus concentrated, purified, bright, unblemished, free from defilements, malleable, workable, firm, and has attained imperturbability, he directs and applies his mind to the knowledge of the destruction of the cankers (*ÄsavÄnaá¹ƒ khayaÃ±Äá¹‡Äya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti*). 'He understands according to reality: "This is suffering (*idaá¹ƒ dukkha*)"; he understands according to reality: "This is the origin of suffering (*dukkhasamudayo*)". He understands as it really is: â€˜This is the cessation of sufferingâ€™; he understands as it really is: â€˜This is the way leading to the cessation of suffering.' He understands as it really is: â€˜These are the corruptionsâ€™; he understands as it really is: â€˜This is the origin of the corruptionsâ€™; he understands as it really is: â€˜This is the cessation of the corruptionsâ€™; he understands as it really is: â€˜This is the way leading to the cessation of the corruptions.â€™ Through his knowing and seeing thus, his mind is liberated from the corruption of sensual desire, from the corruption of becoming, and from the corruption of ignorance, and the knowledge arises in him: â€œThis is deliverance!â€ And he knows: â€œBirth is finished, the holy life has been led, done is what had to be done, there is nothing further here." This, great king, is a fruit of the life of a recluse visible in this very life, more surpassing and sublime than the previous fruits of the life of a recluse. And, great king, there is no other fruit of the life of a recluse visible here and now that is higher or more sublime than this one. The report on AjÄtasattu becoming a lay follower.
250. pajÄnÄti, â€˜ayaá¹ƒ dukkhanirodhoâ€™ti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, â€˜ayaá¹ƒ dukkhanirodhagÄminÄ« paá¹­ipadÄâ€™ti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti. â€˜ime ÄsavÄti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, â€˜ayaá¹ƒ Äsavasamudayoâ€™ti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, â€˜ayaá¹ƒ Äsavanirodhoâ€™ti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, â€˜ayaá¹ƒ ÄsavanirodhagÄminÄ« paá¹­ipadÄti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti. tassa evaá¹ƒ jÄnato evaá¹ƒ passato kÄmÄsavÄpi cittaá¹ƒ vimuccati, bhavÄsavÄpi cittaá¹ƒ vimuccati, avijjÄsavÄpi cittaá¹ƒ vimuccati, â€˜vimuttasmiá¹ƒ vimuttamiti Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹ƒ hoti, â€˜khÄ«á¹‡Ä jÄti, vusitaá¹ƒ brahmacariyaá¹ƒ, kataá¹ƒ karaá¹‡Ä«yaá¹ƒ, nÄparaá¹ƒ itthattÄyÄâ€™ti pajÄnÄti. idaá¹ƒ kho, mahÄrÄja, sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ purimehi sandiá¹­á¹­hikehi sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalehi abhikkantataraÃ±ca paá¹‡Ä«tataraÃ±ca. imasmÄ ca pana, mahÄrÄja, sandiá¹­á¹­hikÄ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalÄ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ uttaritaraá¹ƒ vÄ paá¹‡Ä«tataraá¹ƒ vÄ natthÄ«"ti. ajÄtasattuupÄsakattapaá¹­ivedanÄ 250. evaá¹ƒ vutte, rÄjÄ mÄgadho ajÄtasattu vedehiputto bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "abhikkantaá¹ƒ, bhante, abhikkantaá¹ƒ, bhante. seyyathÄpi, bhante, nikkujjitaá¹ƒ vÄ ukkujjeyya, paá¹­icchannaá¹ƒ vÄ vivareyya, mÅ«á¸·hassa vÄ maggaá¹ƒ Äcikkheyya, andhakÄre vÄ telapajjotaá¹ƒ dhÄreyya â€˜cakkhumanto rÅ«pÄni dakkhantÄ«â€™ti, evamevaá¹ƒ, bhante, bhagavatÄ anekapariyÄyena dhammo pakÄsito. esÄhaá¹ƒ, bhante, bhagavantaá¹ƒ saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ gacchÄmi dhammaÃ±ca bhikkhusaá¹…ghaÃ±ca. upÄsakaá¹ƒ maá¹ƒ bhagavÄ dhÄretu ajjatagge pÄá¹‡upetaá¹ƒ saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ gataá¹ƒ. accayo maá¹ƒ, bhante, accagamÄ yathÄbÄlaá¹ƒ yathÄmÅ«á¸·haá¹ƒ yathÄakusalaá¹ƒ, yohaá¹ƒ pitaraá¹ƒ dhammikaá¹ƒ dhammarÄjÄnaá¹ƒ issariyakÄraá¹‡Ä jÄ«vitÄ voropesiá¹ƒ. tassa me, bhante bhagavÄ accayaá¹ƒ accayato paá¹­iggaá¹‡hÄtu Äyatiá¹ƒ saá¹ƒvarÄyÄ"ti. 251. "taggha tvaá¹ƒ, mahÄrÄja, accayo accagamÄ yathÄbÄlaá¹ƒ yathÄmÅ«á¸·haá¹ƒ yathÄakusalaá¹ƒ, yaá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ pitaraá¹ƒ dhammikaá¹ƒ dhammarÄjÄnaá¹ƒ jÄ«vitÄ voropesi. yato ca kho tvaá¹ƒ, mahÄrÄja, accayaá¹ƒ accayato disvÄ yathÄdhammaá¹ƒ paá¹­ikarosi, taá¹ƒ te mayaá¹ƒ paá¹­iggaá¹‡hÄma. vuddhihesÄ, mahÄrÄja, ariyassa vinaye, yo accayaá¹ƒ accayato disvÄ yathÄdhammaá¹ƒ paá¹­ikaroti, Äyatiá¹ƒ saá¹ƒvaraá¹ƒ ÄpajjatÄ«"ti.
When this was said, King AjÄtasattu, son of Queen Vedehi, said this to the Blessed One: â€œExcellent, venerable sir! Excellent, venerable sir! Just as, venerable sir, one might set upright what has been overturned, or reveal what has been hidden, or point out the path to one who is lost, or hold up a lamp in the darkness so that those with eyes might see forms, even so, venerable sir, has the Dhamma been made clear by the Blessed One in many ways. I go to the Blessed One for refuge, and to the Dhamma, and to the Order of monks ( *bhikkhusaá¹…ghaÃ±ca* ). May the Blessed One accept me as a lay follower ( *upÄsakaá¹ƒ* ) who has gone for refuge ( *saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ gataá¹ƒ* ) from this day forward, for as long as life lasts. Venerable sir, a transgression overcame me, in my foolishness, in my delusion, in my unskillfulness, in that I, for the sake of sovereignty, deprived my father, a righteous man and a righteous king, of his life. May the Blessed One accept my confession of transgression as a transgression, so that I may exercise restraint in the future."
251. pajÄnÄti, â€˜ayaá¹ƒ dukkhanirodhoâ€™ti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, â€˜ayaá¹ƒ dukkhanirodhagÄminÄ« paá¹­ipadÄâ€™ti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti. â€˜ime ÄsavÄti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, â€˜ayaá¹ƒ Äsavasamudayoâ€™ti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, â€˜ayaá¹ƒ Äsavanirodhoâ€™ti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, â€˜ayaá¹ƒ ÄsavanirodhagÄminÄ« paá¹­ipadÄti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti. tassa evaá¹ƒ jÄnato evaá¹ƒ passato kÄmÄsavÄpi cittaá¹ƒ vimuccati, bhavÄsavÄpi cittaá¹ƒ vimuccati, avijjÄsavÄpi cittaá¹ƒ vimuccati, â€˜vimuttasmiá¹ƒ vimuttamiti Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹ƒ hoti, â€˜khÄ«á¹‡Ä jÄti, vusitaá¹ƒ brahmacariyaá¹ƒ, kataá¹ƒ karaá¹‡Ä«yaá¹ƒ, nÄparaá¹ƒ itthattÄyÄâ€™ti pajÄnÄti. idaá¹ƒ kho, mahÄrÄja, sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ purimehi sandiá¹­á¹­hikehi sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalehi abhikkantataraÃ±ca paá¹‡Ä«tataraÃ±ca. imasmÄ ca pana, mahÄrÄja, sandiá¹­á¹­hikÄ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalÄ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ sandiá¹­á¹­hikaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalaá¹ƒ uttaritaraá¹ƒ vÄ paá¹‡Ä«tataraá¹ƒ vÄ natthÄ«"ti. ajÄtasattuupÄsakattapaá¹­ivedanÄ 250. evaá¹ƒ vutte, rÄjÄ mÄgadho ajÄtasattu vedehiputto bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "abhikkantaá¹ƒ, bhante, abhikkantaá¹ƒ, bhante. seyyathÄpi, bhante, nikkujjitaá¹ƒ vÄ ukkujjeyya, paá¹­icchannaá¹ƒ vÄ vivareyya, mÅ«á¸·hassa vÄ maggaá¹ƒ Äcikkheyya, andhakÄre vÄ telapajjotaá¹ƒ dhÄreyya â€˜cakkhumanto rÅ«pÄni dakkhantÄ«â€™ti, evamevaá¹ƒ, bhante, bhagavatÄ anekapariyÄyena dhammo pakÄsito. esÄhaá¹ƒ, bhante, bhagavantaá¹ƒ saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ gacchÄmi dhammaÃ±ca bhikkhusaá¹…ghaÃ±ca. upÄsakaá¹ƒ maá¹ƒ bhagavÄ dhÄretu ajjatagge pÄá¹‡upetaá¹ƒ saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ gataá¹ƒ. accayo maá¹ƒ, bhante, accagamÄ yathÄbÄlaá¹ƒ yathÄmÅ«á¸·haá¹ƒ yathÄakusalaá¹ƒ, yohaá¹ƒ pitaraá¹ƒ dhammikaá¹ƒ dhammarÄjÄnaá¹ƒ issariyakÄraá¹‡Ä jÄ«vitÄ voropesiá¹ƒ. tassa me, bhante bhagavÄ accayaá¹ƒ accayato paá¹­iggaá¹‡hÄtu Äyatiá¹ƒ saá¹ƒvarÄyÄ"ti. 251. "taggha tvaá¹ƒ, mahÄrÄja, accayo accagamÄ yathÄbÄlaá¹ƒ yathÄmÅ«á¸·haá¹ƒ yathÄakusalaá¹ƒ, yaá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ pitaraá¹ƒ dhammikaá¹ƒ dhammarÄjÄnaá¹ƒ jÄ«vitÄ voropesi. yato ca kho tvaá¹ƒ, mahÄrÄja, accayaá¹ƒ accayato disvÄ yathÄdhammaá¹ƒ paá¹­ikarosi, taá¹ƒ te mayaá¹ƒ paá¹­iggaá¹‡hÄma. vuddhihesÄ, mahÄrÄja, ariyassa vinaye, yo accayaá¹ƒ accayato disvÄ yathÄdhammaá¹ƒ paá¹­ikaroti, Äyatiá¹ƒ saá¹ƒvaraá¹ƒ ÄpajjatÄ«"ti.
"Indeed, great king, a transgression overcame you, in your foolishness, in your delusion, in your unskillfulness, in that you deprived your father, a righteous man and a righteous king, of his life. But since you, great king, having seen your transgression as a transgression, make amends in accordance with the Dhamma, we accept it from you. This, great king, is progress in the discipline of the Noble One, that one sees one's transgression as such, makes amends in accordance with the Dhamma, and undertakes restraint in the future."
252. 252. evaá¹ƒ vutte, rÄjÄ mÄgadho ajÄtasattu vedehiputto bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "handa ca dÄni mayaá¹ƒ, bhante, gacchÄma bahukiccÄ mayaá¹ƒ bahukaraá¹‡Ä«yÄ"ti. "yassadÄni tvaá¹ƒ, mahÄrÄja, kÄlaá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asÄ«"ti. atha kho rÄjÄ mÄgadho ajÄtasattu vedehiputto bhagavato bhÄsitaá¹ƒ abhinanditvÄ anumoditvÄ uá¹­á¹­hÄyÄsanÄ bhagavantaá¹ƒ abhivÄdetvÄ padakkhiá¹‡aá¹ƒ katvÄ pakkÄmi. 253. atha kho bhagavÄ acirapakkantassa raÃ±Ã±o mÄgadhassa ajÄtasattussa vedehiputtassa bhikkhÅ« Ämantesi â€“ "khatÄyaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, rÄjÄ. upahatÄyaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, rÄjÄ. sacÄyaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, rÄjÄ pitaraá¹ƒ dhammikaá¹ƒ dhammarÄjÄnaá¹ƒ jÄ«vitÄ na voropessatha, imasmiÃ±Ã±eva Äsane virajaá¹ƒ vÄ«tamalaá¹ƒ dhammacakkhuá¹ƒ uppajjissathÄ"ti. idamavoca bhagavÄ. attamanÄ te bhikkhÅ« bhagavato bhÄsitaá¹ƒ abhinandunti. sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalasuttaá¹ƒ niá¹­á¹­hitaá¹ƒ dutiyaá¹ƒ.
When this was said, King AjÄtasattu, son of Queen Vedehi, said this to the Blessed One: "Well then, venerable sir, now we will take our leave, as we are busy and have much to do." "Now is the time, great king, to do as you think fit." Then King AjÄtasattu, son of Queen Vedehi, having delighted in and rejoiced at the words of the Blessed One, rose from his seat, and after paying homage to the Blessed One, circumambulating him, he departed.
253. 252. evaá¹ƒ vutte, rÄjÄ mÄgadho ajÄtasattu vedehiputto bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "handa ca dÄni mayaá¹ƒ, bhante, gacchÄma bahukiccÄ mayaá¹ƒ bahukaraá¹‡Ä«yÄ"ti. "yassadÄni tvaá¹ƒ, mahÄrÄja, kÄlaá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asÄ«"ti. atha kho rÄjÄ mÄgadho ajÄtasattu vedehiputto bhagavato bhÄsitaá¹ƒ abhinanditvÄ anumoditvÄ uá¹­á¹­hÄyÄsanÄ bhagavantaá¹ƒ abhivÄdetvÄ padakkhiá¹‡aá¹ƒ katvÄ pakkÄmi. 253. atha kho bhagavÄ acirapakkantassa raÃ±Ã±o mÄgadhassa ajÄtasattussa vedehiputtassa bhikkhÅ« Ämantesi â€“ "khatÄyaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, rÄjÄ. upahatÄyaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, rÄjÄ. sacÄyaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, rÄjÄ pitaraá¹ƒ dhammikaá¹ƒ dhammarÄjÄnaá¹ƒ jÄ«vitÄ na voropessatha, imasmiÃ±Ã±eva Äsane virajaá¹ƒ vÄ«tamalaá¹ƒ dhammacakkhuá¹ƒ uppajjissathÄ"ti. idamavoca bhagavÄ. attamanÄ te bhikkhÅ« bhagavato bhÄsitaá¹ƒ abhinandunti. sÄmaÃ±Ã±aphalasuttaá¹ƒ niá¹­á¹­hitaá¹ƒ dutiyaá¹ƒ.
Then, soon after King AjÄtasattu, son of Queen Vedehi, had departed, the Blessed One addressed the monks, saying: "Ruined is this king, monks. Injured is this king, monks. If this king had not deprived his father, a righteous man and a righteous king, of his life, the dust-free, stainless eye of the Dhamma ( *dhammacakkhuá¹ƒ* ) would have arisen in him while sitting in this very seat." This is what the Blessed One said. Delighted, those monks rejoiced in the Blessed One's statement. The SÄmaÃ±Ã±aphala Sutta is finished, the second.
254. 3. ambaá¹­á¹­hasuttaá¹ƒ 254. evaá¹ƒ me sutaá¹ƒ â€“ ekaá¹ƒ samayaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ kosalesu cÄrikaá¹ƒ caramÄno mahatÄ bhikkhusaá¹…ghena saddhiá¹ƒ paÃ±camattehi bhikkhusatehi yena icchÄnaá¹…galaá¹ƒ nÄma kosalÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡agÄmo tadavasari. tatra sudaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ icchÄnaá¹…gale viharati icchÄnaá¹…galavanasaá¹‡á¸e. pokkharasÄtivatthu 255. tena kho pana samayena brÄhmaá¹‡o pokkharasÄti ukkaá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒ [pokkharasÄtÄ« (sÄ«.), pokkharasÄdi (pÄ«.)] ajjhÄvasati sattussadaá¹ƒ satiá¹‡akaá¹­á¹­hodakaá¹ƒ sadhaÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ rÄjabhoggaá¹ƒ raÃ±Ã±Ä pasenadinÄ kosalena dinnaá¹ƒ rÄjadÄyaá¹ƒ brahmadeyyaá¹ƒ. assosi kho brÄhmaá¹‡o pokkharasÄti â€“ "samaá¹‡o khalu, bho, gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulÄ pabbajito kosalesu cÄrikaá¹ƒ caramÄno mahatÄ bhikkhusaá¹…ghena saddhiá¹ƒ paÃ±camattehi bhikkhusatehi icchÄnaá¹…galaá¹ƒ anuppatto icchÄnaá¹…gale viharati icchÄnaá¹…galavanasaá¹‡á¸e. taá¹ƒ kho pana bhavantaá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ kalyÄá¹‡o kittisaddo abbhuggato â€“ â€˜itipi so bhagavÄ arahaá¹ƒ sammÄsambuddho vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampanno sugato lokavidÅ« anuttaro purisadammasÄrathi satthÄ devamanussÄnaá¹ƒ buddho bhagavÄâ€™ [bhagavÄti (syÄ. kaá¹ƒ.), uparisoá¹‡adaá¹‡á¸asuttÄdÄ«supi buddhaguá¹‡akathÄyaá¹ƒ evameva dissati]. so imaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ sadevakaá¹ƒ samÄrakaá¹ƒ sabrahmakaá¹ƒ sassamaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡iá¹ƒ pajaá¹ƒ sadevamanussaá¹ƒ sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ pavedeti. so dhammaá¹ƒ deseti ÄdikalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ majjhekalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ pariyosÄnakalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ, sÄtthaá¹ƒ sabyaÃ±janaá¹ƒ, kevalaparipuá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ parisuddhaá¹ƒ brahmacariyaá¹ƒ pakÄseti. sÄdhu kho pana tathÄrÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ arahataá¹ƒ dassanaá¹ƒ hotÄ«"ti. ambaá¹­á¹­hamÄá¹‡avo 256. tena kho pana samayena brÄhmaá¹‡assa pokkharasÄtissa ambaá¹­á¹­ho nÄma mÄá¹‡avo antevÄsÄ« hoti ajjhÄyako mantadharo tiá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vedÄnaá¹ƒ [bedÄnaá¹ƒ (ka.)] pÄragÅ« sanighaá¹‡á¸ukeá¹­ubhÄnaá¹ƒ sÄkkharappabhedÄnaá¹ƒ itihÄsapaÃ±camÄnaá¹ƒ padako veyyÄkaraá¹‡o lokÄyatamahÄpurisalakkhaá¹‡esu anavayo anuÃ±Ã±Ätapaá¹­iÃ±Ã±Äto sake Äcariyake tevijjake
Thus have I heard. On one occasion the Blessed One was wandering in Kosala, and eventually arrived at a Kosalan Brahmin village named IcchÄnaá¹…gala, together with a large Saá¹…gha of about five hundred monks. And there the Blessed One dwelt in the wood near IcchÄnaá¹…gala. *The Story of PokkharasÄti*
255. 3. ambaá¹­á¹­hasuttaá¹ƒ 254. evaá¹ƒ me sutaá¹ƒ â€“ ekaá¹ƒ samayaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ kosalesu cÄrikaá¹ƒ caramÄno mahatÄ bhikkhusaá¹…ghena saddhiá¹ƒ paÃ±camattehi bhikkhusatehi yena icchÄnaá¹…galaá¹ƒ nÄma kosalÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡agÄmo tadavasari. tatra sudaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ icchÄnaá¹…gale viharati icchÄnaá¹…galavanasaá¹‡á¸e. pokkharasÄtivatthu 255. tena kho pana samayena brÄhmaá¹‡o pokkharasÄti ukkaá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒ [pokkharasÄtÄ« (sÄ«.), pokkharasÄdi (pÄ«.)] ajjhÄvasati sattussadaá¹ƒ satiá¹‡akaá¹­á¹­hodakaá¹ƒ sadhaÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ rÄjabhoggaá¹ƒ raÃ±Ã±Ä pasenadinÄ kosalena dinnaá¹ƒ rÄjadÄyaá¹ƒ brahmadeyyaá¹ƒ. assosi kho brÄhmaá¹‡o pokkharasÄti â€“ "samaá¹‡o khalu, bho, gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulÄ pabbajito kosalesu cÄrikaá¹ƒ caramÄno mahatÄ bhikkhusaá¹…ghena saddhiá¹ƒ paÃ±camattehi bhikkhusatehi icchÄnaá¹…galaá¹ƒ anuppatto icchÄnaá¹…gale viharati icchÄnaá¹…galavanasaá¹‡á¸e. taá¹ƒ kho pana bhavantaá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ kalyÄá¹‡o kittisaddo abbhuggato â€“ â€˜itipi so bhagavÄ arahaá¹ƒ sammÄsambuddho vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampanno sugato lokavidÅ« anuttaro purisadammasÄrathi satthÄ devamanussÄnaá¹ƒ buddho bhagavÄâ€™ [bhagavÄti (syÄ. kaá¹ƒ.), uparisoá¹‡adaá¹‡á¸asuttÄdÄ«supi buddhaguá¹‡akathÄyaá¹ƒ evameva dissati]. so imaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ sadevakaá¹ƒ samÄrakaá¹ƒ sabrahmakaá¹ƒ sassamaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡iá¹ƒ pajaá¹ƒ sadevamanussaá¹ƒ sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ pavedeti. so dhammaá¹ƒ deseti ÄdikalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ majjhekalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ pariyosÄnakalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ, sÄtthaá¹ƒ sabyaÃ±janaá¹ƒ, kevalaparipuá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ parisuddhaá¹ƒ brahmacariyaá¹ƒ pakÄseti. sÄdhu kho pana tathÄrÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ arahataá¹ƒ dassanaá¹ƒ hotÄ«"ti. ambaá¹­á¹­hamÄá¹‡avo 256. tena kho pana samayena brÄhmaá¹‡assa pokkharasÄtissa ambaá¹­á¹­ho nÄma mÄá¹‡avo antevÄsÄ« hoti ajjhÄyako mantadharo tiá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vedÄnaá¹ƒ [bedÄnaá¹ƒ (ka.)] pÄragÅ« sanighaá¹‡á¸ukeá¹­ubhÄnaá¹ƒ sÄkkharappabhedÄnaá¹ƒ itihÄsapaÃ±camÄnaá¹ƒ padako veyyÄkaraá¹‡o lokÄyatamahÄpurisalakkhaá¹‡esu anavayo anuÃ±Ã±Ätapaá¹­iÃ±Ã±Äto sake Äcariyake tevijjake
Now at that time, the Brahmin PokkharasÄti was dwelling at Ukkaá¹­á¹­ha, a place teeming with life, with grass, wood and water, and with grain, a royal domain granted by King Pasenadi of Kosala as a royal gift, a sacred grant. And the Brahmin PokkharasÄti heard, "The ascetic Gotama, the son of the ÅšÄkyans, who went forth from the ÅšÄkya clan, is wandering in Kosala with a large Saá¹…gha of monks, and has arrived at IcchÄnaá¹…gala, and is dwelling in the wood near IcchÄnaá¹…gala. Now concerning that venerable Gotama, such a good report has been spread about: â€˜Thus indeed, the Blessed One is an *arhat*, a fully enlightened *sammÄsambuddha*, perfect in knowledge and conduct (*vijjÄ-caraá¹‡a-sampanno*), a *sugata*, knower of the world (*lokavidÅ«*), unsurpassed leader of persons to be tamed (*anuttaro purisa-damma-sÄrathi*), teacher of gods and humans (*satthÄ deva-manussÄnaá¹ƒ*), the Buddha, the Blessed One.â€™ He makes knownâ€”having realized it through direct knowledgeâ€”this world with its gods (*sadevakaá¹ƒ*), its *MÄras* (*samÄrakaá¹ƒ*), and its *BrahmÄs* (*sabrahmakaá¹ƒ*), its generations with their contemplatives & brahmins (*sassamaá¹‡a-brÄhmaá¹‡iá¹ƒ*), their rulers & commonfolk; (*sadevamanussaá¹ƒ*) He teaches the Dharma that is good at the beginning (*Ädi-kalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ*) â€¦ he reveals the spiritual life (*brahmacariyaá¹ƒ*) that is utterly perfect and pure (*kevalaparipuá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ parisuddhaá¹ƒ*). â€¦Now it is good see such *arhats*." *Ambaá¹­á¹­ha MÄá¹‡ava*
256. 3. ambaá¹­á¹­hasuttaá¹ƒ 254. evaá¹ƒ me sutaá¹ƒ â€“ ekaá¹ƒ samayaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ kosalesu cÄrikaá¹ƒ caramÄno mahatÄ bhikkhusaá¹…ghena saddhiá¹ƒ paÃ±camattehi bhikkhusatehi yena icchÄnaá¹…galaá¹ƒ nÄma kosalÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡agÄmo tadavasari. tatra sudaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ icchÄnaá¹…gale viharati icchÄnaá¹…galavanasaá¹‡á¸e. pokkharasÄtivatthu 255. tena kho pana samayena brÄhmaá¹‡o pokkharasÄti ukkaá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒ [pokkharasÄtÄ« (sÄ«.), pokkharasÄdi (pÄ«.)] ajjhÄvasati sattussadaá¹ƒ satiá¹‡akaá¹­á¹­hodakaá¹ƒ sadhaÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ rÄjabhoggaá¹ƒ raÃ±Ã±Ä pasenadinÄ kosalena dinnaá¹ƒ rÄjadÄyaá¹ƒ brahmadeyyaá¹ƒ. assosi kho brÄhmaá¹‡o pokkharasÄti â€“ "samaá¹‡o khalu, bho, gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulÄ pabbajito kosalesu cÄrikaá¹ƒ caramÄno mahatÄ bhikkhusaá¹…ghena saddhiá¹ƒ paÃ±camattehi bhikkhusatehi icchÄnaá¹…galaá¹ƒ anuppatto icchÄnaá¹…gale viharati icchÄnaá¹…galavanasaá¹‡á¸e. taá¹ƒ kho pana bhavantaá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ kalyÄá¹‡o kittisaddo abbhuggato â€“ â€˜itipi so bhagavÄ arahaá¹ƒ sammÄsambuddho vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampanno sugato lokavidÅ« anuttaro purisadammasÄrathi satthÄ devamanussÄnaá¹ƒ buddho bhagavÄâ€™ [bhagavÄti (syÄ. kaá¹ƒ.), uparisoá¹‡adaá¹‡á¸asuttÄdÄ«supi buddhaguá¹‡akathÄyaá¹ƒ evameva dissati]. so imaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ sadevakaá¹ƒ samÄrakaá¹ƒ sabrahmakaá¹ƒ sassamaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡iá¹ƒ pajaá¹ƒ sadevamanussaá¹ƒ sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ pavedeti. so dhammaá¹ƒ deseti ÄdikalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ majjhekalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ pariyosÄnakalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ, sÄtthaá¹ƒ sabyaÃ±janaá¹ƒ, kevalaparipuá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ parisuddhaá¹ƒ brahmacariyaá¹ƒ pakÄseti. sÄdhu kho pana tathÄrÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ arahataá¹ƒ dassanaá¹ƒ hotÄ«"ti. ambaá¹­á¹­hamÄá¹‡avo 256. tena kho pana samayena brÄhmaá¹‡assa pokkharasÄtissa ambaá¹­á¹­ho nÄma mÄá¹‡avo antevÄsÄ« hoti ajjhÄyako mantadharo tiá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vedÄnaá¹ƒ [bedÄnaá¹ƒ (ka.)] pÄragÅ« sanighaá¹‡á¸ukeá¹­ubhÄnaá¹ƒ sÄkkharappabhedÄnaá¹ƒ itihÄsapaÃ±camÄnaá¹ƒ padako veyyÄkaraá¹‡o lokÄyatamahÄpurisalakkhaá¹‡esu anavayo anuÃ±Ã±Ätapaá¹­iÃ±Ã±Äto sake Äcariyake tevijjake
Now at that time the Brahmin PokkharasÄti had a student named Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, a young man (*mÄá¹‡ava*) who was a resident pupil (*antevÄsÄ«*), a reciter (*ajjhÄyako*), a master of the *mantras* (*mantadharo*), versed in the three Vedas (*tiá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ vedÄnaá¹ƒ pÄragÅ«*), with their vocabularies (*sanighaá¹‡á¸ukeá¹­ubhÄnaá¹ƒ*), the differentiation of their letters (*sÄkkharappabhedÄnaá¹ƒ*), and fifthly the traditions (*itihÄsa-paÃ±camÄnaá¹ƒ*), skilled in word and sentence structure (*padako veyyÄkaraá¹‡o*), and not subject to refutation in the systems of materialism (*lokÄyata*) and the characteristics of a great man (*mahÄpurisa-lakkhaá¹‡esu anavayo*), acknowledged and accepted by his teacher in the Three Vedas In the context of speaking, it means: "You know the Dhamma that I know and I know the Dhamma that you know."
257. pÄvacane â€“ "yamahaá¹ƒ jÄnÄmi, taá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ jÄnÄsi, yaá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ jÄnÄsi tamahaá¹ƒ jÄnÄmÄ«"ti. 257. atha kho brÄhmaá¹‡o pokkharasÄti ambaá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avaá¹ƒ Ämantesi â€“ "ayaá¹ƒ, tÄta ambaá¹­á¹­ha, samaá¹‡o gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulÄ pabbajito kosalesu cÄrikaá¹ƒ caramÄno mahatÄ bhikkhusaá¹…ghena saddhiá¹ƒ paÃ±camattehi bhikkhusatehi icchÄnaá¹…galaá¹ƒ anuppatto icchÄnaá¹…gale viharati icchÄnaá¹…galavanasaá¹‡á¸e. taá¹ƒ kho pana bhavantaá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ kalyÄá¹‡o kittisaddo abbhuggato â€“ â€˜itipi so bhagavÄ, arahaá¹ƒ sammÄsambuddho vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampanno sugato lokavidÅ« anuttaro purisadammasÄrathi satthÄ devamanussÄnaá¹ƒ buddho bhagavÄâ€™. so imaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ sadevakaá¹ƒ samÄrakaá¹ƒ sabrahmakaá¹ƒ sassamaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡iá¹ƒ pajaá¹ƒ sadevamanussaá¹ƒ sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ pavedeti. so dhammaá¹ƒ deseti ÄdikalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ majjhekalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ pariyosÄnakalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ, sÄtthaá¹ƒ sabyaÃ±janaá¹ƒ kevalaparipuá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ parisuddhaá¹ƒ brahmacariyaá¹ƒ pakÄseti. sÄdhu kho pana tathÄrÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ arahataá¹ƒ dassanaá¹ƒ hotÄ«ti. ehi tvaá¹ƒ tÄta ambaá¹­á¹­ha, yena samaá¹‡o gotamo tenupasaá¹…kama, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ samaá¹‡aá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ jÄnÄhi, yadi vÄ taá¹ƒ bhavantaá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ tathÄsantaá¹ƒyeva saddo abbhuggato, yadi vÄ no tathÄ. yadi vÄ so bhavaá¹ƒ gotamo tÄdiso, yadi vÄ na tÄdiso, tathÄ mayaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ bhavantaá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ vedissÄmÄ"ti. 258. "yathÄ kathaá¹ƒ panÄhaá¹ƒ, bho, taá¹ƒ bhavantaá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ jÄnissÄmi â€“ â€˜yadi vÄ taá¹ƒ bhavantaá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ tathÄsantaá¹ƒyeva saddo abbhuggato, yadi vÄ no tathÄ. yadi vÄ so bhavaá¹ƒ gotamo tÄdiso, yadi vÄ na tÄdiso"â€™ti. "ÄgatÄni kho, tÄta ambaá¹­á¹­ha, amhÄkaá¹ƒ mantesu dvattiá¹ƒsa mahÄpurisalakkhaá¹‡Äni, yehi samannÄgatassa mahÄpurisassa dveyeva gatiyo bhavanti anaÃ±Ã±Ä. sace agÄraá¹ƒ ajjhÄvasati, rÄjÄ hoti cakkavattÄ« dhammiko dhammarÄjÄ cÄturanto vijitÄvÄ« janapadatthÄvariyappatto sattaratanasamannÄgato. tassimÄni satta ratanÄni bhavanti. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ cakkaratanaá¹ƒ, hatthiratanaá¹ƒ, assaratanaá¹ƒ, maá¹‡iratanaá¹ƒ, itthiratanaá¹ƒ, gahapatiratanaá¹ƒ, pariá¹‡Äyakaratanameva sattamaá¹ƒ. parosahassaá¹ƒ kho panassa puttÄ
Then the *brÄhmaá¹‡a* PokkharasÄti addressed the *mÄá¹‡ava* Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, saying: "Come, dear Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, the *Å›ramaá¹‡a* Gotama, the son of the ÅšÄkyas, who has gone forth from the ÅšÄkya clan, is wandering in Kosala, and has arrived at IcchÄnangala with a great *bhikkhu-saá¹ƒgha*, with about five hundred *bhikkhus*, and is staying in the grove of IcchÄnangalavana. And concerning that Blessed Lord Gotama, a good report has spread about thus: 'Indeed, the Blessed One is an *arhat*, a perfectly enlightened Buddha (*sammÄsambuddho*), endowed with knowledge and conduct (*vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampanno*), a Well-Farer (*sugato*), Knower of the worlds (*lokavidÅ«*), an unsurpassed trainer of persons to be tamed (*anuttaro purisadammasÄrathi*), teacher of gods and humans (*satthÄ devamanussÄnaá¹ƒ*), a Buddha (*buddho*), a Blessed Lord (*bhagavÄ*)'. He, having realized it by his own super-knowledge (*abhiÃ±Ã±Ä*), proclaims this world with its gods (*sadevakaá¹ƒ*), its *MÄras* (*samÄrakaá¹ƒ*), and its *BrahmÄs* (*sabrahmakaá¹ƒ*), this generation with its *Å›ramaá¹‡as* and *brÄhmaá¹‡as* (*sassamaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡iá¹ƒ*), its rulers and people (*sadevamanussaá¹ƒ*). He teaches the *Dharma* (*dhammaá¹ƒ*), which is lovely in its beginning (*ÄdikalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ*), lovely in its middle (*majjhekalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ*), lovely in its ending (*pariyosÄnakalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ*), in the spirit (*sÄtthaá¹ƒ*) and in the letter (*sabyaÃ±janaá¹ƒ*), and displays the fully perfected and purified holy life (*brahmacariyaá¹ƒ pakÄseti*). It is good to see such *arhats*." "Come, dear Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, go to the *Å›ramaá¹‡a* Gotama; having gone, find out about the *Å›ramaá¹‡a* Gotama; whether the report about the Reverend Gotama is as it is, or not. Whether the Reverend Gotama is such, or not, in that way we shall know the Reverend Gotama."
258. pÄvacane â€“ "yamahaá¹ƒ jÄnÄmi, taá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ jÄnÄsi, yaá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ jÄnÄsi tamahaá¹ƒ jÄnÄmÄ«"ti. 257. atha kho brÄhmaá¹‡o pokkharasÄti ambaá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avaá¹ƒ Ämantesi â€“ "ayaá¹ƒ, tÄta ambaá¹­á¹­ha, samaá¹‡o gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulÄ pabbajito kosalesu cÄrikaá¹ƒ caramÄno mahatÄ bhikkhusaá¹…ghena saddhiá¹ƒ paÃ±camattehi bhikkhusatehi icchÄnaá¹…galaá¹ƒ anuppatto icchÄnaá¹…gale viharati icchÄnaá¹…galavanasaá¹‡á¸e. taá¹ƒ kho pana bhavantaá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ kalyÄá¹‡o kittisaddo abbhuggato â€“ â€˜itipi so bhagavÄ, arahaá¹ƒ sammÄsambuddho vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampanno sugato lokavidÅ« anuttaro purisadammasÄrathi satthÄ devamanussÄnaá¹ƒ buddho bhagavÄâ€™. so imaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ sadevakaá¹ƒ samÄrakaá¹ƒ sabrahmakaá¹ƒ sassamaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡iá¹ƒ pajaá¹ƒ sadevamanussaá¹ƒ sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ pavedeti. so dhammaá¹ƒ deseti ÄdikalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ majjhekalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ pariyosÄnakalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ, sÄtthaá¹ƒ sabyaÃ±janaá¹ƒ kevalaparipuá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ parisuddhaá¹ƒ brahmacariyaá¹ƒ pakÄseti. sÄdhu kho pana tathÄrÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ arahataá¹ƒ dassanaá¹ƒ hotÄ«ti. ehi tvaá¹ƒ tÄta ambaá¹­á¹­ha, yena samaá¹‡o gotamo tenupasaá¹…kama, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ samaá¹‡aá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ jÄnÄhi, yadi vÄ taá¹ƒ bhavantaá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ tathÄsantaá¹ƒyeva saddo abbhuggato, yadi vÄ no tathÄ. yadi vÄ so bhavaá¹ƒ gotamo tÄdiso, yadi vÄ na tÄdiso, tathÄ mayaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ bhavantaá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ vedissÄmÄ"ti. 258. "yathÄ kathaá¹ƒ panÄhaá¹ƒ, bho, taá¹ƒ bhavantaá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ jÄnissÄmi â€“ â€˜yadi vÄ taá¹ƒ bhavantaá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ tathÄsantaá¹ƒyeva saddo abbhuggato, yadi vÄ no tathÄ. yadi vÄ so bhavaá¹ƒ gotamo tÄdiso, yadi vÄ na tÄdiso"â€™ti. "ÄgatÄni kho, tÄta ambaá¹­á¹­ha, amhÄkaá¹ƒ mantesu dvattiá¹ƒsa mahÄpurisalakkhaá¹‡Äni, yehi samannÄgatassa mahÄpurisassa dveyeva gatiyo bhavanti anaÃ±Ã±Ä. sace agÄraá¹ƒ ajjhÄvasati, rÄjÄ hoti cakkavattÄ« dhammiko dhammarÄjÄ cÄturanto vijitÄvÄ« janapadatthÄvariyappatto sattaratanasamannÄgato. tassimÄni satta ratanÄni bhavanti. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ cakkaratanaá¹ƒ, hatthiratanaá¹ƒ, assaratanaá¹ƒ, maá¹‡iratanaá¹ƒ, itthiratanaá¹ƒ, gahapatiratanaá¹ƒ, pariá¹‡Äyakaratanameva sattamaá¹ƒ. parosahassaá¹ƒ kho panassa puttÄ
"But how, sir, shall I know the Reverend Gotamaâ€”whether the report about the Reverend Gotama is as it is, or not. Whether the Reverend Gotama is such, or not?" "It has come down to us, dear Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, in our *mantras*, that the great man who is possessed of the thirty-two marks of a great man (*mahÄpurisalakkhaá¹‡Äni*) has only two courses open to him, no other. If he lives the household life, he will become a ruler, a wheel-turning righteous monarch of the law (*cakravartin*), a righteous king (*dhammarÄjÄ*), conqueror of the four quarters (*cÄturanto*), all-victorious (*vijitÄvÄ«*), who has established the security of his realm (*janapadatthÄvariyappatto*) and is possessed of the seven treasures (*sattaratanasamannÄgato*). He has these seven treasures (*satta ratanÄni*): Namely: the wheel-treasure (*cakkaratanaá¹ƒ*), the elephant-treasure (*hatthiratanaá¹ƒ*), the horse-treasure (*assaratanaá¹ƒ*), the jewel-treasure (*maá¹‡iratanaá¹ƒ*), the woman-treasure (*itthiratanaá¹ƒ*), the householder-treasure (*gahapatiratanaá¹ƒ*), and the counsellor-treasure (*pariá¹‡Äyakaratanameva*) as the seventh. He has more than a thousand sons (*parosahassaá¹ƒ kho panassa puttÄ*). They are heroes, of heroic stature, conquerors of the hostile army. He dwells having conquered this sea-girt land without stick or sword, by the Dhamma. But if he goes forth from the household life into homelessness, then he will become an *arhat* (arahant), a *sammÄsambuddha* (fully-enlightened Buddha), one who draws back the veil from the world. And, Ambattha, I am the giver of the *mantras*, and you are the receiver. "Very good, sir", said Ambattha, the young Brahmin, assenting to the words of the Brahmin PokkharasÄti. He rose from his seat, respectfully circumambulated PokkharasÄti, and mounting his chariot drawn by a mare, proceeded with a large number of young men towards the grove of IcchÄnaá¹…gala. He drove as far as the carriage could go, then alighted from the carriage and continued on foot into the park. Now at that time a number of monks were doing walking meditation in the open air. Then Ambattha, the young Brahmin, approached those monks and said to them: "Where, indeed, is the revered Gotama currently staying? For we have come here to see the revered Gotama". Then the monks thought: "This Ambattha, the young Brahmin, is of well-known lineage and a pupil of the renowned Brahmin PokkharasÄti. It would not trouble the Blessed One to have a conversation with such a young man". They said to Ambattha, the young Brahmin: "That is the dwelling (*vihÄra*) of the Blessed One, with its doors shut. Approach it quietly, without haste, enter the porch, clear your throat, and knock on the bolt. The Blessed One will open the door for you". Then Ambattha, the young Brahmin, went to the dwelling (*vihÄra*) with the closed door. Approaching it quietly and without haste, he entered the porch, cleared his throat, and knocked on the bolt. The Blessed One opened the door. Ambattha, the young Brahmin, entered. The young men also entered, exchanged courteous greetings with the Blessed One, and after exchanging polite and courteous conversation, sat down to one side. But Ambattha, the young Brahmin, even while walking, exchanged some polite conversation with the Blessed One, who was sitting. Even while standing, he exchanged some polite conversation with the Blessed One, who was sitting. Then the Blessed One said to Ambattha, the young Brahmin: "Is this how you converse with venerable and learned Brahmins, elderly teachers of teachers, as you do with me, walking and standing while I am sitting, uttering vague words of politeness?" First denigration of becoming. "No, Master Gotama. For a Brahmin should converse with a Brahmin who is walking while walking, with a Brahmin who is standing while standing, with a Brahmin who is sitting while sitting, and with a Brahmin who is lying down while lying down. Those shaven, petty ascetics, menials, the black offspring of Brahma's feetâ€”it is fitting to speak with them as I do with the Reverend Gotama.â€ â€œAmbattha, you came here seeking something. For whatever purpose you came, you should carefully attend to that purpose. Ambattha, this worthy young man has not perfected his training. His conceit of being trained stems merely from his inexperience." Then Ambattha, the young Brahmin, being addressed with the words of one untrained, became angry and displeased. Reviling the Blessed One, berating the Blessed One, disparaging the Blessed One, he said this to the Blessed One: "The ascetic Gotama is malicious to me!" "The Sakyans, Reverend Gotama, are fierce; the Sakyans, Reverend Gotama, are rough; the Sakyans, Reverend Gotama, are flighty; the Sakyans, Reverend Gotama, are abusive. Though menial, being menial, they do not honor Brahmins, they do not respect Brahmins. kaá¹ƒ: A kind of *bÄ«ja*; well; for the benefit of (after a dative). pÄ«: reduplication for pyÄy; schmï¿¤hen; hassen; spotten; to taunt. na: not; no; nor; neither; like. They do not esteem the Brahmins, they do not venerate the Brahmins, they do not respect the Brahmins. 'Regarding this, Gotama, it is unseemly, it is not fitting that these ÅšÄkyas, menials though they are, being menials, should not honor the Brahmins, should not respect the Brahmins, should not esteem the Brahmins, should not venerate the Brahmins, should not respect the Brahmins.â€™â€ This, it seems, was the first time that Ambaá¹­á¹­ha the student cast the charge of menial birth against the ÅšÄkyas. The Second Charge of Menial Birth â€œWhat then, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, have the ÅšÄkyas done against you?â€ â€œOnce, venerable Gotama, I went to Kapilavatthu on some business or other for PokkharasÄti, the Brahmin, my teacher. I went to the meeting-hall of the ÅšÄkyas. And at that time many ÅšÄkyas and ÅšÄkya youths were sitting on high seats in the meeting-hall, poking each other with their fingers, laughing and playing, and, I thought, making fun of me; and no one even invited me to sit down. 'Regarding this, Gotama, it is unseemly, it is not fitting that these ÅšÄkyas, menials though they are, being menials, should not honor the Brahmins, should not respect the Brahmins, should not esteem the Brahmins, should not venerate the Brahmins, should not respect the Brahmins.â€™â€ This, it seems, was the second time that Ambaá¹­á¹­ha the student cast the charge of menial birth against the ÅšÄkyas. The Third Charge of Menial Birth â€œEven the quail, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, little bird that it is, can say what it likes in its own nest. This Kapilavatthu belongs to the ÅšÄkyas, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, and venerable Ambaá¹­á¹­ha does not deserve to be censured for this trifle.â€ â€œThere are these four classes, Gotama: the nobles, the Brahmins, the merchants, and the laborers. And of these four classes, Gotama, three classes â€“ the nobles, the merchants, and the laborers â€“ are simply the servants of the Brahmins. 'Regarding this, Gotama, it is unseemly, it is not fitting that these ÅšÄkyas, menials though they are, being menials, should not honor the Brahmins, should not respect the Brahmins, should not esteem the Brahmins, should not venerate the Brahmins, should not respect the Brahmins.â€™â€ This, it seems, was the third time that Ambaá¹­á¹­ha the student cast the charge of menial birth against the ÅšÄkyas. â€œInsulting with the claim of being born of a slave."
259. bhavanti sÅ«rÄ vÄ«raá¹…garÅ«pÄ parasenappamaddanÄ. so imaá¹ƒ pathaviá¹ƒ sÄgarapariyantaá¹ƒ adaá¹‡á¸ena asatthena dhammena abhivijiya ajjhÄvasati. sace kho pana agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajati, arahaá¹ƒ hoti sammÄsambuddho loke vivaá¹­á¹­acchado. ahaá¹ƒ kho pana, tÄta ambaá¹­á¹­ha, mantÄnaá¹ƒ dÄtÄ, tvaá¹ƒ mantÄnaá¹ƒ paá¹­iggahetÄ"ti. 259. "evaá¹ƒ, bho"ti kho ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo brÄhmaá¹‡assa pokkharasÄtissa paá¹­issutvÄ uá¹­á¹­hÄyÄsanÄ brÄhmaá¹‡aá¹ƒ pokkharasÄtiá¹ƒ abhivÄdetvÄ padakkhiá¹‡aá¹ƒ katvÄ vaá¸·avÄrathamÄruyha sambahulehi mÄá¹‡avakehi saddhiá¹ƒ yena icchÄnaá¹…galavanasaá¹‡á¸o tena pÄyÄsi. yÄvatikÄ yÄnassa bhÅ«mi yÄnena gantvÄ yÄnÄ paccorohitvÄ pattikova ÄrÄmaá¹ƒ pÄvisi. tena kho pana samayena sambahulÄ bhikkhÅ« abbhokÄse caá¹…kamanti. atha kho ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo yena te bhikkhÅ« tenupasaá¹…kami, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ te bhikkhÅ« etadavoca â€“ "kahaá¹ƒ nu kho, bho, etarahi so bhavaá¹ƒ gotamo viharati? taÃ±hi mayaá¹ƒ bhavantaá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ dassanÄya idhÅ«pasaá¹…kantÄ"ti. 260. atha kho tesaá¹ƒ bhikkhÅ«naá¹ƒ etadahosi â€“ "ayaá¹ƒ kho ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo abhiÃ±Ã±ÄtakolaÃ±Ã±o ceva abhiÃ±Ã±Ätassa ca brÄhmaá¹‡assa pokkharasÄtissa antevÄsÄ«. agaru kho pana bhagavato evarÅ«pehi kulaputtehi saddhiá¹ƒ kathÄsallÄpo hotÄ«"ti. te ambaá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avaá¹ƒ etadavocuá¹ƒ â€“ "eso ambaá¹­á¹­ha vihÄro saá¹ƒvutadvÄro, tena appasaddo upasaá¹…kamitvÄ ataramÄno Äá¸·indaá¹ƒ pavisitvÄ ukkÄsitvÄ aggaá¸·aá¹ƒ Äkoá¹­ehi, vivarissati te bhagavÄ dvÄra"nti. 261. atha kho ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo yena so vihÄro saá¹ƒvutadvÄro, tena appasaddo upasaá¹…kamitvÄ ataramÄno Äá¸·indaá¹ƒ pavisitvÄ ukkÄsitvÄ aggaá¸·aá¹ƒ Äkoá¹­esi. vivari bhagavÄ dvÄraá¹ƒ. pÄvisi ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo. mÄá¹‡avakÄpi pavisitvÄ bhagavatÄ saddhiá¹ƒ sammodiá¹ƒsu, sammodanÄ«yaá¹ƒ kathaá¹ƒ sÄraá¹‡Ä«yaá¹ƒ vÄ«tisÄretvÄ ekamantaá¹ƒ nisÄ«diá¹ƒsu. ambaá¹­á¹­ho pana mÄá¹‡avo caá¹…kamantopi nisinnena bhagavatÄ kaÃ±ci kaÃ±ci [kiÃ±ci kiÃ±ci (ka.)]
â€˜Very good, sirâ€™, said Ambattha at Pokkharasatiâ€™s words, and he got up, passed by Pokkharasati with his right side, got into his chariot drawn by a mare and, accompanied by a number of young men, headed for the dense jungle of Icchanankala. He drove as far as the carriage would go, then alighted and continued on foot to the *ÄrÄma*. At that time a number of monks were doing walking meditation in the open air. Then Ambattha approached those monks and said: â€˜Where is the Reverend Gotama to be found just now? For we have come here to see the Reverend Gotama.â€™
260. bhavanti sÅ«rÄ vÄ«raá¹…garÅ«pÄ parasenappamaddanÄ. so imaá¹ƒ pathaviá¹ƒ sÄgarapariyantaá¹ƒ adaá¹‡á¸ena asatthena dhammena abhivijiya ajjhÄvasati. sace kho pana agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajati, arahaá¹ƒ hoti sammÄsambuddho loke vivaá¹­á¹­acchado. ahaá¹ƒ kho pana, tÄta ambaá¹­á¹­ha, mantÄnaá¹ƒ dÄtÄ, tvaá¹ƒ mantÄnaá¹ƒ paá¹­iggahetÄ"ti. 259.
