"evaá¹ƒ, bho"ti kho ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo brÄhmaá¹‡assa pokkharasÄtissa paá¹­issutvÄ uá¹­á¹­hÄyÄsanÄ brÄhmaá¹‡aá¹ƒ pokkharasÄtiá¹ƒ abhivÄdetvÄ padakkhiá¹‡aá¹ƒ katvÄ vaá¸·avÄrathamÄruyha sambahulehi mÄá¹‡avakehi saddhiá¹ƒ yena icchÄnaá¹…galavanasaá¹‡á¸o tena pÄyÄsi. yÄvatikÄ yÄnassa bhÅ«mi yÄnena gantvÄ yÄnÄ paccorohitvÄ pattikova ÄrÄmaá¹ƒ pÄvisi. tena kho pana samayena sambahulÄ bhikkhÅ« abbhokÄse caá¹…kamanti. atha kho ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo yena te bhikkhÅ« tenupasaá¹…kami, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ te bhikkhÅ« etadavoca â€“ "kahaá¹ƒ nu kho, bho, etarahi so bhavaá¹ƒ gotamo viharati? taÃ±hi mayaá¹ƒ bhavantaá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ dassanÄya idhÅ«pasaá¹…kantÄ"ti. 260. atha kho tesaá¹ƒ bhikkhÅ«naá¹ƒ etadahosi â€“ "ayaá¹ƒ kho ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo abhiÃ±Ã±ÄtakolaÃ±Ã±o ceva abhiÃ±Ã±Ätassa ca brÄhmaá¹‡assa pokkharasÄtissa antevÄsÄ«. agaru kho pana bhagavato evarÅ«pehi kulaputtehi saddhiá¹ƒ kathÄsallÄpo hotÄ«"ti. te ambaá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avaá¹ƒ etadavocuá¹ƒ â€“ "eso ambaá¹­á¹­ha vihÄro saá¹ƒvutadvÄro, tena appasaddo upasaá¹…kamitvÄ ataramÄno Äá¸·indaá¹ƒ pavisitvÄ ukkÄsitvÄ aggaá¸·aá¹ƒ Äkoá¹­ehi, vivarissati te bhagavÄ dvÄra"nti. 261. atha kho ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo yena so vihÄro saá¹ƒvutadvÄro, tena appasaddo upasaá¹…kamitvÄ ataramÄno Äá¸·indaá¹ƒ pavisitvÄ ukkÄsitvÄ aggaá¸·aá¹ƒ Äkoá¹­esi. vivari bhagavÄ dvÄraá¹ƒ. pÄvisi ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo. mÄá¹‡avakÄpi pavisitvÄ bhagavatÄ saddhiá¹ƒ sammodiá¹ƒsu, sammodanÄ«yaá¹ƒ kathaá¹ƒ sÄraá¹‡Ä«yaá¹ƒ vÄ«tisÄretvÄ ekamantaá¹ƒ nisÄ«diá¹ƒsu. ambaá¹­á¹­ho pana mÄá¹‡avo caá¹…kamantopi nisinnena bhagavatÄ kaÃ±ci kaÃ±ci [kiÃ±ci kiÃ±ci (ka.)]
Then those monks thought: â€˜This is Ambattha, a youth of good family and a pupil of the distinguished Brahmin Pokkharasati. The Lord would not mind having a conversation with such a young man.â€™ They said to Ambattha: "That is his dwelling, with the door closed. Go quietly up to it, go on to the verandah without haste, cough, and knock on the bolt. The Blessed One will open the door to you".
261. bhavanti sÅ«rÄ vÄ«raá¹…garÅ«pÄ parasenappamaddanÄ. so imaá¹ƒ pathaviá¹ƒ sÄgarapariyantaá¹ƒ adaá¹‡á¸ena asatthena dhammena abhivijiya ajjhÄvasati. sace kho pana agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajati, arahaá¹ƒ hoti sammÄsambuddho loke vivaá¹­á¹­acchado. ahaá¹ƒ kho pana, tÄta ambaá¹­á¹­ha, mantÄnaá¹ƒ dÄtÄ, tvaá¹ƒ mantÄnaá¹ƒ paá¹­iggahetÄ"ti. 259. "evaá¹ƒ, bho"ti kho ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo brÄhmaá¹‡assa pokkharasÄtissa paá¹­issutvÄ uá¹­á¹­hÄyÄsanÄ brÄhmaá¹‡aá¹ƒ pokkharasÄtiá¹ƒ abhivÄdetvÄ padakkhiá¹‡aá¹ƒ katvÄ vaá¸·avÄrathamÄruyha sambahulehi mÄá¹‡avakehi saddhiá¹ƒ yena icchÄnaá¹…galavanasaá¹‡á¸o tena pÄyÄsi. yÄvatikÄ yÄnassa bhÅ«mi yÄnena gantvÄ yÄnÄ paccorohitvÄ pattikova ÄrÄmaá¹ƒ pÄvisi. tena kho pana samayena sambahulÄ bhikkhÅ« abbhokÄse caá¹…kamanti. atha kho ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo yena te bhikkhÅ« tenupasaá¹…kami, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ te bhikkhÅ« etadavoca â€“ "kahaá¹ƒ nu kho, bho, etarahi so bhavaá¹ƒ gotamo viharati? taÃ±hi mayaá¹ƒ bhavantaá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ dassanÄya idhÅ«pasaá¹…kantÄ"ti. 260. atha kho tesaá¹ƒ bhikkhÅ«naá¹ƒ etadahosi â€“ "ayaá¹ƒ kho ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo abhiÃ±Ã±ÄtakolaÃ±Ã±o ceva abhiÃ±Ã±Ätassa ca brÄhmaá¹‡assa pokkharasÄtissa antevÄsÄ«. agaru kho pana bhagavato evarÅ«pehi kulaputtehi saddhiá¹ƒ kathÄsallÄpo hotÄ«"ti. te ambaá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avaá¹ƒ etadavocuá¹ƒ â€“ "eso ambaá¹­á¹­ha vihÄro saá¹ƒvutadvÄro, tena appasaddo upasaá¹…kamitvÄ ataramÄno Äá¸·indaá¹ƒ pavisitvÄ ukkÄsitvÄ aggaá¸·aá¹ƒ Äkoá¹­ehi, vivarissati te bhagavÄ dvÄra"nti. 261. atha kho ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo yena so vihÄro saá¹ƒvutadvÄro, tena appasaddo upasaá¹…kamitvÄ ataramÄno Äá¸·indaá¹ƒ pavisitvÄ ukkÄsitvÄ aggaá¸·aá¹ƒ Äkoá¹­esi. vivari bhagavÄ dvÄraá¹ƒ. pÄvisi ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo. mÄá¹‡avakÄpi pavisitvÄ bhagavatÄ saddhiá¹ƒ sammodiá¹ƒsu, sammodanÄ«yaá¹ƒ kathaá¹ƒ sÄraá¹‡Ä«yaá¹ƒ vÄ«tisÄretvÄ ekamantaá¹ƒ nisÄ«diá¹ƒsu. ambaá¹­á¹­ho pana mÄá¹‡avo caá¹…kamantopi nisinnena bhagavatÄ kaÃ±ci kaÃ±ci [kiÃ±ci kiÃ±ci (ka.)]
Then Ambattha approached the dwelling, which had its door shut, quietly and without haste, entered the porch, coughed, and knocked on the bolt. The Blessed One opened the door. Ambattha entered. The young men also entered and exchanged greetings with the Blessed One. After courteous and agreeable talk, they sat down to one side. But Ambattha, while walking back and forth, exchanged some words of civility with the Blessed One who was seated; even while standing, he exchanged some words of civility with the Blessed One who was seated.
262. kathaá¹ƒ sÄraá¹‡Ä«yaá¹ƒ vÄ«tisÄreti, á¹­hitopi nisinnena bhagavatÄ kiÃ±ci kiÃ±ci kathaá¹ƒ sÄraá¹‡Ä«yaá¹ƒ vÄ«tisÄreti. 262. atha kho bhagavÄ ambaá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "evaá¹ƒ nu te, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, brÄhmaá¹‡ehi vuddhehi mahallakehi ÄcariyapÄcariyehi saddhiá¹ƒ kathÄsallÄpo hoti, yathayidaá¹ƒ caraá¹ƒ tiá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒ nisinnena mayÄ kiÃ±ci kiÃ±ci kathaá¹ƒ sÄraá¹‡Ä«yaá¹ƒ vÄ«tisÄretÄ«"ti? paá¹­hamaibbhavÄdo 263. "no hidaá¹ƒ, bho gotama. gacchanto vÄ hi, bho gotama, gacchantena brÄhmaá¹‡o brÄhmaá¹‡ena saddhiá¹ƒ sallapitumarahati, á¹­hito vÄ hi, bho gotama, á¹­hitena brÄhmaá¹‡o brÄhmaá¹‡ena saddhiá¹ƒ sallapitumarahati, nisinno vÄ hi, bho gotama, nisinnena brÄhmaá¹‡o brÄhmaá¹‡ena saddhiá¹ƒ sallapitumarahati, sayÄno vÄ hi, bho gotama, sayÄnena brÄhmaá¹‡o brÄhmaá¹‡ena saddhiá¹ƒ sallapitumarahati. ye ca kho te, bho gotama, muá¹‡á¸akÄ samaá¹‡akÄ ibbhÄ kaá¹‡hÄ [kiá¹‡hÄ (ka. sÄ«. pÄ«.)] bandhupÄdÄpaccÄ, tehipi me saddhiá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ kathÄsallÄpo hoti, yathariva bhotÄ gotamenÄ"ti. "atthikavato kho pana te, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, idhÄgamanaá¹ƒ ahosi, yÄyeva kho panatthÄya ÄgaccheyyÄtha [ÄgaccheyyÄtho (sÄ«. pÄ«.)], tameva atthaá¹ƒ sÄdhukaá¹ƒ manasi kareyyÄtha [manasikareyyÄtho (sÄ«. pÄ«.)]. avusitavÄyeva kho pana bho ayaá¹ƒ ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo vusitamÄnÄ« kimaÃ±Ã±atra avusitattÄ"ti. 264. atha kho ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo bhagavatÄ avusitavÄdena vuccamÄno kupito anattamano bhagavantaá¹ƒyeva khuá¹ƒsento bhagavantaá¹ƒyeva vambhento bhagavantaá¹ƒyeva upavadamÄno â€“ "samaá¹‡o ca me, bho, gotamo pÄpito bhavissatÄ«"ti bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "caá¹‡á¸Ä, bho gotama, sakyajÄti, pharusÄ, bho gotama, sakyajÄti, lahusÄ, bho gotama, sakyajÄti, bhassÄ, bho gotama, sakyajÄti, ibbhÄ santÄ ibbhÄ samÄnÄ na brÄhmaá¹‡e sakkaronti, na brÄhmaá¹‡e garuá¹ƒ karonti [garukaronti (sÄ«. syÄ. kaá¹ƒ. pÄ«.)], na
Then the Blessed One said to Ambattha: â€˜Well now, Ambattha, would you behave like this if you were talking to venerable and learned Brahmins, teachers of teachers, as you do with me, walking and standing while I am sitting, and uttering vague words of politeness?â€ First quarrel about (low) birth.

"no hidaá¹ƒ, bho gotama. gacchanto vÄ hi, bho gotama, gacchantena brÄhmaá¹‡o brÄhmaá¹‡ena saddhiá¹ƒ sallapitumarahati, á¹­hito vÄ hi, bho gotama, á¹­hitena brÄhmaá¹‡o brÄhmaá¹‡ena saddhiá¹ƒ sallapitumarahati, nisinno vÄ hi, bho gotama, nisinnena brÄhmaá¹‡o brÄhmaá¹‡ena saddhiá¹ƒ sallapitumarahati, sayÄno vÄ hi, bho gotama, sayÄnena brÄhmaá¹‡o brÄhmaá¹‡ena saddhiá¹ƒ sallapitumarahati. ye ca kho te, bho gotama, muá¹‡á¸akÄ samaá¹‡akÄ ibbhÄ kaá¹‡hÄ [kiá¹‡hÄ (ka. sÄ«. pÄ«.)] bandhupÄdÄpaccÄ, tehipi me saddhiá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ kathÄsallÄpo hoti, yathariva bhotÄ gotamenÄ"ti. "atthikavato kho pana te, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, idhÄgamanaá¹ƒ ahosi, yÄyeva kho panatthÄya ÄgaccheyyÄtha [ÄgaccheyyÄtho (sÄ«. pÄ«.)], tameva atthaá¹ƒ sÄdhukaá¹ƒ manasi kareyyÄtha [manasikareyyÄtho (sÄ«. pÄ«.)]. avusitavÄyeva kho pana bho ayaá¹ƒ ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo vusitamÄnÄ« kimaÃ±Ã±atra avusitattÄ"ti. 264. atha kho ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo bhagavatÄ avusitavÄdena vuccamÄno kupito anattamano bhagavantaá¹ƒyeva khuá¹ƒsento bhagavantaá¹ƒyeva vambhento bhagavantaá¹ƒyeva upavadamÄno â€“ "samaá¹‡o ca me, bho, gotamo pÄpito bhavissatÄ«"ti bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "caá¹‡á¸Ä, bho gotama, sakyajÄti, pharusÄ, bho gotama, sakyajÄti, lahusÄ, bho gotama, sakyajÄti, bhassÄ, bho gotama, sakyajÄti, ibbhÄ santÄ ibbhÄ samÄnÄ na brÄhmaá¹‡e sakkaronti, na brÄhmaá¹‡e garuá¹ƒ karonti [garukaronti (sÄ«. syÄ. kaá¹ƒ. pÄ«.)], na
â€œNo indeed, Reverend Gotama! A Brahmin should walk with a walking Brahmin, stand with a standing Brahmin, sit with a sitting Brahmin, and lie down with a Brahmin who is lying down. But as for those shaven little ascetics, menials, black scourings from Brahmaâ€™s foot, with them it is fitting to speak just as I do with the Reverend Gotamaâ€. â€˜But, Ambattha, you came here seeking something. Whatever it was you came for, you should pay close attention to hear about it. Ambattha, you have not perfected your training. Your conceit of being trained is due to nothing but inexperience.â€
264. kathaá¹ƒ sÄraá¹‡Ä«yaá¹ƒ vÄ«tisÄreti, á¹­hitopi nisinnena bhagavatÄ kiÃ±ci kiÃ±ci kathaá¹ƒ sÄraá¹‡Ä«yaá¹ƒ vÄ«tisÄreti. 262. atha kho bhagavÄ ambaá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "evaá¹ƒ nu te, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, brÄhmaá¹‡ehi vuddhehi mahallakehi ÄcariyapÄcariyehi saddhiá¹ƒ kathÄsallÄpo hoti, yathayidaá¹ƒ caraá¹ƒ tiá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒ nisinnena mayÄ kiÃ±ci kiÃ±ci kathaá¹ƒ sÄraá¹‡Ä«yaá¹ƒ vÄ«tisÄretÄ«"ti? paá¹­hamaibbhavÄdo 263. "no hidaá¹ƒ, bho gotama. gacchanto vÄ hi, bho gotama, gacchantena brÄhmaá¹‡o brÄhmaá¹‡ena saddhiá¹ƒ sallapitumarahati, á¹­hito vÄ hi, bho gotama, á¹­hitena brÄhmaá¹‡o brÄhmaá¹‡ena saddhiá¹ƒ sallapitumarahati, nisinno vÄ hi, bho gotama, nisinnena brÄhmaá¹‡o brÄhmaá¹‡ena saddhiá¹ƒ sallapitumarahati, sayÄno vÄ hi, bho gotama, sayÄnena brÄhmaá¹‡o brÄhmaá¹‡ena saddhiá¹ƒ sallapitumarahati. ye ca kho te, bho gotama, muá¹‡á¸akÄ samaá¹‡akÄ ibbhÄ kaá¹‡hÄ [kiá¹‡hÄ (ka. sÄ«. pÄ«.)] bandhupÄdÄpaccÄ, tehipi me saddhiá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ kathÄsallÄpo hoti, yathariva bhotÄ gotamenÄ"ti. "atthikavato kho pana te, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, idhÄgamanaá¹ƒ ahosi, yÄyeva kho panatthÄya ÄgaccheyyÄtha [ÄgaccheyyÄtho (sÄ«. pÄ«.)], tameva atthaá¹ƒ sÄdhukaá¹ƒ manasi kareyyÄtha [manasikareyyÄtho (sÄ«. pÄ«.)]. avusitavÄyeva kho pana bho ayaá¹ƒ ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo vusitamÄnÄ« kimaÃ±Ã±atra avusitattÄ"ti. 264. atha kho ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo bhagavatÄ avusitavÄdena vuccamÄno kupito anattamano bhagavantaá¹ƒyeva khuá¹ƒsento bhagavantaá¹ƒyeva vambhento bhagavantaá¹ƒyeva upavadamÄno â€“ "samaá¹‡o ca me, bho, gotamo pÄpito bhavissatÄ«"ti bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "caá¹‡á¸Ä, bho gotama, sakyajÄti, pharusÄ, bho gotama, sakyajÄti, lahusÄ, bho gotama, sakyajÄti, bhassÄ, bho gotama, sakyajÄti, ibbhÄ santÄ ibbhÄ samÄnÄ na brÄhmaá¹‡e sakkaronti, na brÄhmaá¹‡e garuá¹ƒ karonti [garukaronti (sÄ«. syÄ. kaá¹ƒ. pÄ«.)], na
But Ambattha was angry and displeased at being called untrained, and he turned on the Lord with curses and insults. Thinking: â€˜The ascetic Gotama bears me ill-willâ€™, he said: â€˜Reverend Gotama, the Sakyans are fierce, rough-spoken, touchy and violent. Being of menial origin, being menials, they do not honour, respect, esteem, revere or pay homage to Brahmins. *kaá¹ƒ*. *pÄ«*. )], not They do not honor the Brahmins, they do not respect the Brahmins, they do not venerate the Brahmins. With regard to this, venerable Gotama, it is improper, it is unseemly that these ÅšÄkyas, being menials, considering themselves menials, do not pay homage to the Brahmins, do not respect the Brahmins, do not esteem the Brahmins, do not venerate the Brahmins, and do not defer to the Brahmins.â€™ This was the first time that Ambaá¹­á¹­ha the student accused the ÅšÄkyas of being menials. The second accusation of meniality. â€œBut what offense have these ÅšÄkyas committed against you, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha?â€ â€œOnce, venerable Gotama, I went to Kapilavatthu on some business or other for PokkharasÄti, my Brahmin teacher. I went to the ÅšÄkyasâ€™ meeting hall. And at that time, many ÅšÄkyas and ÅšÄkya youths were sitting on high seats in their assembly hall, poking each other with their fingers, laughing and playing, seemingly just mocking me; no one even invited me to a seat. With regard to this, venerable Gotama, it is improper, it is unseemly that these ÅšÄkyas, being menials, considering themselves menials, do not pay homage to the Brahmins, do not respect the Brahmins, do not esteem the Brahmins, do not venerate the Brahmins, and do not defer to the Brahmins.â€™ This was the second time that Ambaá¹­á¹­ha the student accused the ÅšÄkyas of being menials. The third accusation of meniality. â€˜But Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, even a quail, that little bird, can chirp as she likes in her own nest. Kapilavatthu is the ÅšÄkyasâ€™ own, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha; the esteemed Ambaá¹­á¹­ha does not deserve to be censured for this trifle.â€™ â€œVenerable Gotama, there are these four social classes (*vará¹‡a*): nobles (*ká¹£atriya*), Brahmins, merchants (*vaiÅ›ya*), and laborers (*Å›Å«dra*). And of these four social classes, venerable Gotama, the three social classesâ€”nobles, merchants, and laborersâ€”are, in fact, merely attendants of the Brahmins. With regard to this, venerable Gotama, it is improper, it is unseemly that these ÅšÄkyas, being menials, considering themselves menials, do not pay homage to the Brahmins, do not respect the Brahmins, do not esteem the Brahmins, do not venerate the Brahmins, and do not defer to the Brahmins.â€™ This was the third time that Ambaá¹­á¹­ha the student accused the ÅšÄkyas of being menials. Insulting with the term "born of a slave girl."
265. brÄhmaá¹‡e mÄnenti, na brÄhmaá¹‡e pÅ«jenti, na brÄhmaá¹‡e apacÄyanti. tayidaá¹ƒ, bho gotama, nacchannaá¹ƒ, tayidaá¹ƒ nappatirÅ«paá¹ƒ, yadime sakyÄ ibbhÄ santÄ ibbhÄ samÄnÄ na brÄhmaá¹‡e sakkaronti, na brÄhmaá¹‡e garuá¹ƒ karonti, na brÄhmaá¹‡e mÄnenti, na brÄhmaá¹‡e pÅ«jenti, na brÄhmaá¹‡e apacÄyantÄ«"ti. itiha ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo idaá¹ƒ paá¹­hamaá¹ƒ sakyesu ibbhavÄdaá¹ƒ nipÄtesi. dutiyaibbhavÄdo 265. "kiá¹ƒ pana te, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, sakyÄ aparaddhu"nti? "ekamidÄhaá¹ƒ, bho gotama, samayaá¹ƒ Äcariyassa brÄhmaá¹‡assa pokkharasÄtissa kenacideva karaá¹‡Ä«yena kapilavatthuá¹ƒ agamÄsiá¹ƒ. yena sakyÄnaá¹ƒ sandhÄgÄraá¹ƒ tenupasaá¹…kamiá¹ƒ. tena kho pana samayena sambahulÄ sakyÄ ceva sakyakumÄrÄ ca sandhÄgÄre [santhÄgÄre (sÄ«. pÄ«.)] uccesu Äsanesu nisinnÄ honti aÃ±Ã±amaÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ aá¹…gulipatodakehi [aá¹…gulipatodakena (pÄ«.)] saÃ±jagghantÄ saá¹ƒkÄ«á¸·antÄ, aÃ±Ã±adatthu mamaÃ±Ã±eva maÃ±Ã±e anujagghantÄ, na maá¹ƒ koci Äsanenapi nimantesi. tayidaá¹ƒ, bho gotama, nacchannaá¹ƒ, tayidaá¹ƒ nappatirÅ«paá¹ƒ, yadime sakyÄ ibbhÄ santÄ ibbhÄ samÄnÄ na brÄhmaá¹‡e sakkaronti, na brÄhmaá¹‡e garuá¹ƒ karonti, na brÄhmaá¹‡e mÄnenti, na brÄhmaá¹‡e pÅ«jenti, na brÄhmaá¹‡e apacÄyantÄ«"ti. itiha ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo idaá¹ƒ dutiyaá¹ƒ sakyesu ibbhavÄdaá¹ƒ nipÄtesi. tatiyaibbhavÄdo 266. "laá¹­ukikÄpi kho, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, sakuá¹‡ikÄ sake kulÄvake kÄmalÄpinÄ« hoti. sakaá¹ƒ kho panetaá¹ƒ, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, sakyÄnaá¹ƒ yadidaá¹ƒ kapilavatthuá¹ƒ, nÄrahatÄyasmÄ ambaá¹­á¹­ho imÄya appamattÄya abhisajjitu"nti. 267. dÄsiputtavÄdo 267. atha kho bhagavato etadahosi â€“ "atibÄá¸·haá¹ƒ kho ayaá¹ƒ ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo sakyesu ibbhavÄdena nimmÄdeti, yaá¹ƒnÅ«nÄhaá¹ƒ gottaá¹ƒ puccheyya"nti. atha kho bhagavÄ ambaá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "kathaá¹ƒ gottosi, ambaá¹­á¹­hÄ"ti? "kaá¹‡hÄyanohamasmi, bho gotamÄ"ti. porÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ kho pana te ambaá¹­á¹­ha mÄtÄpettikaá¹ƒ nÄmagottaá¹ƒ anussarato ayyaputtÄ sakyÄ bhavanti, dÄsiputto tvamasi sakyÄnaá¹ƒ. sakyÄ kho pana, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, rÄjÄnaá¹ƒ okkÄkaá¹ƒ pitÄmahaá¹ƒ dahanti. "bhÅ«tapubbaá¹ƒ, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, rÄjÄ okkÄko yÄ sÄ mahesÄ« piyÄ manÄpÄ, tassÄ puttassa rajjaá¹ƒ pariá¹‡ÄmetukÄmo jeá¹­á¹­hakumÄre raá¹­á¹­hasmÄ pabbÄjesi â€“ okkÄmukhaá¹ƒ karakaá¹‡á¸aá¹ƒ [ukkÄmukhaá¹ƒ karakaá¹‡á¸uá¹ƒ (sÄ«. syÄ.)] hatthinikaá¹ƒ sinisÅ«raá¹ƒ [sinipuraá¹ƒ (sÄ«. syÄ.)]. te raá¹­á¹­hasmÄ pabbÄjitÄ himavantapasse pokkharaá¹‡iyÄ tÄ«re mahÄsÄkasaá¹‡á¸o, tattha vÄsaá¹ƒ kappesuá¹ƒ. te jÄtisambhedabhayÄ sakÄhi bhaginÄ«hi saddhiá¹ƒ saá¹ƒvÄsaá¹ƒ kappesuá¹ƒ. "atha kho, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, rÄjÄ okkÄko amacce pÄrisajje Ämantesi â€“ â€˜kahaá¹ƒ nu kho, bho, etarahi kumÄrÄ sammantÄ«â€™ti? â€˜atthi, deva, himavantapasse pokkharaá¹‡iyÄ tÄ«re mahÄsÄkasaá¹‡á¸o, tatthetarahi kumÄrÄ sammanti. te jÄtisambhedabhayÄ sakÄhi bhaginÄ«hi saddhiá¹ƒ saá¹ƒvÄsaá¹ƒ kappentÄ«â€™ti. atha kho, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, rÄjÄ okkÄko udÄnaá¹ƒ udÄnesi â€“ â€˜sakyÄ vata, bho, kumÄrÄ, paramasakyÄ vata, bho, kumÄrÄâ€™ti. tadagge kho pana ambaá¹­á¹­ha sakyÄ paÃ±Ã±Äyanti, so ca nesaá¹ƒ pubbapuriso. "raÃ±Ã±o kho pana, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, okkÄkassa disÄ nÄma dÄsÄ« ahosi. sÄ kaá¹‡haá¹ƒ nÄma [sÄ kaá¹‡haá¹ƒ (pÄ«.)] janesi. jÄto kaá¹‡ho pabyÄhÄsi â€“ â€˜dhovatha maá¹ƒ, amma, nahÄpetha maá¹ƒ amma, imasmÄ maá¹ƒ asucismÄ parimocetha, atthÄya vo bhavissÄmÄ«â€™ti. yathÄ kho pana ambaá¹­á¹­ha etarahi manussÄ pisÄce disvÄ â€˜pisÄcÄâ€™ti saÃ±jÄnanti, evameva kho, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, tena kho pana samayena manussÄ pisÄce â€˜kaá¹‡hÄâ€™ti saÃ±jÄnanti. te evamÄhaá¹ƒsu â€“ â€˜ayaá¹ƒ jÄto pabyÄhÄsi, kaá¹‡ho jÄto, pisÄco jÄtoâ€™ti. tadagge kho pana, ambaá¹­á¹­ha kaá¹‡hÄyanÄ paÃ±Ã±Äyanti, so ca kaá¹‡hÄyanÄnaá¹ƒ pubbapuriso. iti kho
Then the Lord thought: 'This Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, young man, goes too far in abusing the Sakyans. Suppose I were to ask after his clan?" Then the Lord said to Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, the young man: "What is your clan, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha?" "I am a Kaá¹‡hÄyana, venerable Gotama." 'Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, in former days, according to those who remember the ancestral lineage, the Sakyans were the masters, and you are descended from a slave-girl (*dÄsiputto*) of the Sakyans. For the Sakyans regard King OkkÄka as their ancestor. At one time King OkkÄka, to whom his queen was dear and beloved, wishing to transfer the kingdom to her son, banished his elder brothers from the kingdom â€” OkkÄmukha, Karakaá¹‡á¸a, Hatthinika and SinisÅ«ra. And these, being banished, made their home on the flank of the Himalayas beside a lotus-pond where there was a big grove of teak-trees. And for fear of contaminating the stock they cohabited with their own sisters. "Then King OkkÄka addressed his ministers and courtiers: â€˜Where, pray, are the princes now staying?â€™ â€˜There is, O King, on the flank of the Himalayas, beside a lotus-pond, a big grove of teak-trees; that is where the princes are now staying. And for fear of contaminating the stock they cohabit with their own sisters.â€™ At this King OkkÄka exclaimed: â€œThey are strong as teak, these princes, they are real Sakyans!â€ From that time forth, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, the Sakyans have been known as such; and he was their first ancestor. "Now King OkkÄka had a slave-girl called DisÄ. She gave birth to a black child ( *kaá¹‡haá¹ƒ*). The black thing, when it was born, exclaimed: â€œWash me, mother! Bath me, mother! Deliver me from this dirt, and I will bring you profit!â€ Because, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, just as people today use the term hobgoblin as a term of abuse, so in those days they said black. And they said: â€œAs soon as he was born, he spoke. He is born a Kanha, a hobgoblin!â€ From that time forth, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, the Kaá¹‡hÄyanas have been known as such; and he was the first ancestor of the Kaá¹‡hÄyanas. "Because when you, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, recall your ancient lineage through both mother and father, the Sakyans are the masters, and you are descended from a slave-girl of the Sakyans."
268. te, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, porÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ mÄtÄpettikaá¹ƒ nÄmagottaá¹ƒ anussarato ayyaputtÄ sakyÄ bhavanti, dÄsiputto tvamasi sakyÄna"nti. 268. evaá¹ƒ vutte, te mÄá¹‡avakÄ bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavocuá¹ƒ â€“ "mÄ bhavaá¹ƒ gotamo ambaá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒ atibÄá¸·haá¹ƒ dÄsiputtavÄdena nimmÄdesi. sujÄto ca, bho gotama ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, kulaputto ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, bahussuto ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, kalyÄá¹‡avÄkkaraá¹‡o ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, paá¹‡á¸ito ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, pahoti ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo bhotÄ gotamena saddhiá¹ƒ asmiá¹ƒ vacane paá¹­imantetu"nti. 269. atha kho bhagavÄ te mÄá¹‡avake etadavoca â€“ "sace kho tumhÄkaá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avakÄnaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ hoti â€“ â€˜dujjÄto ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, akulaputto ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, appassuto ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, akalyÄá¹‡avÄkkaraá¹‡o ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, duppaÃ±Ã±o ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, na ca pahoti ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo samaá¹‡ena gotamena saddhiá¹ƒ asmiá¹ƒ vacane paá¹­imantetuâ€™nti, tiá¹­á¹­hatu ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, tumhe mayÄ saddhiá¹ƒ mantavho asmiá¹ƒ vacane. sace pana tumhÄkaá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avakÄnaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ hoti â€“ â€˜sujÄto ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, kulaputto ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, bahussuto ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, kalyÄá¹‡avÄkkaraá¹‡o ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, paá¹‡á¸ito ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, pahoti ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo samaá¹‡ena gotamena saddhiá¹ƒ asmiá¹ƒ vacane paá¹­imantetuâ€™nti, tiá¹­á¹­hatha tumhe, ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo mayÄ saddhiá¹ƒ paá¹­imantetÅ«"ti. "sujÄto ca, bho gotama, ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, kulaputto ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, bahussuto ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, kalyÄá¹‡avÄkkaraá¹‡o ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, paá¹‡á¸ito ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, pahoti ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo bhotÄ gotamena saddhiá¹ƒ asmiá¹ƒ vacane paá¹­imantetuá¹ƒ, tuá¹‡hÄ« mayaá¹ƒ bhavissÄma, ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo bhotÄ gotamena saddhiá¹ƒ asmiá¹ƒ vacane paá¹­imantetÅ«"ti. 270. atha kho bhagavÄ ambaá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "ayaá¹ƒ kho pana te, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, sahadhammiko paÃ±ho Ägacchati, akÄmÄ byÄkÄtabbo. sace tvaá¹ƒ na byÄkarissasi, aÃ±Ã±ena vÄ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ paá¹­icarissasi, tuá¹‡hÄ« vÄ bhavissasi,
When this was said, the young men said to the Blessed One: "Reverend Gotama, do not humiliate Ambaá¹­á¹­ha too much with talk of his being descended from a slave-girl. Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, Reverend Gotama, is well-born, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha is of a good family, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha is very learned, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha is well-spoken, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha is a scholar, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha is well able to hold his own in this discussion with the Reverend Gotama!"
269. te, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, porÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ mÄtÄpettikaá¹ƒ nÄmagottaá¹ƒ anussarato ayyaputtÄ sakyÄ bhavanti, dÄsiputto tvamasi sakyÄna"nti. 268. evaá¹ƒ vutte, te mÄá¹‡avakÄ bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavocuá¹ƒ â€“ "mÄ bhavaá¹ƒ gotamo ambaá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒ atibÄá¸·haá¹ƒ dÄsiputtavÄdena nimmÄdesi. sujÄto ca, bho gotama ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, kulaputto ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, bahussuto ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, kalyÄá¹‡avÄkkaraá¹‡o ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, paá¹‡á¸ito ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, pahoti ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo bhotÄ gotamena saddhiá¹ƒ asmiá¹ƒ vacane paá¹­imantetu"nti. 269. atha kho bhagavÄ te mÄá¹‡avake etadavoca â€“ "sace kho tumhÄkaá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avakÄnaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ hoti â€“ â€˜dujjÄto ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, akulaputto ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, appassuto ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, akalyÄá¹‡avÄkkaraá¹‡o ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, duppaÃ±Ã±o ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, na ca pahoti ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo samaá¹‡ena gotamena saddhiá¹ƒ asmiá¹ƒ vacane paá¹­imantetuâ€™nti, tiá¹­á¹­hatu ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, tumhe mayÄ saddhiá¹ƒ mantavho asmiá¹ƒ vacane. sace pana tumhÄkaá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avakÄnaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ hoti â€“ â€˜sujÄto ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, kulaputto ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, bahussuto ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, kalyÄá¹‡avÄkkaraá¹‡o ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, paá¹‡á¸ito ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, pahoti ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo samaá¹‡ena gotamena saddhiá¹ƒ asmiá¹ƒ vacane paá¹­imantetuâ€™nti, tiá¹­á¹­hatha tumhe, ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo mayÄ saddhiá¹ƒ paá¹­imantetÅ«"ti. "sujÄto ca, bho gotama, ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, kulaputto ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, bahussuto ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, kalyÄá¹‡avÄkkaraá¹‡o ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, paá¹‡á¸ito ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, pahoti ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo bhotÄ gotamena saddhiá¹ƒ asmiá¹ƒ vacane paá¹­imantetuá¹ƒ, tuá¹‡hÄ« mayaá¹ƒ bhavissÄma, ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo bhotÄ gotamena saddhiá¹ƒ asmiá¹ƒ vacane paá¹­imantetÅ«"ti. 270. atha kho bhagavÄ ambaá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "ayaá¹ƒ kho pana te, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, sahadhammiko paÃ±ho Ägacchati, akÄmÄ byÄkÄtabbo. sace tvaá¹ƒ na byÄkarissasi, aÃ±Ã±ena vÄ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ paá¹­icarissasi, tuá¹‡hÄ« vÄ bhavissasi,
Then the Lord said to the young men: "If you consider that Ambaá¹­á¹­ha is ill-born, not of a good family, unlearned, ill-spoken, no scholar, unable to hold his own in this discussion with the ascetic Gotama, then let Ambaá¹­á¹­ha be silent, and you conduct this discussion with me. But if you think he is well-born, of a good family, very learned, well-spoken, a scholar, able to hold his own in this discussion with the ascetic Gotama, then you be quiet, and let Ambaá¹­á¹­ha discuss with me." "Ambaá¹­á¹­ha is well-born, Reverend Gotama, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha is of a good family, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha is very learned, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha is well-spoken, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha is a scholar, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha is well able to hold his own in this discussion with the Reverend Gotama. We will be silent, let Ambaá¹­á¹­ha continue this discussion with the Reverend Gotama."
270. te, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, porÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ mÄtÄpettikaá¹ƒ nÄmagottaá¹ƒ anussarato ayyaputtÄ sakyÄ bhavanti, dÄsiputto tvamasi sakyÄna"nti. 268. evaá¹ƒ vutte, te mÄá¹‡avakÄ bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavocuá¹ƒ â€“ "mÄ bhavaá¹ƒ gotamo ambaá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒ atibÄá¸·haá¹ƒ dÄsiputtavÄdena nimmÄdesi. sujÄto ca, bho gotama ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, kulaputto ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, bahussuto ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, kalyÄá¹‡avÄkkaraá¹‡o ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, paá¹‡á¸ito ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, pahoti ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo bhotÄ gotamena saddhiá¹ƒ asmiá¹ƒ vacane paá¹­imantetu"nti. 269. atha kho bhagavÄ te mÄá¹‡avake etadavoca â€“ "sace kho tumhÄkaá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avakÄnaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ hoti â€“ â€˜dujjÄto ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, akulaputto ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, appassuto ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, akalyÄá¹‡avÄkkaraá¹‡o ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, duppaÃ±Ã±o ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, na ca pahoti ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo samaá¹‡ena gotamena saddhiá¹ƒ asmiá¹ƒ vacane paá¹­imantetuâ€™nti, tiá¹­á¹­hatu ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, tumhe mayÄ saddhiá¹ƒ mantavho asmiá¹ƒ vacane. sace pana tumhÄkaá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avakÄnaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ hoti â€“ â€˜sujÄto ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, kulaputto ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, bahussuto ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, kalyÄá¹‡avÄkkaraá¹‡o ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, paá¹‡á¸ito ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, pahoti ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo samaá¹‡ena gotamena saddhiá¹ƒ asmiá¹ƒ vacane paá¹­imantetuâ€™nti, tiá¹­á¹­hatha tumhe, ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo mayÄ saddhiá¹ƒ paá¹­imantetÅ«"ti. "sujÄto ca, bho gotama, ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, kulaputto ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, bahussuto ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, kalyÄá¹‡avÄkkaraá¹‡o ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, paá¹‡á¸ito ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, pahoti ca ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo bhotÄ gotamena saddhiá¹ƒ asmiá¹ƒ vacane paá¹­imantetuá¹ƒ, tuá¹‡hÄ« mayaá¹ƒ bhavissÄma, ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo bhotÄ gotamena saddhiá¹ƒ asmiá¹ƒ vacane paá¹­imantetÅ«"ti. 270. atha kho bhagavÄ ambaá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "ayaá¹ƒ kho pana te, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, sahadhammiko paÃ±ho Ägacchati, akÄmÄ byÄkÄtabbo. sace tvaá¹ƒ na byÄkarissasi, aÃ±Ã±ena vÄ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ paá¹­icarissasi, tuá¹‡hÄ« vÄ bhavissasi,
Then the Lord said to Ambaá¹­á¹­ha: "Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, I have a fundamental question for you, which you will not like to answer. If you donâ€™t answer, or evade the issue, if you keep silent, or go away, your head will split into seven pieces. What do you think, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha? Have you heard from old and venerable Brahmins, teachers of teachers, where the Kaá¹‡hÄyanas came from, or who was their ancestor?" At this, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha remained silent. The Lord asked him a second time: "What do you think, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha? Have you heard from old and venerable Brahmins, teachers of teachers, where the Kaá¹‡hÄyanas came from, or who was their ancestor?" Again Ambaá¹­á¹­ha remained silent. Then the Lord said to Ambaá¹­á¹­ha: "Answer me now, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, this is not a time for silence. Whoever, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, does not answer a fundamental question put to him by a *TathÄgata* by the third asking has his head split into seven pieces."
271. pakkamissasi vÄ ettheva te sattadhÄ muddhÄ phalissati. taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, kinti te sutaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ vuddhÄnaá¹ƒ mahallakÄnaá¹ƒ ÄcariyapÄcariyÄnaá¹ƒ bhÄsamÄnÄnaá¹ƒ kutopabhutikÄ kaá¹‡hÄyanÄ, ko ca kaá¹‡hÄyanÄnaá¹ƒ pubbapuriso"ti? evaá¹ƒ vutte, ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo tuá¹‡hÄ« ahosi. dutiyampi kho bhagavÄ ambaá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, kinti te sutaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ vuddhÄnaá¹ƒ mahallakÄnaá¹ƒ ÄcariyapÄcariyÄnaá¹ƒ bhÄsamÄnÄnaá¹ƒ kutopabhutikÄ kaá¹‡hÄyanÄ, ko ca kaá¹‡hÄyanÄnaá¹ƒ pubbapuriso"ti? dutiyampi kho ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo tuá¹‡hÄ« ahosi. atha kho bhagavÄ ambaá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "byÄkarohi dÄni ambaá¹­á¹­ha, na dÄni, te tuá¹‡hÄ«bhÄvassa kÄlo. yo kho, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, tathÄgatena yÄvatatiyakaá¹ƒ sahadhammikaá¹ƒ paÃ±haá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­ho na byÄkaroti, etthevassa sattadhÄ muddhÄ phalissatÄ«"ti. 271. tena kho pana samayena vajirapÄá¹‡Ä« yakkho mahantaá¹ƒ ayokÅ«á¹­aá¹ƒ ÄdÄya Ädittaá¹ƒ sampajjalitaá¹ƒ sajotibhÅ«taá¹ƒ [saÃ±jotibhÅ«taá¹ƒ (syÄ.)] ambaá¹­á¹­hassa mÄá¹‡avassa upari vehÄsaá¹ƒ á¹­hito hoti â€“ "sacÄyaá¹ƒ ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo bhagavatÄ yÄvatatiyakaá¹ƒ sahadhammikaá¹ƒ paÃ±haá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­ho na byÄkarissati, etthevassa sattadhÄ muddhaá¹ƒ phÄlessÄmÄ«"ti. taá¹ƒ kho pana vajirapÄá¹‡iá¹ƒ yakkhaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ ceva passati ambaá¹­á¹­ho ca mÄá¹‡avo. 272. atha kho ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo bhÄ«to saá¹ƒviggo lomahaá¹­á¹­hajÄto bhagavantaá¹ƒyeva tÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ gavesÄ« bhagavantaá¹ƒyeva leá¹‡aá¹ƒ gavesÄ« bhagavantaá¹ƒyeva saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ gavesÄ« â€“ upanisÄ«ditvÄ bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "kimetaá¹ƒ [kiá¹ƒ me taá¹ƒ (ka.)] bhavaá¹ƒ gotamo Äha? punabhavaá¹ƒ gotamo bravitÅ«"ti [brÅ«tu (syÄ.)]. "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, kinti te sutaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ vuddhÄnaá¹ƒ mahallakÄnaá¹ƒ ÄcariyapÄcariyÄnaá¹ƒ bhÄsamÄnÄnaá¹ƒ kutopabhutikÄ kaá¹‡hÄyanÄ, ko ca kaá¹‡hÄyanÄnaá¹ƒ pubbapuriso"ti? "evameva me, bho gotama, sutaá¹ƒ yatheva bhavaá¹ƒ gotamo Äha. tatopabhutikÄ kaá¹‡hÄyanÄ, so ca kaá¹‡hÄyanÄnaá¹ƒ pubbapuriso"ti.
And at that moment VajirapÄá¹‡i the *yaká¹£a*, holding a huge iron club, flaming, ablaze and glowing, up in the sky just above Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, was thinking: "If this young man Ambaá¹­á¹­ha does not answer a proper question put to him by the Blessed Lord by the third time of asking, Iâ€™ll split his head into seven pieces!" The Lord saw VajirapÄá¹‡i the *yaká¹£a*, and so did Ambaá¹­á¹­ha.
272. pakkamissasi vÄ ettheva te sattadhÄ muddhÄ phalissati. taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, kinti te sutaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ vuddhÄnaá¹ƒ mahallakÄnaá¹ƒ ÄcariyapÄcariyÄnaá¹ƒ bhÄsamÄnÄnaá¹ƒ kutopabhutikÄ kaá¹‡hÄyanÄ, ko ca kaá¹‡hÄyanÄnaá¹ƒ pubbapuriso"ti? evaá¹ƒ vutte, ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo tuá¹‡hÄ« ahosi. dutiyampi kho bhagavÄ ambaá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, kinti te sutaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ vuddhÄnaá¹ƒ mahallakÄnaá¹ƒ ÄcariyapÄcariyÄnaá¹ƒ bhÄsamÄnÄnaá¹ƒ kutopabhutikÄ kaá¹‡hÄyanÄ, ko ca kaá¹‡hÄyanÄnaá¹ƒ pubbapuriso"ti? dutiyampi kho ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo tuá¹‡hÄ« ahosi. atha kho bhagavÄ ambaá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "byÄkarohi dÄni ambaá¹­á¹­ha, na dÄni, te tuá¹‡hÄ«bhÄvassa kÄlo. yo kho, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, tathÄgatena yÄvatatiyakaá¹ƒ sahadhammikaá¹ƒ paÃ±haá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­ho na byÄkaroti, etthevassa sattadhÄ muddhÄ phalissatÄ«"ti. 271. tena kho pana samayena vajirapÄá¹‡Ä« yakkho mahantaá¹ƒ ayokÅ«á¹­aá¹ƒ ÄdÄya Ädittaá¹ƒ sampajjalitaá¹ƒ sajotibhÅ«taá¹ƒ [saÃ±jotibhÅ«taá¹ƒ (syÄ.)] ambaá¹­á¹­hassa mÄá¹‡avassa upari vehÄsaá¹ƒ á¹­hito hoti â€“ "sacÄyaá¹ƒ ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo bhagavatÄ yÄvatatiyakaá¹ƒ sahadhammikaá¹ƒ paÃ±haá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­ho na byÄkarissati, etthevassa sattadhÄ muddhaá¹ƒ phÄlessÄmÄ«"ti. taá¹ƒ kho pana vajirapÄá¹‡iá¹ƒ yakkhaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ ceva passati ambaá¹­á¹­ho ca mÄá¹‡avo. 272. atha kho ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo bhÄ«to saá¹ƒviggo lomahaá¹­á¹­hajÄto bhagavantaá¹ƒyeva tÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ gavesÄ« bhagavantaá¹ƒyeva leá¹‡aá¹ƒ gavesÄ« bhagavantaá¹ƒyeva saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ gavesÄ« â€“ upanisÄ«ditvÄ bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "kimetaá¹ƒ [kiá¹ƒ me taá¹ƒ (ka.)] bhavaá¹ƒ gotamo Äha? punabhavaá¹ƒ gotamo bravitÅ«"ti [brÅ«tu (syÄ.)]. "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, kinti te sutaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ vuddhÄnaá¹ƒ mahallakÄnaá¹ƒ ÄcariyapÄcariyÄnaá¹ƒ bhÄsamÄnÄnaá¹ƒ kutopabhutikÄ kaá¹‡hÄyanÄ, ko ca kaá¹‡hÄyanÄnaá¹ƒ pubbapuriso"ti? And at the sight, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha was terrified and unnerved, his hairs stood on end, and he sought protection, shelter and safety from the Lord. Crouching down close to the Lord, he said: "What did the Reverend Gotama say? Let the Reverend Gotama repeat it!" "What do you think, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha? Have you heard from old and venerable Brahmins, teachers of teachers, who was the ancestor of the Kaá¹‡hÄyanas?" "Yes, Reverend Gotama, I have heard it just as the Reverend Gotama said. That is where the Kaá¹‡hÄyanas came from, he was their ancestor." The Story of the Lineage of Ambaá¹­á¹­ha.
273. ambaá¹­á¹­havaá¹ƒsakathÄ 273. evaá¹ƒ vutte, te mÄá¹‡avakÄ unnÄdino uccÄsaddamahÄsaddÄ ahesuá¹ƒ â€“ "dujjÄto kira, bho, ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, akulaputto kira, bho, ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, dÄsiputto kira, bho, ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo sakyÄnaá¹ƒ. ayyaputtÄ kira, bho, ambaá¹­á¹­hassa mÄá¹‡avassa sakyÄ bhavanti. dhammavÄdiá¹ƒyeva kira mayaá¹ƒ samaá¹‡aá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ apasÄdetabbaá¹ƒ amaÃ±Ã±imhÄ"ti. 274. atha kho bhagavato etadahosi â€“ "atibÄá¸·haá¹ƒ kho ime mÄá¹‡avakÄ ambaá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avaá¹ƒ dÄsiputtavÄdena nimmÄdenti, yaá¹ƒnÅ«nÄhaá¹ƒ parimoceyya"nti. atha kho bhagavÄ te mÄá¹‡avake etadavoca â€“ "mÄ kho tumhe, mÄá¹‡avakÄ, ambaá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avaá¹ƒ atibÄá¸·haá¹ƒ dÄsiputtavÄdena nimmÄdetha. uá¸·Äro so kaá¹‡ho isi ahosi. so dakkhiá¹‡ajanapadaá¹ƒ gantvÄ brahmamante adhÄ«yitvÄ rÄjÄnaá¹ƒ okkÄkaá¹ƒ upasaá¹…kamitvÄ maddarÅ«piá¹ƒ dhÄ«taraá¹ƒ yÄci. tassa rÄjÄ okkÄko â€“ â€˜ko nevaá¹ƒ re ayaá¹ƒ mayhaá¹ƒ dÄsiputto samÄno maddarÅ«piá¹ƒ dhÄ«taraá¹ƒ yÄcatÄ«"â€™ ti, kupito anattamano khurappaá¹ƒ sannayhi [sannahi (ka.)]. so taá¹ƒ khurappaá¹ƒ neva asakkhi muÃ±cituá¹ƒ, no paá¹­isaá¹ƒharituá¹ƒ. "atha kho, mÄá¹‡avakÄ, amaccÄ pÄrisajjÄ kaá¹‡haá¹ƒ isiá¹ƒ upasaá¹…kamitvÄ etadavocuá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜sotthi, bhaddante [bhadante (sÄ«. syÄ.)], hotu raÃ±Ã±o, sotthi, bhaddante, hotu raÃ±Ã±oâ€™ti. â€˜sotthi bhavissati raÃ±Ã±o, api ca rÄjÄ yadi adho khurappaá¹ƒ muÃ±cissati, yÄvatÄ raÃ±Ã±o vijitaá¹ƒ, ettÄvatÄ pathavÄ« undriyissatÄ«â€™ti. â€˜sotthi, bhaddante, hotu raÃ±Ã±o, sotthi janapadassÄâ€™ti. â€˜sotthi bhavissati raÃ±Ã±o, sotthi janapadassa, api ca rÄjÄ yadi uddhaá¹ƒ khurappaá¹ƒ muÃ±cissati, yÄvatÄ raÃ±Ã±o vijitaá¹ƒ, ettÄvatÄ satta vassÄni devo na vassissatÄ«â€™ti. â€˜sotthi, bhaddante, hotu raÃ±Ã±o sotthi janapadassa devo ca vassatÅ«â€™ti. â€˜sotthi bhavissati raÃ±Ã±o sotthi janapadassa devo ca vassissati, api ca rÄjÄ jeá¹­á¹­hakumÄre khurappaá¹ƒ patiá¹­á¹­hÄpetu, sotthi kumÄro pallomo bhavissatÄ«â€™ti. atha kho, mÄá¹‡avakÄ, amaccÄ okkÄkassa Ärocesuá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜okkÄko jeá¹­á¹­hakumÄre khurappaá¹ƒ patiá¹­á¹­hÄpetu. sotthi kumÄro pallomo bhavissatÄ«â€™ti. atha kho rÄjÄ okkÄko jeá¹­á¹­hakumÄre khurappaá¹ƒ patiá¹­á¹­hapesi, sotthi kumÄro
When this was said, those youths, being noisy, made a loud and great noise, saying: "Ambaá¹­á¹­ha the youth is indeed ill-born, sir! Ambaá¹­á¹­ha the youth is indeed not of good family, sir! Ambaá¹­á¹­ha the youth is indeed the son of a slave girl of the ÅšÄkyas, sir! The ÅšÄkyas, sir, are indeed the masters of Ambaá¹­á¹­ha the youth. Indeed, we thought that the ascetic Gotama should only be disparaged as a speaker of truth!"
274. ambaá¹­á¹­havaá¹ƒsakathÄ 273. evaá¹ƒ vutte, te mÄá¹‡avakÄ unnÄdino uccÄsaddamahÄsaddÄ ahesuá¹ƒ â€“ "dujjÄto kira, bho, ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, akulaputto kira, bho, ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo, dÄsiputto kira, bho, ambaá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo sakyÄnaá¹ƒ. ayyaputtÄ kira, bho, ambaá¹­á¹­hassa mÄá¹‡avassa sakyÄ bhavanti. dhammavÄdiá¹ƒyeva kira mayaá¹ƒ samaá¹‡aá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ apasÄdetabbaá¹ƒ amaÃ±Ã±imhÄ"ti. 274. atha kho bhagavato etadahosi â€“ "atibÄá¸·haá¹ƒ kho ime mÄá¹‡avakÄ ambaá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avaá¹ƒ dÄsiputtavÄdena nimmÄdenti, yaá¹ƒnÅ«nÄhaá¹ƒ parimoceyya"nti. atha kho bhagavÄ te mÄá¹‡avake etadavoca â€“ "mÄ kho tumhe, mÄá¹‡avakÄ, ambaá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avaá¹ƒ atibÄá¸·haá¹ƒ dÄsiputtavÄdena nimmÄdetha. uá¸·Äro so kaá¹‡ho isi ahosi. so dakkhiá¹‡ajanapadaá¹ƒ gantvÄ brahmamante adhÄ«yitvÄ rÄjÄnaá¹ƒ okkÄkaá¹ƒ upasaá¹…kamitvÄ maddarÅ«piá¹ƒ dhÄ«taraá¹ƒ yÄci. tassa rÄjÄ okkÄko â€“ â€˜ko nevaá¹ƒ re ayaá¹ƒ mayhaá¹ƒ dÄsiputto samÄno maddarÅ«piá¹ƒ dhÄ«taraá¹ƒ yÄcatÄ«"â€™ ti, kupito anattamano khurappaá¹ƒ sannayhi [sannahi (ka.)]. so taá¹ƒ khurappaá¹ƒ neva asakkhi muÃ±cituá¹ƒ, no paá¹­isaá¹ƒharituá¹ƒ. "atha kho, mÄá¹‡avakÄ, amaccÄ pÄrisajjÄ kaá¹‡haá¹ƒ isiá¹ƒ upasaá¹…kamitvÄ etadavocuá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜sotthi, bhaddante [bhadante (sÄ«. syÄ.)], hotu raÃ±Ã±o, sotthi, bhaddante, hotu raÃ±Ã±oâ€™ti. â€˜sotthi bhavissati raÃ±Ã±o, api ca rÄjÄ yadi adho khurappaá¹ƒ muÃ±cissati, yÄvatÄ raÃ±Ã±o vijitaá¹ƒ, ettÄvatÄ pathavÄ« undriyissatÄ«â€™ti. â€˜sotthi, bhaddante, hotu raÃ±Ã±o, sotthi janapadassÄâ€™ti. â€˜sotthi bhavissati raÃ±Ã±o, sotthi janapadassa, api ca rÄjÄ yadi uddhaá¹ƒ khurappaá¹ƒ muÃ±cissati, yÄvatÄ raÃ±Ã±o vijitaá¹ƒ, ettÄvatÄ satta vassÄni devo na vassissatÄ«â€™ti. â€˜sotthi, bhaddante, hotu raÃ±Ã±o sotthi janapadassa devo ca vassatÅ«â€™ti. â€˜sotthi bhavissati raÃ±Ã±o sotthi janapadassa devo ca vassissati, api ca rÄjÄ jeá¹­á¹­hakumÄre khurappaá¹ƒ patiá¹­á¹­hÄpetu, sotthi kumÄro pallomo bhavissatÄ«â€™ti. atha kho, mÄá¹‡avakÄ, amaccÄ okkÄkassa Ärocesuá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜okkÄko jeá¹­á¹­hakumÄre khurappaá¹ƒ patiá¹­á¹­hÄpetu. sotthi kumÄro pallomo bhavissatÄ«â€™ti. atha kho rÄjÄ okkÄko jeá¹­á¹­hakumÄre khurappaá¹ƒ patiá¹­á¹­hapesi, sotthi kumÄro
Then the Blessed One thought: "These youths excessively humiliate Ambaá¹­á¹­ha the youth with the accusation of being the son of a slave girl. What if I were to liberate him from that?" Then, the Blessed One said this to those youths: "Do not, youths, excessively humiliate Ambaá¹­á¹­ha the youth with the accusation of being the son of a slave girl. That Kanhha (Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a) was a mighty sage (á¹›á¹£i). Having gone to the Southern country and learned the *brahma*-mantras, he approached King OkkÄka and asked for his daughter MaddarÅ«pÄ«. To him, King OkkÄka said: â€˜Who is this fellow who, being the son of a slave-girl, dares to ask for MaddarÅ«pÄ«, my daughter?â€™ Angered and displeased, he fitted an arrow (khurappaá¹ƒ). He was unable either to release that arrow or to withdraw it. Then, youths, the ministers and courtiers approached the sage Kanhha (Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a) and said: 'May there be well-being (svasti), reverend sir (bhadante), to the king; may there be well-being (svasti), reverend sir (bhadante), to the king!' â€˜There will be well-being to the king, and if the king releases the arrow downwards, to the extent of the king's realm, the earth will quake.â€™ â€˜May there be well-being (svasti), reverend sir (bhadante), to the king; may there be well-being (svasti) to the land!â€™ â€˜There will be well-being to the king; there will be well-being to the land, and if the king releases the arrow upwards, for seven years, to the extent of the king's realm, the god (deva) will not send rain.â€™ â€˜May there be well-being (svasti), reverend sir (bhadante), to the king; may there be well-being (svasti) to the land, and may the god (deva) send rain!â€™ â€˜There will be well-being to the king; there will be well-being to the land, and the god (deva) will send rain, and if the king aims the arrow at the eldest prince (jeá¹­á¹­hakumÄre), the prince will be perfectly safe (pallomo).â€™ Then, youths, the ministers announced to OkkÄka: 'Let OkkÄka aim the arrow at the eldest prince (jeá¹­á¹­hakumÄre). The prince will be perfectly safe (pallomo).' Then King OkkÄka aimed the arrow at the eldest prince (jeá¹­á¹­hakumÄre), and the prince was safe (sotthi). He became perfectly safe. Then King Okkaka, terrified and fearful, with his hair standing on end, punished by the divine punishment, gave his daughter Maddarupi. So, young men, do not disparage Ambattha too much for being the son of a slave-girl. That Kaá¹‡ha was a mighty sage.â€™ The superiority of the warrior (Ká¹£atriya) class. Then the Lord addressed the youth Ambattha: â€˜What do you think, Ambattha? Suppose a Khattiya youth were to cohabit with a Brahmin maiden, and a son were to be born from their cohabitation? Would that son born of a Khattiya youth and a Brahmin maiden be likely to receive a seat or water from the Brahmins?â€™ â€˜He would receive it, Reverend Gotama.â€™ â€˜Would the Brahmins allow him to eat at funeral rites, at ceremonial milk-rice offerings, at sacrifices, or as a guest?â€™ â€˜They would allow him, Reverend Gotama.â€™ â€˜Would the Brahmins teach him *mantras*, or not?â€™ â€˜They would teach him, Reverend Gotama.â€™ â€˜Would their women be kept covered or uncovered in his presence?â€™ â€˜Uncovered indeed, Reverend Gotama.â€™ â€˜Would Khattiyas consecrate him with the Khattiya consecration?â€™ â€˜No, Reverend Gotama.â€™ â€˜What is the reason for that?â€™ â€˜Because he is not well-born on his motherâ€™s side, Reverend Gotama.â€™ â€˜What do you think, Ambattha? Suppose a Brahmin youth were to cohabit with a Khattiya maiden, and a son were to be born from their cohabitation? Would that son born of a Brahmin youth and a Khattiya maiden be likely to receive a seat or water from the Brahmins?â€™ â€˜He would receive it, Reverend Gotama.â€™ â€˜Would the Brahmins allow him to eat at funeral rites, at ceremonial milk-rice offerings, at sacrifices, or as a guest?â€™ â€˜They would allow him, Reverend Gotama.â€™ â€˜Would the Brahmins teach him *mantras*, or not?â€™ â€˜They would teach him, Reverend Gotama.â€™ â€˜Would their women be kept covered or uncovered in his presence?â€™ â€˜Uncovered indeed, Reverend Gotama.â€™ â€˜Would Khattiyas consecrate him with the Khattiya consecration?â€™ â€˜No, Reverend Gotama.â€™ â€˜What is the reason for that?â€™ â€˜Because he is not well-born on his fatherâ€™s side, Reverend Gotama.â€™ â€˜So, Ambattha, whether a woman takes a man or a man takes a woman, the Khattiyas are superior, and the Brahmins are inferior. What do you think, Ambattha? Suppose the Brahmins shaved the head of a Brahmin for some reason, and after smearing him with ashes, banished him from the country or the city. Would he be likely to receive a seat or water from the Brahmins?â€™ â€˜No, Reverend Gotama.â€™ â€˜Would the Brahmins allow him to eat at funeral rites, at ceremonial milk-rice offerings, at sacrifices, or as a guest?â€™ â€˜No, Reverend Gotama.â€™ â€˜Would the Brahmins teach him *mantras*, or not?â€™ â€˜No, Reverend Gotama.â€™ â€˜Would their women be kept covered or uncovered in his presence?â€™ â€˜Covered indeed, Reverend Gotama.â€™ â€˜What do you think, Ambattha? Suppose the Khattiyas shaved the head of a Khattiya for some reason, and after smearing him with ashes, banished him from the country or the city. Would he be likely to receive a seat or water from the Brahmins?â€™ â€˜He would receive it, Reverend Gotama.â€™ â€˜Would the Brahmins allow him to eat at funeral rites, at ceremonial milk-rice offerings, at sacrifices, or as a guest?â€™ â€˜They would allow him, Reverend Gotama.â€™ â€˜Would the Brahmins teach him *mantras*, or not?â€™ â€˜They would teach him, Reverend Gotama.â€™ â€˜Would their women be kept covered or uncovered in his presence?â€™ â€˜Uncovered indeed, Reverend Gotama.â€™ â€˜But that Khattiya has reached the extreme of humiliation when the Khattiyas shave his head, and after smearing him with ashes, banish him from the country or the city. So, Ambattha, even when a Khattiya has reached the extreme of humiliation, the Khattiyas are still superior, and the Brahmins are inferior. This verse was uttered by BrahmÄ SanankumÄra: â€˜The Khattiya is the best among people, who value lineage.â€™ He is endowed with knowledge and conduct, he is the best of gods and humans.â€ â€œThat verse, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, was well sung, not ill-sung, well spoken, not ill-spoken, connected with meaning, not unconnected with meaning, approved by me, by BrahmÄ SanankumÄra. And I too, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, say this: The Khattiya is the best among those who value clan; He with knowledge and conduct, is best of gods and men.â€ End of the first recitation-section. The discourse on knowledge and conduct.
275. pallomo samabhavi. atha kho tassa rÄjÄ okkÄko bhÄ«to saá¹ƒviggo lomahaá¹­á¹­hajÄto brahmadaá¹‡á¸ena tajjito maddarÅ«piá¹ƒ dhÄ«taraá¹ƒ adÄsi. mÄ kho tumhe, mÄá¹‡avakÄ, ambaá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avaá¹ƒ atibÄá¸·haá¹ƒ dÄsiputtavÄdena nimmÄdetha, uá¸·Äro so kaá¹‡ho isi ahosÄ«"ti. khattiyaseá¹­á¹­habhÄvo 275. atha kho bhagavÄ ambaá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avaá¹ƒ Ämantesi â€“ "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, idha khattiyakumÄro brÄhmaá¹‡akaÃ±Ã±Äya saddhiá¹ƒ saá¹ƒvÄsaá¹ƒ kappeyya, tesaá¹ƒ saá¹ƒvÄsamanvÄya putto jÄyetha. yo so khattiyakumÄrena brÄhmaá¹‡akaÃ±Ã±Äya putto uppanno, api nu so labhetha brÄhmaá¹‡esu Äsanaá¹ƒ vÄ udakaá¹ƒ vÄ"ti? Then the Blessed One addressed the youth Ambaá¹­á¹­ha: "What do you think, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha? If a noble youth were to cohabit with a *brÄhmaá¹‡a* maiden, and a son were born to them, would that son of a noble youth and a *brÄhmaá¹‡a* maiden receive a seat or water among the *brÄhmaá¹‡as*?" "He would receive it, venerable Gotama." "Would the *brÄhmaá¹‡as* allow him to eat at a funeral feast (*Å›raddha*), a ceremonial milk-rice offering (*thÄlipÄka*), a sacrifice (*yajÃ±a*), or as a guest (*pÄhuna*)?" "They would allow him, venerable Gotama." "Would the *brÄhmaá¹‡as* teach him *mantras* or not?" "They would teach him, venerable Gotama." "Would their women be kept covered or uncovered in his presence?" "Uncovered, venerable Gotama." "Would nobles consecrate him with the consecration of a noble?" "No, venerable Gotama." "What is the reason for that?" "Because he is not well-born on his motherâ€™s side, venerable Gotama." "What do you think, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha? If a *brÄhmaá¹‡a* youth were to cohabit with a noble maiden, and a son were born to them, would that son of a *brÄhmaá¹‡a* youth and a noble maiden receive a seat or water among the *brÄhmaá¹‡as*?" "He would receive it, venerable Gotama." "Would the *brÄhmaá¹‡as* allow him to eat at a funeral feast (*Å›raddha*), a ceremonial milk-rice offering (*thÄlipÄka*), a sacrifice (*yajÃ±a*), or as a guest (*pÄhuna*)?" "They would allow him, venerable Gotama." "Would the *brÄhmaá¹‡as* teach him *mantras* or not?" "They would teach him, venerable Gotama." "Would their women be kept covered or uncovered in his presence?" "Uncovered, venerable Gotama." "Would nobles consecrate him with the consecration of a noble?" "No, venerable Gotama." "What is the reason for that?" "Because he is not well-born on his fatherâ€™s side, venerable Gotama."

"Thus, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, whether it is a woman taking a woman or a man taking a man, the nobles (*ká¹£atriyas*) are superior, and the *brÄhmaá¹‡as* are inferior. What do you think, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha? If *brÄhmaá¹‡as* were to shave the head of a *brÄhmaá¹‡a* for some reason, sprinkle him with ashes, and banish him from the country or the city, would he receive a seat or water among the *brÄhmaá¹‡as*?" "No, venerable Gotama." "Would the *brÄhmaá¹‡as* allow him to eat at a funeral feast (*Å›raddha*), a ceremonial milk-rice offering (*thÄlipÄka*), a sacrifice (*yajÃ±a*), or as a guest (*pÄhuna*)?" "What do you think, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha? If nobles (*ká¹£atriyas*) were to shave the head of a noble (*ká¹£atriya*) for some reason, sprinkle him with ashes, and banish him from the country or the city, would he receive a seat or water among the *brÄhmaá¹‡as*?" "He would receive it, venerable Gotama." "Would the *brÄhmaá¹‡as* allow him to eat at a funeral feast (*Å›raddha*), a ceremonial milk-rice offering (*thÄlipÄka*), a sacrifice (*yajÃ±a*), or as a guest (*pÄhuna*)?" "They would allow him, venerable Gotama." "Would the *brÄhmaá¹‡as* teach him *mantras* or not?" "They would teach him, venerable Gotama." "ettÄvatÄ kho, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, khattiyo paramanihÄ«nataá¹ƒ patto hoti, yadeva naá¹ƒ khattiyÄ khuramuá¹‡á¸aá¹ƒ karitvÄ bhassapuá¹­ena vadhitvÄ raá¹­á¹­hÄ vÄ nagarÄ vÄ pabbÄjenti. iti kho, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, yadÄ khattiyo paramanihÄ«nataá¹ƒ patto hoti, tadÄpi khattiyÄva seá¹­á¹­hÄ, hÄ«nÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä. brahmunÄ pesÄ, ambaá¹­á¹­ha [brahmunÄpi ambaá¹­á¹­ha (ka.), brahmunÄpi eso ambaá¹­á¹­ha (pÄ«.)], sanaá¹…kumÄrena gÄthÄ bhÄsitÄ â€“ â€˜khattiyo seá¹­á¹­ho janetasmiá¹ƒ, ye gottapaá¹­isÄrino, vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampanno, so seá¹­á¹­ho devamÄnuseâ€™ti. "sÄ kho panesÄ, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, brahmunÄ sanaá¹…kumÄrena gÄthÄ sugÄ«tÄ no duggÄ«tÄ, subhÄsitÄ no dubbhÄsitÄ, atthasaá¹ƒhitÄ no anatthasaá¹ƒhitÄ, anumatÄ mayÄ. ahampi hi, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, evaá¹ƒ vadÄmi â€“
"To this extent, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, a noble (*ká¹£atriya*) can reach the lowest degradation: when nobles shave his head, sprinkle him with ashes, and banish him from the country or the city. Thus, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, even when a noble (*ká¹£atriya*) has reached the lowest degradation, the nobles (*ká¹£atriyas*) are still superior, and the *brÄhmaá¹‡as* are inferior. This verse was spoken by BrahmÄ SanankumÄra, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha [or, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, this was sent by BrahmÄ, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha]: â€˜The *ká¹£atriya* is best among those who value lineage; He is endowed with knowledge and conduct, He is the best of gods and humans." "That verse, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, was well sung, not ill-sung, by BrahmÄ SanankumÄra; well spoken, not ill-spoken; connected with meaning, not without meaning; and approved by me. And I too, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, say this: The Khattiya is the best among those who value clan. He with knowledge and conduct, is best of gods and men." The first section for recitation is finished. The Discourse on Knowledge and Conduct.
278. â€˜khattiyo seá¹­á¹­ho janetasmiá¹ƒ, ye gottapaá¹­isÄrino, vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampanno, so seá¹­á¹­ho devamÄnuseâ€™ti. bhÄá¹‡avÄro paá¹­hamo. vijjÄcaraá¹‡akathÄ 278. "katamaá¹ƒ pana taá¹ƒ, bho gotama, caraá¹‡aá¹ƒ, katamÄ ca pana sÄ vijjÄ"ti? "na kho, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, anuttarÄya vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampadÄya jÄtivÄdo vÄ vuccati, gottavÄdo vÄ vuccati, mÄnavÄdo vÄ vuccati â€“ â€˜arahasi vÄ maá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ, na vÄ maá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ arahasÄ«â€™ti. yattha kho, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, ÄvÄho vÄ hoti, vivÄho vÄ hoti, ÄvÄhavivÄho vÄ hoti, etthetaá¹ƒ vuccati jÄtivÄdo vÄ itipi gottavÄdo vÄ itipi mÄnavÄdo vÄ itipi â€“ â€˜arahasi vÄ maá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ, na vÄ maá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ arahasÄ«â€™ti. ye hi keci ambaá¹­á¹­ha jÄtivÄdavinibaddhÄ vÄ gottavÄdavinibaddhÄ vÄ mÄnavÄdavinibaddhÄ vÄ ÄvÄhavivÄhavinibaddhÄ vÄ, ÄrakÄ te anuttarÄya vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampadÄya. pahÄya kho, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, jÄtivÄdavinibaddhaÃ±ca gottavÄdavinibaddhaÃ±ca mÄnavÄdavinibaddhaÃ±ca ÄvÄhavivÄhavinibaddhaÃ±ca anuttarÄya vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampadÄya sacchikiriyÄ hotÄ«"ti. 279. "katamaá¹ƒ pana taá¹ƒ, bho gotama, caraá¹‡aá¹ƒ, katamÄ ca sÄ vijjÄ"ti? "idha, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, tathÄgato loke uppajjati arahaá¹ƒ sammÄsambuddho vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampanno sugato lokavidÅ« anuttaro purisadammasÄrathi satthÄ devamanussÄnaá¹ƒ buddho bhagavÄ. so imaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ sadevakaá¹ƒ samÄrakaá¹ƒ sabrahmakaá¹ƒ sassamaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡iá¹ƒ pajaá¹ƒ sadevamanussaá¹ƒ sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ pavedeti. so dhammaá¹ƒ deseti ÄdikalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ majjhekalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ pariyosÄnakalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ sÄtthaá¹ƒ sabyaÃ±janaá¹ƒ kevalaparipuá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ parisuddhaá¹ƒ brahmacariyaá¹ƒ pakÄseti. taá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ suá¹‡Äti gahapati vÄ gahapatiputto vÄ aÃ±Ã±atarasmiá¹ƒ vÄ kule paccÄjÄto. so taá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ sutvÄ
"But what, Venerable Gotama, is conduct, and what is knowledge?" "It is not, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, in the pursuit of the unexcelled attainment of knowledge and conduct that talk of birth, clan, or conceit arisesâ€”â€˜You are worthy of me, or you are not worthy of me.â€™ For wherever, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, there is a giving, a taking in marriage, there is always this talk and this conceintâ€”â€˜You are worthy of me, or you are not worthy of me.â€™ But those who are enslaved by such things are far from the attainment of the unexcelled knowledge-and-conduct. Only by abandoning talk of birth, clan, and conceit and the giving and taking in marriage, can the unexcelled attainment of knowledge and conduct be realized."
279. â€˜khattiyo seá¹­á¹­ho janetasmiá¹ƒ, ye gottapaá¹­isÄrino, vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampanno, so seá¹­á¹­ho devamÄnuseâ€™ti. bhÄá¹‡avÄro paá¹­hamo. vijjÄcaraá¹‡akathÄ 278. "katamaá¹ƒ pana taá¹ƒ, bho gotama, caraá¹‡aá¹ƒ, katamÄ ca pana sÄ vijjÄ"ti? "na kho, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, anuttarÄya vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampadÄya jÄtivÄdo vÄ vuccati, gottavÄdo vÄ vuccati, mÄnavÄdo vÄ vuccati â€“ â€˜arahasi vÄ maá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ, na vÄ maá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ arahasÄ«â€™ti. yattha kho, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, ÄvÄho vÄ hoti, vivÄho vÄ hoti, ÄvÄhavivÄho vÄ hoti, etthetaá¹ƒ vuccati jÄtivÄdo vÄ itipi gottavÄdo vÄ itipi mÄnavÄdo vÄ itipi â€“ â€˜arahasi vÄ maá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ, na vÄ maá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ arahasÄ«â€™ti. ye hi keci ambaá¹­á¹­ha jÄtivÄdavinibaddhÄ vÄ gottavÄdavinibaddhÄ vÄ mÄnavÄdavinibaddhÄ vÄ ÄvÄhavivÄhavinibaddhÄ vÄ, ÄrakÄ te anuttarÄya vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampadÄya. pahÄya kho, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, jÄtivÄdavinibaddhaÃ±ca gottavÄdavinibaddhaÃ±ca mÄnavÄdavinibaddhaÃ±ca ÄvÄhavivÄhavinibaddhaÃ±ca anuttarÄya vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampadÄya sacchikiriyÄ hotÄ«"ti. 279. "katamaá¹ƒ pana taá¹ƒ, bho gotama, caraá¹‡aá¹ƒ, katamÄ ca sÄ vijjÄ"ti? "idha, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, tathÄgato loke uppajjati arahaá¹ƒ sammÄsambuddho vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampanno sugato lokavidÅ« anuttaro purisadammasÄrathi satthÄ devamanussÄnaá¹ƒ buddho bhagavÄ. so imaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ sadevakaá¹ƒ samÄrakaá¹ƒ sabrahmakaá¹ƒ sassamaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡iá¹ƒ pajaá¹ƒ sadevamanussaá¹ƒ sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ pavedeti. so dhammaá¹ƒ deseti ÄdikalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ majjhekalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ pariyosÄnakalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ sÄtthaá¹ƒ sabyaÃ±janaá¹ƒ kevalaparipuá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ parisuddhaá¹ƒ brahmacariyaá¹ƒ pakÄseti. taá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ suá¹‡Äti gahapati vÄ gahapatiputto vÄ aÃ±Ã±atarasmiá¹ƒ vÄ kule paccÄjÄto. so taá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ sutvÄ
"But what, Venerable Gotama, is conduct, and what is knowledge?" "Here, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, a TathÄgata arises in the world, a worthy one, a rightly self-awakened one, impeccable in conduct and understanding, fortunate, knower of the worlds, unsurpassed, trainer of beings, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed one. He, having realised it by his own super-knowledge, proclaims this world with its devas, maras and Brahmas, its princes and people. He teaches the Dhamma, which is lovely in its beginning, lovely in its middle, lovely in its ending, in the spirit and in the letter, and displays the fully-perfected and purified holy life. A householder or householderâ€™s son or one born in some other clan hears that Dhamma. Having heard this Dhamma, he gains faith in the Tathagata. He, being endowed with that acquisition of faith, reflects thus... (as in 191, these passages should be expanded in the same way). â€¦ â€œQuite secluded from sensuality, secluded from unskillful qualities, the monk enters & remains in the first *jhÄna*: rapture & pleasure born of seclusion, accompanied by directed thought & evaluationâ€¦ this is part of his conduct. â€œAgain, with the stilling of directed thoughts & evaluations, the monk enters & remains in the second *jhÄna*: rapture & pleasure born of concentration, unification of awareness free from directed thought & evaluationâ€”internal assuranceâ€¦ this is part of his conduct. â€œAnd further, with the fading of rapture, the monk remains equanimous, mindful, & alert, and senses pleasure with the body. He enters & remains in the third *jhÄna*, of which the noble ones declare, â€˜Equanimous & mindful, he has a pleasant abiding.â€™â€¦ this is part of his conduct. â€œAnd further, with the abandoning of pleasure & painâ€”as with the earlier disappearance of elation & distressâ€”the monk enters & remains in the fourth *jhÄna*: purity of equanimity & mindfulness, neither pleasure nor painâ€¦ this is part of his conduct. This, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, is conduct. â€œWith his mind thus serene, purified, cleansed, without blemish, rid of defilement, supple, malleable, firm, & attained to imperturbability, he directs and inclines it to knowledge and visionâ€¦ this is part of his knowledgeâ€¦ he understands, â€˜There is nothing further for this state of beingâ€™â€¦ this is part of his knowledge. This, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, is knowledge. â€œThis, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, is what is called a monk who is â€˜accomplished in knowledge,â€™ â€˜accomplished in conduct,â€™ and â€˜accomplished in knowledge & conduct.â€™ And beyond this there is no further development of knowledge and conduct that is higher or more perfect. Four paths of failure.
280. tathÄgate saddhaá¹ƒ paá¹­ilabhati. so tena saddhÄpaá¹­ilÄbhena samannÄgato iti paá¹­isaÃ±cikkhatiâ€¦peâ€¦ (yathÄ 191 Ädayo anucchedÄ, evaá¹ƒ vitthÄretabbaá¹ƒ).â€¦ "so vivicceva kÄmehi, vivicca akusalehi dhammehi, savitakkaá¹ƒ savicÄraá¹ƒ vivekajaá¹ƒ pÄ«tisukhaá¹ƒ paá¹­hamaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒ upasampajja viharatiâ€¦peâ€¦ idampissa hoti caraá¹‡asmiá¹ƒ. "puna caparaá¹ƒ, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, bhikkhu vitakkavicÄrÄnaá¹ƒ vÅ«pasamÄ ajjhattaá¹ƒ sampasÄdanaá¹ƒ cetaso ekodibhÄvaá¹ƒ avitakkaá¹ƒ avicÄraá¹ƒ samÄdhijaá¹ƒ pÄ«tisukhaá¹ƒ dutiyaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒ upasampajja viharatiâ€¦peâ€¦ idampissa hoti caraá¹‡asmiá¹ƒ. "puna caparaá¹ƒ, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, bhikkhu pÄ«tiyÄ ca virÄgÄ upekkhako ca viharati sato ca sampajÄno, sukhaÃ±ca kÄyena paá¹­isaá¹ƒvedeti, yaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ ariyÄ Äcikkhanti â€“ "upekkhako satimÄ sukhavihÄrÄ«â€™ti, tatiyaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒ upasampajja viharatiâ€¦peâ€¦ idampissa hoti caraá¹‡asmiá¹ƒ. "puna caparaá¹ƒ, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahÄnÄ dukkhassa ca pahÄnÄ, pubbeva somanassadomanassÄnaá¹ƒ atthaá¹…gamÄ adukkhamasukhaá¹ƒ upekkhÄsatipÄrisuddhiá¹ƒ catutthaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒ upasampajja viharatiâ€¦peâ€¦ idampissa hoti caraá¹‡asmiá¹ƒ. idaá¹ƒ kho taá¹ƒ, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, caraá¹‡aá¹ƒ. "so evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte Ã±Äá¹‡adassanÄya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmetiâ€¦peâ€¦ idampissa hoti vijjÄyaâ€¦peâ€¦ nÄparaá¹ƒ itthattÄyÄti pajÄnÄti, idampissa hoti vijjÄya. ayaá¹ƒ kho sÄ, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, vijjÄ. "ayaá¹ƒ vuccati, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, bhikkhu â€˜vijjÄsampannoâ€™ itipi, â€˜caraá¹‡asampannoâ€™ itipi, â€˜vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampannoâ€™ itipi. imÄya ca ambaá¹­á¹­ha vijjÄsampadÄya caraá¹‡asampadÄya ca aÃ±Ã±Ä vijjÄsampadÄ ca caraá¹‡asampadÄ ca uttaritarÄ vÄ paá¹‡Ä«tatarÄ vÄ natthi. catuapÄyamukhaá¹ƒ 280. "imÄya kho, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, anuttarÄya vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampadÄya cattÄri apÄyamukhÄni bhavanti. katamÄni cattÄri? idha, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, ekacco samaá¹‡o vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡o vÄ imaÃ±Ã±eva anuttaraá¹ƒ vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampadaá¹ƒ anabhisambhuá¹‡amÄno
"But, Ambattha, in the pursuit of this unexcelled attainment of knowledge and condact there are four paths of failure. What are the four? Here, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, some recluse or Brahmin, without attaining this unexcelled perfection of knowledge and conduct, Taking various sorts of *khÄri* vessels, he enters a forest dwelling, thinking, "I will live on windfalls." But in this way, he only becomes an attendant on one who has attained to unexcelled knowledge and conduct (*vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampadÄ*). This, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, is the first path of failure in the pursuit of this unexcelled attainment of knowledge and conduct. "Again, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, some ascetic or Brahmin, being unable to fully realize this unexcelled knowledge and conduct (*anuttaraá¹ƒ vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampadaá¹ƒ*), and being unable to live on windfalls, takes a spade and basket and enters a forest grove, thinking, 'I will live on tubers, roots, and fruits.'" But in this way, he only becomes an attendant on one who has attained to unexcelled knowledge and conduct (*vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampadÄ*). This, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, is the second path of failure in the pursuit of this unexcelled attainment of knowledge and conduct. "Again, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, some ascetic or Brahmin, being unable to fully realize this unexcelled knowledge and conduct (*anuttaraá¹ƒ vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampadaá¹ƒ*), being unable to live on windfalls, and being unable to live on tubers, roots, and fruits, makes a fire-hearth at the edge of a village or small town and sits tending the flame. But in this way, he only becomes an attendant on one who has attained to unexcelled knowledge and conduct (*vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampadÄ*). This, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, is the third path of failure in the pursuit of this unexcelled attainment of knowledge and conduct. "Again, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, some ascetic or Brahmin, being unable to fully realize this unexcelled knowledge and conduct (*anuttaraá¹ƒ vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampadaá¹ƒ*), being unable to live on windfalls, being unable to live on tubers, roots, and fruits, and being unable to tend the flame, erects a house with four doors at the crossroads thinking: 'Whatever ascetic or Brahmin arrives from these four quarters, I will honour to the best of my strength and ability.'" But in this way, he only becomes an attendant on one who has attained to unexcelled knowledge and conduct (*vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampadÄ*). This, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, is the fourth path of failure in the pursuit of this unexcelled attainment of knowledge and conduct. These, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, are the four paths of failure in the pursuit of this unexcelled attainment of knowledge and conduct (*anuttarÄya vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampadÄya*). "What do you think, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha? Do you and your teacher live in accordance with this unexcelled knowledge and conduct (*anuttarÄya vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampadÄya*)?" "No, Master Gotama." â€˜What am I, They make their living by such base arts, such as: palmistry (*aá¹…ga*), divining by signs (*nimitta*), portents (*uppÄta*), dreams (*supinaá¹ƒ*), body-marks (*lakkhaá¹‡aá¹ƒ*), mouse-gnawings (*mÅ«sikacchinnaá¹ƒ*), fire-oblations (*aggihomaá¹ƒ*), oblations from a ladle (*dabbihomaá¹ƒ*), oblations of husks (*thusahomaá¹ƒ*), oblations of rice powder (*kaá¹‡ahomaá¹ƒ*), oblations of rice grains (*taá¹‡á¸ulahomaá¹ƒ*), oblations of ghee (*sappihomaá¹ƒ*), oblations of oil (*telahomaá¹ƒ*), oblations from the mouth (*mukhahomaá¹ƒ*), oblations of blood (*lohitahomaá¹ƒ*), reading the finger-tips (*aá¹…gavijjÄ*), house- and garden-lore (*vatthuvijjÄ*), skill in charms (*khattavijjÄ*), ghost-lore (*sivavijjÄ*), earth-house lore (*bhÅ«tavijjÄ*), snake-lore (*bhÅ«rivijjÄ*), poison-lore (*ahivijjÄ*), rat-lore (*visavijjÄ*), bird-lore (*vicchikavijjÄ*), crow-lore (*mÅ«sikavijjÄ*), foretelling a personâ€™s life-span (*sakuá¹‡avijjÄ*), charms against arrows (*vÄyasavijjÄ*), knowledge of animalsâ€™ cries (*pakkajjhÄnaá¹ƒ*), the ascetic Gotama refrains from such base arts. Thus, indeed, mendicants, a worldling, when speaking in praise of the *tathÄgata*, might speak.
281. khÄrividhamÄdÄya [khÄrivividhamÄdÄya (sÄ«. syÄ. pÄ«.)] araÃ±Ã±Äyatanaá¹ƒ ajjhogÄhati â€“ â€˜pavattaphalabhojano bhavissÄmÄ«â€™ti. so aÃ±Ã±adatthu vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampannasseva paricÄrako sampajjati. imÄya kho, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, anuttarÄya vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampadÄya idaá¹ƒ paá¹­hamaá¹ƒ apÄyamukhaá¹ƒ bhavati. "evameva kho tvaá¹ƒ, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, ye te ahesuá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ pubbakÄ isayo mantÄnaá¹ƒ kattÄro mantÄnaá¹ƒ pavattÄro, yesamidaá¹ƒ etarahi brÄhmaá¹‡Ä porÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ mantapadaá¹ƒ gÄ«taá¹ƒ pavuttaá¹ƒ samihitaá¹ƒ, tadanugÄyanti tadanubhÄsanti bhÄsitamanubhÄsanti vÄcitamanuvÄcenti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ aá¹­á¹­hako vÄmako vÄmadevo vessÄmitto yamataggi [yamadaggi (ka.)] aá¹…gÄ«raso bhÄradvÄjo vÄseá¹­á¹­ho kassapo bhagu â€“ â€˜tyÄhaá¹ƒ mante adhiyÄmi sÄcariyakoâ€™ti, tÄvatÄ tvaá¹ƒ bhavissasi isi vÄ isitthÄya vÄ paá¹­ipannoti netaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ vijjati. 286. â€œAmbaá¹­á¹­ha, the Brahmin PokkharasÄti lives by the grace and favour of King Pasenadi of Kosala. And yet the King does not allow him to have audience face to face. When he confers with the King it is through a curtain. Why should the King not grant audience face to face to one on whom he has besÂ­towed a proper and blameless source of revenue? See how your teacher has let you down!
284. pubbakaisibhÄvÄnuyogo 283. "brÄhmaá¹‡o kho pana, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, pokkharasÄti raÃ±Ã±o pasenadissa kosalassa dattikaá¹ƒ bhuÃ±jati. tassa rÄjÄ pasenadi kosalo sammukhÄ«bhÄvampi na dadÄti. yadÄpi tena manteti, tirodussantena manteti. yassa kho pana, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, dhammikaá¹ƒ payÄtaá¹ƒ bhikkhaá¹ƒ paá¹­iggaá¹‡heyya, kathaá¹ƒ tassa rÄjÄ pasenadi kosalo sammukhÄ«bhÄvampi na dadeyya. passa, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, yÄva aparaddhaÃ±ca te idaá¹ƒ Äcariyassa brÄhmaá¹‡assa pokkharasÄtissa. 284. "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, idha rÄjÄ pasenadi kosalo hatthigÄ«vÄya vÄ nisinno assapiá¹­á¹­he vÄ nisinno rathÅ«patthare vÄ á¹­hito uggehi vÄ rÄjaÃ±Ã±ehi vÄ kiÃ±cideva mantanaá¹ƒ manteyya. so tamhÄ padesÄ apakkamma ekamantaá¹ƒ tiá¹­á¹­heyya. atha Ägaccheyya suddo vÄ suddadÄso vÄ, tasmiá¹ƒ padese á¹­hito tadeva mantanaá¹ƒ manteyya â€“ â€˜evampi rÄjÄ pasenadi kosalo Äha, evampi rÄjÄ pasenadi kosalo ÄhÄâ€™ti. apinu so rÄjabhaá¹‡itaá¹ƒ vÄ bhaá¹‡ati rÄjamantanaá¹ƒ vÄ manteti? ettÄvatÄ so assa rÄjÄ vÄ rÄjamatto vÄ"ti? "no hidaá¹ƒ, bho gotama". 285. "evameva kho tvaá¹ƒ, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, ye te ahesuá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ pubbakÄ isayo mantÄnaá¹ƒ kattÄro mantÄnaá¹ƒ pavattÄro, yesamidaá¹ƒ etarahi brÄhmaá¹‡Ä porÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ mantapadaá¹ƒ gÄ«taá¹ƒ pavuttaá¹ƒ samihitaá¹ƒ, tadanugÄyanti tadanubhÄsanti bhÄsitamanubhÄsanti vÄcitamanuvÄcenti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ aá¹­á¹­hako vÄmako vÄmadevo vessÄmitto yamataggi [yamadaggi (ka.)] aá¹…gÄ«raso bhÄradvÄjo vÄseá¹­á¹­ho kassapo bhagu â€“ â€˜tyÄhaá¹ƒ mante adhiyÄmi sÄcariyakoâ€™ti, tÄvatÄ tvaá¹ƒ bhavissasi isi vÄ isitthÄya vÄ paá¹­ipannoti netaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ vijjati. 286. "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, ambaá¹­á¹­ha, kinti te sutaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ vuddhÄnaá¹ƒ mahallakÄnaá¹ƒ ÄcariyapÄcariyÄnaá¹ƒ bhÄsamÄnÄnaá¹ƒ â€“ ye te ahesuá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ pubbakÄ isayo mantÄnaá¹ƒ kattÄro mantÄnaá¹ƒ pavattÄro,
â€œWhat do you think, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha? Suppose King Pasenadi was sitting on the neck of an elephant or on horseback, or was standing on the chariot-mat, conferring with his ministers and princes about something. And suppose he were to step aside and some workman or workmanâ€™s servant were to come along and stand in his place. And standing there he might say: â€œThis is what King Passenadi of Kosala says!â€ Would he be speaking the Kingâ€™s words, or speaking the Kingâ€™s counsel? Would he thereby be a king or a minister?â€ â€œNo, Gotama.â€
