â€œBut, Reverend Gotama, is there any sacrifice (yajÃ±a) that is more distinguished, less arduous, more fruitful, and more beneficial than this threefold accomplishment of sacrifice (yajÃ±asampadÄ) with its sixteen accessories (soá¸·asaparikkhÄra), than this regular giving (niccadÄna), this continuous sacrifice (anukulayaÃ±Ã±a), than this giving of monasteries (vihÄradÄna), than these going for refuge (saraá¹‡agamana), and than these precepts (sikkhÄpadehi)?â€ â€œThere is, Brahmin.â€ â€œWhat is it, Reverend Gotama, that is a sacrifice (yajÃ±a) more distinguished, less arduous, more fruitful, and more beneficial than this threefold accomplishment of sacrifice (yajÃ±asampadÄ) with its sixteen accessories (soá¸·asaparikkhÄra), than this regular giving (niccadÄna), this continuous sacrifice (anukulayaÃ±Ã±a), than this giving of monasteries (vihÄradÄna), than these going for refuge (saraá¹‡agamana), and than these precepts (sikkhÄpadehi)?â€ â€œHere, Brahmin, a *TathÄgata* arises in the world, an *Arhat*, a perfectly awakened Buddha (sammÄsambuddho)â€¦peâ€¦ (as in sections 190-212, so it should be expanded). Thus, Brahmin, a monk is accomplished in virtue (sÄ«lasampanno hoti)â€¦peâ€¦he attains and abides in the first *jhÄna* (paá¹­hamaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒ upasampajja viharati). This, Brahmin, is a sacrifice (yajÃ±a) more distinguished, less arduous, more fruitful, and more beneficial than the previous sacrifices (purimehi yaÃ±Ã±ehi)â€¦peâ€¦the second *jhÄna* (dutiyaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒ)â€¦peâ€¦the third *jhÄna* (tatiyaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒ)â€¦peâ€¦he attains and abides in the fourth *jhÄna* (catutthaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒ upasampajja viharati). This, Brahmin, is a sacrifice (yajÃ±a) more distinguished, less arduous, more fruitful, and more beneficial than the previous sacrifices (purimehi yaÃ±Ã±ehi). He directs and inclines his mind to the knowledge and vision (Ã±Äá¹‡adassanÄya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti)â€¦peâ€¦This, Brahmin, is a sacrifice (yajÃ±a) more distinguished, less arduous, more fruitful, and more beneficial than the previous sacrifices (purimehi yaÃ±Ã±ehi)â€¦peâ€¦he understands, â€˜There is nothing further hereâ€™ (nÄparaá¹ƒ itthattÄyÄti pajÄnÄti). This, Brahmin, is a sacrifice (yajÃ±a) more distinguished, less arduous, more fruitful, and more beneficial than the previous sacrifices (purimehi yaÃ±Ã±ehi). And, Brahmin, there is no other accomplishment of sacrifice (yaÃ±Ã±asampadÄ) that is higher or more excellent than this accomplishment of sacrifice (yaÃ±Ã±asampadÄ)." The report of KÅ«á¹­adanta's adopting the lay life (kÅ«á¹­adantaupÄsakattapaá¹­ivedanÄ)
354. appaá¹­á¹­hataro ca appasamÄrambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahÄnisaá¹ƒsataro cÄ"ti. "katamo pana so, bho gotama, yaÃ±Ã±o imÄya ca tividhÄya yaÃ±Ã±asampadÄya soá¸·asaparikkhÄrÄya iminÄ ca niccadÄnena anukulayaÃ±Ã±ena iminÄ ca vihÄradÄnena imehi ca saraá¹‡agamanehi imehi ca sikkhÄpadehi appaá¹­á¹­hataro ca appasamÄrambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahÄnisaá¹ƒsataro cÄ"ti? "idha, brÄhmaá¹‡a, tathÄgato loke uppajjati arahaá¹ƒ sammÄsambuddhoâ€¦peâ€¦ (yathÄ 190-212 anucchedesu, evaá¹ƒ vitthÄretabbaá¹ƒ). evaá¹ƒ kho, brÄhmaá¹‡a, bhikkhu sÄ«lasampanno hotiâ€¦peâ€¦ paá¹­hamaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒ upasampajja viharati. ayaá¹ƒ kho, brÄhmaá¹‡a, yaÃ±Ã±o purimehi yaÃ±Ã±ehi appaá¹­á¹­hataro ca appasamÄrambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahÄnisaá¹ƒsataro caâ€¦peâ€¦ dutiyaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒâ€¦peâ€¦ tatiyaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒâ€¦peâ€¦ catutthaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒ upasampajja viharati. ayampi kho, brÄhmaá¹‡a, yaÃ±Ã±o purimehi yaÃ±Ã±ehi appaá¹­á¹­hataro ca appasamÄrambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahÄnisaá¹ƒsataro cÄti. Ã±Äá¹‡adassanÄya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmetiâ€¦peâ€¦ ayampi kho, brÄhmaá¹‡a, yaÃ±Ã±o purimehi yaÃ±Ã±ehi appaá¹­á¹­hataro ca appasamÄrambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahÄnisaá¹ƒsataro caâ€¦peâ€¦ nÄparaá¹ƒ itthattÄyÄti pajÄnÄti. ayampi kho, brÄhmaá¹‡a, yaÃ±Ã±o purimehi yaÃ±Ã±ehi appaá¹­á¹­hataro ca appasamÄrambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahÄnisaá¹ƒsataro ca. imÄya ca, brÄhmaá¹‡a, yaÃ±Ã±asampadÄya aÃ±Ã±Ä yaÃ±Ã±asampadÄ uttaritarÄ vÄ paá¹‡Ä«tatarÄ vÄ natthÄ«"ti. kÅ«á¹­adantaupÄsakattapaá¹­ivedanÄ 354. evaá¹ƒ vutte, kÅ«á¹­adanto brÄhmaá¹‡o bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "abhikkantaá¹ƒ, bho gotama, abhikkantaá¹ƒ, bho gotama! seyyathÄpi bho gotama, nikkujjitaá¹ƒ vÄ ukkujjeyya, paá¹­icchannaá¹ƒ vÄ vivareyya, mÅ«á¸·hassa vÄ maggaá¹ƒ Äcikkheyya, andhakÄre vÄ telapajjotaá¹ƒ dhÄreyya â€˜cakkhumanto rÅ«pÄni dakkhantÄ«â€™ti, evamevaá¹ƒ bhotÄ gotamena anekapariyÄyena
When this was said, KÅ«á¹­adanta the Brahmin said this to the Blessed One (bhagavantaá¹ƒ): â€œExcellent, Reverend Gotama, excellent, Reverend Gotama! Reverend Gotama, it is as if one were to set upright what had been overthrown, or to reveal what was hidden, or to show the way to one who was lost, or to hold up a lamp in the dark, so that those with eyes might see forms. In the same way, the Dhamma has been made clear by Reverend Gotama in many ways. The Dhamma is proclaimed. I go to the esteemed Gotama for refuge, and to the Dhamma, and to the monastic community (bhikkhusaá¹…gha). May the esteemed Gotama remember me as a lay follower (upÄsaka) who has gone to him for refuge, from this day forward, as long as life shall last. "And, Reverend Gotama, I release seven hundred bulls (usabha), seven hundred bullocks (vacchatarasatÄni), seven hundred heifers (vacchatarÄ«satÄni), seven hundred he-goats (ajasatÄni) and seven hundred rams (urabbhasatÄni). I grant them life, let them eat green grass and drink cool water, and let a cool breeze blow upon them." Realization of the fruit of stream-entry (sotÄpattiphalasacchikiriyÄ). Then the Blessed One gave KÅ«á¹­adanta the Brahmin a progressive talk, that is to say, a talk on giving (dÄnakathaá¹ƒ), a talk on moral conduct (sÄ«lakathaá¹ƒ), a talk on heaven (saggakathaá¹ƒ), he revealed the drawbacks (ÄdÄ«nava), degradation (okÄraá¹ƒ), and corruption (saá¹ƒkilesaá¹ƒ) of sensual pleasures, and the benefits of renunciation (nekkhamme Änisaá¹ƒsaá¹ƒ). When the Blessed One knew that KÅ«á¹­adanta the Brahmin had a pliable mind (kallacittaá¹ƒ), a gentle mind (muducittaá¹ƒ), a mind free from hindrances (vinÄ«varaá¹‡acittaá¹ƒ), an elated mind (udaggacittaá¹ƒ), and a serene mind (pasannacittaá¹ƒ), then he revealed the teaching that is unique to the Buddhas, that is: suffering (dukkhaá¹ƒ), its origin (samudayaá¹ƒ), its cessation (nirodhaá¹ƒ), and the path (maggaá¹ƒ). Just as a clean cloth, free from stains, would perfectly absorb dye, even so, as KÅ«á¹­adanta the Brahmin sat there, there arose in him the pure and spotless eye of the Dhamma (dhammacakkhuá¹ƒ): "Whatever is subject to arising, all of that is subject to cessation." Then KÅ«á¹­adanta the Brahmin, having seen the Dhamma, attained the Dhamma, known the Dhamma, fathomed the Dhamma, having transcended doubt, having overcome uncertainty, having attained confidence, independent of others in the Teacher's Dispensation, said this to the Blessed One: "May the esteemed Gotama accept a meal from me tomorrow, together with the monastic community (bhikkhusaá¹…ghena)." The Blessed One consented by remaining silent (tuá¹‡hÄ«bhÄvena). Then KÅ«á¹­adanta the Brahmin, knowing the Blessed One's acceptance, rose from his seat, paid homage to the Blessed One, circumambulated him to the right, and departed. Then KÅ«á¹­adanta the Brahmin, as the night was ending, had exquisite staple and non-staple food prepared at his sacrificial ground (yaÃ±Ã±avÄá¹­e), and had the time announced to the Blessed One: "It is time, esteemed Gotama, the meal is ready." Then, in the morning, the Blessed One, having dressed, taking his bowl and robe, together with the monastic community (bhikkhusaá¹…ghena), went to KÅ«á¹­adanta the Brahmin's sacrificial ground (yaÃ±Ã±avÄá¹­e), and having arrived, sat down on the prepared seat (Äsane). Then KÅ«á¹­adanta the Brahmin, with his own hands (sahatthÄ), served and satisfied the monastic community (bhikkhusaá¹…ghaá¹ƒ), with the Buddha at its head (buddhappamukhaá¹ƒ), with exquisite staple and non-staple food (khÄdanÄ«yena bhojanÄ«yena). Then KÅ«á¹­adanta the Brahmin, when the Blessed One had finished eating and had removed his hand from the bowl (onÄ«tapattapÄá¹‡iá¹ƒ), took a low seat (Äsanaá¹ƒ), sat down to one side (ekamantaá¹ƒ nisÄ«di). Then the Blessed One, having instructed, inspired, roused, and gladdened KÅ«á¹­adanta the Brahmin, who was sitting to one side (ekamantaá¹ƒ nisinnaá¹ƒ), with a talk on the Dhamma (dhammiyÄ kathÄya), rose from his seat and departed. The KÅ«á¹­adanta Sutta, the fifth, is concluded.
355. dhammo pakÄsito. esÄhaá¹ƒ bhavantaá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ gacchÄmi dhammaÃ±ca bhikkhusaá¹…ghaÃ±ca. upÄsakaá¹ƒ maá¹ƒ bhavaá¹ƒ gotamo dhÄretu ajjatagge pÄá¹‡upetaá¹ƒ saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ gataá¹ƒ. esÄhaá¹ƒ bho gotama satta ca usabhasatÄni satta ca vacchatarasatÄni satta ca vacchatarÄ«satÄni satta ca ajasatÄni satta ca urabbhasatÄni muÃ±cÄmi, jÄ«vitaá¹ƒ demi, haritÄni ceva tiá¹‡Äni khÄdantu, sÄ«tÄni ca pÄnÄ«yÄni pivantu, sÄ«to ca nesaá¹ƒ vÄto upavÄyatÅ«"ti. sotÄpattiphalasacchikiriyÄ 355. atha kho bhagavÄ kÅ«á¹­adantassa brÄhmaá¹‡assa anupubbiá¹ƒ kathaá¹ƒ kathesi, seyyathidaá¹ƒ, dÄnakathaá¹ƒ sÄ«lakathaá¹ƒ saggakathaá¹ƒ, kÄmÄnaá¹ƒ ÄdÄ«navaá¹ƒ okÄraá¹ƒ saá¹ƒkilesaá¹ƒ nekkhamme Änisaá¹ƒsaá¹ƒ pakÄsesi. yadÄ bhagavÄ aÃ±Ã±Äsi kÅ«á¹­adantaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡aá¹ƒ kallacittaá¹ƒ muducittaá¹ƒ vinÄ«varaá¹‡acittaá¹ƒ udaggacittaá¹ƒ pasannacittaá¹ƒ, atha yÄ buddhÄnaá¹ƒ sÄmukkaá¹ƒsikÄ dhammadesanÄ, taá¹ƒ pakÄsesi â€“ dukkhaá¹ƒ samudayaá¹ƒ nirodhaá¹ƒ maggaá¹ƒ. seyyathÄpi nÄma suddhaá¹ƒ vatthaá¹ƒ apagatakÄá¸·akaá¹ƒ sammadeva rajanaá¹ƒ paá¹­iggaá¹‡heyya, evameva kÅ«á¹­adantassa brÄhmaá¹‡assa tasmiÃ±Ã±eva Äsane virajaá¹ƒ vÄ«tamalaá¹ƒ dhammacakkhuá¹ƒ udapÄdi â€“ "yaá¹ƒ kiÃ±ci samudayadhammaá¹ƒ, sabbaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ nirodhadhamma"nti. 356. atha kho kÅ«á¹­adanto brÄhmaá¹‡o diá¹­á¹­hadhammo pattadhammo viditadhammo pariyogÄá¸·hadhammo tiá¹‡á¹‡avicikiccho vigatakathaá¹ƒkatho vesÄrajjappatto aparappaccayo satthusÄsane bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "adhivÄsetu me bhavaá¹ƒ gotamo svÄtanÄya bhattaá¹ƒ saddhiá¹ƒ bhikkhusaá¹…ghenÄ"ti. adhivÄsesi bhagavÄ tuá¹‡hÄ«bhÄvena. 357. atha kho kÅ«á¹­adanto brÄhmaá¹‡o bhagavato adhivÄsanaá¹ƒ viditvÄ uá¹­á¹­hÄyÄsanÄ bhagavantaá¹ƒ abhivÄdetvÄ padakkhiá¹‡aá¹ƒ katvÄ pakkÄmi. atha kho kÅ«á¹­adanto brÄhmaá¹‡o tassÄ rattiyÄ accayena sake yaÃ±Ã±avÄá¹­e paá¹‡Ä«taá¹ƒ khÄdanÄ«yaá¹ƒ bhojanÄ«yaá¹ƒ paá¹­iyÄdÄpetvÄ bhagavato kÄlaá¹ƒ ÄrocÄpesi â€“ "kÄlo, bho gotama, niá¹­á¹­hitaá¹ƒ bhatta"nti.
[Translation for paragraph 355]
356. dhammo pakÄsito. esÄhaá¹ƒ bhavantaá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ gacchÄmi dhammaÃ±ca bhikkhusaá¹…ghaÃ±ca. upÄsakaá¹ƒ maá¹ƒ bhavaá¹ƒ gotamo dhÄretu ajjatagge pÄá¹‡upetaá¹ƒ saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ gataá¹ƒ. esÄhaá¹ƒ bho gotama satta ca usabhasatÄni satta ca vacchatarasatÄni satta ca vacchatarÄ«satÄni satta ca ajasatÄni satta ca urabbhasatÄni muÃ±cÄmi, jÄ«vitaá¹ƒ demi, haritÄni ceva tiá¹‡Äni khÄdantu, sÄ«tÄni ca pÄnÄ«yÄni pivantu, sÄ«to ca nesaá¹ƒ vÄto upavÄyatÅ«"ti. sotÄpattiphalasacchikiriyÄ 355. atha kho bhagavÄ kÅ«á¹­adantassa brÄhmaá¹‡assa anupubbiá¹ƒ kathaá¹ƒ kathesi, seyyathidaá¹ƒ, dÄnakathaá¹ƒ sÄ«lakathaá¹ƒ saggakathaá¹ƒ, kÄmÄnaá¹ƒ ÄdÄ«navaá¹ƒ okÄraá¹ƒ saá¹ƒkilesaá¹ƒ nekkhamme Änisaá¹ƒsaá¹ƒ pakÄsesi. yadÄ bhagavÄ aÃ±Ã±Äsi kÅ«á¹­adantaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡aá¹ƒ kallacittaá¹ƒ muducittaá¹ƒ vinÄ«varaá¹‡acittaá¹ƒ udaggacittaá¹ƒ pasannacittaá¹ƒ, atha yÄ buddhÄnaá¹ƒ sÄmukkaá¹ƒsikÄ dhammadesanÄ, taá¹ƒ pakÄsesi â€“ dukkhaá¹ƒ samudayaá¹ƒ nirodhaá¹ƒ maggaá¹ƒ. seyyathÄpi nÄma suddhaá¹ƒ vatthaá¹ƒ apagatakÄá¸·akaá¹ƒ sammadeva rajanaá¹ƒ paá¹­iggaá¹‡heyya, evameva kÅ«á¹­adantassa brÄhmaá¹‡assa tasmiÃ±Ã±eva Äsane virajaá¹ƒ vÄ«tamalaá¹ƒ dhammacakkhuá¹ƒ udapÄdi â€“ "yaá¹ƒ kiÃ±ci samudayadhammaá¹ƒ, sabbaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ nirodhadhamma"nti. 356. atha kho kÅ«á¹­adanto brÄhmaá¹‡o diá¹­á¹­hadhammo pattadhammo viditadhammo pariyogÄá¸·hadhammo tiá¹‡á¹‡avicikiccho vigatakathaá¹ƒkatho vesÄrajjappatto aparappaccayo satthusÄsane bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "adhivÄsetu me bhavaá¹ƒ gotamo svÄtanÄya bhattaá¹ƒ saddhiá¹ƒ bhikkhusaá¹…ghenÄ"ti. adhivÄsesi bhagavÄ tuá¹‡hÄ«bhÄvena. 357. atha kho kÅ«á¹­adanto brÄhmaá¹‡o bhagavato adhivÄsanaá¹ƒ viditvÄ uá¹­á¹­hÄyÄsanÄ bhagavantaá¹ƒ abhivÄdetvÄ padakkhiá¹‡aá¹ƒ katvÄ pakkÄmi. atha kho kÅ«á¹­adanto brÄhmaá¹‡o tassÄ rattiyÄ accayena sake yaÃ±Ã±avÄá¹­e paá¹‡Ä«taá¹ƒ khÄdanÄ«yaá¹ƒ bhojanÄ«yaá¹ƒ paá¹­iyÄdÄpetvÄ bhagavato kÄlaá¹ƒ ÄrocÄpesi â€“ "kÄlo, bho gotama, niá¹­á¹­hitaá¹ƒ bhatta"nti.
[Translation for paragraph 356]
357. dhammo pakÄsito. esÄhaá¹ƒ bhavantaá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ gacchÄmi dhammaÃ±ca bhikkhusaá¹…ghaÃ±ca. upÄsakaá¹ƒ maá¹ƒ bhavaá¹ƒ gotamo dhÄretu ajjatagge pÄá¹‡upetaá¹ƒ saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ gataá¹ƒ. esÄhaá¹ƒ bho gotama satta ca usabhasatÄni satta ca vacchatarasatÄni satta ca vacchatarÄ«satÄni satta ca ajasatÄni satta ca urabbhasatÄni muÃ±cÄmi, jÄ«vitaá¹ƒ demi, haritÄni ceva tiá¹‡Äni khÄdantu, sÄ«tÄni ca pÄnÄ«yÄni pivantu, sÄ«to ca nesaá¹ƒ vÄto upavÄyatÅ«"ti. sotÄpattiphalasacchikiriyÄ 355. atha kho bhagavÄ kÅ«á¹­adantassa brÄhmaá¹‡assa anupubbiá¹ƒ kathaá¹ƒ kathesi, seyyathidaá¹ƒ, dÄnakathaá¹ƒ sÄ«lakathaá¹ƒ saggakathaá¹ƒ, kÄmÄnaá¹ƒ ÄdÄ«navaá¹ƒ okÄraá¹ƒ saá¹ƒkilesaá¹ƒ nekkhamme Änisaá¹ƒsaá¹ƒ pakÄsesi. yadÄ bhagavÄ aÃ±Ã±Äsi kÅ«á¹­adantaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡aá¹ƒ kallacittaá¹ƒ muducittaá¹ƒ vinÄ«varaá¹‡acittaá¹ƒ udaggacittaá¹ƒ pasannacittaá¹ƒ, atha yÄ buddhÄnaá¹ƒ sÄmukkaá¹ƒsikÄ dhammadesanÄ, taá¹ƒ pakÄsesi â€“ dukkhaá¹ƒ samudayaá¹ƒ nirodhaá¹ƒ maggaá¹ƒ. seyyathÄpi nÄma suddhaá¹ƒ vatthaá¹ƒ apagatakÄá¸·akaá¹ƒ sammadeva rajanaá¹ƒ paá¹­iggaá¹‡heyya, evameva kÅ«á¹­adantassa brÄhmaá¹‡assa tasmiÃ±Ã±eva Äsane virajaá¹ƒ vÄ«tamalaá¹ƒ dhammacakkhuá¹ƒ udapÄdi â€“ "yaá¹ƒ kiÃ±ci samudayadhammaá¹ƒ, sabbaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ nirodhadhamma"nti. 356. atha kho kÅ«á¹­adanto brÄhmaá¹‡o diá¹­á¹­hadhammo pattadhammo viditadhammo pariyogÄá¸·hadhammo tiá¹‡á¹‡avicikiccho vigatakathaá¹ƒkatho vesÄrajjappatto aparappaccayo satthusÄsane bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "adhivÄsetu me bhavaá¹ƒ gotamo svÄtanÄya bhattaá¹ƒ saddhiá¹ƒ bhikkhusaá¹…ghenÄ"ti. adhivÄsesi bhagavÄ tuá¹‡hÄ«bhÄvena. 357. atha kho kÅ«á¹­adanto brÄhmaá¹‡o bhagavato adhivÄsanaá¹ƒ viditvÄ uá¹­á¹­hÄyÄsanÄ bhagavantaá¹ƒ abhivÄdetvÄ padakkhiá¹‡aá¹ƒ katvÄ pakkÄmi. atha kho kÅ«á¹­adanto brÄhmaá¹‡o tassÄ rattiyÄ accayena sake yaÃ±Ã±avÄá¹­e paá¹‡Ä«taá¹ƒ khÄdanÄ«yaá¹ƒ bhojanÄ«yaá¹ƒ paá¹­iyÄdÄpetvÄ bhagavato kÄlaá¹ƒ ÄrocÄpesi â€“ "kÄlo, bho gotama, niá¹­á¹­hitaá¹ƒ bhatta"nti.
[Translation for paragraph 357]
358. 358. atha kho bhagavÄ pubbaá¹‡hasamayaá¹ƒ nivÄsetvÄ pattacÄ«varamÄdÄya saddhiá¹ƒ bhikkhusaá¹…ghena yena kÅ«á¹­adantassa brÄhmaá¹‡assa yaÃ±Ã±avÄá¹­o tenupasaá¹…kami, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ paÃ±Ã±atte Äsane nisÄ«di. atha kho kÅ«á¹­adanto brÄhmaá¹‡o buddhappamukhaá¹ƒ bhikkhusaá¹…ghaá¹ƒ paá¹‡Ä«tena khÄdanÄ«yena bhojanÄ«yena sahatthÄ santappesi sampavÄresi. atha kho kÅ«á¹­adanto brÄhmaá¹‡o bhagavantaá¹ƒ bhuttÄviá¹ƒ onÄ«tapattapÄá¹‡iá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±ataraá¹ƒ nÄ«caá¹ƒ Äsanaá¹ƒ gahetvÄ ekamantaá¹ƒ nisÄ«di. ekamantaá¹ƒ nisinnaá¹ƒ kho kÅ«á¹­adantaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡aá¹ƒ bhagavÄ dhammiyÄ kathÄya sandassetvÄ samÄdapetvÄ samuttejetvÄ sampahaá¹ƒsetvÄ uá¹­á¹­hÄyÄsanÄ pakkÄmÄ«ti. kÅ«á¹­adantasuttaá¹ƒ niá¹­á¹­hitaá¹ƒ paÃ±camaá¹ƒ.
[Translation for paragraph 358]
359. 6. mahÄlisuttaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡adÅ«tavatthu 359. evaá¹ƒ me sutaá¹ƒ â€“ uekaá¹ƒ samayaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ vesÄliyaá¹ƒ viharati mahÄvane kÅ«á¹­ÄgÄrasÄlÄyaá¹ƒ. tena kho pana samayena sambahulÄ kosalakÄ ca brÄhmaá¹‡adÅ«tÄ mÄgadhakÄ ca brÄhmaá¹‡adÅ«tÄ vesÄliyaá¹ƒ paá¹­ivasanti kenacideva karaá¹‡Ä«yena. assosuá¹ƒ kho te kosalakÄ ca brÄhmaá¹‡adÅ«tÄ mÄgadhakÄ ca brÄhmaá¹‡adÅ«tÄ â€“ "samaá¹‡o khalu, bho, gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulÄ pabbajito vesÄliyaá¹ƒ viharati mahÄvane kÅ«á¹­ÄgÄrasÄlÄyaá¹ƒ. taá¹ƒ kho pana bhavantaá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ kalyÄá¹‡o kittisaddo abbhuggato â€“ â€˜itipi so bhagavÄ arahaá¹ƒ sammÄsambuddho vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampanno sugato lokavidÅ« anuttaro purisadammasÄrathi satthÄ devamanussÄnaá¹ƒ buddho bhagavÄâ€™. so imaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ sadevakaá¹ƒ samÄrakaá¹ƒ sabrahmakaá¹ƒ sassamaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡iá¹ƒ pajaá¹ƒ sadevamanussaá¹ƒ sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ pavedeti. so dhammaá¹ƒ deseti ÄdikalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ majjhekalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ pariyosÄnakalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ sÄtthaá¹ƒ sabyaÃ±janaá¹ƒ kevalaparipuá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ parisuddhaá¹ƒ brahmacariyaá¹ƒ pakÄseti. sÄdhu kho pana tathÄrÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ arahataá¹ƒ dassanaá¹ƒ hotÄ«"ti. 360. atha kho te kosalakÄ ca brÄhmaá¹‡adÅ«tÄ mÄgadhakÄ ca brÄhmaá¹‡adÅ«tÄ yena mahÄvanaá¹ƒ kÅ«á¹­ÄgÄrasÄlÄ tenupasaá¹…kamiá¹ƒsu. tena kho pana samayena ÄyasmÄ nÄgito bhagavato upaá¹­á¹­hÄko hoti. atha kho te kosalakÄ ca brÄhmaá¹‡adÅ«tÄ mÄgadhakÄ ca brÄhmaá¹‡adÅ«tÄ yenÄyasmÄ nÄgito tenupasaá¹…kamiá¹ƒsu. upasaá¹…kamitvÄ Äyasmantaá¹ƒ nÄgitaá¹ƒ etadavocuá¹ƒ â€“ "kahaá¹ƒ nu kho, bho nÄgita, etarahi so bhavaá¹ƒ gotamo viharati? dassanakÄmÄ hi mayaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ bhavantaá¹ƒ gotama"nti. "akÄlo kho, Ävuso, bhagavantaá¹ƒ dassanÄya, paá¹­isallÄ«no bhagavÄ"ti. atha kho te kosalakÄ ca brÄhmaá¹‡adÅ«tÄ mÄgadhakÄ ca brÄhmaá¹‡adÅ«tÄ tattheva ekamantaá¹ƒ nisÄ«diá¹ƒsu â€“ "disvÄva mayaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ bhavantaá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ gamissÄmÄ"ti.
Thus have I heard. On one occasion the Blessed One was staying at VesÄli, at the Gabled Hall in the Great Forest. And at that time a large number of Brahmin emissaries from Kosala and Magadha were staying at Vesali on some business. And they heard say: â€˜The ascetic Gotama, son of the Sakyans, who has gone forth from the Sakya clan, is staying at Vesali, at the Gabled Hall in the Great Forest. and that concerning the Blessed Lord Gotama a good report had been spread about: â€˜Indeed, the Blessed One is an *Arhat*, a fully enlightened *Buddha*, perfect in knowledge and conduct, a *Sugata*, knower of the world, unsurpassed trainer of those to be tamed, teacher of gods and humans, a *Buddha*, a Blessed One.â€™ He, having realised it by his own super-knowledge, proclaims this world with its gods (*devas*), *MÄras*, and *BrahmÄs*, its princes and people. He preaches the *Dhamma*, which is lovely in its beginning, lovely in its middle, lovely in its ending, in the spirit and in the letter, and displays the fully-perfected and purified holy life (*brahmacariya*). It is good to see such *arahants*.â€™
360. 6. mahÄlisuttaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡adÅ«tavatthu 359. evaá¹ƒ me sutaá¹ƒ â€“ uekaá¹ƒ samayaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ vesÄliyaá¹ƒ viharati mahÄvane kÅ«á¹­ÄgÄrasÄlÄyaá¹ƒ. tena kho pana samayena sambahulÄ kosalakÄ ca brÄhmaá¹‡adÅ«tÄ mÄgadhakÄ ca brÄhmaá¹‡adÅ«tÄ vesÄliyaá¹ƒ paá¹­ivasanti kenacideva karaá¹‡Ä«yena. assosuá¹ƒ kho te kosalakÄ ca brÄhmaá¹‡adÅ«tÄ mÄgadhakÄ ca brÄhmaá¹‡adÅ«tÄ â€“ "samaá¹‡o khalu, bho, gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulÄ pabbajito vesÄliyaá¹ƒ viharati mahÄvane kÅ«á¹­ÄgÄrasÄlÄyaá¹ƒ. taá¹ƒ kho pana bhavantaá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ kalyÄá¹‡o kittisaddo abbhuggato â€“ â€˜itipi so bhagavÄ arahaá¹ƒ sammÄsambuddho vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampanno sugato lokavidÅ« anuttaro purisadammasÄrathi satthÄ devamanussÄnaá¹ƒ buddho bhagavÄâ€™. so imaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ sadevakaá¹ƒ samÄrakaá¹ƒ sabrahmakaá¹ƒ sassamaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡iá¹ƒ pajaá¹ƒ sadevamanussaá¹ƒ sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ pavedeti. so dhammaá¹ƒ deseti ÄdikalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ majjhekalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ pariyosÄnakalyÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ sÄtthaá¹ƒ sabyaÃ±janaá¹ƒ kevalaparipuá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ parisuddhaá¹ƒ brahmacariyaá¹ƒ pakÄseti. sÄdhu kho pana tathÄrÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ arahataá¹ƒ dassanaá¹ƒ hotÄ«"ti. 360. atha kho te kosalakÄ ca brÄhmaá¹‡adÅ«tÄ mÄgadhakÄ ca brÄhmaá¹‡adÅ«tÄ yena mahÄvanaá¹ƒ kÅ«á¹­ÄgÄrasÄlÄ tenupasaá¹…kamiá¹ƒsu. tena kho pana samayena ÄyasmÄ nÄgito bhagavato upaá¹­á¹­hÄko hoti. atha kho te kosalakÄ ca brÄhmaá¹‡adÅ«tÄ mÄgadhakÄ ca brÄhmaá¹‡adÅ«tÄ yenÄyasmÄ nÄgito tenupasaá¹…kamiá¹ƒsu. upasaá¹…kamitvÄ Äyasmantaá¹ƒ nÄgitaá¹ƒ etadavocuá¹ƒ â€“ "kahaá¹ƒ nu kho, bho nÄgita, etarahi so bhavaá¹ƒ gotamo viharati? dassanakÄmÄ hi mayaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ bhavantaá¹ƒ gotama"nti. "akÄlo kho, Ävuso, bhagavantaá¹ƒ dassanÄya, paá¹­isallÄ«no bhagavÄ"ti. atha kho te kosalakÄ ca brÄhmaá¹‡adÅ«tÄ mÄgadhakÄ ca brÄhmaá¹‡adÅ«tÄ tattheva ekamantaá¹ƒ nisÄ«diá¹ƒsu â€“ "disvÄva mayaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ bhavantaá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ gamissÄmÄ"ti.
And so these Brahmin emissaries from Kosala and MaÂ­gadha went to the Great Forest, to the Gabled Hall. At that time the Venerable NÄgita was the Lordâ€™s personal attendant. So they approached the Venerable NÄgita and said: â€˜Reverend NÄgita, where is the Reverend Gotama now staying? We would like to see the Reverend Gotama.â€™ â€˜Friends, it is not the right time to see the Lord. He is in solitary meditation.â€™ But the Brahmins just sat down to one side and said: â€˜When we have seen the Lord Gotama, we will go.â€™ The Subject of Oá¹­á¹­haddha the Licchavi
361. oá¹­á¹­haddhalicchavÄ«vatthu 361. oá¹­á¹­haddhopi licchavÄ« mahatiyÄ licchavÄ«parisÄya saddhiá¹ƒ yena mahÄvanaá¹ƒ kÅ«á¹­ÄgÄrasÄlÄ yenÄyasmÄ nÄgito tenupasaá¹…kami, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ Äyasmantaá¹ƒ nÄgitaá¹ƒ abhivÄdetvÄ ekamantaá¹ƒ aá¹­á¹­hÄsi. ekamantaá¹ƒ á¹­hito kho oá¹­á¹­haddhopi licchavÄ« Äyasmantaá¹ƒ nÄgitaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "kahaá¹ƒ nu kho, bhante nÄgita, etarahi so bhagavÄ viharati arahaá¹ƒ sammÄsambuddho, dassanakÄmÄ hi mayaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ bhagavantaá¹ƒ arahantaá¹ƒ sammÄsambuddha"nti. "akÄlo kho, mahÄli, bhagavantaá¹ƒ dassanÄya, paá¹­isallÄ«no bhagavÄ"ti. oá¹­á¹­haddhopi licchavÄ« tattheva ekamantaá¹ƒ nisÄ«di â€“ "disvÄva ahaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ bhagavantaá¹ƒ gamissÄmi arahantaá¹ƒ sammÄsambuddha"nti. 362. atha kho sÄ«ho samaá¹‡uddeso yenÄyasmÄ nÄgito tenupasaá¹…kami, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ Äyasmantaá¹ƒ nÄgitaá¹ƒ abhivÄdetvÄ ekamantaá¹ƒ aá¹­á¹­hÄsi. ekamantaá¹ƒ á¹­hito kho sÄ«ho samaá¹‡uddeso Äyasmantaá¹ƒ nÄgitaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "ete, bhante kassapa, sambahulÄ kosalakÄ ca brÄhmaá¹‡adÅ«tÄ mÄgadhakÄ ca brÄhmaá¹‡adÅ«tÄ idhÅ«pasaá¹…kantÄ bhagavantaá¹ƒ dassanÄya, oá¹­á¹­haddhopi licchavÄ« mahatiyÄ licchavÄ«parisÄya saddhiá¹ƒ idhÅ«pasaá¹…kanto bhagavantaá¹ƒ dassanÄya, sÄdhu, bhante kassapa, labhataá¹ƒ esÄ janatÄ bhagavantaá¹ƒ dassanÄyÄ"ti. "tena hi, sÄ«ha, tvaÃ±Ã±eva bhagavato ÄrocehÄ«"ti. "evaá¹ƒ, bhante"ti kho sÄ«ho samaá¹‡uddeso Äyasmato nÄgitassa paá¹­issutvÄ yena bhagavÄ tenupasaá¹…kami, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ bhagavantaá¹ƒ abhivÄdetvÄ ekamantaá¹ƒ aá¹­á¹­hÄsi. ekamantaá¹ƒ á¹­hito kho sÄ«ho samaá¹‡uddeso bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "ete, bhante, sambahulÄ kosalakÄ ca brÄhmaá¹‡adÅ«tÄ mÄgadhakÄ ca brÄhmaá¹‡adÅ«tÄ idhÅ«pasaá¹…kantÄ bhagavantaá¹ƒ dassanÄya, oá¹­á¹­haddhopi licchavÄ« mahatiyÄ licchavÄ«parisÄya saddhiá¹ƒ idhÅ«pasaá¹…kanto bhagavantaá¹ƒ dassanÄya. sÄdhu, bhante, labhataá¹ƒ esÄ janatÄ bhagavantaá¹ƒ dassanÄyÄ"ti. "tena hi, sÄ«ha, vihÄrapacchÄyÄyaá¹ƒ Äsanaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apehÄ«"ti. "evaá¹ƒ, bhante"ti kho sÄ«ho samaá¹‡uddeso bhagavato paá¹­issutvÄ vihÄrapacchÄyÄyaá¹ƒ Äsanaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apesi.
Just then Oá¹­á¹­haddha the Licchavi came to the Gabled Hall with a large company, saluted the Venerable NÄgita and stood aside, saying: â€˜Where is the Blessed Lord staying, the *Arhat*, the fully-enlightened *Buddha*? We would like to see him.â€™ â€˜MahÄli, it is not the right time to see the Lord, He is in solitary meditation.â€™ But Oá¹­á¹­haddha just sat down to one side, and said: â€˜When I have seen the Blessed Lord, the *Arhat*, the fully-enlightened *Buddha*, I will go.â€™
362. oá¹­á¹­haddhalicchavÄ«vatthu 361. oá¹­á¹­haddhopi licchavÄ« mahatiyÄ licchavÄ«parisÄya saddhiá¹ƒ yena mahÄvanaá¹ƒ kÅ«á¹­ÄgÄrasÄlÄ yenÄyasmÄ nÄgito tenupasaá¹…kami, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ Äyasmantaá¹ƒ nÄgitaá¹ƒ abhivÄdetvÄ ekamantaá¹ƒ aá¹­á¹­hÄsi. ekamantaá¹ƒ á¹­hito kho oá¹­á¹­haddhopi licchavÄ« Äyasmantaá¹ƒ nÄgitaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "kahaá¹ƒ nu kho, bhante nÄgita, etarahi so bhagavÄ viharati arahaá¹ƒ sammÄsambuddho, dassanakÄmÄ hi mayaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ bhagavantaá¹ƒ arahantaá¹ƒ sammÄsambuddha"nti. "akÄlo kho, mahÄli, bhagavantaá¹ƒ dassanÄya, paá¹­isallÄ«no bhagavÄ"ti. oá¹­á¹­haddhopi licchavÄ« tattheva ekamantaá¹ƒ nisÄ«di â€“ "disvÄva ahaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ bhagavantaá¹ƒ gamissÄmi arahantaá¹ƒ sammÄsambuddha"nti. 362. atha kho sÄ«ho samaá¹‡uddeso yenÄyasmÄ nÄgito tenupasaá¹…kami, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ Äyasmantaá¹ƒ nÄgitaá¹ƒ abhivÄdetvÄ ekamantaá¹ƒ aá¹­á¹­hÄsi. ekamantaá¹ƒ á¹­hito kho sÄ«ho samaá¹‡uddeso Äyasmantaá¹ƒ nÄgitaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "ete, bhante kassapa, sambahulÄ kosalakÄ ca brÄhmaá¹‡adÅ«tÄ mÄgadhakÄ ca brÄhmaá¹‡adÅ«tÄ idhÅ«pasaá¹…kantÄ bhagavantaá¹ƒ dassanÄya, oá¹­á¹­haddhopi licchavÄ« mahatiyÄ licchavÄ«parisÄya saddhiá¹ƒ idhÅ«pasaá¹…kanto bhagavantaá¹ƒ dassanÄya, sÄdhu, bhante kassapa, labhataá¹ƒ esÄ janatÄ bhagavantaá¹ƒ dassanÄyÄ"ti. "tena hi, sÄ«ha, tvaÃ±Ã±eva bhagavato ÄrocehÄ«"ti. "evaá¹ƒ, bhante"ti kho sÄ«ho samaá¹‡uddeso Äyasmato nÄgitassa paá¹­issutvÄ yena bhagavÄ tenupasaá¹…kami, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ bhagavantaá¹ƒ abhivÄdetvÄ ekamantaá¹ƒ aá¹­á¹­hÄsi. ekamantaá¹ƒ á¹­hito kho sÄ«ho samaá¹‡uddeso bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "ete, bhante, sambahulÄ kosalakÄ ca brÄhmaá¹‡adÅ«tÄ mÄgadhakÄ ca brÄhmaá¹‡adÅ«tÄ idhÅ«pasaá¹…kantÄ bhagavantaá¹ƒ dassanÄya, oá¹­á¹­haddhopi licchavÄ« mahatiyÄ licchavÄ«parisÄya saddhiá¹ƒ idhÅ«pasaá¹…kanto bhagavantaá¹ƒ dassanÄya. sÄdhu, bhante, labhataá¹ƒ esÄ janatÄ bhagavantaá¹ƒ dassanÄyÄ"ti. "tena hi, sÄ«ha, vihÄrapacchÄyÄyaá¹ƒ Äsanaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apehÄ«"ti. "evaá¹ƒ, bhante"ti kho sÄ«ho samaá¹‡uddeso bhagavato paá¹­issutvÄ vihÄrapacchÄyÄyaá¹ƒ Äsanaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apesi.
Then the novice SÄ«ha came to the Venerable NÄgita, stood aside and said: â€˜Venerable Kassapa, these many BrahÂ­min emissaries from Kosala and Magadha have come here to see the Lord, and Oá¹­á¹­haddha the Licchavi, too, has come with a large company to see the Lord. It would be well, Venerable Kassapa, to allow these people to see him.â€™ â€˜Well then, SÄ«ha, you announce them to the Lord.â€™ â€˜Yes, Venerable Sirâ€™, said Siha. Then he went to the Lord, saluted him, stood aside and said: â€˜Lord, these Brahmin emissaries from Kosala and MaÂ­gadha have come here to see the Lord, and Oá¹­á¹­haddha the Licchavi likewise with a large company. It would be well if the Lord were to let these people see him.â€™ â€˜Then, Siha, prepare a seat in the shade of this dwelling.â€™ â€˜Yes, Lordâ€™, said Siha, and did so.

Then, indeed, the Lord, having left the monastery, sat down on the seat laid out in the shade of the monastery. Then, indeed, those Kosalan Brahmin envoys and Magadhan Brahmin envoys approached the Lord, and after approaching, they exchanged greetings with the Lord. Having concluded their greetings and cordial talk, they sat down to one side. Otthaddha the Licchavi also, with a large Licchavi assembly, approached the Lord, and after approaching, having paid homage to the Lord, sat down to one side.

Having sat down to one side, Otthaddha the Licchavi said this to the Lord: "Some days ago, venerable sir, some time ago, Sunakkhatta the Licchavi's son approached me and said this to me: 'Since the time I have been living under the guidance of the Lord, it has not been long, only three years, and indeed, I see heavenly forms, pleasing forms, connected with sensual pleasure, delightful, but I do not hear heavenly sounds, pleasing forms, connected with sensual pleasure, delightful.'" "Are there indeed, venerable sir, heavenly sounds that Sunakkhatta the Licchavi's son does not hear, pleasing forms, connected with sensual pleasure, delightful, or are there no such sounds?" one-sided cultivated concentration (ekaá¹ƒsabhÄvitasamÄdhi)

"There are indeed, MahÄli, heavenly sounds that Sunakkhatta the Licchavi's son does not hear, pleasing forms, connected with sensual pleasure, delightful, there are not no such sounds." "What now, venerable sir, is the cause, what is the reason, why Sunakkhatta the Licchavi's son does not hear heavenly sounds, pleasing forms, connected with sensual pleasure, delightful, there are not no such sounds?"

"idha, mahÄli, bhikkhuno puratthimÄya disÄya ekaá¹ƒsabhÄvito samÄdhi hoti dibbÄnaá¹ƒ rÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ dassanÄya piyarÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄnaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yÄnaá¹ƒ, no ca kho dibbÄnaá¹ƒ saddÄnaá¹ƒ savanÄya piyarÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄnaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yÄnaá¹ƒ. so puratthimÄya disÄya ekaá¹ƒsabhÄvite samÄdhimhi dibbÄnaá¹ƒ rÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ dassanÄya piyarÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄnaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yÄnaá¹ƒ, no ca kho dibbÄnaá¹ƒ saddÄnaá¹ƒ savanÄya piyarÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄnaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yÄnaá¹ƒ. puratthimÄya disÄya dibbÄni rÅ«pÄni passati piyarÅ«pÄni kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄni rajanÄ«yÄni, no ca kho dibbÄni saddÄni suá¹‡Äti piyarÅ«pÄni kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄni rajanÄ«yÄni. taá¹ƒ kissa hetu? evaÃ±hetaá¹ƒ, mahÄli, hoti
"Here, MahÄli, a monk in the eastern direction has a one-sided cultivated concentration (ekaá¹ƒsabhÄvito samÄdhi) for the sight of heavenly forms, pleasing forms, connected with sensual pleasure, delightful, but not for the hearing of heavenly sounds, pleasing forms, connected with sensual pleasure, delightful. He, in the eastern direction, in a one-sided cultivated concentration (ekaá¹ƒsabhÄvite samÄdhimhi) for the sight of heavenly forms, pleasing forms, connected with sensual pleasure, delightful, but not for the hearing of heavenly sounds, pleasing forms, connected with sensual pleasure, delightful. In the eastern direction, he sees heavenly forms, pleasing forms, connected with sensual pleasure, delightful, but he does not hear heavenly sounds, pleasing forms, connected with sensual pleasure, delightful. What is the cause of that? It is just so, MahÄli. â€˜In the case of a monk, in the east, in one-sided *samÄdhi*, there is the seeing of heavenly forms (divine sights â€“ *divyÄnÄá¹ƒ rÅ«pÄá¹‡Äá¹ƒ*), which are agreeable, connected with sensual pleasure, and delightful, but not the hearing of heavenly sounds, which are agreeable, connected with sensual pleasure, and delightful.
367. bhikkhuno puratthimÄya disÄya ekaá¹ƒsabhÄvite samÄdhimhi dibbÄnaá¹ƒ rÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ dassanÄya piyarÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄnaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yÄnaá¹ƒ, no ca kho dibbÄnaá¹ƒ saddÄnaá¹ƒ savanÄya piyarÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄnaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yÄnaá¹ƒ. 367. "puna caparaá¹ƒ, mahÄli, bhikkhuno dakkhiá¹‡Äya disÄyaâ€¦peâ€¦ pacchimÄya disÄyaâ€¦ uttarÄya disÄyaâ€¦ uddhamadho tiriyaá¹ƒ ekaá¹ƒsabhÄvito
â€˜Again, MahÄli, in the case of a monk, facing southâ€¦westâ€¦northâ€¦goes into a one-sided *samÄdhi* and facing upwards, downwards, or across, sees heavenly sights (*dibbÄnaá¹ƒ rÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ dassanÄya*), which are agreeable, connected with sensual pleasure, and delightful, but does not hear heavenly sounds (*dibbÄnaá¹ƒ saddÄnaá¹ƒ savanÄya*), which are agreeable, connected with sensual pleasure, and delightful. He, facing upwards, downwards, or across, in one-sided *samÄdhi*, sees heavenly sights, which are agreeable, connected with sensual pleasure, and delightful, but does not hear heavenly sounds, which are agreeable, connected with sensual pleasure, and delightful. Facing upwards, downwards, or across, he sees heavenly sights, which are agreeable, connected with sensual pleasure, and delightful, but does not hear heavenly sounds, which are agreeable, connected with sensual pleasure, and delightful. What is the reason for that? Because this is how it is, MahÄli, for a monk facing upwards, downwards, or across, in one-sided *samÄdhi*, there is the seeing of heavenly sights, which are agreeable, connected with sensual pleasure, and delightful, but not the hearing of heavenly sounds, which are agreeable, connected with sensual pleasure, and delightful.

â€˜Again, MahÄli, in the case of a monk, facing southâ€¦westâ€¦northâ€¦facing upwards, downwards or across, in one-sided This samÄdhi (concentration) leads to the hearing of heavenly sounds that are pleasant, delightful and enticing, but not to the seeing of heavenly sights that are pleasant, delightful and enticing. By means of this one-sided samÄdhi (concentration), facing upwards, downwards, and across, he hears heavenly sounds that are pleasant, delightful, and enticing, but does not see heavenly sights that are pleasant, delightful, and enticing. Facing upwards, downwards and across, he hears heavenly sounds that are pleasant, delightful, and enticing, but does not see heavenly sights that are pleasant, delightful, and enticing. What is the reason for this? It is because, MahÄli, this one-sided samÄdhi (concentration) of the monk, facing upwards, downwards and across, leads to the hearing of heavenly sounds that are pleasant, delightful and enticing, but not to the seeing of heavenly sights that are pleasant, delightful and enticing.

"idha, mahÄli, bhikkhuno puratthimÄya disÄya ubhayaá¹ƒsabhÄvito samÄdhi hoti dibbÄnaÃ±ca rÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ dassanÄya piyarÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄnaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yÄnaá¹ƒ dibbÄnaÃ±ca saddÄnaá¹ƒ savanÄya piyarÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄnaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yÄnaá¹ƒ. so puratthimÄya disÄya ubhayaá¹ƒsabhÄvite samÄdhimhi dibbÄnaÃ±ca rÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ dassanÄya piyarÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄnaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yÄnaá¹ƒ, dibbÄnaÃ±ca saddÄnaá¹ƒ savanÄya piyarÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄnaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yÄnaá¹ƒ. puratthimÄya disÄya dibbÄni ca rÅ«pÄni passati piyarÅ«pÄni kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄni rajanÄ«yÄni, dibbÄni ca saddÄni suá¹‡Äti piyarÅ«pÄni kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄni rajanÄ«yÄni. taá¹ƒ kissa hetu? evaÃ±hetaá¹ƒ, mahÄli, hoti bhikkhuno puratthimÄya disÄya ubhayaá¹ƒsabhÄvite samÄdhimhi dibbÄnaÃ±ca rÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ dassanÄya piyarÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄnaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yÄnaá¹ƒ dibbÄnaÃ±ca saddÄnaá¹ƒ savanÄya piyarÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄnaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yÄnaá¹ƒ. 371. "puna caparaá¹ƒ, mahÄli, bhikkhuno dakkhiá¹‡Äya disÄyaâ€¦peâ€¦ pacchimÄya disÄyaâ€¦ uttarÄya disÄyaâ€¦ uddhamadho tiriyaá¹ƒ ubhayaá¹ƒsabhÄvito samÄdhi hoti dibbÄnaÃ±ca rÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ dassanÄya piyarÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄnaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yÄnaá¹ƒ, dibbÄnaÃ±ca saddÄnaá¹ƒ savanÄya piyarÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄnaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yÄnaá¹ƒ. so uddhamadho tiriyaá¹ƒ ubhayaá¹ƒsabhÄvite samÄdhimhi dibbÄnaÃ±ca rÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ dassanÄya piyarÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄnaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yÄnaá¹ƒ dibbÄnaÃ±ca saddÄnaá¹ƒ savanÄya piyarÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄnaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yÄnaá¹ƒ. uddhamadho tiriyaá¹ƒ dibbÄni ca rÅ«pÄni passati
"Here, MahÄli, a monk, facing east, goes into two-sided samÄdhi (concentration) and both sees heavenly sights that are pleasant, delightful, and enticing, and hears heavenly sounds that are pleasant, delightful, and enticing. Facing east, by means of this two-sided samÄdhi (concentration), he sees heavenly sights that are pleasant, delightful and enticing, and hears heavenly sounds that are pleasant, delightful and enticing. Facing east, he sees heavenly sights that are pleasant, delightful and enticing, and hears heavenly sounds that are pleasant, delightful and enticing. What is the reason for this? It is because, MahÄli, this two-sided samÄdhi (concentration) of the monk, facing east, leads to both the seeing of heavenly sights that are pleasant, delightful and enticing, and the hearing of heavenly sounds that are pleasant, delightful and enticing.
371. samÄdhi hoti dibbÄnaá¹ƒ saddÄnaá¹ƒ savanÄya piyarÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄnaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yÄnaá¹ƒ, no ca kho dibbÄnaá¹ƒ rÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ dassanÄya piyarÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄnaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yÄnaá¹ƒ. so uddhamadho tiriyaá¹ƒ ekaá¹ƒsabhÄvite samÄdhimhi dibbÄnaá¹ƒ saddÄnaá¹ƒ savanÄya piyarÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄnaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yÄnaá¹ƒ, no ca kho dibbÄnaá¹ƒ rÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ dassanÄya piyarÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄnaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yÄnaá¹ƒ. uddhamadho tiriyaá¹ƒ dibbÄni saddÄni suá¹‡Äti piyarÅ«pÄni kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄni rajanÄ«yÄni, no ca kho dibbÄni rÅ«pÄni passati piyarÅ«pÄni kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄni rajanÄ«yÄni. taá¹ƒ kissa hetu? evaÃ±hetaá¹ƒ, mahÄli, hoti bhikkhuno uddhamadho tiriyaá¹ƒ ekaá¹ƒsabhÄvite samÄdhimhi dibbÄnaá¹ƒ saddÄnaá¹ƒ savanÄya piyarÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄnaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yÄnaá¹ƒ, no ca kho dibbÄnaá¹ƒ rÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ dassanÄya piyarÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄnaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yÄnaá¹ƒ. 370. "idha, mahÄli, bhikkhuno puratthimÄya disÄya ubhayaá¹ƒsabhÄvito samÄdhi hoti dibbÄnaÃ±ca rÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ dassanÄya piyarÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄnaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yÄnaá¹ƒ dibbÄnaÃ±ca saddÄnaá¹ƒ savanÄya piyarÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄnaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yÄnaá¹ƒ. so puratthimÄya disÄya ubhayaá¹ƒsabhÄvite samÄdhimhi dibbÄnaÃ±ca rÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ dassanÄya piyarÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄnaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yÄnaá¹ƒ, dibbÄnaÃ±ca saddÄnaá¹ƒ savanÄya piyarÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄnaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yÄnaá¹ƒ. puratthimÄya disÄya dibbÄni ca rÅ«pÄni passati piyarÅ«pÄni kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄni rajanÄ«yÄni, dibbÄni ca saddÄni suá¹‡Äti piyarÅ«pÄni kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄni rajanÄ«yÄni. taá¹ƒ kissa hetu? evaÃ±hetaá¹ƒ, mahÄli, hoti bhikkhuno puratthimÄya disÄya ubhayaá¹ƒsabhÄvite samÄdhimhi dibbÄnaÃ±ca rÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ dassanÄya piyarÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄnaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yÄnaá¹ƒ dibbÄnaÃ±ca saddÄnaá¹ƒ savanÄya piyarÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄnaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yÄnaá¹ƒ. 371. "puna caparaá¹ƒ, mahÄli, bhikkhuno dakkhiá¹‡Äya disÄyaâ€¦peâ€¦ pacchimÄya disÄyaâ€¦ uttarÄya disÄyaâ€¦ uddhamadho tiriyaá¹ƒ ubhayaá¹ƒsabhÄvito samÄdhi hoti dibbÄnaÃ±ca rÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ dassanÄya piyarÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄnaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yÄnaá¹ƒ, dibbÄnaÃ±ca saddÄnaá¹ƒ savanÄya piyarÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄnaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yÄnaá¹ƒ. so uddhamadho tiriyaá¹ƒ ubhayaá¹ƒsabhÄvite samÄdhimhi dibbÄnaÃ±ca rÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ dassanÄya piyarÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄnaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yÄnaá¹ƒ dibbÄnaÃ±ca saddÄnaá¹ƒ savanÄya piyarÅ«pÄnaá¹ƒ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄnaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yÄnaá¹ƒ. uddhamadho tiriyaá¹ƒ dibbÄni ca rÅ«pÄni passati
"Again, MahÄli, a monk facing south... west... north... facing upwards, downwards or across, goes into two-sided samÄdhi (concentration) and sees heavenly sights that are pleasant, delightful, and enticing, and hears heavenly sounds that are pleasant, delightful, and enticing. Facing upwards, downwards, and across, by means of this two-sided samÄdhi (concentration), he sees heavenly sights that are pleasant, delightful and enticing, and hears heavenly sounds that are pleasant, delightful and enticing. Facing upwards, downwards and across, he sees heavenly sights They hear pleasant sights, joined with desire, and things that provoke passion, and they hear heavenly sounds that are pleasant, joined with desire, and things that provoke passion. Why is that? Because this is how it is, MahÄli, a monk in whom has arisen through cultivation, concentration directed both upward and downward, and across, sees heavenly forms that are pleasant, joined with desire, and things that provoke passion, and hears heavenly sounds for listening to, that are pleasant, joined with desire, and things that provoke passion. This, MahÄli, is the cause, this is the reason why Sunakkhatta, son of the Licchavis, being without, only hears heavenly sounds, pleasant sights, joined with desire, and things that provoke passion, and not un-peaceful things.â€ â€œSurely, venerable sir, it is for the sake of realising these samÄdhi- states, these states of concentration that monks lead the holy life under the Blessed One?â€ â€œNo, MahÄli, it is not for the sake of realising these samÄdhi- states, these states of concentration that monks lead the holy life under me. There are other things, MahÄli, higher and more sublime than that, for the sake of realising which monks lead the holy life under me.â€ The four noble fruits. â€œBut what are those states, venerable sir, higher and more sublime, for the sake of realising which monks lead the holy life under the Blessed One?â€ â€œHere, MahÄli, a monk, with the destruction of the three fetters ( *saá¹ƒyojana*), is a stream-enterer ( *sotÄpanna*), no longer subject to downfall, assured, destined for enlightenment ( *sambodhi*). This too, MahÄli, is a quality higher and more sublime, for the sake of realizing which monks lead the holy life under me. â€œAgain, MahÄli, a monk, with the destruction of the three fetters, and with the attenuation of greed, hatred, and delusion, becomes a once-returner ( *sakadÄgÄmÄ«*), who, having returned to this world only once more, will make an end of suffering. This too, MahÄli, is a quality higher and more sublime, for the sake of realizing which monks lead the holy life under me. â€œAgain, MahÄli, a monk, with the destruction of the five lower fetters, is reborn spontaneously ( *opapÄtiko*), there to attain final nirvÄá¹‡a ( *parinibbÄyÄ«*), no longer subject to returning from that world. This too, MahÄli, is a quality higher and more sublime, for the sake of realizing which monks lead the holy life under me. â€œAgain, MahÄli, a monk, with the destruction of the Äsavas, realizes for himself with direct knowledge, here and now, the taintless deliverance of mind, deliverance through wisdom, and having entered upon it, abides in it. This too, MahÄli, is a quality higher and more sublime, for the sake of realizing which monks lead the holy life under me. These, MahÄli, are those states higher and more sublime, for the sake of realising which monks lead the holy life under me.â€ The Noble Eightfold Path ( *ariyaaá¹­á¹­haá¹…gikamaggo*) â€œBut venerable sir, is there a path, is there a practice, for the realization of these things?â€ â€œThere is a path, MahÄli, there is a practice for the realization of these things.â€ â€œBut what, venerable sir, is that path, what is that practice, for the realization of these things?â€ â€œJust this Noble Eightfold Path: Right View ( *sammÄdiá¹­á¹­hi*), Right Intention ( *sammÄsaá¹…kappo*), Right Speech ( *sammÄvÄcÄ*), Right Action ( *sammÄkammanto*), Right Livelihood ( *sammÄÄjÄ«vo*), Right Effort ( *sammÄvÄyÄmo*), Right Mindfulness ( *sammÄsati*), Right Concentration ( *sammÄsamÄdhi*). This, MahÄli, is the path, this is the practice for the realization of these things. The story of the two wanderers â€œOnce, MahÄli, I was staying at KosambÄ«, in Ghosita Park. Then two wanderers, Muá¹‡á¸iya and the wanderer JÄliya, a resident of the DÄrupattika monastery, approached me. Having approached, they exchanged greetings with me. Having concluded their courteous and amiable talk, they stood to one side. Standing to one side, those two wanderers said this to me: â€˜Friend Gotama, is the soul the same as the body, or is the soul one thing and the body another?â€™ â€œThen listen, friend, attend carefully, I will speak.â€ â€˜Yes, friend,â€™ those two wanderers replied to me. I said this: â€˜Here, friend, a TathÄgata appears in the world, an *arahaá¹ƒ* (worthy one), a *sammÄsambuddho* (fully enlightened one)â€¦peâ€¦ (as in sections 190-212, so it should be related in full). In this way, friend, a monk is virtuousâ€¦peâ€¦enters upon and abides in the first jhÄna. A monk who knows and sees in this way, is it appropriate for him to say â€“ â€˜the soul is the same as the bodyâ€™? Having taken various sorts of *khÄri* [or, taking a *khÄri* of various sorts], he enters the forest dwelling, thinking, â€˜I will live on windfalls.â€™ In this way, he only becomes an attendant on one who has attained to unexcelled knowledge and conduct. This, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, is the first path of failure in the pursuit of this unexcelled attainment of knowledge and conduct. â€œAgain, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, some ascetic or Brahmin, being unable to live on windfalls, takes a spade and basket and enters the forest, thinking, â€˜I will live on tubers, roots, and fruits.â€™ In this way, he only becomes an attendant on one who has attained to unexcelled knowledge and conduct. This, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, is the second path of failure in the pursuit of this unexcelled attainment of knowledge and conduct. â€œAgain, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, some ascetic or Brahmin, being unable to live on windfalls or on tubers, roots, and fruits, makes a fire-hearth at the edge of a village or small town and sits tending the flame. In this way, he only becomes an attendant on one who has attained to unexcelled knowledge and conduct. This, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, is the third path of failure in the pursuit of this unexcelled attainment of knowledge and conduct. â€œAgain, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, some ascetic or Brahmin, being unable to live on windfalls or on tubers, roots, and fruits, or to tend the flame, erects a house with four doors at the crossroads thinking: â€˜Whatever ascetic or Brahmin arrives from the four quarters, I will honour to the best of my strength and ability.â€™ In this way, he only becomes an attendant on one who has attained to unexcelled knowledge and conduct. This, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, is the fourth path of failure in the pursuit of this unexcelled attainment of knowledge and conduct. These, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha, are the four paths of failure in the pursuit of this unexcelled attainment of knowledge and conduct. â€œWhat do you think, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha? Do you and your teacher live in accordance with this unexcelled knowledge and conduct?â€ â€œNo, Gotama.â€ â€˜Where was I...? â€œGood Gotama, with your teacher, what is the unsurpassed perfection of knowledge and conduct? I am far, good Gotama, from the unsurpassed perfection of knowledge and conduct, with my teacher.â€ â€œWhat do you think, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha? Could you and your teacher, being unable to gain this unsurpassed perfection of knowledge and conduct, go with your carrying-poles into the depths of the forest, intending to live on windfalls?â€ â€œNo, Gotama.â€ â€œWhat do you think, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha? Could you and your teacher, being unable to gain this unsurpassed perfection of knowledge and conduct, live on windfalls, being unable to gain that, take your digging stick and basket and go into the depths of the forest, intending to live on tubers, roots, and fruits?â€ â€œNo, Gotama.â€ â€œWhat do you think, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha? Could you and your teacher, being unable to gain this unsurpassed perfection of knowledge and conduct, live on windfalls, being unable to gain that, live on tubers, roots, and fruits, being unable to gain that, make a fire hut near a village or town, attending to the fire?â€ â€œNo, Gotama.â€ â€œWhat do you think, Ambaá¹­á¹­ha? Could you and your teacher, being unable to gain this unsurpassed perfection of knowledge and conduct, live on windfalls, being unable to gain that, live on tubers, roots, and fruits, being unable to gain that, attend to the fire, being unable to gain that, build a four-doored guest house at the crossroads, thinking, â€˜Whatever ascetic or Brahmin comes from these four directions, we will treat them according to our ability and powerâ€™?â€ â€œNo, Gotama.â€

"katamo pana, bhante, maggo katamÄ paá¹­ipadÄ etesaá¹ƒ dhammÄnaá¹ƒ sacchikiriyÄyÄ"ti? "ayameva ariyo aá¹­á¹­haá¹…giko maggo. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ sammÄdiá¹­á¹­hi sammÄsaá¹…kappo sammÄvÄcÄ sammÄkammanto sammÄÄjÄ«vo sammÄvÄyÄmo sammÄsati sammÄsamÄdhi. ayaá¹ƒ kho, mahÄli, maggo ayaá¹ƒ paá¹­ipadÄ etesaá¹ƒ dhammÄnaá¹ƒ sacchikiriyÄya. dvepabbajitavatthu 376. 376. "puna caparaá¹ƒ, mahÄli, bhikkhu ÄsavÄnaá¹ƒ khayÄ anÄsavaá¹ƒ cetovimuttiá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±Ävimuttiá¹ƒ diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ upasampajja viharati. ayampi kho, mahÄli, dhammo uttaritaro ca paá¹‡Ä«tataro ca, yassa sacchikiriyÄhetu bhikkhÅ« mayi brahmacariyaá¹ƒ caranti. ime kho te, mahÄli, dhammÄ uttaritarÄ ca paá¹‡Ä«tatarÄ ca, yesaá¹ƒ sacchikiriyÄhetu bhikkhÅ« mayi brahmacariyaá¹ƒ carantÄ«"ti. ariyaaá¹­á¹­haá¹…gikamaggo 374. 378. 7. jÄliyasuttaá¹ƒ dvepabbajitavatthu 378. evaá¹ƒ me sutaá¹ƒ â€“ ekaá¹ƒ samayaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ kosambiyaá¹ƒ viharati ghositÄrÄme. tena kho pana samayena dve pabbajitÄ â€“ muá¹‡á¸iyo ca paribbÄjako jÄliyo ca dÄrupattikantevÄsÄ« yena bhagavÄ tenupasaá¹…kamiá¹ƒsu, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ bhagavatÄ saddhiá¹ƒ sammodiá¹ƒsu. sammodanÄ«yaá¹ƒ kathaá¹ƒ sÄraá¹‡Ä«yaá¹ƒ vÄ«tisÄretvÄ ekamantaá¹ƒ aá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒsu. ekamantaá¹ƒ á¹­hitÄ kho te dve pabbajitÄ bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavocuá¹ƒ â€“ "kiá¹ƒ nu kho, Ävuso gotama, taá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ sarÄ«raá¹ƒ, udÄhu aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ sarÄ«ra"nti? 379. "evamÄvuso"ti kho te dve pabbajitÄ bhagavato paccassosuá¹ƒ. bhagavÄ etadavoca â€“ "idhÄvuso, tathÄgato loke uppajjati arahaá¹ƒ, sammÄsambuddhoâ€¦peâ€¦ (yathÄ 190-212 anucchedesu evaá¹ƒ vitthÄretabbaá¹ƒ). evaá¹ƒ kho, Ävuso, bhikkhu sÄ«lasampanno hotiâ€¦peâ€¦ paá¹­hamaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒ upasampajja viharati. yo kho, Ävuso, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ jÄnÄti evaá¹ƒ passati, kallaá¹ƒ nu kho tassetaá¹ƒ vacanÄya â€“ â€˜taá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄ â€˜aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄti. yo so, Ävuso, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ jÄnÄti evaá¹ƒ passati, kallaá¹ƒ tassetaá¹ƒ vacanÄya â€“ â€˜taá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄ â€˜aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄti. ahaá¹ƒ kho panetaá¹ƒ, Ävuso, evaá¹ƒ jÄnÄmi evaá¹ƒ passÄmi. atha ca panÄhaá¹ƒ na vadÄmi â€“ â€˜taá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄ â€˜aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄâ€¦peâ€¦ dutiyaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒâ€¦peâ€¦ tatiyaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒâ€¦peâ€¦ catutthaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒ upasampajja viharati. yo kho, Ävuso, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ jÄnÄti evaá¹ƒ passati, kallaá¹ƒ nu kho tassetaá¹ƒ vacanÄya â€“ â€˜taá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄ â€˜aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄti? yo so, Ävuso, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ jÄnÄti evaá¹ƒ passati kallaá¹ƒ, tassetaá¹ƒ vacanÄya â€“ â€˜taá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄ â€˜aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄti. ahaá¹ƒ kho panetaá¹ƒ, Ävuso, evaá¹ƒ jÄnÄmi evaá¹ƒ passÄmi. atha ca panÄhaá¹ƒ na vadÄmi â€“ â€˜taá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄ â€˜aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄâ€¦peâ€¦ Ã±Äá¹‡adassanÄya
Thus have I heard. On one occasion the Blessed One was dwelling at Kosambi in Ghositaâ€™s Park. Then, at that time, two wanderers, Muá¹‡á¸iya and the wanderer JÄliya, the student of the wooden bowl ascetic, approached the Blessed One. Having approached, they exchanged courteous greetings with the Blessed One. Having exchanged courteous and amiable greetings, they stood to one side. Standing to one side, those two wanderers said this to the Blessed One: â€œFriend Gotama, is the soul the same as the body, or is the soul one thing and the body another?â€
379. 7. jÄliyasuttaá¹ƒ dvepabbajitavatthu 378. evaá¹ƒ me sutaá¹ƒ â€“ ekaá¹ƒ samayaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ kosambiyaá¹ƒ viharati ghositÄrÄme. tena kho pana samayena dve pabbajitÄ â€“ muá¹‡á¸iyo ca paribbÄjako jÄliyo ca dÄrupattikantevÄsÄ« yena bhagavÄ tenupasaá¹…kamiá¹ƒsu, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ bhagavatÄ saddhiá¹ƒ sammodiá¹ƒsu. sammodanÄ«yaá¹ƒ kathaá¹ƒ sÄraá¹‡Ä«yaá¹ƒ vÄ«tisÄretvÄ ekamantaá¹ƒ aá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒsu. ekamantaá¹ƒ á¹­hitÄ kho te dve pabbajitÄ bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavocuá¹ƒ â€“ "kiá¹ƒ nu kho, Ävuso gotama, taá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ sarÄ«raá¹ƒ, udÄhu aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ sarÄ«ra"nti? 379. "tena hÄvuso, suá¹‡Ätha sÄdhukaá¹ƒ manasi karotha, bhÄsissÄmÄ«"ti. "evamÄvuso"ti kho te dve pabbajitÄ bhagavato paccassosuá¹ƒ. bhagavÄ etadavoca â€“ "idhÄvuso, tathÄgato loke uppajjati arahaá¹ƒ, sammÄsambuddhoâ€¦peâ€¦ (yathÄ 190-212 anucchedesu evaá¹ƒ vitthÄretabbaá¹ƒ). evaá¹ƒ kho, Ävuso, bhikkhu sÄ«lasampanno hotiâ€¦peâ€¦ paá¹­hamaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒ upasampajja viharati. yo kho, Ävuso, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ jÄnÄti evaá¹ƒ passati, kallaá¹ƒ nu kho tassetaá¹ƒ vacanÄya â€“ â€˜taá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄ â€˜aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄti. yo so, Ävuso, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ jÄnÄti evaá¹ƒ passati, kallaá¹ƒ tassetaá¹ƒ vacanÄya â€“ â€˜taá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄ â€˜aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄti. ahaá¹ƒ kho panetaá¹ƒ, Ävuso, evaá¹ƒ jÄnÄmi evaá¹ƒ passÄmi. atha ca panÄhaá¹ƒ na vadÄmi â€“ â€˜taá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄ â€˜aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄâ€¦peâ€¦ dutiyaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒâ€¦peâ€¦ tatiyaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒâ€¦peâ€¦ catutthaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒ upasampajja viharati. yo kho, Ävuso, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ jÄnÄti evaá¹ƒ passati, kallaá¹ƒ nu kho tassetaá¹ƒ vacanÄya â€“ â€˜taá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄ â€˜aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄti? yo so, Ävuso, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ jÄnÄti evaá¹ƒ passati kallaá¹ƒ, tassetaá¹ƒ vacanÄya â€“ â€˜taá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄ â€˜aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄti. ahaá¹ƒ kho panetaá¹ƒ, Ävuso, evaá¹ƒ jÄnÄmi evaá¹ƒ passÄmi. atha ca panÄhaá¹ƒ na vadÄmi â€“ â€˜taá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄ â€˜aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄâ€¦peâ€¦ Ã±Äá¹‡adassanÄya
â€œThen listen, friends, pay close attention, I will speak.â€ â€œYes, friend,â€ those two wanderers replied to the Blessed One. The Blessed One said this: â€œHere, friend, a *TathÄgata* arises in the world, an *Arhat*, a fully enlightened *SammÄsambuddha*â€¦peâ€¦ (as it should be expanded according to sections 190-212). Thus, friend, a monk is accomplished in virtueâ€¦peâ€¦he attains and remains in the first *jhÄna*. That monk who thus knows and thus sees, is it proper for him to say: â€˜The soul is the same as the body,â€™ or â€˜The soul is one thing and the body another?â€™ That monk who thus knows and thus sees, it is fitting for him to say: â€˜The soul is the same as the body,â€™ or â€˜The soul is one thing and the body another.â€™ But I, friend, know and see thus. And yet, I do not say: â€˜The soul is the same as the body,â€™ or â€˜The soul is one thing and the body anotherâ€™â€¦peâ€¦ he attains and remains in the second *jhÄna*â€¦peâ€¦ the third *jhÄna*â€¦peâ€¦ the fourth *jhÄna*. That monk who thus knows and thus sees, is it proper for him to say: â€˜The soul is the same as the body,â€™ or â€˜The soul is one thing and the body another?â€™ That monk who thus knows and thus sees, it is fitting for him to say: â€˜The soul is the same as the body,â€™ or â€˜The soul is one thing and the body another.â€™ But I, friend, know and see thus. And yet, I do not say: â€˜The soul is the same as the body,â€™ or â€˜The soul is one thing and the body anotherâ€™â€¦peâ€¦ for the knowledge and vision, the mind is directed and inclinedâ€¦peâ€¦ That monk who thus knows and thus sees, is it proper for him to say: â€˜The soul is the same as the body,â€™ or â€˜The soul is one thing and the body another?â€™ That monk who thus knows and thus sees, it is fitting for him to say: â€˜The soul is the same as the body,â€™ or â€˜The soul is one thing and the body another.â€™ But I, friend, know and see thus. And yet, I do not say: â€˜The soul is the same as the body,â€™ or â€˜The soul is one thing and the body anotherâ€™â€¦peâ€¦.
380. cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmetiâ€¦peâ€¦ yo kho, Ävuso, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ jÄnÄti evaá¹ƒ passati, kallaá¹ƒ nu kho tassetaá¹ƒ vacanÄya â€“ â€˜taá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄ â€˜aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄti. yo so, Ävuso, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ jÄnÄti evaá¹ƒ passati kallaá¹ƒ tassetaá¹ƒ vacanÄya â€“ â€˜taá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄ â€˜aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄti. ahaá¹ƒ kho panetaá¹ƒ, Ävuso, evaá¹ƒ jÄnÄmi evaá¹ƒ passÄmi. atha ca panÄhaá¹ƒ na vadÄmi â€“ â€˜taá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄ â€˜aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄâ€¦peâ€¦. 380. â€¦peâ€¦ nÄparaá¹ƒ itthattÄyÄti pajÄnÄti. yo kho, Ävuso, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ jÄnÄti evaá¹ƒ passati, kallaá¹ƒ nu kho tassetaá¹ƒ vacanÄya â€“ â€˜taá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄ â€˜aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄti? yo so, Ävuso, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ jÄnÄti evaá¹ƒ passati, na kallaá¹ƒ tassetaá¹ƒ vacanÄya â€“ â€˜taá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄ â€˜aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄti. ahaá¹ƒ kho panetaá¹ƒ, Ävuso, evaá¹ƒ jÄnÄmi evaá¹ƒ passÄmi. atha ca panÄhaá¹ƒ na vadÄmi â€“ â€˜taá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄ â€˜aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄ"ti. idamavoca bhagavÄ. attamanÄ te dve pabbajitÄ bhagavato bhÄsitaá¹ƒ abhinandunti. jÄliyasuttaá¹ƒ niá¹­á¹­hitaá¹ƒ sattamaá¹ƒ.
â€¦peâ€¦ He understands: â€˜There is nothing further here.â€™ That monk who thus knows and thus sees, is it proper for him to say: â€˜The soul is the same as the body,â€™ or â€˜The soul is one thing and the body another?â€™ That monk who thus knows and thus sees, it is not fitting for him to say: â€˜The soul is the same as the body,â€™ or â€˜The soul is one thing and the body another.â€™ But I, friend, know and see thus. And yet, I do not say: â€˜The soul is the same as the body,â€™ or â€˜The soul is one thing and the body another.â€™â€ This is what the Blessed One said. Satisfied, those two wanderers rejoiced in the Blessed Oneâ€™s words. The JÄliya Discourse, the seventh, is concluded.
381. 8. mahÄsÄ«hanÄdasuttaá¹ƒ acelakassapavatthu 381. evaá¹ƒ me sutaá¹ƒ â€“ ekaá¹ƒ samayaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ uruÃ±Ã±Äyaá¹ƒ [ujuÃ±Ã±Äyaá¹ƒ (sÄ«. syÄ. kaá¹ƒ. pÄ«.)] viharati kaá¹‡á¹‡akatthale migadÄye. atha kho acelo kassapo yena bhagavÄ tenupasaá¹…kami, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ bhagavatÄ saddhiá¹ƒ sammodi. sammodanÄ«yaá¹ƒ kathaá¹ƒ sÄraá¹‡Ä«yaá¹ƒ vÄ«tisÄretvÄ ekamantaá¹ƒ aá¹­á¹­hÄsi. ekamantaá¹ƒ á¹­hito kho acelo kassapo bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "sutaá¹ƒ metaá¹ƒ, bho gotama â€“ â€˜samaá¹‡o gotamo sabbaá¹ƒ tapaá¹ƒ garahati, sabbaá¹ƒ tapassiá¹ƒ lÅ«khÄjÄ«viá¹ƒ ekaá¹ƒsena upakkosati upavadatÄ«â€™ti. ye te, bho gotama, evamÄhaá¹ƒsu â€“ â€˜samaá¹‡o gotamo sabbaá¹ƒ tapaá¹ƒ garahati, sabbaá¹ƒ tapassiá¹ƒ lÅ«khÄjÄ«viá¹ƒ ekaá¹ƒsena upakkosati upavadatÄ«â€™ti, kacci te bhoto gotamassa vuttavÄdino, na ca bhavantaá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ abhÅ«tena abbhÄcikkhanti, dhammassa cÄnudhammaá¹ƒ byÄkaronti, na ca koci sahadhammiko vÄdÄnuvÄdo gÄrayhaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ Ägacchati? anabbhakkhÄtukÄmÄ hi mayaá¹ƒ bhavantaá¹ƒ gotama"nti. 382. "ye te, kassapa, evamÄhaá¹ƒsu â€“ â€˜samaá¹‡o gotamo sabbaá¹ƒ tapaá¹ƒ garahati, sabbaá¹ƒ tapassiá¹ƒ lÅ«khÄjÄ«viá¹ƒ ekaá¹ƒsena upakkosati upavadatÄ«â€™ti, na me te vuttavÄdino, abbhÄcikkhanti ca pana maá¹ƒ te asatÄ abhÅ«tena. idhÄhaá¹ƒ, kassapa, ekaccaá¹ƒ tapassiá¹ƒ lÅ«khÄjÄ«viá¹ƒ passÄmi dibbena cakkhunÄ visuddhena atikkantamÄnusakena kÄyassa bhedÄ paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä apÄyaá¹ƒ duggatiá¹ƒ vinipÄtaá¹ƒ nirayaá¹ƒ upapannaá¹ƒ. idha panÄhaá¹ƒ, kassapa, ekaccaá¹ƒ tapassiá¹ƒ lÅ«khÄjÄ«viá¹ƒ passÄmi dibbena cakkhunÄ visuddhena atikkantamÄnusakena kÄyassa bhedÄ paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä sugatiá¹ƒ saggaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ upapannaá¹ƒ. 383. "idhÄhaá¹ƒ, kassapa, ekaccaá¹ƒ tapassiá¹ƒ appadukkhavihÄriá¹ƒ passÄmi dibbena cakkhunÄ visuddhena atikkantamÄnusakena kÄyassa bhedÄ paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä apÄyaá¹ƒ duggatiá¹ƒ vinipÄtaá¹ƒ nirayaá¹ƒ upapannaá¹ƒ. idha panÄhaá¹ƒ, kassapa, ekaccaá¹ƒ tapassiá¹ƒ appadukkhavihÄriá¹ƒ passÄmi dibbena cakkhunÄ visuddhena atikkantamÄnusakena kÄyassa bhedÄ paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä sugatiá¹ƒ saggaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ upapannaá¹ƒ. yohaá¹ƒ, kassapa, imesaá¹ƒ tapassÄ«naá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ ÄgatiÃ±ca gatiÃ±ca cutiÃ±ca upapattiÃ±ca yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ
Thus have I heard. On one occasion the Blessed One was staying near UruÃ±Ã±Ä, in the Deer Park at Kaá¹‡á¹‡akatthala. Then the naked ascetic Kassapa approached the Blessed One, exchanged greetings with him. After an exchange of friendly greetings & courtesies, he stood to one side. Standing to one side, the naked ascetic Kassapa said this to the Blessed One: â€œI have heard it said, venerable Gotama: â€˜The ascetic Gotama disapproves of all austerity (tapa), and censures and blames all those ascetics who lead a harsh life (lÅ«khÄjÄ«vi).â€™â€ â€œThose who say this, venerable Gotama: â€˜The ascetic Gotama disapproves of all austerity (tapa), and censures and blames all those ascetics who lead a harsh life (lÅ«khÄjÄ«vi),â€™ do they speak according to the Blessed Gotamaâ€™s words? Do they not accuse the Blessed Gotama falsely? Do they explain the Dhamma in accordance with the Dhamma? Is there any co-religionist who might deserve to be blamed for this statement? For we do not wish to misrepresent the Blessed Gotama.â€
382. 8. mahÄsÄ«hanÄdasuttaá¹ƒ acelakassapavatthu 381. evaá¹ƒ me sutaá¹ƒ â€“ ekaá¹ƒ samayaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ uruÃ±Ã±Äyaá¹ƒ [ujuÃ±Ã±Äyaá¹ƒ (sÄ«. syÄ. kaá¹ƒ. pÄ«.)] viharati kaá¹‡á¹‡akatthale migadÄye. atha kho acelo kassapo yena bhagavÄ tenupasaá¹…kami, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ bhagavatÄ saddhiá¹ƒ sammodi. sammodanÄ«yaá¹ƒ kathaá¹ƒ sÄraá¹‡Ä«yaá¹ƒ vÄ«tisÄretvÄ ekamantaá¹ƒ aá¹­á¹­hÄsi. ekamantaá¹ƒ á¹­hito kho acelo kassapo bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "sutaá¹ƒ metaá¹ƒ, bho gotama â€“ â€˜samaá¹‡o gotamo sabbaá¹ƒ tapaá¹ƒ garahati, sabbaá¹ƒ tapassiá¹ƒ lÅ«khÄjÄ«viá¹ƒ ekaá¹ƒsena upakkosati upavadatÄ«â€™ti. ye te, bho gotama, evamÄhaá¹ƒsu â€“ â€˜samaá¹‡o gotamo sabbaá¹ƒ tapaá¹ƒ garahati, sabbaá¹ƒ tapassiá¹ƒ lÅ«khÄjÄ«viá¹ƒ ekaá¹ƒsena upakkosati upavadatÄ«â€™ti, kacci te bhoto gotamassa vuttavÄdino, na ca bhavantaá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ abhÅ«tena abbhÄcikkhanti, dhammassa cÄnudhammaá¹ƒ byÄkaronti, na ca koci sahadhammiko vÄdÄnuvÄdo gÄrayhaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ Ägacchati? anabbhakkhÄtukÄmÄ hi mayaá¹ƒ bhavantaá¹ƒ gotama"nti. 382. "ye te, kassapa, evamÄhaá¹ƒsu â€“ â€˜samaá¹‡o gotamo sabbaá¹ƒ tapaá¹ƒ garahati, sabbaá¹ƒ tapassiá¹ƒ lÅ«khÄjÄ«viá¹ƒ ekaá¹ƒsena upakkosati upavadatÄ«â€™ti, na me te vuttavÄdino, abbhÄcikkhanti ca pana maá¹ƒ te asatÄ abhÅ«tena. idhÄhaá¹ƒ, kassapa, ekaccaá¹ƒ tapassiá¹ƒ lÅ«khÄjÄ«viá¹ƒ passÄmi dibbena cakkhunÄ visuddhena atikkantamÄnusakena kÄyassa bhedÄ paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä apÄyaá¹ƒ duggatiá¹ƒ vinipÄtaá¹ƒ nirayaá¹ƒ upapannaá¹ƒ. idha panÄhaá¹ƒ, kassapa, ekaccaá¹ƒ tapassiá¹ƒ lÅ«khÄjÄ«viá¹ƒ passÄmi dibbena cakkhunÄ visuddhena atikkantamÄnusakena kÄyassa bhedÄ paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä sugatiá¹ƒ saggaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ upapannaá¹ƒ. 383. "idhÄhaá¹ƒ, kassapa, ekaccaá¹ƒ tapassiá¹ƒ appadukkhavihÄriá¹ƒ passÄmi dibbena cakkhunÄ visuddhena atikkantamÄnusakena kÄyassa bhedÄ paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä apÄyaá¹ƒ duggatiá¹ƒ vinipÄtaá¹ƒ nirayaá¹ƒ upapannaá¹ƒ. idha panÄhaá¹ƒ, kassapa, ekaccaá¹ƒ tapassiá¹ƒ appadukkhavihÄriá¹ƒ passÄmi dibbena cakkhunÄ visuddhena atikkantamÄnusakena kÄyassa bhedÄ paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä sugatiá¹ƒ saggaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ upapannaá¹ƒ. yohaá¹ƒ, kassapa, imesaá¹ƒ tapassÄ«naá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ ÄgatiÃ±ca gatiÃ±ca cutiÃ±ca upapattiÃ±ca yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ
â€œKassapa, those who say this: â€˜The ascetic Gotama disapproves of all austerity (tapa), and censures and blames all those ascetics who lead a harsh life (lÅ«khÄjÄ«vi),â€™ do not speak according to my words; they accuse me falsely, untruthfully. Here, Kassapa, I see one ascetic (tapassiá¹ƒ) who leads a harsh life (lÅ«khÄjÄ«viá¹ƒ), and with the divine eye (dibbena cakkhunÄ), which is purified beyond the human, I see that on the dissolution of the body, after death, he has reappeared in a state of deprivation (apÄyaá¹ƒ), in an unhappy destination (duggatiá¹ƒ), in perdition (vinipÄtaá¹ƒ), in hell (nirayaá¹ƒ). Again, Kassapa, I see one ascetic (tapassiá¹ƒ) who leads a harsh life (lÅ«khÄjÄ«viá¹ƒ), and with the divine eye (dibbena cakkhunÄ), which is purified beyond the human, I see that on the dissolution of the body, after death, he has reappeared in a good destination (sugatiá¹ƒ), in the heavenly world (saggaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ).
383. 8. mahÄsÄ«hanÄdasuttaá¹ƒ acelakassapavatthu 381. evaá¹ƒ me sutaá¹ƒ â€“ ekaá¹ƒ samayaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ uruÃ±Ã±Äyaá¹ƒ [ujuÃ±Ã±Äyaá¹ƒ (sÄ«. syÄ. kaá¹ƒ. pÄ«.)] viharati kaá¹‡á¹‡akatthale migadÄye. atha kho acelo kassapo yena bhagavÄ tenupasaá¹…kami, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ bhagavatÄ saddhiá¹ƒ sammodi. sammodanÄ«yaá¹ƒ kathaá¹ƒ sÄraá¹‡Ä«yaá¹ƒ vÄ«tisÄretvÄ ekamantaá¹ƒ aá¹­á¹­hÄsi. ekamantaá¹ƒ á¹­hito kho acelo kassapo bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "sutaá¹ƒ metaá¹ƒ, bho gotama â€“ â€˜samaá¹‡o gotamo sabbaá¹ƒ tapaá¹ƒ garahati, sabbaá¹ƒ tapassiá¹ƒ lÅ«khÄjÄ«viá¹ƒ ekaá¹ƒsena upakkosati upavadatÄ«â€™ti. ye te, bho gotama, evamÄhaá¹ƒsu â€“ â€˜samaá¹‡o gotamo sabbaá¹ƒ tapaá¹ƒ garahati, sabbaá¹ƒ tapassiá¹ƒ lÅ«khÄjÄ«viá¹ƒ ekaá¹ƒsena upakkosati upavadatÄ«â€™ti, kacci te bhoto gotamassa vuttavÄdino, na ca bhavantaá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ abhÅ«tena abbhÄcikkhanti, dhammassa cÄnudhammaá¹ƒ byÄkaronti, na ca koci sahadhammiko vÄdÄnuvÄdo gÄrayhaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ Ägacchati? anabbhakkhÄtukÄmÄ hi mayaá¹ƒ bhavantaá¹ƒ gotama"nti. 382. "ye te, kassapa, evamÄhaá¹ƒsu â€“ â€˜samaá¹‡o gotamo sabbaá¹ƒ tapaá¹ƒ garahati, sabbaá¹ƒ tapassiá¹ƒ lÅ«khÄjÄ«viá¹ƒ ekaá¹ƒsena upakkosati upavadatÄ«â€™ti, na me te vuttavÄdino, abbhÄcikkhanti ca pana maá¹ƒ te asatÄ abhÅ«tena. idhÄhaá¹ƒ, kassapa, ekaccaá¹ƒ tapassiá¹ƒ lÅ«khÄjÄ«viá¹ƒ passÄmi dibbena cakkhunÄ visuddhena atikkantamÄnusakena kÄyassa bhedÄ paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä apÄyaá¹ƒ duggatiá¹ƒ vinipÄtaá¹ƒ nirayaá¹ƒ upapannaá¹ƒ. idha panÄhaá¹ƒ, kassapa, ekaccaá¹ƒ tapassiá¹ƒ lÅ«khÄjÄ«viá¹ƒ passÄmi dibbena cakkhunÄ visuddhena atikkantamÄnusakena kÄyassa bhedÄ paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä sugatiá¹ƒ saggaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ upapannaá¹ƒ. 383. "idhÄhaá¹ƒ, kassapa, ekaccaá¹ƒ tapassiá¹ƒ appadukkhavihÄriá¹ƒ passÄmi dibbena cakkhunÄ visuddhena atikkantamÄnusakena kÄyassa bhedÄ paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä apÄyaá¹ƒ duggatiá¹ƒ vinipÄtaá¹ƒ nirayaá¹ƒ upapannaá¹ƒ. idha panÄhaá¹ƒ, kassapa, ekaccaá¹ƒ tapassiá¹ƒ appadukkhavihÄriá¹ƒ passÄmi dibbena cakkhunÄ visuddhena atikkantamÄnusakena kÄyassa bhedÄ paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä sugatiá¹ƒ saggaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ upapannaá¹ƒ. yohaá¹ƒ, kassapa, imesaá¹ƒ tapassÄ«naá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ ÄgatiÃ±ca gatiÃ±ca cutiÃ±ca upapattiÃ±ca yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ
â€œHere, Kassapa, I see one ascetic (tapassiá¹ƒ) who lives with little suffering (appadukkhavihÄriá¹ƒ), and with the divine eye (dibbena cakkhunÄ) which is purified beyond the human, I see that on the dissolution of the body, after death, he has reappeared in a state of deprivation (apÄyaá¹ƒ), in an unhappy destination (duggatiá¹ƒ), in perdition (vinipÄtaá¹ƒ), in hell (nirayaá¹ƒ). Again, Kassapa, I see one ascetic (tapassiá¹ƒ) who lives with little suffering (appadukkhavihÄriá¹ƒ), and with the divine eye (dibbena cakkhunÄ) which is purified beyond the human, I see that on the dissolution of the body, after death, he has reappeared in a good destination (sugatiá¹ƒ), in the heavenly world (saggaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ). That I, Kassapa, for these ascetics (tapassÄ«naá¹ƒ), concerning their destination (ÄgatiÃ±ca), their destiny (gatiÃ±ca), their decease (cutiÃ±ca) and rebirth (upapattiÃ±ca), have knowledge as it actually is (yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ). Since I understand as it truly is the arising, the destiny, the death and re-arising of these ascetics, how could I disapprove of all austerities (tapa), and censure and blame all those ascetics who lead a harsh life (lÅ«khÄjÄ«vi) of self-mortification?
384. pajÄnÄmi, sohaá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ sabbaá¹ƒ tapaá¹ƒ garahissÄmi, sabbaá¹ƒ vÄ tapassiá¹ƒ lÅ«khÄjÄ«viá¹ƒ ekaá¹ƒsena upakkosissÄmi upavadissÄmi? 384. "santi, kassapa, eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä paá¹‡á¸itÄ nipuá¹‡Ä kataparappavÄdÄ vÄlavedhirÅ«pÄ. te bhindantÄ maÃ±Ã±e caranti paÃ±Ã±Ägatena diá¹­á¹­higatÄni. tehipi me saddhiá¹ƒ ekaccesu á¹­hÄnesu sameti, ekaccesu á¹­hÄnesu na sameti. yaá¹ƒ te ekaccaá¹ƒ vadanti â€˜sÄdhÅ«â€™ti, mayampi taá¹ƒ ekaccaá¹ƒ vadema â€˜sÄdhÅ«â€™ti. yaá¹ƒ te ekaccaá¹ƒ vadanti â€˜na sÄdhÅ«â€™ti, mayampi taá¹ƒ ekaccaá¹ƒ vadema â€˜na sÄdhÅ«â€™ti. yaá¹ƒ te ekaccaá¹ƒ vadanti â€˜sÄdhÅ«â€™ti, mayaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ ekaccaá¹ƒ vadema â€˜na sÄdhÅ«â€™ti. yaá¹ƒ te ekaccaá¹ƒ vadanti â€˜na sÄdhÅ«â€™ti, mayaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ ekaccaá¹ƒ vadema â€˜sÄdhÅ«â€™ti. "yaá¹ƒ mayaá¹ƒ ekaccaá¹ƒ vadema â€˜sÄdhÅ«â€™ti, parepi taá¹ƒ ekaccaá¹ƒ vadanti â€˜sÄdhÅ«â€™ti. yaá¹ƒ mayaá¹ƒ ekaccaá¹ƒ vadema â€˜na sÄdhÅ«â€™ti, parepi taá¹ƒ ekaccaá¹ƒ vadanti â€˜na sÄdhÅ«â€™ti. yaá¹ƒ mayaá¹ƒ ekaccaá¹ƒ vadema â€˜na sÄdhÅ«â€™ti, pare taá¹ƒ ekaccaá¹ƒ vadanti â€˜sÄdhÅ«â€™ti. yaá¹ƒ mayaá¹ƒ ekaccaá¹ƒ vadema â€˜sÄdhÅ«â€™ti, pare taá¹ƒ ekaccaá¹ƒ vadanti â€˜na sÄdhÅ«â€™ti. samanuyuÃ±jÄpanakathÄ 385. "tyÄhaá¹ƒ upasaá¹…kamitvÄ evaá¹ƒ vadÄmi â€“ yesu no, Ävuso, á¹­hÄnesu na sameti, tiá¹­á¹­hantu tÄni á¹­hÄnÄni. yesu á¹­hÄnesu sameti, tattha viÃ±Ã±Å« samanuyuÃ±jantaá¹ƒ samanugÄhantaá¹ƒ samanubhÄsantaá¹ƒ satthÄrÄ vÄ satthÄraá¹ƒ saá¹…ghena vÄ saá¹…ghaá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜ye imesaá¹ƒ bhavataá¹ƒ dhammÄ akusalÄ akusalasaá¹…khÄtÄ, sÄvajjÄ sÄvajjasaá¹…khÄtÄ, asevitabbÄ asevitabbasaá¹…khÄtÄ, na alamariyÄ na alamariyasaá¹…khÄtÄ, kaá¹‡hÄ kaá¹‡hasaá¹…khÄtÄ. ko ime dhamme anavasesaá¹ƒ pahÄya vattati, samaá¹‡o vÄ gotamo, pare vÄ pana bhonto gaá¹‡ÄcariyÄâ€™ti? 386. "á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ kho panetaá¹ƒ, kassapa, vijjati, yaá¹ƒ viÃ±Ã±Å« samanuyuÃ±jantÄ samanugÄhantÄ samanubhÄsantÄ evaá¹ƒ vadeyyuá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜ye imesaá¹ƒ bhavataá¹ƒ dhammÄ akusalÄ akusalasaá¹…khÄtÄ, sÄvajjÄ sÄvajjasaá¹…khÄtÄ, asevitabbÄ asevitabbasaá¹…khÄtÄ, na alamariyÄ na alamariyasaá¹…khÄtÄ, kaá¹‡hÄ kaá¹‡hasaá¹…khÄtÄ. samaá¹‡o gotamo ime dhamme anavasesaá¹ƒ pahÄya vattati, yaá¹ƒ vÄ pana bhonto pare gaá¹‡ÄcariyÄâ€™ti. itiha, kassapa,
â€œKassapa, there are some ascetics and Brahmins who are wise (paá¹‡á¸ita), skilled (nipuá¹‡a), practised in refuting the doctrines of others (kataparappavÄdÄ), splitters of hairs (vÄlavedhirÅ«pÄ). They wander about, as it were, demolishing the views (dÄ«á¹­á¹­higatÄni) of others with their wisdom (paÃ±Ã±Ägatena). Sometimes their views accord with mine, sometimes they do not. What they sometimes applaud, we also sometimes applaud. What they sometimes do not applaud, we also sometimes do not applaud. What they sometimes applaud, we sometimes do not applaud. What they sometimes do not applaud, we sometimes applaud. What we sometimes applaud, others also sometimes applaud. What we sometimes do not applaud, others also sometimes do not applaud. What we sometimes do not applaud, others sometimes applaud. What we sometimes applaud, others sometimes do not applaud. [This is] discussion conducive to questioning.
385. pajÄnÄmi, sohaá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ sabbaá¹ƒ tapaá¹ƒ garahissÄmi, sabbaá¹ƒ vÄ tapassiá¹ƒ lÅ«khÄjÄ«viá¹ƒ ekaá¹ƒsena upakkosissÄmi upavadissÄmi? 384. "santi, kassapa, eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä paá¹‡á¸itÄ nipuá¹‡Ä kataparappavÄdÄ vÄlavedhirÅ«pÄ. te bhindantÄ maÃ±Ã±e caranti paÃ±Ã±Ägatena diá¹­á¹­higatÄni. tehipi me saddhiá¹ƒ ekaccesu á¹­hÄnesu sameti, ekaccesu á¹­hÄnesu na sameti. yaá¹ƒ te ekaccaá¹ƒ vadanti â€˜sÄdhÅ«â€™ti, mayampi taá¹ƒ ekaccaá¹ƒ vadema â€˜sÄdhÅ«â€™ti. yaá¹ƒ te ekaccaá¹ƒ vadanti â€˜na sÄdhÅ«â€™ti, mayampi taá¹ƒ ekaccaá¹ƒ vadema â€˜na sÄdhÅ«â€™ti. yaá¹ƒ te ekaccaá¹ƒ vadanti â€˜sÄdhÅ«â€™ti, mayaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ ekaccaá¹ƒ vadema â€˜na sÄdhÅ«â€™ti. yaá¹ƒ te ekaccaá¹ƒ vadanti â€˜na sÄdhÅ«â€™ti, mayaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ ekaccaá¹ƒ vadema â€˜sÄdhÅ«â€™ti. "yaá¹ƒ mayaá¹ƒ ekaccaá¹ƒ vadema â€˜sÄdhÅ«â€™ti, parepi taá¹ƒ ekaccaá¹ƒ vadanti â€˜sÄdhÅ«â€™ti. yaá¹ƒ mayaá¹ƒ ekaccaá¹ƒ vadema â€˜na sÄdhÅ«â€™ti, parepi taá¹ƒ ekaccaá¹ƒ vadanti â€˜na sÄdhÅ«â€™ti. yaá¹ƒ mayaá¹ƒ ekaccaá¹ƒ vadema â€˜na sÄdhÅ«â€™ti, pare taá¹ƒ ekaccaá¹ƒ vadanti â€˜sÄdhÅ«â€™ti. yaá¹ƒ mayaá¹ƒ ekaccaá¹ƒ vadema â€˜sÄdhÅ«â€™ti, pare taá¹ƒ ekaccaá¹ƒ vadanti â€˜na sÄdhÅ«â€™ti. samanuyuÃ±jÄpanakathÄ 385. "tyÄhaá¹ƒ upasaá¹…kamitvÄ evaá¹ƒ vadÄmi â€“ yesu no, Ävuso, á¹­hÄnesu na sameti, tiá¹­á¹­hantu tÄni á¹­hÄnÄni. yesu á¹­hÄnesu sameti, tattha viÃ±Ã±Å« samanuyuÃ±jantaá¹ƒ samanugÄhantaá¹ƒ samanubhÄsantaá¹ƒ satthÄrÄ vÄ satthÄraá¹ƒ saá¹…ghena vÄ saá¹…ghaá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜ye imesaá¹ƒ bhavataá¹ƒ dhammÄ akusalÄ akusalasaá¹…khÄtÄ, sÄvajjÄ sÄvajjasaá¹…khÄtÄ, asevitabbÄ asevitabbasaá¹…khÄtÄ, na alamariyÄ na alamariyasaá¹…khÄtÄ, kaá¹‡hÄ kaá¹‡hasaá¹…khÄtÄ. ko ime dhamme anavasesaá¹ƒ pahÄya vattati, samaá¹‡o vÄ gotamo, pare vÄ pana bhonto gaá¹‡ÄcariyÄâ€™ti? 386. "á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ kho panetaá¹ƒ, kassapa, vijjati, yaá¹ƒ viÃ±Ã±Å« samanuyuÃ±jantÄ samanugÄhantÄ samanubhÄsantÄ evaá¹ƒ vadeyyuá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜ye imesaá¹ƒ bhavataá¹ƒ dhammÄ akusalÄ akusalasaá¹…khÄtÄ, sÄvajjÄ sÄvajjasaá¹…khÄtÄ, asevitabbÄ asevitabbasaá¹…khÄtÄ, na alamariyÄ na alamariyasaá¹…khÄtÄ, kaá¹‡hÄ kaá¹‡hasaá¹…khÄtÄ. samaá¹‡o gotamo ime dhamme anavasesaá¹ƒ pahÄya vattati, yaá¹ƒ vÄ pana bhonto pare gaá¹‡ÄcariyÄâ€™ti. itiha, kassapa,
â€œThen I approach them and say this: â€˜In those matters where there is no agreement between us, let those matters stand aside. In those matters where there is agreement, there let the wise take up, cross-question, and criticise these matters with the teachers (satthÄrÄ) or with their followers, saying: â€˜Those things of yours, reverends, which are unskilful (akusala), reckoned as unskilful (akusalasaá¹…khÄtÄ), blameworthy (sÄvajja), reckoned as blameworthy (sÄvajjasankhÄtÄ), not to be cultivated (asevitabbÄ), reckoned as not to be cultivated (asevitabbasaá¹…khÄtÄ), not befitting a Noble One (ariya), reckoned as not befitting a Noble One (na alamariyÄ na alamariyasaá¹…khÄtÄ), dark (kaá¹‡hÄ), reckoned as dark (kaá¹‡hasaá¹…khÄtÄ). Who is it that has completely abandoned these things, the ascetic Gotama, or some other venerable teachers (gaá¹‡ÄcariyÄ)?â€™
386. pajÄnÄmi, sohaá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ sabbaá¹ƒ tapaá¹ƒ garahissÄmi, sabbaá¹ƒ vÄ tapassiá¹ƒ lÅ«khÄjÄ«viá¹ƒ ekaá¹ƒsena upakkosissÄmi upavadissÄmi? 384. "santi, kassapa, eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä paá¹‡á¸itÄ nipuá¹‡Ä kataparappavÄdÄ vÄlavedhirÅ«pÄ. te bhindantÄ maÃ±Ã±e caranti paÃ±Ã±Ägatena diá¹­á¹­higatÄni. tehipi me saddhiá¹ƒ ekaccesu á¹­hÄnesu sameti, ekaccesu á¹­hÄnesu na sameti. yaá¹ƒ te ekaccaá¹ƒ vadanti â€˜sÄdhÅ«â€™ti, mayampi taá¹ƒ ekaccaá¹ƒ vadema â€˜sÄdhÅ«â€™ti. yaá¹ƒ te ekaccaá¹ƒ vadanti â€˜na sÄdhÅ«â€™ti, mayampi taá¹ƒ ekaccaá¹ƒ vadema â€˜na sÄdhÅ«â€™ti. yaá¹ƒ te ekaccaá¹ƒ vadanti â€˜sÄdhÅ«â€™ti, mayaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ ekaccaá¹ƒ vadema â€˜na sÄdhÅ«â€™ti. yaá¹ƒ te ekaccaá¹ƒ vadanti â€˜na sÄdhÅ«â€™ti, mayaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ ekaccaá¹ƒ vadema â€˜sÄdhÅ«â€™ti. "tyÄhaá¹ƒ upasaá¹…kamitvÄ evaá¹ƒ vadÄmi â€“ yesu no, Ävuso, á¹­hÄnesu na sameti, tiá¹­á¹­hantu tÄni á¹­hÄnÄni. yesu á¹­hÄnesu sameti, tattha viÃ±Ã±Å« samanuyuÃ±jantaá¹ƒ samanugÄhantaá¹ƒ samanubhÄsantaá¹ƒ satthÄrÄ vÄ satthÄraá¹ƒ saá¹…ghena vÄ saá¹…ghaá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜ye imesaá¹ƒ bhavataá¹ƒ dhammÄ akusalÄ akusalasaá¹…khÄtÄ, sÄvajjÄ sÄvajjasaá¹…khÄtÄ, asevitabbÄ asevitabbasaá¹…khÄtÄ, na alamariyÄ na alamariyasaá¹…khÄtÄ, kaá¹‡hÄ kaá¹‡hasaá¹…khÄtÄ. ko ime dhamme anavasesaá¹ƒ pahÄya vattati, samaá¹‡o vÄ gotamo, pare vÄ pana bhonto gaá¹‡ÄcariyÄâ€™ti? 386. â€œKassapa, it may be that the wise, cross-questioning and criticising, might say: â€˜Those things of yours, reverends, which are unskilful (akusala), reckoned as unskilful (akusalasaá¹…khÄtÄ), blameworthy (sÄvajja), reckoned as blameworthy (sÄvajjasankhÄtÄ), not to be cultivated (asevitabbÄ), reckoned as not to be cultivated (asevitabbasaá¹…khÄtÄ), not befitting a Noble One (ariya), reckoned as not befitting a Noble One (na alamariyÄ na alamariyasaá¹…khÄtÄ), dark (kaá¹‡hÄ), reckoned as dark (kaá¹‡hasaá¹…khÄtÄ). The ascetic Gotama has completely abandoned these things, or some other venerable teachers (gaá¹‡ÄcariyÄ).â€™ Thus it is, Kassapa. â€˜In this case, the wise, cross-questioning, investigating, and discussing, would give us the greatest share of praise.

"Furthermore, Kassapa, the wise, cross-questioning, investigating, and discussing, might say of the teacher or the Saá¹…gha: â€˜Of those things that are skilled (kusala) and reckoned as such, blameless (anavajja), and reckoned as such, to be practised (sevitabba) and reckoned as such, fitting for a Noble One (alamariya) and reckoned as such, bright (sukka) and reckoned as such.â€™ Who is there who has completely mastered these thingsâ€”the ascetic Gotama (Gautama), or some other venerable teachers (gaá¹‡ÄcariyÄ)?"
