"á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ kho panetaá¹ƒ, kassapa, vijjati, yaá¹ƒ viÃ±Ã±Å« samanuyuÃ±jantÄ samanugÄhantÄ samanubhÄsantÄ evaá¹ƒ vadeyyuá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜ye imesaá¹ƒ bhavataá¹ƒ dhammÄ kusalÄ kusalasaá¹…khÄtÄ, anavajjÄ anavajjasaá¹…khÄtÄ, sevitabbÄ sevitabbasaá¹…khÄtÄ, alamariyÄ alamariyasaá¹…khÄtÄ, sukkÄ sukkasaá¹…khÄtÄ. gotamasÄvakasaá¹…gho ime dhamme anavasesaá¹ƒ samÄdÄya vattati, yaá¹ƒ vÄ pana bhonto pare gaá¹‡ÄcariyasÄvakasaá¹…ghÄâ€™ti. itiha, kassapa, viÃ±Ã±Å« samanuyuÃ±jantÄ samanugÄhantÄ samanubhÄsantÄ amheva tattha yebhuyyena pasaá¹ƒseyyuá¹ƒ. ariyo aá¹­á¹­haá¹…giko maggo 393. "atthi, kassapa, maggo atthi paá¹­ipadÄ, yathÄpaá¹­ipanno sÄmaá¹ƒyeva Ã±assati sÄmaá¹ƒ dakkhati [dakkhiti (sÄ«.)] â€“ â€˜samaá¹‡ova gotamo kÄlavÄdÄ« bhÅ«tavÄdÄ« atthavÄdÄ« dhammavÄdÄ« vinayavÄdÄ«â€™ti. katamo ca, kassapa, maggo, katamÄ ca paá¹­ipadÄ, yathÄpaá¹­ipanno sÄmaá¹ƒyeva Ã±assati sÄmaá¹ƒ dakkhati â€“ â€˜samaá¹‡ova gotamo kÄlavÄdÄ« bhÅ«tavÄdÄ« atthavÄdÄ« dhammavÄdÄ« vinayavÄdÄ«â€™ti? ayameva ariyo aá¹­á¹­haá¹…giko maggo. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ sammÄdiá¹­á¹­hi sammÄsaá¹…kappo sammÄvÄcÄ sammÄkammanto sammÄÄjÄ«vo sammÄvÄyÄmo sammÄsati sammÄsamÄdhi. ayaá¹ƒ kho, kassapa, maggo, ayaá¹ƒ paá¹­ipadÄ, yathÄpaá¹­ipanno sÄmaá¹ƒyeva Ã±assati sÄmaá¹ƒ dakkhati â€˜samaá¹‡ova gotamo kÄlavÄdÄ« bhÅ«tavÄdÄ« atthavÄdÄ« dhammavÄdÄ« vinayavÄdÄ«"â€™ti.
"Furthermore, Kassapa, the wise, cross-questioning, investigating, and discussing, might say of the teacher or the Saá¹…gha: â€˜Of those things that are skilled and reckoned as such, blameless and reckoned as such, to be practiced and reckoned as such, fitting for a Noble One and reckoned as such, bright and reckoned as such, Who is there who has completely mastered these thingsâ€”the community of Gotamaâ€™s disciples, or some other venerable teachers and their disciples?â€™
392. 391. "aparampi no, kassapa, viÃ±Ã±Å« samanuyuÃ±jantaá¹ƒ samanugÄhantaá¹ƒ samanubhÄsantaá¹ƒ satthÄrÄ vÄ satthÄraá¹ƒ saá¹…ghena vÄ saá¹…ghaá¹ƒ. â€˜ye imesaá¹ƒ bhavataá¹ƒ dhammÄ kusalÄ kusalasaá¹…khÄtÄ, anavajjÄ anavajjasaá¹…khÄtÄ, sevitabbÄ sevitabbasaá¹…khÄtÄ, alamariyÄ alamariyasaá¹…khÄtÄ, sukkÄ sukkasaá¹…khÄtÄ. ko ime dhamme anavasesaá¹ƒ samÄdÄya vattati, gotamasÄvakasaá¹…gho vÄ, pare vÄ pana bhonto gaá¹‡ÄcariyasÄvakasaá¹…ghÄâ€™ti. 392. "á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ kho panetaá¹ƒ, kassapa, vijjati, yaá¹ƒ viÃ±Ã±Å« samanuyuÃ±jantÄ samanugÄhantÄ samanubhÄsantÄ evaá¹ƒ vadeyyuá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜ye imesaá¹ƒ bhavataá¹ƒ dhammÄ kusalÄ kusalasaá¹…khÄtÄ, anavajjÄ anavajjasaá¹…khÄtÄ, sevitabbÄ sevitabbasaá¹…khÄtÄ, alamariyÄ alamariyasaá¹…khÄtÄ, sukkÄ sukkasaá¹…khÄtÄ. gotamasÄvakasaá¹…gho ime dhamme anavasesaá¹ƒ samÄdÄya vattati, yaá¹ƒ vÄ pana bhonto pare gaá¹‡ÄcariyasÄvakasaá¹…ghÄâ€™ti. itiha, kassapa, viÃ±Ã±Å« samanuyuÃ±jantÄ samanugÄhantÄ samanubhÄsantÄ amheva tattha yebhuyyena pasaá¹ƒseyyuá¹ƒ. ariyo aá¹­á¹­haá¹…giko maggo 393. "atthi, kassapa, maggo atthi paá¹­ipadÄ, yathÄpaá¹­ipanno sÄmaá¹ƒyeva Ã±assati sÄmaá¹ƒ dakkhati [dakkhiti (sÄ«.)] â€“ â€˜samaá¹‡ova gotamo kÄlavÄdÄ« bhÅ«tavÄdÄ« atthavÄdÄ« dhammavÄdÄ« vinayavÄdÄ«â€™ti. katamo ca, kassapa, maggo, katamÄ ca paá¹­ipadÄ, yathÄpaá¹­ipanno sÄmaá¹ƒyeva Ã±assati sÄmaá¹ƒ dakkhati â€“ â€˜samaá¹‡ova gotamo kÄlavÄdÄ« bhÅ«tavÄdÄ« atthavÄdÄ« dhammavÄdÄ« vinayavÄdÄ«â€™ti? ayameva ariyo aá¹­á¹­haá¹…giko maggo. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ sammÄdiá¹­á¹­hi sammÄsaá¹…kappo sammÄvÄcÄ sammÄkammanto sammÄÄjÄ«vo sammÄvÄyÄmo sammÄsati sammÄsamÄdhi. ayaá¹ƒ kho, kassapa, maggo, ayaá¹ƒ paá¹­ipadÄ, yathÄpaá¹­ipanno sÄmaá¹ƒyeva Ã±assati sÄmaá¹ƒ dakkhati â€˜samaá¹‡ova gotamo kÄlavÄdÄ« bhÅ«tavÄdÄ« atthavÄdÄ« dhammavÄdÄ« vinayavÄdÄ«"â€™ti.
"It is possible, Kassapa, that the wise, cross-questioning, investigating, and discussing, might say this: â€˜Of these things that are skilled and reckoned as such, blameless and reckoned as such, to be practiced and reckoned as such, fitting for a Noble One and reckoned as such, bright and reckoned as such, the community of Gotamaâ€™s disciples has completely mastered these things, but the other venerable teachers and their disciples only in part.â€™ In this case, Kassapa, the wise, cross-questioning, investigating, and discussing, would give us the greatest share of praise. The Noble Eightfold Path (ariyo aá¹­á¹­haá¹…giko maggo)
393. 391. "aparampi no, kassapa, viÃ±Ã±Å« samanuyuÃ±jantaá¹ƒ samanugÄhantaá¹ƒ samanubhÄsantaá¹ƒ satthÄrÄ vÄ satthÄraá¹ƒ saá¹…ghena vÄ saá¹…ghaá¹ƒ. â€˜ye imesaá¹ƒ bhavataá¹ƒ dhammÄ kusalÄ kusalasaá¹…khÄtÄ, anavajjÄ anavajjasaá¹…khÄtÄ, sevitabbÄ sevitabbasaá¹…khÄtÄ, alamariyÄ alamariyasaá¹…khÄtÄ, sukkÄ sukkasaá¹…khÄtÄ. ko ime dhamme anavasesaá¹ƒ samÄdÄya vattati, gotamasÄvakasaá¹…gho vÄ, pare vÄ pana bhonto gaá¹‡ÄcariyasÄvakasaá¹…ghÄâ€™ti. 392. "á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ kho panetaá¹ƒ, kassapa, vijjati, yaá¹ƒ viÃ±Ã±Å« samanuyuÃ±jantÄ samanugÄhantÄ samanubhÄsantÄ evaá¹ƒ vadeyyuá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜ye imesaá¹ƒ bhavataá¹ƒ dhammÄ kusalÄ kusalasaá¹…khÄtÄ, anavajjÄ anavajjasaá¹…khÄtÄ, sevitabbÄ sevitabbasaá¹…khÄtÄ, alamariyÄ alamariyasaá¹…khÄtÄ, sukkÄ sukkasaá¹…khÄtÄ. gotamasÄvakasaá¹…gho ime dhamme anavasesaá¹ƒ samÄdÄya vattati, yaá¹ƒ vÄ pana bhonto pare gaá¹‡ÄcariyasÄvakasaá¹…ghÄâ€™ti. itiha, kassapa, viÃ±Ã±Å« samanuyuÃ±jantÄ samanugÄhantÄ samanubhÄsantÄ amheva tattha yebhuyyena pasaá¹ƒseyyuá¹ƒ. ariyo aá¹­á¹­haá¹…giko maggo 393. "atthi, kassapa, maggo atthi paá¹­ipadÄ, yathÄpaá¹­ipanno sÄmaá¹ƒyeva Ã±assati sÄmaá¹ƒ dakkhati [dakkhiti (sÄ«.)] â€“ â€˜samaá¹‡ova gotamo kÄlavÄdÄ« bhÅ«tavÄdÄ« atthavÄdÄ« dhammavÄdÄ« vinayavÄdÄ«â€™ti. katamo ca, kassapa, maggo, katamÄ ca paá¹­ipadÄ, yathÄpaá¹­ipanno sÄmaá¹ƒyeva Ã±assati sÄmaá¹ƒ dakkhati â€“ â€˜samaá¹‡ova gotamo kÄlavÄdÄ« bhÅ«tavÄdÄ« atthavÄdÄ« dhammavÄdÄ« vinayavÄdÄ«â€™ti? ayameva ariyo aá¹­á¹­haá¹…giko maggo. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ sammÄdiá¹­á¹­hi sammÄsaá¹…kappo sammÄvÄcÄ sammÄkammanto sammÄÄjÄ«vo sammÄvÄyÄmo sammÄsati sammÄsamÄdhi. ayaá¹ƒ kho, kassapa, maggo, ayaá¹ƒ paá¹­ipadÄ, yathÄpaá¹­ipanno sÄmaá¹ƒyeva Ã±assati sÄmaá¹ƒ dakkhati â€˜samaá¹‡ova gotamo kÄlavÄdÄ« bhÅ«tavÄdÄ« atthavÄdÄ« dhammavÄdÄ« vinayavÄdÄ«"â€™ti.
"There is a path, Kassapa, there is a course of training, whereby one who has followed it will know and see for himself: â€˜The ascetic Gotama speaks at the proper time, what is true, to the pointâ€”the Dhamma and the discipline.â€™ What is this path and this course of training? It is just this Noble Eightfold Path: namely, right view (sammÄdiá¹­á¹­hi), right intention (sammÄsaá¹…kappo), right speech (sammÄvÄcÄ), right action (sammÄkammanto), right livelihood (sammÄÄjÄ«vo), right effort (sammÄvÄyÄmo), right mindfulness (sammÄsati), right concentration (sammÄsamÄdhi). This is the path, Kassapa, this is the course of training, whereby one who has followed it will know and see for himself: â€˜The ascetic Gotama speaks at the proper time, what is true, to the pointâ€”the Dhamma and the discipline.â€™" Talk about Ascetic Practices
394. tapopakkamakathÄ 394. evaá¹ƒ vutte, acelo kassapo bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "imepi kho, Ävuso gotama, tapopakkamÄ etesaá¹ƒ samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±asaá¹…khÄtÄ ca brahmaÃ±Ã±asaá¹…khÄtÄ ca. acelako hoti, muttÄcÄro, hatthÄpalekhano, na ehibhaddantiko, na tiá¹­á¹­habhaddantiko, nÄbhihaá¹­aá¹ƒ, na uddissakataá¹ƒ, na nimantanaá¹ƒ sÄdiyati. so na kumbhimukhÄ paá¹­iggaá¹‡hÄti, na kaá¸·opimukhÄ paá¹­iggaá¹‡hÄti, na eá¸·akamantaraá¹ƒ, na daá¹‡á¸amantaraá¹ƒ, na musalamantaraá¹ƒ, na dvinnaá¹ƒ bhuÃ±jamÄnÄnaá¹ƒ, na gabbhiniyÄ, na pÄyamÄnÄya, na purisantaragatÄya, na saá¹…kittÄ«su, na yattha sÄ upaá¹­á¹­hito hoti, na yattha makkhikÄ saá¹‡á¸asaá¹‡á¸acÄrinÄ«, na macchaá¹ƒ, na maá¹ƒsaá¹ƒ, na suraá¹ƒ, na merayaá¹ƒ, na thusodakaá¹ƒ pivati. so ekÄgÄriko vÄ hoti ekÄlopiko, dvÄgÄriko vÄ hoti dvÄlopikoâ€¦peâ€¦ sattÄgÄriko vÄ hoti sattÄlopiko, ekissÄpi dattiyÄ yÄpeti, dvÄ«hipi dattÄ«hi yÄpetiâ€¦ sattahipi dattÄ«hi yÄpeti, ekÄhikampi ÄhÄraá¹ƒ ÄhÄreti, dvÄ«hikampi ÄhÄraá¹ƒ ÄhÄretiâ€¦ sattÄhikampi ÄhÄraá¹ƒ ÄhÄreti. iti evarÅ«paá¹ƒ addhamÄsikampi pariyÄyabhattabhojanÄnuyogamanuyutto viharati. 395. "imepi kho, Ävuso gotama, tapopakkamÄ etesaá¹ƒ samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±asaá¹…khÄtÄ ca brahmaÃ±Ã±asaá¹…khÄtÄ ca. sÄkabhakkho vÄ hoti, sÄmÄkabhakkho vÄ hoti, nÄ«vÄrabhakkho vÄ hoti, daddulabhakkho vÄ hoti, haá¹­abhakkho vÄ hoti, kaá¹‡abhakkho vÄ hoti, ÄcÄmabhakkho vÄ hoti, piÃ±Ã±Äkabhakkho vÄ hoti, tiá¹‡abhakkho vÄ hoti, gomayabhakkho vÄ hoti, vanamÅ«laphalÄhÄro yÄpeti pavattaphalabhojÄ«. 396. "imepi kho, Ävuso gotama, tapopakkamÄ etesaá¹ƒ samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±asaá¹…khÄtÄ ca brahmaÃ±Ã±asaá¹…khÄtÄ ca. sÄá¹‡Änipi dhÄreti, masÄá¹‡Änipi dhÄreti, chavadussÄnipi dhÄreti, paá¹ƒsukÅ«lÄnipi dhÄreti, tirÄ«á¹­Änipi dhÄreti, ajinampi dhÄreti, ajinakkhipampi dhÄreti, kusacÄ«rampi dhÄreti, vÄkacÄ«rampi dhÄreti, phalakacÄ«rampi dhÄreti, kesakambalampi dhÄreti, vÄá¸·akambalampi dhÄreti, ulÅ«kapakkhikampi dhÄreti, kesamassulocakopi hoti kesamassulocanÄnuyogamanuyutto,
When this was said, the naked ascetic Kassapa said this to the Blessed One: "These ascetic practices of those ascetics and *brÄhmaá¹‡as* are considered as asceticism and Brahmanism. The naked ascetic lives rejecting conventions, licking his hands, not responding to polite requests to come or stay. He does not accept food offered or prepared for him, or an invitation to a meal. He does not receive anything from a pot or a pan, across a threshold, across a stick, or across a pestle, from two people eating together, from a pregnant woman, from a woman giving suck, from a woman lying with a man, from where food is advertised to be distributed, from where flies are swarming. He eats no fish or meat and drinks no rum or spirits or fermented rice-gruel. He may be a one-house man or a one-morsel man, a two-house man or a two-morsel manâ€¦ up to a seven-house man or a seven-morsel man. He sustains himself on one offering, two offeringsâ€¦ up to seven offerings. He takes food once a day, once every two daysâ€¦ up to once every seven days. Thus he lives pursuing the practice of taking food at stated intervals even up to once every fortnight.
395. tapopakkamakathÄ 394. evaá¹ƒ vutte, acelo kassapo bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "imepi kho, Ävuso gotama, tapopakkamÄ etesaá¹ƒ samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±asaá¹…khÄtÄ ca brahmaÃ±Ã±asaá¹…khÄtÄ ca. acelako hoti, muttÄcÄro, hatthÄpalekhano, na ehibhaddantiko, na tiá¹­á¹­habhaddantiko, nÄbhihaá¹­aá¹ƒ, na uddissakataá¹ƒ, na nimantanaá¹ƒ sÄdiyati. so na kumbhimukhÄ paá¹­iggaá¹‡hÄti, na kaá¸·opimukhÄ paá¹­iggaá¹‡hÄti, na eá¸·akamantaraá¹ƒ, na daá¹‡á¸amantaraá¹ƒ, na musalamantaraá¹ƒ, na dvinnaá¹ƒ bhuÃ±jamÄnÄnaá¹ƒ, na gabbhiniyÄ, na pÄyamÄnÄya, na purisantaragatÄya, na saá¹…kittÄ«su, na yattha sÄ upaá¹­á¹­hito hoti, na yattha makkhikÄ saá¹‡á¸asaá¹‡á¸acÄrinÄ«, na macchaá¹ƒ, na maá¹ƒsaá¹ƒ, na suraá¹ƒ, na merayaá¹ƒ, na thusodakaá¹ƒ pivati. so ekÄgÄriko vÄ hoti ekÄlopiko, dvÄgÄriko vÄ hoti dvÄlopikoâ€¦peâ€¦ sattÄgÄriko vÄ hoti sattÄlopiko, ekissÄpi dattiyÄ yÄpeti, dvÄ«hipi dattÄ«hi yÄpetiâ€¦ sattahipi dattÄ«hi yÄpeti, ekÄhikampi ÄhÄraá¹ƒ ÄhÄreti, dvÄ«hikampi ÄhÄraá¹ƒ ÄhÄretiâ€¦ sattÄhikampi ÄhÄraá¹ƒ ÄhÄreti. iti evarÅ«paá¹ƒ addhamÄsikampi pariyÄyabhattabhojanÄnuyogamanuyutto viharati. 395. "imepi kho, Ävuso gotama, tapopakkamÄ etesaá¹ƒ samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±asaá¹…khÄtÄ ca brahmaÃ±Ã±asaá¹…khÄtÄ ca. sÄkabhakkho vÄ hoti, sÄmÄkabhakkho vÄ hoti, nÄ«vÄrabhakkho vÄ hoti, daddulabhakkho vÄ hoti, haá¹­abhakkho vÄ hoti, kaá¹‡abhakkho vÄ hoti, ÄcÄmabhakkho vÄ hoti, piÃ±Ã±Äkabhakkho vÄ hoti, tiá¹‡abhakkho vÄ hoti, gomayabhakkho vÄ hoti, vanamÅ«laphalÄhÄro yÄpeti pavattaphalabhojÄ«. 396. "imepi kho, Ävuso gotama, tapopakkamÄ etesaá¹ƒ samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±asaá¹…khÄtÄ ca brahmaÃ±Ã±asaá¹…khÄtÄ ca. sÄá¹‡Änipi dhÄreti, masÄá¹‡Änipi dhÄreti, chavadussÄnipi dhÄreti, paá¹ƒsukÅ«lÄnipi dhÄreti, tirÄ«á¹­Änipi dhÄreti, ajinampi dhÄreti, ajinakkhipampi dhÄreti, kusacÄ«rampi dhÄreti, vÄkacÄ«rampi dhÄreti, phalakacÄ«rampi dhÄreti, kesakambalampi dhÄreti, vÄá¸·akambalampi dhÄreti, ulÅ«kapakkhikampi dhÄreti, kesamassulocakopi hoti kesamassulocanÄnuyogamanuyutto,
"These ascetic practices of those ascetics and *brÄhmaá¹‡as* are considered as asceticism and Brahmanism. He is an eater of greens or millet or wild rice or *daddula* or *haá¹­a* or rice bran or rice scum or sesame flour or grass or cow dung. He lives on forest roots and fruits, he feeds on fallen fruits.
396. tapopakkamakathÄ 394. evaá¹ƒ vutte, acelo kassapo bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "imepi kho, Ävuso gotama, tapopakkamÄ etesaá¹ƒ samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±asaá¹…khÄtÄ ca brahmaÃ±Ã±asaá¹…khÄtÄ ca. acelako hoti, muttÄcÄro, hatthÄpalekhano, na ehibhaddantiko, na tiá¹­á¹­habhaddantiko, nÄbhihaá¹­aá¹ƒ, na uddissakataá¹ƒ, na nimantanaá¹ƒ sÄdiyati. so na kumbhimukhÄ paá¹­iggaá¹‡hÄti, na kaá¸·opimukhÄ paá¹­iggaá¹‡hÄti, na eá¸·akamantaraá¹ƒ, na daá¹‡á¸amantaraá¹ƒ, na musalamantaraá¹ƒ, na dvinnaá¹ƒ bhuÃ±jamÄnÄnaá¹ƒ, na gabbhiniyÄ, na pÄyamÄnÄya, na purisantaragatÄya, na saá¹…kittÄ«su, na yattha sÄ upaá¹­á¹­hito hoti, na yattha makkhikÄ saá¹‡á¸asaá¹‡á¸acÄrinÄ«, na macchaá¹ƒ, na maá¹ƒsaá¹ƒ, na suraá¹ƒ, na merayaá¹ƒ, na thusodakaá¹ƒ pivati. so ekÄgÄriko vÄ hoti ekÄlopiko, dvÄgÄriko vÄ hoti dvÄlopikoâ€¦peâ€¦ sattÄgÄriko vÄ hoti sattÄlopiko, ekissÄpi dattiyÄ yÄpeti, dvÄ«hipi dattÄ«hi yÄpetiâ€¦ sattahipi dattÄ«hi yÄpeti, ekÄhikampi ÄhÄraá¹ƒ ÄhÄreti, dvÄ«hikampi ÄhÄraá¹ƒ ÄhÄretiâ€¦ sattÄhikampi ÄhÄraá¹ƒ ÄhÄreti. iti evarÅ«paá¹ƒ addhamÄsikampi pariyÄyabhattabhojanÄnuyogamanuyutto viharati. 395. "imepi kho, Ävuso gotama, tapopakkamÄ etesaá¹ƒ samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±asaá¹…khÄtÄ ca brahmaÃ±Ã±asaá¹…khÄtÄ ca. sÄkabhakkho vÄ hoti, sÄmÄkabhakkho vÄ hoti, nÄ«vÄrabhakkho vÄ hoti, daddulabhakkho vÄ hoti, haá¹­abhakkho vÄ hoti, kaá¹‡abhakkho vÄ hoti, ÄcÄmabhakkho vÄ hoti, piÃ±Ã±Äkabhakkho vÄ hoti, tiá¹‡abhakkho vÄ hoti, gomayabhakkho vÄ hoti, vanamÅ«laphalÄhÄro yÄpeti pavattaphalabhojÄ«. 396. "imepi kho, Ävuso gotama, tapopakkamÄ etesaá¹ƒ samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±asaá¹…khÄtÄ ca brahmaÃ±Ã±asaá¹…khÄtÄ ca. sÄá¹‡Änipi dhÄreti, masÄá¹‡Änipi dhÄreti, chavadussÄnipi dhÄreti, paá¹ƒsukÅ«lÄnipi dhÄreti, tirÄ«á¹­Änipi dhÄreti, ajinampi dhÄreti, ajinakkhipampi dhÄreti, kusacÄ«rampi dhÄreti, vÄkacÄ«rampi dhÄreti, phalakacÄ«rampi dhÄreti, kesakambalampi dhÄreti, vÄá¸·akambalampi dhÄreti, ulÅ«kapakkhikampi dhÄreti, kesamassulocakopi hoti kesamassulocanÄnuyogamanuyutto,
"These ascetic practices of those ascetics and *brÄhmaá¹‡as* are considered as asceticism and Brahmanism. He wears coarse hemp or mixed material, shrouds from corpses, rags from the dust heap, garments of bark fiber, antelope skins, a strip of antelope hide, *kusa*-grass fabric, bark fabric, *phalaka* fabric, blankets of human hair or horsehair, the wings of owls. He is a plucker-out of hair and beard, devoted to this practice. He is one who stands continuously, rejecting seats; he is one who squats continuously, devoted to maintaining the squatting position; he is one who uses a mattress of spikes, making a mattress of spikes his bed; he uses a plank bed, or a bare-ground bed. He lives resorting to only one posture, covered with dirt and grime. He lives in the open air, accepting whatever seat is offered. He is one who avoids company, devoted to the practice of avoiding company, one who is addicted to the practice of avoiding drinks, and he dwells pursuing the practice of bathing in water three times daily including the evening." Commentary on the meaninglessness of ascetic practices
397. ubbhaá¹­á¹­hakopi [ubbhaá¹­á¹­hikopi (ka.)] hoti Äsanapaá¹­ikkhitto, ukkuá¹­ikopi hoti ukkuá¹­ikappadhÄnamanuyutto, kaá¹‡á¹­akÄpassayikopi hoti kaá¹‡á¹­akÄpassaye seyyaá¹ƒ kappeti, phalakaseyyampi kappeti, thaá¹‡á¸ilaseyyampi kappeti, ekapassayikopi hoti rajojalladharo, abbhokÄsikopi hoti yathÄsanthatiko, vekaá¹­ikopi hoti vikaá¹­abhojanÄnuyogamanuyutto, apÄnakopi hoti apÄnakattamanuyutto, sÄyatatiyakampi udakorohanÄnuyogamanuyutto viharatÄ«"ti. tapopakkamaniratthakathÄ 397. "acelako cepi, kassapa, hoti, muttÄcÄro, hatthÄpalekhanoâ€¦peâ€¦ iti evarÅ«paá¹ƒ addhamÄsikampi pariyÄyabhattabhojanÄnuyogamanuyutto viharati. tassa cÄyaá¹ƒ sÄ«lasampadÄ cittasampadÄ paÃ±Ã±ÄsampadÄ abhÄvitÄ hoti asacchikatÄ. atha kho so ÄrakÄva sÄmaÃ±Ã±Ä ÄrakÄva brahmaÃ±Ã±Ä. yato kho, kassapa, bhikkhu averaá¹ƒ abyÄpajjaá¹ƒ mettacittaá¹ƒ bhÄveti, ÄsavÄnaÃ±ca khayÄ anÄsavaá¹ƒ cetovimuttiá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±Ävimuttiá¹ƒ diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ upasampajja viharati. ayaá¹ƒ vuccati, kassapa, bhikkhu samaá¹‡o itipi brÄhmaá¹‡o itipi. "sÄkabhakkho cepi, kassapa, hoti, sÄmÄkabhakkhoâ€¦peâ€¦ vanamÅ«laphalÄhÄro yÄpeti pavattaphalabhojÄ«. tassa cÄyaá¹ƒ sÄ«lasampadÄ cittasampadÄ paÃ±Ã±ÄsampadÄ abhÄvitÄ hoti asacchikatÄ. atha kho so ÄrakÄva sÄmaÃ±Ã±Ä ÄrakÄva brahmaÃ±Ã±Ä. yato kho, kassapa, bhikkhu averaá¹ƒ abyÄpajjaá¹ƒ mettacittaá¹ƒ bhÄveti, ÄsavÄnaÃ±ca khayÄ anÄsavaá¹ƒ cetovimuttiá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±Ävimuttiá¹ƒ diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ upasampajja viharati. ayaá¹ƒ vuccati, kassapa, bhikkhu samaá¹‡o itipi brÄhmaá¹‡o itipi. "sÄá¹‡Äni cepi, kassapa, dhÄreti, masÄá¹‡Änipi dhÄretiâ€¦peâ€¦ sÄyatatiyakampi udakorohanÄnuyogamanuyutto viharati. tassa cÄyaá¹ƒ sÄ«lasampadÄ cittasampadÄ paÃ±Ã±ÄsampadÄ abhÄvitÄ hoti asacchikatÄ. atha kho so ÄrakÄva sÄmaÃ±Ã±Ä ÄrakÄva
"Even if a naked ascetic, Kassapa, lives rejecting conventions, licking his handsâ€¦ and pursues the practice of taking food at stated intervals even up to once every fortnight, but if his morality ( *Å›Ä«lasampadÄ*), his heart (*cittasampadÄ*) and his wisdom (*prajÃ±ÄsampadÄ*) are undeveloped and unrealized, then indeed he is still far from being an ascetic (*Å›ramaá¹‡a*) or a *brÄhmaá¹‡a*. But, Kassapa, when a *bhikkhu* develops non-enmity, non-ill-will and a heart full of loving-kindness, and abandoning the corruptions, realizes and dwells in the uncorrupted deliverance of mind, the deliverance through wisdom, having realized it in this very life by his own insight, then, Kassapa, that *bhikkhu* is termed an ascetic (*Å›ramaá¹‡a*) and a *brÄhmaá¹‡a*. "Even if he is a herb-eater, Kassapa, or a millet-eaterâ€¦ and lives on forest roots and fruits, feeding on fallen fruits, but if his morality ( *Å›Ä«lasampadÄ*), his heart (*cittasampadÄ*) and his wisdom (*prajÃ±ÄsampadÄ*) are undeveloped and unrealized, then indeed he is still far from being an ascetic (*Å›ramaá¹‡a*) or a *brÄhmaá¹‡a*. But, Kassapa, when a *bhikkhu* develops non-enmity, non-ill-will and a heart full of loving-kindness, and abandoning the corruptions, realizes and dwells in the uncorrupted deliverance of mind, the deliverance through wisdom, having realized it in this very life by his own insight, then, Kassapa, that *bhikkhu* is termed an ascetic (*Å›ramaá¹‡a*) and a *brÄhmaá¹‡a*. "Even if, Kassapa, he wears coarse hemp or mixed materialâ€¦ and dwells pursuing the practice of bathing in water three times daily including the evening, but if his morality ( *Å›Ä«lasampadÄ*), his heart (*cittasampadÄ*) and his wisdom (*prajÃ±ÄsampadÄ*) are undeveloped and unrealized, then indeed he is still far from being an ascetic (*Å›ramaá¹‡a*) or a By means of a *brahmaÃ±Ã±a*. But, Kassapa, when a monk develops non-enmity (*averaá¹ƒ*), non-ill-will (*abyÄpajjaá¹ƒ*) and a heart full of loving-kindness (*mettacittaá¹ƒ*), and, abandoning the corruptions (*ÄsavÄnaá¹ƒ khayÄ*), realizes and dwells in the uncorrupted deliverance of mind (*anÄsavaá¹ƒ cetovimuttiá¹ƒ*), the deliverance through wisdom (*paÃ±Ã±Ävimuttiá¹ƒ*), having realized it in this very life (*diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme*) by his own insight (*sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä*)â€¦ Then, Kassapa, that monk is termed an ascetic (*samaá¹‡o*) and a Brahmin (*brÄhmaá¹‡o*).'
398. brahmaÃ±Ã±Ä. yato kho, kassapa, bhikkhu averaá¹ƒ abyÄpajjaá¹ƒ mettacittaá¹ƒ bhÄveti, ÄsavÄnaÃ±ca khayÄ anÄsavaá¹ƒ cetovimuttiá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±Ävimuttiá¹ƒ diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ upasampajja viharati. ayaá¹ƒ vuccati, kassapa, bhikkhu samaá¹‡o itipi brÄhmaá¹‡o itipÄ«"ti. 398. evaá¹ƒ vutte, acelo kassapo bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "dukkaraá¹ƒ, bho gotama, sÄmaÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ dukkaraá¹ƒ brahmaÃ±Ã±a"nti. "sÄkabhakkho cepi, kassapa, hoti, sÄmÄkabhakkhoâ€¦peâ€¦ vanamÅ«laphalÄhÄro yÄpeti pavattaphalabhojÄ«. imÄya ca, kassapa, mattÄya iminÄ tapopakkamena sÄmaÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ vÄ abhavissa brahmaÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ vÄ dukkaraá¹ƒ sudukkaraá¹ƒ, netaá¹ƒ abhavissa kallaá¹ƒ vacanÄya â€“ â€˜dukkaraá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ dukkaraá¹ƒ brahmaÃ±Ã±aâ€™nti. At this Kassapa said to the Lord: â€˜Reverend Gotama, it is hard to be an ascetic (*sÄmaÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ*), it is hard to be a *brahmaÃ±Ã±a*.â€™ â€˜So they say in the world, Kassapa: â€œIt is hard to be an ascetic (*sÄmaÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ*), it is hard to be a *brahmaÃ±Ã±a*.â€ because even if he goes naked (*acelako*), is of loose habits, licks his handâ€¦ and applies himself to the practice of partaking of food at fixed intervals of half a month. and if this were the measure and practice of the difficulty, the great difficulty, of being an ascetic (*sÄmaÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ*) or *brahmaÃ±Ã±a*, it would not be right to say: â€œIt is hard to be an ascetic (*sÄmaÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ*), it is hard to be a *brahmaÃ±Ã±a*â€, because any houseÂ­holder or householderâ€™s son â€” even the slave-girl who draws water â€” could do this saying: â€œWell, I will go naked (*acelako*)â€¦ But, Kassapa, because there is a very different kind of asceticism beside this, therefore it is right to say: â€œIt is hard to be an ascetic (*sÄmaÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ*), it is hard to be a *brahmaÃ±Ã±a*.â€ But, Kassapa, when a monk develops non-enmity (*averaá¹ƒ*), non-ill-will (*abyÄpajjaá¹ƒ*) and a heart full of loving-kindness (*mettacittaá¹ƒ*), and, abandoning the corruptions (*ÄsavÄnaá¹ƒ khayÄ*), realizes and dwells in the uncorrupted deliverance of mind (*anÄsavaá¹ƒ cetovimuttiá¹ƒ*), the deliverance through wisdom (*paÃ±Ã±Ävimuttiá¹ƒ*), having realized it in this very life (*diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme*) by his own insight (*sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä*)â€¦ Then, Kassapa, that monk is termed an ascetic (*samaá¹‡o*) and a Brahmin (*brÄhmaá¹‡o*). He is an eater of greens (*sÄkabhakkho*) or millet (*sÄmÄkabhakkho*)â€¦He lives on forest roots and fruits (*vanamÅ«laphalÄhÄro*), he feeds on fallen fruits (*pavattaphalabhojÄ«*). and if this were the measure and practice of the difficulty, the great difficulty, of being an ascetic (*sÄmaÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ*) or *brahmaÃ±Ã±a*, it would not be right to say: â€œIt is hard to be an ascetic (*sÄmaÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ*), it is hard to be a *brahmaÃ±Ã±a*â€, because any houseÂ­holder or householderâ€™s son â€” even the slave-girl who draws water â€” could do this saying: â€œWell, I will be an eater of greens (*sÄkabhakkho*) or millet (*sÄmÄkabhakkho*)â€¦ I live on forest roots and fruits (*vanamÅ«laphalÄhÄro*), I feed on fallen fruits (*pavattaphalabhojÄ«*)!â€ But, Kassapa, because there is a very different kind of asceticism or Brahmanism beside this, therefore it is right to say: â€œIt is hard to be an ascetic ( *Å›ramaá¹‡a*), it is hard to be a Brahmin ( *brÄhmaá¹‡a*).â€ But, Kassapa, when a monk ( *bhikkhu*) develops non-enmity ( *averaá¹ƒ*), non-ill-will ( *abyÄpajjaá¹ƒ*) and a heart full of loving-kindness ( *mettacittaá¹ƒ*) and, abandoning the corruptions ( *ÄsavÄnaá¹ƒ khayÄ*), realizes and dwells in the uncorrupted deliverance of mind ( *anÄsavaá¹ƒ cetovimuttiá¹ƒ*), the deliverance through wisdom ( *paÃ±Ã±Ävimuttiá¹ƒ*), having realized it in this very life ( *diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme*) by his own insight ( *sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ*) then, Kassapa, that monk ( *bhikkhu*) is termed an ascetic ( *samaá¹‡o*) and a Brahmin ( *brÄhmaá¹‡o*).â€™ "Even if, Kassapa, he wears hempen garments ( *sÄá¹‡Äni dhÄreti*), hempen undergarments ( *masÄá¹‡Äni dhÄreti*)â€¦peâ€¦ he dwells addicted to the practice of repeated bathing ( *sÄyatatiyakampi udakorohanÄnuyogamanuyutto viharati*)." And if this were the measure and practice of asceticism ( *sÄmaÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ*) or Brahmanism ( *brahmaÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ*), the difficulty, the great difficulty, it would not be right to say: â€œIt is hard to be an ascetic ( *Å›ramaá¹‡a*), it is hard to be a Brahmin ( *brÄhmaá¹‡a*).â€ "And this could have been done by a householder ( *gahapatinÄ*) or a householderâ€™s son ( *gahapatiputtena*) or even a slave woman ( *kumbhadÄsiyÄ*) â€“ â€˜Come, I will wear hempen garments ( *sÄá¹‡Äni dhÄremi*), hempen undergarments ( *masÄá¹‡Äni dhÄremi*)â€¦peâ€¦ I will dwell addicted to the practice of repeated bathing (*sÄyatatiyakampi udakorohanÄnuyogamanuyutto viharÄmi*)." But, Kassapa, because there is a very different kind of asceticism (*sÄmaÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ*) or Brahmanism (*brahmaÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ*) beside this, therefore it is right to say: â€œIt is hard to be an ascetic (*Å›ramaá¹‡a*), it is hard to be a Brahmin (*brÄhmaá¹‡a*).â€ But, Kassapa, when a monk ( *bhikkhu*) develops non-enmity ( *averaá¹ƒ*), non-ill-will ( *abyÄpajjaá¹ƒ*) and a heart full of loving-kindness ( *mettacittaá¹ƒ*) and, abandoning the corruptions ( *ÄsavÄnaá¹ƒ khayÄ*), realizes and dwells in the uncorrupted deliverance of mind ( *anÄsavaá¹ƒ cetovimuttiá¹ƒ*), the deliverance through wisdom ( *paÃ±Ã±Ävimuttiá¹ƒ*), having realized it in this very life ( *diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme*) by his own insight ( *sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ*). then that monk (*bhikkhu*) is called an ascetic (*samaá¹‡o*) and a Brahmin(*brÄhmaá¹‡o*).â€™

When this was said, the naked ascetic Kassapa said to the Blessed One ( *bhagavantaá¹ƒ*): â€œIt is hard to understand an ascetic ( *samaá¹‡o*), Venerable Gotama, it is hard to understand a Brahmin ( *brÄhmaá¹‡o*).â€ "So they say in the world (*lokasmiá¹ƒ*), Kassapa: â€œIt is hard to understand an ascetic (*samaá¹‡o*), it is hard to understand a Brahmin (*brÄhmaá¹‡o*)." Even a naked ascetic (*acelako*), Kassapa, might be of loose habits ( *muttÄcÄro*), a hand-licker ( *hatthÄpalekhano*)â€¦peâ€¦ thus he dwells addicted to the practice of eating alternative meals every fortnight (*addhamÄsikampi pariyÄyabhattabhojanÄnuyogamanuyutto viharati*). And if this were the measure and practice of an ascetic ( *samaá¹‡o*) And even if, Kassapa, he wears hempen garments, and also wears coarse hempen garmentsâ€¦and he practices repeated bathing in water. And, Kassapa, if a *Å›ramaá¹‡a* or a *brÄhmaá¹‡a* were difficult or very difficult to understand by this measure, by this practice of austerity, then it would not be right to say: "A *Å›ramaá¹‡a* is difficult to understand, a *brÄhmaá¹‡a* is difficult to understand." And it would be possible to know of him, either by a householder, or by a son of a householder, or even by a slave woman using a pot, that, "This one wears hempen garments, and also wears coarse hempen garmentsâ€¦and he practices repeated bathing in water." But because, Kassapa, there is a very different kind of *Å›ramaá¹‡a* or *brÄhmaá¹‡a* beside this, who is difficult or very difficult to understand, therefore it is right to say: "A *Å›ramaá¹‡a* is difficult to understand, a *brÄhmaá¹‡a* is difficult to understand.â€ But, Kassapa, when a *bhiká¹£u* develops non-enmity, non-ill-will and a heart full of loving-kindness, and, abandoning the corruptions, realises and dwells in the uncorrupted deliverance of mind, the deÂ­liverance through wisdom, having realised it in this very life by his own insight, then, Kassapa, that *bhiká¹£u* is termed an ascetic (*Å›ramaá¹‡a*) and a Brahmin (*brÄhmaá¹‡a*).â€™ The perfection of morality, concentration, and wisdom.
400. "idha, kassapa, tathÄgato loke uppajjati arahaá¹ƒ, sammÄsambuddhoâ€¦peâ€¦ (yathÄ 190-193 anucchedesu, evaá¹ƒ vitthÄretabbaá¹ƒ) bhayadassÄvÄ« samÄdÄya sikkhati sikkhÄpadesu, kÄyakammavacÄ«kammena samannÄgato kusalena parisuddhÄjÄ«vo sÄ«lasampanno indriyesu guttadvÄro satisampajaÃ±Ã±ena samannÄgato santuá¹­á¹­ho. 401. "kathaÃ±ca, kassapa, bhikkhu sÄ«lasampanno hoti? idha, kassapa, bhikkhu pÄá¹‡ÄtipÄtaá¹ƒ pahÄya pÄá¹‡ÄtipÄtÄ paá¹­ivirato hoti nihitadaá¹‡á¸o nihitasattho lajjÄ« dayÄpanno, sabbapÄá¹‡abhÅ«tahitÄnukampÄ« viharati. idampissa hoti sÄ«lasampadÄya â€¦peâ€¦ (yathÄ 194 yÄva 210 anucchedesu) "yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vena jÄ«vitaá¹ƒ
When this was said, the naked ascetic, Kassapa, said this to the Blessed One: "But what, Venerable Gotama, is the perfection of morality (*Å›Ä«lasampadÄ*)? What is the perfection of mind (*cittasampadÄ*)? What is the perfection of wisdom (*prajÃ±ÄsampadÄ*)?" "Here, Kassapa, a *TathÄgata* arises in the world, an *arhat*, a fully enlightened Buddhaâ€¦ (as in sections 190-193, so it should be explained in detail) seeing danger, he undertakes and trains himself in the training rules, endowed with wholesome bodily and verbal action, with purified livelihood, perfected in morality, guarding the doors of the senses, endowed with mindfulness and clear comprehension, content.
401. "sÄá¹‡Äni cepi, kassapa, dhÄreti, masÄá¹‡Änipi dhÄretiâ€¦peâ€¦ sÄyatatiyakampi udakorohanÄnuyogamanuyutto viharati. imÄya ca, kassapa, mattÄya iminÄ tapopakkamena samaá¹‡o vÄ abhavissa brÄhmaá¹‡o vÄ dujjÄno sudujjÄno, netaá¹ƒ abhavissa kallaá¹ƒ vacanÄya â€“ â€˜dujjÄno samaá¹‡o dujjÄno brÄhmaá¹‡oâ€™ti. "sakkÄ ca paneso abhavissa Ã±Ätuá¹ƒ gahapatinÄ vÄ gahapatiputtena vÄ antamaso kumbhadÄsiyÄpi â€“ â€˜ayaá¹ƒ sÄá¹‡Änipi dhÄreti, masÄá¹‡Änipi dhÄretiâ€¦peâ€¦ sÄyatatiyakampi udakorohanÄnuyogamanuyutto viharatÄ«â€™ti. "yasmÄ ca kho, kassapa, aÃ±Ã±atreva imÄya mattÄya aÃ±Ã±atra iminÄ tapopakkamena samaá¹‡o vÄ hoti brÄhmaá¹‡o vÄ dujjÄno sudujjÄno, tasmÄ etaá¹ƒ kallaá¹ƒ vacanÄya â€“ â€˜dujjÄno samaá¹‡o dujjÄno brÄhmaá¹‡oâ€™ti. yato kho, kassapa, bhikkhu averaá¹ƒ abyÄpajjaá¹ƒ mettacittaá¹ƒ bhÄveti, ÄsavÄnaÃ±ca khayÄ anÄsavaá¹ƒ cetovimuttiá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±Ävimuttiá¹ƒ diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ upasampajja viharati. ayaá¹ƒ vuccati, kassapa, bhikkhu samaá¹‡o itipi brÄhmaá¹‡o itipÄ«"ti. sÄ«lasamÄdhipaÃ±Ã±ÄsampadÄ 400. evaá¹ƒ vutte, acelo kassapo bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "katamÄ pana sÄ, bho gotama, sÄ«lasampadÄ, katamÄ cittasampadÄ, katamÄ paÃ±Ã±ÄsampadÄ"ti? "idha, kassapa, tathÄgato loke uppajjati arahaá¹ƒ, sammÄsambuddhoâ€¦peâ€¦ (yathÄ 190-193 anucchedesu, evaá¹ƒ vitthÄretabbaá¹ƒ) bhayadassÄvÄ« samÄdÄya sikkhati sikkhÄpadesu, kÄyakammavacÄ«kammena samannÄgato kusalena parisuddhÄjÄ«vo sÄ«lasampanno indriyesu guttadvÄro satisampajaÃ±Ã±ena samannÄgato santuá¹­á¹­ho. 401. "kathaÃ±ca, kassapa, bhikkhu sÄ«lasampanno hoti? idha, kassapa, bhikkhu pÄá¹‡ÄtipÄtaá¹ƒ pahÄya pÄá¹‡ÄtipÄtÄ paá¹­ivirato hoti nihitadaá¹‡á¸o nihitasattho lajjÄ« dayÄpanno, sabbapÄá¹‡abhÅ«tahitÄnukampÄ« viharati. idampissa hoti sÄ«lasampadÄya â€¦peâ€¦ (yathÄ 194 yÄva 210 anucchedesu) "yathÄ vÄ paneke bhonto samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä saddhÄdeyyÄni bhojanÄni bhuÃ±jitvÄ te evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vena jÄ«vitaá¹ƒ
â€œAnd how, Kassapa, is a *bhiká¹£u* perfected in morality (*Å›Ä«lasampanno*)? Here, Kassapa, a *bhiká¹£u*, having abandoned the taking of life, abstains from taking life, with his rod laid down, his weapon laid down, conscientious, full of kindness, he dwells full of compassion for the welfare of all living beings. This pertains to his perfection of morality (*Å›Ä«lasampadÄ*)â€¦ (as in sections 194 up to 210) "Whereas some ascetics and Brahmins, while living on the food offered by the faithful, earn their living by a wrong means of livelihood, by such debased arts they make their living. That is to say: spells for safety, spells for successâ€¦(as in section 211) the *prÄtimoká¹£a* of medicinal herbs, either this or that; he abstains from wrong livelihood, by such base arts. This pertains to his perfection of morality (*Å›Ä«lasampadÄ*). "Great king, the *bhiká¹£u* who is thus possessed of moral discipline (*Å›Ä«lasampanno*) sees no danger anywhere in regard to his restraint by moral discipline. Just as a head-anointed noble warrior who has defeated his enemies sees no danger anywhere from his enemies. So too, Kassapa, the *bhiká¹£u* who is thus possessed of moral discipline (*Å›Ä«lasampanno*) sees no danger anywhere in regard to his restraint by moral discipline. Endowed with this noble aggregate of moral discipline (*Å›Ä«lakkhandha*), he experiences within himself a blameless happiness (*anavajjasukhaá¹ƒ*). Thus, Kassapa, a *bhiká¹£u* is perfected in morality (*Å›Ä«lasampanno*). That, Kassapa, is the perfection of morality (*Å›Ä«lasampadÄ*)â€¦he attains the first *jhÄna*, and dwells in it. This comes to him through the perfection of the heart/mind (*cittasampadÄ*)â€¦the second *jhÄna*â€¦the third *jhÄna*â€¦the fourth *jhÄna*, he attains and dwells in it. This pertains to his perfection of the heart/mind (*cittasampadÄ*). That, Kassapa, is the perfection of the heart/mind (*cittasampadÄ*). â€œSo, with the heart/mind thus concentratedâ€¦he directs and inclines the heart/mind to the knowledge and visionâ€¦This pertains to his perfection of wisdom (*prajÃ±ÄsampadÄ*)â€¦he understands: â€˜There is nothing further hereâ€™â€¦This pertains to his perfection of wisdom (*prajÃ±ÄsampadÄ*). That, Kassapa, is the perfection of wisdom (*prajÃ±ÄsampadÄ*). â€œAnd, Kassapa, there is nothing further or more perfect than this perfection of morality (*Å›Ä«lasampadÄya*), of the heart/mind (*cittasampadÄya*) and of wisdom (*prajÃ±ÄsampadÄya*). The Lion's Roar Discourse
402. kappenti. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ santikammaá¹ƒ paá¹‡idhikammaá¹ƒâ€¦peâ€¦ (yathÄ 211 anucchede) osadhÄ«naá¹ƒ patimokkho iti vÄ iti, evarÅ«pÄya tiracchÄnavijjÄya micchÄjÄ«vÄ paá¹­ivirato hoti. idampissa hoti sÄ«lasampadÄya. "sa kho so [ayaá¹ƒ kho (ka.)], kassapa, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ sÄ«lasampanno na kutoci bhayaá¹ƒ samanupassati, yadidaá¹ƒ sÄ«lasaá¹ƒvarato. seyyathÄpi, kassapa, rÄjÄ khattiyo muddhÄvasitto nihatapaccÄmitto na kutoci bhayaá¹ƒ samanupassati, yadidaá¹ƒ paccatthikato. evameva kho, kassapa, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ sÄ«lasampanno na kutoci bhayaá¹ƒ samanupassati, yadidaá¹ƒ sÄ«lasaá¹ƒvarato. so iminÄ ariyena sÄ«lakkhandhena samannÄgato ajjhattaá¹ƒ anavajjasukhaá¹ƒ paá¹­isaá¹ƒvedeti. evaá¹ƒ kho, kassapa, bhikkhu sÄ«lasampanno hoti. ayaá¹ƒ kho, kassapa, sÄ«lasampadÄâ€¦peâ€¦ paá¹­hamaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒ upasampajja viharati. idampissa hoti cittasampadÄyaâ€¦peâ€¦ dutiyaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒâ€¦peâ€¦ tatiyaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒâ€¦peâ€¦ catutthaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒ upasampajja viharati. idampissa hoti cittasampadÄya. ayaá¹ƒ kho, kassapa, cittasampadÄ. "so evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citteâ€¦peâ€¦ Ã±Äá¹‡adassanÄya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmetiâ€¦peâ€¦ idampissa hoti paÃ±Ã±ÄsampadÄyaâ€¦peâ€¦ nÄparaá¹ƒ itthattÄyÄti pajÄnÄtiâ€¦peâ€¦ idampissa hoti paÃ±Ã±ÄsampadÄya. ayaá¹ƒ kho, kassapa, paÃ±Ã±ÄsampadÄ. "imÄya ca, kassapa, sÄ«lasampadÄya cittasampadÄya paÃ±Ã±ÄsampadÄya aÃ±Ã±Ä sÄ«lasampadÄ cittasampadÄ paÃ±Ã±ÄsampadÄ uttaritarÄ vÄ paá¹‡Ä«tatarÄ vÄ natthi. sÄ«hanÄdakathÄ 402. "santi, kassapa, eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä sÄ«lavÄdÄ. te anekapariyÄyena sÄ«lassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsanti. yÄvatÄ, kassapa, ariyaá¹ƒ paramaá¹ƒ sÄ«laá¹ƒ, nÄhaá¹ƒ tattha attano samasamaá¹ƒ samanupassÄmi, kuto bhiyyo! atha kho ahameva tattha bhiyyo, yadidaá¹ƒ adhisÄ«laá¹ƒ. "santi, kassapa, eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä tapojigucchÄvÄdÄ. te anekapariyÄyena tapojigucchÄya vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsanti. yÄvatÄ, kassapa, ariyÄ
â€˜Kassapa, there are some ascetics and Brahmins who preach morality (*Å›Ä«lavÄdÄ*). They praise morality (*Å›Ä«lassa vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ*) in various ways. But as regards the highest Ariyan morality (*ariyaá¹ƒ paramaá¹ƒ sÄ«laá¹ƒ*), Kassapa, I do not see any who have surpassed me in this. But rather, I alone am greater in that, namely, higher morality (*adhiÅ›Ä«laá¹ƒ*). "Kassapa, there are some ascetics and Brahmins who preach self-mortification and scrupulous austerity (*tapojigucchÄvÄdÄ*). They praise self-mortification and scrupulous austerity (*tapojigucchÄya vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ*) in various ways. As far as, Kassapa, the noble, supreme Supreme is self-mortification and scrupulous austerity, but as regards that, I do not see anyone equal to me, how could there be anyone greater! But indeed, I alone am greater in that, namely, excessive scrupulousness. "Kassapa, there are some ascetics and Brahmins who preach wisdom (paÃ±Ã±ÄvÄdÄ). They praise wisdom in various ways. But as regards the highest Ä€ryan wisdom (ariyÄ paramÄ paÃ±Ã±Ä), Kassapa, I do not see any who have surpassed me in this. But indeed, I alone am greater in that, namely, superior wisdom (adhipaÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ). "Kassapa, there are some ascetics and Brahmins who preach liberation (vimuttivÄdÄ). They praise liberation in various ways. But as regards the highest Ä€ryan liberation (ariyÄ paramÄ vimutti), Kassapa, I do not see any who have surpassed me in this. But indeed, I alone am greater in that, namely, superior liberation (adhivimutti).

"santi, kassapa, eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä paÃ±Ã±ÄvÄdÄ. te anekapariyÄyena paÃ±Ã±Äya vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsanti. yÄvatÄ, kassapa, ariyÄ paramÄ paÃ±Ã±Ä, nÄhaá¹ƒ tattha attano samasamaá¹ƒ samanupassÄmi, kuto bhiyyo! atha kho ahameva tattha bhiyyo, yadidaá¹ƒ adhipaÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ. "santi, kassapa, eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä vimuttivÄdÄ. te anekapariyÄyena vimuttiyÄ vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ bhÄsanti. yÄvatÄ, kassapa, ariyÄ paramÄ vimutti, nÄhaá¹ƒ tattha attano samasamaá¹ƒ samanupassÄmi, kuto bhiyyo! atha kho ahameva tattha bhiyyo, yadidaá¹ƒ adhivimutti. 403. "á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ kho panetaá¹ƒ, kassapa, vijjati, yaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±atitthiyÄ paribbÄjakÄ evaá¹ƒ vadeyyuá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜sÄ«hanÄdaá¹ƒ kho samaá¹‡o gotamo nadati, taÃ±ca kho suÃ±Ã±ÄgÄre nadati, no parisÄsÅ«â€™ti. te â€“ â€˜mÄ hevaâ€™ntissu vacanÄ«yÄ. â€˜sÄ«hanÄdaÃ±ca samaá¹‡o gotamo nadati, parisÄsu ca nadatÄ«â€™ti evamassu, kassapa, vacanÄ«yÄ. "á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ kho panetaá¹ƒ, kassapa, vijjati, yaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±atitthiyÄ paribbÄjakÄ evaá¹ƒ vadeyyuá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜sÄ«hanÄdaÃ±ca samaá¹‡o gotamo nadati, parisÄsu ca nadati, no ca kho visÄrado nadatÄ«â€™ti. te â€“ â€˜mÄ hevaâ€™ntissu vacanÄ«yÄ. â€˜sÄ«hanÄdaÃ±ca samaá¹‡o gotamo nadati, parisÄsu ca nadati, visÄrado ca nadatÄ«"ti evamassu, kassapa, vacanÄ«yÄ. "á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ kho panetaá¹ƒ, kassapa, vijjati, yaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±atitthiyÄ paribbÄjakÄ evaá¹ƒ vadeyyuá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜sÄ«hanÄdaÃ±ca samaá¹‡o gotamo nadati, parisÄsu ca nadati, visÄrado ca nadati, no ca kho naá¹ƒ paÃ±haá¹ƒ pucchantiâ€¦peâ€¦ paÃ±haÃ±ca naá¹ƒ pucchanti, no ca kho nesaá¹ƒ paÃ±haá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­ho byÄkarotiâ€¦peâ€¦ paÃ±haÃ±ca nesaá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­ho byÄkaroti, no ca kho paÃ±hassa veyyÄkaraá¹‡ena cittaá¹ƒ ÄrÄdhetiâ€¦peâ€¦ paÃ±hassa ca veyyÄkaraá¹‡ena cittaá¹ƒ ÄrÄdheti, no ca kho sotabbaá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±antiâ€¦peâ€¦ sotabbaÃ±cassa maÃ±Ã±anti, no ca kho sutvÄ pasÄ«dantiâ€¦peâ€¦ sutvÄ cassa
"Kassapa, it may be that wanderers of other sects will say: â€œThe ascetic Gotama roars his lionâ€™s roar (sÄ«hanÄdaá¹ƒ), but only in empty places, not in company.â€ They should be told that this is not true: â€˜mÄ hevaâ€™. â€œThe ascetic Gotama roars his lionâ€™s roar (sÄ«hanÄdaá¹ƒ), and he roars it in company (parisÄsu),â€ that, Kassapa, is what they should be told. "Kassapa, it may be that wanderers of other sects will say: â€œThe ascetic Gotama roars his lionâ€™s roar (sÄ«hanÄdaá¹ƒ), and in company, but he does so without confidence (visÄrado).â€ They should be told that this is not true: â€˜mÄ hevaâ€™. â€œThe ascetic Gotama roars his lionâ€™s roar (sÄ«hanÄdaá¹ƒ), in company and confidently (visÄrado),â€ that, Kassapa, is what they should be told. "Kassapa, it may be that wanderers of other sects will say: â€œThe ascetic Gotama roars his lionâ€™s roar (sÄ«hanÄdaá¹ƒ), in company and confidently, but they do not question himâ€¦ they question him, but he does not answerâ€¦ he answers, but he does not win them over with his answersâ€¦but they donâ€™t find it pleasingâ€¦ but they are satisfied with what they have heardâ€¦ They are satisfied, but they do not show an appearance of satisfactionâ€¦peâ€¦ they do show an appearance of satisfaction, but they do not embark on the path of truthâ€¦peâ€¦ they do embark on the path of truth, but those who have embarked do not find satisfaction.â€™ They should be told that this is not true. â€œThe ascetic Gotama roars his lionâ€™s roar, and in company he roars, and confidently he roars, and they question him, and when questioned by them, he answers, and with his answers he pleases their minds, and they consider it worth listening to, and having heard it they are satisfied, and they show an appearance of satisfaction, and they embark on the path of truth, and those who have embarked find satisfaction.â€ That, Kassapa, is what they should be told. The topic of probation for those formerly of other sects.
404. pasÄ«danti, no ca kho pasannÄkÄraá¹ƒ karontiâ€¦peâ€¦ pasannÄkÄraÃ±ca karonti, no ca kho tathattÄya paá¹­ipajjantiâ€¦peâ€¦ tathattÄya ca paá¹­ipajjanti, no ca kho paá¹­ipannÄ ÄrÄdhentÄ«â€™ti. te â€“ â€˜mÄ hevaâ€™ntissu vacanÄ«yÄ. â€˜sÄ«hanÄdaÃ±ca samaá¹‡o gotamo nadati, parisÄsu ca nadati, visÄrado ca nadati, paÃ±haÃ±ca naá¹ƒ pucchanti, paÃ±haÃ±ca nesaá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­ho byÄkaroti, paÃ±hassa ca veyyÄkaraá¹‡ena cittaá¹ƒ ÄrÄdheti, sotabbaÃ±cassa maÃ±Ã±anti, sutvÄ cassa pasÄ«danti, pasannÄkÄraÃ±ca karonti, tathattÄya ca paá¹­ipajjanti, paá¹­ipannÄ ca ÄrÄdhentÄ«â€™ti evamassu, kassapa, vacanÄ«yÄ. titthiyaparivÄsakathÄ 404. "ekamidÄhaá¹ƒ, kassapa, samayaá¹ƒ rÄjagahe viharÄmi gijjhakÅ«á¹­e pabbate. tatra maá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±ataro tapabrahmacÄrÄ« nigrodho nÄma adhijegucche paÃ±haá¹ƒ apucchi. tassÄhaá¹ƒ adhijegucche paÃ±haá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­ho byÄkÄsiá¹ƒ. byÄkate ca pana me attamano ahosi paraá¹ƒ viya mattÄyÄ"ti. "ko hi, bhante, bhagavato dhammaá¹ƒ sutvÄ na attamano assa paraá¹ƒ viya mattÄya? ahampi hi, bhante, bhagavato dhammaá¹ƒ sutvÄ attamano paraá¹ƒ viya mattÄya. abhikkantaá¹ƒ, bhante, abhikkantaá¹ƒ, bhante. seyyathÄpi, bhante, nikkujjitaá¹ƒ vÄ ukkujjeyya, paá¹­icchannaá¹ƒ vÄ vivareyya, mÅ«á¸·hassa vÄ maggaá¹ƒ Äcikkheyya, andhakÄre vÄ telapajjotaá¹ƒ dhÄreyya â€“ â€˜cakkhumanto rÅ«pÄni dakkhantÄ«â€™ti, evamevaá¹ƒ bhagavatÄ anekapariyÄyena dhammo pakÄsito. esÄhaá¹ƒ, bhante, bhagavantaá¹ƒ saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ gacchÄmi, dhammaÃ±ca bhikkhusaá¹…ghaÃ±ca. labheyyÄhaá¹ƒ, bhante, bhagavato santike pabbajjaá¹ƒ, labheyyaá¹ƒ upasampada"nti. 405. "yo kho, kassapa, aÃ±Ã±atitthiyapubbo imasmiá¹ƒ dhammavinaye Äkaá¹…khati pabbajjaá¹ƒ, Äkaá¹…khati upasampadaá¹ƒ, so cattÄro mÄse parivasati, catunnaá¹ƒ mÄsÄnaá¹ƒ accayena ÄraddhacittÄ bhikkhÅ« pabbÄjenti, upasampÄdenti bhikkhubhÄvÄya. api ca mettha puggalavemattatÄ viditÄ"ti. "sace, bhante, aÃ±Ã±atitthiyapubbÄ imasmiá¹ƒ dhammavinaye Äkaá¹…khanti pabbajjaá¹ƒ, Äkaá¹…khanti upasampadaá¹ƒ, cattÄro mÄse parivasanti, catunnaá¹ƒ mÄsÄnaá¹ƒ accayena ÄraddhacittÄ bhikkhÅ« pabbÄjenti, upasampÄdenti bhikkhubhÄvÄya. ahaá¹ƒ cattÄri vassÄni parivasissÄmi, catunnaá¹ƒ vassÄnaá¹ƒ accayena ÄraddhacittÄ bhikkhÅ« pabbÄjentu, upasampÄdentu bhikkhubhÄvÄyÄ"ti.
â€œOnce, Kassapa, I was staying at RÄjagaha, at Vultureâ€™s Peak Mountain. There a certain ascetic and celibate named Nigrodha asked me a question about the practice of austerity at Adhijegucche. When asked that question by him at Adhijegucche, I explained it. And he was delighted with my explanation beyond all measure.â€ â€œWho, venerable sir, having heard the *Dhamma* from the Blessed One, would not be delighted beyond all measure? I too, venerable sir, having heard the *Dhamma* from the Blessed One, am delighted beyond all measure." Wonderful, venerable sir, wonderful, venerable sir! Just as, venerable sir, one might set upright what was overturned, or reveal what was hidden, or point out the way to one who was lost, or hold up an oil lamp in the dark, so that those with eyes might see formsâ€”just so, by the Blessed One, in many ways has the *Dhamma* been made clear. I go to the Blessed One for refuge, and to the *Dhamma*, and to the *bhikkhu-saá¹…gha* (community of monks). May I receive the going forth (*pravrajyÄ*) in the Blessed Oneâ€™s presence, may I receive the higher ordination (*upasampadÄ*)".
405. pasÄ«danti, no ca kho pasannÄkÄraá¹ƒ karontiâ€¦peâ€¦ pasannÄkÄraÃ±ca karonti, no ca kho tathattÄya paá¹­ipajjantiâ€¦peâ€¦ tathattÄya ca paá¹­ipajjanti, no ca kho paá¹­ipannÄ ÄrÄdhentÄ«â€™ti. te â€“ â€˜mÄ hevaâ€™ntissu vacanÄ«yÄ. â€˜sÄ«hanÄdaÃ±ca samaá¹‡o gotamo nadati, parisÄsu ca nadati, visÄrado ca nadati, paÃ±haÃ±ca naá¹ƒ pucchanti, paÃ±haÃ±ca nesaá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­ho byÄkaroti, paÃ±hassa ca veyyÄkaraá¹‡ena cittaá¹ƒ ÄrÄdheti, sotabbaÃ±cassa maÃ±Ã±anti, sutvÄ cassa pasÄ«danti, pasannÄkÄraÃ±ca karonti, tathattÄya ca paá¹­ipajjanti, paá¹­ipannÄ ca ÄrÄdhentÄ«â€™ti evamassu, kassapa, vacanÄ«yÄ. titthiyaparivÄsakathÄ 404. "ekamidÄhaá¹ƒ, kassapa, samayaá¹ƒ rÄjagahe viharÄmi gijjhakÅ«á¹­e pabbate. tatra maá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±ataro tapabrahmacÄrÄ« nigrodho nÄma adhijegucche paÃ±haá¹ƒ apucchi. tassÄhaá¹ƒ adhijegucche paÃ±haá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­ho byÄkÄsiá¹ƒ. byÄkate ca pana me attamano ahosi paraá¹ƒ viya mattÄyÄ"ti. "ko hi, bhante, bhagavato dhammaá¹ƒ sutvÄ na attamano assa paraá¹ƒ viya mattÄya? ahampi hi, bhante, bhagavato dhammaá¹ƒ sutvÄ attamano paraá¹ƒ viya mattÄya. abhikkantaá¹ƒ, bhante, abhikkantaá¹ƒ, bhante. seyyathÄpi, bhante, nikkujjitaá¹ƒ vÄ ukkujjeyya, paá¹­icchannaá¹ƒ vÄ vivareyya, mÅ«á¸·hassa vÄ maggaá¹ƒ Äcikkheyya, andhakÄre vÄ telapajjotaá¹ƒ dhÄreyya â€“ â€˜cakkhumanto rÅ«pÄni dakkhantÄ«â€™ti, evamevaá¹ƒ bhagavatÄ anekapariyÄyena dhammo pakÄsito. esÄhaá¹ƒ, bhante, bhagavantaá¹ƒ saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ gacchÄmi, dhammaÃ±ca bhikkhusaá¹…ghaÃ±ca. labheyyÄhaá¹ƒ, bhante, bhagavato santike pabbajjaá¹ƒ, labheyyaá¹ƒ upasampada"nti. 405. "yo kho, kassapa, aÃ±Ã±atitthiyapubbo imasmiá¹ƒ dhammavinaye Äkaá¹…khati pabbajjaá¹ƒ, Äkaá¹…khati upasampadaá¹ƒ, so cattÄro mÄse parivasati, catunnaá¹ƒ mÄsÄnaá¹ƒ accayena ÄraddhacittÄ bhikkhÅ« pabbÄjenti, upasampÄdenti bhikkhubhÄvÄya. api ca mettha puggalavemattatÄ viditÄ"ti. "sace, bhante, aÃ±Ã±atitthiyapubbÄ imasmiá¹ƒ dhammavinaye Äkaá¹…khanti pabbajjaá¹ƒ, Äkaá¹…khanti upasampadaá¹ƒ, cattÄro mÄse parivasanti, catunnaá¹ƒ mÄsÄnaá¹ƒ accayena ÄraddhacittÄ bhikkhÅ« pabbÄjenti, upasampÄdenti bhikkhubhÄvÄya. ahaá¹ƒ cattÄri vassÄni parivasissÄmi, catunnaá¹ƒ vassÄnaá¹ƒ accayena ÄraddhacittÄ bhikkhÅ« pabbÄjentu, upasampÄdentu bhikkhubhÄvÄyÄ"ti.
â€œKassapa, whoever has formerly belonged to another sect and wishes for the going forth (*pravrajyÄ*) or the higher ordination (*upasampadÄ*) in this *Dhamma*-discipline, he lives on probation for four months; at the end of four months, if the monks are satisfied, they give him the going forth (*pravrajyÄ*) and the higher ordination (*upasampadÄ*) into the state of a *bhikkhu* (monk). But in this matter, a distinction of persons is known to me.â€ â€œIf, venerable sir, those formerly of other sects desire the going forth (*pravrajyÄ*) in this *Dhamma*-discipline, desire the higher ordination (*upasampadÄ*), and live on probation for four months; and at the end of four months, if the monks are satisfied, they give them the going forth (*pravrajyÄ*) and the higher ordination (*upasampadÄ*), I will live on probation for four years, and at the end of four years, if the monks are satisfied, may they give me the going forth (*pravrajyÄ*) and the higher ordination (*upasampadÄ*) into the state of a *bhikkhu* (monk)." He speaks thus: â€˜The self (*Ätman*) and the world are eternal, barren, steadfast as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar. And though these beings roam and wander, pass away and re-arise, yet the self and the world remain the same just like eternity itself.â€™ What is the reason for that? Because I, by means of ardour (*Ätappa*), endeavour (*padhÄna*), application (*anuyoga*), diligence (*appamÄda*), and right reflection (*sammÄmanasikÄra*), attain to such a degree of mental concentration (*cetosamÄdhi*) that with my mind thus concentrated, I recollect my numerous past lives (*pubbenivÄsa*) . That is to say, one period of contraction and expansion of the world, two periods of contraction and expansion of the world, three periods of contraction and expansion of the world, four periods of contraction and expansion of the world, five periods of contraction and expansion of the world, ten periods of contraction and expansion of the world. "There I was of such a name, such a clan, such an appearance; such was my food, such my experience of pleasure and pain, such my life span. Passing away from there, I arose there. There too I was of such a name, such a clan, such an appearance; such was my food, such my experience of pleasure and pain, such my life span. Passing away from there, I was reborn here." In this way I recollect many past lives with their characteristics and particulars. For this reason I know this: the self (*Ätman*) and the world are eternal, barren, steadfast as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar. And though these beings roam and wander, pass away and re-arise, yet the self and the world remain the same just like eternity itself.â€™ This, monks (*bhikkhave*), is the second reason, which some ascetics and Brahmins, adhering to the eternalist doctrine (*sassatavÄdÄ*), declare the self (*Ätman*) and the world to be eternal.
406. 9. poá¹­á¹­hapÄdasuttaá¹ƒ poá¹­á¹­hapÄdaparibbÄjakavatthu 406. evaá¹ƒ me sutaá¹ƒ â€“ ekaá¹ƒ samayaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ sÄvatthiyaá¹ƒ viharati jetavane anÄthapiá¹‡á¸ikassa ÄrÄme. tena kho pana samayena poá¹­á¹­hapÄdo paribbÄjako samayappavÄdake tindukÄcÄ«re ekasÄlake mallikÄya ÄrÄme paá¹­ivasati mahatiyÄ paribbÄjakaparisÄya saddhiá¹ƒ tiá¹ƒsamattehi paribbÄjakasatehi. atha kho bhagavÄ pubbaá¹‡hasamayaá¹ƒ nivÄsetvÄ pattacÄ«varamÄdÄya sÄvatthiá¹ƒ piá¹‡á¸Äya pÄvisi. 407. atha kho bhagavato etadahosi â€“ "atippago kho tÄva sÄvatthiyaá¹ƒ piá¹‡á¸Äya carituá¹ƒ. yaá¹ƒnÅ«nÄhaá¹ƒ yena samayappavÄdako tindukÄcÄ«ro ekasÄlako mallikÄya ÄrÄmo, yena poá¹­á¹­hapÄdo paribbÄjako tenupasaá¹…kameyya"nti. atha kho bhagavÄ yena samayappavÄdako tindukÄcÄ«ro ekasÄlako mallikÄya ÄrÄmo tenupasaá¹…kami. 408. tena kho pana samayena poá¹­á¹­hapÄdo paribbÄjako mahatiyÄ paribbÄjakaparisÄya saddhiá¹ƒ nisinno hoti unnÄdiniyÄ uccÄsaddamahÄsaddÄya anekavihitaá¹ƒ tiracchÄnakathaá¹ƒ kathentiyÄ. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ rÄjakathaá¹ƒ corakathaá¹ƒ mahÄmattakathaá¹ƒ senÄkathaá¹ƒ bhayakathaá¹ƒ yuddhakathaá¹ƒ annakathaá¹ƒ pÄnakathaá¹ƒ vatthakathaá¹ƒ sayanakathaá¹ƒ mÄlÄkathaá¹ƒ gandhakathaá¹ƒ Ã±Ätikathaá¹ƒ yÄnakathaá¹ƒ gÄmakathaá¹ƒ nigamakathaá¹ƒ nagarakathaá¹ƒ janapadakathaá¹ƒ itthikathaá¹ƒ sÅ«rakathaá¹ƒ visikhÄkathaá¹ƒ kumbhaá¹­á¹­hÄnakathaá¹ƒ pubbapetakathaá¹ƒ nÄnattakathaá¹ƒ lokakkhÄyikaá¹ƒ samuddakkhÄyikaá¹ƒ itibhavÄbhavakathaá¹ƒ iti vÄ. 409. addasÄ kho poá¹­á¹­hapÄdo paribbÄjako bhagavantaá¹ƒ dÅ«ratova Ägacchantaá¹ƒ, disvÄna sakaá¹ƒ parisaá¹ƒ saá¹‡á¹­hapesi â€“ "appasaddÄ bhonto hontu, mÄ bhonto saddamakattha. ayaá¹ƒ samaá¹‡o gotamo Ägacchati. appasaddakÄmo kho so ÄyasmÄ appasaddassa vaá¹‡á¹‡avÄdÄ«. appeva nÄma appasaddaá¹ƒ parisaá¹ƒ viditvÄ upasaá¹…kamitabbaá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±eyyÄ"ti. evaá¹ƒ vutte te paribbÄjakÄ tuá¹‡hÄ« ahesuá¹ƒ.
Thus have I heard: On one occasion the Blessed One was dwelling at SÄvatthÄ« in Jeta's Grove, at AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ika's monastery. Now at that time Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda the wanderer was staying at the single-pavilion rest house in the Tinduka grove, a place for philosophical debates, together with a large company of wanderers, with about three hundred wanderers. Then, in the morning, the Blessed One, having dressed and taken his bowl and robe, entered SÄvatthÄ« for alms.
407. 9. poá¹­á¹­hapÄdasuttaá¹ƒ poá¹­á¹­hapÄdaparibbÄjakavatthu 406. evaá¹ƒ me sutaá¹ƒ â€“ ekaá¹ƒ samayaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ sÄvatthiyaá¹ƒ viharati jetavane anÄthapiá¹‡á¸ikassa ÄrÄme. tena kho pana samayena poá¹­á¹­hapÄdo paribbÄjako samayappavÄdake tindukÄcÄ«re ekasÄlake mallikÄya ÄrÄme paá¹­ivasati mahatiyÄ paribbÄjakaparisÄya saddhiá¹ƒ tiá¹ƒsamattehi paribbÄjakasatehi. atha kho bhagavÄ pubbaá¹‡hasamayaá¹ƒ nivÄsetvÄ pattacÄ«varamÄdÄya sÄvatthiá¹ƒ piá¹‡á¸Äya pÄvisi. 407. atha kho bhagavato etadahosi â€“ "atippago kho tÄva sÄvatthiyaá¹ƒ piá¹‡á¸Äya carituá¹ƒ. yaá¹ƒnÅ«nÄhaá¹ƒ yena samayappavÄdako tindukÄcÄ«ro ekasÄlako mallikÄya ÄrÄmo, yena poá¹­á¹­hapÄdo paribbÄjako tenupasaá¹…kameyya"nti. atha kho bhagavÄ yena samayappavÄdako tindukÄcÄ«ro ekasÄlako mallikÄya ÄrÄmo tenupasaá¹…kami. 408. tena kho pana samayena poá¹­á¹­hapÄdo paribbÄjako mahatiyÄ paribbÄjakaparisÄya saddhiá¹ƒ nisinno hoti unnÄdiniyÄ uccÄsaddamahÄsaddÄya anekavihitaá¹ƒ tiracchÄnakathaá¹ƒ kathentiyÄ. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ rÄjakathaá¹ƒ corakathaá¹ƒ mahÄmattakathaá¹ƒ senÄkathaá¹ƒ bhayakathaá¹ƒ yuddhakathaá¹ƒ annakathaá¹ƒ pÄnakathaá¹ƒ vatthakathaá¹ƒ sayanakathaá¹ƒ mÄlÄkathaá¹ƒ gandhakathaá¹ƒ Ã±Ätikathaá¹ƒ yÄnakathaá¹ƒ gÄmakathaá¹ƒ nigamakathaá¹ƒ nagarakathaá¹ƒ janapadakathaá¹ƒ itthikathaá¹ƒ sÅ«rakathaá¹ƒ visikhÄkathaá¹ƒ kumbhaá¹­á¹­hÄnakathaá¹ƒ pubbapetakathaá¹ƒ nÄnattakathaá¹ƒ lokakkhÄyikaá¹ƒ samuddakkhÄyikaá¹ƒ itibhavÄbhavakathaá¹ƒ iti vÄ. 409. addasÄ kho poá¹­á¹­hapÄdo paribbÄjako bhagavantaá¹ƒ dÅ«ratova Ägacchantaá¹ƒ, disvÄna sakaá¹ƒ parisaá¹ƒ saá¹‡á¹­hapesi â€“ "appasaddÄ bhonto hontu, mÄ bhonto saddamakattha. ayaá¹ƒ samaá¹‡o gotamo Ägacchati. appasaddakÄmo kho so ÄyasmÄ appasaddassa vaá¹‡á¹‡avÄdÄ«. appeva nÄma appasaddaá¹ƒ parisaá¹ƒ viditvÄ upasaá¹…kamitabbaá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±eyyÄ"ti. evaá¹ƒ vutte te paribbÄjakÄ tuá¹‡hÄ« ahesuá¹ƒ.
Then the Blessed One considered: â€œIt is still too early to wander for alms in SÄvatthÄ«. Why don't I go to Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda the wanderer at the single-pavilion rest house in the Tinduka grove, a place for philosophical debates." Then the Blessed One went to Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda the wanderer at the single-pavilion rest house in the Tinduka grove, a place for philosophical debates.
408. 9. poá¹­á¹­hapÄdasuttaá¹ƒ poá¹­á¹­hapÄdaparibbÄjakavatthu 406. evaá¹ƒ me sutaá¹ƒ â€“ ekaá¹ƒ samayaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ sÄvatthiyaá¹ƒ viharati jetavane anÄthapiá¹‡á¸ikassa ÄrÄme. tena kho pana samayena poá¹­á¹­hapÄdo paribbÄjako samayappavÄdake tindukÄcÄ«re ekasÄlake mallikÄya ÄrÄme paá¹­ivasati mahatiyÄ paribbÄjakaparisÄya saddhiá¹ƒ tiá¹ƒsamattehi paribbÄjakasatehi. atha kho bhagavÄ pubbaá¹‡hasamayaá¹ƒ nivÄsetvÄ pattacÄ«varamÄdÄya sÄvatthiá¹ƒ piá¹‡á¸Äya pÄvisi. 407. atha kho bhagavato etadahosi â€“ "atippago kho tÄva sÄvatthiyaá¹ƒ piá¹‡á¸Äya carituá¹ƒ. yaá¹ƒnÅ«nÄhaá¹ƒ yena samayappavÄdako tindukÄcÄ«ro ekasÄlako mallikÄya ÄrÄmo, yena poá¹­á¹­hapÄdo paribbÄjako tenupasaá¹…kameyya"nti. atha kho bhagavÄ yena samayappavÄdako tindukÄcÄ«ro ekasÄlako mallikÄya ÄrÄmo tenupasaá¹…kami. 408. tena kho pana samayena poá¹­á¹­hapÄdo paribbÄjako mahatiyÄ paribbÄjakaparisÄya saddhiá¹ƒ nisinno hoti unnÄdiniyÄ uccÄsaddamahÄsaddÄya anekavihitaá¹ƒ tiracchÄnakathaá¹ƒ kathentiyÄ. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ rÄjakathaá¹ƒ corakathaá¹ƒ mahÄmattakathaá¹ƒ senÄkathaá¹ƒ bhayakathaá¹ƒ yuddhakathaá¹ƒ annakathaá¹ƒ pÄnakathaá¹ƒ vatthakathaá¹ƒ sayanakathaá¹ƒ mÄlÄkathaá¹ƒ gandhakathaá¹ƒ Ã±Ätikathaá¹ƒ yÄnakathaá¹ƒ gÄmakathaá¹ƒ nigamakathaá¹ƒ nagarakathaá¹ƒ janapadakathaá¹ƒ itthikathaá¹ƒ sÅ«rakathaá¹ƒ visikhÄkathaá¹ƒ kumbhaá¹­á¹­hÄnakathaá¹ƒ pubbapetakathaá¹ƒ nÄnattakathaá¹ƒ lokakkhÄyikaá¹ƒ samuddakkhÄyikaá¹ƒ itibhavÄbhavakathaá¹ƒ iti vÄ. 409. addasÄ kho poá¹­á¹­hapÄdo paribbÄjako bhagavantaá¹ƒ dÅ«ratova Ägacchantaá¹ƒ, disvÄna sakaá¹ƒ parisaá¹ƒ saá¹‡á¹­hapesi â€“ "appasaddÄ bhonto hontu, mÄ bhonto saddamakattha. ayaá¹ƒ samaá¹‡o gotamo Ägacchati. appasaddakÄmo kho so ÄyasmÄ appasaddassa vaá¹‡á¹‡avÄdÄ«. appeva nÄma appasaddaá¹ƒ parisaá¹ƒ viditvÄ upasaá¹…kamitabbaá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±eyyÄ"ti. evaá¹ƒ vutte te paribbÄjakÄ tuá¹‡hÄ« ahesuá¹ƒ.
Now at that time Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda the wanderer was sitting with a large company of wanderers, making a great noise and racket, engaged in many kinds of trifling talk, such as: Talk about kings, robbers, ministers, armies, dangers, war, food, drink, clothing, beds, garlands, perfumes, relatives, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, countries, women, heroes, street gossip, well gossip, tales of the departed, and speculations about land and sea, talk of being and non-being.
409. 9. poá¹­á¹­hapÄdasuttaá¹ƒ poá¹­á¹­hapÄdaparibbÄjakavatthu 406. evaá¹ƒ me sutaá¹ƒ â€“ ekaá¹ƒ samayaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ sÄvatthiyaá¹ƒ viharati jetavane anÄthapiá¹‡á¸ikassa ÄrÄme. tena kho pana samayena poá¹­á¹­hapÄdo paribbÄjako samayappavÄdake tindukÄcÄ«re ekasÄlake mallikÄya ÄrÄme paá¹­ivasati mahatiyÄ paribbÄjakaparisÄya saddhiá¹ƒ tiá¹ƒsamattehi paribbÄjakasatehi. atha kho bhagavÄ pubbaá¹‡hasamayaá¹ƒ nivÄsetvÄ pattacÄ«varamÄdÄya sÄvatthiá¹ƒ piá¹‡á¸Äya pÄvisi. 407. atha kho bhagavato etadahosi â€“ "atippago kho tÄva sÄvatthiyaá¹ƒ piá¹‡á¸Äya carituá¹ƒ. yaá¹ƒnÅ«nÄhaá¹ƒ yena samayappavÄdako tindukÄcÄ«ro ekasÄlako mallikÄya ÄrÄmo, yena poá¹­á¹­hapÄdo paribbÄjako tenupasaá¹…kameyya"nti. atha kho bhagavÄ yena samayappavÄdako tindukÄcÄ«ro ekasÄlako mallikÄya ÄrÄmo tenupasaá¹…kami. 408. tena kho pana samayena poá¹­á¹­hapÄdo paribbÄjako mahatiyÄ paribbÄjakaparisÄya saddhiá¹ƒ nisinno hoti unnÄdiniyÄ uccÄsaddamahÄsaddÄya anekavihitaá¹ƒ tiracchÄnakathaá¹ƒ kathentiyÄ. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ rÄjakathaá¹ƒ corakathaá¹ƒ mahÄmattakathaá¹ƒ senÄkathaá¹ƒ bhayakathaá¹ƒ yuddhakathaá¹ƒ annakathaá¹ƒ pÄnakathaá¹ƒ vatthakathaá¹ƒ sayanakathaá¹ƒ mÄlÄkathaá¹ƒ gandhakathaá¹ƒ Ã±Ätikathaá¹ƒ yÄnakathaá¹ƒ gÄmakathaá¹ƒ nigamakathaá¹ƒ nagarakathaá¹ƒ janapadakathaá¹ƒ itthikathaá¹ƒ sÅ«rakathaá¹ƒ visikhÄkathaá¹ƒ kumbhaá¹­á¹­hÄnakathaá¹ƒ pubbapetakathaá¹ƒ nÄnattakathaá¹ƒ lokakkhÄyikaá¹ƒ samuddakkhÄyikaá¹ƒ itibhavÄbhavakathaá¹ƒ iti vÄ. 409. addasÄ kho poá¹­á¹­hapÄdo paribbÄjako bhagavantaá¹ƒ dÅ«ratova Ägacchantaá¹ƒ, disvÄna sakaá¹ƒ parisaá¹ƒ saá¹‡á¹­hapesi â€“ "appasaddÄ bhonto hontu, mÄ bhonto saddamakattha. ayaá¹ƒ samaá¹‡o gotamo Ägacchati. appasaddakÄmo kho so ÄyasmÄ appasaddassa vaá¹‡á¹‡avÄdÄ«. appeva nÄma appasaddaá¹ƒ parisaá¹ƒ viditvÄ upasaá¹…kamitabbaá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±eyyÄ"ti. evaá¹ƒ vutte te paribbÄjakÄ tuá¹‡hÄ« ahesuá¹ƒ.
Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda the wanderer saw the Blessed One coming from afar. Seeing him, he hushed his own company: â€œBe quiet, good sirs! Do not make a noise! The contemplative Gotama is coming. That venerable one desires quiet and speaks in praise of quiet. Perhaps, knowing our company to be quiet, he will consider it worthwhile to visit us." When this was said, those wanderers became silent.
410. 410. atha kho bhagavÄ yena poá¹­á¹­hapÄdo paribbÄjako tenupasaá¹…kami. atha kho poá¹­á¹­hapÄdo paribbÄjako bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "etu kho, bhante, bhagavÄ. svÄgataá¹ƒ, bhante, bhagavato. cirassaá¹ƒ kho, bhante, bhagavÄ imaá¹ƒ pariyÄyamakÄsi, yadidaá¹ƒ idhÄgamanÄya. nisÄ«datu, bhante, bhagavÄ, idaá¹ƒ Äsanaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±atta"nti. nisÄ«di bhagavÄ paÃ±Ã±atte Äsane. poá¹­á¹­hapÄdopi kho paribbÄjako aÃ±Ã±ataraá¹ƒ nÄ«caá¹ƒ Äsanaá¹ƒ gahetvÄ ekamantaá¹ƒ nisÄ«di. ekamantaá¹ƒ nisinnaá¹ƒ kho poá¹­á¹­hapÄdaá¹ƒ paribbÄjakaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ etadavoca â€“ "kÄya nuttha [kÄya nottha (syÄ. ka.)], poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, etarahi kathÄya sannisinnÄ, kÄ ca pana vo antarÄkathÄ vippakatÄ"ti. abhisaÃ±Ã±ÄnirodhakathÄ 411. evaá¹ƒ vutte poá¹­á¹­hapÄdo paribbÄjako bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "tiá¹­á¹­hatesÄ, bhante, kathÄ, yÄya mayaá¹ƒ etarahi kathÄya sannisinnÄ. nesÄ, bhante, kathÄ bhagavato dullabhÄ bhavissati pacchÄpi savanÄya. purimÄni, bhante, divasÄni purimatarÄni, nÄnÄtitthiyÄnaá¹ƒ samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ kotÅ«halasÄlÄya sannisinnÄnaá¹ƒ sannipatitÄnaá¹ƒ abhisaÃ±Ã±Änirodhe kathÄ udapÄdi â€“ â€˜kathaá¹ƒ nu kho, bho, abhisaÃ±Ã±Änirodho hotÄ«â€™ti? tatrekacce evamÄhaá¹ƒsu â€“ â€˜ahetÅ« appaccayÄ purisassa saÃ±Ã±Ä uppajjantipi nirujjhantipi. yasmiá¹ƒ samaye uppajjanti, saÃ±Ã±Ä« tasmiá¹ƒ samaye hoti. yasmiá¹ƒ samaye nirujjhanti, asaÃ±Ã±Ä« tasmiá¹ƒ samaye hotÄ«â€™ti. ittheke abhisaÃ±Ã±Änirodhaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti. "tamaÃ±Ã±o evamÄha â€“ â€˜na kho pana metaá¹ƒ [na kho nÄmetaá¹ƒ (sÄ«. pÄ«.)], bho, evaá¹ƒ bhavissati. saÃ±Ã±Ä hi, bho, purisassa attÄ. sÄ ca kho upetipi apetipi. yasmiá¹ƒ samaye upeti, saÃ±Ã±Ä« tasmiá¹ƒ samaye hoti. yasmiá¹ƒ samaye apeti, asaÃ±Ã±Ä« tasmiá¹ƒ samaye hotÄ«â€™ti. ittheke abhisaÃ±Ã±Änirodhaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti. "tamaÃ±Ã±o evamÄha â€“ â€˜na kho pana metaá¹ƒ, bho, evaá¹ƒ bhavissati. santi hi, bho, samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä mahiddhikÄ mahÄnubhÄvÄ. te imassa purisassa saÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ upakaá¸á¸hantipi apakaá¸á¸hantipi. yasmiá¹ƒ samaye upakaá¸á¸hanti, saÃ±Ã±Ä« tasmiá¹ƒ
Then the Blessed One approached Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda the wanderer. Then Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda the wanderer said to the Blessed One: â€œCome, Blessed One! Welcome, Blessed One! It is a long time, Blessed One, since you have made an opportunity to come here. Please sit down, Blessed One; this seat is ready." The Blessed One sat down on the prepared seat. And Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda the wanderer, taking a low seat, sat down at one side. As he was sitting to one side, the Blessed One said to Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda the wanderer: â€œWith what discussion were you engaged just now? What was the discussion between you that was interrupted?â€ The discussion about the cessation of perception (*abhisaÃ±Ã±ÄnirodhakathÄ*).
411. 410. atha kho bhagavÄ yena poá¹­á¹­hapÄdo paribbÄjako tenupasaá¹…kami. atha kho poá¹­á¹­hapÄdo paribbÄjako bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "etu kho, bhante, bhagavÄ. svÄgataá¹ƒ, bhante, bhagavato. cirassaá¹ƒ kho, bhante, bhagavÄ imaá¹ƒ pariyÄyamakÄsi, yadidaá¹ƒ idhÄgamanÄya. nisÄ«datu, bhante, bhagavÄ, idaá¹ƒ Äsanaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±atta"nti. nisÄ«di bhagavÄ paÃ±Ã±atte Äsane. poá¹­á¹­hapÄdopi kho paribbÄjako aÃ±Ã±ataraá¹ƒ nÄ«caá¹ƒ Äsanaá¹ƒ gahetvÄ ekamantaá¹ƒ nisÄ«di. ekamantaá¹ƒ nisinnaá¹ƒ kho poá¹­á¹­hapÄdaá¹ƒ paribbÄjakaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ etadavoca â€“ "kÄya nuttha [kÄya nottha (syÄ. ka.)], poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, etarahi kathÄya sannisinnÄ, kÄ ca pana vo antarÄkathÄ vippakatÄ"ti. abhisaÃ±Ã±ÄnirodhakathÄ 411. evaá¹ƒ vutte poá¹­á¹­hapÄdo paribbÄjako bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "tiá¹­á¹­hatesÄ, bhante, kathÄ, yÄya mayaá¹ƒ etarahi kathÄya sannisinnÄ. nesÄ, bhante, kathÄ bhagavato dullabhÄ bhavissati pacchÄpi savanÄya. purimÄni, bhante, divasÄni purimatarÄni, nÄnÄtitthiyÄnaá¹ƒ samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ kotÅ«halasÄlÄya sannisinnÄnaá¹ƒ sannipatitÄnaá¹ƒ abhisaÃ±Ã±Änirodhe kathÄ udapÄdi â€“ â€˜kathaá¹ƒ nu kho, bho, abhisaÃ±Ã±Änirodho hotÄ«â€™ti? tatrekacce evamÄhaá¹ƒsu â€“ â€˜ahetÅ« appaccayÄ purisassa saÃ±Ã±Ä uppajjantipi nirujjhantipi. yasmiá¹ƒ samaye uppajjanti, saÃ±Ã±Ä« tasmiá¹ƒ samaye hoti. yasmiá¹ƒ samaye nirujjhanti, asaÃ±Ã±Ä« tasmiá¹ƒ samaye hotÄ«â€™ti. ittheke abhisaÃ±Ã±Änirodhaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti. "tamaÃ±Ã±o evamÄha â€“ â€˜na kho pana metaá¹ƒ [na kho nÄmetaá¹ƒ (sÄ«. pÄ«.)], bho, evaá¹ƒ bhavissati. saÃ±Ã±Ä hi, bho, purisassa attÄ. sÄ ca kho upetipi apetipi. yasmiá¹ƒ samaye upeti, saÃ±Ã±Ä« tasmiá¹ƒ samaye hoti. yasmiá¹ƒ samaye apeti, asaÃ±Ã±Ä« tasmiá¹ƒ samaye hotÄ«â€™ti. ittheke abhisaÃ±Ã±Änirodhaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apenti. "tamaÃ±Ã±o evamÄha â€“ â€˜na kho pana metaá¹ƒ, bho, evaá¹ƒ bhavissati. santi hi, bho, samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä mahiddhikÄ mahÄnubhÄvÄ. te imassa purisassa saÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ upakaá¸á¸hantipi apakaá¸á¸hantipi. yasmiá¹ƒ samaye upakaá¸á¸hanti, saÃ±Ã±Ä« tasmiá¹ƒ
When this was said, Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda the wanderer said to the Blessed One: â€œLet that discussion rest, venerable sir, with which we were engaged just now. It will not be difficult for the Blessed One to hear of that discussion later. Some time ago, venerable sir, when various ascetics and brahmins, adherents of other views, were gathered and assembled in the hall of debate, a discussion on the cessation of perception arose: â€˜How, indeed, does the cessation of perception occur?â€™ Some said thus: â€˜Without a cause, without a condition, perceptions arise and cease in a person. At the time when they arise, at that time one is percipient. At the time when they cease, at that time one is non-percipient.â€™ In this way, some describe the cessation of perception. But another one says thus: â€˜It is not so!" pÄ«. â€™ â€˜Yes, sir, thatâ€™s how it will be.â€™ Perception (*saÃ±Ã±Ä*) is a personâ€™s self (*attÄ*), sir. which comes and goes. When it comes, one is percipient. When it goes, one is not percipient.â€™ Thatâ€™s how one group described the ultimate cessation of perception (*abhisaÃ±Ã±Änirodhaá¹ƒ*). â€œThen someone else said, â€˜No, thatâ€™s not how it is. for there are contemplatives and Brahmins (*samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä*) of great power, great potency (*mahiddhikÄ mahÄnubhÄvÄ*). They draw perception in and out of a person. When they draw it in, one is percipient. It is at that time. When they draw it out, one is not percipient.â€™ Thatâ€™s how one group described the ultimate cessation of perception (abhisaÃ±Ã±Änirodha). â€œThen someone else said, â€˜No, thatâ€™s not how it is. for there are gods (*devatÄ*) of great power, great potency. They draw perception in and out of a person. When they draw it in, one is percipient. When they draw it out, one is not percipient.â€™ Thatâ€™s how one group described the ultimate cessation of perception (abhisaÃ±Ã±Änirodha). â€œThen the memory of the Blessed One (*bhagavÄ*) arose within me: â€˜Ah, the Blessed One! Ah, the One Well-Goneâ€”who surely is well-skilled in these matters.â€™ The Blessed One (*bhagavÄ*) is skilled and expert in the ultimate cessation of perception (abhisaÃ±Ã±Änirodha). So what, lord, is the ultimate cessation of perception (abhisaÃ±Ã±Änirodha)?â€ A discussion about the arising and ceasing of perception with a cause.

"tatra, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, ye te samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä evamÄhaá¹ƒsu â€“ â€˜ahetÅ« appaccayÄ purisassa saÃ±Ã±Ä uppajjantipi nirujjhantipÄ«â€™ti, Äditova tesaá¹ƒ aparaddhaá¹ƒ. taá¹ƒ kissa hetu? sahetÅ« hi, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, sappaccayÄ purisassa saÃ±Ã±Ä uppajjantipi nirujjhantipi. sikkhÄ ekÄ saÃ±Ã±Ä uppajjati, sikkhÄ ekÄ saÃ±Ã±Ä nirujjhati". 413. "kÄ ca sikkhÄ"ti? bhagavÄ avoca â€“ "idha, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, tathÄgato loke uppajjati arahaá¹ƒ, sammÄsambuddhoâ€¦peâ€¦ (yathÄ 190-212 anucchedesu, evaá¹ƒ vitthÄretabbaá¹ƒ). evaá¹ƒ kho, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, bhikkhu sÄ«lasampanno hotiâ€¦peâ€¦ tassime paÃ±canÄ«varaá¹‡e pahÄ«ne attani samanupassato pÄmojjaá¹ƒ jÄyati, pamuditassa pÄ«ti jÄyati, pÄ«timanassa kÄyo passambhati, passaddhakÄyo sukhaá¹ƒ vedeti, sukhino cittaá¹ƒ samÄdhiyati. so vivicceva kÄmehi, vivicca akusalehi dhammehi, savitakkaá¹ƒ savicÄraá¹ƒ vivekajaá¹ƒ pÄ«tisukhaá¹ƒ paá¹­hamaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒ upasampajja viharati. tassa yÄ purimÄ kÄmasaÃ±Ã±Ä, sÄ nirujjhati. vivekajapÄ«tisukhasukhumasaccasaÃ±Ã±Ä tasmiá¹ƒ samaye hoti, vivekajapÄ«tisukhasukhuma-saccasaÃ±Ã±Ä«yeva tasmiá¹ƒ samaye hoti. evampi sikkhÄ ekÄ saÃ±Ã±Ä uppajjati, sikkhÄ ekÄ saÃ±Ã±Ä nirujjhati. ayaá¹ƒ sikkhÄ"ti bhagavÄ avoca.
â€œIn this regard, Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, those contemplatives & brahmans who say that a personâ€™s perception arises & ceases without cause, without reason, are wrong from the very start. Why is that? Because a personâ€™s perception arises & ceases with a cause, with a reason. With training, one perception (*saÃ±Ã±Ä*) arises and with training another perception (*saÃ±Ã±Ä*) ceases.â€

"And what is training (sikkhÄ)?" The Blessed One (*bhagavÄ*) said: "Here, Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, the TathÄgata arises in the world, a worthy one, a fully awakened one...pe... (as in sections 190-212, so it should be expanded). â€œThis is how a monk is consummate in virtue.â€¦ â€œSeeing that these five hindrances have been abandoned within him, he becomes glad. Glad, he becomes enraptured. Enraptured, his body grows tranquil. His body tranquil, he is sensitive to pleasure. Feeling pleasure, his mind becomes concentrated. â€œQuite secluded from sensuality, secluded from unskillful qualities, the monk enters & remains in the first *jhÄna*: rapture & pleasure born of seclusion, accompanied by directed thought & evaluation. His earlier perception of sensuality ceases. and on that occasion there is a perception of a refined truth of rapture & pleasure born of seclusion. On that occasion he is one who is percipient of a refined truth of rapture & pleasure born of seclusion. And thus it is that with training one perception arises and with training another perception ceases. This is training (sikkhÄ)," said the Blessed One (*bhagavÄ*). â€œAnd further, Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, with the complete transcending of the dimension of the infinitude of space (*ÄkÄsÄnaÃ±cÄyatana*), thinking, â€˜Infinite consciousness,â€™ the monk enters & remains in the dimension of the infinitude of consciousness (*viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aÃ±cÄyatana*). His earlier perception of a refined truth of the dimension of the infinitude of space (*ÄkÄsÄnaÃ±cÄyatana-sukhumasacca-saÃ±Ã±Ä*) ceases. And on that occasion there is a perception of a refined truth of the dimension of the infinitude of consciousness (*viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aÃ±cÄyatana-sukhumasacca-saÃ±Ã±Ä*). On that occasion he is one who is percipient of a refined truth of the dimension of the infinitude of consciousness (*viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aÃ±cÄyatana-sukhumasacca-saÃ±Ã±Ä«*). And thus it is that with training one perception (*saÃ±Ã±Ä*) arises and with training another perception (*saÃ±Ã±Ä*) ceases. This too is a training," the Blessed One said. â€œAnd further, Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, with the complete transcending of the dimension of the infinitude of consciousness (*viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aÃ±cÄyatana*), thinking, â€˜There is nothing,â€™ enters & remains in the dimension of nothingness (*ÄkiÃ±caÃ±Ã±Äyatana*). His earlier perception of a refined truth of the dimension of the infinitude of consciousness (*viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aÃ±cÄyatana-sukhumasacca-saÃ±Ã±Ä*) ceases. and on that occasion there is a perception of a refined truth of the dimension of nothingness (*ÄkiÃ±caÃ±Ã±Äyatana-sukhumasacca-saÃ±Ã±Ä*). On that occasion he is one who is percipient of a refined truth of the dimension of nothingness (*ÄkiÃ±caÃ±Ã±Äyatana-sukhumasacca-saÃ±Ã±Ä«*). And thus it is that with training one perception (*saÃ±Ã±Ä*) arises and with training another perception (*saÃ±Ã±Ä*) ceases. This too is a training," the Blessed One said.

"puna caparaá¹ƒ, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, bhikkhu sabbaso ÄkÄsÄnaÃ±cÄyatanaá¹ƒ samatikkamma â€˜anantaá¹ƒ viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aâ€™nti viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aÃ±cÄyatanaá¹ƒ upasampajja viharati. tassa yÄ purimÄ ÄkÄsÄnaÃ±cÄyatanasukhumasaccasaÃ±Ã±Ä, sÄ nirujjhati. viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aÃ±cÄyatanasukhumasaccasaÃ±Ã±Ä tasmiá¹ƒ samaye hoti, viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aÃ±cÄyatanasukhumasaccasaÃ±Ã±Ä«yeva tasmiá¹ƒ samaye hoti. evampi sikkhÄ ekÄ saÃ±Ã±Ä uppajjati, sikkhÄ ekÄ saÃ±Ã±Ä nirujjhati. ayampi sikkhÄ"ti bhagavÄ avoca. "puna caparaá¹ƒ, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, bhikkhu sabbaso viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aÃ±cÄyatanaá¹ƒ samatikkamma â€˜natthi kiÃ±cÄ«â€™ti ÄkiÃ±caÃ±Ã±Äyatanaá¹ƒ upasampajja viharati. tassa yÄ purimÄ viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aÃ±cÄyatanasukhumasaccasaÃ±Ã±Ä, sÄ nirujjhati. ÄkiÃ±caÃ±Ã±ÄyatanasukhumasaccasaÃ±Ã±Ä tasmiá¹ƒ samaye hoti, ÄkiÃ±caÃ±Ã±ÄyatanasukhumasaccasaÃ±Ã±Ä«yeva tasmiá¹ƒ samaye hoti. evampi sikkhÄ ekÄ saÃ±Ã±Ä uppajjati, sikkhÄ ekÄ saÃ±Ã±Ä nirujjhati. ayampi sikkhÄ"ti bhagavÄ avoca. 414. "yato kho, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, bhikkhu idha sakasaÃ±Ã±Ä« hoti, so tato amutra tato amutra anupubbena saÃ±Ã±aggaá¹ƒ phusati. tassa saÃ±Ã±agge á¹­hitassa evaá¹ƒ hoti â€“ â€˜cetayamÄnassa me pÄpiyo, acetayamÄnassa me seyyo. ahaÃ±ceva kho pana ceteyyaá¹ƒ, abhisaá¹…khareyyaá¹ƒ, imÄ ca me saÃ±Ã±Ä nirujjheyyuá¹ƒ, aÃ±Ã±Ä ca oá¸·ÄrikÄ saÃ±Ã±Ä uppajjeyyuá¹ƒ, yaá¹ƒnÅ«nÄhaá¹ƒ na ceva ceteyyaá¹ƒ na ca abhisaá¹…khareyyaâ€™nti. so na ceva ceteti, na ca abhisaá¹…kharoti. tassa acetayato anabhisaá¹…kharoto tÄ ceva saÃ±Ã±Ä nirujjhanti, aÃ±Ã±Ä ca oá¸·ÄrikÄ saÃ±Ã±Ä na uppajjanti. so nirodhaá¹ƒ phusati. evaá¹ƒ kho, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, anupubbÄbhisaÃ±Ã±Änirodha-sampajÄna-samÄpatti hoti. "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, api nu te ito pubbe evarÅ«pÄ anupubbÄbhisaÃ±Ã±Änirodha-sampajÄna-samÄpatti sutapubbÄ"ti? "no hetaá¹ƒ, bhante. evaá¹ƒ kho ahaá¹ƒ, bhante, bhagavato bhÄsitaá¹ƒ ÄjÄnÄmi â€“ â€˜yato kho, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, bhikkhu idha sakasaÃ±Ã±Ä« hoti, so tato amutra tato amutra anupubbena saÃ±Ã±aggaá¹ƒ phusati, tassa saÃ±Ã±agge á¹­hitassa evaá¹ƒ hoti â€“ "cetayamÄnassa me pÄpiyo, acetayamÄnassa me seyyo. ahaÃ±ceva kho pana
â€œNow, when the monk is percipient of himself here, then from there to there, step by step, he touches the peak of perception (*saÃ±Ã±agga*). As he remains at the peak of perception (*saÃ±Ã±agga*), the thought occurs to him, â€˜Thinking is bad for me. Not thinking is better for me.' If I were to think and will, these perceptions (*saÃ±Ã±Ä*) of mine would cease, and other gross perceptions (*saÃ±Ã±Ä*) would appear. What if I were neither to think nor to will?â€™ So he neither thinks nor wills. and as he is neither thinking nor willing, those very perceptions (*saÃ±Ã±Ä*) cease and other, grosser perceptions (*saÃ±Ã±Ä*) do not appear. He touches cessation (*nirodhaá¹ƒ phusati*). This, Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, is how there is the alert step-by step attainment of the cessation of perception (*anupubbÄbhisaÃ±Ã±Änirodha-sampajÄna-samÄpatti*). â€œNow what do you think, Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda? Have you ever before heard of such an alert step-by step attainment of the cessation of perception (*anupubbÄbhisaÃ±Ã±Änirodha-sampajÄna-samÄpatti*)?â€ â€œNo, venerable sir.â€ And here is how I understand the Dhamma taught by the Blessed One: â€˜When the monk is percipient of himself here, then from there to there, step by step, he touches the peak of perception (*saÃ±Ã±agga*). As he remains at the peak of perception (*saÃ±Ã±agga*), the thought occurs to him, "Thinking is bad for me. Not thinking is better for me. If I were to think and will, this perception of mine would cease, and a grosser perception would appear. What if I were neither to think nor to will?â€ So he neither thinks nor wills, and as he is neither thinking nor willing, that perception ceases and another, grosser perception does not appear. He touches cessation. (nirodhaá¹ƒ phusati) This, Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, is how there is the alert step-by step attainment of the ultimate cessation of perception.â€™ (evaá¹ƒ kho, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, anupubbÄbhisaÃ±Ã±Änirodha-sampajÄna-samÄpatti hotÄ«â€™'ti) â€œThatâ€™s right, Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda.â€ (evaá¹ƒ, poá¹­á¹­hapÄdÄ"ti) â€œBut, lord, does the Blessed One describe one peak of perception or many peaks of perception?â€ â€œPoá¹­á¹­hapÄda, I describe one peak of perception and many peaks of perception.â€ (ekampi kho ahaá¹ƒ, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, saÃ±Ã±aggaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apemi, puthÅ«pi saÃ±Ã±agge paÃ±Ã±apemÄ«"ti) â€œBut how, lord, does the Blessed One describe one peak of perception and many peaks of perception?â€ â€œPoá¹­á¹­hapÄda, in whatever way one touches cessation, in that way I describe a peak of perception. Thatâ€™s how I describe one peak of perception and many peaks of perception.â€ â€œNow, lord, does perception arise first, and knowledge after; or does knowledge arise first, and perception after; or do perception & knowledge arise simultaneously?â€ â€œPoá¹­á¹­hapÄda, perception arises first, and knowledge after. And the arising of knowledge comes from the arising of perception. One discerns, â€˜Itâ€™s in dependence on this that my knowledge has arisen.â€™ Through this line of reasoning one can realize how perception arises first, and knowledge after, and how the arising of knowledge comes from the arising of perception.â€ The Discourse about Perception and Self â€œNow, lord, is perception a personâ€™s self, or is perception one thing and self another?â€ â€œWhat sort of self do you posit, Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda?â€ â€œLord, I posit a gross self, possessed of form, made up of the four great elements, feeding on physical food.â€ â€œThen, Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, your self would be gross, possessed of form, made up of the four great elements, feeding on physical food. That being the case, then for you perception would be one thing and self another. And itâ€™s through this line of reasoning that one can realize how perception will be one thing and self another: even as there remains this gross selfâ€”possessed of form, made up of the four great elements, and feeding on foodâ€”one perception arises for that person as another perception passes away. Itâ€™s through this line of reasoning that one can realize how perception will be one thing and self another.â€ â€œThen, lord, I posit a mind-made self complete in all its parts, not inferior in its faculties.â€ â€œThen, Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, your self would be mind-made, complete in all its parts, not inferior in its faculties. That being the case, then for you perception would be one thing and self another. And itâ€™s through this line of reasoning that one can realize how perception will be one thing and self another. even as there remains this mind-made selfâ€”complete in all its parts, not inferior in its facultiesâ€”one perception arises for that person as another perception passes away. Itâ€™s through this line of reasoning that one can realize how perception will be one thing and self another.â€ â€œThen, lord, I posit a formless self made of perception.â€ (arÅ«piá¹ƒ kho ahaá¹ƒ, bhante, attÄnaá¹ƒ paccemi saÃ±Ã±Ämaya"nti.) â€œThen, Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, your self would be formless and made of perception. That being the case, then for you perception would be one thing and self another. And itâ€™s through this line of reasoning that one can realize how perception will be one thing and self another. â€even as there remains this formless self made of perception, one perception arises for that person as another perception passes away. Itâ€™s through this line of reasoning that one can realize how perception will be one thing and self another.â€ â€œIs it possible for me to know, lord, whether perception is a personâ€™s self or if perception is one thing and self another?â€ Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, since you have other views (aÃ±Ã±adiá¹­á¹­hika), other practices (aÃ±Ã±akhantika), other inclinations (aÃ±Ã±arucikena), other aims (aÃ±Ã±atrÄyogena), and other teachers (aÃ±Ã±atrÄcariyakena), it is difficult for you to know whether perception (saÃ±Ã±Ä) is a person's self (attÄ), or whether perception is one thing and the self another.
415. ceteyyaá¹ƒ abhisaá¹…khareyyaá¹ƒ, imÄ ca me saÃ±Ã±Ä nirujjheyyuá¹ƒ, aÃ±Ã±Ä ca oá¸·ÄrikÄ saÃ±Ã±Ä uppajjeyyuá¹ƒ, yaá¹ƒnÅ«nÄhaá¹ƒ na ceva ceteyyaá¹ƒ, na ca abhisaá¹…khareyya"nti. so na ceva ceteti, na cÄbhisaá¹…kharoti, tassa acetayato anabhisaá¹…kharoto tÄ ceva saÃ±Ã±Ä nirujjhanti, aÃ±Ã±Ä ca oá¸·ÄrikÄ saÃ±Ã±Ä na uppajjanti. so nirodhaá¹ƒ phusati. evaá¹ƒ kho, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, anupubbÄbhisaÃ±Ã±Änirodha-sampajÄna-samÄpatti hotÄ«"â€™ti. â€œNow, lord, does perception (saÃ±Ã±Ä) arise first, and knowledge (Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹ƒ) after; or does knowledge (Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹ƒ) arise first, and perception (saÃ±Ã±Ä) after; or do perception (saÃ±Ã±Ä) & knowledge (Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹ƒ) arise simultaneously?â€ â€œPoá¹­á¹­hapÄda, perception (saÃ±Ã±Ä) arises first, and knowledge (Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹ƒ) after. And the arising of knowledge (Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹ƒ) comes from the arising of perception (saÃ±Ã±Ä). One discerns, â€˜Itâ€™s in dependence on this that my knowledge (Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹ƒ) has arisen.â€™ Through this line of reasoning one can realize how perception (saÃ±Ã±Ä) arises first, and knowledge (Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹ƒ) after, and how the arising of knowledge (Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹ƒ) comes from the arising of perception (saÃ±Ã±Ä).â€ A talk on self and perception (saÃ±Ã±ÄattakathÄ).

â€œNow, lord, is perception (saÃ±Ã±Ä) a personâ€™s self (attÄ), or is perception (saÃ±Ã±Ä) one thing and self (attÄ) another?â€ â€œWhat kind of self (attÄ) do you posit, Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda?â€ â€œLord, I posit a gross self (attÄnaá¹ƒ), possessed of form (rÅ«piá¹ƒ), made up of the four great elements (cÄtumahÄbhÅ«tikaá¹ƒ), feeding on physical food (kabaá¸·Ä«kÄrÄhÄrabhakkhaá¹ƒ).â€ â€œThen, Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, your self (attÄ) would be gross (oá¸·Äriko), possessed of form (rÅ«pÄ«), made up of the four great elements (cÄtumahÄbhÅ«tiko), feeding on physical food (kabaá¸·Ä«kÄrÄhÄrabhakkho). That being the case, then for you perception (saÃ±Ã±Ä) would be one thing and self (attÄ) another. And itâ€™s through this line of reasoning that one can realize how perception (saÃ±Ã±Ä) will be one thing and self (attÄ) another. even as there remains this gross self (attÄ)â€”possessed of form (rÅ«pÄ«), made up of the four great elements (cÄtumahÄbhÅ«tiko), and feeding on foodâ€”one perception (saÃ±Ã±Ä) arises for that person as another perception (saÃ±Ã±Ä) passes away. "arÅ«piá¹ƒ kho ahaá¹ƒ, bhante, attÄnaá¹ƒ paccemi saÃ±Ã±Ämaya"nti.
