"sakkÄ panetaá¹ƒ, bhante, mayÄ Ã±Ätuá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜saÃ±Ã±Ä purisassa attÄâ€™ti vÄ â€˜aÃ±Ã±Äva saÃ±Ã±Ä aÃ±Ã±o attÄti vÄâ€™ti? "dujjÄnaá¹ƒ kho etaá¹ƒ [evaá¹ƒ (ka.)], poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, tayÄ aÃ±Ã±adiá¹­á¹­hikena aÃ±Ã±akhantikena aÃ±Ã±arucikena aÃ±Ã±atrÄyogena aÃ±Ã±atrÄcariyakena â€“ â€˜saÃ±Ã±Ä purisassa attÄâ€™ti vÄ, â€˜aÃ±Ã±Äva saÃ±Ã±Ä aÃ±Ã±o attÄti vÄ"â€™ti.
â€œIs it possible for me to know, lord, whether perception (saÃ±Ã±Ä) is a personâ€™s self (attÄ) or if perception (saÃ±Ã±Ä) is one thing and self (attÄ) another?â€ "Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, since you have other views (*aÃ±Ã±adiá¹­á¹­hi*), other practices (*aÃ±Ã±akhanti*), other preferences (*aÃ±Ã±aruci*), other aims (*aÃ±Ã±atrayoga*), and other teachers (*aÃ±Ã±atrÄcariyaka*), it is difficult for you to know whether perception (*saÃ±Ã±Ä*) is a person's self (*attÄ*), or whether perception is one thing and the self is another."
421. 421. atha kho te paribbÄjakÄ acirapakkantassa bhagavato poá¹­á¹­hapÄdaá¹ƒ paribbÄjakaá¹ƒ samantato vÄcÄ [vÄcÄya (syÄ. ka.)] sannitodakena saÃ±jhabbharimakaá¹ƒsu â€“ "evameva panÄyaá¹ƒ bhavaá¹ƒ poá¹­á¹­hapÄdo yaÃ±Ã±adeva samaá¹‡o gotamo bhÄsati, taá¹ƒ tadevassa abbhanumodati â€“ â€˜evametaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ evametaá¹ƒ, sugatÄâ€™ti. na kho pana mayaá¹ƒ kiÃ±ci [kaÃ±ci (pÄ«.)] samaá¹‡assa gotamassa ekaá¹ƒsikaá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ desitaá¹ƒ ÄjÄnÄma â€“ â€˜sassato lokoâ€™ti vÄ, â€˜asassato lokoâ€™ti vÄ, â€˜antavÄ lokoâ€™ti vÄ, â€˜anantavÄ lokoâ€™ti vÄ, â€˜taá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄ, â€˜aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄ, â€˜hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äâ€™ti vÄ, â€˜na hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äâ€™ti vÄ, â€˜hoti ca na ca hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äâ€™ti vÄ, â€˜neva hoti na na hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äâ€™ti vÄ"ti. evaá¹ƒ vutte poá¹­á¹­hapÄdo paribbÄjako te paribbÄjake etadavoca â€“ "ahampi kho, bho, na kiÃ±ci samaá¹‡assa gotamassa ekaá¹ƒsikaá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ desitaá¹ƒ ÄjÄnÄmi â€“ â€˜sassato lokoâ€™ti vÄ, â€˜asassato lokoâ€™ti vÄâ€¦peâ€¦ â€˜neva hoti na na hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äâ€™ti vÄ, api ca samaá¹‡o gotamo bhÅ«taá¹ƒ tacchaá¹ƒ tathaá¹ƒ paá¹­ipadaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apeti dhammaá¹­á¹­hitataá¹ƒ dhammaniyÄmataá¹ƒ. bhÅ«taá¹ƒ kho pana tacchaá¹ƒ tathaá¹ƒ paá¹­ipadaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apentassa dhammaá¹­á¹­hitataá¹ƒ dhammaniyÄmataá¹ƒ, kathaÃ±hi nÄma mÄdiso viÃ±Ã±Å« samaá¹‡assa gotamassa subhÄsitaá¹ƒ subhÄsitato nÄbbhanumodeyyÄ"ti? cittahatthisÄriputtapoá¹­á¹­hapÄdavatthu 422. atha kho dvÄ«hatÄ«hassa accayena citto ca hatthisÄriputto poá¹­á¹­hapÄdo ca paribbÄjako yena bhagavÄ tenupasaá¹…kamiá¹ƒsu, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ citto hatthisÄriputto bhagavantaá¹ƒ abhivÄdetvÄ ekamantaá¹ƒ nisÄ«di. poá¹­á¹­hapÄdo pana paribbÄjako bhagavatÄ saddhiá¹ƒ sammodi. sammodanÄ«yaá¹ƒ kathaá¹ƒ sÄraá¹‡Ä«yaá¹ƒ vÄ«tisÄretvÄ ekamantaá¹ƒ nisÄ«di. ekamantaá¹ƒ nisinno kho poá¹­á¹­hapÄdo paribbÄjako bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "tadÄ maá¹ƒ, bhante, te paribbÄjakÄ acirapakkantassa bhagavato samantato vÄcÄsannitodakena saÃ±jhabbharimakaá¹ƒsu â€“ â€˜evameva panÄyaá¹ƒ bhavaá¹ƒ poá¹­á¹­hapÄdo yaÃ±Ã±adeva
Then, the wanderers, not long after the Blessed One had left, jeered at Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda the wanderer from all sides with words like stinging darts, saying, "Indeed, whatever the contemplative Gotama says, Master Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda approves of it, saying, 'So it is, Blessed One! So it is, O Well-Gone!'" But we do not understand the ascetic Gotama to have taught any categorical *dhamma*, saying, "The world is eternal ( *sassato loko*)" or "The world is not eternal (*asassato loko*)," or "The world is finite (*antavÄ loko*) " or "The world is infinite (*anantavÄ loko*)," or "The life-principle (*jÄ«va*) is the same as the body (*sarÄ«ra*)" or "The life-principle is one thing, and the body another (*aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ sarÄ«ra*)," or "The *TathÄgata* exists after death (*hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä*)," or "The *TathÄgata* does not exist after death (*na hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä*)," or "The *TathÄgata* both exists and does not exist after death," or "The *TathÄgata* neither exists nor does not exist after death." When this was said, Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda the wanderer said to those wanderers, "I, too, friends, do not understand the ascetic Gotama to have taught any categorical *dhamma*, saying, 'The world is eternal' or 'The world is not eternal'â€¦ or 'The *TathÄgata* neither exists nor does not exist after death.' But the ascetic Gotama teaches a genuine, authentic, and accurate practice, grounded in the *dhamma* and consonant with the *dhamma*. And when a genuine, authentic, and accurate practice, grounded in the *dhamma* and consonant with the *dhamma* is being explained, why should a wise person such as myself not rejoice in the well-spokenness of the ascetic Gotama's well-spoken words?" The Story of Citta, Hatthissariputta and Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda.
422. 421. atha kho te paribbÄjakÄ acirapakkantassa bhagavato poá¹­á¹­hapÄdaá¹ƒ paribbÄjakaá¹ƒ samantato vÄcÄ [vÄcÄya (syÄ. ka.)] sannitodakena saÃ±jhabbharimakaá¹ƒsu â€“ "evameva panÄyaá¹ƒ bhavaá¹ƒ poá¹­á¹­hapÄdo yaÃ±Ã±adeva samaá¹‡o gotamo bhÄsati, taá¹ƒ tadevassa abbhanumodati â€“ â€˜evametaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ evametaá¹ƒ, sugatÄâ€™ti. na kho pana mayaá¹ƒ kiÃ±ci [kaÃ±ci (pÄ«.)] samaá¹‡assa gotamassa ekaá¹ƒsikaá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ desitaá¹ƒ ÄjÄnÄma â€“ â€˜sassato lokoâ€™ti vÄ, â€˜asassato lokoâ€™ti vÄ, â€˜antavÄ lokoâ€™ti vÄ, â€˜anantavÄ lokoâ€™ti vÄ, â€˜taá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄ, â€˜aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti vÄ, â€˜hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äâ€™ti vÄ, â€˜na hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äâ€™ti vÄ, â€˜hoti ca na ca hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äâ€™ti vÄ, â€˜neva hoti na na hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äâ€™ti vÄ"ti. evaá¹ƒ vutte poá¹­á¹­hapÄdo paribbÄjako te paribbÄjake etadavoca â€“ "ahampi kho, bho, na kiÃ±ci samaá¹‡assa gotamassa ekaá¹ƒsikaá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ desitaá¹ƒ ÄjÄnÄmi â€“ â€˜sassato lokoâ€™ti vÄ, â€˜asassato lokoâ€™ti vÄâ€¦peâ€¦ â€˜neva hoti na na hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äâ€™ti vÄ, api ca samaá¹‡o gotamo bhÅ«taá¹ƒ tacchaá¹ƒ tathaá¹ƒ paá¹­ipadaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apeti dhammaá¹­á¹­hitataá¹ƒ dhammaniyÄmataá¹ƒ. bhÅ«taá¹ƒ kho pana tacchaá¹ƒ tathaá¹ƒ paá¹­ipadaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apentassa dhammaá¹­á¹­hitataá¹ƒ dhammaniyÄmataá¹ƒ, kathaÃ±hi nÄma mÄdiso viÃ±Ã±Å« samaá¹‡assa gotamassa subhÄsitaá¹ƒ subhÄsitato nÄbbhanumodeyyÄ"ti? cittahatthisÄriputtapoá¹­á¹­hapÄdavatthu 422. atha kho dvÄ«hatÄ«hassa accayena citto ca hatthisÄriputto poá¹­á¹­hapÄdo ca paribbÄjako yena bhagavÄ tenupasaá¹…kamiá¹ƒsu, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ citto hatthisÄriputto bhagavantaá¹ƒ abhivÄdetvÄ ekamantaá¹ƒ nisÄ«di. poá¹­á¹­hapÄdo pana paribbÄjako bhagavatÄ saddhiá¹ƒ sammodi. sammodanÄ«yaá¹ƒ kathaá¹ƒ sÄraá¹‡Ä«yaá¹ƒ vÄ«tisÄretvÄ ekamantaá¹ƒ nisÄ«di. ekamantaá¹ƒ nisinno kho poá¹­á¹­hapÄdo paribbÄjako bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "tadÄ maá¹ƒ, bhante, te paribbÄjakÄ acirapakkantassa bhagavato samantato vÄcÄsannitodakena saÃ±jhabbharimakaá¹ƒsu â€“ â€˜evameva panÄyaá¹ƒ bhavaá¹ƒ poá¹­á¹­hapÄdo yaÃ±Ã±adeva
Then, after two or three days, Citta, Hatthissariputta, and Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda the wanderer went to the Blessed One. Having arrived, Citta, Hatthissariputta, bowed down to the Blessed One and sat down to one side. But Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda the wanderer exchanged greetings with the Blessed One. Having concluded their courteous and amiable conversation, he sat down to one side. Having sat down to one side, Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda the wanderer said to the Blessed One: "Venerable Sir, the other day the wanderers jeered at me on all sides, after you had recently departed, with words that stung like darts: â€˜Indeed, whatever the ascetic Gotama says, Master Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda approves, saying: â€˜So it is, Blessed One! The ascetic Gotama speaks, and Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda rejoices in his every word: â€œSo it is, Blessed One. So it is, O One Well-Gone.â€ But we donâ€™t understand the ascetic Gotama as having taught any categorical teaching as to whether the cosmos is eternal ( *sassato loko* ) or the cosmos is not eternal ( *asassato loko* ) or whether the cosmos is finite ( *antavÄ loko* ) or the cosmos is infinite ( *anantavÄ loko* ) or whether the soul & the body are the same ( *taá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ sarÄ«ra* ) or whether the soul is one thing and the body another ( *aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ sarÄ«ra* ) or whether after death a *TathÄgata* exists ( *hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä* ) or whether after death a *TathÄgata* does not exist ( *na hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä* ) or whether after death a *TathÄgata* both exists & does not exist ( *hoti ca na ca hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä* ) or whether after death a *TathÄgata* neither exists nor does not exist ( *neva hoti na na hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä* ).â€™ When this was said, I replied to the wanderers, â€˜I, too, donâ€™t understand the ascetic Gotama as having taught any categorical teaching as to whether the cosmos is eternal or the cosmos is not eternal â€¦whether after death a *TathÄgata* neither exists nor does not exist. But the ascetic Gotama describes a genuine, authentic, and accurate practice, grounded in the Dhamma and consonant with the Dhamma. And when a genuine, authentic, and accurate practice, grounded in the Dhamma and consonant with the Dhamma is being explained, why shouldnâ€™t a knowledgeable person such as myself rejoice in the well-spokenness of the ascetic Gotamaâ€™s well-spoken words?â€
423. samaá¹‡o gotamo bhÄsati, taá¹ƒ tadevassa abbhanumodati â€“ â€˜evametaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ evametaá¹ƒ sugatÄ"ti. na kho pana mayaá¹ƒ kiÃ±ci samaá¹‡assa gotamassa ekaá¹ƒsikaá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ desitaá¹ƒ ÄjÄnÄma â€“ "sassato loko"ti vÄ, "asassato loko"ti vÄ, "antavÄ loko"ti vÄ, "anantavÄ loko"ti vÄ, "taá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ sarÄ«ra"nti vÄ, "aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ sarÄ«ra"nti vÄ, "hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä"ti vÄ, "na hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä"ti vÄ, "hoti ca na ca hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä"ti vÄ, "neva hoti na na hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä"ti vÄâ€™ti. evaá¹ƒ vuttÄhaá¹ƒ, bhante, te paribbÄjake etadavocaá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜ahampi kho, bho, na kiÃ±ci samaá¹‡assa gotamassa ekaá¹ƒsikaá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ desitaá¹ƒ ÄjÄnÄmi â€“ "sassato loko"ti vÄ, "asassato loko"ti vÄâ€¦peâ€¦ "neva hoti na na hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä"ti vÄ, api ca samaá¹‡o gotamo bhÅ«taá¹ƒ tacchaá¹ƒ tathaá¹ƒ paá¹­ipadaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apeti dhammaá¹­á¹­hitataá¹ƒ dhammaniyÄmataá¹ƒ. bhÅ«taá¹ƒ kho pana tacchaá¹ƒ tathaá¹ƒ paá¹­ipadaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±apentassa dhammaá¹­á¹­hitataá¹ƒ dhammaniyÄmataá¹ƒ, kathaÃ±hi nÄma mÄdiso viÃ±Ã±Å« samaá¹‡assa gotamassa subhÄsitaá¹ƒ subhÄsitato nÄbbhanumodeyyÄ"ti? 423. "sabbeva kho ete, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, paribbÄjakÄ andhÄ acakkhukÄ, tvaá¹ƒyeva nesaá¹ƒ eko cakkhumÄ. ekaá¹ƒsikÄpi hi kho, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, mayÄ dhammÄ desitÄ paÃ±Ã±attÄ, anekaá¹ƒsikÄpi hi kho, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, mayÄ dhammÄ desitÄ paÃ±Ã±attÄ. "katame ca te, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, mayÄ anekaá¹ƒsikÄ dhammÄ desitÄ paÃ±Ã±attÄ? â€˜sassato lokoâ€™ti [lokoti vÄ (sÄ«. ka.)] kho, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, mayÄ anekaá¹ƒsiko dhammo desito paÃ±Ã±atto, â€˜asassato lokoâ€™ti [lokoti vÄ (sÄ«. ka.)] kho, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, mayÄ anekaá¹ƒsiko dhammo desito paÃ±Ã±atto, â€˜antavÄ lokoâ€™ti [lokoti vÄ (sÄ«. ka.)] kho poá¹­á¹­hapÄdaâ€¦peâ€¦ â€˜anantavÄ lokoâ€™ti [lokoti vÄ (sÄ«. ka.)] kho poá¹­á¹­hapÄdaâ€¦ â€˜taá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti kho poá¹­á¹­hapÄdaâ€¦ â€˜aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ sarÄ«raâ€™nti kho poá¹­á¹­hapÄdaâ€¦ â€˜hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äâ€™ti kho poá¹­á¹­hapÄdaâ€¦ na hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äâ€™ti kho poá¹­á¹­hapÄdaâ€¦ â€˜hoti ca na ca hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äâ€™ti kho poá¹­á¹­hapÄdaâ€¦
â€œPoá¹­á¹­hapÄda, all those wanderers are blind and have no eyes. You alone among them have eyes. I have taught and declared some teachings to be categorical, and some teachings to be not categorical. â€œAnd what are the teachings that I have taught and declared to be not categorical? â€˜The cosmos is eternalâ€™ ( *sassato loko* ), I have taught and declared to be a not categorical teaching. â€˜The cosmos is not eternalâ€™ ( *asassato loko* ), I have taught and declared to be a not categorical teaching. â€˜The cosmos is finiteâ€™ ( *antavÄ loko* )â€¦â€˜The cosmos is infiniteâ€™ ( *anantavÄ loko* )â€¦ â€˜The soul & the body are the sameâ€™ ( *taá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ sarÄ«ra* )â€¦ â€˜The soul is one thing and the body anotherâ€™ ( *aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ jÄ«vaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ sarÄ«ra* )â€¦ â€˜After death a *TathÄgata* existsâ€™ ( *hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä* )â€¦ â€˜After death a *TathÄgata* does not existâ€™ ( *na hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä* )â€¦ â€˜After death a *TathÄgata* both exists & does not existâ€™ ( *hoti ca na ca hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä* )â€¦ â€˜After death a *TathÄgata* neither exists nor does not existâ€™ ( *neva hoti na na hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä* ) I have taught and declared to be a not categorical teaching. â€œAnd why have I taught and declared these teachings to be not categorical? Because they are not conducive to the goal, are not conducive to the Dhamma, are not basic to the holy life. They donâ€™t lead to disenchantment, to dispassion, to cessation, to calm, to direct knowledge, to self-awakening, to unbinding. Thatâ€™s why I have taught and declared them to be not categorical.â€ A Categorical teaching.
424. â€˜neva hoti na na hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äâ€™ti kho, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, mayÄ anekaá¹ƒsiko dhammo desito paÃ±Ã±atto. "kasmÄ ca te, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, mayÄ anekaá¹ƒsikÄ dhammÄ desitÄ paÃ±Ã±attÄ? na hete, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, atthasaá¹ƒhitÄ na dhammasaá¹ƒhitÄ na ÄdibrahmacariyakÄ na nibbidÄya na virÄgÄya na nirodhÄya na upasamÄya na abhiÃ±Ã±Äya na sambodhÄya na nibbÄnÄya saá¹ƒvattanti. tasmÄ te mayÄ anekaá¹ƒsikÄ dhammÄ desitÄ paÃ±Ã±attÄ". ekaá¹ƒsikadhammo 424. "katame ca te, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, mayÄ ekaá¹ƒsikÄ dhammÄ desitÄ paÃ±Ã±attÄ? idaá¹ƒ dukkhanti kho, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, mayÄ ekaá¹ƒsiko dhammo desito paÃ±Ã±atto. ayaá¹ƒ dukkhasamudayoti kho, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, mayÄ ekaá¹ƒsiko dhammo desito paÃ±Ã±atto. ayaá¹ƒ dukkhanirodhoti kho, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, mayÄ ekaá¹ƒsiko dhammo desito paÃ±Ã±atto. ayaá¹ƒ dukkhanirodhagÄminÄ« paá¹­ipadÄti kho, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, mayÄ ekaá¹ƒsiko dhammo desito paÃ±Ã±atto. "kasmÄ ca te, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, mayÄ ekaá¹ƒsikÄ dhammÄ desitÄ paÃ±Ã±attÄ? ete, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, atthasaá¹ƒhitÄ, ete dhammasaá¹ƒhitÄ, ete ÄdibrahmacariyakÄ ete nibbidÄya virÄgÄya nirodhÄya upasamÄya abhiÃ±Ã±Äya sambodhÄya nibbÄnÄya saá¹ƒvattanti. tasmÄ te mayÄ ekaá¹ƒsikÄ dhammÄ desitÄ paÃ±Ã±attÄ. 425. "santi, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, eke samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä evaá¹ƒvÄdino evaá¹ƒdiá¹­á¹­hino â€“ â€˜ekantasukhÄ« attÄ hoti arogo paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äâ€™ti. tyÄhaá¹ƒ upasaá¹…kamitvÄ evaá¹ƒ vadÄmi â€“ â€˜saccaá¹ƒ kira tumhe Äyasmanto evaá¹ƒvÄdino evaá¹ƒdiá¹­á¹­hino â€“ "ekantasukhÄ« attÄ hoti arogo paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äâ€™ti? te ce me evaá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­hÄ â€˜ÄmÄâ€™ti paá¹­ijÄnanti. tyÄhaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ vadÄmi â€“ â€˜api pana tumhe Äyasmanto ekantasukhaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ jÄnaá¹ƒ passaá¹ƒ viharathÄâ€™ti? iti puá¹­á¹­hÄ â€˜noâ€™ti vadanti. "tyÄhaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ vadÄmi â€“ â€˜api pana tumhe Äyasmanto ekaá¹ƒ vÄ rattiá¹ƒ ekaá¹ƒ vÄ divasaá¹ƒ upaá¸á¸haá¹ƒ vÄ rattiá¹ƒ upaá¸á¸haá¹ƒ vÄ divasaá¹ƒ ekantasukhiá¹ƒ attÄnaá¹ƒ
â€œAnd what are the teachings that I have taught and declared to be categorical? â€˜This is stressâ€™ ( *idaá¹ƒ dukkhaá¹ƒ* ) I have taught and declared to be a categorical teaching. â€˜This is the origination of stressâ€™ ( *ayaá¹ƒ dukkhasamudayo* ) I have taught and declared to be a categorical teaching. â€˜This is the cessation of stressâ€™ ( *ayaá¹ƒ dukkhanirodho* ) I have taught and declared to be a categorical teaching. â€˜This is the path of practice leading to the cessation of stressâ€™ ( *ayaá¹ƒ dukkhanirodhagÄminÄ« paá¹­ipadÄ* ) I have taught and declared to be a categorical teaching. â€œAnd why have I taught and declared these teachings to be categorical? Because they are conducive to the goal, are conducive to the Dhamma, are basic to the holy life. They lead to disenchantment, to dispassion, to cessation, to calm, to direct knowledge, to self-awakening, to unbinding. Thatâ€™s why I have taught and declared them to be categorical.
425. â€˜neva hoti na na hoti tathÄgato paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äâ€™ti kho, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, mayÄ anekaá¹ƒsiko dhammo desito paÃ±Ã±atto. "kasmÄ ca te, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, mayÄ anekaá¹ƒsikÄ dhammÄ desitÄ paÃ±Ã±attÄ? na hete, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, atthasaá¹ƒhitÄ na dhammasaá¹ƒhitÄ na ÄdibrahmacariyakÄ na nibbidÄya na virÄgÄya na nirodhÄya na upasamÄya na abhiÃ±Ã±Äya na sambodhÄya na nibbÄnÄya saá¹ƒvattanti. tasmÄ te mayÄ anekaá¹ƒsikÄ dhammÄ desitÄ paÃ±Ã±attÄ". ekaá¹ƒsikadhammo 424. "katame ca te, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, mayÄ ekaá¹ƒsikÄ dhammÄ desitÄ paÃ±Ã±attÄ? idaá¹ƒ dukkhanti kho, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, mayÄ ekaá¹ƒsiko dhammo desito paÃ±Ã±atto. ayaá¹ƒ dukkhasamudayoti kho, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, mayÄ ekaá¹ƒsiko dhammo desito paÃ±Ã±atto. ayaá¹ƒ dukkhanirodhoti kho, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, mayÄ ekaá¹ƒsiko dhammo desito paÃ±Ã±atto. ayaá¹ƒ dukkhanirodhagÄminÄ« paá¹­ipadÄti kho, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, mayÄ ekaá¹ƒsiko dhammo desito paÃ±Ã±atto. "tyÄhaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ vadÄmi â€“ â€˜api pana tumhe Äyasmanto ekaá¹ƒ vÄ rattiá¹ƒ ekaá¹ƒ vÄ divasaá¹ƒ upaá¸á¸haá¹ƒ vÄ rattiá¹ƒ upaá¸á¸haá¹ƒ vÄ divasaá¹ƒ ekantasukhiá¹ƒ attÄnaá¹ƒ
â€œThere are some contemplatives & brahmans with a doctrine & view like this: â€˜After death, the self ( *attÄ* ) is exclusively happy and free from disease.â€™ I approached them and asked them, â€˜Is it true that you have a doctrine & view like this: â€œAfter death, the self is exclusively happy and free from diseaseâ€?â€™ If they answered me in the affirmative, I would say: â€˜But do you dwell having known or seen an exclusively happy world?â€™ If so asked, they answer, â€˜No.â€™ â€œI would say: â€˜But have you ever been aware of a self ( *attÄnaá¹ƒ* ) exclusively happy for a day or a night, or for half a day or half a night?â€™ Are you aware?"â€™iti puá¹­á¹­hÄ â€˜noâ€™ti vadanti. Then I say this to them: â€˜But do you, venerable sirs, know that "this is the path, this is the practice for the realization of an exclusively happy world"?â€™iti puá¹­á¹­hÄ â€˜noâ€™ti vadanti. â€œThen I say this to them: â€˜But have you, venerable sirs, heard the voices of the gods reborn in an exclusively happy world, saying, â€œPractice well, my dears. When this is the case, donâ€™t the words of those ascetics and Brahmins turn out to be unconvincing?â€ â€œYes, lord. When this is the case, the words of those ascetics and Brahmins turn out to be unconvincing.â€

â€œPoá¹­á¹­hapÄda, itâ€™s as if a man were to say, â€˜Iâ€™m in love with the most beautiful woman in this country,â€™ and other people were to say to him, â€˜Well, my good man, this most beautiful woman in this country with whom you are in love: do you know if sheâ€™s of the warrior caste *ká¹£atriyÄ«*, the Brahman caste *brÄhmaá¹‡Ä«*, the merchant caste *vessÄ«*, or the laborer caste *Å›Å«ddÄ«*?â€™iti puá¹­á¹­ho â€˜noâ€™ti vadeyya. Then they would say to him, â€˜Well then, do you know her name or clan name? Whether sheâ€™s tall *dÄ«ghÄ*, short *rassÄ*, or of medium height *majjhimÄ*? Whether sheâ€™s dark *kÄá¸·Ä«*, fair *sÄmÄ*, or ruddy-skinned *maá¹…guracchavÄ«*? Do you know what village *gÄme* or town *nigame* or city *nagare* sheâ€™s from?â€™iti puá¹­á¹­ho â€˜noâ€™ti vadeyya. Then they would say to him, â€˜So youâ€™ve never known or seen the woman youâ€™re in love with?â€™iti puá¹­á¹­ho â€˜ÄmÄâ€™ti vadeyya. â€œSo what do you think, Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda? When this is the case, donâ€™t the words of that man turn out to be unconvincing?â€ â€œSurely, venerable sir, that being so, that manâ€™s talk would amount to nonsense.â€ â€œIn the same way, Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, there are some ascetics and Brahmins with a doctrine and view like this: â€˜After death, the self *ÄtmÄ* is exclusively happy and free from disease *aroga*.â€™ I approached them and asked them, â€˜Is it true that you have a doctrine and view like this: These are of such a view: â€œAfter death, the self is exclusively happy, free from disease.â€ When asked this, they acknowledge, â€˜Yes.â€™ Then I say to them, â€˜But do you, venerable sirs, dwell having known or seen an exclusively happy world?â€™ When asked this, they say, â€˜No.â€™ Then I say to them, â€˜But do you, venerable sirs, ever cognize a self as exclusively happy for even a night, a day, half a night, or half a day?â€™ When asked this, they say, â€˜No.â€™ Then I say to them, â€˜But do you, venerable sirs, know that â€œThis is the path, this is the practice for the realization of an exclusively happy worldâ€?â€™ When asked this, they say, â€˜No.â€™ Then I say to them, â€˜But have you, venerable sirs, heard the sound of those deities who have arisen in an exclusively happy world speaking thus: "Those practicing well, friends, those practicing uprightly, friends, are those [who attain] the realization of an exclusively happy world. We, too, friends, by practicing thus, have arisen in an exclusively happy world"?â€™ When asked this, they say, â€˜No.â€™ â€œWhat do you think, Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda? When this is the case, doesnâ€™t the speech of those ascetics and Brahmins turn out to be unconvincing?â€ â€œSurely, venerable sir, when this is the case, the speech of those ascetics and Brahmins turns out to be unconvincing.â€
427. evaá¹ƒdiá¹­á¹­hino â€“ "ekantasukhÄ« attÄ hoti arogo paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä"â€™ti? te ce me evaá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­hÄ â€˜ÄmÄâ€™ti paá¹­ijÄnanti. tyÄhaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ vadÄmi â€“ â€˜api pana tumhe Äyasmanto ekantasukhaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ jÄnaá¹ƒ passaá¹ƒ viharathÄâ€™ti? iti puá¹­á¹­hÄ â€˜noâ€™ti vadanti. "seyyathÄpi, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, puriso cÄtumahÄpathe nisseá¹‡iá¹ƒ kareyya pÄsÄdassa Ärohaá¹‡Äya. tamenaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ vadeyyuá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜ambho purisa, yassa tvaá¹ƒ [yaá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ (sÄ«. ka.)] pÄsÄdassa Ärohaá¹‡Äya nisseá¹‡iá¹ƒ karosi, jÄnÄsi taá¹ƒ pÄsÄdaá¹ƒ puratthimÄya vÄ disÄya dakkhiá¹‡Äya vÄ disÄya pacchimÄya vÄ disÄya uttarÄya vÄ disÄya ucco vÄ nÄ«co vÄ majjhimo vÄâ€™ti? iti puá¹­á¹­ho â€˜noâ€™ti vadeyya. tamenaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ vadeyyuá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜ambho purisa, yaá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ na jÄnÄsi na passasi, tassa tvaá¹ƒ pÄsÄdassa Ärohaá¹‡Äya nisseá¹‡iá¹ƒ karosÄ«â€™ti? iti puá¹­á¹­ho â€˜ÄmÄâ€™ti vadeyya. "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, nanu evaá¹ƒ sante tassa purisassa appÄá¹­ihÄ«rakataá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ sampajjatÄ«"ti? "addhÄ kho, bhante, evaá¹ƒ sante tassa purisassa appÄá¹­ihÄ«rakataá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ sampajjatÄ«"ti.
â€œSuppose, Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, a man were to build a staircase at a crossroads for ascending to a palace. Someone might say to him, â€˜Good man, do you know if that palace for which you are building the staircase is to the east, south, west, or north? Is it high, low, or middling?â€™ When asked this, he would say, â€˜No.â€™ Someone might say to him, â€˜Good man, you do not know or see that palace, and yet you are building a staircase to ascend to it?â€™ When asked this, he would say, â€˜Yes.â€™ â€œWhat do you think, Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda? When this is the case, doesnâ€™t the speech of that man turn out to be unconvincing?â€ â€œSurely, venerable sir, when this is the case, the speech of that man turns out to be unconvincing.â€ In the same way, Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, there are some ascetics and *brÄhmaá¹‡as* who maintain and hold the view that: â€˜After death, the self (Ätman) is exclusively happy and free from disease.â€™ I approached them and asked them, â€˜Is it true that you, venerable sirs, maintain and hold the view that: "After death, the self (Ätman) is exclusively happy and free from disease?"â€™ If they, being asked by me in this way, acknowledge â€˜Yes,â€™ I then say this: â€˜But do you, venerable sirs, dwell having known or seen an exclusively happy world (loka)?â€™ Being asked thus, they say, â€˜No.â€™ I then say this: â€˜But have you, venerable sirs, ever been aware of a self (Ätman) that is exclusively happy for even a day or a night, or for half a day or half a night?â€™ Being asked thus, they say, â€˜No.â€™ I then say this: â€˜But do you, venerable sirs, know that "This is the path, this is the practice for the realization of an exclusively happy world (loka)?"â€™ Being asked thus, they say, â€˜No.â€™ I then say this: â€˜But have you, venerable sirs, heard the voices of the deities (devatÄ) reborn in an exclusively happy world (loka), saying, "Practice well, dear sirs. Practice straightforwardly, dear sirs, for the realization of an exclusively happy world (loka), because it was through such a practice that we ourselves have been reborn in an exclusively happy world (loka)?"â€™ Being asked thus, they say, â€˜No.â€™ â€œWhat do you think, Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda? When this is the case, donâ€™t the words of those ascetics and *brÄhmaá¹‡as* turn out to be unconvincing?â€ â€œYes, lord. When this is the case, the words of those ascetics and *brÄhmaá¹‡as* turn out to be unconvincing.â€ There are three appropriations of a self (Ätman). â€œPoá¹­á¹­hapÄda, there are these three appropriations of a self (Ätman): the gross appropriation of a self (oá¸·Äriko attapaá¹­ilÄbho), the mind-made appropriation of a self (manomayo attapaá¹­ilÄbho), and the formless appropriation of a self (arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbho). And what, Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, is the gross appropriation of a self (oá¸·Äriko attapaá¹­ilÄbho)? It is possessed of form, made of the four great elements (cÄtumahÄbhÅ«tiko), and feeds on solid food (kabaá¸·Ä«kÄrÄhÄrabhakkho). This is the gross appropriation of a self (oá¸·Äriko attapaá¹­ilÄbho). And what is the mind-made appropriation of a self (manomayo attapaá¹­ilÄbho)? It is possessed of form, mind-made, complete in all its parts, not inferior in its faculties. This is the mind-made appropriation of a self (manomayo attapaá¹­ilÄbho). And what is the formless appropriation of a self (arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbho)? It is formless and made of perception (saÃ±Ã±Ämayo). This is the formless appropriation of a self (arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbho). â€œFurthermore, Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, I teach the Dharma for the abandoning of the gross appropriation of a self, such that, when you practice it, defiling mental qualities (*saá¹ƒkilesikÄ dharma*) will be abandoned, bright mental qualities (*vodÄniyÄ dharma*) will grow, and you will enter and remain in the culmination and abundance of discernment, having known and realized it for yourself in the here and now. If the thought should occur to you that, when defiling mental qualities are abandoned and bright mental qualities have grown, and one enters and remains in the culmination and abundance of discernment, having known and realized it for oneself in the here and now, oneâ€™s abiding is stressful/painful, you should not see it in that way. When defiling mental qualities are abandoned and bright mental qualities have grown, and one enters and remains in the culmination and abundance of discernment, having known and realized it for oneself in the here and now, there is joy (*pÄmujjaá¹ƒ*), rapture (*pÄ«ti*), calm (*passaddhi*), mindfulness (*sati*), alertness (*sampajaÃ±Ã±a*) and a pleasant/happy abiding (*sukho vihÄro*). â€œI also, Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, teach the Dharma for the abandoning of the mind-made appropriation of a self, such that, when you practice it, defiling mental qualities will be abandoned, bright mental qualities will grow, and you will enter and remain in the culmination and abundance of discernment, having known and realized it for yourself in the here and now. If the thought should occur to you that, when defiling mental qualities are abandoned and bright mental qualities have grown, and one enters and remains in the culmination and abundance of discernment, having known and realized it for oneself in the here and now, oneâ€™s abiding is stressful/painful, you should not see it in that way. When defiling mental qualities are abandoned and bright mental qualities have grown, and one enters and remains in the culmination and abundance of discernment, having known and realized it for oneself in the here and now, there is joy, rapture, calm, mindfulness, alertness, and a pleasant/happy abiding. â€œFurthermore, Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, I teach the Dharma for the abandoning of the formless appropriation of a self, such that, when you practice it, defiling mental qualities will be abandoned, bright mental qualities will grow, and you will enter and remain in the culmination and abundance of discernment, having known and realized it for yourself in the here and now. If the thought should occur to you that, when defiling mental qualities are abandoned and bright mental qualities have grown, and one enters and remains in the culmination and abundance of discernment, having known and realized it for oneself in the here and now, oneâ€™s abiding is stressful/painful, you should not He says thus: â€˜The self ( *attÄ*) and the world (*loka*) are eternal, barren, steadfast as a mountain peak (*kÅ«á¹­aá¹­á¹­ha*), standing firm like a pillar (*esikaá¹­á¹­hÄyiá¹­á¹­hita*). And though these beings roam and wander (*sandhÄvanti saá¹ƒsaranti*), pass away (*cavanti*) and re-arise (*upapajjanti*), yet the self and the world remain the same just like eternity itself. Why is that? Because I, by means of ardour (*Ätappa*), endeavour (*padhÄna*), application (*anuyoga*), diligence (*appamÄda*), and right reflection (*sammÄmanasikÄra*), attain to such a degree of mental concentration (*cetosamÄdhi*) that with my mind thus concentrated, I recollect my numerous past lives (*pubbenivÄsa*) . that he recalls ten, twenty, thirty, forty periods of contraction and expansion (*saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­avivaá¹­á¹­Äni*). â€œThere my name was so-and-soâ€¦â€. In this way I recollected many past lives (*pubbenivÄsa*) with their characteristics (*sÄkÄraá¹ƒ*) and particulars (*sauddesaá¹ƒ*). For this reason I know this: the self (*attÄ*) and the world (*loka*) are eternal, barren, steadfast as a mountain peak (*kÅ«á¹­aá¹­á¹­ho*), standing firm like a pillar (*esikaá¹­á¹­hÄyiá¹­á¹­hito*). And though these beings roam and wander (*sandhÄvanti saá¹ƒsaranti*), pass away (*cavanti*) and re-arise (*upapajjanti*), yet the self and the world remain the same just like eternity itself.â€™ This, monks (*bhikkhave*), is the third case, owing to which, with reference to which, some ascetics and Brahmins (*samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä*) proclaim the eternity of the self (*attÄ*) and the world (*loka*).
428. "evameva kho, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, ye te samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä evaá¹ƒvÄdino evaá¹ƒdiá¹­á¹­hino â€“ â€˜ekantasukhÄ« attÄ hoti arogo paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äâ€™ti. tyÄhaá¹ƒ upasaá¹…kamitvÄ evaá¹ƒ vadÄmi â€“ â€˜saccaá¹ƒ kira tumhe Äyasmanto evaá¹ƒvÄdino evaá¹ƒdiá¹­á¹­hino â€“ "ekantasukhÄ« attÄ hoti arogo paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Äâ€™ti? te ce me evaá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­hÄ â€˜ÄmÄâ€™ti paá¹­ijÄnanti. tyÄhaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ vadÄmi â€“ â€˜api pana tumhe Äyasmanto ekantasukhaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ jÄnaá¹ƒ passaá¹ƒ viharathÄâ€™ti? iti puá¹­á¹­hÄ â€˜noâ€™ti vadanti. "tyÄhaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ vadÄmi â€“ â€˜api pana tumhe Äyasmanto ekaá¹ƒ vÄ rattiá¹ƒ ekaá¹ƒ vÄ divasaá¹ƒ upaá¸á¸haá¹ƒ vÄ rattiá¹ƒ upaá¸á¸haá¹ƒ vÄ divasaá¹ƒ ekantasukhiá¹ƒ attÄnaá¹ƒ saÃ±jÄnÄthÄâ€™ti? iti puá¹­á¹­hÄ â€˜noâ€™ti vadanti. tyÄhaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ vadÄmi â€“ â€˜api pana tumhe Äyasmanto jÄnÄtha ayaá¹ƒ maggo ayaá¹ƒ paá¹­ipadÄ ekantasukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyÄyÄâ€™ti? iti puá¹­á¹­hÄ â€˜noâ€™ti vadanti. "tyÄhaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ vadÄmi â€“ â€˜api pana tumhe Äyasmanto yÄ tÄ devatÄ ekantasukhaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ upapannÄâ€™ tÄsaá¹ƒ devatÄnaá¹ƒ bhÄsamÄnÄnaá¹ƒ saddaá¹ƒ suá¹‡Ätha- "suppaá¹­ipannÄttha, mÄrisÄ, ujuppaá¹­ipannÄttha, mÄrisÄ, ekantasukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyÄya, mayampi hi, mÄrisÄ, evaá¹ƒ paá¹­ipannÄ ekantasukhaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ upapannÄâ€™ti? iti puá¹­á¹­hÄ "no"ti vadanti. "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, nanu evaá¹ƒ sante tesaá¹ƒ samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ appÄá¹­ihÄ«rakataá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ sampajjatÄ«"ti? "addhÄ kho, bhante, evaá¹ƒ sante tesaá¹ƒ samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ appÄá¹­ihÄ«rakataá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ sampajjatÄ«"ti. tayo attapaá¹­ilÄbhÄ 428. "tayo kho me, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, attapaá¹­ilÄbhÄ â€“ oá¸·Äriko attapaá¹­ilÄbho, manomayo attapaá¹­ilÄbho, arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbho. katamo ca, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, oá¸·Äriko attapaá¹­ilÄbho? rÅ«pÄ« cÄtumahÄbhÅ«tiko kabaá¸·Ä«kÄrÄhÄrabhakkho [kabaá¸·Ä«kÄrabhakkho (syÄ. ka.)], ayaá¹ƒ oá¸·Äriko attapaá¹­ilÄbho. katamo manomayo attapaá¹­ilÄbho? rÅ«pÄ« manomayo sabbaá¹…gapaccaá¹…gÄ« ahÄ«nindriyo, ayaá¹ƒ manomayo attapaá¹­ilÄbho. katamo arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbho? arÅ«pÄ« saÃ±Ã±Ämayo, ayaá¹ƒ arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbho.
[Translation for paragraph 428]
429. 429. "oá¸·Ärikassapi kho ahaá¹ƒ, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, attapaá¹­ilÄbhassa pahÄnÄya dhammaá¹ƒ desemi â€“ yathÄpaá¹­ipannÄnaá¹ƒ vo saá¹ƒkilesikÄ dhammÄ pahÄ«yissanti, vodÄniyÄ dhammÄ abhivaá¸á¸hissanti, paÃ±Ã±ÄpÄripÅ«riá¹ƒ vepullattaÃ±ca diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ upasampajja viharissathÄti. siyÄ kho pana te, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, evamassa â€“ saá¹ƒkilesikÄ dhammÄ pahÄ«yissanti, vodÄniyÄ dhammÄ abhivaá¸á¸hissanti, paÃ±Ã±ÄpÄripÅ«riá¹ƒ vepullattaÃ±ca diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ upasampajja viharissati, dukkho ca kho vihÄroti, na kho panetaá¹ƒ, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, evaá¹ƒ daá¹­á¹­habbaá¹ƒ. saá¹ƒkilesikÄ ceva dhammÄ pahÄ«yissanti, vodÄniyÄ ca dhammÄ abhivaá¸á¸hissanti, paÃ±Ã±ÄpÄripÅ«riá¹ƒ vepullattaÃ±ca diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ upasampajja viharissati, pÄmujjaá¹ƒ ceva bhavissati pÄ«ti ca passaddhi ca sati ca sampajaÃ±Ã±aÃ±ca sukho ca vihÄro. 430. 432. panetaá¹ƒ, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, evaá¹ƒ daá¹­á¹­habbaá¹ƒ. saá¹ƒkilesikÄ ceva dhammÄ pahÄ«yissanti, vodÄniyÄ ca dhammÄ abhivaá¸á¸hissanti, paÃ±Ã±ÄpÄripÅ«riá¹ƒ vepullattaÃ±ca diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ upasampajja viharissati, pÄmujjaá¹ƒ ceva bhavissati pÄ«ti ca passaddhi ca sati ca sampajaÃ±Ã±aÃ±ca sukho ca vihÄro. 432. "pare ce, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, amhe evaá¹ƒ puccheyyuá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜katamo pana so, Ävuso, oá¸·Äriko attapaá¹­ilÄbho, yassa tumhe pahÄnÄya dhammaá¹ƒ desetha, yathÄpaá¹­ipannÄnaá¹ƒ vo saá¹ƒkilesikÄ dhammÄ pahÄ«yissanti, vodÄniyÄ dhammÄ abhivaá¸á¸hissanti, paÃ±Ã±ÄpÄripÅ«riá¹ƒ vepullattaÃ±ca diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ upasampajja viharissathÄâ€™ti, tesaá¹ƒ mayaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­hÄ evaá¹ƒ byÄkareyyÄma â€“ â€˜ayaá¹ƒ vÄ so, Ävuso, oá¸·Äriko attapaá¹­ilÄbho, yassa mayaá¹ƒ pahÄnÄya dhammaá¹ƒ desema, yathÄpaá¹­ipannÄnaá¹ƒ vo saá¹ƒkilesikÄ dhammÄ pahÄ«yissanti, vodÄniyÄ dhammÄ abhivaá¸á¸hissanti, paÃ±Ã±ÄpÄripÅ«riá¹ƒ vepullattaÃ±ca diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ upasampajja viharissathÄâ€™ti. 433. "pare ce, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, amhe evaá¹ƒ puccheyyuá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜katamo pana so, Ävuso, manomayo attapaá¹­ilÄbho, yassa tumhe pahÄnÄya dhammaá¹ƒ desetha, yathÄpaá¹­ipannÄnaá¹ƒ vo saá¹ƒkilesikÄ dhammÄ pahÄ«yissanti, vodÄniyÄ dhammÄ abhivaá¸á¸hissanti, paÃ±Ã±ÄpÄripÅ«riá¹ƒ vepullattaÃ±ca diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ upasampajja viharissathÄâ€™ti? tesaá¹ƒ mayaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­hÄ evaá¹ƒ byÄkareyyÄma â€“ â€˜ayaá¹ƒ vÄ so, Ävuso, manomayo attapaá¹­ilÄbho yassa mayaá¹ƒ pahÄnÄya dhammaá¹ƒ desema, yathÄpaá¹­ipannÄnaá¹ƒ vo saá¹ƒkilesikÄ dhammÄ pahÄ«yissanti, vodÄniyÄ dhammÄ abhivaá¸á¸hissanti, paÃ±Ã±ÄpÄripÅ«riá¹ƒ vepullattaÃ±ca diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ upasampajja viharissathÄâ€™ti. 434. "pare ce, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, amhe evaá¹ƒ puccheyyuá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜katamo pana so, Ävuso, arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbho, yassa tumhe pahÄnÄya dhammaá¹ƒ desetha, yathÄpaá¹­ipannÄnaá¹ƒ vo saá¹ƒkilesikÄ dhammÄ pahÄ«yissanti, vodÄniyÄ dhammÄ abhivaá¸á¸hissanti, paÃ±Ã±ÄpÄripÅ«riá¹ƒ vepullattaÃ±ca diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ upasampajja viharissathÄâ€™ti, tesaá¹ƒ mayaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ
â€œIn the past, I have been asked, â€˜What, friend, is the gross appropriation of a self (*oá¸·Äriko attapaá¹­ilÄbho*) for whose abandoning you teach the Dhamma such that, when you practice it, defiling mental qualities will be abandoned, bright mental qualities will grow, and you will enter & remain in the culmination & abundance of discernment, having known & realized it for yourself in the here & now?â€™ When asked this, I would answer, â€˜This, friend, is that gross appropriation of a self (*oá¸·Äriko attapaá¹­ilÄbho*) for whose abandoning I teach the Dhamma such that, when you practice it, defiling mental qualities will be abandoned, bright mental qualities will grow, and you will enter & remain in the culmination & abundance of discernment, having known & realized it for yourself in the here & now.â€™
433. panetaá¹ƒ, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, evaá¹ƒ daá¹­á¹­habbaá¹ƒ. saá¹ƒkilesikÄ ceva dhammÄ pahÄ«yissanti, vodÄniyÄ ca dhammÄ abhivaá¸á¸hissanti, paÃ±Ã±ÄpÄripÅ«riá¹ƒ vepullattaÃ±ca diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ upasampajja viharissati, pÄmujjaá¹ƒ ceva bhavissati pÄ«ti ca passaddhi ca sati ca sampajaÃ±Ã±aÃ±ca sukho ca vihÄro. 432. "pare ce, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, amhe evaá¹ƒ puccheyyuá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜katamo pana so, Ävuso, oá¸·Äriko attapaá¹­ilÄbho, yassa tumhe pahÄnÄya dhammaá¹ƒ desetha, yathÄpaá¹­ipannÄnaá¹ƒ vo saá¹ƒkilesikÄ dhammÄ pahÄ«yissanti, vodÄniyÄ dhammÄ abhivaá¸á¸hissanti, paÃ±Ã±ÄpÄripÅ«riá¹ƒ vepullattaÃ±ca diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ upasampajja viharissathÄâ€™ti, tesaá¹ƒ mayaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­hÄ evaá¹ƒ byÄkareyyÄma â€“ â€˜ayaá¹ƒ vÄ so, Ävuso, oá¸·Äriko attapaá¹­ilÄbho, yassa mayaá¹ƒ pahÄnÄya dhammaá¹ƒ desema, yathÄpaá¹­ipannÄnaá¹ƒ vo saá¹ƒkilesikÄ dhammÄ pahÄ«yissanti, vodÄniyÄ dhammÄ abhivaá¸á¸hissanti, paÃ±Ã±ÄpÄripÅ«riá¹ƒ vepullattaÃ±ca diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ upasampajja viharissathÄâ€™ti. 433. "pare ce, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, amhe evaá¹ƒ puccheyyuá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜katamo pana so, Ävuso, manomayo attapaá¹­ilÄbho, yassa tumhe pahÄnÄya dhammaá¹ƒ desetha, yathÄpaá¹­ipannÄnaá¹ƒ vo saá¹ƒkilesikÄ dhammÄ pahÄ«yissanti, vodÄniyÄ dhammÄ abhivaá¸á¸hissanti, paÃ±Ã±ÄpÄripÅ«riá¹ƒ vepullattaÃ±ca diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ upasampajja viharissathÄâ€™ti? tesaá¹ƒ mayaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­hÄ evaá¹ƒ byÄkareyyÄma â€“ â€˜ayaá¹ƒ vÄ so, Ävuso, manomayo attapaá¹­ilÄbho yassa mayaá¹ƒ pahÄnÄya dhammaá¹ƒ desema, yathÄpaá¹­ipannÄnaá¹ƒ vo saá¹ƒkilesikÄ dhammÄ pahÄ«yissanti, vodÄniyÄ dhammÄ abhivaá¸á¸hissanti, paÃ±Ã±ÄpÄripÅ«riá¹ƒ vepullattaÃ±ca diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ upasampajja viharissathÄâ€™ti. 434. "pare ce, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, amhe evaá¹ƒ puccheyyuá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜katamo pana so, Ävuso, arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbho, yassa tumhe pahÄnÄya dhammaá¹ƒ desetha, yathÄpaá¹­ipannÄnaá¹ƒ vo saá¹ƒkilesikÄ dhammÄ pahÄ«yissanti, vodÄniyÄ dhammÄ abhivaá¸á¸hissanti, paÃ±Ã±ÄpÄripÅ«riá¹ƒ vepullattaÃ±ca diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ upasampajja viharissathÄâ€™ti, tesaá¹ƒ mayaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ
â€œIn the past, I have been asked, â€˜What, friend, is the mind-made appropriation of a self (*manomayo attapaá¹­ilÄbho*) for whose abandoning you teach the Dhamma such that, when you practice it, defiling mental qualities will be abandoned, bright mental qualities will grow, and you will enter & remain in the culmination & abundance of discernment, having known & realized it for yourself in the here & now?â€™ When asked this, I would answer, â€˜This, friend, is that mind-made appropriation of a self (*manomayo attapaá¹­ilÄbho*) for whose abandoning I teach the Dhamma such that, when you practice it, defiling mental qualities will be abandoned, bright mental qualities will grow, and you will enter & remain in the culmination & abundance of discernment, having known & realized it for yourself in the here & now.â€™

â€œIn the past, I have been asked, â€˜What, friend, is the formless appropriation of a self (*arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbho*) for whose abandoning you teach the Dhamma such that, when you practice it, defiling mental qualities will be abandoned, bright mental qualities will grow, and you will enter & remain in the culmination & abundance of discernment, having known & realized it for yourself in the here & now?â€™ When Having been asked thus, we would answer: â€˜This, friend, is that formless appropriation of self (*arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbho*) for whose abandonment we teach the Dhamma, so that when you practice accordingly, your defiling qualities (*saá¹ƒkilesikÄ dhammÄ*) will be abandoned, your purifying qualities (*vodÄniyÄ dhammÄ*) will grow, and in this very life, having directly known and realized it for yourselves through insight (*abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ*), you will attain and abide in the complete fulfillment and abundance of wisdom (*paÃ±Ã±ÄpÄripÅ«riá¹ƒ vepullattaÃ±ca*)â€™. â€œWhat do you think, Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda? When this is the case, donâ€™t those words turn out to be convincing (*sappÄá¹­ihÄ«rakataá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ sampajjatÄ«*)?â€ â€œYes, venerable sir, when this is the case, those words turn out to be convincing.â€
435. puá¹­á¹­hÄ evaá¹ƒ byÄkareyyÄma â€“ â€˜ayaá¹ƒ vÄ so, Ävuso, arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbho yassa mayaá¹ƒ pahÄnÄya dhammaá¹ƒ desema, yathÄpaá¹­ipannÄnaá¹ƒ vo saá¹ƒkilesikÄ dhammÄ pahÄ«yissanti, vodÄniyÄ dhammÄ abhivaá¸á¸hissanti, paÃ±Ã±ÄpÄripÅ«riá¹ƒ vepullattaÃ±ca diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ upasampajja viharissathÄâ€™ti. "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, nanu evaá¹ƒ sante sappÄá¹­ihÄ«rakataá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ sampajjatÄ«"ti? "addhÄ kho, bhante, evaá¹ƒ sante sappÄá¹­ihÄ«rakataá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ sampajjatÄ«"ti. 435. "seyyathÄpi, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, puriso nisseá¹‡iá¹ƒ kareyya pÄsÄdassa Ärohaá¹‡Äya tasseva pÄsÄdassa heá¹­á¹­hÄ. tamenaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ vadeyyuá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜ambho purisa, yassa tvaá¹ƒ pÄsÄdassa Ärohaá¹‡Äya nisseá¹‡iá¹ƒ karosi, jÄnÄsi taá¹ƒ pÄsÄdaá¹ƒ, puratthimÄya vÄ disÄya dakkhiá¹‡Äya vÄ disÄya pacchimÄya vÄ disÄya uttarÄya vÄ disÄya ucco vÄ nÄ«co vÄ majjhimo vÄâ€™ti? so evaá¹ƒ vadeyya â€“ â€˜ayaá¹ƒ vÄ so, Ävuso, pÄsÄdo, yassÄhaá¹ƒ Ärohaá¹‡Äya nisseá¹‡iá¹ƒ karomi, tasseva pÄsÄdassa heá¹­á¹­hÄâ€™ti. "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, nanu evaá¹ƒ sante tassa purisassa sappÄá¹­ihÄ«rakataá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ sampajjatÄ«"ti? "addhÄ kho, bhante, evaá¹ƒ sante tassa purisassa sappÄá¹­ihÄ«rakataá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ sampajjatÄ«"ti. 436. "evameva kho, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, pare ce amhe evaá¹ƒ puccheyyuá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜katamo pana so, Ävuso, oá¸·Äriko attapaá¹­ilÄbhoâ€¦peâ€¦ katamo pana so, Ävuso, manomayo attapaá¹­ilÄbhoâ€¦peâ€¦ katamo pana so, Ävuso, arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbho, yassa tumhe pahÄnÄya dhammaá¹ƒ desetha, yathÄpaá¹­ipannÄnaá¹ƒ vo saá¹ƒkilesikÄ dhammÄ pahÄ«yissanti, vodÄniyÄ dhammÄ abhivaá¸á¸hissanti, paÃ±Ã±ÄpÄripÅ«riá¹ƒ vepullattaÃ±ca diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ upasampajja viharissathÄâ€™ti, tesaá¹ƒ mayaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­hÄ evaá¹ƒ byÄkareyyÄma â€“ â€˜ayaá¹ƒ vÄ so, Ävuso, arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbho, yassa mayaá¹ƒ pahÄnÄya dhammaá¹ƒ desema, yathÄpaá¹­ipannÄnaá¹ƒ vo saá¹ƒkilesikÄ dhammÄ pahÄ«yissanti, vodÄniyÄ dhammÄ abhivaá¸á¸hissanti,
â€œSuppose, Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, a man were to construct a staircase at a crossroads to ascend to a palace, but the staircase was at the very bottom of that palace. People might say to him, â€˜Hey, fellow, you're building a staircase to ascend to a palace. Do you know where that palace is located? Is it to the east, south, west, or north? Is it high, low, or in between?â€™ Then he might say, â€˜Hey friends, this is the palace for which I am building the staircase. The staircase is at the very bottom of the palace itself.â€™ â€œWhat do you think, Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda? When this is the case, donâ€™t that man's words turn out to be convincing (*sappÄá¹­ihÄ«rakataá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ sampajjatÄ«*)?â€ â€œYes, venerable sir, when this is the case, that man's words turn out to be convincing.â€
436. puá¹­á¹­hÄ evaá¹ƒ byÄkareyyÄma â€“ â€˜ayaá¹ƒ vÄ so, Ävuso, arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbho yassa mayaá¹ƒ pahÄnÄya dhammaá¹ƒ desema, yathÄpaá¹­ipannÄnaá¹ƒ vo saá¹ƒkilesikÄ dhammÄ pahÄ«yissanti, vodÄniyÄ dhammÄ abhivaá¸á¸hissanti, paÃ±Ã±ÄpÄripÅ«riá¹ƒ vepullattaÃ±ca diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ upasampajja viharissathÄâ€™ti. "evameva kho, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, pare ce amhe evaá¹ƒ puccheyyuá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜katamo pana so, Ävuso, oá¸·Äriko attapaá¹­ilÄbhoâ€¦peâ€¦ katamo pana so, Ävuso, manomayo attapaá¹­ilÄbhoâ€¦peâ€¦ katamo pana so, Ävuso, arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbho, yassa tumhe pahÄnÄya dhammaá¹ƒ desetha, yathÄpaá¹­ipannÄnaá¹ƒ vo saá¹ƒkilesikÄ dhammÄ pahÄ«yissanti, vodÄniyÄ dhammÄ abhivaá¸á¸hissanti, paÃ±Ã±ÄpÄripÅ«riá¹ƒ vepullattaÃ±ca diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ upasampajja viharissathÄâ€™ti, tesaá¹ƒ mayaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­hÄ evaá¹ƒ byÄkareyyÄma â€“ â€˜ayaá¹ƒ vÄ so, Ävuso, arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbho, yassa mayaá¹ƒ pahÄnÄya dhammaá¹ƒ desema, yathÄpaá¹­ipannÄnaá¹ƒ vo saá¹ƒkilesikÄ dhammÄ pahÄ«yissanti, vodÄniyÄ dhammÄ abhivaá¸á¸hissanti,
â€œJust so, Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, if others were to ask us: â€˜What, friend, is the gross appropriation of self (*oá¸·Äriko attapaá¹­ilÄbho*)? ... What, friend, is the mind-made appropriation of self (*manomayo attapaá¹­ilÄbho*)? ... What, friend, is the formless appropriation of self (*arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbho*) for whose abandonment you teach the Dhamma, so that when you practice accordingly, your defiling qualities (*saá¹ƒkilesikÄ dhammÄ*) will be abandoned, your purifying qualities (*vodÄniyÄ dhammÄ*) will grow, and in this very life, having directly known and realized it for yourselves through insight (*abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ*), you will attain and abide in the complete fulfillment and abundance of wisdom (*paÃ±Ã±ÄpÄripÅ«riá¹ƒ vepullattaÃ±ca*)?â€™ Then, being asked thus, we would answer thus: â€˜This, friend, is that formless appropriation of self (*arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbho*) for whose abandonment we teach the Dhamma, so that when you practice accordingly, your defiling qualities (*saá¹ƒkilesikÄ dhammÄ*) will be abandoned, your purifying qualities (*vodÄniyÄ dhammÄ*) will grow, and in this very life, having directly known and realized it for yourselves through insight (*abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ*), you will attain and abide in the complete fulfillment and abundance of wisdom (*paÃ±Ã±ÄpÄripÅ«riá¹ƒ vepullattaÃ±ca*)â€™. â€œWhat do you think, Poá¹­á¹­hapÄda? When this is the case, donâ€™t those words turn out to be convincing (*sappÄá¹­ihÄ«rakataá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ sampajjatÄ«*)?â€ â€œYes, venerable sir, when this is the case, those words turn out to be convincing.â€
437. paÃ±Ã±ÄpÄripÅ«riá¹ƒ vepullattaÃ±ca diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ upasampajja viharissathÄâ€™ti. "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, nanu evaá¹ƒ sante sappÄá¹­ihÄ«rakataá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ sampajjatÄ«"ti? "addhÄ kho, bhante, evaá¹ƒ sante sappÄá¹­ihÄ«rakataá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ sampajjatÄ«"ti. 437. evaá¹ƒ vutte citto hatthisÄriputto bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "yasmiá¹ƒ, bhante, samaye oá¸·Äriko attapaá¹­ilÄbho hoti, moghassa tasmiá¹ƒ samaye manomayo attapaá¹­ilÄbho hoti, mogho arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbho hoti, oá¸·Äriko vÄssa attapaá¹­ilÄbho tasmiá¹ƒ samaye sacco hoti. yasmiá¹ƒ, bhante, samaye manomayo attapaá¹­ilÄbho hoti, moghassa tasmiá¹ƒ samaye oá¸·Äriko attapaá¹­ilÄbho hoti, mogho arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbho hoti, manomayo vÄssa attapaá¹­ilÄbho tasmiá¹ƒ samaye sacco hoti. yasmiá¹ƒ, bhante, samaye arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbho hoti, moghassa tasmiá¹ƒ samaye oá¸·Äriko attapaá¹­ilÄbho hoti, mogho manomayo attapaá¹­ilÄbho hoti, arÅ«po vÄssa attapaá¹­ilÄbho tasmiá¹ƒ samaye sacco hotÄ«"ti. "yasmiá¹ƒ, citta, samaye oá¸·Äriko attapaá¹­ilÄbho hoti, neva tasmiá¹ƒ samaye manomayo attapaá¹­ilÄbhoti saá¹…khaá¹ƒ gacchati, na arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbhoti saá¹…khaá¹ƒ gacchati, oá¸·Äriko attapaá¹­ilÄbhotveva tasmiá¹ƒ samaye saá¹…khaá¹ƒ gacchati. yasmiá¹ƒ, citta, samaye manomayo attapaá¹­ilÄbho hoti, neva tasmiá¹ƒ samaye oá¸·Äriko attapaá¹­ilÄbhoti saá¹…khaá¹ƒ gacchati, na arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbhoti saá¹…khaá¹ƒ gacchati, manomayo attapaá¹­ilÄbhotveva tasmiá¹ƒ samaye saá¹…khaá¹ƒ gacchati. yasmiá¹ƒ, citta, samaye arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbho hoti, neva tasmiá¹ƒ samaye oá¸·Äriko attapaá¹­ilÄbhoti saá¹…khaá¹ƒ gacchati, na manomayo attapaá¹­ilÄbhoti saá¹…khaá¹ƒ gacchati, arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbhotveva tasmiá¹ƒ samaye saá¹…khaá¹ƒ gacchati. 438. "sace taá¹ƒ, citta, evaá¹ƒ puccheyyuá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜ahosi tvaá¹ƒ atÄ«tamaddhÄnaá¹ƒ, na tvaá¹ƒ nÄhosi, bhavissasi tvaá¹ƒ anÄgatamaddhÄnaá¹ƒ, na tvaá¹ƒ na bhavissasi, atthi
When this was said, Citta the elephant trainer's son said to the Blessed One: "Venerable sir, at the time when there is a gross appropriation of self (*oá¸·Äriko attapaá¹­ilÄbho*), is the mind-made appropriation of self (*manomayo attapaá¹­ilÄbho*) then void, and the formless appropriation of self (*arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbho*) void, and only the gross appropriation of self (*oá¸·Äriko attapaá¹­ilÄbho*) true at that time? Venerable sir, at the time when there is a mind-made appropriation of self (*manomayo attapaá¹­ilÄbho*), is the gross appropriation of self (*oá¸·Äriko attapaá¹­ilÄbho*) then void, and the formless appropriation of self (*arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbho*) void, and only the mind-made appropriation of self (*manomayo attapaá¹­ilÄbho*) true at that time? Venerable sir, at the time when there is a formless appropriation of self (*arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbho*), is the gross appropriation of self (*oá¸·Äriko attapaá¹­ilÄbho*) then void, and the mind-made appropriation of self (*manomayo attapaá¹­ilÄbho*) void, and only the formless appropriation of self (*arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbho*) true at that time?" "Citta, at the time when there is a gross appropriation of self (*oá¸·Äriko attapaá¹­ilÄbho*), it is not reckoned as 'a mind-made appropriation of self (*manomayo attapaá¹­ilÄbho*)', nor is it reckoned as 'a formless appropriation of self (*arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbho*)'; it is reckoned only as 'a gross appropriation of self (*oá¸·Äriko attapaá¹­ilÄbho*)' at that time. Citta, at the time when there is a mind-made appropriation of self (*manomayo attapaá¹­ilÄbho*), it is not reckoned as 'a gross appropriation of self (*oá¸·Äriko attapaá¹­ilÄbho*)', nor is it reckoned as 'a formless appropriation of self (*arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbho*)'; it is reckoned only as 'a mind-made appropriation of self (*manomayo attapaá¹­ilÄbho*)' at that time. Citta, at the time when there is a formless appropriation of self (*arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbho*), it is not reckoned as 'a gross appropriation of self (*oá¸·Äriko attapaá¹­ilÄbho*)', nor is it reckoned as 'a mind-made appropriation of self (*manomayo attapaá¹­ilÄbho*)'; it is reckoned only as 'a formless appropriation of self (*arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbho*)' at that time.
438. paÃ±Ã±ÄpÄripÅ«riá¹ƒ vepullattaÃ±ca diá¹­á¹­heva dhamme sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ upasampajja viharissathÄâ€™ti. "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, poá¹­á¹­hapÄda, nanu evaá¹ƒ sante sappÄá¹­ihÄ«rakataá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ sampajjatÄ«"ti? "addhÄ kho, bhante, evaá¹ƒ sante sappÄá¹­ihÄ«rakataá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ sampajjatÄ«"ti. 437. evaá¹ƒ vutte citto hatthisÄriputto bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "yasmiá¹ƒ, bhante, samaye oá¸·Äriko attapaá¹­ilÄbho hoti, moghassa tasmiá¹ƒ samaye manomayo attapaá¹­ilÄbho hoti, mogho arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbho hoti, oá¸·Äriko vÄssa attapaá¹­ilÄbho tasmiá¹ƒ samaye sacco hoti. yasmiá¹ƒ, bhante, samaye manomayo attapaá¹­ilÄbho hoti, moghassa tasmiá¹ƒ samaye oá¸·Äriko attapaá¹­ilÄbho hoti, mogho arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbho hoti, manomayo vÄssa attapaá¹­ilÄbho tasmiá¹ƒ samaye sacco hoti. yasmiá¹ƒ, bhante, samaye arÅ«po attapaá¹­ilÄbho hoti, moghassa tasmiá¹ƒ samaye oá¸·Äriko attapaá¹­ilÄbho hoti, mogho manomayo attapaá¹­ilÄbho hoti, arÅ«po vÄssa attapaá¹­ilÄbho tasmiá¹ƒ samaye sacco hotÄ«"ti. "sace taá¹ƒ, citta, evaá¹ƒ puccheyyuá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜ahosi tvaá¹ƒ atÄ«tamaddhÄnaá¹ƒ, na tvaá¹ƒ nÄhosi, bhavissasi tvaá¹ƒ anÄgatamaddhÄnaá¹ƒ, na tvaá¹ƒ na bhavissasi, atthi
"Citta, if they were to ask you thus: 'Did you exist in the past? Did you not not exist? Will you exist in the future? Will you not not exist? Do you exist

â€œIn the same way, Citta, when there is a gross appropriation of a self, at that time, it is not classified as a mind-made appropriation of a self, nor is it classified as a formless appropriation of a self. It is classified just as a gross appropriation of a self. Citta, when there is a mind-made appropriation of a self... When there is a formless appropriation of a self, at that time, it is not classified as a gross appropriation of a self, nor is it classified as a mind-made appropriation of a self. It is classified just as a formless appropriation of a self.

â€œJust as, Citta, milk comes from a cow, curds from milk, butter from curds, ghee from butter, and the skimmings of ghee from ghee. When there is milk, itâ€™s not classified as curds, butter, ghee, or skimmings of ghee. Itâ€™s classified just as milk. When there are curds... When there is butter... When there is ghee... When there are the skimmings of ghee, theyâ€™re not classified as milk, curds, butter, or ghee. Theyâ€™re classified just as the skimmings of ghee. In the same way, Citta, when there is a gross appropriation of a self... When there is a mind-made appropriation of a self... When there is a formless appropriation of a self, at that time, it is not classified as a gross appropriation of a self, nor is it classified as a mind-made appropriation of a self. It is classified just as a formless appropriation of a self. Citta, these are the world's designations (lokasamaÃ±Ã±Ä), the world's expressions (lokaniruttiyo), the world's ways of speaking (lokavohÄrÄ), the world's descriptions (lokapaÃ±Ã±attiyo), with which the *TathÄgata* expresses himself but without grasping to them.â€
441. 439.
