"ayaá¹ƒ kho so, mÄá¹‡ava, ariyo samÄdhikkhandho yassa so bhagavÄ vaá¹‡á¹‡avÄdÄ« ahosi, yattha ca imaá¹ƒ janataá¹ƒ samÄdapesi nivesesi patiá¹­á¹­hÄpesi. atthi cevettha uttarikaraá¹‡Ä«ya"nti. "acchariyaá¹ƒ, bho Änanda, abbhutaá¹ƒ, bho Änanda! so cÄyaá¹ƒ, bho Änanda, ariyo samÄdhikkhandho paripuá¹‡á¹‡o, no aparipuá¹‡á¹‡o. evaá¹ƒ paripuá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ cÄhaá¹ƒ, bho Änanda, ariyaá¹ƒ samÄdhikkhandhaá¹ƒ ito bahiddhÄ aÃ±Ã±esu samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡esu na samanupassÄmi. evaá¹ƒ paripuá¹‡á¹‡aÃ±ca, bho Änanda, ariyaá¹ƒ samÄdhikkhandhaá¹ƒ ito bahiddhÄ aÃ±Ã±e samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡Ä attani samanupasseyyuá¹ƒ, te tÄvatakeneva attamanÄ assu â€“ â€˜alamettÄvatÄ, katamettÄvatÄ, anuppatto no sÄmaÃ±Ã±attho, natthi no kiÃ±ci uttarikaraá¹‡Ä«yaâ€™nti. atha ca pana bhavaá¹ƒ Änando evamÄha â€“ â€˜atthi cevettha uttarikaraá¹‡Ä«ya"â€™nti.
"This, young man, is the noble division of concentration (*ariyo samÄdhikkhandho*) of which the Blessed One was a proponent, and with which he aroused, exhorted and established this populace. But something more remains to be done.â€ â€œIt is wonderful, venerable Ä€nanda, it is marvelous, venerable Ä€nanda! This noble division of concentration (*ariyo samÄdhikkhandho*) is perfectly complete, not incomplete. And I do not see this noble division of concentration (*ariyaá¹ƒ samÄdhikkhandhaá¹ƒ*) thus perfectly complete anywhere outside of this among other ascetics and *BrÄhmaá¹‡as*. And if any other ascetics and *BrÄhmaá¹‡as* were to perceive this noble division of concentration (*ariyaá¹ƒ samÄdhikkhandhaá¹ƒ*) as thus perfectly complete in themselves, they would be delighted with just that much, [thinking,] 'Enough has been done by us, the goal has been reached by us, there is nothing more for us to do.' But yet venerable Ä€nanda says thus: 'But something more remains to be done.'" *PaÃ±Ã±Äkkhandho* - The aggregate of wisdom.
472. paÃ±Ã±Äkkhandho 472. "katamo pana so, bho Änanda, ariyo paÃ±Ã±Äkkhandho, yassa bho bhavaá¹ƒ gotamo vaá¹‡á¹‡avÄdÄ« ahosi, yattha ca imaá¹ƒ janataá¹ƒ samÄdapesi nivesesi patiá¹­á¹­hÄpesÄ«"ti? "so evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte Ã±Äá¹‡adassanÄya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so evaá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti â€“ â€˜ayaá¹ƒ kho me kÄyo rÅ«pÄ« cÄtumahÄbhÅ«tiko mÄtÄpettikasambhavo odanakummÄsÅ«pacayo aniccucchÄdanaparimaddanabhedanaviddhaá¹ƒsanadhammo, idaÃ±ca pana me viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹ƒ ettha sitaá¹ƒ ettha paá¹­ibaddhaâ€™nti. "seyyathÄpi, mÄá¹‡ava, maá¹‡i veá¸·uriyo subho jÄtimÄ aá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒso suparikammakato accho vippasanno anÄvilo sabbÄkÄrasampanno. tatrÄssa suttaá¹ƒ Ävutaá¹ƒ nÄ«laá¹ƒ vÄ pÄ«taá¹ƒ vÄ lohitaá¹ƒ vÄ odÄtaá¹ƒ vÄ paá¹‡á¸usuttaá¹ƒ vÄ. tamenaá¹ƒ cakkhumÄ puriso hatthe karitvÄ paccavekkheyya â€“ â€˜ayaá¹ƒ kho maá¹‡i veá¸·uriyo subho jÄtimÄ aá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒso suparikammakato accho vippasanno anÄvilo sabbÄkÄrasampanno. tatridaá¹ƒ suttaá¹ƒ Ävutaá¹ƒ nÄ«laá¹ƒ vÄ pÄ«taá¹ƒ vÄ lohitaá¹ƒ vÄ odÄtaá¹ƒ vÄ paá¹‡á¸usuttaá¹ƒ vÄâ€™ti. evameva kho, mÄá¹‡ava, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte Ã±Äá¹‡adassanÄya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so evaá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti â€“ â€˜ayaá¹ƒ kho me kÄyo rÅ«pÄ« cÄtumahÄbhÅ«tiko mÄtÄpettikasambhavo odanakummÄsÅ«pacayo aniccucchÄdanaparimaddanabhedana-viddhaá¹ƒsanadhammo. idaÃ±ca pana me viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹ƒ ettha sitaá¹ƒ ettha paá¹­ibaddhaâ€™nti. yampi, mÄá¹‡ava, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citteâ€¦peâ€¦ ÄneÃ±jappatte Ã±Äá¹‡adassanÄya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so evaá¹ƒ pajÄnÄtiâ€¦peâ€¦ ettha paá¹­ibaddhanti. idampissa hoti paÃ±Ã±Äya. 473. "so evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte manomayaá¹ƒ kÄyaá¹ƒ abhinimmÄnÄya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so imamhÄ kÄyÄ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ kÄyaá¹ƒ abhinimminÄti rÅ«piá¹ƒ manomayaá¹ƒ sabbaá¹…gapaccaá¹…giá¹ƒ ahÄ«nindriyaá¹ƒ.
"Reverend Ä€nanda, what is the division of Ariyan wisdom (*ariyo paÃ±Ã±Äkkhandho*) which the Reverend Gotama praised? Where did he encourage, establish, and settle these people?" "And so, with mind concentrated (*samÄhite citte*), purified (*parisuddhe*) and cleansed (*pariyodÄte*), unblemished (*anaá¹…gaá¹‡e*), free from impurities (*vigatÅ«pakkilese*), malleable (*mudubhÅ«te*), workable (*kammaniye*), established (*á¹­hite*), and having gained imperturbability (*ÄneÃ±jappatte*), he directs and inclines his mind towards knowledge and vision (*Ã±Äá¹‡adassanÄya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti*). And he understands thus: â€˜This my body (*kÄyo*) is material (*rÅ«pÄ«*), made up of the four great elements (*cÄtumahÄbhÅ«tiko*), born of mother and father (*mÄtÄpettikasambhavo*), fed on rice and gruel (*odanakummÄsÅ«pacayo*), impermanent (*anicca*), liable to be injured and abraded (*ucchÄdanaparimaddana*), broken and destroyed (*bhedanaviddhaá¹ƒsanadhammo*), and this is my consciousness (*viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹ƒ*) which is bound to it and dependent on it.â€™ "Suppose, young man (*mÄá¹‡ava*), there were a beautiful beryl gem (*maá¹‡i veá¸·uriyo*) of purest water, eight-faceted (*aá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒso*), well cut (*suparikammakato*), clear (*accho*), bright (*vippasanno*), unflawed (*anÄvilo*), perfect in every respect (*sabbÄkÄrasampanno*). And through it there would run a blue (*nÄ«laá¹ƒ*), yellow (*pÄ«taá¹ƒ*), red (*lohitaá¹ƒ*), white (*odÄtaá¹ƒ*), or brown thread (*paá¹‡á¸usuttaá¹ƒ*). Then a man with good sight (*cakkhumÄ puriso*), taking it in his hand (*hatthe karitvÄ*), might review it thus: â€œThis is a beautiful beryl gem (*maá¹‡i veá¸·uriyo*) of purest water, eight-faceted (*aá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒso*), well cut (*suparikammakato*), clear (*accho*), bright (*vippasanno*), unflawed (*anÄvilo*), perfect in every respect (*sabbÄkÄrasampanno*). And through it there would run a blue (*nÄ«laá¹ƒ*), yellow (*pÄ«taá¹ƒ*), red (*lohitaá¹ƒ*), white (*odÄtaá¹ƒ*), or brown thread (*paá¹‡á¸usuttaá¹ƒ*).â€ In the same way, young man (*mÄá¹‡ava*), when a *bhikkhu*'s mind is thus concentrated (*samÄhite citte*), pure (*parisuddhe*) and bright (*pariyodÄte*), unblemished (*anaá¹…gaá¹‡e*), free from defects (*vigatÅ«pakkilese*), malleable (*mudubhÅ«te*), wieldy (*kammaniye*), steady (*á¹­hite*) and attained to imperturbability (*ÄneÃ±jappatte*), he directs and inclines it to knowledge and vision (*Ã±Äá¹‡adassanÄya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti*). And he understands thus: â€˜This my body (*kÄyo*) is material (*rÅ«pÄ«*), made up of the four great elements (*cÄtumahÄbhÅ«tiko*), born of mother and father (*mÄtÄpettikasambhavo*), fed on rice and gruel (*odanakummÄsÅ«pacayo*), impermanent (*anicca*), liable to be injured and abraded (*ucchÄdanaparimaddana*), broken and destroyed (*bhedanaviddhaá¹ƒsanadhammo*). And this is my consciousness (*viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹ƒ*) which is bound to it and dependent on it.â€™ And furthermore, young man (*mÄá¹‡ava*), when a *bhikkhu*'s mind is thus concentrated (*samÄhite citte*)â€¦ and has gained imperturbability (*ÄneÃ±jappatte*), he directs and inclines it to knowledge and vision (*Ã±Äá¹‡adassanÄya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti*). He understands thus... and is bound up with it. This comes to him through wisdom (*paÃ±Ã±Äya*).
473. paÃ±Ã±Äkkhandho 472. "katamo pana so, bho Änanda, ariyo paÃ±Ã±Äkkhandho, yassa bho bhavaá¹ƒ gotamo vaá¹‡á¹‡avÄdÄ« ahosi, yattha ca imaá¹ƒ janataá¹ƒ samÄdapesi nivesesi patiá¹­á¹­hÄpesÄ«"ti? "seyyathÄpi, mÄá¹‡ava, maá¹‡i veá¸·uriyo subho jÄtimÄ aá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒso suparikammakato accho vippasanno anÄvilo sabbÄkÄrasampanno. tatrÄssa suttaá¹ƒ Ävutaá¹ƒ nÄ«laá¹ƒ vÄ pÄ«taá¹ƒ vÄ lohitaá¹ƒ vÄ odÄtaá¹ƒ vÄ paá¹‡á¸usuttaá¹ƒ vÄ. tamenaá¹ƒ cakkhumÄ puriso hatthe karitvÄ paccavekkheyya â€“ â€˜ayaá¹ƒ kho maá¹‡i veá¸·uriyo subho jÄtimÄ aá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒso suparikammakato accho vippasanno anÄvilo sabbÄkÄrasampanno. tatridaá¹ƒ suttaá¹ƒ Ävutaá¹ƒ nÄ«laá¹ƒ vÄ pÄ«taá¹ƒ vÄ lohitaá¹ƒ vÄ odÄtaá¹ƒ vÄ paá¹‡á¸usuttaá¹ƒ vÄâ€™ti. evameva kho, mÄá¹‡ava, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte Ã±Äá¹‡adassanÄya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so evaá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti â€“ â€˜ayaá¹ƒ kho me kÄyo rÅ«pÄ« cÄtumahÄbhÅ«tiko mÄtÄpettikasambhavo odanakummÄsÅ«pacayo aniccucchÄdanaparimaddanabhedana-viddhaá¹ƒsanadhammo. idaÃ±ca pana me viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹ƒ ettha sitaá¹ƒ ettha paá¹­ibaddhaâ€™nti. yampi, mÄá¹‡ava, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citteâ€¦peâ€¦ ÄneÃ±jappatte Ã±Äá¹‡adassanÄya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so evaá¹ƒ pajÄnÄtiâ€¦peâ€¦ ettha paá¹­ibaddhanti. idampissa hoti paÃ±Ã±Äya. 473. "so evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte manomayaá¹ƒ kÄyaá¹ƒ abhinimmÄnÄya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so imamhÄ kÄyÄ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ kÄyaá¹ƒ abhinimminÄti rÅ«piá¹ƒ manomayaá¹ƒ sabbaá¹…gapaccaá¹…giá¹ƒ ahÄ«nindriyaá¹ƒ.
â€œWhen his mind is thus concentrated (*samÄhite citte*), pure (*parisuddhe*) and bright (*pariyodÄte*), unblemished (*anaá¹…gaá¹‡e*), free from defects (*vigatÅ«pakkilese*), malleable (*mudubhÅ«te*), wieldy (*kammaniye*), steady (*á¹­hite*), and attained to imperturbability (*ÄneÃ±jappatte*), he directs and inclines it to creating a mind-made body (*manomayaá¹ƒ kÄyaá¹ƒ abhinimmÄnÄya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti*). From this body (*kÄyÄ*) he creates another body (*kÄyaá¹ƒ*) having material form (*rÅ«piá¹ƒ*), mind-made (*manomayaá¹ƒ*), complete in all its parts (*sabbaá¹…gapaccaá¹…giá¹ƒ*), not lacking any faculties (*ahÄ«nindriyaá¹ƒ*). It is just as if, young man, a person were to draw out a reed from its sheath. He would think, â€˜This is the reed, this is the sheath; the reed is one thing, the sheath another, but the reed has been drawn out from the sheath.â€™ Or as if, young man, a person were to draw a sword from its scabbard. He would think, â€˜This is the sword, this is the scabbard; the sword is one thing, the scabbard another, but the sword has been drawn out from the scabbard.â€™ Or as if, young man, a person were to pull a snake out from its slough. He would think, â€˜This is the snake, this is the slough; the snake is one thing, the slough another; it is from the slough that the snake has been pulled out.â€™ In the same way, young man, a *bhikkhu* â€¦peâ€¦ when his mind is thus concentrated, pure and bright, unblemished, free from impurities, malleable, workable, established, and having gained imperturbability, directs and inclines his mind towards creating a mind-made body (*manomayaá¹ƒ kÄyaá¹ƒ*)â€¦peâ€¦. This comes to him through wisdom (*paÃ±Ã±Äya*).
474. "seyyathÄpi, mÄá¹‡ava, puriso muÃ±jamhÄ Ä«sikaá¹ƒ pavÄheyya. tassa evamassa â€“ â€˜ayaá¹ƒ muÃ±jo ayaá¹ƒ Ä«sikÄ, aÃ±Ã±o muÃ±jo aÃ±Ã±Ä Ä«sikÄ, muÃ±jamhÄ tveva Ä«sikÄ pavÄá¸·hÄâ€™ti. seyyathÄ vÄ pana, mÄá¹‡ava, puriso asiá¹ƒ kosiyÄ pavÄheyya. tassa evamassa â€“ â€˜ayaá¹ƒ asi, ayaá¹ƒ kosi, aÃ±Ã±o asi, aÃ±Ã±Ä kosi, kosiyÄ tveva asi pavÄá¸·hoâ€™ti. seyyathÄ vÄ pana, mÄá¹‡ava, puriso ahiá¹ƒ karaá¹‡á¸Ä uddhareyya. tassa evamassa â€“ â€˜ayaá¹ƒ ahi, ayaá¹ƒ karaá¹‡á¸o, aÃ±Ã±o ahi, aÃ±Ã±o karaá¹‡á¸o, karaá¹‡á¸Ä tveva ahi ubbhatoâ€™ti. evameva kho, mÄá¹‡ava, bhikkhuâ€¦peâ€¦ yampi, mÄá¹‡ava, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte manomayaá¹ƒ kÄyaá¹ƒ abhinimmÄnÄya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmetiâ€¦peâ€¦. idampissa hoti paÃ±Ã±Äya. 474. "so evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte iddhividhÄya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so anekavihitaá¹ƒ iddhividhaá¹ƒ paccanubhoti. ekopi hutvÄ bahudhÄ hoti, bahudhÄpi hutvÄ eko hoti. ÄvibhÄvaá¹ƒ tirobhÄvaá¹ƒ tirokuá¹­á¹­aá¹ƒ tiropÄkÄraá¹ƒ tiropabbataá¹ƒ asajjamÄno gacchati seyyathÄpi ÄkÄse. pathaviyÄpi ummujjanimujjaá¹ƒ karoti, seyyathÄpi udake. udakepi abhijjamÄne gacchati seyyathÄpi pathaviyaá¹ƒ. ÄkÄsepi pallaá¹…kena kamati seyyathÄpi pakkhÄ« sakuá¹‡o. imepi candimasÅ«riye evaá¹ƒ mahiddhike evaá¹ƒ mahÄnubhÄve pÄá¹‡inÄ parÄmasati parimajjati. yÄva brahmalokÄpi kÄyena vasaá¹ƒ vatteti. "seyyathÄpi, mÄá¹‡ava, dakkho kumbhakÄro vÄ kumbhakÄrantevÄsÄ« vÄ suparikammakatÄya mattikÄya yaÃ±Ã±adeva bhÄjanavikatiá¹ƒ Äkaá¹…kheyya, taá¹ƒ tadeva kareyya abhinipphÄdeyya. seyyathÄ vÄ pana, mÄá¹‡ava, dakkho dantakÄro vÄ dantakÄrantevÄsÄ« vÄ suparikammakatasmiá¹ƒ dantasmiá¹ƒ yaÃ±Ã±adeva dantavikatiá¹ƒ Äkaá¹…kheyya, taá¹ƒ tadeva kareyya abhinipphÄdeyya. seyyathÄ vÄ pana, mÄá¹‡ava, dakkho suvaá¹‡á¹‡akÄro vÄ suvaá¹‡á¹‡akÄrantevÄsÄ« vÄ suparikammakatasmiá¹ƒ suvaá¹‡á¹‡asmiá¹ƒ yaÃ±Ã±adeva suvaá¹‡á¹‡avikatiá¹ƒ Äkaá¹…kheyya, taá¹ƒ tadeva kareyya abhinipphÄdeyya. evameva kho, mÄá¹‡ava,
And he, with mind concentrated, purified and cleansed, unblemished, free from impurities, malleable, workable, established, and having gained imperturbability, directs and inclines his mind towards the modes of supernormal power (*iddhividhÄya*). He enjoys various supernormal powers (*anekavihitaá¹ƒ iddhividhaá¹ƒ paccanubhoti*). Having been one, he becomes many; having been many, he becomes one. He goes unimpeded through walls, ramparts, and mountains as if through space. He dives in and out of the earth as if it were water. He walks on the water without sinking as if it were land. Sitting cross-legged, he travels through space like a winged bird. He even touches and strokes with his hand the sun and moon, mighty and powerful as they are. He exercises mastery over the body as far as the BrahmÄ-world (*brahmalokÄpi kÄyena vasaá¹ƒ vatteti*). Just as, young man, a skilled potter or his apprentice might make and fashion out of well-prepared clay whatever kind of vessel he might desire. Or just as, young man, a skilled ivory-worker or his apprentice might make and fashion out of well-prepared ivory whatever kind of ivory work he might desire. Or just as, young man, a skilled goldsmith or his apprentice might make and fashion out of well-prepared gold whatever kind of gold work he might desire. In the same way, young man, Bhikkhu... and so on... furthermore, MÄá¹‡ava, when a *bhikkhu*'s mind is thus concentrated, purified, cleansed, without blemish, rid of defilements, pliable, workable, established, and unshakeable, he directs and applies his mind to the modes of supernormal power. He experiences the various kinds of supernormal power. Having been one, he becomes many...and so on...he wields bodily mastery even as far as the Brahma-world. That comes to him through wisdom.
475. bhikkhu â€¦peâ€¦ yampi mÄá¹‡ava bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte iddhividhÄya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so anekavihitaá¹ƒ iddhividhaá¹ƒ paccanubhoti. ekopi hutvÄ bahudhÄ hoti â€¦peâ€¦ yÄva brahmalokÄpi kÄyena vasaá¹ƒ vatteti. idampissa hoti paÃ±Ã±Äya. 475. "so evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citteâ€¦peâ€¦ ÄneÃ±jappatte dibbÄya sotadhÄtuyÄ cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so dibbÄya sotadhÄtuyÄ visuddhÄya atikkantamÄnusikÄya ubho sadde suá¹‡Äti dibbe ca mÄnuse ca ye dÅ«re santike ca. seyyathÄpi, mÄá¹‡ava, puriso addhÄnamaggappaá¹­ipanno. so suá¹‡eyya bherisaddampi mudiá¹…gasaddampi saá¹…khapaá¹‡avadindimasaddampi. tassa evamassa â€“ â€˜bherisaddo itipi mudiá¹…gasaddo itipi saá¹…khapaá¹‡avadindimasaddo itiâ€™pi [itipÄ«ti (ka.)]. evameva kho, mÄá¹‡ava, bhikkhuâ€¦peâ€¦. yampi mÄá¹‡ava, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citteâ€¦peâ€¦ ÄneÃ±jappatte dibbÄya sotadhÄtuyÄ cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so dibbÄya sotadhÄtuyÄ visuddhÄya atikkantamÄnusikÄya ubho sadde suá¹‡Äti dibbe ca mÄnuse ca ye dÅ«re santike ca. idampissa hoti paÃ±Ã±Äya. 476. "so evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte cetopariyaÃ±Äá¹‡Äya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so parasattÄnaá¹ƒ parapuggalÄnaá¹ƒ cetasÄ ceto paricca pajÄnÄti, â€˜sarÄgaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ sarÄgaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, â€˜vÄ«tarÄgaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ vÄ«tarÄgaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, â€˜sadosaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ sadosaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, â€˜vÄ«tadosaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ vÄ«tadosaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, â€˜samohaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ samohaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, â€˜vÄ«tamohaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ vÄ«tamohaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, â€˜saá¹…khittaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ saá¹…khittaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, â€˜vikkhittaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ vikkhittaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, â€˜mahaggataá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ mahaggataá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, â€˜amahaggataá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ amahaggataá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, â€˜sauttaraá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ sauttaraá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, â€˜anuttaraá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ anuttaraá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, â€˜samÄhitaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ samÄhitaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, â€˜asamÄhitaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ asamÄhitaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti,
"When his mind is thus concentrated...and so on...attained to imperturbability, he directs and applies it to the divine element of the ear (*dibba sotadhÄtu*). With the divine ear-element (*dibbÄya sotadhÄtuyÄ*), which is purified and surpasses the human, he hears both kinds of sounds, divine and human, those which are far and near. Just as, MÄá¹‡ava, a man is traveling along a road. He might hear the sound of a kettle drum, a small drum, a conch, cymbals, or a kettle-drum. He would think: â€˜This is the sound of a kettle drum, this is the sound of a small drum, this is the sound of a conch, cymbals, or a kettle-drum.â€™ Just so, MÄá¹‡ava, a *bhikkhu*â€¦and so onâ€¦. Furthermore, MÄá¹‡ava, when a *bhikkhu*'s mind is thus concentratedâ€¦and so onâ€¦attained to imperturbability, he directs and applies it to the divine element of the ear (*dibbÄya sotadhÄtuyÄ*). With the divine ear-element (*dibbÄya sotadhÄtuyÄ*), which is purified and surpasses the human, he hears both kinds of sounds, divine and human, those which are far and near. That comes to him through wisdom.
476. bhikkhu â€¦peâ€¦ yampi mÄá¹‡ava bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte iddhividhÄya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so anekavihitaá¹ƒ iddhividhaá¹ƒ paccanubhoti. ekopi hutvÄ bahudhÄ hoti â€¦peâ€¦ yÄva brahmalokÄpi kÄyena vasaá¹ƒ vatteti. idampissa hoti paÃ±Ã±Äya. 475. "so evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citteâ€¦peâ€¦ ÄneÃ±jappatte dibbÄya sotadhÄtuyÄ cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so dibbÄya sotadhÄtuyÄ visuddhÄya atikkantamÄnusikÄya ubho sadde suá¹‡Äti dibbe ca mÄnuse ca ye dÅ«re santike ca. seyyathÄpi, mÄá¹‡ava, puriso addhÄnamaggappaá¹­ipanno. so suá¹‡eyya bherisaddampi mudiá¹…gasaddampi saá¹…khapaá¹‡avadindimasaddampi. tassa evamassa â€“ â€˜bherisaddo itipi mudiá¹…gasaddo itipi saá¹…khapaá¹‡avadindimasaddo itiâ€™pi [itipÄ«ti (ka.)]. evameva kho, mÄá¹‡ava, bhikkhuâ€¦peâ€¦. yampi mÄá¹‡ava, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citteâ€¦peâ€¦ ÄneÃ±jappatte dibbÄya sotadhÄtuyÄ cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so dibbÄya sotadhÄtuyÄ visuddhÄya atikkantamÄnusikÄya ubho sadde suá¹‡Äti dibbe ca mÄnuse ca ye dÅ«re santike ca. idampissa hoti paÃ±Ã±Äya. 476. "so evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte cetopariyaÃ±Äá¹‡Äya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so parasattÄnaá¹ƒ parapuggalÄnaá¹ƒ cetasÄ ceto paricca pajÄnÄti, â€˜sarÄgaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ sarÄgaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, â€˜vÄ«tarÄgaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ vÄ«tarÄgaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, â€˜sadosaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ sadosaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, â€˜vÄ«tadosaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ vÄ«tadosaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, â€˜samohaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ samohaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, â€˜vÄ«tamohaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ vÄ«tamohaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, â€˜saá¹…khittaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ saá¹…khittaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, â€˜vikkhittaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ vikkhittaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, â€˜mahaggataá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ mahaggataá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, â€˜amahaggataá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ amahaggataá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, â€˜sauttaraá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ sauttaraá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, â€˜anuttaraá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ anuttaraá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, â€˜samÄhitaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ samÄhitaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, â€˜asamÄhitaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ asamÄhitaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti,
"When his mind is thus concentrated, purified and cleansed, without blemish, rid of defilements, pliable, workable, established, and having attained imperturbability, he directs and applies his mind to the knowledge of penetrating the minds of others (*cetopariyaÃ±Äá¹‡a*). He understands the minds of other beings and other persons, having encompassed them with his own mind; he understands a mind with lust as â€˜a mind with lust,â€™ a mind without lust as â€˜a mind without lust,â€™ a mind with hate as â€˜a mind with hate,â€™ a mind without hate as â€˜a mind without hate,â€™ a mind with delusion as â€˜a mind with delusion,â€™ a mind without delusion as â€˜a mind without delusion,â€™ a contracted mind as â€˜a contracted mind,â€™ a distracted mind as â€˜a distracted mind,â€™ an exalted mind as â€˜an exalted mind,â€™ an unexalted mind as â€˜an unexalted mind,â€™ a surpassable mind as â€˜a surpassable mind,â€™ an unsurpassable mind as â€˜an unsurpassable mind,â€™ a concentrated mind as â€˜a concentrated mind,â€™ an unconcentrated mind as â€˜an unconcentrated mind.' He understands a liberated mind as a liberated mind, and an unliberated mind as an unliberated mind. â€œJust as, young man, a woman or a man, young, youthful, fond of ornaments, examining their own facial reflection in a clear bright mirror or in a bowl of clear water, would know, if there were a blemish, â€˜It has a blemish,â€™ and if there were no blemish, â€˜It has no blemish.â€™ In the same way, young man, a *bhiká¹£u*â€¦ and when, young man, a *bhiká¹£u* with mind thus concentrated... directs and inclines his mind to the knowledge of encompassing the minds of others. He discerns the awareness of other beings, other individuals, having encompassed it with his own awareness. He understands a mind with lust as a mind with lustâ€¦ and an unliberated mind as an unliberated mind. This comes to him through wisdom.
477. â€˜vimuttaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ vimuttaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti, â€˜avimuttaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ avimuttaá¹ƒ cittaâ€™nti pajÄnÄti. "seyyathÄpi, mÄá¹‡ava, itthÄ« vÄ puriso vÄ daharo yuvÄ maá¹‡á¸anajÄtiko ÄdÄse vÄ parisuddhe pariyodÄte acche vÄ udakapatte sakaá¹ƒ mukhanimittaá¹ƒ paccavekkhamÄno sakaá¹‡ikaá¹ƒ vÄ sakaá¹‡ikanti jÄneyya, akaá¹‡ikaá¹ƒ vÄ akaá¹‡ikanti jÄneyya. evameva kho, mÄá¹‡ava, bhikkhuâ€¦peâ€¦ yampi, mÄá¹‡ava, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ samÄhiteâ€¦peâ€¦ ÄneÃ±jappatte cetopariyaÃ±Äá¹‡Äya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so parasattÄnaá¹ƒ purapuggalÄnaá¹ƒ cetasÄ ceto paricca pajÄnÄti, sarÄgaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ sarÄgaá¹ƒ cittanti pajÄnÄtiâ€¦peâ€¦ avimuttaá¹ƒ vÄ cittaá¹ƒ avimuttaá¹ƒ cittanti pajÄnÄti. idampissa hoti paÃ±Ã±Äya. 477. "so evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citteâ€¦peâ€¦ ÄneÃ±jappatte pubbenivÄsÄnussatiÃ±Äá¹‡Äya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so anekavihitaá¹ƒ pubbenivÄsaá¹ƒ anussarati. seyyathidaá¹ƒ, ekampi jÄtiá¹ƒ dvepi jÄtiyo tissopi jÄtiyo catassopi jÄtiyo paÃ±capi jÄtiyo dasapi jÄtiyo vÄ«sampi jÄtiyo tiá¹ƒsampi jÄtiyo cattÄlÄ«sampi jÄtiyo paÃ±Ã±Äsampi jÄtiyo jÄtisatampi jÄtisahassampi jÄtisatasahassampi anekepi saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­akappe anekepi vivaá¹­á¹­akappe anekepi saá¹ƒvaá¹­á¹­avivaá¹­á¹­akappe â€“ â€˜amutrÄsiá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒnÄmo evaá¹ƒgotto evaá¹ƒvaá¹‡á¹‡o evamÄhÄro evaá¹ƒsukhadukkhappaá¹­isaá¹ƒvedÄ« evamÄyupariyanto. so tato cuto amutra udapÄdiá¹ƒ, tatrÄpÄsiá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒnÄmo evaá¹ƒgotto evaá¹ƒvaá¹‡á¹‡o evamÄhÄro evaá¹ƒsukhadukkhappaá¹­isaá¹ƒvedÄ« evamÄyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhÅ«papannoâ€™ti. iti sÄkÄraá¹ƒ sauddesaá¹ƒ anekavihitaá¹ƒ pubbenivÄsaá¹ƒ anussarati. "seyyathÄpi, mÄá¹‡ava, puriso sakamhÄ gÄmÄ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ gÄmaá¹ƒ gaccheyya, tamhÄpi gÄmÄ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ gÄmaá¹ƒ gaccheyya, so tamhÄ gÄmÄ sakaá¹ƒyeva gÄmaá¹ƒ paccÄgaccheyya. tassa evamassa â€“ â€˜ahaá¹ƒ kho sakamhÄ gÄmÄ amuá¹ƒ gÄmaá¹ƒ agacchiá¹ƒ, tatra evaá¹ƒ aá¹­á¹­hÄsiá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ nisÄ«diá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ abhÄsiá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ tuá¹‡hÄ« ahosiá¹ƒ. so tamhÄpi gÄmÄ amuá¹ƒ gÄmaá¹ƒ gacchiá¹ƒ, tatrÄpi evaá¹ƒ aá¹­á¹­hÄsiá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ nisÄ«diá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ abhÄsiá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ tuá¹‡hÄ« ahosiá¹ƒ. somhi tamhÄ gÄmÄ sakaá¹ƒyeva gÄmaá¹ƒ paccÄgatoâ€™ti. evameva kho, mÄá¹‡ava, bhikkhuâ€¦peâ€¦ yampi, mÄá¹‡ava, bhikkhu
â€œWhen his mind is thus concentratedâ€¦ he directs and inclines his mind to the knowledge of recollecting past lives. He recollects his numerous past lives. That is, one birth, two births, three, four, or five births; ten, twenty, thirty, forty, or fifty births; a hundred births, a thousand births, or a hundred thousand births; many aeons of world contraction, many aeons of world expansion, many aeons of world contraction and expansion: â€˜There I had such a name, belonged to such a clan, had such an appearance; such was my food, such my experience of pleasure and pain, such my span of life. Passing away from that, I arose there. There too I had such a name, belonged to such a clan, had such an appearance; such was my food, such my experience of pleasure and pain, such my span of life. Passing away from there, I was reborn here.â€™ Thus he recollects his numerous past lives in their modes and their details. â€œJust as, young man, a man might go from his own village to another village, then from that village to still another village, and then from that village he would return to his own village. He might think: â€˜I went from my own village to that village, and there I stood in such a way, sat in such a way, spoke in such a way, and remained silent in such a way. And from that village I went to that other village, and there too I stood in such a way, sat in such a way, spoke in such a way, and remained silent in such a way. And from that village I have just returned to my own village.â€™ In the same way, young man, a *bhiká¹£u*â€¦ and when, young man, a *bhiká¹£u*â€¦ Thus, with mind concentratedâ€¦and attained to imperturbability, he directs and inclines his mind to the knowledge of recollecting past lives. He recollects his manifold past lives. That is, one birthâ€¦Thus with their aspects and particulars he recollects his manifold past lives. That is known to him by wisdom.
478. evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citteâ€¦peâ€¦ ÄneÃ±jappatte pubbenivÄsÄnussatiÃ±Äá¹‡Äya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so anekavihitaá¹ƒ pubbenivÄsaá¹ƒ anussarati. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ ekampi jÄtiá¹ƒâ€¦peâ€¦ iti sÄkÄraá¹ƒ sauddesaá¹ƒ anekavihitaá¹ƒ pubbenivÄsaá¹ƒ anussarati. idampissa hoti paÃ±Ã±Äya. 478. "so evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citteâ€¦peâ€¦ ÄneÃ±jappatte sattÄnaá¹ƒ cutÅ«papÄtaÃ±Äá¹‡Äya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so dibbena cakkhunÄ visuddhena atikkantamÄnusakena satte passati cavamÄne upapajjamÄne hÄ«ne paá¹‡Ä«te suvaá¹‡á¹‡e dubbaá¹‡á¹‡e sugate duggate, yathÄkammÅ«page satte pajÄnÄti â€“ â€˜ime vata bhonto sattÄ kÄyaduccaritena samannÄgatÄ vacÄ«duccaritena samannÄgatÄ manoduccaritena samannÄgatÄ ariyÄnaá¹ƒ upavÄdakÄ micchÄdiá¹­á¹­hikÄ micchÄdiá¹­á¹­hikammasamÄdÄnÄ. te kÄyassa bhedÄ paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä apÄyaá¹ƒ duggatiá¹ƒ vinipÄtaá¹ƒ nirayaá¹ƒ upapannÄ. ime vÄ pana bhonto sattÄ kÄyasucaritena samannÄgatÄ vacÄ«sucaritena samannÄgatÄ manosucaritena samannÄgatÄ ariyÄnaá¹ƒ anupavÄdakÄ sammÄdiá¹­á¹­hikÄ sammÄdiá¹­á¹­hikammasamÄdÄnÄ. te kÄyassa bhedÄ paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä sugatiá¹ƒ saggaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ upapannÄâ€™ti. iti dibbena cakkhunÄ visuddhena atikkantamÄnusakena satte passati cavamÄne upapajjamÄne hÄ«ne paá¹‡Ä«te suvaá¹‡á¹‡e dubbaá¹‡á¹‡e sugate duggate, yathÄkammÅ«page satte pajÄnÄti. "seyyathÄpi, mÄá¹‡ava, majjhesiá¹…ghÄá¹­ake pÄsÄdo, tattha cakkhumÄ puriso á¹­hito passeyya manusse gehaá¹ƒ pavisantepi nikkhamantepi rathikÄyapi vÄ«thiá¹ƒ saÃ±carante majjhesiá¹…ghÄá¹­ake nisinnepi. tassa evamassa â€“ â€˜ete manussÄ gehaá¹ƒ pavisanti, ete nikkhamanti, ete rathikÄya vÄ«thiá¹ƒ saÃ±caranti, ete majjhesiá¹…ghÄá¹­ake nisinnÄâ€™ti. evameva kho, mÄá¹‡ava, bhikkhuâ€¦peâ€¦ yampi, mÄá¹‡ava, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citteâ€¦peâ€¦ ÄneÃ±jappatte sattÄnaá¹ƒ cutÅ«papÄtaÃ±Äá¹‡Äya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so dibbena cakkhunÄ visuddhena atikkantamÄnusakena satte passati cavamÄne upapajjamÄne hÄ«ne paá¹‡Ä«te suvaá¹‡á¹‡e dubbaá¹‡á¹‡e sugate duggate, yathÄkammÅ«page satte pajÄnÄti. idampissa hoti paÃ±Ã±Äya. 479. "so evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte ÄsavÄnaá¹ƒ
â€œWhen his mind is thus concentratedâ€¦and attained to imperturbability, he directs and inclines it to the knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings. With the divine eye, which is purified and surpasses the human, he sees beings passing away and reappearingâ€”inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, fortunate and unfortunateâ€”and he understands how beings fare according to their *kamma*, thus: â€˜These beingsâ€” who were endowed with bad conduct of body, speech, and mind, who reviled the noble ones, held wrong views, and undertook actions governed by wrong viewsâ€” with the breakup of the body, after death, have reappeared in the plane of misery, the bad destinations, the lower realms, in hell. But these beings who engaged in good conduct of body, speech, and mind, who did not abuse the noble ones, who held right view and acted accordingly, at the breaking up of the body after death, have been reborn in a good destination, a heaven world.â€™ Thus with the divine eye, purified and surpassing that of humans, he sees beings passing away and re-arising. â€œJust as, young man, if there were a pavilion in the middle of a crossroads, and a man with good eyesight standing there might see people entering or leaving a house, walking along the street, or sitting in the middle of the crossroads. He would think to himself: â€˜Those people are entering the house, those are leaving it, those are walking along the streets, and those are sitting in the central square.â€™ In the same way, young man, the monkâ€¦and attained to imperturbability, directs and inclines his mind to the knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings. With the divine eye, which is purified and surpasses the human, one sees beings passing away and reappearing, inferior and superior, fair and ugly, fortunate and unfortunate, and one understands how beings pass on according to their actions. That is known to him by wisdom.
479. evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citteâ€¦peâ€¦ ÄneÃ±jappatte pubbenivÄsÄnussatiÃ±Äá¹‡Äya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so anekavihitaá¹ƒ pubbenivÄsaá¹ƒ anussarati. seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ ekampi jÄtiá¹ƒâ€¦peâ€¦ iti sÄkÄraá¹ƒ sauddesaá¹ƒ anekavihitaá¹ƒ pubbenivÄsaá¹ƒ anussarati. idampissa hoti paÃ±Ã±Äya. 478. "so evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citteâ€¦peâ€¦ ÄneÃ±jappatte sattÄnaá¹ƒ cutÅ«papÄtaÃ±Äá¹‡Äya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so dibbena cakkhunÄ visuddhena atikkantamÄnusakena satte passati cavamÄne upapajjamÄne hÄ«ne paá¹‡Ä«te suvaá¹‡á¹‡e dubbaá¹‡á¹‡e sugate duggate, yathÄkammÅ«page satte pajÄnÄti â€“ â€˜ime vata bhonto sattÄ kÄyaduccaritena samannÄgatÄ vacÄ«duccaritena samannÄgatÄ manoduccaritena samannÄgatÄ ariyÄnaá¹ƒ upavÄdakÄ micchÄdiá¹­á¹­hikÄ micchÄdiá¹­á¹­hikammasamÄdÄnÄ. te kÄyassa bhedÄ paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä apÄyaá¹ƒ duggatiá¹ƒ vinipÄtaá¹ƒ nirayaá¹ƒ upapannÄ. ime vÄ pana bhonto sattÄ kÄyasucaritena samannÄgatÄ vacÄ«sucaritena samannÄgatÄ manosucaritena samannÄgatÄ ariyÄnaá¹ƒ anupavÄdakÄ sammÄdiá¹­á¹­hikÄ sammÄdiá¹­á¹­hikammasamÄdÄnÄ. te kÄyassa bhedÄ paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä sugatiá¹ƒ saggaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ upapannÄâ€™ti. iti dibbena cakkhunÄ visuddhena atikkantamÄnusakena satte passati cavamÄne upapajjamÄne hÄ«ne paá¹‡Ä«te suvaá¹‡á¹‡e dubbaá¹‡á¹‡e sugate duggate, yathÄkammÅ«page satte pajÄnÄti. "seyyathÄpi, mÄá¹‡ava, majjhesiá¹…ghÄá¹­ake pÄsÄdo, tattha cakkhumÄ puriso á¹­hito passeyya manusse gehaá¹ƒ pavisantepi nikkhamantepi rathikÄyapi vÄ«thiá¹ƒ saÃ±carante majjhesiá¹…ghÄá¹­ake nisinnepi. tassa evamassa â€“ â€˜ete manussÄ gehaá¹ƒ pavisanti, ete nikkhamanti, ete rathikÄya vÄ«thiá¹ƒ saÃ±caranti, ete majjhesiá¹…ghÄá¹­ake nisinnÄâ€™ti. evameva kho, mÄá¹‡ava, bhikkhuâ€¦peâ€¦ yampi, mÄá¹‡ava, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citteâ€¦peâ€¦ ÄneÃ±jappatte sattÄnaá¹ƒ cutÅ«papÄtaÃ±Äá¹‡Äya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so dibbena cakkhunÄ visuddhena atikkantamÄnusakena satte passati cavamÄne upapajjamÄne hÄ«ne paá¹‡Ä«te suvaá¹‡á¹‡e dubbaá¹‡á¹‡e sugate duggate, yathÄkammÅ«page satte pajÄnÄti. idampissa hoti paÃ±Ã±Äya. 479. "so evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte parisuddhe pariyodÄte anaá¹…gaá¹‡e vigatÅ«pakkilese mudubhÅ«te kammaniye á¹­hite ÄneÃ±jappatte ÄsavÄnaá¹ƒ
â€œWhen his mind is thus concentrated, purified and bright, unblemished, rid of imperfection, malleable, wieldy, steady, and attained to imperturbability, He directs and inclines his mind to the knowledge of the destruction of the corruptions ( *ÄsavÄnaá¹ƒ khayaÃ±Äá¹‡Äya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti*). He understands as it actually is: "This is suffering" ( *idaá¹ƒ dukkhaá¹ƒ*), he understands as it actually is: "This is the origin of suffering" ( *dukkhasamudayo*), he understands as it actually is: "This is the cessation of suffering" ( *dukkha nirodho*), he understands as it actually is: "This is the path leading to the cessation of suffering" ( *dukkha nirodha gÄminÄ« paá¹­ipadÄ*), he understands as it actually is: "These are the cankers" ( *ime ÄsavÄ*), He understands as it actually is: "This is the origin of the cankers" ( *Äsavasamudayo*), He understands as it actually is: "This is the cessation of the cankers" ( *Äsavanirodho*), He understands as it actually is: "This is the path leading to the cessation of the cankers" ( *ÄsavanirodhagÄminÄ« paá¹­ipadÄ*). When he knows and sees thus, his mind is liberated from the canker of sensual desire ( *kÄmÄsavÄpi cittaá¹ƒ vimuccati*), from the canker of existence ( *bhavÄsavÄpi cittaá¹ƒ vimuccati*), and from the canker of ignorance ( *avijjÄsavÄpi cittaá¹ƒ vimuccati*). When it is liberated, the knowledge arises: â€˜Itâ€™s liberated.â€™ He understands: â€˜Destroyed is birth ( *khÄ«á¹‡Ä jÄti*), the holy life has been lived ( *vusitaá¹ƒ brahmacariyaá¹ƒ*), what had to be done has been done ( *kataá¹ƒ karaá¹‡Ä«yaá¹ƒ*), there is no more for this state of being ( *nÄparaá¹ƒ itthattÄya*).â€™ "Just as if, MÄá¹‡ava, in the midst of the mountains there were a pond, clear ( *accho*), limpid ( *vippasanno*), and undisturbed ( *anÄvilo*). A man with good eyesight standing on the bank could see oyster-shells (*sippikasambukaá¹ƒpi*), gravel and pebbles (*sakkharakathalaá¹ƒpi*), and shoals of fish (*macchagumbaá¹ƒpi*) moving about (*carantampi*) and keeping still (*tiá¹­á¹­hantampi*). He might think: â€œThis pond ( *udakarahado* ) is clear (*accho*), limpid (*vippasanno*), and undisturbed (*anÄvilo*). There are oyster-shells (*sippikasambukÄpi*), gravel and pebbles (*sakkharakathalÄpi*), and shoals of fish (*macchagumbÄpi*) moving about (*carantipi*) and keeping still (*tiá¹­á¹­hantipÄ«â€™ti*).â€ In the same way, MÄá¹‡ava, a monkâ€¦and so onâ€¦ just as that monk, MÄá¹‡ava, with mind thus concentrated ( *evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citte* )â€¦ and so onâ€¦ having attained imperturbability ( *ÄneÃ±jappatte*), directs and inclines his mind to the knowledge of the destruction of the corruptions (*ÄsavÄnaá¹ƒ khayaÃ±Äá¹‡Äya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti*). He understands as it actually is: "This is suffering" ( *idaá¹ƒ dukkhaá¹ƒ* )â€¦ and so onâ€¦ "This is the path leading to the cessation of the taints" ( *ÄsavanirodhagÄminÄ« paá¹­ipadÄ*). When he knows and sees thus, his mind is liberated from the canker of sensual desire ( *kÄmÄsavÄpi cittaá¹ƒ vimuccati*), from the canker of existence ( *bhavÄsavÄpi cittaá¹ƒ vimuccati*), and from the canker of ignorance ( *avijjÄsavÄpi cittaá¹ƒ vimuccati*). When it is liberated, the knowledge arises: â€˜Itâ€™s liberated.â€™ He understands: â€˜Destroyed is birth ( *khÄ«á¹‡Ä jÄti*), the holy life has been lived ( *vusitaá¹ƒ brahmacariyaá¹ƒ*), what had to be done has been done ( *kataá¹ƒ karaá¹‡Ä«yaá¹ƒ*), there is no more for this state of being ( *nÄparaá¹ƒ itthattÄya*).â€™ This comes to him through wisdom ( *paÃ±Ã±Äya*).
480. khayaÃ±Äá¹‡Äya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so idaá¹ƒ dukkhanti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, ayaá¹ƒ dukkhasamudayoti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, ayaá¹ƒ dukkhanirodhoti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, ayaá¹ƒ dukkhanirodhagÄminÄ« paá¹­ipadÄti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, ime ÄsavÄti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, ayaá¹ƒ Äsavasamudayoti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, ayaá¹ƒ Äsavanirodhoti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti, ayaá¹ƒ ÄsavanirodhagÄminÄ« paá¹­ipadÄti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti. tassa evaá¹ƒ jÄnato evaá¹ƒ passato kÄmÄsavÄpi cittaá¹ƒ vimuccati, bhavÄsavÄpi cittaá¹ƒ vimuccati, avijjÄsavÄpi cittaá¹ƒ vimuccati, vimuttasmiá¹ƒ vimuttamiti Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹ƒ hoti. â€˜khÄ«á¹‡Ä jÄti, vusitaá¹ƒ brahmacariyaá¹ƒ, kataá¹ƒ karaá¹‡Ä«yaá¹ƒ, nÄparaá¹ƒ itthattÄyÄâ€™ti pajÄnÄti. "seyyathÄpi, mÄá¹‡ava, pabbatasaá¹…khepe udakarahado accho vippasanno anÄvilo. tattha cakkhumÄ puriso tÄ«re á¹­hito passeyya sippikasambukampi sakkharakathalampi macchagumbampi carantampi tiá¹­á¹­hantampi. tassa evamassa â€“ â€˜ayaá¹ƒ kho udakarahado accho vippasanno anÄvilo. tatrime sippikasambukÄpi sakkharakathalÄpi macchagumbÄpi carantipi tiá¹­á¹­hantipÄ«â€™ti. evameva kho, mÄá¹‡ava, bhikkhuâ€¦peâ€¦ yampi, mÄá¹‡ava, bhikkhu evaá¹ƒ samÄhite citteâ€¦peâ€¦ ÄneÃ±jappatte ÄsavÄnaá¹ƒ khayaÃ±Äá¹‡Äya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmeti. so idaá¹ƒ dukkhanti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄtiâ€¦peâ€¦ ÄsavanirodhagÄminÄ« paá¹­ipadÄti yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ƒ pajÄnÄti. tassa evaá¹ƒ jÄnato evaá¹ƒ passato kÄmÄsavÄpi cittaá¹ƒ vimuccati, bhavÄsavÄpi cittaá¹ƒ vimuccati, avijjÄsavÄpi cittaá¹ƒ vimuccati, vimuttasmiá¹ƒ vimuttamiti Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹ƒ hoti, â€˜khÄ«á¹‡Ä jÄti, vusitaá¹ƒ brahmacariyaá¹ƒ, kataá¹ƒ karaá¹‡Ä«yaá¹ƒ, nÄparaá¹ƒ itthattÄyÄâ€™ti pajÄnÄti. idampissa hoti paÃ±Ã±Äya. 480. "ayaá¹ƒ kho, so mÄá¹‡ava, ariyo paÃ±Ã±Äkkhandho yassa so bhagavÄ vaá¹‡á¹‡avÄdÄ« ahosi, yattha ca imaá¹ƒ janataá¹ƒ samÄdapesi nivesesi patiá¹­á¹­hÄpesi. natthi cevettha uttarikaraá¹‡Ä«ya"nti. "acchariyaá¹ƒ, bho Änanda, abbhutaá¹ƒ, bho Änanda! so cÄyaá¹ƒ, bho Änanda, ariyo paÃ±Ã±Äkkhandho paripuá¹‡á¹‡o, no aparipuá¹‡á¹‡o. evaá¹ƒ paripuá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ cÄhaá¹ƒ, bho Änanda, ariyaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±Äkkhandhaá¹ƒ ito bahiddhÄ aÃ±Ã±esu samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡esu na samanupassÄmi.
"That, MÄá¹‡ava, is the noble aggregate of wisdom ( *ariyo paÃ±Ã±Äkkhandho* ) of which the Blessed One was an advocate, with which he aroused, exhorted and established this populace. Beyond that there is nothing to be done ( *natthi cevettha uttarikaraá¹‡Ä«ya*)." "Wonderful, Ä€nanda, amazing, Ä€nanda! This noble aggregate of wisdom ( *ariyo paÃ±Ã±Äkkhandho* ) is perfectly complete ( *paripuá¹‡á¹‡o*), not incomplete ( *no aparipuá¹‡á¹‡o*). Thus perfectly complete, I, Ä€nanda, do not see this noble aggregate of wisdom ( *ariyaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±Äkkhandhaá¹ƒ* ) anywhere else among ascetics and Brahmins.
481. 11. kevaá¹­á¹­asuttaá¹ƒ kevaá¹­á¹­agahapatiputtavatthu 481. evaá¹ƒ me sutaá¹ƒ â€“ ekaá¹ƒ samayaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ nÄá¸·andÄyaá¹ƒ viharati pÄvÄrikambavane. atha kho kevaá¹­á¹­o gahapatiputto yena bhagavÄ tenupasaá¹…kami, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ bhagavantaá¹ƒ abhivÄdetvÄ ekamantaá¹ƒ nisÄ«di. ekamantaá¹ƒ nisinno kho kevaá¹­á¹­o gahapatiputto bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "ayaá¹ƒ, bhante, nÄá¸·andÄ iddhÄ ceva phÄ«tÄ ca bahujanÄ Äkiá¹‡á¹‡amanussÄ bhagavati abhippasannÄ. sÄdhu, bhante, bhagavÄ ekaá¹ƒ bhikkhuá¹ƒ samÄdisatu, yo uttarimanussadhammÄ, iddhipÄá¹­ihÄriyaá¹ƒ karissati, evÄyaá¹ƒ nÄá¸·andÄ bhiyyoso mattÄya bhagavati abhippasÄ«dissatÄ«"ti. evaá¹ƒ vutte, bhagavÄ kevaá¹­á¹­aá¹ƒ gahapatiputtaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "na kho ahaá¹ƒ, kevaá¹­á¹­a, bhikkhÅ«naá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ desemi â€“ etha tumhe, bhikkhave, gihÄ«naá¹ƒ odÄtavasanÄnaá¹ƒ uttarimanussadhammÄ iddhipÄá¹­ihÄriyaá¹ƒ karothÄ"ti. 482. dutiyampi kho kevaá¹­á¹­o gahapatiputto bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "nÄhaá¹ƒ, bhante, bhagavantaá¹ƒ dhaá¹ƒsemi, api ca, evaá¹ƒ vadÄmi â€“ â€˜ayaá¹ƒ, bhante, nÄá¸·andÄ iddhÄ ceva phÄ«tÄ ca bahujanÄ Äkiá¹‡á¹‡amanussÄ bhagavati abhippasannÄ. sÄdhu, bhante, bhagavÄ ekaá¹ƒ bhikkhuá¹ƒ samÄdisatu, yo uttarimanussadhammÄ iddhipÄá¹­ihÄriyaá¹ƒ karissati, evÄyaá¹ƒ nÄá¸·andÄ bhiyyoso mattÄya bhagavati abhippasÄ«dissatÄ«"â€™ti. dutiyampi kho bhagavÄ kevaá¹­á¹­aá¹ƒ gahapatiputtaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "na kho ahaá¹ƒ, kevaá¹­á¹­a, bhikkhÅ«naá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ desemi â€“ etha tumhe, bhikkhave, gihÄ«naá¹ƒ odÄtavasanÄnaá¹ƒ uttarimanussadhammÄ iddhipÄá¹­ihÄriyaá¹ƒ karothÄ"â€™ti. tatiyampi kho kevaá¹­á¹­o gahapatiputto bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "nÄhaá¹ƒ, bhante, bhagavantaá¹ƒ dhaá¹ƒsemi, api ca, evaá¹ƒ vadÄmi â€“ â€˜ayaá¹ƒ, bhante, nÄá¸·andÄ iddhÄ ceva phÄ«tÄ ca bahujanÄ Äkiá¹‡á¹‡amanussÄ bhagavati abhippasannÄ. sÄdhu, bhante, bhagavÄ ekaá¹ƒ bhikkhuá¹ƒ samÄdisatu, yo uttarimanussadhammÄ iddhipÄá¹­ihÄriyaá¹ƒ karissati. evÄyaá¹ƒ nÄá¸·andÄ bhiyyoso mattÄya bhagavati abhippasÄ«dissatÄ«â€™ti.
Thus have I heard. On one occasion the Blessed One was staying at NÄá¸·andÄ in PÄvÄrika's mango grove. Then Kevatta, the householderâ€™s son, approached the Blessed One, prostrated himself before him, and sat down to one side. Seated to one side, Kevatta, the householderâ€™s son, said to the Blessed One: "Venerable Sir, NÄá¸·andÄ is thriving, prosperous, populous, crowded with people, and its people have faith in the Blessed One. Venerable Sir, it would be good if the Blessed One were to instruct a monk to perform a superhuman feat, a miracle of psychic power, so that NÄá¸·andÄ would have even greater faith in the Blessed One." When this was said, the Blessed One said to Kevatta, the householderâ€™s son: "Kevaá¹­á¹­a, I do not teach the monks in this way: 'Come, monks, perform superhuman feats, miracles of psychic power, for the white-clothed laypeople!'"
482. 11. kevaá¹­á¹­asuttaá¹ƒ kevaá¹­á¹­agahapatiputtavatthu 481. evaá¹ƒ me sutaá¹ƒ â€“ ekaá¹ƒ samayaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ nÄá¸·andÄyaá¹ƒ viharati pÄvÄrikambavane. atha kho kevaá¹­á¹­o gahapatiputto yena bhagavÄ tenupasaá¹…kami, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ bhagavantaá¹ƒ abhivÄdetvÄ ekamantaá¹ƒ nisÄ«di. ekamantaá¹ƒ nisinno kho kevaá¹­á¹­o gahapatiputto bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "ayaá¹ƒ, bhante, nÄá¸·andÄ iddhÄ ceva phÄ«tÄ ca bahujanÄ Äkiá¹‡á¹‡amanussÄ bhagavati abhippasannÄ. sÄdhu, bhante, bhagavÄ ekaá¹ƒ bhikkhuá¹ƒ samÄdisatu, yo uttarimanussadhammÄ, iddhipÄá¹­ihÄriyaá¹ƒ karissati, evÄyaá¹ƒ nÄá¸·andÄ bhiyyoso mattÄya bhagavati abhippasÄ«dissatÄ«"ti. evaá¹ƒ vutte, bhagavÄ kevaá¹­á¹­aá¹ƒ gahapatiputtaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "na kho ahaá¹ƒ, kevaá¹­á¹­a, bhikkhÅ«naá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ desemi â€“ etha tumhe, bhikkhave, gihÄ«naá¹ƒ odÄtavasanÄnaá¹ƒ uttarimanussadhammÄ iddhipÄá¹­ihÄriyaá¹ƒ karothÄ"ti. 482. dutiyampi kho kevaá¹­á¹­o gahapatiputto bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "nÄhaá¹ƒ, bhante, bhagavantaá¹ƒ dhaá¹ƒsemi, api ca, evaá¹ƒ vadÄmi â€“ â€˜ayaá¹ƒ, bhante, nÄá¸·andÄ iddhÄ ceva phÄ«tÄ ca bahujanÄ Äkiá¹‡á¹‡amanussÄ bhagavati abhippasannÄ. sÄdhu, bhante, bhagavÄ ekaá¹ƒ bhikkhuá¹ƒ samÄdisatu, yo uttarimanussadhammÄ iddhipÄá¹­ihÄriyaá¹ƒ karissati, evÄyaá¹ƒ nÄá¸·andÄ bhiyyoso mattÄya bhagavati abhippasÄ«dissatÄ«"â€™ti. dutiyampi kho bhagavÄ kevaá¹­á¹­aá¹ƒ gahapatiputtaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "na kho ahaá¹ƒ, kevaá¹­á¹­a, bhikkhÅ«naá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ desemi â€“ etha tumhe, bhikkhave, gihÄ«naá¹ƒ odÄtavasanÄnaá¹ƒ uttarimanussadhammÄ iddhipÄá¹­ihÄriyaá¹ƒ karothÄ"â€™ti. tatiyampi kho kevaá¹­á¹­o gahapatiputto bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "nÄhaá¹ƒ, bhante, bhagavantaá¹ƒ dhaá¹ƒsemi, api ca, evaá¹ƒ vadÄmi â€“ â€˜ayaá¹ƒ, bhante, nÄá¸·andÄ iddhÄ ceva phÄ«tÄ ca bahujanÄ Äkiá¹‡á¹‡amanussÄ bhagavati abhippasannÄ. sÄdhu, bhante, bhagavÄ ekaá¹ƒ bhikkhuá¹ƒ samÄdisatu, yo uttarimanussadhammÄ iddhipÄá¹­ihÄriyaá¹ƒ karissati. evÄyaá¹ƒ nÄá¸·andÄ bhiyyoso mattÄya bhagavati abhippasÄ«dissatÄ«â€™ti.
For a second time, Kevatta, the householderâ€™s son, said to the Blessed One: "Venerable Sir, I am not importuning the Blessed One, but I say: 'Venerable Sir, NÄá¸·andÄ is thriving, prosperous, populous, crowded with people, and its people have faith in the Blessed One. Venerable Sir, it would be good if the Blessed One were to instruct a monk to perform a superhuman feat, a miracle of psychic power, so that NÄá¸·andÄ would have even greater faith in the Blessed One.'" For a second time, the Blessed One said to Kevatta, the householderâ€™s son: "Kevaá¹­á¹­a, I do not teach the monks in this way: 'Come, monks, perform superhuman feats, miracles of psychic power, for the white-clothed laypeople!'" For a third time, Kevatta, the householderâ€™s son, said to the Blessed One: "Venerable Sir, I am not importuning the Blessed One, but I say: 'Venerable Sir, NÄá¸·andÄ is thriving, prosperous, populous, crowded with people, and its people have faith in the Blessed One. Venerable Sir, it would be good if the Blessed One were to instruct a monk to perform a superhuman feat, a miracle of psychic power, so that NÄá¸·andÄ would have even greater faith in the Blessed One.'"
483. iddhipÄá¹­ihÄriyaá¹ƒ 483. "tÄ«á¹‡i kho imÄni, kevaá¹­á¹­a, pÄá¹­ihÄriyÄni mayÄ sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ paveditÄni. katamÄni tÄ«á¹‡i? iddhipÄá¹­ihÄriyaá¹ƒ, ÄdesanÄpÄá¹­ihÄriyaá¹ƒ, anusÄsanÄ«pÄá¹­ihÄriyaá¹ƒ. 484. "katamaÃ±ca, kevaá¹­á¹­a, iddhipÄá¹­ihÄriyaá¹ƒ? idha, kevaá¹­á¹­a, bhikkhu anekavihitaá¹ƒ iddhividhaá¹ƒ paccanubhoti. ekopi hutvÄ bahudhÄ hoti, bahudhÄpi hutvÄ eko hoti, ÄvibhÄvaá¹ƒ tirobhÄvaá¹ƒ tirokuá¹­á¹­aá¹ƒ tiropÄkÄraá¹ƒ tiropabbataá¹ƒ asajjamÄno gacchati seyyathÄpi ÄkÄse, pathaviyÄpi ummujjanimujjaá¹ƒ karoti seyyathÄpi udake, udakepi abhijjamÄne gacchati seyyathÄpi pathaviyaá¹ƒ, ÄkÄsepi pallaá¹…kena kamati seyyathÄpi pakkhÄ« sakuá¹‡o, imepi candimasÅ«riye evaá¹ƒ mahiddhike evaá¹ƒ mahÄnubhÄve pÄá¹‡inÄ parÄmasati parimajjati, yÄva brahmalokÄpi kÄyena vasaá¹ƒ vatteti. "tamenaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±ataro saddho pasanno passati taá¹ƒ bhikkhuá¹ƒ anekavihitaá¹ƒ iddhividhaá¹ƒ paccanubhontaá¹ƒ â€“ ekopi hutvÄ bahudhÄ hontaá¹ƒ, bahudhÄpi hutvÄ eko hontaá¹ƒ, ÄvibhÄvaá¹ƒ tirobhÄvaá¹ƒ, tirokuá¹­á¹­aá¹ƒ tiropÄkÄraá¹ƒ tiropabbataá¹ƒ asajjamÄnaá¹ƒ gacchantaá¹ƒ seyyathÄpi ÄkÄse, pathaviyÄpi ummujjanimujjaá¹ƒ karontaá¹ƒ seyyathÄpi udake, udakepi abhijjamÄne gacchantaá¹ƒ seyyathÄpi pathaviyaá¹ƒ, ÄkÄsepi pallaá¹…kena kamantaá¹ƒ seyyathÄpi pakkhÄ« sakuá¹‡o, imepi candimasÅ«riye evaá¹ƒ mahiddhike evaá¹ƒ mahÄnubhÄve pÄá¹‡inÄ parÄmasantaá¹ƒ parimajjantaá¹ƒ yÄva brahmalokÄpi kÄyena vasaá¹ƒ vattentaá¹ƒ. "tamenaá¹ƒ so saddho pasanno aÃ±Ã±atarassa assaddhassa appasannassa Äroceti â€“ â€˜acchariyaá¹ƒ vata, bho, abbhutaá¹ƒ vata, bho, samaá¹‡assa mahiddhikatÄ mahÄnubhÄvatÄ. amÄhaá¹ƒ bhikkhuá¹ƒ addasaá¹ƒ anekavihitaá¹ƒ iddhividhaá¹ƒ paccanubhontaá¹ƒ â€“ ekopi hutvÄ bahudhÄ hontaá¹ƒ, bahudhÄpi hutvÄ eko hontaá¹ƒâ€¦peâ€¦ yÄva brahmalokÄpi kÄyena vasaá¹ƒ vattentaâ€™nti. "tamenaá¹ƒ so assaddho appasanno taá¹ƒ saddhaá¹ƒ pasannaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ vadeyya â€“ â€˜atthi kho, bho, gandhÄrÄ« nÄma vijjÄ. tÄya so bhikkhu anekavihitaá¹ƒ iddhividhaá¹ƒ paccanubhoti â€“ ekopi hutvÄ bahudhÄ hoti, bahudhÄpi hutvÄ eko hotiâ€¦peâ€¦ yÄva brahmalokÄpi kÄyena vasaá¹ƒ vattetÄ«â€™ti.
The Lord said: â€˜Kevaá¹­á¹­a, there are three kinds of miracle that I have declared, having realised them by my own insight. Which three? The miracle of psychic power (*iddhipÄá¹­ihÄriyaá¹ƒ*), the miracle of telepathy (*ÄdesanÄpÄá¹­ihÄriyaá¹ƒ*), the miracle of instruction (*anusÄsanÄ«pÄá¹­ihÄriyaá¹ƒ*).
484. iddhipÄá¹­ihÄriyaá¹ƒ 483. "tÄ«á¹‡i kho imÄni, kevaá¹­á¹­a, pÄá¹­ihÄriyÄni mayÄ sayaá¹ƒ abhiÃ±Ã±Ä sacchikatvÄ paveditÄni. katamÄni tÄ«á¹‡i? iddhipÄá¹­ihÄriyaá¹ƒ, ÄdesanÄpÄá¹­ihÄriyaá¹ƒ, anusÄsanÄ«pÄá¹­ihÄriyaá¹ƒ. 484. "katamaÃ±ca, kevaá¹­á¹­a, iddhipÄá¹­ihÄriyaá¹ƒ? idha, kevaá¹­á¹­a, bhikkhu anekavihitaá¹ƒ iddhividhaá¹ƒ paccanubhoti. ekopi hutvÄ bahudhÄ hoti, bahudhÄpi hutvÄ eko hoti, ÄvibhÄvaá¹ƒ tirobhÄvaá¹ƒ tirokuá¹­á¹­aá¹ƒ tiropÄkÄraá¹ƒ tiropabbataá¹ƒ asajjamÄno gacchati seyyathÄpi ÄkÄse, pathaviyÄpi ummujjanimujjaá¹ƒ karoti seyyathÄpi udake, udakepi abhijjamÄne gacchati seyyathÄpi pathaviyaá¹ƒ, ÄkÄsepi pallaá¹…kena kamati seyyathÄpi pakkhÄ« sakuá¹‡o, imepi candimasÅ«riye evaá¹ƒ mahiddhike evaá¹ƒ mahÄnubhÄve pÄá¹‡inÄ parÄmasati parimajjati, yÄva brahmalokÄpi kÄyena vasaá¹ƒ vatteti. "tamenaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±ataro saddho pasanno passati taá¹ƒ bhikkhuá¹ƒ anekavihitaá¹ƒ iddhividhaá¹ƒ paccanubhontaá¹ƒ â€“ ekopi hutvÄ bahudhÄ hontaá¹ƒ, bahudhÄpi hutvÄ eko hontaá¹ƒ, ÄvibhÄvaá¹ƒ tirobhÄvaá¹ƒ, tirokuá¹­á¹­aá¹ƒ tiropÄkÄraá¹ƒ tiropabbataá¹ƒ asajjamÄnaá¹ƒ gacchantaá¹ƒ seyyathÄpi ÄkÄse, pathaviyÄpi ummujjanimujjaá¹ƒ karontaá¹ƒ seyyathÄpi udake, udakepi abhijjamÄne gacchantaá¹ƒ seyyathÄpi pathaviyaá¹ƒ, ÄkÄsepi pallaá¹…kena kamantaá¹ƒ seyyathÄpi pakkhÄ« sakuá¹‡o, imepi candimasÅ«riye evaá¹ƒ mahiddhike evaá¹ƒ mahÄnubhÄve pÄá¹‡inÄ parÄmasantaá¹ƒ parimajjantaá¹ƒ yÄva brahmalokÄpi kÄyena vasaá¹ƒ vattentaá¹ƒ. "tamenaá¹ƒ so saddho pasanno aÃ±Ã±atarassa assaddhassa appasannassa Äroceti â€“ â€˜acchariyaá¹ƒ vata, bho, abbhutaá¹ƒ vata, bho, samaá¹‡assa mahiddhikatÄ mahÄnubhÄvatÄ. amÄhaá¹ƒ bhikkhuá¹ƒ addasaá¹ƒ anekavihitaá¹ƒ iddhividhaá¹ƒ paccanubhontaá¹ƒ â€“ ekopi hutvÄ bahudhÄ hontaá¹ƒ, bahudhÄpi hutvÄ eko hontaá¹ƒâ€¦peâ€¦ yÄva brahmalokÄpi kÄyena vasaá¹ƒ vattentaâ€™nti. "tamenaá¹ƒ so assaddho appasanno taá¹ƒ saddhaá¹ƒ pasannaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ vadeyya â€“ â€˜atthi kho, bho, gandhÄrÄ« nÄma vijjÄ. tÄya so bhikkhu anekavihitaá¹ƒ iddhividhaá¹ƒ paccanubhoti â€“ ekopi hutvÄ bahudhÄ hoti, bahudhÄpi hutvÄ eko hotiâ€¦peâ€¦ yÄva brahmalokÄpi kÄyena vasaá¹ƒ vattetÄ«â€™ti.
â€˜And what, Kevaddha, is the miracle of psychic power (*iddhipÄá¹­ihÄriyaá¹ƒ*)? Here, Kevaddha, a monk experiences various kinds of psychic power (*anekavihitaá¹ƒ iddhividhaá¹ƒ*). Being one he becomes many, being many he becomes one; he appears and vanishes; he goes unhindered through a wall, through an enclosure, through a mountain as though through space; he dives in and out of the earth as though it were water; he walks on water without sinking as though it were earth; seated cross-legged, he travels in space like a bird; with his hand he touches and strokes the moon and sun so powerful and mighty; he wields mastery with the body as far as the Brahma world. â€˜Suppose a faithful believer sees that monk wielding various kinds of psychic power (*anekavihitaá¹ƒ iddhividhaá¹ƒ*)â€”being one he becomes many, being many he becomes one; he appears and vanishes; he goes unhindered through a wall, through an enclosure, through a mountain as though through space; he dives in and out of the earth as though it were water; he walks on water without sinking as though it were earth; seated cross-legged, he travels in space like a bird; with his hand he touches and strokes the moon and sun so powerful and mighty; he wields mastery with the body as far as the Brahma world. â€˜He tells this to someone else who is sceptical and un- believing, saying: â€œIt is wonderful, sir, it is marvellous, the great power and skill of that asceticâ€¦â€ â€œI saw a monk wielding various kinds of psychic power (*anekavihitaá¹ƒ iddhividhaá¹ƒ*)â€”being one he becomes many, being many he becomes oneâ€¦he wields mastery with the body as far as the brahma world.â€ â€˜And that man might say: â€œSir, there is something called the *gandhÄrÄ«* charm. It is by means of this that that monk experiences various kinds of psychic power (*anekavihitaá¹ƒ iddhividhaá¹ƒ*)â€”being one he becomes many, being many he becomes oneâ€¦he wields mastery with the body as far as the Brahma world.â€ â€œWhat do you think, Kevaddha, would not a sceptic say that to a believer?â€ â€œHe would, venerable sir.â€ â€œAnd that is why, Kevaddha, seeing the danger of the miracle of mind-reading ( *iddhipÄá¹­ihÄriya*), I am troubled, ashamed, and disgusted by the miracle of mind-reading.â€ Mind-reading miracle (*ÄdesanÄpÄá¹­ihÄriyaá¹ƒ*).
485. "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, kevaá¹­á¹­a, api nu so assaddho appasanno taá¹ƒ saddhaá¹ƒ pasannaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ vadeyyÄ"ti? "vadeyya, bhante"ti. "imaá¹ƒ kho ahaá¹ƒ, kevaá¹­á¹­a, iddhipÄá¹­ihÄriye ÄdÄ«navaá¹ƒ sampassamÄno iddhipÄá¹­ihÄriyena aá¹­á¹­Ä«yÄmi harÄyÄmi jigucchÄmi". ÄdesanÄpÄá¹­ihÄriyaá¹ƒ 485. "katamaÃ±ca, kevaá¹­á¹­a, ÄdesanÄpÄá¹­ihÄriyaá¹ƒ? idha, kevaá¹­á¹­a, bhikkhu parasattÄnaá¹ƒ parapuggalÄnaá¹ƒ cittampi Ädisati, cetasikampi Ädisati, vitakkitampi Ädisati, vicÄritampi Ädisati â€“ â€˜evampi te mano, itthampi te mano, itipi te cittaâ€™nti. "tamenaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±ataro saddho pasanno passati taá¹ƒ bhikkhuá¹ƒ parasattÄnaá¹ƒ parapuggalÄnaá¹ƒ cittampi Ädisantaá¹ƒ, cetasikampi Ädisantaá¹ƒ, vitakkitampi Ädisantaá¹ƒ, vicÄritampi Ädisantaá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜evampi te mano, itthampi te mano, itipi te cittaâ€™nti. tamenaá¹ƒ so saddho pasanno aÃ±Ã±atarassa assaddhassa appasannassa Äroceti â€“ â€˜acchariyaá¹ƒ vata, bho, abbhutaá¹ƒ vata, bho, samaá¹‡assa mahiddhikatÄ mahÄnubhÄvatÄ. amÄhaá¹ƒ bhikkhuá¹ƒ addasaá¹ƒ parasattÄnaá¹ƒ parapuggalÄnaá¹ƒ cittampi Ädisantaá¹ƒ, cetasikampi Ädisantaá¹ƒ, vitakkitampi Ädisantaá¹ƒ, vicÄritampi Ädisantaá¹ƒ â€“ "evampi te mano, itthampi te mano, itipi te citta"â€™nti. "tamenaá¹ƒ so assaddho appasanno taá¹ƒ saddhaá¹ƒ pasannaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ vadeyya â€“ â€˜atthi kho, bho, maá¹‡ikÄ nÄma vijjÄ, tÄya so bhikkhu parasattÄnaá¹ƒ parapuggalÄnaá¹ƒ cittampi Ädisati, cetasikampi Ädisati, vitakkitampi Ädisati, vicÄritampi Ädisati â€“ â€˜evampi te mano, itthampi te mano, itipi te citta"â€™nti. "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, kevaá¹­á¹­a, api nu so assaddho appasanno taá¹ƒ saddhaá¹ƒ pasannaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ vadeyyÄ"ti? "vadeyya, bhante"ti. "imaá¹ƒ kho ahaá¹ƒ, kevaá¹­á¹­a, ÄdesanÄpÄá¹­ihÄriye ÄdÄ«navaá¹ƒ sampassamÄno ÄdesanÄpÄá¹­ihÄriyena aá¹­á¹­Ä«yÄmi harÄyÄmi jigucchÄmi". anusÄsanÄ«pÄá¹­ihÄriyaá¹ƒ 486. "katamaÃ±ca, kevaá¹­á¹­a, anusÄsanÄ«pÄá¹­ihÄriyaá¹ƒ? idha, kevaá¹­á¹­a, bhikkhu evamanusÄsati â€“ â€˜evaá¹ƒ vitakketha, mÄ evaá¹ƒ vitakkayittha, evaá¹ƒ manasikarotha,
â€œAnd what, Kevaddha, is the miracle of mind-reading (*ÄdesanÄpÄá¹­ihÄriyaá¹ƒ*)? Here, Kevaddha, a monk reads the minds of other beings ( *parasattÄnaá¹ƒ*), of other people ( *parapuggalÄnaá¹ƒ*), reads their mental states ( *cittaá¹ƒ*), their thoughts ( *cetasikaá¹ƒ*), their ponderings ( *vitakkitaá¹ƒ*), and their deliberations ( *vicÄritaá¹ƒ*), and says: â€˜That is how your mind (*mano*) is, that is how it inclines, that is in your heart.â€™â€ â€œThen a believer sees that monk reading the minds of other beings, of other people, reading their mental states, their thoughts, their ponderings, and their deliberations, and saying: â€˜That is how your mind is, that is how it inclines, that is in your heart.â€™â€ Then that believer tells this to someone else who is sceptical and un-believing, saying: â€œIt is wonderful, sir, it is marvellous, the great power (*mahiddhikatÄ*) and skill (*mahÄnubhÄvatÄ*) of that ascetic. I saw a monk reading the minds of other beings, of other people, reading their mental states, their thoughts, their ponderings, and their deliberations, and saying: â€˜That is how your mind is, that is how it inclines, that is in your heart.â€™â€ â€œAnd that sceptic might say to that believer: â€˜Sir, there is something called the Manika charm ( *maá¹‡ikÄ nÄma vijjÄ*). It is by means of this that that monk can read the minds ( *cittaá¹ƒ* ) of others beings ( *parasattÄnaá¹ƒ*), of other people ( *parapuggalÄnaá¹ƒ*), reads their mental states ( *cetasikaá¹ƒ*), their thoughts ( *vitakkitaá¹ƒ*), and their deliberations ( *vicÄritaá¹ƒ*), and says: â€˜That is how your mind is, that is how it inclines, that is in your heart.â€™â€ â€œWhat do you think, Kevaddha, would not a sceptic say that to a believer?â€ â€œHe would, venerable sir.â€ â€œAnd that is why, Kevaddha, seeing the danger of the miracle of mind-reading (*ÄdesanÄpÄá¹­ihÄriyaá¹ƒ*), I am troubled, ashamed, and disgusted by the miracle of mind-reading (*ÄdesanÄpÄá¹­ihÄriyena*).â€ The miracle of instruction (*anusÄsanÄ«pÄá¹­ihÄriyaá¹ƒ*).
486. "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, kevaá¹­á¹­a, api nu so assaddho appasanno taá¹ƒ saddhaá¹ƒ pasannaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ vadeyyÄ"ti? "vadeyya, bhante"ti. "tamenaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±ataro saddho pasanno passati taá¹ƒ bhikkhuá¹ƒ parasattÄnaá¹ƒ parapuggalÄnaá¹ƒ cittampi Ädisantaá¹ƒ, cetasikampi Ädisantaá¹ƒ, vitakkitampi Ädisantaá¹ƒ, vicÄritampi Ädisantaá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜evampi te mano, itthampi te mano, itipi te cittaâ€™nti. tamenaá¹ƒ so saddho pasanno aÃ±Ã±atarassa assaddhassa appasannassa Äroceti â€“ â€˜acchariyaá¹ƒ vata, bho, abbhutaá¹ƒ vata, bho, samaá¹‡assa mahiddhikatÄ mahÄnubhÄvatÄ. amÄhaá¹ƒ bhikkhuá¹ƒ addasaá¹ƒ parasattÄnaá¹ƒ parapuggalÄnaá¹ƒ cittampi Ädisantaá¹ƒ, cetasikampi Ädisantaá¹ƒ, vitakkitampi Ädisantaá¹ƒ, vicÄritampi Ädisantaá¹ƒ â€“ "evampi te mano, itthampi te mano, itipi te citta"â€™nti. "tamenaá¹ƒ so assaddho appasanno taá¹ƒ saddhaá¹ƒ pasannaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ vadeyya â€“ â€˜atthi kho, bho, maá¹‡ikÄ nÄma vijjÄ, tÄya so bhikkhu parasattÄnaá¹ƒ parapuggalÄnaá¹ƒ cittampi Ädisati, cetasikampi Ädisati, vitakkitampi Ädisati, vicÄritampi Ädisati â€“ â€˜evampi te mano, itthampi te mano, itipi te citta"â€™nti. "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, kevaá¹­á¹­a, api nu so assaddho appasanno taá¹ƒ saddhaá¹ƒ pasannaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ vadeyyÄ"ti? "vadeyya, bhante"ti. "imaá¹ƒ kho ahaá¹ƒ, kevaá¹­á¹­a, ÄdesanÄpÄá¹­ihÄriye ÄdÄ«navaá¹ƒ sampassamÄno ÄdesanÄpÄá¹­ihÄriyena aá¹­á¹­Ä«yÄmi harÄyÄmi jigucchÄmi". anusÄsanÄ«pÄá¹­ihÄriyaá¹ƒ 486. "katamaÃ±ca, kevaá¹­á¹­a, anusÄsanÄ«pÄá¹­ihÄriyaá¹ƒ? idha, kevaá¹­á¹­a, bhikkhu evamanusÄsati â€“ â€˜evaá¹ƒ vitakketha, mÄ evaá¹ƒ vitakkayittha, evaá¹ƒ manasikarotha,
â€œAnd what, Kevaddha, is the miracle of instruction (*anusÄsanÄ«pÄá¹­ihÄriyaá¹ƒ*)? Here, Kevaddha, a monk gives instruction as follows: â€˜Consider in this way ( *evaá¹ƒ vitakketha*), donâ€™t consider in that way ( *mÄ evaá¹ƒ vitakkayittha*), direct your mind this way ( *evaá¹ƒ manasikarotha*), And because they do not become forgetful, those gods do not fall from that state. They are permanent ( *niccÄ*), stable (*dhuvÄ*), eternal (*sassatÄ*), not subject to change (*avipariá¹‡ÄmadhammÄ*), and they will remain the same just like eternity itself. But we, who were corrupted by play (*khiá¸á¸ÄpadosikÄ*), spent an excessive amount of time addicted to merriment, play and enjoyment. They spend an excessive amount of time addicted to merriment, play and enjoyment, so that their mindfulness is dissipated. When we became forgetful, we passed away from that plane. Coming to this world, now we are impermanent (*aniccÄ*), unstable (*addhuvÄ*), short-lived (*appÄyukÄ*), doomed to perish (*cavanadhammÄ*), and we have come to this world. This, monks, is the second case, wherein approaching and relying on what, some ascetics and Brahmins propound that the self and the world are partly eternalists (*ekaccasassatikÄ*) and partly non-eternalists (*ekaccaasassatikÄ*), partly eternal (*sassataá¹ƒ*) and partly non-eternal (*asassataá¹ƒ*).

"Once, Kevaddha, in this very community of *bhiká¹£us*, this thought arose in the mind of a certain *bhiká¹£u*: 'Where, indeed, do these four great elementsâ€”the earth element (*pá¹›thivÄ«-dhÄtu*), the water element (*Äpo-dhÄtu*), the fire element (*tejo-dhÄtu*), and the air element (*vÄyo-dhÄtu*)â€”cease without remainder?'

"Then, Kevaddha, that *bhiká¹£u* attained such a state of *samÄdhi* that, in his mind thus concentrated, the path to the world of the gods (*deva*) appeared. Then, Kevaddha, that *bhiká¹£u* approached the gods of the Realm of the Four Great Kings (*cÄtumahÄrÄjika*), and having approached the gods of the *cÄtumahÄrÄjika*, he said to them: 'Friends (*Ävusos*), where do these four great elementsâ€”the earth element (*pá¹›thivÄ«-dhÄtu*), the water element (*Äpo-dhÄtu*), the fire element (*tejo-dhÄtu*), and the air element (*vÄyo-dhÄtu*)â€”cease without remainder?' "When this was said, Kevaddha, the *cÄtumahÄrÄjika* gods said to that *bhiká¹£u*: 'Even we, *bhiká¹£u*, do not know where these four great elementsâ€”the earth element (*pá¹›thivÄ«-dhÄtu*), the water element (*Äpo-dhÄtu*), the fire element (*tejo-dhÄtu*), and the air element (*vÄyo-dhÄtu*)â€”cease without remainder. It exists, indeed (pÄ«. Likewise above)]. It exists, indeed [air element (*vÄyo-dhÄtu*). It exists, indeed (pÄ«. Likewise above)], *bhiká¹£u*, the Four Great Kings (*mahÄrÄjÄno*) are more excellent than us. more surpassing and more sublime. They may know where the four great elements cease without remainder, namely the earth element (*pathavÄ«dhÄtu*), the water element (*ÄpodhÄtu*), the fire element (*tejodhÄtu*), and the air element (*vÄyodhÄtu*)."
489. abhikkantatarÄ ca paá¹‡Ä«tatarÄ ca. te kho etaá¹ƒ jÄneyyuá¹ƒ, yatthime cattÄro mahÄbhÅ«tÄ aparisesÄ nirujjhanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ pathavÄ«dhÄtu ÄpodhÄtu tejodhÄtu vÄyodhÄtÅ«â€™ti. 489. "atha kho so, kevaá¹­á¹­a, bhikkhu yena cattÄro mahÄrÄjÄno tenupasaá¹…kami, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ cattÄro mahÄrÄje etadavoca â€“ â€˜kattha nu kho, Ävuso, ime cattÄro mahÄbhÅ«tÄ aparisesÄ nirujjhanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ pathavÄ«dhÄtu ÄpodhÄtu tejodhÄtu vÄyodhÄtÅ«â€™ti? evaá¹ƒ vutte, kevaá¹­á¹­a, cattÄro mahÄrÄjÄno taá¹ƒ bhikkhuá¹ƒ etadavocuá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜mayampi kho, bhikkhu, na jÄnÄma, yatthime cattÄro mahÄbhÅ«tÄ aparisesÄ nirujjhanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ pathavÄ«dhÄtu, ÄpodhÄtu tejodhÄtu vÄyodhÄtÅ«ti. atthi kho, bhikkhu, tÄvatiá¹ƒsÄ nÄma devÄ amhehi abhikkantatarÄ ca paá¹‡Ä«tatarÄ ca. te kho etaá¹ƒ jÄneyyuá¹ƒ, yatthime cattÄro mahÄbhÅ«tÄ aparisesÄ nirujjhanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ pathavÄ«dhÄtu ÄpodhÄtu tejodhÄtu vÄyodhÄtÅ«â€™ti. 490. "atha kho so, kevaá¹­á¹­a, bhikkhu yena tÄvatiá¹ƒsÄ devÄ tenupasaá¹…kami, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ tÄvatiá¹ƒse deve etadavoca â€“ â€˜kattha nu kho, Ävuso, ime cattÄro mahÄbhÅ«tÄ aparisesÄ nirujjhanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ pathavÄ«dhÄtu ÄpodhÄtu tejodhÄtu vÄyodhÄtÅ«â€™ti? evaá¹ƒ vutte, kevaá¹­á¹­a, tÄvatiá¹ƒsÄ devÄ taá¹ƒ bhikkhuá¹ƒ etadavocuá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜mayampi kho, bhikkhu, na jÄnÄma, yatthime cattÄro mahÄbhÅ«tÄ aparisesÄ nirujjhanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ pathavÄ«dhÄtu ÄpodhÄtu tejodhÄtu vÄyodhÄtÅ«ti. atthi kho, bhikkhu, sakko nÄma devÄnamindo amhehi abhikkantataro ca paá¹‡Ä«tataro ca. so kho etaá¹ƒ jÄneyya, yatthime cattÄro mahÄbhÅ«tÄ aparisesÄ nirujjhanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ pathavÄ«dhÄtu ÄpodhÄtu tejodhÄtu vÄyodhÄtÅ«â€™ti. 491. "atha kho so, kevaá¹­á¹­a, bhikkhu yena sakko devÄnamindo tenupasaá¹…kami, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ sakkaá¹ƒ devÄnamindaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ â€˜kattha nu kho, Ävuso, ime cattÄro mahÄbhÅ«tÄ aparisesÄ nirujjhanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ pathavÄ«dhÄtu ÄpodhÄtu tejodhÄtu vÄyodhÄtÅ«â€™ti? evaá¹ƒ vutte, kevaá¹­á¹­a, sakko devÄnamindo taá¹ƒ bhikkhuá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ â€˜ahampi kho, bhikkhu,
Then that monk, Kevatta, went to the Four Great Kings and having approached them, said to the Four Great Kings: â€œWhere, friends, do these four great elements cease without remainder, namely the earth element (*pathavÄ«dhÄtu*), the water element (*ÄpodhÄtu*), the fire element (*tejodhÄtu*), and the air element (*vÄyodhÄtu*)?â€ When this was said, Kevatta, the Four Great Kings said to that monk: â€œWe also, monk, do not know where these four great elements cease without remainder, namely the earth element (*pathavÄ«dhÄtu*), the water element (*ÄpodhÄtu*), the fire element (*tejodhÄtu*), and the air element (*vÄyodhÄtu*)." But the Thirty-Three Gods, monk, are more surpassing and more sublime than we are. They may know where the four great elements cease without remainder, namely the earth element (*pathavÄ«dhÄtu*), the water element (*ÄpodhÄtu*), the fire element (*tejodhÄtu*), and the air element (*vÄyodhÄtu*)."
490. abhikkantatarÄ ca paá¹‡Ä«tatarÄ ca. te kho etaá¹ƒ jÄneyyuá¹ƒ, yatthime cattÄro mahÄbhÅ«tÄ aparisesÄ nirujjhanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ pathavÄ«dhÄtu ÄpodhÄtu tejodhÄtu vÄyodhÄtÅ«â€™ti. 489. "atha kho so, kevaá¹­á¹­a, bhikkhu yena cattÄro mahÄrÄjÄno tenupasaá¹…kami, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ cattÄro mahÄrÄje etadavoca â€“ â€˜kattha nu kho, Ävuso, ime cattÄro mahÄbhÅ«tÄ aparisesÄ nirujjhanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ pathavÄ«dhÄtu ÄpodhÄtu tejodhÄtu vÄyodhÄtÅ«â€™ti? evaá¹ƒ vutte, kevaá¹­á¹­a, cattÄro mahÄrÄjÄno taá¹ƒ bhikkhuá¹ƒ etadavocuá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜mayampi kho, bhikkhu, na jÄnÄma, yatthime cattÄro mahÄbhÅ«tÄ aparisesÄ nirujjhanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ pathavÄ«dhÄtu, ÄpodhÄtu tejodhÄtu vÄyodhÄtÅ«ti. atthi kho, bhikkhu, tÄvatiá¹ƒsÄ nÄma devÄ amhehi abhikkantatarÄ ca paá¹‡Ä«tatarÄ ca. te kho etaá¹ƒ jÄneyyuá¹ƒ, yatthime cattÄro mahÄbhÅ«tÄ aparisesÄ nirujjhanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ pathavÄ«dhÄtu ÄpodhÄtu tejodhÄtu vÄyodhÄtÅ«â€™ti. 490. "atha kho so, kevaá¹­á¹­a, bhikkhu yena tÄvatiá¹ƒsÄ devÄ tenupasaá¹…kami, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ tÄvatiá¹ƒse deve etadavoca â€“ â€˜kattha nu kho, Ävuso, ime cattÄro mahÄbhÅ«tÄ aparisesÄ nirujjhanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ pathavÄ«dhÄtu ÄpodhÄtu tejodhÄtu vÄyodhÄtÅ«â€™ti? evaá¹ƒ vutte, kevaá¹­á¹­a, tÄvatiá¹ƒsÄ devÄ taá¹ƒ bhikkhuá¹ƒ etadavocuá¹ƒ â€“ â€˜mayampi kho, bhikkhu, na jÄnÄma, yatthime cattÄro mahÄbhÅ«tÄ aparisesÄ nirujjhanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ pathavÄ«dhÄtu ÄpodhÄtu tejodhÄtu vÄyodhÄtÅ«ti. atthi kho, bhikkhu, sakko nÄma devÄnamindo amhehi abhikkantataro ca paá¹‡Ä«tataro ca. so kho etaá¹ƒ jÄneyya, yatthime cattÄro mahÄbhÅ«tÄ aparisesÄ nirujjhanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ pathavÄ«dhÄtu ÄpodhÄtu tejodhÄtu vÄyodhÄtÅ«â€™ti. 491. "atha kho so, kevaá¹­á¹­a, bhikkhu yena sakko devÄnamindo tenupasaá¹…kami, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ sakkaá¹ƒ devÄnamindaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ â€˜kattha nu kho, Ävuso, ime cattÄro mahÄbhÅ«tÄ aparisesÄ nirujjhanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ pathavÄ«dhÄtu ÄpodhÄtu tejodhÄtu vÄyodhÄtÅ«â€™ti? evaá¹ƒ vutte, kevaá¹­á¹­a, sakko devÄnamindo taá¹ƒ bhikkhuá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ â€˜ahampi kho, bhikkhu,
Then that monk, Kevatta, went to the Thirty-Three Gods and having approached them, said to the Thirty-Three Gods: â€œWhere, friends, do these four great elements cease without remainder, namely the earth element (*pathavÄ«dhÄtu*), the water element (*ÄpodhÄtu*), the fire element (*tejodhÄtu*), and the air element (*vÄyodhÄtu*)?â€ When this was said, Kevatta, the Thirty-Three Gods said to that monk: â€œWe also, monk, do not know where these four great elements cease without remainder, namely the earth element (*pathavÄ«dhÄtu*), the water element (*ÄpodhÄtu*), the fire element (*tejodhÄtu*), and the air element (*vÄyodhÄtu*)." But Sakka, the lord of the gods (*devÄnamindo*), monk, is more surpassing and more sublime than we are. He may know where the four great elements cease without remainder, namely the earth element (*pathavÄ«dhÄtu*), the water element (*ÄpodhÄtu*), the fire element (*tejodhÄtu*), and the air element (*vÄyodhÄtu*)."
491. abhikkantatarÄ ca paá¹‡Ä«tatarÄ ca. te kho etaá¹ƒ jÄneyyuá¹ƒ, yatthime cattÄro mahÄbhÅ«tÄ aparisesÄ nirujjhanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ pathavÄ«dhÄtu ÄpodhÄtu tejodhÄtu vÄyodhÄtÅ«â€™ti. 489. "atha kho so, kevaá¹­á¹­a, bhikkhu yena sakko devÄnamindo tenupasaá¹…kami, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ sakkaá¹ƒ devÄnamindaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ â€˜kattha nu kho, Ävuso, ime cattÄro mahÄbhÅ«tÄ aparisesÄ nirujjhanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ pathavÄ«dhÄtu ÄpodhÄtu tejodhÄtu vÄyodhÄtÅ«â€™ti? evaá¹ƒ vutte, kevaá¹­á¹­a, sakko devÄnamindo taá¹ƒ bhikkhuá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ â€˜ahampi kho, bhikkhu,
Then that monk, Kevatta, went to Sakka, the lord of the gods, and having approached Sakka, the lord of the gods, said: â€œWhere, friends, do these four great elements cease without remainder, namely the earth element (*pathavÄ«dhÄtu*), the water element (*ÄpodhÄtu*), the fire element (*tejodhÄtu*), and the air element (*vÄyodhÄtu*)?â€ When this was said, Kevatta, Sakka, the lord of the gods, said to that monk: â€œI also, monk, I do not know where the four great elements cease without remainder, namely, the earth element (*pathavÄ«dhÄtu*), the water element (*ÄpodhÄtu*), the fire element (*tejodhÄtu*), and the air element (*vÄyodhÄtu*). Furthermore, monk, the Yama gods exist... Suyama, son of the gods, existsâ€¦ The Tusita gods existâ€¦ Santussita, son of the gods, existsâ€¦ The Nimmanarati gods existâ€¦ Sunimmita, son of the gods, existsâ€¦ The Paranimmita-vasavatti gods existâ€¦ Vasavatti, son of the gods, exists, and is more eminent and refined than us. He would know where the four great elements cease without remainder, namely, the earth element (*pathavÄ«dhÄtu*), the water element (*ÄpodhÄtu*), the fire element (*tejodhÄtu*), and the air element (*vÄyodhÄtu*).
