"micchÄdiá¹­á¹­hi, bho gotama". "micchÄdiá¹­á¹­hissa kho ahaá¹ƒ, lohicca, dvinnaá¹ƒ gatÄ«naá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±ataraá¹ƒ gatiá¹ƒ vadÄmi â€“ nirayaá¹ƒ vÄ tiracchÄnayoniá¹ƒ vÄ". 511. "iti kira, lohicca, yo evaá¹ƒ vadeyya â€“ "lohicco brÄhmaá¹‡o sÄlavatikaá¹ƒ ajjhÄvasati, yÄ sÄlavatikÄya samudayasaÃ±jÄti, lohiccova taá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡o ekako paribhuÃ±jeyya, na aÃ±Ã±esaá¹ƒ dadeyyÄ"ti. evaá¹ƒvÄdÄ« so ye taá¹ƒ upajÄ«vanti, tesaá¹ƒ antarÄyakaro hoti. antarÄyakaro samÄno ahitÄnukampÄ« hoti, ahitÄnukampissa sapattakaá¹ƒ cittaá¹ƒ paccupaá¹­á¹­hitaá¹ƒ hoti, sapattake citte paccupaá¹­á¹­hite micchÄdiá¹­á¹­hi hoti. evameva kho, lohicca, yo evaá¹ƒ vadeyya â€“ "idha
"Now surely, Lohicca, if anyone were to say: "The *brÄhmaá¹‡a* Lohicca resides at SÄlavatika, and that the *brÄhmaá¹‡a* Lohicca should alone enjoy all the revenue that arises from SÄlavatika, not giving anything to others"â€” Anyone who speaks thus is a source of danger to those who depend on him. Being a source of danger, he is not solicitous for their welfare, and not being solicitous for their welfare, he has a heart full of hatred; in a heart full of hatred there is wrong view (*micchÄdiá¹­á¹­hi*). Even so, Lohicca, if anyone should say: "Here, If a renunciate (*Å›ramaá¹‡a*) or a Brahmin were to attain wholesome doctrine (*kuÅ›alaá¹ƒ dharmaá¹ƒ adhigaccheyya*), having attained wholesome doctrine, they should not declare it to another, for what can one person do for another? It is just as if someone, having cut through an old fetter, were to create a new fetter... One who speaks thus is a source of danger to those young men of good family (*kulaputtÄ*) who, having come to the Teaching and Discipline (*dhammavinaya*) proclaimed by the TathÄgata, attain such excellent and distinguished qualities; they realize the fruit of stream-entry (*sotÄpatti-phala*), they realize the fruit of once-returner (*sakadÄgÄmi-phala*), they realize the fruit of non-returner (*anÄgÄmi-phala*), they realize even *arhatship*. And to those who ripen these divine seeds (*dibbÄ gabbhÄ*) for rebirth in the divine realms (*dibbÄnaá¹ƒ bhavÄnaá¹ƒ abhinibbattiyÄ*), they are a source of danger. Being a source of danger, they are uncompassionate (*ahitÄnukampÄ«*). In the uncompassionate, a hostile mind (*sapattakaá¹ƒ cittaá¹ƒ*) is present. With a hostile mind present, there is wrong view (*micchÄdiá¹­á¹­hi*). But I declare, Lohicca, that wrong view leads to one of two destinies: hell (*nirayaá¹ƒ*) or the animal realm (*tiracchÄnayoniá¹ƒ*).
512. samaá¹‡o vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡o vÄ kusalaá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ adhigaccheyya, kusalaá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ adhigantvÄ na parassa Äroceyya, kiÃ±hi paro parassa karissati. seyyathÄpi nÄma purÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ bandhanaá¹ƒ chinditvÄ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ navaá¹ƒ bandhanaá¹ƒ kareyyaâ€¦peâ€¦ karissatÄ«"ti. evaá¹ƒvÄdÄ« so ye te kulaputtÄ tathÄgatappaveditaá¹ƒ dhammavinayaá¹ƒ Ägamma evarÅ«paá¹ƒ uá¸·Äraá¹ƒ visesaá¹ƒ adhigacchanti, sotÄpattiphalampi sacchikaronti, sakadÄgÄmiphalampi sacchikaronti, anÄgÄmiphalampi sacchikaronti, arahattampi sacchikaronti, ye cime dibbÄ gabbhÄ paripÄcenti dibbÄnaá¹ƒ bhavÄnaá¹ƒ abhinibbattiyÄ, tesaá¹ƒ antarÄyakaro hoti, antarÄyakaro samÄno ahitÄnukampÄ« hoti, ahitÄnukampissa sapattakaá¹ƒ cittaá¹ƒ paccupaá¹­á¹­hitaá¹ƒ hoti, sapattake citte paccupaá¹­á¹­hite micchÄdiá¹­á¹­hi hoti. micchÄdiá¹­á¹­hissa kho ahaá¹ƒ, lohicca, dvinnaá¹ƒ gatÄ«naá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±ataraá¹ƒ gatiá¹ƒ vadÄmi â€“ nirayaá¹ƒ vÄ tiracchÄnayoniá¹ƒ vÄ. 512. "iti kira, lohicca, yo evaá¹ƒ vadeyya â€“ "rÄjÄ pasenadi kosalo kÄsikosalaá¹ƒ ajjhÄvasati, yÄ kÄsikosale samudayasaÃ±jÄti, rÄjÄva taá¹ƒ pasenadi kosalo ekako paribhuÃ±jeyya, na aÃ±Ã±esaá¹ƒ dadeyyÄ"ti. evaá¹ƒvÄdÄ« so ye rÄjÄnaá¹ƒ pasenadiá¹ƒ kosalaá¹ƒ upajÄ«vanti tumhe ceva aÃ±Ã±e ca, tesaá¹ƒ antarÄyakaro hoti. antarÄyakaro samÄno ahitÄnukampÄ« hoti, ahitÄnukampissa sapattakaá¹ƒ cittaá¹ƒ paccupaá¹­á¹­hitaá¹ƒ hoti, sapattake citte paccupaá¹­á¹­hite micchÄdiá¹­á¹­hi hoti. evameva kho, lohicca, yo evaá¹ƒ vadeyya â€“ "idha samaá¹‡o vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡o vÄ kusalaá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ adhigaccheyya, kusalaá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ adhigantvÄ na parassa Äroceyya, kiÃ±hi paro parassa karissati. seyyathÄpi nÄmaâ€¦peâ€¦ kiÃ±hi paro parassa karissatÄ«"ti, evaá¹ƒ vÄdÄ« so ye te kulaputtÄ tathÄgatappaveditaá¹ƒ dhammavinayaá¹ƒ Ägamma evarÅ«paá¹ƒ uá¸·Äraá¹ƒ visesaá¹ƒ adhigacchanti, sotÄpattiphalampi sacchikaronti, sakadÄgÄmiphalampi sacchikaronti, anÄgÄmiphalampi sacchikaronti, arahattampi sacchikaronti. ye cime dibbÄ gabbhÄ paripÄcenti dibbÄnaá¹ƒ bhavÄnaá¹ƒ abhinibbattiyÄ, tesaá¹ƒ antarÄyakaro hoti, antarÄyakaro samÄno ahitÄnukampÄ« hoti, ahitÄnukampissa sapattakaá¹ƒ cittaá¹ƒ paccupaá¹­á¹­hitaá¹ƒ hoti, sapattake citte paccupaá¹­á¹­hite micchÄdiá¹­á¹­hi hoti. micchÄdiá¹­á¹­hissa kho ahaá¹ƒ, lohicca, dvinnaá¹ƒ gatÄ«naá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±ataraá¹ƒ gatiá¹ƒ vadÄmi â€“ nirayaá¹ƒ vÄ tiracchÄnayoniá¹ƒ vÄ.
"Thus, Lohicca, if anyone were to say: "King Pasenadi of Kosala resides in Kasi-Kosala. All the income arising in Kasi-Kosala, King Pasenadi of Kosala alone should enjoy it, not giving any to others." One who speaks thus is a source of danger to those who live in dependence on King Pasenadi of Kosala, both you and others. Being a source of danger, they are uncompassionate. In the uncompassionate, a hostile mind is present. With a hostile mind present, there is wrong view. In the same way, Lohicca, if a renunciate or a Brahmin were to attain wholesome doctrine, having attained wholesome doctrine, they should not declare it to another, for what can one person do for another? It is just as if... what can one person do for another?", one who speaks thus is a source of danger to those young men of good family who, having come to the Teaching and Discipline proclaimed by the TathÄgata, attain such excellent and distinguished qualities; they realize the fruit of stream-entry, they realize the fruit of once-returner, they realize the fruit of non-returner, they realize even arhatship. And to those who ripen these divine seeds for rebirth in the divine realms, they are a source of danger. Being a source of danger, they are uncompassionate. In the uncompassionate, a hostile mind is present. With a hostile mind present, there is wrong view. But I declare, Lohicca, that wrong view leads to one of two destinies: hell or the animal realm. Three are worthy of blame.
513. tayo codanÄrahÄ 513. "tayo khome, lohicca, satthÄro, ye loke codanÄrahÄ, yo ca panevarÅ«pe satthÄro codeti, sÄ codanÄ bhÅ«tÄ tacchÄ dhammikÄ anavajjÄ. katame tayo? idha, lohicca, ekacco satthÄ yassatthÄya agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajito hoti, svÄssa sÄmaÃ±Ã±attho ananuppatto hoti. so taá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±atthaá¹ƒ ananupÄpuá¹‡itvÄ sÄvakÄnaá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ deseti â€“ "idaá¹ƒ vo hitÄya idaá¹ƒ vo sukhÄyÄ"ti. tassa sÄvakÄ na sussÅ«santi, na sotaá¹ƒ odahanti, na aÃ±Ã±Ä cittaá¹ƒ upaá¹­á¹­hapenti, vokkamma ca satthusÄsanÄ vattanti. so evamassa codetabbo â€“ "ÄyasmÄ kho yassatthÄya agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajito, so te sÄmaÃ±Ã±attho ananuppatto, taá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±atthaá¹ƒ ananupÄpuá¹‡itvÄ sÄvakÄnaá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ desesi â€“ â€˜idaá¹ƒ vo hitÄya idaá¹ƒ vo sukhÄyÄâ€™ti. tassa te sÄvakÄ na sussÅ«santi, na sotaá¹ƒ odahanti, na aÃ±Ã±Ä cittaá¹ƒ upaá¹­á¹­hapenti, vokkamma ca satthusÄsanÄ vattanti. seyyathÄpi nÄma osakkantiyÄ vÄ ussakkeyya, parammukhiá¹ƒ vÄ Äliá¹…geyya, evaá¹ƒ sampadamidaá¹ƒ pÄpakaá¹ƒ lobhadhammaá¹ƒ vadÄmi â€“ kiÃ±hi paro parassa karissatÄ«"ti. ayaá¹ƒ kho, lohicca, paá¹­hamo satthÄ, yo loke codanÄraho, yo ca panevarÅ«paá¹ƒ satthÄraá¹ƒ codeti, sÄ codanÄ bhÅ«tÄ tacchÄ dhammikÄ anavajjÄ. 514. "puna caparaá¹ƒ, lohicca, idhekacco satthÄ yassatthÄya agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajito hoti, svÄssa sÄmaÃ±Ã±attho ananuppatto hoti. so taá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±atthaá¹ƒ ananupÄpuá¹‡itvÄ sÄvakÄnaá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ deseti â€“ "idaá¹ƒ vo hitÄya, idaá¹ƒ vo sukhÄyÄ"ti. tassa sÄvakÄ sussÅ«santi, sotaá¹ƒ odahanti, aÃ±Ã±Ä cittaá¹ƒ upaá¹­á¹­hapenti, na ca vokkamma satthusÄsanÄ vattanti. so evamassa codetabbo â€“ "ÄyasmÄ kho yassatthÄya agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajito, so te sÄmaÃ±Ã±attho ananuppatto. taá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±atthaá¹ƒ ananupÄpuá¹‡itvÄ sÄvakÄnaá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ desesi â€“ â€˜idaá¹ƒ vo hitÄya idaá¹ƒ vo sukhÄyÄâ€™ti. tassa te sÄvakÄ sussÅ«santi, sotaá¹ƒ odahanti, aÃ±Ã±Ä cittaá¹ƒ upaá¹­á¹­hapenti, na ca vokkamma satthusÄsanÄ vattanti. seyyathÄpi nÄma sakaá¹ƒ khettaá¹ƒ ohÄya paraá¹ƒ khettaá¹ƒ niddÄyitabbaá¹ƒ
"These three, Lohicca, are teachers in the world who are worthy of blame. And if someone blames such teachers, that blame is true, factual, in accordance with the Dhamma, and blameless. Which three? Here, Lohicca, a certain teacher has gone forth from the household life into homelessness for some purpose, but that goal of the ascetic life is not attained by him. And without having attained that goal of the ascetic life, he teaches his disciples the Dhamma, saying: "This is for your benefit, this is for your happiness." His disciples do not listen, do not lend an ear, do not apply their minds to understanding, and deviate from the teacher's instruction. He should be reproached in this way: "Venerable sir, that purpose for which you went forth from the household life into homelessness, that goal of the ascetic life has not been attained by you. And without attaining that goal of the ascetic life, you teach your disciples the Dhamma, saying, 'This is for your benefit, this is for your happiness.'" His disciples do not listen, do not lend an ear, do not apply their minds to understanding, and deviate from the teacher's instruction. It is just as if one were to importune a woman who is turning away or embrace one who is facing elsewhere. So do I declare this evil doctrine based on attachment: what, indeed, can one person do for another?" This, Lohicca, is the first teacher who is worthy of blame. And if someone blames such a teacher, that blame is true, factual, in accordance with the Dhamma, and blameless.
514. tayo codanÄrahÄ 513. "tayo khome, lohicca, satthÄro, ye loke codanÄrahÄ, yo ca panevarÅ«pe satthÄro codeti, sÄ codanÄ bhÅ«tÄ tacchÄ dhammikÄ anavajjÄ. katame tayo? idha, lohicca, ekacco satthÄ yassatthÄya agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajito hoti, svÄssa sÄmaÃ±Ã±attho ananuppatto hoti. so taá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±atthaá¹ƒ ananupÄpuá¹‡itvÄ sÄvakÄnaá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ deseti â€“ "idaá¹ƒ vo hitÄya idaá¹ƒ vo sukhÄyÄ"ti. tassa sÄvakÄ na sussÅ«santi, na sotaá¹ƒ odahanti, na aÃ±Ã±Ä cittaá¹ƒ upaá¹­á¹­hapenti, vokkamma ca satthusÄsanÄ vattanti. so evamassa codetabbo â€“ "ÄyasmÄ kho yassatthÄya agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajito, so te sÄmaÃ±Ã±attho ananuppatto, taá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±atthaá¹ƒ ananupÄpuá¹‡itvÄ sÄvakÄnaá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ desesi â€“ â€˜idaá¹ƒ vo hitÄya idaá¹ƒ vo sukhÄyÄâ€™ti. tassa te sÄvakÄ na sussÅ«santi, na sotaá¹ƒ odahanti, na aÃ±Ã±Ä cittaá¹ƒ upaá¹­á¹­hapenti, vokkamma ca satthusÄsanÄ vattanti. seyyathÄpi nÄma osakkantiyÄ vÄ ussakkeyya, parammukhiá¹ƒ vÄ Äliá¹…geyya, evaá¹ƒ sampadamidaá¹ƒ pÄpakaá¹ƒ lobhadhammaá¹ƒ vadÄmi â€“ kiÃ±hi paro parassa karissatÄ«"ti. ayaá¹ƒ kho, lohicca, paá¹­hamo satthÄ, yo loke codanÄraho, yo ca panevarÅ«paá¹ƒ satthÄraá¹ƒ codeti, sÄ codanÄ bhÅ«tÄ tacchÄ dhammikÄ anavajjÄ. 514. "puna caparaá¹ƒ, lohicca, idhekacco satthÄ yassatthÄya agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajito hoti, svÄssa sÄmaÃ±Ã±attho ananuppatto hoti. so taá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±atthaá¹ƒ ananupÄpuá¹‡itvÄ sÄvakÄnaá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ deseti â€“ "idaá¹ƒ vo hitÄya, idaá¹ƒ vo sukhÄyÄ"ti. tassa sÄvakÄ sussÅ«santi, sotaá¹ƒ odahanti, aÃ±Ã±Ä cittaá¹ƒ upaá¹­á¹­hapenti, na ca vokkamma satthusÄsanÄ vattanti. so evamassa codetabbo â€“ "ÄyasmÄ kho yassatthÄya agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajito, so te sÄmaÃ±Ã±attho ananuppatto. taá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±atthaá¹ƒ ananupÄpuá¹‡itvÄ sÄvakÄnaá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ desesi â€“ â€˜idaá¹ƒ vo hitÄya idaá¹ƒ vo sukhÄyÄâ€™ti. tassa te sÄvakÄ sussÅ«santi, sotaá¹ƒ odahanti, aÃ±Ã±Ä cittaá¹ƒ upaá¹­á¹­hapenti, na ca vokkamma satthusÄsanÄ vattanti. seyyathÄpi nÄma sakaá¹ƒ khettaá¹ƒ ohÄya paraá¹ƒ khettaá¹ƒ niddÄyitabbaá¹ƒ
"Furthermore, Lohicca, here a certain teacher has gone forth from the household life into homelessness for some purpose, but that goal of the ascetic life is not attained by him. And without having attained that goal of the ascetic life, he teaches his disciples the Dhamma, saying: "This is for your benefit, this is for your happiness." His disciples listen, lend an ear, apply their minds to understanding, and do not deviate from the teacher's instruction. He should be reproached in this way: "Venerable sir, that purpose for which you went forth from the household life into homelessness, that goal of the ascetic life has not been attained by you. And without attaining that goal of the ascetic life, you teach your disciples the Dhamma, saying, 'This is for your benefit, this is for your happiness.'" His disciples listen, lend an ear, apply their minds to understanding, and do not deviate from the teacher's instruction. It is as if one were to neglect one's own field and think that another's field needs weeding. And after I made this resolution. This, monks, is the third case, whereby some ascetics and Brahmins are partly eternalists and partly non-eternalists, and proclaim the self (Ätman) and the world (loka) to be partly eternal and partly non-eternal.
515. maÃ±Ã±eyya, evaá¹ƒ sampadamidaá¹ƒ pÄpakaá¹ƒ lobhadhammaá¹ƒ vadÄmi â€“ kiÃ±hi paro parassa karissatÄ«"ti. ayaá¹ƒ kho, lohicca, dutiyo satthÄ, yo, loke codanÄraho, yo ca panevarÅ«paá¹ƒ satthÄraá¹ƒ codeti, sÄ codanÄ bhÅ«tÄ tacchÄ dhammikÄ anavajjÄ. 515. "puna caparaá¹ƒ, lohicca, idhekacco satthÄ yassatthÄya agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajito hoti, svÄssa sÄmaÃ±Ã±attho anuppatto hoti. so taá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±atthaá¹ƒ anupÄpuá¹‡itvÄ sÄvakÄnaá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ deseti â€“ "idaá¹ƒ vo hitÄya idaá¹ƒ vo sukhÄyÄ"ti. tassa sÄvakÄ na sussÅ«santi, na sotaá¹ƒ odahanti, na aÃ±Ã±Ä cittaá¹ƒ upaá¹­á¹­hapenti, vokkamma ca satthusÄsanÄ vattanti. so evamassa codetabbo â€“ "ÄyasmÄ kho yassatthÄya agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajito, so te sÄmaÃ±Ã±attho anuppatto. taá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±atthaá¹ƒ anupÄpuá¹‡itvÄ sÄvakÄnaá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ desesi â€“ â€˜idaá¹ƒ vo hitÄya idaá¹ƒ vo sukhÄyÄâ€™ti. tassa te sÄvakÄ na sussÅ«santi, na sotaá¹ƒ odahanti, na aÃ±Ã±Ä cittaá¹ƒ upaá¹­á¹­hapenti, vokkamma ca satthusÄsanÄ vattanti. seyyathÄpi nÄma purÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ bandhanaá¹ƒ chinditvÄ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ navaá¹ƒ bandhanaá¹ƒ kareyya, evaá¹ƒ sampadamidaá¹ƒ pÄpakaá¹ƒ lobhadhammaá¹ƒ vadÄmi, kiÃ±hi paro parassa karissatÄ«"ti. ayaá¹ƒ kho, lohicca, tatiyo satthÄ, yo loke codanÄraho, yo ca panevarÅ«paá¹ƒ satthÄraá¹ƒ codeti, sÄ codanÄ bhÅ«tÄ tacchÄ dhammikÄ anavajjÄ. ime kho, lohicca, tayo satthÄro, ye loke codanÄrahÄ, yo ca panevarÅ«pe satthÄro codeti, sÄ codanÄ bhÅ«tÄ tacchÄ dhammikÄ anavajjÄti. nacodanÄrahasatthu 516. evaá¹ƒ vutte, lohicco brÄhmaá¹‡o bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "atthi pana, bho gotama, koci satthÄ, yo loke nacodanÄraho"ti? "atthi kho, lohicca, satthÄ, yo loke nacodanÄraho"ti. "katamo pana so, bho gotama, satthÄ, yo loke nacodanÄraho"ti? "idha, lohicca, tathÄgato loke uppajjati arahaá¹ƒ, sammÄsambuddhoâ€¦peâ€¦ (yathÄ 190-212 anucchedesu evaá¹ƒ vitthÄretabbaá¹ƒ). evaá¹ƒ kho, lohicca, bhikkhu
Furthermore, Lohicca, here a certain teacher has gone forth from the household life into homelessness for some purpose, and he has attained the goal of asceticism (*sÄmaÃ±Ã±attha*). But without having attained that goal of asceticism, he teaches his disciples the Dhamma, saying: "This is for your good, this is for your happiness." His disciples do not want to hear, they do not listen, they do not focus their minds, and they turn away from the Teacher's Dispensation (*satthusÄsanÄ*). He should be blamed, saying: "Venerable one, you have gone forth from the household life into homelessness for some purpose, but you have not attained that goal of asceticism (*sÄmaÃ±Ã±attha*). Without having attained that goal of asceticism (*sÄmaÃ±Ã±attha*), you teach your disciples the *Dhamma*, saying: â€˜This is for your benefit, this is for your happiness.â€™ Your disciples do not want to hear, they do not listen, they do not focus their minds, and they turn away from the Teacher's Dispensation (*satthusÄsanÄ*). Just as if, having cut through an old fetter, one were to make a new one, I declare that this is an evil doctrine rooted in attachment, for what can one man do for another?" This, Lohicca, is the third teacher who is blameworthy. And if anyone blames that kind of teacher, that blame is true, in accordance with reality, righteous, and faultless. These, Lohicca, are the three teachers who are blameworthy, and if anyone blames that kind of teacher, that blame is true, in accordance with reality, righteous, and faultless. A teacher not worthy of blame
516. maÃ±Ã±eyya, evaá¹ƒ sampadamidaá¹ƒ pÄpakaá¹ƒ lobhadhammaá¹ƒ vadÄmi â€“ kiÃ±hi paro parassa karissatÄ«"ti. ayaá¹ƒ kho, lohicca, dutiyo satthÄ, yo, loke codanÄraho, yo ca panevarÅ«paá¹ƒ satthÄraá¹ƒ codeti, sÄ codanÄ bhÅ«tÄ tacchÄ dhammikÄ anavajjÄ. 515. "puna caparaá¹ƒ, lohicca, idhekacco satthÄ yassatthÄya agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajito hoti, svÄssa sÄmaÃ±Ã±attho anuppatto hoti. so taá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±atthaá¹ƒ anupÄpuá¹‡itvÄ sÄvakÄnaá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ deseti â€“ "idaá¹ƒ vo hitÄya idaá¹ƒ vo sukhÄyÄ"ti. tassa sÄvakÄ na sussÅ«santi, na sotaá¹ƒ odahanti, na aÃ±Ã±Ä cittaá¹ƒ upaá¹­á¹­hapenti, vokkamma ca satthusÄsanÄ vattanti. so evamassa codetabbo â€“ "ÄyasmÄ kho yassatthÄya agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajito, so te sÄmaÃ±Ã±attho anuppatto. taá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ sÄmaÃ±Ã±atthaá¹ƒ anupÄpuá¹‡itvÄ sÄvakÄnaá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ desesi â€“ â€˜idaá¹ƒ vo hitÄya idaá¹ƒ vo sukhÄyÄâ€™ti. tassa te sÄvakÄ na sussÅ«santi, na sotaá¹ƒ odahanti, na aÃ±Ã±Ä cittaá¹ƒ upaá¹­á¹­hapenti, vokkamma ca satthusÄsanÄ vattanti. seyyathÄpi nÄma purÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ bandhanaá¹ƒ chinditvÄ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ navaá¹ƒ bandhanaá¹ƒ kareyya, evaá¹ƒ sampadamidaá¹ƒ pÄpakaá¹ƒ lobhadhammaá¹ƒ vadÄmi, kiÃ±hi paro parassa karissatÄ«"ti. ayaá¹ƒ kho, lohicca, tatiyo satthÄ, yo loke codanÄraho, yo ca panevarÅ«paá¹ƒ satthÄraá¹ƒ codeti, sÄ codanÄ bhÅ«tÄ tacchÄ dhammikÄ anavajjÄ. ime kho, lohicca, tayo satthÄro, ye loke codanÄrahÄ, yo ca panevarÅ«pe satthÄro codeti, sÄ codanÄ bhÅ«tÄ tacchÄ dhammikÄ anavajjÄti. nacodanÄrahasatthu 516. evaá¹ƒ vutte, lohicco brÄhmaá¹‡o bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "atthi pana, bho gotama, koci satthÄ, yo loke nacodanÄraho"ti? "atthi kho, lohicca, satthÄ, yo loke nacodanÄraho"ti. "katamo pana so, bho gotama, satthÄ, yo loke nacodanÄraho"ti? "idha, lohicca, tathÄgato loke uppajjati arahaá¹ƒ, sammÄsambuddhoâ€¦peâ€¦ (yathÄ 190-212 anucchedesu evaá¹ƒ vitthÄretabbaá¹ƒ). evaá¹ƒ kho, lohicca, bhikkhu
When this was said, Lohicca the Brahmin said to the Blessed One: "Is there, venerable Gotama, any teacher who is not blameworthy in the world?" "There is, Lohicca, a teacher who is not blameworthy in the world." "Which one, venerable Gotama, is that teacher who is not blameworthy in the world?" "Here, Lohicca, a *TathÄgata* arises in the world, an *Arahant*, a fully enlightened *Buddha*... (as in sections 190-212, so it should be expanded). Thus, Lohicca, a *bhikkhu* is accomplished in moral discipline (*sÄ«lasampanno*)... He enters and abides in the first *jhÄna*... Whenever, Lohicca, a disciple of a teacher attains such excellent distinction, this, Lohicca, is a teacher who is not blameworthy in the world. And if anyone blames that kind of teacher, that blame is untrue, not in accordance with reality, unrighteous, and faulty... He enters and abides in the second *jhÄna*... third *jhÄna*... fourth *jhÄna*. Whenever, Lohicca, a disciple of a teacher attains such excellent distinction, this, Lohicca, is a teacher who is not blameworthy in the world, and if anyone blames that kind of teacher, that blame is untrue, not in accordance with reality, unrighteous, and faultyâ€¦ he directs and inclines his mind to knowledge and visionâ€¦ Whenever, Lohicca, a disciple of a teacher attains such excellent distinction, this, Lohicca, is a teacher who is not blameworthy in the world, and if anyone blames that kind of teacher, that blame is untrue, not in accordance with reality, unrighteous, and faultyâ€¦ he understands, â€˜There is no more beyond this.â€™ Whenever, Lohicca, a disciple of a teacher attains such excellent distinction, this, Lohicca, is a teacher who is not blameworthy in the world, and if anyone blames that kind of teacher, that blame is untrue, not in accordance with reality, unrighteous, and faulty."
517. sÄ«lasampanno hotiâ€¦peâ€¦ paá¹­hamaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒ upasampajja viharatiâ€¦ yasmiá¹ƒ kho, lohicca, satthari sÄvako evarÅ«paá¹ƒ uá¸·Äraá¹ƒ visesaá¹ƒ adhigacchati, ayampi kho, lohicca, satthÄ, yo loke nacodanÄraho. yo ca panevarÅ«paá¹ƒ satthÄraá¹ƒ codeti, sÄ codanÄ abhÅ«tÄ atacchÄ adhammikÄ sÄvajjÄâ€¦peâ€¦ dutiyaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒâ€¦peâ€¦ tatiyaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒâ€¦peâ€¦ catutthaá¹ƒ jhÄnaá¹ƒ upasampajja viharati. yasmiá¹ƒ kho, lohicca, satthari sÄvako evarÅ«paá¹ƒ uá¸·Äraá¹ƒ visesaá¹ƒ adhigacchati, ayampi kho, lohicca, satthÄ, yo loke nacodanÄraho, yo ca panevarÅ«paá¹ƒ satthÄraá¹ƒ codeti, sÄ codanÄ abhÅ«tÄ atacchÄ adhammikÄ sÄvajjÄâ€¦ Ã±Äá¹‡adassanÄya cittaá¹ƒ abhinÄ«harati abhininnÄmetiâ€¦peâ€¦ yasmiá¹ƒ kho, lohicca, satthari sÄvako evarÅ«paá¹ƒ uá¸·Äraá¹ƒ visesaá¹ƒ adhigacchati, ayampi kho, lohicca, satthÄ, yo loke nacodanÄraho, yo ca panevarÅ«paá¹ƒ satthÄraá¹ƒ codeti, sÄ codanÄ abhÅ«tÄ atacchÄ adhammikÄ sÄvajjÄâ€¦ nÄparaá¹ƒ itthattÄyÄti pajÄnÄti. yasmiá¹ƒ kho, lohicca, satthari sÄvako evarÅ«paá¹ƒ uá¸·Äraá¹ƒ visesaá¹ƒ adhigacchati, ayampi kho, lohicca, satthÄ, yo loke nacodanÄraho, yo ca panevarÅ«paá¹ƒ satthÄraá¹ƒ codeti, sÄ codanÄ abhÅ«tÄ atacchÄ adhammikÄ sÄvajjÄ"ti. 517. evaá¹ƒ vutte, lohicco brÄhmaá¹‡o bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "seyyathÄpi, bho gotama, puriso purisaá¹ƒ narakapapÄtaá¹ƒ patantaá¹ƒ kesesu gahetvÄ uddharitvÄ thale patiá¹­á¹­hapeyya, evamevÄhaá¹ƒ bhotÄ gotamena narakapapÄtaá¹ƒ papatanto uddharitvÄ thale patiá¹­á¹­hÄpito. abhikkantaá¹ƒ, bho gotama, abhikkantaá¹ƒ, bho gotama, seyyathÄpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaá¹ƒ vÄ ukkujjeyya, paá¹­icchannaá¹ƒ vÄ vivareyya, mÅ«á¸·hassa vÄ maggaá¹ƒ Äcikkheyya, andhakÄre vÄ telapajjotaá¹ƒ dhÄreyya, â€˜cakkhumanto rÅ«pÄni dakkhantÄ«â€™ti. evamevaá¹ƒ bhotÄ gotamena anekapariyÄyena dhammo pakÄsito. esÄhaá¹ƒ bhavantaá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ gacchÄmi dhammaÃ±ca bhikkhusaá¹…ghaÃ±ca. upÄsakaá¹ƒ maá¹ƒ bhavaá¹ƒ gotamo dhÄretu ajjatagge pÄá¹‡upetaá¹ƒ saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ gata"nti. lohiccasuttaá¹ƒ niá¹­á¹­hitaá¹ƒ dvÄdasamaá¹ƒ.
When this was said, Lohicca the Brahmin said to the Blessed One: "It is as if, venerable Gotama, a man were to seize another man who was falling into a pit of hell by the hair, lift him up, and set him on dry ground. Just so, I have been lifted up by you, venerable Gotama, as I was falling into a pit of hell, and set on dry ground. Excellent, venerable Gotama, excellent, venerable Gotama! It is as if, venerable Gotama, one were to set upright what had been overturned, or to reveal what was hidden, or to point out the way to one who was lost, or to hold up an oil lamp in the darkness, so that those with eyes might see forms. In this way, venerable Gotama, the *Dhamma* has been made clear in many ways. I go to the venerable Gotama for refuge, and to the *Dhamma*, and to the *Saá¹ƒgha* of *bhikkhus*. May the venerable Gotama remember me as a lay follower (*upÄsaka*) who has taken refuge from today onwards, for as long as life shall last." The Lohicca *Sutta*, the twelfth, is finished.
518. 13. tevijjasuttaá¹ƒ 518. evaá¹ƒ me sutaá¹ƒ â€“ ekaá¹ƒ samayaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ kosalesu cÄrikaá¹ƒ caramÄno mahatÄ bhikkhusaá¹…ghena saddhiá¹ƒ paÃ±camattehi bhikkhusatehi yena manasÄkaá¹­aá¹ƒ nÄma kosalÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡agÄmo tadavasari. tatra sudaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ manasÄkaá¹­e viharati uttarena manasÄkaá¹­assa aciravatiyÄ nadiyÄ tÄ«re ambavane. 519. tena kho pana samayena sambahulÄ abhiÃ±Ã±ÄtÄ abhiÃ±Ã±ÄtÄ brÄhmaá¹‡amahÄsÄlÄ manasÄkaá¹­e paá¹­ivasanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ caá¹…kÄ« brÄhmaá¹‡o tÄrukkho brÄhmaá¹‡o pokkharasÄti brÄhmaá¹‡o jÄá¹‡usoá¹‡i brÄhmaá¹‡o todeyyo brÄhmaá¹‡o aÃ±Ã±e ca abhiÃ±Ã±ÄtÄ abhiÃ±Ã±ÄtÄ brÄhmaá¹‡amahÄsÄlÄ. 520. atha kho vÄseá¹­á¹­habhÄradvÄjÄnaá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avÄnaá¹ƒ jaá¹…ghavihÄraá¹ƒ anucaá¹…kamantÄnaá¹ƒ anuvicarantÄnaá¹ƒ maggÄmagge kathÄ udapÄdi. atha kho vÄseá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo evamÄha â€“ "ayameva ujumaggo, ayamaÃ±jasÄyano niyyÄniko niyyÄti takkarassa brahmasahabyatÄya, yvÄyaá¹ƒ akkhÄto brÄhmaá¹‡ena pokkharasÄtinÄ"ti. bhÄradvÄjopi mÄá¹‡avo evamÄha â€“ "ayameva ujumaggo, ayamaÃ±jasÄyano niyyÄniko, niyyÄti takkarassa brahmasahabyatÄya, yvÄyaá¹ƒ akkhÄto brÄhmaá¹‡ena tÄrukkhenÄ"ti. neva kho asakkhi vÄseá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo bhÄradvÄjaá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avaá¹ƒ saÃ±Ã±Äpetuá¹ƒ, na pana asakkhi bhÄradvÄjo mÄá¹‡avopi vÄseá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avaá¹ƒ saÃ±Ã±Äpetuá¹ƒ. 521. atha kho vÄseá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo bhÄradvÄjaá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avaá¹ƒ Ämantesi â€“ "ayaá¹ƒ kho, bhÄradvÄja, samaá¹‡o gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulÄ pabbajito manasÄkaá¹­e viharati uttarena manasÄkaá¹­assa aciravatiyÄ nadiyÄ tÄ«re ambavane. taá¹ƒ kho pana bhavantaá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ kalyÄá¹‡o kittisaddo abbhuggato â€“ "itipi so bhagavÄ arahaá¹ƒ sammÄsambuddho vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampanno sugato lokavidÅ« anuttaro purisadammasÄrathi
Thus have I heard. On one occasion the Blessed One was wandering in Kosala with a large Saá¹…gha of monks, about five hundred in all. He arrived at a Kosalan Brahmin village called ManasÄkaá¹­a. The Blessed One stayed near ManasÄkaá¹­a, in a mango grove on the bank of the AciravatÄ« River, to the north of ManasÄkaá¹­a.
519. 13. tevijjasuttaá¹ƒ 518. evaá¹ƒ me sutaá¹ƒ â€“ ekaá¹ƒ samayaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ kosalesu cÄrikaá¹ƒ caramÄno mahatÄ bhikkhusaá¹…ghena saddhiá¹ƒ paÃ±camattehi bhikkhusatehi yena manasÄkaá¹­aá¹ƒ nÄma kosalÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡agÄmo tadavasari. tatra sudaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ manasÄkaá¹­e viharati uttarena manasÄkaá¹­assa aciravatiyÄ nadiyÄ tÄ«re ambavane. 519. tena kho pana samayena sambahulÄ abhiÃ±Ã±ÄtÄ abhiÃ±Ã±ÄtÄ brÄhmaá¹‡amahÄsÄlÄ manasÄkaá¹­e paá¹­ivasanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ caá¹…kÄ« brÄhmaá¹‡o tÄrukkho brÄhmaá¹‡o pokkharasÄti brÄhmaá¹‡o jÄá¹‡usoá¹‡i brÄhmaá¹‡o todeyyo brÄhmaá¹‡o aÃ±Ã±e ca abhiÃ±Ã±ÄtÄ abhiÃ±Ã±ÄtÄ brÄhmaá¹‡amahÄsÄlÄ. 520. atha kho vÄseá¹­á¹­habhÄradvÄjÄnaá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avÄnaá¹ƒ jaá¹…ghavihÄraá¹ƒ anucaá¹…kamantÄnaá¹ƒ anuvicarantÄnaá¹ƒ maggÄmagge kathÄ udapÄdi. atha kho vÄseá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo evamÄha â€“ "ayameva ujumaggo, ayamaÃ±jasÄyano niyyÄniko niyyÄti takkarassa brahmasahabyatÄya, yvÄyaá¹ƒ akkhÄto brÄhmaá¹‡ena pokkharasÄtinÄ"ti. bhÄradvÄjopi mÄá¹‡avo evamÄha â€“ "ayameva ujumaggo, ayamaÃ±jasÄyano niyyÄniko, niyyÄti takkarassa brahmasahabyatÄya, yvÄyaá¹ƒ akkhÄto brÄhmaá¹‡ena tÄrukkhenÄ"ti. neva kho asakkhi vÄseá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo bhÄradvÄjaá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avaá¹ƒ saÃ±Ã±Äpetuá¹ƒ, na pana asakkhi bhÄradvÄjo mÄá¹‡avopi vÄseá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avaá¹ƒ saÃ±Ã±Äpetuá¹ƒ. 521. atha kho vÄseá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo bhÄradvÄjaá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avaá¹ƒ Ämantesi â€“ "ayaá¹ƒ kho, bhÄradvÄja, samaá¹‡o gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulÄ pabbajito manasÄkaá¹­e viharati uttarena manasÄkaá¹­assa aciravatiyÄ nadiyÄ tÄ«re ambavane. taá¹ƒ kho pana bhavantaá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ kalyÄá¹‡o kittisaddo abbhuggato â€“ "itipi so bhagavÄ arahaá¹ƒ sammÄsambuddho vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampanno sugato lokavidÅ« anuttaro purisadammasÄrathi
Now at that time, numerous well-known and wealthy Brahmins were residing in ManasÄkaá¹­a, namely, the Brahmin Caá¹…kÄ«, the Brahmin TÄrukkha, the Brahmin PokkharasÄti, the Brahmin JÄá¹‡ussoá¹‡i, the Brahmin Todeyya, and other well-known and wealthy Brahmins.
520. 13. tevijjasuttaá¹ƒ 518. evaá¹ƒ me sutaá¹ƒ â€“ ekaá¹ƒ samayaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ kosalesu cÄrikaá¹ƒ caramÄno mahatÄ bhikkhusaá¹…ghena saddhiá¹ƒ paÃ±camattehi bhikkhusatehi yena manasÄkaá¹­aá¹ƒ nÄma kosalÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡agÄmo tadavasari. tatra sudaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ manasÄkaá¹­e viharati uttarena manasÄkaá¹­assa aciravatiyÄ nadiyÄ tÄ«re ambavane. 519. tena kho pana samayena sambahulÄ abhiÃ±Ã±ÄtÄ abhiÃ±Ã±ÄtÄ brÄhmaá¹‡amahÄsÄlÄ manasÄkaá¹­e paá¹­ivasanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ caá¹…kÄ« brÄhmaá¹‡o tÄrukkho brÄhmaá¹‡o pokkharasÄti brÄhmaá¹‡o jÄá¹‡usoá¹‡i brÄhmaá¹‡o todeyyo brÄhmaá¹‡o aÃ±Ã±e ca abhiÃ±Ã±ÄtÄ abhiÃ±Ã±ÄtÄ brÄhmaá¹‡amahÄsÄlÄ. 520. atha kho vÄseá¹­á¹­habhÄradvÄjÄnaá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avÄnaá¹ƒ jaá¹…ghavihÄraá¹ƒ anucaá¹…kamantÄnaá¹ƒ anuvicarantÄnaá¹ƒ maggÄmagge kathÄ udapÄdi. atha kho vÄseá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo evamÄha â€“ "ayameva ujumaggo, ayamaÃ±jasÄyano niyyÄniko niyyÄti takkarassa brahmasahabyatÄya, yvÄyaá¹ƒ akkhÄto brÄhmaá¹‡ena pokkharasÄtinÄ"ti. bhÄradvÄjopi mÄá¹‡avo evamÄha â€“ "ayameva ujumaggo, ayamaÃ±jasÄyano niyyÄniko, niyyÄti takkarassa brahmasahabyatÄya, yvÄyaá¹ƒ akkhÄto brÄhmaá¹‡ena tÄrukkhenÄ"ti. neva kho asakkhi vÄseá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo bhÄradvÄjaá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avaá¹ƒ saÃ±Ã±Äpetuá¹ƒ, na pana asakkhi bhÄradvÄjo mÄá¹‡avopi vÄseá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avaá¹ƒ saÃ±Ã±Äpetuá¹ƒ. 521. atha kho vÄseá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo bhÄradvÄjaá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avaá¹ƒ Ämantesi â€“ "ayaá¹ƒ kho, bhÄradvÄja, samaá¹‡o gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulÄ pabbajito manasÄkaá¹­e viharati uttarena manasÄkaá¹­assa aciravatiyÄ nadiyÄ tÄ«re ambavane. taá¹ƒ kho pana bhavantaá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ kalyÄá¹‡o kittisaddo abbhuggato â€“ "itipi so bhagavÄ arahaá¹ƒ sammÄsambuddho vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampanno sugato lokavidÅ« anuttaro purisadammasÄrathi
Then, as the two Brahmin students VÄseá¹­á¹­ha and BhÄradvÄja were out for a walk, a discussion arose between them about the true path and the false path. Then the Brahmin student VÄseá¹­á¹­ha said thus: â€œThis alone is the direct path, this is the straightforward way that leads to union with BrahmÄ, as taught by the Brahmin PokkharasÄti.â€ The Brahmin student BhÄradvÄja also said thus: â€œThis alone is the direct path, this is the straightforward way that leads to union with BrahmÄ, as taught by the Brahmin TÄrukkha.â€ VÄseá¹­á¹­ha was unable to convince the Brahmin student BhÄradvÄja, nor was BhÄradvÄja able to convince VÄseá¹­á¹­ha.
521. 13. tevijjasuttaá¹ƒ 518. evaá¹ƒ me sutaá¹ƒ â€“ ekaá¹ƒ samayaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ kosalesu cÄrikaá¹ƒ caramÄno mahatÄ bhikkhusaá¹…ghena saddhiá¹ƒ paÃ±camattehi bhikkhusatehi yena manasÄkaá¹­aá¹ƒ nÄma kosalÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡agÄmo tadavasari. tatra sudaá¹ƒ bhagavÄ manasÄkaá¹­e viharati uttarena manasÄkaá¹­assa aciravatiyÄ nadiyÄ tÄ«re ambavane. 519. tena kho pana samayena sambahulÄ abhiÃ±Ã±ÄtÄ abhiÃ±Ã±ÄtÄ brÄhmaá¹‡amahÄsÄlÄ manasÄkaá¹­e paá¹­ivasanti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ caá¹…kÄ« brÄhmaá¹‡o tÄrukkho brÄhmaá¹‡o pokkharasÄti brÄhmaá¹‡o jÄá¹‡usoá¹‡i brÄhmaá¹‡o todeyyo brÄhmaá¹‡o aÃ±Ã±e ca abhiÃ±Ã±ÄtÄ abhiÃ±Ã±ÄtÄ brÄhmaá¹‡amahÄsÄlÄ. 520. atha kho vÄseá¹­á¹­habhÄradvÄjÄnaá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avÄnaá¹ƒ jaá¹…ghavihÄraá¹ƒ anucaá¹…kamantÄnaá¹ƒ anuvicarantÄnaá¹ƒ maggÄmagge kathÄ udapÄdi. atha kho vÄseá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo evamÄha â€“ "ayameva ujumaggo, ayamaÃ±jasÄyano niyyÄniko niyyÄti takkarassa brahmasahabyatÄya, yvÄyaá¹ƒ akkhÄto brÄhmaá¹‡ena pokkharasÄtinÄ"ti. bhÄradvÄjopi mÄá¹‡avo evamÄha â€“ "ayameva ujumaggo, ayamaÃ±jasÄyano niyyÄniko, niyyÄti takkarassa brahmasahabyatÄya, yvÄyaá¹ƒ akkhÄto brÄhmaá¹‡ena tÄrukkhenÄ"ti. neva kho asakkhi vÄseá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo bhÄradvÄjaá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avaá¹ƒ saÃ±Ã±Äpetuá¹ƒ, na pana asakkhi bhÄradvÄjo mÄá¹‡avopi vÄseá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avaá¹ƒ saÃ±Ã±Äpetuá¹ƒ. 521. atha kho vÄseá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo bhÄradvÄjaá¹ƒ mÄá¹‡avaá¹ƒ Ämantesi â€“ "ayaá¹ƒ kho, bhÄradvÄja, samaá¹‡o gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulÄ pabbajito manasÄkaá¹­e viharati uttarena manasÄkaá¹­assa aciravatiyÄ nadiyÄ tÄ«re ambavane. taá¹ƒ kho pana bhavantaá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ kalyÄá¹‡o kittisaddo abbhuggato â€“ "itipi so bhagavÄ arahaá¹ƒ sammÄsambuddho vijjÄcaraá¹‡asampanno sugato lokavidÅ« anuttaro purisadammasÄrathi
Then the Brahmin student VÄseá¹­á¹­ha addressed the Brahmin student BhÄradvÄja, saying: â€œThis ascetic Gotama, the son of the Sakyans, who has gone forth from the Sakyan clan, is staying in ManasÄkaá¹­a, in the mango grove on the bank of the AciravatÄ« River, to the north of ManasÄkaá¹­a. Now a good report of the Blessed Gotama has spread about, saying: â€˜Thus indeed, that Blessed One is an Arhat, a fully enlightened Buddha, perfect in knowledge and conduct, sublime, knower of the world, unsurpassed trainer of those who can be taught, teacher of gods and humans, enlightened, blessed.â€™ Come, BhÄradvÄja, let us go to the ascetic Gotama and ask him about this matter. Whatever the ascetic Gotama explains to us, so shall we remember it.â€ â€œVery well, friend,â€ the Brahmin student BhÄradvÄja replied to the Brahmin student VÄseá¹­á¹­ha. The discussion of the true and untrue path.
522. satthÄ devamanussÄnaá¹ƒ buddho bhagavÄ"ti. ÄyÄma, bho bhÄradvÄja, yena samaá¹‡o gotamo tenupasaá¹…kamissÄma, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ etamatthaá¹ƒ samaá¹‡aá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ pucchissÄma. yathÄ no samaá¹‡o gotamo byÄkarissati, tathÄ naá¹ƒ dhÄressÄmÄ"ti. "evaá¹ƒ, bho"ti kho bhÄradvÄjo mÄá¹‡avo vÄseá¹­á¹­hassa mÄá¹‡avassa paccassosi. maggÄmaggakathÄ 522. atha kho vÄseá¹­á¹­habhÄradvÄjÄ mÄá¹‡avÄ yena bhagavÄ tenupasaá¹…kamiá¹ƒsu, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ bhagavatÄ saddhiá¹ƒ sammodiá¹ƒsu. sammodanÄ«yaá¹ƒ kathaá¹ƒ sÄraá¹‡Ä«yaá¹ƒ vÄ«tisÄretvÄ ekamantaá¹ƒ nisÄ«diá¹ƒsu. ekamantaá¹ƒ nisinno kho vÄseá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "idha, bho gotama, amhÄkaá¹ƒ jaá¹…ghavihÄraá¹ƒ anucaá¹…kamantÄnaá¹ƒ anuvicarantÄnaá¹ƒ maggÄmagge kathÄ udapÄdi. ahaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ vadÄmi â€“ â€˜ayameva ujumaggo, ayamaÃ±jasÄyano niyyÄniko niyyÄti takkarassa brahmasahabyatÄya, yvÄyaá¹ƒ akkhÄto brÄhmaá¹‡ena pokkharasÄtinÄâ€™ti. bhÄradvÄjo mÄá¹‡avo evamÄha â€“ â€˜ayameva ujumaggo ayamaÃ±jasÄyano niyyÄniko niyyÄti takkarassa brahmasahabyatÄya, yvÄyaá¹ƒ akkhÄto brÄhmaá¹‡ena tÄrukkhenÄâ€™ti. ettha, bho gotama, attheva viggaho, atthi vivÄdo, atthi nÄnÄvÄdo"ti. 523. "iti kira, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, tvaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ vadesi â€“ "ayameva ujumaggo, ayamaÃ±jasÄyano niyyÄniko niyyÄti takkarassa brahmasahabyatÄya, yvÄyaá¹ƒ akkhÄto brÄhmaá¹‡ena pokkharasÄtinÄ"ti. bhÄradvÄjo mÄá¹‡avo evamÄha â€“ "ayameva ujumaggo ayamaÃ±jasÄyano niyyÄniko niyyÄti takkarassa brahmasahabyatÄya, yvÄyaá¹ƒ akkhÄto brÄhmaá¹‡ena tÄrukkhenÄ"ti. atha kismiá¹ƒ pana vo, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, viggaho, kismiá¹ƒ vivÄdo, kismiá¹ƒ nÄnÄvÄdo"ti. 524. "maggÄmagge, bho gotama. kiÃ±cÄpi, bho gotama, brÄhmaá¹‡Ä nÄnÄmagge paÃ±Ã±apenti, addhariyÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä tittiriyÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä chandokÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä bavhÄrijjhÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä, atha kho sabbÄni tÄni niyyÄnikÄ niyyanti takkarassa brahmasahabyatÄya.
Then the Brahmin students VÄseá¹­á¹­ha and BhÄradvÄja went to where the Blessed One was. Having approached, they exchanged friendly greetings with the Blessed One. After an exchange of polite and courteous greetings, they sat down to one side. Seated to one side, the Brahmin student VÄseá¹­á¹­ha said this to the Blessed One: â€œHere, Reverend Gotama, as we were out for a walk, a discussion arose between us about the true path and the untrue path. I say thus: â€˜This alone is the direct path, this is the straightforward way that leads to union with BrahmÄ, as taught by the Brahmin PokkharasÄti.â€™ The Brahmin BhÄradvÄja says thus: â€˜This alone is the direct path, this is the straightforward way that leads to union with BrahmÄ, as taught by the Brahmin TÄrukkha.â€™ In this matter, Reverend Gotama, there is disagreement, there is dispute, there is divergence of views.â€
523. satthÄ devamanussÄnaá¹ƒ buddho bhagavÄ"ti. ÄyÄma, bho bhÄradvÄja, yena samaá¹‡o gotamo tenupasaá¹…kamissÄma, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ etamatthaá¹ƒ samaá¹‡aá¹ƒ gotamaá¹ƒ pucchissÄma. yathÄ no samaá¹‡o gotamo byÄkarissati, tathÄ naá¹ƒ dhÄressÄmÄ"ti. "evaá¹ƒ, bho"ti kho bhÄradvÄjo mÄá¹‡avo vÄseá¹­á¹­hassa mÄá¹‡avassa paccassosi. maggÄmaggakathÄ 522. atha kho vÄseá¹­á¹­habhÄradvÄjÄ mÄá¹‡avÄ yena bhagavÄ tenupasaá¹…kamiá¹ƒsu, upasaá¹…kamitvÄ bhagavatÄ saddhiá¹ƒ sammodiá¹ƒsu. sammodanÄ«yaá¹ƒ kathaá¹ƒ sÄraá¹‡Ä«yaá¹ƒ vÄ«tisÄretvÄ ekamantaá¹ƒ nisÄ«diá¹ƒsu. ekamantaá¹ƒ nisinno kho vÄseá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "idha, bho gotama, amhÄkaá¹ƒ jaá¹…ghavihÄraá¹ƒ anucaá¹…kamantÄnaá¹ƒ anuvicarantÄnaá¹ƒ maggÄmagge kathÄ udapÄdi. ahaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ vadÄmi â€“ â€˜ayameva ujumaggo, ayamaÃ±jasÄyano niyyÄniko niyyÄti takkarassa brahmasahabyatÄya, yvÄyaá¹ƒ akkhÄto brÄhmaá¹‡ena pokkharasÄtinÄâ€™ti. bhÄradvÄjo mÄá¹‡avo evamÄha â€“ â€˜ayameva ujumaggo ayamaÃ±jasÄyano niyyÄniko niyyÄti takkarassa brahmasahabyatÄya, yvÄyaá¹ƒ akkhÄto brÄhmaá¹‡ena tÄrukkhenÄâ€™ti. ettha, bho gotama, attheva viggaho, atthi vivÄdo, atthi nÄnÄvÄdo"ti. 523. "maggÄmagge, bho gotama. kiÃ±cÄpi, bho gotama, brÄhmaá¹‡Ä nÄnÄmagge paÃ±Ã±apenti, addhariyÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä tittiriyÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä chandokÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä bavhÄrijjhÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä, atha kho sabbÄni tÄni niyyÄnikÄ niyyanti takkarassa brahmasahabyatÄya.
â€œSo, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, is this what you say: â€˜This alone is the direct path, this is the straightforward way that leads to union with BrahmÄ, as taught by the Brahmin PokkharasÄtiâ€™?â€ The Brahmin BhÄradvÄja says thus: â€˜This alone is the direct path, this is the straightforward way that leads to union with BrahmÄ, as taught by the Brahmin TÄrukkha.â€™ What then, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, is the subject of your disagreement, of your dispute, of your divergence of views?â€
524. satthÄ devamanussÄnaá¹ƒ buddho bhagavÄ"ti. â€œThe true path and the untrue path, Reverend Gotama. Even though, Reverend Gotama, the Brahmins teach various paths â€“ the Adhvariya Brahmins, the Tittiriya Brahmins, the Chandoka Brahmins, the BavhÄrijjha Brahmins â€“ do all those paths lead to union with BrahmÄ?" Just as if, Reverend Gotama, there were near a town or village many different paths, and all these come together at that village; even so, Reverend Gotama, although the *brÄhmaá¹‡as* propound different pathsâ€”the Adhvariya *brÄhmaá¹‡as*, the Tittiriya *brÄhmaá¹‡as*, the Chandoka *brÄhmaá¹‡as*, the BavhÄrijjhÄ *brÄhmaá¹‡as*â€”do all these paths lead the one who follows them to union with BrahmÄ? The Discourse to VÄseá¹­á¹­ha about the Youths

â€œDo you say â€˜they leadâ€™, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha?â€ â€œI say, â€˜they leadâ€™, Reverend Gotama.â€ â€œDo you say, â€˜they lead,â€™ VÄseá¹­á¹­ha?â€ â€œI say, â€˜they lead,â€™ Reverend Gotama.â€ â€œDo you say, â€˜they lead,â€™ VÄseá¹­á¹­ha?â€ â€œI say, â€˜they lead,â€™ Reverend Gotama.â€ â€œBut, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, is there then a single one of these *brÄhmaá¹‡as* learned in the Three Vedas (*tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ*) who has seen BrahmÄ face to face?â€ â€œNo, Reverend Gotama.â€ â€œThen has the teacher of any one of them seen BrahmÄ face to face?â€ â€œNo, Reverend Gotama.â€ â€œThen has the teacherâ€™s teacher of any one of them seen BrahmÄ face to face?â€ â€œNo, Reverend Gotama.â€ â€œThen has the ancestor seven generations back of the teacher of one of them seen BrahmÄ face to face?â€ â€œNo, Reverend Gotama.â€

â€œSo, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, not one of these *brÄhmaá¹‡as* learned in the Three Vedas (*tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ*) has seen BrahmÄ face to face. This is the only straight path, this is the direct path, the path of salvation that leads one who follows it to union with BrahmÄ.â€
528. 527. "seyyathÄpi, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, andhaveá¹‡i paramparasaá¹ƒsattÄ purimopi na passati, majjhimopi na passati, pacchimopi na passati. evameva kho, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, andhaveá¹‡Å«pamaá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±e tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ, purimopi na passati, majjhimopi na passati, pacchimopi na passati. tesamidaá¹ƒ tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ hassakaÃ±Ã±eva sampajjati, nÄmakaÃ±Ã±eva sampajjati, rittakaÃ±Ã±eva sampajjati, tucchakaÃ±Ã±eva sampajjati.
â€œWhat do you think, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha? Such being the case, does not what these *brÄhmaá¹‡as* learned in the Three Vedas (*tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ*) declare turn out to be ill-founded?â€ â€œYes indeed, Reverend Gotama, such being the case, what these *brÄhmaá¹‡as* learned in the Three Vedas (*tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ*) declare does turn out to be ill-founded.â€ â€œThat is right, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha. When these *brÄhmaá¹‡as* learned in the Three Vedas (*tevijjÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä*) teach a path that they do not know and see, saying: â€˜This is the only straight path, this is the direct path, the path of salvation that leads one who follows it to union with BrahmÄ,â€™ this cannot possibly be right.
529. 527. "iti kira, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, natthi koci tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ ekabrÄhmaá¹‡opi, yena brahmÄ sakkhidiá¹­á¹­ho. natthi koci tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ ekÄcariyopi, yena brahmÄ sakkhidiá¹­á¹­ho. natthi koci tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ ekÄcariyapÄcariyopi, yena brahmÄ sakkhidiá¹­á¹­ho. natthi koci tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ yÄva sattamÄ ÄcariyÄmahayugÄ yena brahmÄ sakkhidiá¹­á¹­ho. yepi kira tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ pubbakÄ isayo mantÄnaá¹ƒ kattÄro mantÄnaá¹ƒ pavattÄro, yesamidaá¹ƒ etarahi tevijjÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä porÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ mantapadaá¹ƒ gÄ«taá¹ƒ pavuttaá¹ƒ samihitaá¹ƒ, tadanugÄyanti, tadanubhÄsanti, bhÄsitamanubhÄsanti, vÄcitamanuvÄcenti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ aá¹­á¹­hako vÄmako vÄmadevo vessÄmitto yamataggi aá¹…gÄ«raso bhÄradvÄjo vÄseá¹­á¹­ho kassapo bhagu, tepi na evamÄhaá¹ƒsu â€“ â€˜mayametaá¹ƒ jÄnÄma, mayametaá¹ƒ passÄma, yattha vÄ brahmÄ, yena vÄ brahmÄ, yahiá¹ƒ vÄ brahmÄâ€™ti. teva tevijjÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä evamÄhaá¹ƒsu â€“ â€˜yaá¹ƒ na jÄnÄma, yaá¹ƒ na passÄma, tassa sahabyatÄya maggaá¹ƒ desema. ayameva ujumaggo ayamaÃ±jasÄyano niyyÄniko, niyyÄti takkarassa brahmasahabyatÄyÄ"â€™ti. 528. "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, nanu evaá¹ƒ sante tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ appÄá¹­ihÄ«rakataá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ sampajjatÄ«"ti? "sÄdhu, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, te vata [teva (ka.)], vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, tevijjÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä yaá¹ƒ na jÄnanti, yaá¹ƒ na passanti, tassa sahabyatÄya maggaá¹ƒ desessanti. â€˜ayameva ujumaggo, ayamaÃ±jasÄyano niyyÄniko, niyyÄti takkarassa brahmasahabyatÄyÄâ€™ti, netaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ vijjati. 529. "seyyathÄpi, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, andhaveá¹‡i paramparasaá¹ƒsattÄ purimopi na passati, majjhimopi na passati, pacchimopi na passati. evameva kho, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, andhaveá¹‡Å«pamaá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±e tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ, purimopi na passati, majjhimopi na passati, pacchimopi na passati. tesamidaá¹ƒ tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ hassakaÃ±Ã±eva sampajjati, nÄmakaÃ±Ã±eva sampajjati, rittakaÃ±Ã±eva sampajjati, tucchakaÃ±Ã±eva sampajjati.
Just as a file of blind men go on, clinging to each other, and the first one sees nothing, the middle one sees nothing, and the last one sees nothingâ€” so it is with the talk of these *brÄhmaá¹‡as* learned in the Three Vedas (*tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ*): the first one sees nothing, the middle one sees nothing, the last one sees nothing. The talk of these *brÄhmaá¹‡as* learned in the Three Vedas (*tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ*) turns out to be laughable, mere words, empty and vain.
530. 530. "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, passanti tevijjÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä candimasÅ«riye, aÃ±Ã±e cÄpi bahujanÄ, yato ca candimasÅ«riyÄ uggacchanti, yattha ca ogacchanti, ÄyÄcanti thomayanti paÃ±jalikÄ namassamÄnÄ anuparivattantÄ«"ti? 'What do you think, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha? Do the Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas see the moon and sun, just as other people do, and when the moon and sun rise and set, do they pray, sing praises, worship with clasped hands, and circumambulate?' 'Yes, Reverend Gotama, the Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas see the moon and sun, just as other people do, and when the moon and sun rise and set, they pray, sing praises, worship with clasped hands, and circumambulate.'
531. 530. 'What do you think, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha? Can these Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas, who see the moon and sun just as other people do, point out a way to union with the moon and sun, saying: "This is the only straight path, this is the direct way, which leads to union with the moon and sun for whoever practices it?"' 'No, Reverend Gotama.' 'So, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, these Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas cannot point out a way to union with the moon and sun, which they have seen, saying: "This is the only straight path, this is the direct way, which leads to union with the moon and sun for whoever practices it."'
532. 530. 'Thus, indeed, the BrahmÄ has not been seen face-to-face by the Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas. Nor has BrahmÄ been seen face-to-face by the teachers of the Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas. Nor has BrahmÄ been seen face-to-face by the teachers of the teachers of the Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas. Nor has BrahmÄ been seen face-to-face by the most ancient teachers, going back even seven generations, of the Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas. And those ancient *á¹›á¹£is* (seers) of the Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas, the creators of the *mantras* (hymns), the expounders of the *mantras*, whose ancient *mantra-pada* (words of the hymns) is chanted, uttered, and compiled by the Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas of today, they also sing after, they also speak after, they also repeat what was spoken, they also cause to recite what was recited, namely: Aá¹­á¹­haka, VÄmaka, VÄmadeva, VessÄmitta, Yamataggi, Aá¹…gÄ«rasa, BhÄradvÄja, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, Kassapa, and Bhagu, even they did not say, "We know this, we see this, where BrahmÄ is, by whom BrahmÄ is, and in whom BrahmÄ is." The Brahmins versed in the three Vedas declared thus: "We teach the path to union with that which we neither know nor see â€“ this alone is the straight path, this is the direct way, the means of escape, leading to union with BrahmÄ for one who acts accordingly."
533. vÄmadevo vessÄmitto yamataggi aá¹…gÄ«raso bhÄradvÄjo vÄseá¹­á¹­ho kassapo bhagu, tepi na evamÄhaá¹ƒsu â€“ "mayametaá¹ƒ jÄnÄma, mayametaá¹ƒ passÄma, yattha vÄ brahmÄ, yena vÄ brahmÄ, yahiá¹ƒ vÄ brahmÄ"ti. teva tevijjÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä evamÄhaá¹ƒsu â€“ "yaá¹ƒ na jÄnÄma, yaá¹ƒ na passÄma, tassa sahabyatÄya maggaá¹ƒ desema â€“ ayameva ujumaggo ayamaÃ±jasÄyano niyyÄniko niyyÄti takkarassa brahmasahabyatÄyÄ"ti. 533. "What do you think, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha? Such being the case, does not what these Brahmins versed in the three Vedas declare turn out to be unfounded?" "Indeed, Reverend Gotama, such being the case, what these Brahmins versed in the three Vedas declare turns out to be unfounded." "Well done, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha! Indeed, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, the Brahmins versed in the three Vedas, not knowing, not seeing, will teach the path to union with that â€“ 'This alone is the straight path, this the direct way, the means of escape, leading to union with BrahmÄ for one who acts accordingly' â€“ such a thing cannot be." The simile of the beautiful woman of the country.
534. vÄmadevo vessÄmitto yamataggi aá¹…gÄ«raso bhÄradvÄjo vÄseá¹­á¹­ho kassapo bhagu, tepi na evamÄhaá¹ƒsu â€“ "mayametaá¹ƒ jÄnÄma, mayametaá¹ƒ passÄma, yattha vÄ brahmÄ, yena vÄ brahmÄ, yahiá¹ƒ vÄ brahmÄ"ti. teva tevijjÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä evamÄhaá¹ƒsu â€“ "yaá¹ƒ na jÄnÄma, yaá¹ƒ na passÄma, tassa sahabyatÄya maggaá¹ƒ desema â€“ ayameva ujumaggo ayamaÃ±jasÄyano niyyÄniko niyyÄti takkarassa brahmasahabyatÄyÄ"ti. 533. "sÄdhu, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, te vata, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, tevijjÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä yaá¹ƒ na jÄnanti, yaá¹ƒ na passanti, tassa sahabyatÄya maggaá¹ƒ desessanti â€“ "ayameva ujumaggo, ayamaÃ±jasÄyano niyyÄniko, niyyÄti takkarassa brahmasahabyatÄyÄ"ti, netaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ vijjati. janapadakalyÄá¹‡Ä«upamÄ 534. "seyyathÄpi, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, puriso evaá¹ƒ vadeyya â€“ "ahaá¹ƒ yÄ imasmiá¹ƒ janapade janapadakalyÄá¹‡Ä«, taá¹ƒ icchÄmi, taá¹ƒ kÄmemÄ«"ti. tamenaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ vadeyyuá¹ƒ â€“ "ambho purisa, yaá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ janapadakalyÄá¹‡iá¹ƒ icchasi kÄmesi, jÄnÄsi taá¹ƒ janapadakalyÄá¹‡iá¹ƒ â€“ khattiyÄ« vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä« vÄ vessÄ« vÄ suddÄ« vÄ"ti? iti puá¹­á¹­ho "no"ti vadeyya. "tamenaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ vadeyyuá¹ƒ â€“ "ambho purisa, yaá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ janapadakalyÄá¹‡iá¹ƒ icchasi kÄmesi, jÄnÄsi taá¹ƒ janapadakalyÄá¹‡iá¹ƒ â€“ evaá¹ƒnÄmÄ evaá¹ƒgottÄti vÄ, dÄ«ghÄ vÄ rassÄ vÄ majjhimÄ vÄ kÄá¸·Ä« vÄ sÄmÄ vÄ maá¹…guracchavÄ« vÄti, amukasmiá¹ƒ gÄme vÄ nigame vÄ nagare vÄ"ti? iti puá¹­á¹­ho â€˜noâ€™ti vadeyya. tamenaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ vadeyyuá¹ƒ â€“ "ambho purisa, yaá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ na jÄnÄsi na passasi, taá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ icchasi kÄmesÄ«"ti? iti puá¹­á¹­ho "ÄmÄ"ti vadeyya. 535. "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, nanu evaá¹ƒ sante tassa purisassa appÄá¹­ihÄ«rakataá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ sampajjatÄ«"ti? "addhÄ kho, bho gotama, evaá¹ƒ sante tassa purisassa appÄá¹­ihÄ«rakataá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ sampajjatÄ«"ti.
"It is just as if, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, a man were to say thus: 'I desire, I long for the most beautiful woman in this country.'" They might say to him thus: "Good man, this most beautiful woman in the country whom you desire and long for, do you know whether she is a noblewoman, a *brÄhmaá¹‡a* woman, a *vessa* woman, or a *sudda* woman?" Asked thus, he would say, "No." "They might say to him thus: "Good man, this most beautiful woman in the country whom you desire and long for, do you know her name, her clan, whether she is tall, short, or of medium height, dark, fair, or of golden skin, or in what village, town, or city she dwells?" Asked thus, he would say, "No." They might say to him thus: "Good man, you desire and long for someone you neither know nor see?" Asked thus, he would say, "Yes."
535. vÄmadevo vessÄmitto yamataggi aá¹…gÄ«raso bhÄradvÄjo vÄseá¹­á¹­ho kassapo bhagu, tepi na evamÄhaá¹ƒsu â€“ "mayametaá¹ƒ jÄnÄma, mayametaá¹ƒ passÄma, yattha vÄ brahmÄ, yena vÄ brahmÄ, yahiá¹ƒ vÄ brahmÄ"ti. teva tevijjÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä evamÄhaá¹ƒsu â€“ "yaá¹ƒ na jÄnÄma, yaá¹ƒ na passÄma, tassa sahabyatÄya maggaá¹ƒ desema â€“ ayameva ujumaggo ayamaÃ±jasÄyano niyyÄniko niyyÄti takkarassa brahmasahabyatÄyÄ"ti. 533. "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, nanu evaá¹ƒ sante tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ appÄá¹­ihÄ«rakataá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ sampajjatÄ«"ti? "addhÄ kho, bho gotama, evaá¹ƒ sante tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ appÄá¹­ihÄ«rakataá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ sampajjatÄ«"ti. "What do you think, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha? Such being the case, does not the speech of that man turn out to be groundless?" "Indeed, Reverend Gotama, such being the case, the speech of that man turns out to be groundless."
536. 536. "evameva kho, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, na kira tevijjehi brÄhmaá¹‡ehi brahmÄ sakkhidiá¹­á¹­ho, napi kira tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ Äcariyehi brahmÄ sakkhidiá¹­á¹­ho, napi kira tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ ÄcariyapÄcariyehi brahmÄ sakkhidiá¹­á¹­ho. napi kira tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ yÄva sattamÄ ÄcariyÄmahayugehi brahmÄ sakkhidiá¹­á¹­ho. yepi kira tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ pubbakÄ isayo mantÄnaá¹ƒ kattÄro mantÄnaá¹ƒ pavattÄro, yesamidaá¹ƒ etarahi tevijjÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä porÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ mantapadaá¹ƒ gÄ«taá¹ƒ pavuttaá¹ƒ samihitaá¹ƒ, tadanugÄyanti, tadanubhÄsanti, bhÄsitamanubhÄsanti, vÄcitamanuvÄcenti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ aá¹­á¹­hako vÄmako vÄmadevo vessÄmitto yamataggi aá¹…gÄ«raso bhÄradvÄjo vÄseá¹­á¹­ho kassapo bhagu, tepi na evamÄhaá¹ƒsu â€“ "mayametaá¹ƒ jÄnÄma, mayametaá¹ƒ passÄma, yattha vÄ brahmÄ, yena vÄ brahmÄ, yahiá¹ƒ vÄ brahmÄ"ti. teva tevijjÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä evamÄhaá¹ƒsu â€“ "yaá¹ƒ na jÄnÄma, yaá¹ƒ na passÄma, tassa sahabyatÄya maggaá¹ƒ desema â€“ ayameva ujumaggo ayamaÃ±jasÄyano niyyÄniko niyyÄti takkarassa brahmasahabyatÄyÄ"ti. 537. "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, nanu evaá¹ƒ sante tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ appÄá¹­ihÄ«rakataá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ sampajjatÄ«"ti? "addhÄ kho, bho gotama, evaá¹ƒ sante tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ appÄá¹­ihÄ«rakataá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ sampajjatÄ«"ti. "seyyathÄpi, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, puriso cÄtumahÄpathe nisseá¹‡iá¹ƒ kareyya â€“ pÄsÄdassa Ärohaá¹‡Äya. tamenaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ vadeyyuá¹ƒ â€“ "ambho purisa, yassa tvaá¹ƒ [yaá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ (syÄ.)] pÄsÄdassa Ärohaá¹‡Äya nisseá¹‡iá¹ƒ karosi, jÄnÄsi taá¹ƒ pÄsÄdaá¹ƒ â€“ puratthimÄya vÄ disÄya dakkhiá¹‡Äya vÄ disÄya
"Even so, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, not one of the Brahmins versed in the three Vedas has seen BrahmÄ face to face, nor has any of their teachers, nor any of the teachers of their teachers. Not even the ancestor seven generations back of the teachers of the Brahmins versed in the three Vedas has seen BrahmÄ face to face. Those former sages of the Brahmins versed in the three Vedas, the composers of the *mantras*, the founders of the *mantras*, those whose ancient verses, words of *mantras*, chanted, uttered, and compiled, are now chanted, repeated, reiterated, and recited by the Brahmins versed in the three Vedasâ€”such as Aá¹­á¹­haka, VÄmaka, VÄmadeva, VessÄmitta, Yamataggi, Aá¹…gÄ«rasa, BhÄradvÄja, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, Kassapa, and Bhaguâ€”even they did not say, "We know this, we see this, where BrahmÄ is, by whom BrahmÄ is, and in whom BrahmÄ is." The Brahmins versed in the three Vedas declared thus: "We teach the path to union with that which we neither know nor see â€“ this alone is the straight path, this is the direct way, the means of escape, leading to union with BrahmÄ for one who acts accordingly."
537. 536. "evameva kho, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, na kira tevijjehi brÄhmaá¹‡ehi brahmÄ sakkhidiá¹­á¹­ho, napi kira tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ Äcariyehi brahmÄ sakkhidiá¹­á¹­ho, napi kira tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ ÄcariyapÄcariyehi brahmÄ sakkhidiá¹­á¹­ho. napi kira tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ yÄva sattamÄ ÄcariyÄmahayugehi brahmÄ sakkhidiá¹­á¹­ho. yepi kira tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ pubbakÄ isayo mantÄnaá¹ƒ kattÄro mantÄnaá¹ƒ pavattÄro, yesamidaá¹ƒ etarahi tevijjÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä porÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ mantapadaá¹ƒ gÄ«taá¹ƒ pavuttaá¹ƒ samihitaá¹ƒ, tadanugÄyanti, tadanubhÄsanti, bhÄsitamanubhÄsanti, vÄcitamanuvÄcenti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ aá¹­á¹­hako vÄmako vÄmadevo vessÄmitto yamataggi aá¹…gÄ«raso bhÄradvÄjo vÄseá¹­á¹­ho kassapo bhagu, tepi na evamÄhaá¹ƒsu â€“ "mayametaá¹ƒ jÄnÄma, mayametaá¹ƒ passÄma, yattha vÄ brahmÄ, yena vÄ brahmÄ, yahiá¹ƒ vÄ brahmÄ"ti. teva tevijjÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä evamÄhaá¹ƒsu â€“ "yaá¹ƒ na jÄnÄma, yaá¹ƒ na passÄma, tassa sahabyatÄya maggaá¹ƒ desema â€“ ayameva ujumaggo ayamaÃ±jasÄyano niyyÄniko niyyÄti takkarassa brahmasahabyatÄyÄ"ti. 537. "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, nanu evaá¹ƒ sante tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ appÄá¹­ihÄ«rakataá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ sampajjatÄ«"ti? "seyyathÄpi, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, puriso cÄtumahÄpathe nisseá¹‡iá¹ƒ kareyya â€“ pÄsÄdassa Ärohaá¹‡Äya. tamenaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ vadeyyuá¹ƒ â€“ "ambho purisa, yassa tvaá¹ƒ [yaá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ (syÄ.)] pÄsÄdassa Ärohaá¹‡Äya nisseá¹‡iá¹ƒ karosi, jÄnÄsi taá¹ƒ pÄsÄdaá¹ƒ â€“ puratthimÄya vÄ disÄya dakkhiá¹‡Äya vÄ disÄya
"What do you think, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha? Such being the case, does not what these Brahmins versed in the three Vedas declare turn out to be unfounded?" "Indeed, Reverend Gotama, such being the case, what these Brahmins versed in the three Vedas declare turns out to be unfounded." "Well done, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha! Indeed, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, the Brahmins versed in the three Vedas, not knowing, not seeing, will teach the path to union with that â€“ 'This alone is the straight path, this the direct way, the means of escape, leading to union with BrahmÄ for one who acts accordingly' â€“ such a thing cannot be." The Simile of the Staircase.
538. 536. "evameva kho, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, na kira tevijjehi brÄhmaá¹‡ehi brahmÄ sakkhidiá¹­á¹­ho, napi kira tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ Äcariyehi brahmÄ sakkhidiá¹­á¹­ho, napi kira tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ ÄcariyapÄcariyehi brahmÄ sakkhidiá¹­á¹­ho. napi kira tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ yÄva sattamÄ ÄcariyÄmahayugehi brahmÄ sakkhidiá¹­á¹­ho. yepi kira tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ pubbakÄ isayo mantÄnaá¹ƒ kattÄro mantÄnaá¹ƒ pavattÄro, yesamidaá¹ƒ etarahi tevijjÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä porÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ mantapadaá¹ƒ gÄ«taá¹ƒ pavuttaá¹ƒ samihitaá¹ƒ, tadanugÄyanti, tadanubhÄsanti, bhÄsitamanubhÄsanti, vÄcitamanuvÄcenti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ aá¹­á¹­hako vÄmako vÄmadevo vessÄmitto yamataggi aá¹…gÄ«raso bhÄradvÄjo vÄseá¹­á¹­ho kassapo bhagu, tepi na evamÄhaá¹ƒsu â€“ "mayametaá¹ƒ jÄnÄma, mayametaá¹ƒ passÄma, yattha vÄ brahmÄ, yena vÄ brahmÄ, yahiá¹ƒ vÄ brahmÄ"ti. teva tevijjÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä evamÄhaá¹ƒsu â€“ "yaá¹ƒ na jÄnÄma, yaá¹ƒ na passÄma, tassa sahabyatÄya maggaá¹ƒ desema â€“ ayameva ujumaggo ayamaÃ±jasÄyano niyyÄniko niyyÄti takkarassa brahmasahabyatÄyÄ"ti. 537. "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, nanu evaá¹ƒ sante tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ appÄá¹­ihÄ«rakataá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ sampajjatÄ«"ti? "addhÄ kho, bho gotama, evaá¹ƒ sante tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ appÄá¹­ihÄ«rakataá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ sampajjatÄ«"ti. "sÄdhu, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, te vata, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, tevijjÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä yaá¹ƒ na jÄnanti, yaá¹ƒ na passanti, tassa sahabyatÄya maggaá¹ƒ desessanti â€“ ayameva ujumaggo ayamaÃ±jasÄyano niyyÄniko niyyÄti takkarassa brahmasahabyatÄyÄti netaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ vijjati. nisseá¹‡Ä«upamÄ 538. "seyyathÄpi, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, puriso cÄtumahÄpathe nisseá¹‡iá¹ƒ kareyya â€“ pÄsÄdassa Ärohaá¹‡Äya. tamenaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ vadeyyuá¹ƒ â€“ "ambho purisa, yassa tvaá¹ƒ [yaá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ (syÄ.)] pÄsÄdassa Ärohaá¹‡Äya nisseá¹‡iá¹ƒ karosi, jÄnÄsi taá¹ƒ pÄsÄdaá¹ƒ â€“ puratthimÄya vÄ disÄya dakkhiá¹‡Äya vÄ disÄya
"It is just as if, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, a man were to make a staircase at a crossroads for ascending to a palace. They might say to him thus: "Good man, this staircase you are making for ascending to a palace, do you know where that palace is, whether it is to the east, to the south, "Whether it will face the western direction or the northern direction, whether it will be high or low or of medium height?" Thus asked, he would answer "no." "Then they might say to him thus: 'Hey fellow, you do not know or see for what palace you are building the staircase!' " Thus asked, he would answer "yes."
539. pacchimÄya vÄ disÄya uttarÄya vÄ disÄya ucco vÄ nÄ«co vÄ majjhimo vÄ"ti? iti puá¹­á¹­ho "no"ti vadeyya. "What do you think, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha? When this is the case, doesn't the talk of that man turn out to be unconvincing?" "Certainly, venerable Gotama, when this is the case, the talk of that man turns out to be unconvincing."
540. pacchimÄya vÄ disÄya uttarÄya vÄ disÄya ucco vÄ nÄ«co vÄ majjhimo vÄ"ti? iti puá¹­á¹­ho "no"ti vadeyya. "tamenaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ vadeyyuá¹ƒ â€“ "ambho purisa, yaá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ na jÄnÄsi, na passasi, tassa tvaá¹ƒ pÄsÄdassa Ärohaá¹‡Äya nisseá¹‡iá¹ƒ karosÄ«"ti? iti puá¹­á¹­ho "ÄmÄ"ti vadeyya. 539. "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, nanu evaá¹ƒ sante tassa purisassa appÄá¹­ihÄ«rakataá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ sampajjatÄ«"ti? "addhÄ kho, bho gotama, evaá¹ƒ sante tassa purisassa appÄá¹­ihÄ«rakataá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ sampajjatÄ«"ti. 540. "evameva kho, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, na kira tevijjehi brÄhmaá¹‡ehi brahmÄ sakkhidiá¹­á¹­ho, napi kira tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ Äcariyehi brahmÄ sakkhidiá¹­á¹­ho, napi kira tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ ÄcariyapÄcariyehi brahmÄ sakkhidiá¹­á¹­ho, napi kira tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ yÄva sattamÄ ÄcariyÄmahayugehi brahmÄ sakkhidiá¹­á¹­ho. yepi kira tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ pubbakÄ isayo mantÄnaá¹ƒ kattÄro mantÄnaá¹ƒ pavattÄro, yesamidaá¹ƒ etarahi tevijjÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä porÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ mantapadaá¹ƒ gÄ«taá¹ƒ pavuttaá¹ƒ samihitaá¹ƒ, tadanugÄyanti, tadanubhÄsanti, bhÄsitamanubhÄsanti, vÄcitamanuvÄcenti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ aá¹­á¹­hako vÄmako vÄmadevo vessÄmitto yamataggi aá¹…gÄ«raso bhÄradvÄjo vÄseá¹­á¹­ho kassapo bhagu, tepi na evamÄhaá¹ƒsu â€“ mayametaá¹ƒ jÄnÄma, mayametaá¹ƒ passÄma, yattha vÄ brahmÄ, yena vÄ brahmÄ, yahiá¹ƒ vÄ brahmÄti. teva tevijjÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä evamÄhaá¹ƒsu â€“ "yaá¹ƒ na jÄnÄma, yaá¹ƒ na passÄma, tassa sahabyatÄya maggaá¹ƒ desema, ayameva ujumaggo ayamaÃ±jasÄyano niyyÄniko niyyÄti takkarassa brahmasahabyatÄyÄ"ti. 541. "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, nanu evaá¹ƒ sante tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ appÄá¹­ihÄ«rakataá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ sampajjatÄ«"ti? "addhÄ kho, bho gotama, evaá¹ƒ sante tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ appÄá¹­ihÄ«rakataá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ sampajjatÄ«"ti. "sÄdhu, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha. te vata, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, tevijjÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä yaá¹ƒ na jÄnanti, yaá¹ƒ na passanti, tassa sahabyatÄya maggaá¹ƒ desessanti. ayameva ujumaggo
"Just so, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, not even one of the Brahmins learned in the three Vedas has directly seen BrahmÄ, nor have their teachers, nor their teachers' teachers, nor even the seventh generation of teachers back. And the ancient sages of the Brahmins learned in the three Vedas, the composers and propagators of the hymns, whose ancient hymn verses the Brahmins learned in the three Vedas nowadays still chant, repeat, recite, and cause to be recited, such as Aá¹­á¹­haka, VÄmaka, VÄmadeva, VessÄmitta, Yamataggi, Aá¹…gÄ«rasa, BhÄradvÄja, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, Kassapa, and Bhagu â€“ even they did not say thus: 'We know this, we see this: where BrahmÄ is, how BrahmÄ is, and in what place BrahmÄ is.' Instead, the Brahmins learned in the three Vedas say thus: 'We do not know, we do not see, but we teach the path to union with that. This is the straight path, this is the direct way, the means of escape, it leads him who acts according to it to union with BrahmÄ.' "
541. pacchimÄya vÄ disÄya uttarÄya vÄ disÄya ucco vÄ nÄ«co vÄ majjhimo vÄ"ti? iti puá¹­á¹­ho "no"ti vadeyya. "tamenaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ vadeyyuá¹ƒ â€“ "ambho purisa, yaá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ na jÄnÄsi, na passasi, tassa tvaá¹ƒ pÄsÄdassa Ärohaá¹‡Äya nisseá¹‡iá¹ƒ karosÄ«"ti? iti puá¹­á¹­ho "ÄmÄ"ti vadeyya. 539. "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, nanu evaá¹ƒ sante tassa purisassa appÄá¹­ihÄ«rakataá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ sampajjatÄ«"ti? "evameva kho, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, na kira tevijjehi brÄhmaá¹‡ehi brahmÄ sakkhidiá¹­á¹­ho, napi kira tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ Äcariyehi brahmÄ sakkhidiá¹­á¹­ho, napi kira tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ ÄcariyapÄcariyehi brahmÄ sakkhidiá¹­á¹­ho, napi kira tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ yÄva sattamÄ ÄcariyÄmahayugehi brahmÄ sakkhidiá¹­á¹­ho. yepi kira tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ pubbakÄ isayo mantÄnaá¹ƒ kattÄro mantÄnaá¹ƒ pavattÄro, yesamidaá¹ƒ etarahi tevijjÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä porÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ mantapadaá¹ƒ gÄ«taá¹ƒ pavuttaá¹ƒ samihitaá¹ƒ, tadanugÄyanti, tadanubhÄsanti, bhÄsitamanubhÄsanti, vÄcitamanuvÄcenti, seyyathidaá¹ƒ â€“ aá¹­á¹­hako vÄmako vÄmadevo vessÄmitto yamataggi aá¹…gÄ«raso bhÄradvÄjo vÄseá¹­á¹­ho kassapo bhagu, tepi na evamÄhaá¹ƒsu â€“ mayametaá¹ƒ jÄnÄma, mayametaá¹ƒ passÄma, yattha vÄ brahmÄ, yena vÄ brahmÄ, yahiá¹ƒ vÄ brahmÄti. teva tevijjÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä evamÄhaá¹ƒsu â€“ "yaá¹ƒ na jÄnÄma, yaá¹ƒ na passÄma, tassa sahabyatÄya maggaá¹ƒ desema, ayameva ujumaggo ayamaÃ±jasÄyano niyyÄniko niyyÄti takkarassa brahmasahabyatÄyÄ"ti. 541. "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, nanu evaá¹ƒ sante tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ appÄá¹­ihÄ«rakataá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ sampajjatÄ«"ti? "addhÄ kho, bho gotama, evaá¹ƒ sante tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ appÄá¹­ihÄ«rakataá¹ƒ bhÄsitaá¹ƒ sampajjatÄ«"ti. "sÄdhu, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha. te vata, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, tevijjÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä yaá¹ƒ na jÄnanti, yaá¹ƒ na passanti, tassa sahabyatÄya maggaá¹ƒ desessanti. ayameva ujumaggo
"What do you think, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha? When this is the case, doesn't the talk of the Brahmins learned in the three Vedas turn out to be unconvincing?" "Certainly, venerable Gotama, when this is the case, the talk of the Brahmins learned in the three Vedas turns out to be unconvincing." "Good, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha. Indeed, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, the Brahmins learned in the three Vedas, not knowing or seeing, will teach the path to union with that. 'This is the straight path, this is the direct way, the means of escape, it leads him who acts according to it to union with BrahmÄ' - this is not possible." The simile of the AciravatÄ« River

"Just as, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, this AciravatÄ« River is full of water, level with the banks, and a crow can drink from it. And a man should come along wishing to cross over, to get to the other side, to get across. Standing on this bank, he should call out to the other bank: 'Come here, far bank, come here!'

"What do you think, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, would the far bank of the AciravatÄ« River come over to this bank because of that man's calling, begging, wishing, or praising?" "No, venerable Gotama."

"Just so, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, the Brahmins learned in the three Vedas, neglecting those things that make one a Brahmin and engaging in those things that do not make one a Brahmin, say thus: 'We call upon Indra, we call upon Soma, we call upon Varuá¹‡a, we call upon ÄªsÄna, we call upon PrajÄpati, we call upon BrahmÄ, we call upon Mahiddhi, we call upon Yama.' "Indeed, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, those Brahmins learned in the three Vedas who, neglecting those things that make one a Brahmin and engaging in those things that do not make one a Brahmin, would, as a result of calling, begging, wishing, or praising, after the break-up of the body, after death, attain union with BrahmÄ â€“ this is not possible.

"seyyathÄpi, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, ayaá¹ƒ aciravatÄ« nadÄ« pÅ«rÄ udakassa samatittikÄ kÄkapeyyÄ. atha puriso Ägaccheyya pÄratthiko pÄragavesÄ« pÄragÄmÄ« pÄraá¹ƒ taritukÄmo. so orime tÄ«re daá¸·hÄya anduyÄ pacchÄbÄhaá¹ƒ gÄá¸·habandhanaá¹ƒ baddho. "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, api nu so puriso aciravatiyÄ nadiyÄ orimÄ tÄ«rÄ pÄrimaá¹ƒ tÄ«raá¹ƒ gaccheyyÄ"ti? "no hidaá¹ƒ, bho gotama".
"Just as, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, this AciravatÄ« River is full of water, level with the banks, and a crow can drink from it. And a man should come along wishing to cross over, to get to the other side, to get across. But he is bound on this bank with a strong chain, his hands behind his back, tightly bound. "What do you think, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, would that man be able to cross from this bank of the AciravatÄ« River to the far bank?" "No, venerable Gotama."

"evameva kho, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, paÃ±cime kÄmaguá¹‡Ä ariyassa vinaye andÅ«tipi vuccanti, bandhanantipi vuccanti. katame paÃ±ca? cakkhuviÃ±Ã±eyyÄ rÅ«pÄ iá¹­á¹­hÄ kantÄ manÄpÄ piyarÅ«pÄ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄ rajanÄ«yÄ. sotaviÃ±Ã±eyyÄ saddÄâ€¦peâ€¦ ghÄnaviÃ±Ã±eyyÄ gandhÄâ€¦ jivhÄviÃ±Ã±eyyÄ rasÄâ€¦ kÄyaviÃ±Ã±eyyÄ phoá¹­á¹­habbÄ iá¹­á¹­hÄ kantÄ manÄpÄ piyarÅ«pÄ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄ rajanÄ«yÄ. "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, api nu so puriso aciravatiyÄ nadiyÄ orimÄ tÄ«rÄ pÄrimaá¹ƒ tÄ«raá¹ƒ gaccheyyÄ"ti? "no hidaá¹ƒ, bho gotama". 548. "evameva kho, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, paÃ±cime nÄ«varaá¹‡Ä ariyassa vinaye Ävaraá¹‡Ätipi vuccanti, nÄ«varaá¹‡Ätipi vuccanti, onÄhanÄtipi vuccanti, pariyonÄhanÄtipi vuccanti. katame paÃ±ca? kÄmacchandanÄ«varaá¹‡aá¹ƒ, byÄpÄdanÄ«varaá¹‡aá¹ƒ, thinamiddhanÄ«varaá¹‡aá¹ƒ, uddhaccakukkuccanÄ«varaá¹‡aá¹ƒ, vicikicchÄnÄ«varaá¹‡aá¹ƒ. ime kho, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, paÃ±ca nÄ«varaá¹‡Ä ariyassa vinaye Ävaraá¹‡Ätipi vuccanti, nÄ«varaá¹‡Ätipi vuccanti, onÄhanÄtipi vuccanti, pariyonÄhanÄtipi vuccanti. 549. "imehi kho, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, paÃ±cahi nÄ«varaá¹‡ehi tevijjÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä Ävuá¹­Ä nivuá¹­Ä onaddhÄ [ophuá¹­Ä (sÄ«. ka.), ophutÄ (syÄ.)] pariyonaddhÄ. te vata, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, tevijjÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä
â€˜In just the same way, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, in the Ariyan discipline these five strands of sense-desire (kÄmaguá¹‡Ä) are called bonds and fetters. Which five? Forms (rÅ«pÄ) cognizable by the eye (cakkhuviÃ±Ã±eyyÄ) that are wished for (iá¹­á¹­hÄ), desired (kantÄ), agreeable (manÄpÄ), and likeable (piyarÅ«pÄ), connected with sensual desire (kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄ) and provocative of lust (rajanÄ«yÄ); Sounds (saddÄ) cognizable by the ear (sotaviÃ±Ã±eyyÄ)â€¦; Odours (gandhÄ) cognizable by the nose (ghÄnaviÃ±Ã±eyyÄ)â€¦; Flavours (rasÄ) cognizable by the tongue (jivhÄviÃ±Ã±eyyÄ)â€¦; Tangibles (phoá¹­á¹­habbÄ) cognizable by the body (kÄyaviÃ±Ã±eyyÄ) that are wished for (iá¹­á¹­hÄ), desired (kantÄ), agreeable (manÄpÄ), and likeable (piyarÅ«pÄ), connected with sensual desire (kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄ) and provocative of lust (rajanÄ«yÄ). These five strands of sense-desire (kÄmaguá¹‡Ä), VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, in the Ariyan discipline are called bonds and fetters. And, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, those Brahmins (brÄhmaá¹‡Ä) learned in the Three Vedas (tevijjÄ) are enslaved (gadhitÄ), infatuated (mucchitÄ) by these five strands of sense-desire (kÄmaguá¹‡e), which they enjoy guiltily (ajjhopannÄ), unaware of danger (anÄdÄ«navadassÄvino), knowing no way out (anissaraá¹‡apaÃ±Ã±Ä). â€˜But that such Brahmins (brÄhmaá¹‡Ä), learned in the Three Vedas (tevijjÄ), who persistently neglect what a Brahmin (brÄhmaá¹‡akÄrakÄ) should do (dhammÄ),â€¦ who are enslaved (gadhitÄ), infatuated (mucchitÄ) by these five strands of sense-desire (kÄmaguá¹‡e),â€¦ knowing no way out (anissaraá¹‡apaÃ±Ã±Ä), should attain after death (maraá¹‡Ä), at the breakÂ­ing-up of the body (kÄyassa bhedÄ), to union with Brahma (brahmÄnaá¹ƒ sahabyÅ«pagÄ) â€” that is just not possible (netaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ vijjati).
547. 546. "evameva kho, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, paÃ±cime kÄmaguá¹‡Ä ariyassa vinaye andÅ«tipi vuccanti, bandhanantipi vuccanti. katame paÃ±ca? cakkhuviÃ±Ã±eyyÄ rÅ«pÄ iá¹­á¹­hÄ kantÄ manÄpÄ piyarÅ«pÄ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄ rajanÄ«yÄ. sotaviÃ±Ã±eyyÄ saddÄâ€¦peâ€¦ ghÄnaviÃ±Ã±eyyÄ gandhÄâ€¦ jivhÄviÃ±Ã±eyyÄ rasÄâ€¦ kÄyaviÃ±Ã±eyyÄ phoá¹­á¹­habbÄ iá¹­á¹­hÄ kantÄ manÄpÄ piyarÅ«pÄ kÄmÅ«pasaá¹ƒhitÄ rajanÄ«yÄ. "seyyathÄpi, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, ayaá¹ƒ aciravatÄ« nadÄ« pÅ«rÄ udakassa samatittikÄ kÄkapeyyÄ. atha puriso Ägaccheyya pÄratthiko pÄragavesÄ« pÄragÄmÄ« pÄraá¹ƒ taritukÄmo. so orime tÄ«re sasÄ«saá¹ƒ pÄrupitvÄ nipajjeyya. "imehi kho, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, paÃ±cahi nÄ«varaá¹‡ehi tevijjÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä Ävuá¹­Ä nivuá¹­Ä onaddhÄ [ophuá¹­Ä (sÄ«. ka.), ophutÄ (syÄ.)] pariyonaddhÄ. te vata, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, tevijjÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä
â€˜It is just as if this River AciravatÄ« (aciravatÄ« nadÄ«) were brimful (pÅ«rÄ) of water (udakassa) so that a crow could drink out of it (samatittikÄ kÄkapeyyÄ). And a man (puriso) should come along (Ägaccheyya) wishing to cross over (taritukÄmo), to get to the other side (pÄragÄmÄ«), to get across (pÄragavesÄ«), and were to lie down (nipajjeyya) on this bank (orime tÄ«re), covering his head (sasÄ«saá¹ƒ pÄrupitvÄ) with a shawl. What do you think (taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi), VÄseá¹­á¹­ha? Would that man (puriso) be able to get to the other side (pÄrimaá¹ƒ tÄ«raá¹ƒ gaccheyyÄ) of the River AciravatÄ« (aciravatiyÄ nadiyÄ) from this bank (orimÄ tÄ«rÄ)?" "No, Gotama (gotama)".

â€˜In the same way, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, in the Ariyan discipline these five hindrances (paÃ±cime nÄ«varaá¹‡Ä) are called obstacles (Ävaraá¹‡Ätipi vuccanti), hindrances (nÄ«varaá¹‡Ätipi vuccanti), coverings-up (onÄhanÄtipi vuccanti), envelopings (pariyonÄhanÄtipi vuccanti). Which five? Sensual desire (kÄmacchandanÄ«varaá¹‡aá¹ƒ), ill will (byÄpÄdanÄ«varaá¹‡aá¹ƒ), sloth and drowsiness (thinamiddhanÄ«varaá¹‡aá¹ƒ), restlessness and anxiety (uddhaccakukkuccanÄ«varaá¹‡aá¹ƒ), and uncertainty (vicikicchÄnÄ«varaá¹‡aá¹ƒ). These five hindrances (paÃ±ca nÄ«varaá¹‡Ä), VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, in the Ariyan discipline are called obstacles (Ävaraá¹‡Ätipi vuccanti), hindrances (nÄ«varaá¹‡Ätipi vuccanti), coverings-up (onÄhanÄtipi vuccanti), envelopings (pariyonÄhanÄtipi vuccanti).

And these Brahmins (brÄhmaá¹‡Ä) learned in the Three Vedas (tevijjÄ) are caught up (Ävuá¹­Ä), hemmed in (nivuá¹­Ä), obstructed (onaddhÄ), entangled (pariyonaddhÄ) in these five hindrances (paÃ±cahi nÄ«varaá¹‡ehi). Those Brahmins (brÄhmaá¹‡Ä) learned in the Three Vedas (tevijjÄ) Those things which are conducive to being a *brÄhmaá¹‡a*, abandoning those things, and behaving; those things which are not conducive to being a *brÄhmaá¹‡a*, taking up those things and behaving; being obstructed, hindered, tied, and completely tied by the five hindrances; at the breaking up of the body, after death, they will attain union with BrahmÄâ€”such a thing is not possible. A discussion of communion.
550. ye dhammÄ brÄhmaá¹‡akÄrakÄ te dhamme pahÄya vattamÄnÄ, ye dhammÄ abrÄhmaá¹‡akÄrakÄ te dhamme samÄdÄya vattamÄnÄ paÃ±cahi nÄ«varaá¹‡ehi Ävuá¹­Ä nivuá¹­Ä onaddhÄ pariyonaddhÄ [pariyonaddhÄ, te (syÄ. ka.)] kÄyassa bhedÄ paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä brahmÄnaá¹ƒ sahabyÅ«pagÄ bhavissantÄ«"ti, netaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ vijjati. saá¹ƒsandanakathÄ 550. "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, kinti te sutaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ vuddhÄnaá¹ƒ mahallakÄnaá¹ƒ ÄcariyapÄcariyÄnaá¹ƒ bhÄsamÄnÄnaá¹ƒ, sapariggaho vÄ brahmÄ apariggaho vÄ"ti? â€œWhat do you think, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha? What have you heard said by *brÄhmaá¹‡as* who are venerable, aged, the teachers of teachers? Is BrahmÄ encumbered with wives and wealth, or unencumbered?â€ â€œUnencumbered, Reverend Gotama.â€ â€œIs he full of hate or without hate?â€ â€œWithout hate, Reverend Gotama.â€ â€œIs he full of ill-will or without ill-will?â€ â€œWithout ill-will, Reverend Gotama.â€ â€œIs he impure or pure?â€ â€œPure, Reverend Gotama.â€ â€œIs he disciplined or undisciplined?â€ â€œDisciplined, Reverend Gotama.â€ â€œWhat do you think, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha? Are the *brÄhmaá¹‡as* learned in the Three Vedas encumbered with wives and wealth, or unencumbered?â€ â€œEncumbered, Reverend Gotama.â€ â€œAre they full of hate or without hate?â€ â€œFull of hate, Reverend Gotama.â€ â€œAre they full of ill-will or without ill-will?â€ â€œFull of ill-will, Reverend Gotama.â€ â€œAre they impure or pure?â€ â€œImpure, Reverend Gotama.â€ â€œAre they disciplined or undisciplined?â€ â€œUndisciplined, Reverend Gotama.â€

"no hidaá¹ƒ, bho gotama". "sÄdhu, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, te vata, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, sapariggahÄ tevijjÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä kÄyassa bhedÄ paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä apariggahassa brahmuno sahabyÅ«pagÄ bhavissantÄ«"ti, netaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ vijjati. "iti kira, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, saveracittÄ tevijjÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä, averacitto brahmÄâ€¦peâ€¦ sabyÄpajjacittÄ tevijjÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä abyÄpajjacitto brahmÄâ€¦ saá¹ƒkiliá¹­á¹­hacittÄ tevijjÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä asaá¹ƒkiliá¹­á¹­hacitto brahmÄâ€¦ avasavattÄ«
â€œSo, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, the *brÄhmaá¹‡as* learned in the Three Vedas are encumbered with wives and wealth, and BrahmÄ is unencumbered. Is there any communion, anything in common between these encumbered *brÄhmaá¹‡as* and the unencumbered BrahmÄ?â€ â€œNo, Reverend Gotama.â€ â€œThat is right, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha. That these encumbered *brÄhmaá¹‡as*, learned in the Three Vedas, should after death, at the breaking-up of the body, be united with the unencumbered BrahmÄâ€”that is just not possible. Likewise, do these *brÄhmaá¹‡as* learned in the Three Vedas and full of hateâ€¦, full of ill-willâ€¦, impureâ€¦, undisciplined, have any communion, anything in common with the disciplined BrahmÄ?â€ â€œNo, Reverend Gotama.â€ â€œThat is right, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha. That these undisciplined *brÄhmaá¹‡as* learned in the Three Vedas, should after death be united with the disciplined BrahmÄ is just not possible.
552. tevijjÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä vasavattÄ« brahmÄ, api nu kho avasavattÄ«naá¹ƒ tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ vasavattinÄ brahmunÄ saddhiá¹ƒ saá¹ƒsandati sametÄ«"ti? "no hidaá¹ƒ, bho gotama". "sÄdhu, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, te vata, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, avasavattÄ« tevijjÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä kÄyassa bhedÄ paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä vasavattissa brahmuno sahabyÅ«pagÄ bhavissantÄ«"ti, netaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ vijjati. 552. "idha kho pana te, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, tevijjÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä ÄsÄ«ditvÄ [ÄdisitvÄ (ka.)] saá¹ƒsÄ«danti, saá¹ƒsÄ«ditvÄ visÄraá¹ƒ [visÄdaá¹ƒ (sÄ«. pÄ«.), visattaá¹ƒ (syÄ.)] pÄpuá¹‡anti, sukkhataraá¹ƒ [sukkhataraá¹‡aá¹ƒ (ka.)] maÃ±Ã±e taranti. tasmÄ idaá¹ƒ tevijjÄnaá¹ƒ brÄhmaá¹‡Änaá¹ƒ tevijjÄiriá¹‡antipi vuccati, tevijjÄvivanantipi vuccati, tevijjÄbyasanantipi vuccatÄ«"ti. 553. evaá¹ƒ vutte, vÄseá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "sutaá¹ƒ metaá¹ƒ, bho gotama, samaá¹‡o gotamo brahmÄnaá¹ƒ sahabyatÄya maggaá¹ƒ jÄnÄtÄ«"ti. "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha. Äsanne ito manasÄkaá¹­aá¹ƒ, na ito dÅ«re manasÄkaá¹­a"nti? "evaá¹ƒ, bho gotama, Äsanne ito manasÄkaá¹­aá¹ƒ, na ito dÅ«re manasÄkaá¹­a"nti. 554. "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, idhassa puriso manasÄkaá¹­e jÄtasaá¹ƒvaddho. tamenaá¹ƒ manasÄkaá¹­ato tÄvadeva avasaá¹­aá¹ƒ manasÄkaá¹­assa maggaá¹ƒ puccheyyuá¹ƒ. siyÄ nu kho, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, tassa purisassa manasÄkaá¹­e jÄtasaá¹ƒvaddhassa manasÄkaá¹­assa maggaá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­hassa dandhÄyitattaá¹ƒ vÄ vitthÄyitattaá¹ƒ vÄ"ti? "no hidaá¹ƒ, bho gotama". "taá¹ƒ kissa hetu"? "amu hi, bho gotama, puriso manasÄkaá¹­e jÄtasaá¹ƒvaddho, tassa sabbÄneva manasÄkaá¹­assa maggÄni suviditÄnÄ«"ti. "siyÄ kho, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, tassa purisassa manasÄkaá¹­e jÄtasaá¹ƒvaddhassa manasÄkaá¹­assa maggaá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­hassa dandhÄyitattaá¹ƒ vÄ vitthÄyitattaá¹ƒ vÄ, na tveva tathÄgatassa brahmaloke vÄ brahmalokagÄminiyÄ vÄ paá¹­ipadÄya puá¹­á¹­hassa dandhÄyitattaá¹ƒ vÄ vitthÄyitattaá¹ƒ vÄ. brahmÄnaá¹ƒ cÄhaá¹ƒ, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, pajÄnÄmi brahmalokaÃ±ca brahmalokagÄminiÃ±ca paá¹­ipadaá¹ƒ, yathÄ paá¹­ipanno ca brahmalokaá¹ƒ upapanno, taÃ±ca pajÄnÄmÄ«"ti.
But these *brÄhmaá¹‡as* learned in the Three Vedas, having sat down on the bank, sink down despairingly, thinking maybe to find a dry way across. Therefore their threefold knowledge is called the threefold desert, the threefold wilderness, the threefold destruction.â€

At these words VÄseá¹­á¹­ha said: â€˜Reverend Gotama, I have heard them say: â€œThe ascetic Gotama knows the way to union with BrahmÄ.â€â€™ "What do you think, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha? Is Manasakata near from here, or is Manasakata not far from here?" "Yes, Reverend Gotama, Manasakata is near from here, not far from here".
