"siyÄ kho, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, tassa purisassa manasÄkaá¹­e jÄtasaá¹ƒvaddhassa manasÄkaá¹­assa maggaá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­hassa dandhÄyitattaá¹ƒ vÄ vitthÄyitattaá¹ƒ vÄ, na tveva tathÄgatassa brahmaloke vÄ brahmalokagÄminiyÄ vÄ paá¹­ipadÄya puá¹­á¹­hassa dandhÄyitattaá¹ƒ vÄ vitthÄyitattaá¹ƒ vÄ. brahmÄnaá¹ƒ cÄhaá¹ƒ, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, pajÄnÄmi brahmalokaÃ±ca brahmalokagÄminiÃ±ca paá¹­ipadaá¹ƒ, yathÄ paá¹­ipanno ca brahmalokaá¹ƒ upapanno, taÃ±ca pajÄnÄmÄ«"ti.
â€œWhat do you think, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha? Suppose there were a man here born and brought up in Manasakata, and somebody who had come from Manasakata and and had missed the road should ask him the way. Would that man, bom and bred in Manasakata, be in a state of confusion or perplexity?â€ â€œNo, Reverend Gotama.â€ â€œWhat is the reason for that?â€ â€œBecause such a man would know all the paths.â€ VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, it might be said that such a man on being asked the way might be confused or perplexedâ€”but the *TathÄgata*, on being asked about the Brahma world and the way to get there, would certainly not be confused or perplexed. "For, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, I know BrahmÄ (brahmÄnaá¹ƒ) and the world of BrahmÄ (brahmalokaÃ±ca), and the path of practice (paá¹­ipadaá¹ƒ) leading to the world of BrahmÄ (brahmalokagÄminiÃ±ca), and how one who has practiced attains to the world of BrahmÄ (brahmalokaá¹ƒ upapanno), that too I know (taÃ±ca pajÄnÄmÄ«"ti)."
555. 555. evaá¹ƒ vutte, vÄseá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "sutaá¹ƒ metaá¹ƒ, bho gotama, samaá¹‡o gotamo brahmÄnaá¹ƒ sahabyatÄya maggaá¹ƒ desetÄ«"ti. "sÄdhu no bhavaá¹ƒ gotamo brahmÄnaá¹ƒ sahabyatÄya maggaá¹ƒ desetu ullumpatu bhavaá¹ƒ gotamo brÄhmaá¹‡iá¹ƒ paja"nti. "tena hi, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, suá¹‡Ähi, sÄdhukaá¹ƒ manasi karohi, bhÄsissÄmÄ«"ti. "evaá¹ƒ bho"ti kho vÄseá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo bhagavato paccassosi. brahmalokamaggadesanÄ 556. bhagavÄ etadavoca â€“ "idha, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, tathÄgato loke uppajjati arahaá¹ƒ, sammÄsambuddhoâ€¦peâ€¦ (yathÄ 190-212 anucchedesu evaá¹ƒ vitthÄretabbaá¹ƒ). evaá¹ƒ kho, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, bhikkhu sÄ«lasampanno hotiâ€¦peâ€¦ tassime paÃ±ca nÄ«varaá¹‡e pahÄ«ne attani samanupassato pÄmojjaá¹ƒ jÄyati, pamuditassa pÄ«ti jÄyati, pÄ«timanassa kÄyo passambhati, passaddhakÄyo sukhaá¹ƒ vedeti, sukhino cittaá¹ƒ samÄdhiyati. "so mettÄsahagatena cetasÄ ekaá¹ƒ disaá¹ƒ pharitvÄ viharati. tathÄ dutiyaá¹ƒ. tathÄ tatiyaá¹ƒ. tathÄ catutthaá¹ƒ. iti uddhamadho tiriyaá¹ƒ sabbadhi sabbattatÄya sabbÄvantaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ mettÄsahagatena cetasÄ vipulena mahaggatena appamÄá¹‡ena averena abyÄpajjena pharitvÄ viharati. "seyyathÄpi, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, balavÄ saá¹…khadhamo appakasireneva catuddisÄ viÃ±Ã±Äpeyya, evameva kho, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, evaá¹ƒ bhÄvitÄya mettÄya cetovimuttiyÄ yaá¹ƒ pamÄá¹‡akataá¹ƒ kammaá¹ƒ na taá¹ƒ tatrÄvasissati, na taá¹ƒ tatrÄvatiá¹­á¹­hati. ayampi kho, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, brahmÄnaá¹ƒ sahabyatÄya maggo. "puna caparaá¹ƒ, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, bhikkhu karuá¹‡Äsahagatena cetasÄâ€¦peâ€¦ muditÄsahagatena cetasÄâ€¦peâ€¦ upekkhÄsahagatena cetasÄ ekaá¹ƒ disaá¹ƒ pharitvÄ viharati. tathÄ dutiyaá¹ƒ. tathÄ tatiyaá¹ƒ. tathÄ catutthaá¹ƒ. iti uddhamadho tiriyaá¹ƒ sabbadhi sabbattatÄya sabbÄvantaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ upekkhÄsahagatena cetasÄ vipulena mahaggatena appamÄá¹‡ena averena abyÄpajjena pharitvÄ viharati.
When this was said, the student VÄseá¹­á¹­ha said this to the Blessed One: â€œMaster Gotama, I have heard that the ascetic Gotama teaches the path to companionship with BrahmÄ.â€ â€œIt would be good if the esteemed Gotama would teach the path to companionship with BrahmÄ! May the esteemed Gotama lift up the Brahma community!â€ â€œThen, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, listen, pay close attention, I will speak.â€ â€œYes, sir,â€ the student VÄseá¹­á¹­ha replied to the Blessed One. Teaching the Path to the Realm of BrahmÄ
556. 555. evaá¹ƒ vutte, vÄseá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavoca â€“ "sutaá¹ƒ metaá¹ƒ, bho gotama, samaá¹‡o gotamo brahmÄnaá¹ƒ sahabyatÄya maggaá¹ƒ desetÄ«"ti. "sÄdhu no bhavaá¹ƒ gotamo brahmÄnaá¹ƒ sahabyatÄya maggaá¹ƒ desetu ullumpatu bhavaá¹ƒ gotamo brÄhmaá¹‡iá¹ƒ paja"nti. "tena hi, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, suá¹‡Ähi, sÄdhukaá¹ƒ manasi karohi, bhÄsissÄmÄ«"ti. "evaá¹ƒ bho"ti kho vÄseá¹­á¹­ho mÄá¹‡avo bhagavato paccassosi. brahmalokamaggadesanÄ 556. bhagavÄ etadavoca â€“ "idha, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, tathÄgato loke uppajjati arahaá¹ƒ, sammÄsambuddhoâ€¦peâ€¦ (yathÄ 190-212 anucchedesu evaá¹ƒ vitthÄretabbaá¹ƒ). evaá¹ƒ kho, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, bhikkhu sÄ«lasampanno hotiâ€¦peâ€¦ tassime paÃ±ca nÄ«varaá¹‡e pahÄ«ne attani samanupassato pÄmojjaá¹ƒ jÄyati, pamuditassa pÄ«ti jÄyati, pÄ«timanassa kÄyo passambhati, passaddhakÄyo sukhaá¹ƒ vedeti, sukhino cittaá¹ƒ samÄdhiyati. "so mettÄsahagatena cetasÄ ekaá¹ƒ disaá¹ƒ pharitvÄ viharati. tathÄ dutiyaá¹ƒ. tathÄ tatiyaá¹ƒ. tathÄ catutthaá¹ƒ. iti uddhamadho tiriyaá¹ƒ sabbadhi sabbattatÄya sabbÄvantaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ mettÄsahagatena cetasÄ vipulena mahaggatena appamÄá¹‡ena averena abyÄpajjena pharitvÄ viharati. "seyyathÄpi, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, balavÄ saá¹…khadhamo appakasireneva catuddisÄ viÃ±Ã±Äpeyya, evameva kho, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, evaá¹ƒ bhÄvitÄya mettÄya cetovimuttiyÄ yaá¹ƒ pamÄá¹‡akataá¹ƒ kammaá¹ƒ na taá¹ƒ tatrÄvasissati, na taá¹ƒ tatrÄvatiá¹­á¹­hati. ayampi kho, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, brahmÄnaá¹ƒ sahabyatÄya maggo. "puna caparaá¹ƒ, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, bhikkhu karuá¹‡Äsahagatena cetasÄâ€¦peâ€¦ muditÄsahagatena cetasÄâ€¦peâ€¦ upekkhÄsahagatena cetasÄ ekaá¹ƒ disaá¹ƒ pharitvÄ viharati. tathÄ dutiyaá¹ƒ. tathÄ tatiyaá¹ƒ. tathÄ catutthaá¹ƒ. iti uddhamadho tiriyaá¹ƒ sabbadhi sabbattatÄya sabbÄvantaá¹ƒ lokaá¹ƒ upekkhÄsahagatena cetasÄ vipulena mahaggatena appamÄá¹‡ena averena abyÄpajjena pharitvÄ viharati.
The Blessed One said this: â€œHere, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, a *TathÄgata* arises in the world, a worthy one, a rightly self-awakened oneâ€¦peâ€¦ (as it should be expanded as in paragraphs 190-212). "This is how, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, a *bhikkhu* is accomplished in virtueâ€¦peâ€¦ When he sees that these five hindrances are abandoned in himself, joy arises. When he is joyful, rapture arises. When his mind is filled with rapture, his body becomes tranquil. With a tranquil body, he experiences happiness. Being happy, his mind becomes concentrated. â€œHe dwells pervading one direction with a mind accompanied by loving-kindness (*mettÄ*). Likewise the second direction. Likewise the third direction. Likewise the fourth direction. Thus, above, below, across, everywhere, completely, he dwells pervading the entire world with a mind accompanied by loving-kindness, vast, exalted, immeasurable, without hostility, and without ill-will. â€œJust as, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, a strong trumpeter could easily make himself heard in the four directions, so too, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, with the mind-deliverance of *mettÄ* developed in this way, no limiting action remains there, none persists there. This too, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, is the path to companionship with BrahmÄ. â€œFurthermore, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, a *bhikkhu* dwells pervading one direction with a mind accompanied by compassion (*karuá¹‡Ä*)â€¦peâ€¦ with a mind accompanied by sympathetic joy (*muditÄ*)â€¦peâ€¦ with a mind accompanied by equanimity (*upekkhÄ*). Likewise the second direction. Likewise the third direction. Likewise the fourth direction. Thus, above, below, across, everywhere, completely, he dwells pervading the entire world with a mind accompanied by equanimity, vast, exalted, immeasurable, without hostility, and without ill-will. â€œJust as, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, a strong trumpeter could easily make himself heard in the four directions. So too, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, with the mind-deliverance of *upekkhÄ* developed in this way, no limiting action remains there, none persists there. This, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, is the path to companionship with BrahmÄ.
557. "seyyathÄpi, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, balavÄ saá¹…khadhamo appakasireneva catuddisÄ viÃ±Ã±Äpeyya. evameva kho, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, evaá¹ƒ bhÄvitÄya upekkhÄya cetovimuttiyÄ yaá¹ƒ pamÄá¹‡akataá¹ƒ kammaá¹ƒ na taá¹ƒ tatrÄvasissati, na taá¹ƒ tatrÄvatiá¹­á¹­hati. ayaá¹ƒ kho, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, brahmÄnaá¹ƒ sahabyatÄya maggo. 557. "taá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, evaá¹ƒvihÄrÄ« bhikkhu sapariggaho vÄ apariggaho vÄ"ti? "apariggaho, bho gotama". "saveracitto vÄ averacitto vÄ"ti? "averacitto, bho gotama". "sabyÄpajjacitto vÄ abyÄpajjacitto vÄ"ti? "abyÄpajjacitto, bho gotama". "saá¹ƒkiliá¹­á¹­hacitto vÄ asaá¹ƒkiliá¹­á¹­hacitto vÄ"ti? "asaá¹ƒkiliá¹­á¹­hacitto, bho gotama". "vasavattÄ« vÄ avasavattÄ« vÄ"ti? "vasavattÄ«, bho gotama". "iti kira, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, apariggaho bhikkhu, apariggaho brahmÄ. api nu kho apariggahassa bhikkhuno apariggahena brahmunÄ saddhiá¹ƒ saá¹ƒsandati sametÄ«"ti? "evaá¹ƒ, bho gotama". "sÄdhu, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, so vata, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, vasavattÄ« bhikkhu kÄyassa bhedÄ paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä vasavattissa brahmuno sahabyÅ«pago bhavissatÄ«ti, á¹­hÄnametaá¹ƒ vijjatÄ«"ti. 559. evaá¹ƒ vutte, vÄseá¹­á¹­habhÄradvÄjÄ mÄá¹‡avÄ bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavocuá¹ƒ â€“ "abhikkantaá¹ƒ, bho gotama, abhikkantaá¹ƒ, bho gotama! seyyathÄpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaá¹ƒ vÄ ukkujjeyya, paá¹­icchannaá¹ƒ vÄ vivareyya, mÅ«á¸·hassa vÄ maggaá¹ƒ Äcikkheyya, andhakÄre vÄ telapajjotaá¹ƒ dhÄreyya â€˜cakkhumanto rÅ«pÄni dakkhantÄ«â€™ti. evamevaá¹ƒ bhotÄ gotamena anekapariyÄyena dhammo
â€œWhat do you think, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, is a *bhikkhu* living in this way encumbered or unencumbered?â€ â€œUnencumbered, Master Gotama.â€ â€œWith hatred or without hatred?â€ â€œWithout hatred, Master Gotama.â€ â€œWith ill-will or without ill-will?â€ â€œWithout ill-will, Master Gotama.â€ â€œDefiled or undefiled?â€ â€œUndefiled, Master Gotama.â€ â€œDisciplined or undisciplined?â€ â€œDisciplined, Master Gotama.â€ â€œThus, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, the *bhikkhu* is unencumbered, and BrahmÄ is unencumbered. Does that unencumbered *bhikkhu* have anything in common with the unencumbered BrahmÄ?â€ â€œYes, Master Gotama.â€ â€œGood, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha! Then, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, it is possible that an unencumbered *bhikkhu*, after death, at the breaking up of the body, will attain companionship with the unencumbered BrahmÄâ€”this possibility exists.â€
558. â€œThus, VÄseá¹­á¹­ha, the *bhikkhu* is without hatred, and BrahmÄ is without hatredâ€¦peâ€¦ the *bhikkhu* is without ill-will, and BrahmÄ is without ill-willâ€¦ the *bhikkhu* is undefiled, and BrahmÄ is undefiledâ€¦ the *bhikkhu* is disciplined, and BrahmÄ is disciplined. "sÄdhu, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, so vata, vÄseá¹­á¹­ha, vasavattÄ« bhikkhu kÄyassa bhedÄ paraá¹ƒ maraá¹‡Ä vasavattissa brahmuno sahabyÅ«pago bhavissatÄ«ti, á¹­hÄnametaá¹ƒ vijjatÄ«"ti. 559. evaá¹ƒ vutte, vÄseá¹­á¹­habhÄradvÄjÄ mÄá¹‡avÄ bhagavantaá¹ƒ etadavocuá¹ƒ â€“ "abhikkantaá¹ƒ, bho gotama, abhikkantaá¹ƒ, bho gotama! seyyathÄpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaá¹ƒ vÄ ukkujjeyya, paá¹­icchannaá¹ƒ vÄ vivareyya, mÅ«á¸·hassa vÄ maggaá¹ƒ Äcikkheyya, andhakÄre vÄ telapajjotaá¹ƒ dhÄreyya â€˜cakkhumanto rÅ«pÄni dakkhantÄ«â€™ti. evamevaá¹ƒ bhotÄ gotamena anekapariyÄyena dhammo
When this was said, the students VÄseá¹­á¹­ha and BhÄradvÄja said this to the Blessed One: â€œExcellent, Master Gotama, excellent, Master Gotama! It is as if, Master Gotama, someone were to set upright what was overturned, or to reveal what was hidden, or to show the way to one who was lost, or to hold up an oil lamp in the dark, so that those with eyes might see forms. In this way, Master Gotama, the Dharma I attain to such concentration of mind that I abide perceiving the world as infinite. Therefore I know that this world is infinite and unbounded. This, mendicants, is the second case. When some ascetics and Brahmins rely on this, with this as their basis, they assert the world is both finite and infinite.
